column2: Travis Hafner had improved every season since first coming up in 2002. So it was logical to view his subpar 2007 with the Indians as an anomaly.

A map with an article on May 4 about restaurants in Copenhagen labeled incorrectly a body of water near Nyhavn. It is Copenhagen Harbor, not the Malmo River. The label on the map is by the former dock for ferries to Malmo, Sweden; there is no Malmo River. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/travel.

To the Editor: I am happy that you published ''No Shoes, No Shirt, No Worries'' (April 27) on naturist resorts, but you left out mention of a niche within that niche: gay nudist vacations. There are dozens of clothing-optional resorts for gay men in such likely places as Palm Springs, Fort Lauderdale and Key West in addition to the less-likely Tucson, and Orlando, among others. There are also gay naturist campgrounds in many states. Perhaps the most popular are the events sponsored by Gay Naturists International, which hosts its annual Gathering of Male Nudists (www.gaynaturists.org) for over 800 men every summer in the Poconos, and several nudist cruises and vacations throughout the year.

IN a program that covers 813,000 trucks and could cost almost $100 million, Toyota is offering to buy back 1995-2000 Tacoma pickups with frames so badly rusted that they cannot be repaired. The automaker is also extending the warranty on those frames from the normal three years or 36,000 miles to 15 years (from the time they were new) and unlimited mileage.
'TEREZíN/ Theresienstadt'

If they are so concerned about the consumer, send automatic payments to the original owners who paid top dollar for the defective vehicles. Toyota has a financing arm, why do they not go through their records, find the original owner and mail payments. -- WILFREDO

An article and a map on April 27 about Ansel Adams's photographs of Yosemite National Park gave an incorrect location of Wauwona Tunnel. It is on the western end of Yosemite Valley, in the southern section of the park, not on the park's southern edge.

An article on Page 54 of The Times Magazine this weekend, about injuries in girls' sports, misstates the results of an Ohio study of the frequency of injuries sustained by student athletes. The rate of concussions sustained by high school girls who play soccer is 1.5 times the rate for boys who play soccer -- not 1.5 percent greater.

THE NEWS A Monet landscape and a sculpture by Rodin brought record prices at a Christie's sale of Impressionist and Modern art. BEHIND THE NEWS So much for fears that the economic slowdown might hurt sales. The weak dollar made prices seem cheap to Europeans, who represented 52 percent of the buyers. Russian buying was also significant. Monet's ''Railroad Bridge at Argenteuil'' (1873) fetched $41.4 million; $35 million had been expected. Rodin's ''Eve, the Large Version,'' sold for a record $18.9 million; the expected price was $9 million to $12 million. ''It was a bit like playing the lottery -- you just don't known if it's your night,'' one dealer said.

The growth of the Russian oil giant Gazprom depends on its ability to develop gas fields in remote and technologically challenging areas like the Yuzhno-Russkoye field in Eastern Arctic Siberia. Clockwise from right, a truck traveled in February on one of the many forested roads near the field; a drilling rig operated through the night; cooks prepared meals for workers on the night shift; and a worker oversaw a derrick.

LEIGHTON--Mariana Stroock, a leader in education in New York City, died of complications from lung cancer on April 25 in New York City. She was 71. She is survived by her husband, Lawrence W. Leighton, two daughters, Sandra L. Galvin, Michelle S. Leighton, two brothers, Robert A. Stroock and Daniel W. Stroock and three grandchildren. Mrs. Leighton's 38 year dedication to education included head of school of the Calhoun School in New York City; head of the lower school of the Trinity School, New York City; and head of the lower school of the Allen-Stevenson School, New York City. At her death she served as chairman of the board of trustees of the Emma Willard School, Troy, NY from which she graduated in 1955. Additionally, she served as a member of the board of New York City's the Gillen Brewer School and served on the board of governors of the Stanwich Club in Greenwich, Connecticut. The memorial service for Mrs. Leighton will be held at 4pm. Friday, May 30 at the Stanwich Club, 888 North St., Greenwich, Connecticut. The family requests that contributions be made to the Emma Willard School, Troy, NY or the Gillen Brewer School, New York, NY.

GALERNE--Andre, who was a pioneer in the Commercial Deep Sea Diving Industry died Tuesday May 6th, 2008 of natural causes in Scottsdale, Arizona at the age of 81. Born in 1926, in Pairs, France, Andre Galerne who was recruited into the French Underground to fight against the German forces occupying France during World War II. He took his first dive in 1943 using Le Prieur apparatus and worked closely with Jaques Yves Cousteau and Phillipe Taillez in the early days of the Aqua-Lung development. Later he honed his engineering skills at l'ecole Tecd'Aeronatique et de Construction Automobile. In 1952, he founded society technique General de Travaux Marine et Fluviaux, SOGETRAM, one of the world's first international firms providing professional diving in industrial work. Using the AquaLung, and light diving helmets, Mr. Galerne's firm revolutionized the underwater industry. In 1959, he left France to start I.U.C. -Canada, in Montreal. In 1962, he immigrated to the United States where he formed The IUC Group, which comprised of several diving companies and professional diving schools. Serving as President until his retirement in 1996. As president of the Association of Diving Contractors, he introduced the region chapter system, modified the bylaws and articles of incorporation, and instigated the formation of the Underwater Magazine. Mr. Galerne is further credited with starting several Hyperbaric treatment facilities that has inspired a new generation of medical personnel for the treatment of various diseases through Oxygen therapy. He holds four U.S. Patents on methodology and equipment advances in the industry. Mr. Galerne is the recipient of the following awards: Honors with appointments as Knight of the ''French Legion de Honor,'' for his service to his country in WWII 1981 13th Annual Lockheed Award 1983 Special Commendation for Improvement Safety and Training Practices from the Diving Industry by NOIA 1986 Lowell Thomas Explorer's Club Award 1988 NOGI Award for Distinguished Service, from the Underwater Society of America 1989 New York Academy of Science Sea Award for Achievement in Science and Technology 1993 Lifetime Achievement Award, from beneath The Sea 1995 Association of Diving Contractors John Galetti Memorial Award. The ADC Board modified their rules, for one time only, to present the award to a sitting Board Member 1998 Oceaneering International award for outstanding undersea biomedical research 2001 Historical Diving Society 2006 Commercial Divin 2008 United States Coast Guard Recognition of Notable service for Homeland Security Andre Galerne is survived by his wife, of 60 years Jeannine, Sons; Olivier, Eric and Lionel and eight grandchildren Services will be held on May 16th, 2008, 10am at Saint Mary Star of Sea at 600 City Island Ave, Bronx, NY 10464 followed by a burial at Pelham Bay Cemetery. Donations in lieu of flowers to The American Diabetes Association www.diabetes.org Honor with a gift.

MANET--Edie. Born Edith Gross in 1932 in NYC, (a.k.a. Schwimmer) and daughter of Henrietta and Martin Gross, she died April 25, 2008, in Paris, France, a city she loved, and where she and her devoted husband, George, were married 54 years ago. They met as students in UCLA's Theater Arts Department, and made their home in California. They also lived in London for 10 years in the 1980s90s. Everyone who knew her loved her for her innate goodness, her sharp wit and wry sense of humor, her perceptive intelligence and sound judgment, and her insights into so many areas of life. Edie was an original spirit. New York was in her genes, but California was in her heart, and she loved being here among her many friends. We will miss her constant concern for our welfare and wellbeing. At her request there will be no religious or memorial service.

Young Gay Rites It strikes me that one of the obvious reasons straight people in their 20s get married is because that's when you pretty much need to start having kids. Gay people are spared that necessity: we get to choose so very much more from the smorgasbord. The chirpy, bright tone of nearly all the 20-somethings, married or affianced, in your article (April 27) was a little scary to me: they sound supercharged -- either on too much Starbucks coffee or on some notion that ''true love'' is something you can trap forever in a legislative cage of marriage. I kept wanting them to take long, long breaths and not feel they had to be ''couples'' in some institutionalized way so very, very quickly.

The Athletics and the Rangers played in throwback uniforms last Sunday, and baseball purists (at least those who obsess about fashion) rejoiced. The celebration was not caused by the Oakland players wearing vests or even their butter-cream-yellow batting helmets. Rather, it was the classic stirrup socks. Aside from a few aficionados of stirrup socks -- Barry Zito, Jonathan Sánchez, Juan Pierre and Jamie Moyer -- the sight of such garb is rare. (Greg Maddux wears socks with stirrups sewn on, which only half counts.)

KLEIN--David Charles. The 21 East 10th Street community mourns the loss of our founding board member and first president. He chaired the tenants committee that led to the formation of our co-op in 1983; serving on the board in a variety of capacities since then. His dedication is unprecedented. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his family and his many friends. KLEIN--David Charles, 88, on May 4th. Beloved husband of Judy Staudenmaier, who will miss him beyond all measure, but has already started to discard his ''precious'' possessions. Also survived by daughter Kelly Klein and her partner Martha Villada, brother Paul Lincoln Klein and his wife Francene. Lifelong resident of NYC with a commitment to service and the common good. Served his country in WWII (earning 13 military decorations, including a silver star and purple heart, and retiring as Lt. Colonel) and his city through many organizations, including 25 years as chair of the Citizens Union Local Candidates Committee and DAV Commander of both Chapter 126 and NY County. He worked as an aide to U.S. Senator Robert F. Wagner and for WABC-TV as an election night commentator. As a lawyer in private practice, he did it ''his way'' for over 60 years. He leaves behind a rich legacy of love, laughter and friendship. Donations in his memory may be sent to Cornell University, P.O. 2600, Ithaca, NY 14851 for the Janet Frisch Klein Scholarship Fund (his mother). Memorial TBA. Good night, sweet prince, and flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.
WEXLER--Melissa Ann. May 9th, 1958-September 12th, 1981. Sweet Missy, we miss you everyday, especially on your Birthday. Love, Mommy Arline Joachim, Eddie, Sheri & Larry

ROSENBLATT--Ruth. We mourn the loss of our beloved mother, grandmother, and mother-in-law Ruth Rosenblatt (nee Ruth Ann Turtletaub) of Pittsburgh, PA, and formerly of New York City. Ruth, 74, passed away in her sleep at Forbes Hospice on April 22, 2008, of complications stemming from her long struggle with Parkinson's Disease. Ruth was a gifted writer, who, under her writing name, Ruth Benjamin, published many poems, a novel (Naked at Forty), and two popular musical reference books with her late husband, Arthur Rosenblatt (The Movie Song Catalog and Who Sang What on Broadway). She is survived by her children, Paul and Judy, grandchildren, Lucas and Ella and daughter-in-law, Petra Fallaux. We all remember her with love, admiration, and affection. A memorial service will be held in New York City. Correspondence address: Paul Rosenblatt, 24 Terminal Way, Pittsburgh, PA, 15219. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research in Ruth's memory. www.michaeljfox.org

RUBIN--Rose, on May 9th, 2008. She is survived by her daughter Suzanne Buchsbaum (David), son Dr. William Benjamin (Carol Eisenberg), grandchildren Louise, Julie, Jeremy and five greatgrandchildren. She was predeceased by her husbands Louis Benjamin and Jack Rubin.

GRAY--Susan, passed away on April 23, 2008 in Santa Fe, New Mexico after a courageous seven-year battle with ovarian cancer. Born in Brooklyn, NY, she began painting as a child. She studied at the Art Students League and Skidmore College and then later at New York University. For fifteen years, Susan and her lifepartner painter Steven Baumann lived in a remote Mediterranean fishing village in southern Spain. Their life revolved around their shared passion for painting and the beauty of the native landscape and culture. Susan's beloved Spanish home had an inescapable influence on her work and her images. The two frequently exhibited in two-person shows and painted together on a single canvas. Anyone who knew Susan knew her immeasurable capacity to create beauty. It was evident in her exquisite landscapes and still-lifes and in virtually everything she touched. Susan is mourned by her partner Steven, her mother Clara Mirkin, son Jonathan and daughter Melissa; her sister Naomi; niece Linda and nephew Jack; her cousin Lucy and many beloved relatives, friends and patrons everywhere who hold her graceful spirit and poetic paintings close to their hearts. Contributions in her name may be sent to The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, or The Arts Students League of New York.

TOLL--Lionel J., 96, of Scarsdale, NY, died May 7, 2008 at home. Beloved husband of Dorothy, loving father of Bill and Buffy, devoted grandfather of Ted, Andy, Christie and Lindsay. Columbia School of Journalism graduate, Daily Mirror reporter, Pentagon PR officer in WWII, producer of ''Blonde Savage'' for 20th Century Fox, business executive, Beach Point member, producer of White Plains Hospital newsletter for 15 years after retirement. You were dearly loved and will be greatly missed.

SEGELIN--Bernard, passed away May 7, 2008. Born in Rochester, New York September 25, 1921. He received a B.A. from the University of Michigan in 1944. He served in the South Pacific with the USAAF from 1943-1946. In 1946 he received his Law Degree from NYU Law School and was admitted to the New York Bar in 1949. He had a distinguished career as an attorney beginning with Phillips Nizer Benjamin & Krim, NYC. In 1956, he joined Metro Goldwyn Mayer, Inc. as a litigation attorney and was elected Secretary of the company in 1970. In 1980 he joined MGM Grand Hotels, Inc, as Vice President, General Counsel. After his retirement from MGM in 1986 he became a consultant for such law firms as Wyman Bautzer Kuchel & Silbert and Katten Muchin Zavis & Weitzman as well as being an arbitrator for the NASD until 2007. He was passionately involved with Fantasy Baseball for 17 years. Predeceased by his wife of 49 years Ziona. He will be greatly missed by his daughter Amy, of Camarillo, who will take care of his beloved rose garden.

Alabama ALABAMA SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL Montgomery. A wonderful oddity of summer theater -- especially at Shakespeare festivals -- is that in prime vacation months and often under sunny skies we gather to witness monumental tragedies. Here is a good example: The schedule at this Southern sanctuary for the classics includes an updated ''Romeo and Juliet'' set in Miami (through June 28). The doomed lovers might seem even more contemporary than their ''West Side Story'' counterparts (July 18-Aug. 24). In between, the theater's master of fine arts acting students are serving up something lighter, ''The Beaux' Stratagem'' (July 11-19), the bawdy Restoration comedy by George Farquhar. (800) 841-4273, asf.net.

To the Editor: Too bad the class I teach on the history of public health policy in 20th-century New York at Columbia University has ended, as we start each class with a review of that week's City section. The Voices feature of May 4 (''She'll Get It for You: Retail'') would have been our first target, and I would have started with this question and comment: Why should Faith Hope Consolo have any regrets? She has indeed driven ''with the trend'' and enriched herself by helping to turn Manhattan into one big retail mall of chain stores and blanket it with banks.

CHU--Jackson. 1918 - 2008. Jackson Chu died on May 2, 2008 in NYC at 90 years old. Born in Shanghai in 1918, it is because of him and his courage we have all been given opportunities that otherwise may not have been possible. Jackson is survived by his former wife, current wife, eight children and five grandchildren. Services will be held Saturday, May 10 at 10:45am at Ng Fook Funeral Home, 36 Mulberry St. in NYC.

PARROTT--Barbara Brown, 91, of Washington, DC and Fishers Island, NY passed away at her home in Georgetown on May 4, 2008. She was born in New Rochelle, NY on July 27, 1916 and had lived in Washington since 1949. A graduate of Miss Porter's School, she was married for 67 years to the late Thomas A. Parrott. She is survived by and will lovingly be missed by her daughters, Cynthia P. MacNair and Susan P. Crary, a son-in-law Horace I Crary, Jr., and three grandchildren, Gardner, Nicholas and Ian, all of NYC. Her son Tommy predeceased her. Services will be held at Arlington National Cemetery on June 17th at 10:00am. Contributions may be made in her memory to St. Albans School-Development Office, Mount St. Alban, Washington DC, 20016.

COHEN--Stanley Lewis, 76, died suddenly on May 9, 2008 in New York. The son of Saul Cohen and Jean Weingarten and stepson of Gladys Cohen, he was born in Boston, MA. After attending Boston Latin School, he graduated from Harvard College, class of 1953, and Harvard Law School, class of 1956. Before starting his law career, he served in the U.S. Army, and he played football for Army while stationed in San Francisco, CA. Cohen became a prominent international corporate banking attorney, first working in Washington D.C. as a lawyer for the State Department under John F. Kennedy's administration. After traveling worldwide on behalf of the State Department, he moved to New York to work in legal finance, first at Bankers Trust for more than 25 years, then for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, and finally as an outside consultant for numerous clients. Concurrent to his professional life, Cohen had a lifelong love and indepth knowledge of music, opera, theater, dance, and the visual arts. For almost 50 years, he was a standingroom regular at the Met, Carnegie Hall, and Lincoln Center venues, in addition to attending innumerable concerts, exhibits, and shows throughout NYC and abroad. He is survived by his beloved wife, Laura DeMarco, of New York, his siblings Linda Loeb, Rachel Faith, and Barry Friedman, all of Massachusetts, his brother-in-laws Michael Loeb and Tom Janssen, his sister-in-law Barbara Friedman, and five nieces and nephews. Funeral to be held on Sunday, May 11 at 11 am at the Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus NJ. Memorial observance at the home of Laura DeMarco from Sunday through Thursday afternoon, 5-8pm. In his memory, donations can be sent to The Sixteenth Street Synagogue, 3 West 16th St, NYC 10011.

Services were held in Boca Raton, FL. Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel.

HAUSMAN--Richard A. of Hewlett Harbor, NY, age 48, on May 5th, 2008. Beloved husband of Debra. Loving father of Rebecca and Matthew. Cherished son of Marjorie and Eugene. Cardozo Law School, University of Rochester and Woodmere Academy. Richard willbe deeply missed.

THOMPSON--James C., The American Geriatrics Society (AGS) mourns the loss of James C. Thompson, MD, FACS, Ashbel Smith Professor Emeritus of Surgery, Physiology and Biophysics, University of Texas Medical Branch, Galveston, Texas. A leader in medicine and a teacher to surgeons all over the world, Jim Thompson was a wonderful friend and supporter of the AGS' Geriatrics-for-Specialists Initiative. We will miss his wise guidance, wonderful warmth and fine wit.

BADY--David, In his 90th year, passed away peacefully on May 7, at his home in Delray Beach, FL. A former resident of NYC and Cove Neck, L.I., he leaves us with enduring memories of lifetime accomplishments. A successful industrialist, brilliant en gineer, a cultured enthusiast of literature and philosophy, and relentless in pursuit of improving his golf handicap. In short, a polymath. For 65 years he was the devoted husband of Sophie, who passed away in 2006, and is survived by his son Michael, daughter - in - law Cecilia, brother Donald, sister Florence Tenzer, and admiring nephews and nieces. He wanted to be remembered by asking that you read anything written by Aldous Huxley.

Faced with a tightening of federal regulations governing foreign adoptions, and suffering from a downturn in business, international adoption agencies in the United States are finding themselves in financial straits and closing their doors in unprecedented numbers, experts say. At least 15 percent of agencies that specialize in international adoptions have recently shut down, are expected to do so this year or will probably merge with other agencies to survive, according to the National Council for Adoption, an advocacy and education group in Virginia.

POWER--June Treadwell, of Hamburg, NJ, formerly of Chatham, NJ died on May 4, 2008 at home at the age of 82. Born in NYC, she was raised in NYC and Bronxville, NY. Mrs. Power is the daughter of the late Eugenie and Harry G. Treadwell who had been an officer at Tiffany & Company. Her sister Jean Francis Easterday and brother H. Gray Treadwell predeceased her. ISELIN--John Jay, 74, died on May 6, 2008 of respiratory failure in New York. Son of William Jay and Fanny (Humphreys) Iselin, he was born in Greenville, SC and graduated from Saint Mark's School and Harvard College, class of 1956. He received a law degree from Cambridge University (Corpus Christi) which he attended as a Marshall Fellow, and a Ph.D. in Government from Harvard University in 1964. During his long and distinguished career in New York, he was National Affairs editor of Newsweek, editor of the trade division of Harper & Row before joining WNET/Channel 13 as general manager in 1971. He served as President of the public television station from 1973 to 1987 where he oversaw its transformation into a major force in the broadcasting world. In 1988, he was appointed President of the Cooper Union in New York, where he remained for 12 years, completing a $50 million capital campaign and endowing several new professorships. In 2000, he became President of the Marconi Society which, based at Columbia University, promotes innovation in telecommunications. Iselin remained on its board until his death. He was a longtime trustee of the Josiah C. Macy Jr. Foundation, the National Geographic Society, The Cathedral of Saint John the Divine, Waterford Institute and The New York State Archives Partnership Trust, and a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the Advisory Council of Storm King Art Center. Throughout his life he was passionately involved in New York civil affairs and remained devoted to Harvard where he had been an overseer and to Cambridge University and the Marshall Fellowships. In 2004, he was appointed honorary Commander of the British Empire by Queen Elizabeth II. He was a member of the Century Association and the Harvard Club of New York. He was also beloved in Columbia County, NY and in Vinalhaven, Maine where he summered with his family for over 40 years. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Lea, five children: William of Paris, Benjamin and his wife Cathy of Brooklyn, Josie and her husband Ken Pearce of San Francisco, Fannie Minot of South Hamilton, MA, Alison Russell and her husband Dan of Brooklyn and thirteen grandchildren. He is also survived by two brothers, Duane of Mt. Desert, ME, William of Charleston, SC and two sisters, Judy Cromwell of Greenville, SC and Lea Rohrbaugh of New York. A Memorial Service will be held at 11am on May 29 in the Great Hall of the Cooper Union. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to The Franklin Fund, Cooper Union, 30 Cooper Sq. 7th Floor, NYC 10003, or the Friends of the John Jay Homestead, P.O. Box 148, Katonah, NY 10536.

He is survived by his children Susan and Robert Fein and his granddaughter Rachal Azani. He was a food industry executive and professional football player for the Green Bay Packers. Much loved by family and friends --his spirit will be forever in our hearts.

GENERATING both praise and criticism in a suburban New York region with plenty of expensive housing but not much of the budget-friendly kind, a Westchester County Department of Planning report urges towns and villages to use land in existing office parks for new housing -- some of it for moderate-income families. Richard Hyman, an independent housing and planning consultant hired by the county for the study, said there were two big reasons he thought the plan would work. To start with, office parks are typically created with more parking than they need, to meet standard zoning requirements. Additionally, the complexes are often built in campuslike settings, with room for more construction -- in this case, new residential buildings.
PERLSTEIN--Jeanne. Mother's Day without you since 1980. We love and miss you. Audrey, Ellen and Suzanne

HEADING HOME As a hitter, you have about two-tenths of a second to decide what pitch you are actually seeing, all the while attempting to put a round bat on a ball that is bending and breaking in three dimensions. It took me my entire professional career to get a halfway decent approach to hitting a curveball. Give me a fastball every day of the week, and twice on Sundays. The curveball reality hit me all at once. I thought I could race through the minor league system on quick hands and exceptional coordination. That was until I ran into Gregg Olson, a pitcher who at one time was a dominant force in the Baltimore Orioles bullpen. He was known for his knee-buckling curveball, and he didn't disappoint. The first time I saw it, I thought, ''This is not good.''
DRATT--Rose My heart feels the despair and emptiness increasing as the years go by, the yearning and need for you is overwhelming. Yours forever, Jackie

GAMPEL--Morison ''Chris'', 87. Raised in Niagara Falls, Ontario, at 17, he voyaged to New York to become an actor. He brought life to many roles on Broadway and in movies. For information on private services please call 617-924-3317.

HEYL--Lawrence, Jr. (b. October 1919), co-founder of the Princeton Hot Club, and longtime resident of Nyack, NY, died on May 5, after a long illness. The only child of Bertha and Lawrence Heyl (Associate Librarian at Princeton University), Larry was a graduate of Princeton Country Day, Lawrenceville, and Princeton (class of 1940). He joined the 9th Division of the Army in January 1941, landing at Normandy on June 12, 1944, following training in England, where he met a British private, Jean, at a dance in Winchester. They married four years later in NYC, while he was Associate Editor of Theatre Arts. Larry was a skilled photographer in the style of Cartier-Bresson, capturing the lives, in black and white, of his family, friends and Rockland County artists. He served on the boards of the Rockland Foundation and Edward Hopper House, and edited Nyack in Black & White (2005). Larry spent most of his career in the oil industry, first at Texaco and API, and then at Mobil, heading Investor Relations. A foe of artifice, prejudice, solecisms, superstition, and poor lighting, Larry is deeply missed by Jean, his wife of 60 years (now of Kendal in Sleepy Hollow), his two surviving children, Margery Heyl (director of Nonotuck Community School in Northampton, MA.) and Dorothy Heyl (a lawyer at Milbank Tweed) and their husbands, and his five grandchildren, Julie and Molly Heyl-Rushmer, Regina Heyl DePietro, and Emily and Gregory Nichols (children of Catherine Heyl, d. 1998). In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be given to Kendal on Hudson (for the healing garden) in Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591 c/o Executive Director.
DOSIK--Sherry. Our 5th Mother's Day without you. It doesn't get any easier. Love Morty, Jill and Jon

Because of a transcription error, a brief report in the Inside the List column on April 27 about Julie Andrews's memoir, ''Home,'' misquoted one word of an interview Andrews had with Terry Gross on NPR. She described being very young with a voice that was able to do cadenzas, not ''condensers.''

To the Editor: I read with delight your story about Ansel Adams and Yosemite National Park (''What Adams Saw Through His Lens,'' April 27). I was privileged to work with Mr. Adams in the summer of 1982 as a professional environmentalist to assist him in protecting Big Sur, in California, from development. Twice he invited me to his home overlooking the Pacific for dinner and once allowed me to observe him reviewing the works of a student. I attended his weeklong photographic workshop in Yosemite and truly enjoyed his teaching style and personal humor. My memories of him will last a lifetime. Joe Walicki

A map with an article on May 4 about restaurants in Copenhagen labeled incorrectly a body of water near Nyhavn. It is Copenhagen Harbor, not the Malmo River. The label on the map is by the former dock for ferries to Malmo, Sweden; there is no Malmo River.

According to Gretchen Neels, a workplace consultant, most people have no idea when they are not listening -- or when they are giving the impression to others that they are not listening. I wasn't surprised to hear that, having grown up in a family where conversation is more of a competitive sport than a polite interaction. In our home, talking over one another and interrupting were fairly standard, and as a result our communication probably suffered. Mastering listening, Ms. Neels says, allows you to get things right the first time, build better relationships and find the nuances behind what is being said.
The killing season is in full swing now, with the San Jose Sharks axing their head coach Ron Wilson this evening.

Jacques Steinberg reports: "ABC on Tuesday is expected to announce a lineup of scripted prime-time shows for next year that will look a lot like this year's slate, with two notable exceptions: a new drama called 'Life on Mars,' in which a police officer is transported from the 21st century back to the 1970s, and 'Scrubs,' a castoff from NBC."

The broadcast networks are not the only companies trolling for advertising dollars during the upfronts this week. The new video Web site Hulu threw itself a party Monday night to highlight its stable of television content and entice advertisers.

School design, particularly public school design, is often lumped in with the design of other institutional structures like jails, civic centers and hospitals, to detrimental effect. My high school, for example, had the dubious distinction of having been designed by the architect responsible for San Quentin. (The convicts got the better building.) Schools fulfill a practical function, to be sure, but shouldn't they be designed to inspire?

Nearly seven years after its controversial $25 billion merger with rival personal computer maker Compaq, Hewlett-Packard seems to have caught the merger bug once again. The company, known widely for its printers, has confirmed that it is close to sealing a deal to buy technology service provider, Electronic Data Systems, for $12 billion to $13 billion.

For those of you with the same irritant, colleagues have been posting a techno-version; it doesn't erase all but offers a newer rendition.

A beta version of Times Reader for Mac users will be released this month. In building Times Reader for the Mac we've focused on providing the core set of features that have made the PC version popular. These include the easy-to-read paginated format, the ability to view the paper offline, a seven-day archive, text search, the ability to adjust the font size and access to Premium Crosswords.
(Lars Klove)

There's nothing posh about Gary Vaynerchuk, and you've got to love him for it. Vaynerchuk is the host of the Internet's zaniest wine-tasting Web cast, "The Thunder Show." While sniffing and sampling a selection of, say, white Burgundies, he's likely to be wearing wrist bands, playing with action figures and expectorating into a metal New York Jets bucket. He's cultivated a sizable fan base by demystifying wine, and this week he has a book coming out, "101 Wines," a selection of his favorite bottles. (Full disclosure: I'm an occasional viewer, but not one of his hardcore followers, known as Vayniacs.)

New York is losing out to rival cities like Seattle, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Austin, Boston, Montreal and Vancouver in attracting companies that develop video games, a burgeoning industry that could easily play a larger role in the local economy, according to a new report [pdf] by a research organization that studies city issues.

The body of a woman who had been slashed to death was discovered on a street in Brooklyn on Monday, about 30 feet from a car where her infant son was found sitting unharmed, the police said. The woman, identified as Iasha Bristol, 27, of Brooklyn, was slashed across her throat, the police said. She was discovered at the corner of Hart Street and Lewis Avenue, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood.A passer-by made the discovery at about 7 a.m. the police said, and officers who responded found a kitchen knife close by that is believed to be the murder weapon. Inside Ms. Brisol's car, a dark-colored Hyundai, the officers found the 1-year-old boy sitting in a car seat. He was immediately transported to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center in Brooklyn.

"Survivor: Micronesia," the sixteenth edition of the CBS franchise, ended on Sunday, drawing the lowest ratings ever for a season finale of the 8-year-old series. The episode drew an average of 12.9 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates, coming up just short of the previous lowest rated finale in the franchise, last year's conclusion of "Survivor: Fiji" in May (13.6 million).

Regnery, the conservative publishing house, has just brought out a book called "10 Books That Screwed Up the World: And 5 Others That Didn't Help." The author, Benjamin Wiker, is a senior fellow at the St. Paul Center for Biblical Theology and co-author of "Answering the New Atheism: Dismantling Richard Dawkins' Case Against God." Accordingly, none of the world's great religious books make the cut in this new volume.

Evercore Partners reported its first quarterly loss ever as a public company, with both arms of its business -- financial advisory and investment management -- taking major body blows. The news sent Evercore's share price to its lowest point since the firm's 2006 initial public offering; after falling nearly 16 percent soon after the market opened, the stock was down about 7 percent at $13.92 shortly before midday.

On the periphery of the PEN World Voices Festival the other week, I was glad to meet Rian Malan, a South African journalist whose book "My Traitor's Heart: A South African Exile Returns to Face His Country, His Tribe, and His Conscience" I highly recommend. The grand-nephew of an architect of apartheid, Malan fled the country to avoid the draft and later returned to write his excellent reckoning with family and national history.

Over the last six years, the police and prosecutors have cooperated in a broad effort that allows convicted felons found with a firearm to be tried in federal court, where sentences are much harsher than in state court. Officials say the initiative has taken hundreds of armed criminals off the street and turned some into informers who have helped solve more serious crimes. But a closer look at those prosecutions, Benjamin Weiser writes, reveals something that has not been trumpeted: more than 20 cases in which judges found police officers' testimony to be unreliable, inconsistent, twisting the truth or just plain false. The judges' language was often withering: "patently incredible," "riddled with exaggerations," "unworthy of belief."

One reference I didn't end up using in today's column was this piece in Reason. It declares that "the oil market is coming to resemble the gold market" where "most gold traders don't even ask the question of how much gold was mined last year or how much spare gold mining capacity there is. "

Cablevision Systems, the cable giant controlled by the Dolan family, has clinched a $650 million deal for Tribune's Newsday newspaper. The much-rumored transaction has had many analysts scratching their heads lately about why Cablevision would do such a deal at that price.
Complete Energy Holdings said on Monday that it will sell itself to GSC Acquisition, a blank-check company, in deal that values the power company at $1.3 billion.

The last time I missed a road game for one of my daughters' christenings, it was Game 7 of the 2001 World Series in Arizona, just before I took the Yankees' beat. This weekend, it was two games and a rainout in Detroit. I doubt any books will be written about these games.

Cumulus Media, the radio broadcaster, said Monday it terminated its July agreement to be taken private by its chairman and an affiliate of Merrill Lynch, stating the parties were "unable to agree on terms on which they could proceed with the transaction." Cumulus said it will get a $15 million break-up fee from the investors, who agreed last year to pay $1.3 billion for the company.
One of the presidential candidates is off to the Pacific Northwest today to talk up a big campaign pledge to combat climate change -- and it's a Republican.

MBIA, the biggest player in the troubled bond insurance industry, said Monday that it lost $2.4 billion for its first quarter, as the credit crisis continued to roil the subprime-based instruments that the company had insured.

Facebook, which has raised $360 million in the last seven months, is taking a different tack this time around, using debt instead of equity to bring in an additional $100 million, BusinessWeek reported.

When Alan Schwartz, Bear Stearns's chief executive, was called to Capitol Hill in early April to testify about the firm's stunning collapse, he was flanked by super-lawyers from Washington and Wall Street.

Becky Sinkler in her final post wrote in such an eloquent and timely fashion about mothers. Missing mothers abound in "Housekeeping," but I've found myself thinking these last couple of days about siblings.

Banks holding billions of pounds worth of debt backing last year's buyout of Alliance Boots, the British healthcare chain, are set to turn to private equity companies after they failed to sell chunks of the debt last week, according to British press reports.

Nicholas Maounis, the hedge-fund manager whose Amaranth Advisors collapsed under a record $6.6 billion loss in 2006, is seeking to start a new firm, Bloomberg News reported, citing a note sent Friday to his former investors.

Investment bankers at Bear Stearns are expected to learn as early as this week whether they'll keep their jobs or be axed, The New York Post reported, citing sources who have spoken to Bear's co-head of investment banking, Jeff Urwin.

The layoffs at big Wall Street firms will be expensive in dollar terms, but they may turn out to be costly in other ways, too. They may fuel market share opportunities for some of their smaller, more flexible rivals, The New York Sun reported.
United Airlines is closing in on a merger with US Airways, after being spurned by Continental Airlines and Delta Air Lines, The Chicago Tribune reported.
Perhaps the next Citigroup tagline should be "Let's Get It Right."

Clear Channel Communications, a major radio and outdoor advertising company at the center of a heated legal battle, reported higher first-quarter earnings on asset sales, but operating results were flat, reflecting weak demand for radio advertising.

The billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian started a cash tender offer on Friday to bolster his stake in the Ford Motor Company to 5.6 percent but stopped short of revealing his long-term plans as a major shareholder in the carmaker.
Canada confirmed its decision to block an American company's takeover of the space and satellite division of MacDonald, Dettwiler & Associates, Canada's leading space technology firm.
Electronic Arts, the video-game company seeking to buy Take-Two Interactive Software, said in a regulatory filing that it arranged $1 billion in loans to help fund its $2 billion offer.
GodTube.com, a YouTube knockoff for the evangelical set, seems to be one step closer to building a kingdom on earth.

A small New York publisher on Friday bought 02138, a magazine for Harvard alumni, with visions of expanding it into social networking and event sponsorship, and then duplicating the operation for each Ivy League school.

Fremont General, once a major subprime lender, may go bankrupt and wipe out shareholders because it will not have enough time or cash to complete the sale of its retail banking business, Bloomberg News reported.

Howard Socol, the chief executive of Barneys New York, who restored the company's stature after it fell into bankruptcy in the 1990s, has told colleagues he intends to resign amid disagreements with the retailer's news owners, The New York Times reported.

For 15 years through 2005, Bill Miller, one of the country's most closely watched and widely worshiped stockpickers, made investments that handily beat stock market averages. But for the last two years, the market has handily pulverized him.
D.B. Zwirn & Company is a leading contender to win the upcoming bankruptcy auction of TVT Records, the record label known for its stable of rap and hip-hop artists.
International Lease Finance Corporation, a unit of American International Group, is worried by the insurer's financial troubles and mulling a split from it, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Microsoft asked Europe's second-highest court to overturn or reduce a record fine of 899 million euros ($1.4 billion) from the European Union.

John C. Malone's Liberty Media filed an appeal to stop Barry Diller's IAC/InterActiveCorp from pursuing a plan to break up the Internet conglomerate, although Liberty's chief executive said it was still exploring a variety of options.

Westpac Banking said Monday that it was in talks on an all-share bid for St. George Bank, which has a market value of 15 billion Australian dollars, in a deal that would create Australia's largest home-lending and wealth-management provider.
Yahoo has acquired Inquisitor in a move to improve how search results appear on Apple computers.

HSBC Holdings said Monday that its first-quarter profit was ahead of the equivalent period a year ago as higher profits in Asia, the Middle East and Latin America helped offset rising bad-debt charges in the U.S. and a write-down at its investment banking arm.
EnCana, Canada's biggest energy company, said on Sunday it plans to split into two separate oil and natural gas firms in an effort to wring out more value with crude prices at record highs.

Companies that are finding it hard to raise money in the United States these days given the faltering economy and weak stock market, increasingly are selling their shares in Canada, according to BusinessWeek.

The Miami buyout firm H.I.G. Capital Partners has taken over bankruptcy financing for Shapes/Arch Holdings, one of South Jersey's largest employers, displacing rival Versa Capital Management, of Philadelphia.
Renault-Nissan and Indian carmaker Bajaj Auto said on Monday they would form a joint venture company to develop a low-cost car model with a wholesale price range starting from $2,500.
Citigroup is considering selling its Japanese consumer finance company CFJ or cutting the unit's business significantly as part of its plans to shed assets, Japanese daily Nikkei reported on Sunday.

With its sales slipping and fixed-line customers defecting, Deutsche Telekom looked set this week to complete plans to buy a stake worth nearly 3 billion euros ($4.6 billion) in Greece's former phone monopoly.

Wind energy company Noble Environmental Power has filed to raise as much as $375 million in an initial public offering, according to a document with the Securities and Exchange Commission that was filed Thursday.

Miniature golf: One person’s leisurely respite puttering around while on vacation is another person’s workday passion.
Whether you know it or not, you probably need a golf lesson. People will go to a driving range 10 times during a season and fork over $100 for range balls.
Being a good miniature golfer can help you in regular golf, or as the professional mini golfers sometimes call it, “big golf.”

CONOLLY--Dr. Joseph B. Jr., of Mill Neck, LI, formerly of Brookville. Peacefully at home on Saturday May 10, 2008 at the age of 90. Beloved husband of Barbara (nee Hewlett), devoted father of Peter and Catherine (Rodney Lee Brown Jr.), and proud grandfather of Abbey Conolly Brown of Seattle. Graduate of Georgetown Dental School, 1942. U.S. Navy 19431946. Dental practice in Glen Cove 1946-83. Member, Creek Club 1947-70, Nassau Country Club 1947-70, Piping Rock Club since 1970. Master of Buckram Beagles 1952-62. Served on Brookville Village board, Northshore Wildlife Sanctuary board, Glen Cove Boys and Girls Club board. Ardent skier, golfer, squash and tennis player, intrepid traveler, restorer of antique cars. Family will receive friends on Monday May 12, 2008 from 2-4 and 7-9pm at DeVine Funeral Home, 293 South Street, Oyster Bay. Mass of Christian burial at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church, Anstice Street, Oyster Bay on Tuesday May 13, 2008 at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers donations to the Glen Cove Boys and Girls Club, 113 Glen Cove Avenue, Glen Cove, NY 11542 would be appreciated.

SHERRID--Samuel D., Ph.D., beloved husband of Gillian, father of Mark and Pamela, and loving grandfather of Molly, Gregory, Eloise and Lucie, died on the 10th of May, 2008. Funeral services will be held today at 1pm at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51 Street.

11 P.M. (SportsNet New York) BEER MONEY Think you know New York sports? Are you willing to bet on it? This new quiz show ventures into the five boroughs -- to stadiums, arenas, ballparks, tailgate parties and even Central Park -- to test New Yorkers' knowledge of their hometown teams. Chris Carlin, above right, and Julie Alexandria will ask each participant a series of three questions, worth $10, $20 and $100; those who answer a question incorrectly can watch their money, and any potential icy brew, go down the drain. BURSTEIN--Anna, 86, on May 10th. Born in Brooklyn to David and Stella Bloomberg. Beloved and devoted wife of the late Charlie. Proud, sacrificing mother of Manny and David (Joan), loving grandmother of Shana and Jonah. Expert bookkeeper, pioneering 1960s working mother, passionate knitter and seamstress, good friend and a modest and selfless human being. She will be missed.

The actor who plummeted through a trapdoor minutes before the Saturday matinee of ''The Little Mermaid'' remained hospitalized on Sunday, said Chris Boneau, a spokesman for the show. AdrianBailey, 51, a member of the show's ensemble, broke his wrists in the fall, which was about 20 feet. Mr. Bailey underwent surgery on his wrists on Sunday morning at Bellevue Hospital Center. Officials from Actors Equity Association began speaking with Disney officials about the accident on Saturday at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, an Equity spokeswoman said.

CATHERWOOD--William S. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, former Executive Director and Club Officer, William Catherwood, and send condolences to his family.

PRAYIAS--Adele A., of Palm Beach, FL and New York City, died on May 9, 2008 after a battle with cancer. She was 67. Adele was born in Brooklyn, NY, the oldest child of Robert and Grace D'Avanzo. She is survived by her husband John, son George and daughter - in - law Kathleen, granddaughter Grace; and brothers, Robert and Stephen D'Avanzo. A beloved wife, mother and grandmother, she was the proprietor of Adele A. Prayias Fine Art, Inc. Friends may call from 5-8 pm on Monday, May 12, 2008 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., NY, NY on Tuesday, May 13, 2008 at 10am, a funeral mass will be held at St. Paul the Apostle Church, 505 W. 59th St., NYC .

Protesters in the thousands, including Dario Fo, the 1997 Nobel laureate in literature, massed on Saturday in Turin, Italy, to demonstrate their opposition to that city's book fair, which highlights the 60th anniversary of Israeli independence. The fair's decision to showcase Israeli writers drew a crowd of ''Free Palestine'' demonstrators -- estimated at 3,000 to 4,000 by photographers, at 10,000 by the organizers and at 1,500 by the 1,000 police officers mobilized to shepherd the protesters, Agence France-Presse reported. The Paris book fair in March, also with an Israeli theme, drew similar pro-Palestinian demonstrations.

The folk singer Pete Seeger, the musician and songwriterBilly Joel and the opera star Susan Graham are to receive honorary degrees of doctor of musical arts when the Manhattan School of Music holds its 82nd commencement ceremony on Friday at Riverside Church in Manhattan. ... Nearly 25 years after Vanessa Williams dropped out of Syracuse University to become the first black Miss America, she received her bachelor of arts degree on Saturday, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Williams, 45, a Tony Award winner and a star of ''Ugly Betty'' on ABC, also delivered the convocation address to graduates of the university's College of Visual and Performing Arts.

MOORE--Eliza Lloyd, May 7, 2008. Resident of Upperville, VA, formerly of NYC and Little Compton, RI. Survived by her mother Rachel Lambert Mellon, her brothers Stacy B. Lloyd III and Robin Lloyd, nephews Stacy B. Lloyd IV and Thomas Lloyd and nieces Samantha and Marissa Lloyd.

T BONE BURNETT ''Tooth of Crime'' (Nonesuch) Pervasive dread meets Texas blues shuffles and big-band horns on ''Tooth of Crime.'' It's the continuation of a solo career that T Bone Burnett resumed in 2006 after a 14-year gap between albums. In the meantime he became a major producer (the soundtrack for ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'' and multimillion-sellers for Counting Crows and the Wallflowers). And in 1997 he wrote songs for a revised version of ''Tooth of Crime,'' Sam Shepard's 1972 play about dueling rock stars and fame in a dystopian future.

A report in the City Room column in some editions on Friday about a sign at the Malcolm Shabazz Marketplace in Harlem that still lists Rudolph W. Giuliani as mayor misstated the location of the marketplace. It is on West 116th Street, not East.

Between songs at Radio City Music Hall on Friday night Erykah Badu leaned over a computer and some electronic equipment to set off burbling, swooping noises straight out of sci-fi B movies, as if she were tuning in the concert from another dimension. Maybe she was. Ms. Badu's Vortex Tour was a visit to her eccentric pop cosmos, which encompasses silliness and hard-nosed realism, idealism and bawdiness, choreography and whim, R&B and hip-hop, funk and jazz. Ms. Badu listed some of her aliases soon after she arrived onstage -- Medulla Oblongata, Sarah Bellum, Analog Girl in a Digital World, Lowdown Loretta Brown -- and those weren't nearly enough to sum her up.

FEIDEN--Hon. Murray T., NYS Supreme Court Judge. Our Uncle Murray was brilliant, loving, handsome and charming. We'll miss our lively dinners, book discussions and political debates. The bright light of his wisdom and spirit will live on as an inspiration to all who knew him. Heartfelt condolences to our beautiful Aunt Claire, Cousin Rica and all the grandchildren and great-grandchildren of whom Uncle Murray was so proud. Karen and Paul Bonheim

A look at the top advertising spenders across all media, including television, Internet, print and outdoor, shows a concentration in consumer products large and small, from Johnson & Johnson's mouthwash to General Motors' cars. Telecommunications and entertainment giants are also perennial participants. In fact, only two companies in the top 10 in February 2008 were not also in the February 2007 ranking. A breakdown of the print advertising segment shows different players: Macy's, Kraft Foods and Campbell Soup concentrate their ads in magazines and newspapers. SHELLY FREIERMAN

BADY--David, In his 90th year, passed away peacefully on May 7, at his home in Delray Beach, FL. A former resident of NYC and Cove Neck, L.I., he leaves us with enduring memories of lifetime accomplishments. A successful industrialist, brilliant en gineer, a cultured enthusiast of literature and philosophy, and relentless in pursuit of improving his golf handicap. In short, a polymath. For 65 years he was the devoted husband of Sophie, who passed away in 2006, and is survived by his son Michael, daughter - in - law Cecilia, brother Donald, sister Florence Tenzer, and admiring nephews and nieces. He wanted to be remembered by asking that you read anything written by Aldous Huxley.

BLOSE--Howard William, 86, May 9, 2008 of New Canaan, CT. Survived by his wife of 61 years, Marion, three children and spouses, Stephen and Gladys, Roger and Robin, Ann and Robert Eydt, four grandchildren, James, Jeffrey, Rebecca, and Alicia. Howard was born in Dayton, OH. He graduated from the School of Chemical Engineering at Cornell University where he played football. He was awarded Honorable Mention All-American and held Cornell's football scoring record for twenty years. During WWll, He commanded an LCSL ship in the U.S. Navy and was awarded the Bronze Star for the Battle of Okinawa. Howard was a retired executive of the Exxon Corporation. A memorial service at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan will be held on May 24 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Americares or Alzheimer's Association.

COHEN--Stanley Lewis, 76, died suddenly on May 9, 2008 in New York. The son of Saul Cohen and Jean Weingarten and stepson of Gladys Cohen, he was born in Boston, MA. After attending Boston Latin School, he graduated from Harvard College, class of 1953, and Harvard Law School, class of 1956. Before starting his law career, he served in the U.S. Army, and he played football for Army while stationed in San Francisco, CA. Cohen became a prominent international corporate banking attorney, first working in Washington D.C. as a lawyer for the State Department under John F. Kennedy's administration. After traveling worldwide on behalf of the State Department, he moved to New York to work in legal finance, first at Bankers Trust for more than 25 years, then for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, and finally as an outside consultant for numerous clients. Concurrent to his professional life, Cohen had a lifelong love and indepth knowledge of music, opera, theater, dance, and the visual arts. For almost 50 years, he was a standingroom regular at the Met, Carnegie Hall, and Lincoln Center venues, in addition to attending innumerable concerts, exhibits, and shows throughout NYC and abroad. He is survived by his beloved wife, Laura DeMarco, of New York, his siblings Linda Loeb, Rachel Faith, and Barry Friedman, all of Massachusetts, his brother-in-laws Michael Loeb and Tom Janssen, his sister-in-law Barbara Friedman, and five nieces and nephews. Funeral to be held on Sunday, May 11 at 11 am at the Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus NJ. Memorial observance at the home of Laura DeMarco from Sunday through Thursday afternoon, 5-8pm. In his memory, donations can be sent to The Sixteenth Street Synagogue, 3 West 16th St, NYC 10011.

Those who assemble programs at New York City Ballet have much to learn, but will they learn? The two new ones that the company presented on Friday (''Russian Roots,'' a quadruple bill) and Saturday afternoon (''World Tour,'' quintuple) were built with quite different objectives, but neither satisfies as a whole. Both programs look outside America; each demonstrates how diverse ballet can be. ''Russian Roots,'' part of the Jerome Robbins Celebration, presents four Russian scores that Robbins choreographed while, sometimes at least, drawing on ideas of Russia he had been assembling in America from his family and others since childhood. ''World Tour'' is an anthology of ballets by four other choreographers, the majority set in foreign countries.

During the second half of ''Miles From India,'' a boldly expansive concert at Town Hall on Friday night, the percussionist Badal Roy ventured a tabla solo, the sort of heroic exhibition that can end only in generous applause. He was annotating a composition called ''Ife,'' which he originally recorded with the trumpeter Miles Davis in 1972. Mr. Roy was the linchpin but not always the focal point of ''Miles From India,'' which generally featured about a dozen other musicians onstage. The concert grew out of an ambitious new double album of the same name on Times Square Records, conceived as a cross-cultural experiment by the producer Bob Belden. On the album assorted Miles Davis alumni appear along with acclaimed Indian musicians -- Mr. Roy hails from both camps of course -- to play music spanning several periods of Davis's chameleonic career.

John Edwards, the former senator from North Carolina, has still not endorsed anyone in the Democratic race, but Sunday he cautioned that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton ''has to be really careful that she's not damaging our prospects'' by staying in the contest against Senator Barack Obama. Appearing on ''Face the Nation'' on CBS, Mr. Edwards said that he saw little chance that Mrs. Clinton could manage a come-from-behind victory.

Deal or No Deal? Will Google and Yahoo come together on a search-ad partnership? The two companies have been discussing an agreement under which Google would deliver ads alongside Yahoo's search results. Since Google earns on average much more than Yahoo for every search, the deal, at least in theory, would increase Yahoo's revenue. No deal has been announced, and the reasons the companies have not come to terms are unknown. But a person with knowledge of the discussions said Google has been thinking about a conundrum: Deal or no deal, the company could end up with something of a public relations black eye.

JACOBY--Daniel, May 8, 2008 in Sarasota, Florida. An original and off-beat toy man, stamp collector, politico, gardener, philosopher, he left an indelible imprint on all who met him. Born in NYC in 1914 he ran B. Shackman & Co for forty years, the toy firm that his grandmother founded. He loved his family, toys, tomatoes and collections. He was happiest in the meadow and lake of his home in Laurel on the North Fork of Long Island. He had a rare humor, zest for life and energy. He leaves his loving wife Betty and children Winifred, Russell and Lauren, four grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Memorial to be announced.

Leonard Bernstein is coming back to New York City Center as part of a celebration of what would have been his 90th birthday. For the first time, the City Center Encores! series will begin in the fall, with ''On the Town,'' the 1944 musical that Bernstein wrote with Betty Comden and Adolph Green. ''On the Town'' is scheduled to run from Nov. 19 to 23, followed by a production of the 1932 Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein musical ''Music in the Air'' from Feb. 5 to 8. The season will conclude with ''Finian's Rainbow,'' the 1949 musical by Burton Lane, E. Y. Harburg and Fred Saidy about what to do with an Irish pot of gold in the state of Missitucky. That is scheduled to run March 26 to 29.

At a time when it seems that everybody is beating up on Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton -- even ''Saturday Night Live'' this weekend ran a skit making fun of her -- one person came to her defense on Sunday: Representative Rahm Emanuel of Illinois, a top Democrat in the House. Mr. Emanuel, in an interview he initiated, assailed Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, for remarks he made when he was asked about the possibility of Senator Barack Obama of Illinois choosing Mrs. Clinton as his running mate.

OLOFSON--Phillip Harrison. The trustees and staff of the Stella and Charles Guttman Foundation mourn the death in Fort Wayne, Indiana on May 8, 2008 of Phillip Harrison Olofson, age 88, the father of the Foundation's exemplary and much loved Executive Director. Mr. Olofson was a leading citizen of Fort Wayne, Indiana, whose successful and varied career in business and community activities included the position of General Manager of the Fort Wayne Memorial Coliseum and promoting, marketing and publicizing a variety of entertainment and other programs for the City of Fort Wayne. We extend our sympathy and love to Elizabeth and her entire family.

LATELLA--Rev. Joseph A., S.J., died on May 9th, 2008. Father Latella, the son of the late Joseph and Elena Latella and brother of Gloria Lafferty, was born in 1927 and attended Regis High School. He entered the Society of Jesus in July, 1945 and was ordained a priest in June, 1958. He served as Alumni Director for many years at Xavier High School on 16th Street in New York. For the last ten years he has been Assistant for Development at Xavier Society for the Blind. Friends may call Wednesday, May 14th, 2-5 and 7-9pm and Thursday, May 15th, 2-5pm. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, May 15th at 7:30pm at St. Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church., Park Avenue at 84th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Xavier Society for the Blind, 154 East 23rd Street, NY, NY 10010.

Deal or No Deal? Will Google and Yahoo come together on a search-ad partnership? The two companies have been discussing an agreement under which Google would deliver ads alongside Yahoo's search results. Since Google earns on average much more than Yahoo for every search, the deal, at least in theory, would increase Yahoo's revenue. No deal has been announced, and the reasons the companies have not come to terms are unknown. But a person with knowledge of the discussions said Google has been thinking about a conundrum: Deal or no deal, the company could end up with something of a public relations black eye.

Leonard Bernstein is coming back to New York City Center as part of a celebration of what would have been his 90th birthday. For the first time, the City Center Encores! series will begin in the fall, with ''On the Town,'' the 1944 musical that Bernstein wrote with Betty Comden and Adolph Green. ''On the Town'' is scheduled to run from Nov. 19 to 23, followed by a production of the 1932 Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein musical ''Music in the Air'' from Feb. 5 to 8. The season will conclude with ''Finian's Rainbow,'' the 1949 musical by Burton Lane, E. Y. Harburg and Fred Saidy about what to do with an Irish pot of gold in the state of Missitucky. That is scheduled to run March 26 to 29.

GALERNE--Andre, who was a pioneer in the Commercial Deep Sea Diving Industry died Tuesday May 6th, 2008 of natural causes in Scottsdale, Arizona at the age of 81. Born in 1926, in Pairs, France, Andre Galerne who was recruited into the French Underground to fight against the German forces occupying France during World War II. He took his first dive in 1943 using Le Prieur apparatus and worked closely with Jaques Yves Cousteau and Phillipe Taillez in the early days of the Aqua-Lung development. Later he honed his engineering skills at l'ecole Tecd'Aeronatique et de Construction Automobile. In 1952, he founded society technique General de Travaux Marine et Fluviaux, SOGETRAM, one of the world's first international firms providing professional diving in industrial work. Using the AquaLung, and light diving helmets, Mr. Galerne's firm revolutionized the underwater industry. In 1959, he left France to start I.U.C. -Canada, in Montreal. In 1962, he immigrated to the United States where he formed The IUC Group, which comprised of several diving companies and professional diving schools. Serving as President until his retirement in 1996. As president of the Association of Diving Contractors, he introduced the region chapter system, modified the bylaws and articles of incorporation, and instigated the formation of the Underwater Magazine. Mr. Galerne is further credited with starting several Hyperbaric treatment facilities that has inspired a new generation of medical personnel for the treatment of various diseases through Oxygen therapy. He holds four U.S. Patents on methodology and equipment advances in the industry. Mr. Galerne is the recipient of the following awards: Honors with appointments as Knight of the ''French Legion de Honor,'' for his service to his country in WWII 1981 13th Annual Lockheed Award 1983 Special Commendation for Improvement Safety and Training Practices from the Diving Industry by NOIA 1986 Lowell Thomas Explorer's Club Award 1988 NOGI Award for Distinguished Service, from the Underwater Society of America 1989 New York Academy of Science Sea Award for Achievement in Science and Technology 1993 Lifetime Achievement Award, from beneath The Sea 1995 Association of Diving Contractors John Galetti Memorial Award. The ADC Board modified their rules, for one time only, to present the award to a sitting Board Member 1998 Oceaneering International award for outstanding undersea biomedical research 2001 Historical Diving Society 2006 Commercial Divin 2008 United States Coast Guard Recognition of Notable service for Homeland Security Andre Galerne is survived by his wife, of 60 years Jeannine, Sons; Olivier, Eric and Lionel and eight grandchildren Services will be held on May 16th, 2008, 10am at Saint Mary Star of Sea at 600 City Island Ave, Bronx, NY 10464 followed by a burial at Pelham Bay Cemetery. Donations in lieu of flowers to The American Diabetes Association www.diabetes.org Honor with a gift.

Société Générale, the French bank that lost billions from a rogue trader, disclosed today that it had restated quarterly income figures for last year to account for the unauthorized trades. The audited numbers, which the company admitted violated accounting standards, now turn out to have been wrong. (The violation of accounting standards, as I explained in this column, involved shifting losses taken in 2008 to 2007. The company got its auditors to agree that was fine, despite the rules.)

Dubai developer Nakheel has released the master blueprint for Waterfront City, the centerpiece of a plan to transform 1.4 billion square feet of empty desert into an urban center twice the size of Hong Kong. Bloomberg's last-ditch effort to revive the Far West Side railyards project ended in failure today after Tishman Speyer Properties failed to come to terms with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on a $1 billion deal.The authority, which needs the proceeds from the sale of the development rights over the railyards for its capital budget, again rejected Tishman Speyer's attempt to change the terms of the deal the two sides struck on March 26. After my book "Dakota" was published, I received many letters from people who had roots in the western Plains. In one, a woman whose grandparents had been neighbors of my mother's family when she was a girl asked, "Can you tell me if my grandmother committed suicide?" Her family name was familiar to me, but the story was not. When I jogged my mother's memory, she recalled a few details. The woman was much younger than her husband, and had endured a difficult pregnancy. One day she disappeared in Bismarck, N.D., some 130 miles away. Some of her clothing was found piled on the banks of the Missouri River, but there was no suicide note. My mother said that her parents were not alone in suspecting that the woman had run away.

Barack Obama may aim to represent post-racial politics, but The Washington Post isn't so sure we're post-anything: "For all the hope and excitement Obama's candidacy is generating, some of his field workers, phone-bank volunteers and campaign surrogates are encountering a raw racism and hostility that have gone largely unnoticed -- and unreported -- this election season," the paper's Kevin Merida tells us. "Doors have been slammed in their faces. They've been called racially derogatory names (including the white volunteers). And they've endured malicious rants and ugly stereotyping from people who can't fathom that the senator from Illinois could become the first African American president."
