State-owned Saudi Arabian Mining Company, known as Maaden, plans to raise 9.25 billion riyals ($2.47 billion) in July in the Middle East's biggest mining initial public offerng, valuing the firm at $4.9 billion, the Saudi bourse regulator said on Monday.
More of your "late night" jokes (send via the comment link below):
Pappas Telecasting, a private broadcasting group, filed for bankruptcy protection over the weekend, blaming weak advertising revenue and poor ratings for the CW Network.
Russians have always preferred their leaders strong. Today, though, they also seem to want them sexy.

Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, says the company is in "crisis" and urged a delay in its annual general meeting, scheduled for Wednesday, in a letter to the board.
Properties on the market in Florida, Tennessee and California.

The owners of The New York Post and The Daily News lost out to Cablevision in the battle for Newsday on Monday, but, according to The New York Times, the tabloid war may be far from over. Either paper could still strike a deal to share operations with Newsday, according to the Times.
Patriot Risk Management, a workers' compensation risk management firm, filed with U.S. regulators on Tuesday to raise up to $115 million in an initial public offering of common stock.

JPMorgan Chase said on Monday that it received a notice from federal regulators indicating that one of its units may face an enforcement action related to "the bidding of various financial instruments associated with municipal securities."

France's biggest retail bank, Credit Agricole, announced a 5.9 billion euros ($9.1 billion) rights issue to shore up its capital after further writedowns at its Calyon investment bank, sending its shares down sharply.

Société Générale, the large French bank pummeled by a rogue trading scandal, reported Tuesday that its net profit fell 23.4 percent in the first quarter, although earnings beat the average market forecast.
With EnCana's stock soaring on a planned demerger, analysts are wondering if other petroleum companies will follow the Canadian energy giant's lead and divide into gas and oil producers.

The Italian aerospace company Finmeccanica reached a $5.2 billion deal to buy DRS Technologies, securing a bigger presence in the growing United States military market, which accounts for half the world's military spending.

IndyMac Bancorp swung to a loss in the first quarter as deteriorating credit markets forced the company, a mortgage lender, to lower the value of mortgage-backed securities. It warned on Monday that it would not post a profitable quarter in 2008.
Sirius Satellite Radio and XM Satellite Radio, the pay radio stations that are seeking to merge, both reported solid gains in subscribers on Monday although both also posted quarterly losses.
A look at a pied-à-terre in the Marais neighborhood.

Remember those plans to build a Las Vegas-style gambling city outside Zaragoza in Spain? Last November the regional government in Aragon approved a scheme calling for 32 hotels and five theme parks covering 5,000 acres, according to the London Times.
Guess she will not be spilling all the details after all.
One of the most confusing aspects of this Democratic primary race has been the arrays of tallies of elected delegates and superdelegates maintained by the news media and the campaigns.
A Samuel Beckett reference on a football blog ...
The earthquake in southwestern China on Monday killed at 10,000 people, including many children whose school buildings collapsed.
A look at the hits and misses of the 2007-2008 Broadway season.
Location: Durham, N.C.

Before the game here at Tropicana Field on Monday, the Rays showed a feature about the life of Trever Miller. It must have been 20 minutes. There were lots of baby pictures, and revealing interviews with his parents and his wife and his grandfather. He seems like a fine fellow.
What goes on in the mouth goes a long way to determining the flavor of food.
New findings support the idea that humans spread southward along the Pacific Coast after entering the Americas.
A researcher has discovered a unique use for your microwave oven — fighting invasive species.
The genetic map for a cute, yet unique, creature turned more heads than those maps for less-interesting creatures.
Dr. Quiñones-Hinojosa, 40, was an illegal immigrant working in the vegetable fields of the Central Valley in California before becoming a neurosurgeon.
Barack Obama took steps to deal with the challenge posed by Hillary Rodham Clinton’s victory in West Virginia.
Would Hillary Rodham Clinton drop her bid in exchange for Barack Obama’s embrace of universal health care?
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s victory over Senator Barack Obama was fueled by strong turnout among the white, working-class voters.
The simplest and best way to consistently provide good customer service is to follow the golden rule and put yourself in the customer’s position.
Schools were closed in Palm Bay, Fla., and hundreds of homes were endangered by spreading, wind-whipped brush fires that may have been deliberately set.

The Pentagon has dropped charges against a Saudi held at Guántanamo Bay, Cuba, whom prosecutors called the ”20th hijacker” in the Sept. 11 attacks, his military defense lawyer said. The defendant, Mohamed al-Kahtani was charged in February with murder and war crimes in the 2001 attacks. The authorities said Kahtani missed taking part in the attacks because he had been denied entry to the United States. In reviewing the case, the convening authority for military commissions, Susan Crawford, decided to dismiss the charges against Kahtani and proceed with the arraignment for the other five, said Lt. Col. Bryan Broyles of the Army, the Saudi’s military lawyer.

Bill Duffy Associates, the agency representing O. J. Mayo, denied any N.C.A.A. rules violations involving Mayo, a day after ESPN reported the group gave cash to an event promoter who provided gifts. Mayo has declared for the N.B.A. draft and hired BDA Sports’s Calvin Andrews as his agent. ESPN’s “Outside the Lines” reported Sunday that Mayo received about $30,000 and other benefits while in high school and during his only season at Southern California, then entered into an oral agreement that allowed the agency to represent him when he turned professional.
The Yankees and Andy Pettitte became the latest team to fall to the sprightly Rays, who have swept their last two series at home.
The Mets made it difficult for the crowd to stick around in the cold past a sloppy fifth inning, when the Nationals scored three runs to snap a tie on their way to a victory.
President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela signed a law to formally assume state control of the Venezuelan unit of Ternium, a steel maker based in Luxembourg.

The Chloride Group, the largest maker of backup power supplies in Europe, rejected a preliminary $1.3 billion takeover approach from the Emerson Electric Company of St. Louis, setting off a 35 percent gain in its share price.
India’s industrial production in March grew at the slowest pace since 2002, as borrowing costs hit a six-year high and discouraged consumer spending.

An article on Thursday about how rarely the Prius hybrid car appears in Hollywood films despite its popularity among Hollywood insiders misstated the given name of the administrator of the Internet Movie Cars Database, which tracks appearances of cars in films. He is Antoine Potten, not Andre.
FRONT PAGE.

An article on May 4 about the growing difficulty that people with health insurance have affording medical care misstated the co-payment that one patient, Sage Holben, must pay at each visit to her doctor. After checking her records, Ms. Holben says her co-payment is $22, not the $25 she originally stated.

A music column on May 1 about the Ponderosa Stomp, an annual event in New Orleans, misstated the given name of its founder, an anesthesiologist known as Dr. Ike. He is Ira Padnos, not Ike Padnos. The column also misstated the number of musicians in the Green Fuz, a band that played at the Stomp, when it released its lone single, “Green Fuz,” in 1969. It had five members, not three.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the increase in commuters who are turning to mass transit because of high gasoline prices misstated the increase in ridership on Metropolitan Transportation Authority buses in the first three months of the year. Ridership on the M.T.A.’s three bus agencies was up about 2.3 percent, not 10.9 percent. (The 10.9 percent increase in bus ridership referred solely to the M.T.A. Bus Company, which operates local and express bus routes around New York City.).

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Friday about the Bronx Opera’s rehearsals for its 40th-anniversary double-bill concert, featuring “The Impresario” and “Pagliacci,” misstated the time of Saturday’s performance at Hofstra University on Long Island. It is in the afternoon, at 2 p.m., not at night.

An article on Friday about a deal to prevent most of the Tejon Ranch in Southern California from being developed misstated the name of a trail that would be partly rerouted through the ranch’s land under the agreement. It is the Pacific Crest Trail, not the Pacific Coast Trail.
A pop music entry in the Listings pages on May 2 about the duo Flight of the Conchords misstated one member’s given name. He is Jemaine Clement, not Jermaine.

The High and Low Finance column on Friday, about a mortgage company that is seeking a reduction in the principal it owes its lenders, misspelled the surname of an analyst for CreditSights who wrote about the situation. He is Richard Hofmann, not Hoffmann.

An art review on Friday about the International Fine Art Fair, at the Park Avenue Armory, misidentified the booth displaying a painting by the Belgian artist Emile Claus, who was influenced by Monet. It was the Schiller & Bodo booth, not Hill-Stone.

An article in some editions last Tuesday about the announcement of a new commuter ferry service between southern Queens and Lower Manhattan misidentified the Rockaways neighborhood where Riis Landing, the launching point, is located. It is Breezy Point, not Far Rockaway.

An obituary on Saturday about the novelist Elaine Dundy rendered incorrectly the name of the college she graduated from and misidentified its location. It is Sweet Briar, not Sweetbriar, and it is in Sweet Briar, Va., not Lynchburg.
The body of a woman who had been slashed to death was discovered on Monday on a Brooklyn street, about 30 feet from her car, and her 1-year-old son was found unharmed in the car, the police said.
On Monday, Manager Joe Girardi said Alex Rodriguez would most likely be out through the weekend with a quadriceps injury.

The Marine Corps far surpassed its recruiting goal last month, enlisting 2,233 people, which was 142 percent of its goal, the Pentagon said. The Army recruited 5,681 people, 101 percent of its goal. The Navy and Air Force also met their goals, 2,905 sailors and 2,435 airmen. A Defense Department spokesman, Bryan Whitman, said that if the Marine Corps continued its recruiting success, it could reach its goal of growing to 202,000 people by the end of 2009, more than a year early.

Several foam makers have agreed to pay $30 million to settle lawsuits brought by survivors and family members of those who died in a 2003 nightclub fire that killed 100 people, according to court papers. The companies that agreed to settle include Leggett & Platt, based in Carthage, Mo., and Wm. T. Burnett & Company, based in Baltimore. More than $100 million has now been offered to victims of the fire at the Station nightclub in West Warwick from several companies, including Home Depot and Clear Channel Broadcasting. The fire was started when a pyrotechnics display for the rock band Great White ignited the flammable foam soundproofing material.

In closing arguments, lawyers painted two vastly different pictures of Antoin Rezko, a businessman and former political fund-raiser accused of soliciting kickbacks from companies seeking state business or regulatory approval. Reid J. Schar, an assistant United States attorney, summarized weeks of testimony from dozens of government witnesses that, he told jurors, proved that Mr. Rezko had used his influence to benefit himself and his friends. But Joseph J. Duffy, Mr. Rezko’s chief lawyer, told jurors that the case was not believable because it hinged on Stuart Levine, who has pleaded guilty and was a member of the two state boards central to the case. Mr. Duffy called Mr. Levine a liar who was trying to get a reduced sentence.

Dry, windy weather fueled wildfires along the central Atlantic coast, destroying at least three homes and driving out hundreds of residents as the governor declared a state of emergency. The largest fire, a 3,000-acre blaze in Brevard County, destroyed at least two homes. Another fire in nearby Palm Bay destroyed one home. In Daytona Beach, about 800 acres had burned, said Timber Weller, a spokesman for the Division of Forestry. The authorities ordered about 500 homes in the northwest part of Daytona to be evacuated.

The State Supreme Court has overturned the conviction of a Conway woman who was found guilty of homicide by child abuse after her stillborn baby tested positive for cocaine. In a unanimous ruling, Chief Justice Jean H. Toal wrote that the woman, Regina D. McKnight, had not received adequate counsel and that other factors could have caused the child’s death. Ms. McKnight’s first trial ended in a mistrial in January 2001. She was convicted in a second trial in May 2001 and was sentenced to 12 years in prison.
Rescuers spent hours searching the Atlantic Ocean for a 46-year-old woman who apparently fell from a cruise ship about 45 miles northeast of Atlantic City, the Coast Guard said.
A new ferry service was born Monday, setting sail from Breezy Point, at the tip of the Rockaways, to Lower Manhattan, with a stop in Brooklyn.
Johan Santana, who may start against the Yankees on Friday, has excellent career statistics at Yankee Stadium.
For true endurance, the statutes known as the Rockefeller-era drug laws are hard to beat. The same may be said about attempts to scrap those laws.
City officials have chosen to turn over the heliport near Wall Street to FirstFlight, an upstate company that has not operated a similar facility in any big city.

Rangers forward Brandon Dubinsky scored three goals and the United States (3-2) scored three times in each period to wrap up its qualifying round at the world championship with a 9-1 victory over Norway in Halifax, Nova Scotia. The Americans will play Finland in the quarterfinals.

Bill Duffy Associates, the agency representing O. J. Mayo, denied any illegal activity involving Mayo, a day after ESPN reported the group gave cash to an event promoter who provided gifts. Mayo has declared for the N.B.A. draft and hired BDA Sports’ Calvin Andrews as his agent. ESPN’s “Outside the Lines” reported Sunday that Mayo received about $30,000 and other benefits while in high school and during his lone season at Southern California, then entered into an oral agreement that allowed the agency to represent him when he turned professional.

Robbie Gould became the N.F.L.’s highest-paid kicker, agreeing to a five-year, $15.5 million contract extension with the Chicago Bears that includes a $4.25 million signing bonus. Gould made 31 of 36 field-goal attempts last season.

Tiger Woods is chipping and putting, and says he hopes to play in the Memorial in two weeks. But even if he cannot compete until the United States Open, he does not expect the same result as his last layoff during a season. Two years ago, Woods did not play for nine weeks after the death of his father. He returned to competition in the United States Open at Winged Foot and missed the cut for the only time in a major. “That was a totally different mental situation than I am now,” said Woods, who had surgery on his left knee April 15 to clean out some cartilage.
Investigators said the group that carried out the assassination was led by a federal police officer, who was arrested with several incriminating documents.

Prosecutors said they would not seek the death penalty against four people charged with murdering the Washington Redskins star Sean Taylor because the accused shooter was a minor when the crime was committed. The United States Supreme Court has ruled that people cannot be executed for crimes committed when they were under 18, and it is a well-established legal principle that others involved in the same case as a minor cannot face the ultimate penalty if they are less directly responsible.

The America’s Cup showdown between the two-time defending champion Alinghi of Switzerland and BMW Oracle Racing of the United States cannot begin for at least 10 months. New York State Supreme Court Judge Herman Cahn said it would be “inequitable” to deprive Alinghi of the full 10-month notice of challenge to prepare its boat. That 10-month period began with Monday’s ruling. BMW Oracle Racing had argued that it had the right as Challenger of Record to hold the best-of-three series in October, but Alinghi argued it would not be able to build a boat in time.
Nuala O’Faolain, the former Irish Times columnist who died last week, will be remembered for her fearless self-examination and her unflinching insights.

It is unclear how African-American preference for menthol cigarettes developed in the first place, but it seems the answer involves cultural and taste preferences as well as tobacco industry marketing.

During their first 10 seasons, the Tampa Bay Rays grew accustomed to serving as gracious hosts whenever they faced the Yankees or the Boston Red Sox at Tropicana Field. But that’s beginning to change.
The higher pricing for some HBO shows is a departure for Apple which for years has insisted on standard pricing for digital downloads, at $1.99.
Researchers in New York have created what is believed to be the first genetically engineered human embryo, which critics immediately branded as a step toward “designer babies.”
Jesús León Santos’s fight to keep farmers from abandoning their parched land is much more than a refusal to give up a millennial way of life.
Hillary Rodham Clinton is determined to rack up primary victories as she seeks to prove her political viability, aides say.
The agreement to protect this much land so close to Los Angeles is a remarkable testament to the cooperative spirit in which this conservation plan was formed.
For Kenneth C. Griffin, who runs one of the biggest and most successful hedge fund firms, the entire banking industry needs to overhaul its thinking, and perhaps accept greater regulation.

EXEMPTION FOR MENTHOL Menthol, the most frequently used cigarette flavoring and a popular cigarette choice of African-American smokers, is being exempted as Congress tries to regulate flavored tobacco.
City and state officials have begun talks with Goldman Sachs in the hope of negotiating a new agreement that would avoid hefty penalties for delays in rebuilding at the World Trade Center site.
Political leaders who have Pakistan’s interests at heart should be able to find a compromise that restores its dismissed judges and promotes judicial reform.
The announcement was made as violence eased across Lebanon, despite some renewed street battles in the north.
Carmona pitched a five-hitter for Cleveland’s second consecutive shutout against the visiting Toronto Blue Jays, a 3-0 victory Monday the first game of a doubleheader.
Glasgow Rangers are in their first European final since 1972, when they won the Cup Winners’ Cup. And their success this season is reflected in their workload.
Hoping to hang on to a seat in a tight special election, Republicans are trying to make the vote into a referendum on Barack Obama.
Having been on the wrong end of the Suns’ warp-speed attack, the Knicks have been granted the chance to adopt it — if their lungs and legs can handle the burden.

Matt Walsh, a former video assistant for the New England Patriots, will meet with the N.F.L. commissioner on Tuesday. The following is a timeline of how Walsh, the Patriots and the league got to this point.

Pavel Datsyuk scored twice in the first period and then again with 2 minutes 41 seconds remaining in the Detroit Red Wings’ 5-2 victory over the Stars in Dallas.
After a year of trouble and courtroom battles, two private equity firms looking to buy Clear Channel were close to settling with the banks financing the deal.
Jane R. Eisner, former editorial page editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, was nominated Monday to become editor of The Forward, the Jewish newsweekly.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may have a few words, like “unconscionable,” that he cannot say frequently enough, but there is at least one word he apparently cannot tolerate: “maintain.”

Charter Communications, the cable TV provider, said Monday it narrowed its first-quarter loss on a 13 percent increase in average revenue per user and a rise in subscribers.

LeBron James scored 21 points, jamming a powerful dunk in the final two minutes, as the host Cleveland Cavaliers beat the Boston Celtics, 88-77, on Monday night.

Iran’s judiciary said it would file lawsuits against the U.S. and Britain, accusing them of providing support to those behind a blast in a mosque that killed 14 people.
Investigators in Moscow said they had charged a man with killing Anna Politkovskaya, the independent journalist shot in a contract-style killing in 2006.

Signaling an end to military-backed emergency rule in Bangladesh, the caretaker administrator announced that the country would hold elections in December.

Since the beginning of his campaign, Senator Barack Obama has combated rumors and e-mails suggesting he was a Muslim or was hostile to Israel.
Jose Lachira Carranza, one of six suspects accused of killing three people in a playground last summer, was sentenced to eight years in prison for assaulting two men during a bar fight in 2006.
Dr. Jarvik was among the first to study a precursor to LSD and researched the physiology and psychology of smoking.
The people who published AAA’s 2008 New York tour book had a hard time recommending any hotels in the Bronx. They could find only one, in fact.
Nicholas Pekearo was shot while working as an auxiliary police officer on March 14, 2007, just four days after his manuscript, about a crime-fighting werewolf, was accepted for publication.
In the biggest workplace immigration raid this year, federal agents swept into a kosher meat plant on Monday in Postville, Iowa, and arrested more than 300 workers.
In addition to posting a $184 million loss for the first quarter of 2008, the mortgage lender warned Monday it would not post a profitable quarter this year.
Having lost four months of its development season to the writers’ strike, the network will, at least initially, rely heavily on fan favorites.
Wall Street rallied on Monday as oil prices fell, easing some investors’ concerns about accelerating inflation. The Dow Jones industrials gained more than 130 points.
The city’s avid bird-watchers have confirmed that the other two baby red-tailed hawks are not in their nest in the south end of Riverside Park.
Leaders of Ewing, in the bluegrass country of northeast Kentucky, are facing a problem any mayor would envy.
Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, also urged a delay in its annual general meeting, scheduled for Wednesday, in a letter to the board.
Mr. Haeberlin’s innovative spin on classical French cuisine helped transform his family’s modest restaurant on the Ill River in Alsace into a culinary powerhouse.

An article on March 27 reported on a virus, infectious salmon anemia, or I.S.A., killing millions of salmon cultivated for export by Chile’s salmon farming industry. It quoted an official at the port of Castro, Chile, describing bags of fish food stored at the facility by Marine Harvest, a Norwegian company, as containing antibiotics, pigments and hormones. The official, Adolfo Flores, identified himself as the port director. He in fact worked as a security guard, The Times learned subsequently. Had The Times been aware of his actual position at the time, it would not have cited him as an authority on the contents of the bags, which were labeled medicated food. The article also should have noted that Marine Harvest and SalmonChile, an industry association, deny that they use hormones or that the pigments they use pose any risk to consumers.
Rejected applicants for an ID card meant to guard against acts of terrorism received a letter from a security administration official that warned: “I have determined that you pose a security threat.”
The Department of Defense has identified 4,069 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:.
Prosecutors who draw on their professional experiences to write novels and assist screenwriters can breathe a little easier after a pair of rulings issued on Monday by the California Supreme Court.
The United States Court of Federal Claims is considering whether the government should pay millions of dollars to the parents of some 4,800 autistic children.
On Tuesday, the California Assembly becomes the first state legislative body in the nation to be led by a black woman, Karen Bass.
A Microsoft executive has been named the new chief executive of the largest foundation in the world, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.

Ben Silverman, the co-chairman of NBC Entertainment, acknowledged that the changing late-night landscape at the network would probably mean that Jay Leno would leave it.
The 30th-anniversary revival of Sam Shepard’s “Curse of the Starving Class,” at the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco, is respectable but timid.

Neil Young, below left, already a singer and songwriter, is now spider man. No, not Peter Parker of comic book fame, but the man whose name has been bestowed on a new species of spider. The tribute was rendered to the 62-year-old musician by Jason E. Bond, a biologist at East Carolina University in Greenville, N.C., who discovered a new trapdoor spider and chose to call it Myrmekiaphila neilyoungi, above. In a statement Dr. Bond said: “There are rather strict rules about how you name new species. As long as these rules are followed, you can give a new species just about any name you please. With regards to Neil Young, I really enjoy his music and have a great appreciation of him as an activist for peace and justice.”.

Free folk music will return to Governors Island this summer, beginning with a performance by Janis Ian on July 5. The second annual Folks on the Island: A Folk Music Festival on Governors Island will run for five Saturdays, ending Aug. 2. Other performers include Slaid Cleaves (July 12), Bearfoot (July 19), Eric Bibb (July 26) and Ronny Cox. Free ferry service to the island will leave from the Battery Maritime Building every hour on the hour beginning at 10 a.m. The concerts, at Colonel’s Row, begin at 1:30 p.m. Information: folksontheisland.com. ... Free performances of Shakespeare’s “Cymbeline” will be offered by New York Classic Theater at 7 p.m. Thursday through Sunday from May 29 to June 22 inside Central Park at West 103rd Street. Scenes in these “Shakespeare on the Run” performances, using footbridges, trees, rocks and benches as scenery, move from place to place in the park. Information: (212) 252-4531 or newyorkclassical.org.

Salman Rushdie was the bookies’ favorite to win the Best of the Booker award when his 1981 novel, “Midnight’s Children,” was chosen Monday for the six-book shortlist, a competition to be named the best of the 41 winners in the history of the Booker Prize, The Associated Press reported. The bookmakers William Hill fixed the odds on Mr. Rushdie’s novel at 5-1. Other nominees for the award, celebrating the 40th anniversary of the prize, which was established in 1969 (it was shared in 1974 and 1992) were: “Disgrace” by the Nobel laureate J. M. Coetzee (10-1); “The Ghost Road” by Pat Barker (20-1); “Oscar and Lucinda” by Peter Carey (25-1); “The Conservationist” by Nadine Gordimer (40-1); “The Siege of Krishnapur” by J. G. Farrell (80-1). The short list was chosen by a panel of judges. The winner of the Best of the Booker prize will be chosen by a vote of the public and will be announced in London on July 10. The award, now called the Man Booker Prize goes annually to the best work of fiction by an author from the British Commonwealth or the Republic of Ireland.

First Talking Heads; now a singing building. That was the prospect for the former Talking Heads frontman David Byrne on Monday, when state officials disclosed plans for him to transform a landmark Lower Manhattan building into a huge musical instrument, The Associated Press reported. The officials said Mr. Byrne’s “Playing the Building” installation, in the Battery Maritime Building, would use devices attached to ceiling beams, plumbing, electrical conduits and other structural elements to produce sound through vibration. The temporary installation and a new waiting room for ferry passengers are to open this month in the 1909 Beaux Arts structure. Mr. Byrne, 55, (above, in situ) is now a solo musician and visual artist.

“Survivor: Micronesia,” the 16th edition of the CBS franchise, ended on Sunday, drawing the lowest ratings ever for a season finale of the eight-year-old series. Nielsen estimated it averaged 12.9 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., just short of the previous low record, last May’s conclusion of “Survivor: Fiji” (13.6 million). In December the final episode of “Survivor: China” fared better than either edition, attracting 15.2 million viewers. Still, the show managed to lead the 8 p.m. hour for CBS against ABC’s “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” (11.9 million), helping make CBS the most watched network on the night by the slimmest of margins. But CBS trailed ABC later in the evening as ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” remained dominant at 9 (15.2 million) and “Brothers & Sisters” (11 million) eked out a victory over CBS’s customary “Survivor” reunion special in the 10 p.m. hour (10.8 million). ABC retained a slight edge for the night ahead of CBS in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49. Fox finished a distant third overall, followed by NBC in fourth.

The father of David Archuleta, one of the three finalists remaining in the competition on “American Idol,” has been banned from attending rehearsals for the show after disputes with the program’s production staff. A person close to the program, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the person was not authorized to speak about the matter, confirmed the account, first reported Friday by the celebrity gossip site TMZ.com. A spokeswoman for Fox, which broadcasts “American Idol,” declined to comment. Jeff Archuleta, above left, the father of David — who at 17 is the youngest current “Idol” contestant — has been the subject of reports in recent months about his active role in his son’s performances and song choices. Last month Naomi Judd, during an appearance on the “Today” program, said that when she was a judge on “Star Search” in 2003, Mr. Archuleta was “the worst stage dad,” a characterization Mr. Archuleta disputed in a subsequent interview with Us magazine. The latest dispute arose after David Archuleta, at his father’s urging, disregarded warnings from the producers against including lyrics from a song by Sean Kingston into his performance of the Ben E. King hit “Stand By Me.” The change required additional rights clearances and royalty payments by the producers.
Broadway is bracing for the Tony Awards in a year that flouted the rule book.
Since 1999 New York City Opera’s lively Vox series has offered concert performances of excerpts from new operas by American composers.
Ballet Boyz make dance immediate, accessible and exhilarating.
A new breed of tinkerers mix science and craft to make things both goofy and grand.
Senator Barack Obama acknowledged that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton would probably win Tuesday’s Democratic primary in West Virginia.

As fiercely as the rock counterculture rejected its parents’ tastes in music, all three women in Sheila Weller's  “Girls Like Us" are revealed as heavily indebted to traditional pop and its quasi-religious faith in romantic love.

8 P.M. (13, 49) A WALK TO BEAUTIFUL Common in the preindustrial United States, obstetric fistula -- in which tearing during childbirth leaves a hole in the vaginal wall, producing chronic incontinence -- is now relegated to third world countries. In Ethiopia, some 100,000 women suffer from untreated fistulas, usually a result of small pelvises and long labor. (Mothers are often malnourished, overworked or giving birth too young.) Many of these women have been shunned by their families. This ''Nova'' documentary follows three village women (above, Ayehu, on her journey) as they travel by foot to a hospital in Addis Ababa, the Ethiopian capital, where a surgical procedure can repair the damage and offer hope for re-entrance into society. 7 P.M. (National Geographic) AIR EMERGENCY: WHO'S FLYING THE PLANE? Sometimes, no one. A look at what happens when autopilots and computerized systems go on the fritz.

Salman Rushdie was the bookies' favorite to win the Best of the Booker award when his 1981 novel, ''Midnight's Children,'' was chosen Monday for the six-book shortlist, a competition to be named the best of the 41 winners in the history of the Booker Prize, The Associated Press reported. The bookmakers William Hill fixed the odds on Mr. Rushdie's novel at 5-1. Other nominees for the award, celebrating the 40th anniversary of the prize, which was established in 1969 (it was shared in 1974 and 1992) were: ''Disgrace'' by the Nobel laureate J. M. Coetzee(10-1); ''The Ghost Road'' by Pat Barker (20-1); ''Oscar and Lucinda'' by Peter Carey (25-1); ''The Conservationist'' by Nadine Gordimer(40-1); ''The Siege of Krishnapur'' by J. G. Farrell (80-1). The short list was chosen by a panel of judges. The winner of the Best of the Booker prize will be chosen by a vote of the public and will be announced in London on July 10. The award, now called the Man Booker Prize goes annually to the best work of fiction by an author from the British Commonwealth or the Republic of Ireland.

An article on March 27 reported on a virus, infectious salmon anemia, or I.S.A., killing millions of salmon cultivated for export by Chile's salmon farming industry. It quoted an official at the port of Castro, Chile, describing bags of fish food stored at the facility by Marine Harvest, a Norwegian company, as containing antibiotics, pigments and hormones. The official, Adolfo Flores, identified himself as the port director. He in fact worked as a security guard, The Times learned subsequently. Had The Times been aware of his actual position at the time, it would not have cited him as an authority on the contents of the bags, which were labeled medicated food. The article also should have noted that Marine Harvest and SalmonChile, an industry association, deny that they use hormones or that the pigments they use pose any risk to consumers.

An Israeli woman was killed Monday by a rocket fired from Gaza into southern Israel, the Israeli military said. The attack occurred as Israeli officials mulled an Egyptian-brokered proposal for a temporary cease-fire in the south. The woman, about 70, was the second such Israeli fatality in less than a week. Hours earlier, Egypt's intelligence chief, Omar Suleiman, presented Israeli officials with a proposal for a period of calm in the south. Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza, says it has accepted the plan and is awaiting Israel's response. A dozen other groups, including Islamic Jihad, have said they will comply. .

SWEENEY--Thomas, 84, of a heart attack on Sunday, May 11th, of Ridgefield Park, New Jersey and Gallatin, New York. Beloved husband for 62 years of Robin, cherished father of Thomas J. III and Deidre, loving father-in-law of Cassandra and adoring grandfather of Keelin. Graduated NYU, BS 1947 and Columbia Law School JDS 1949, Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar. Associate Cravath Swaine and Moore and Senior Vice President and Head of Personal Trust Department of JP Morgan & Co. for many years. Chairman JP Morgan Investment Mgt. Committee. Since 1989 a Partner in the law firm of Decker Hubbard Weldon and Sweeney. Served as a Navigator of B-17s in WWII. President of the United Citizens of Ridgefield Park for many years ensuring honesty and commitment in government to the citizens of Ridgefield Park. Manager for 27 years of Ridgefield Park Babe Ruth League Teams culminating in a State Championship and a trip to the Middle Atlantic Regionals in Windsor, Canada. Trustee of the Sweeney Scholars at NYU providing scholarships for worthy applicants of the contiguous counties to New York whose families had never been to college. Trustee of the Kenan Foundation of Chapel Hill, North Carolina, the Pinkerton Foundation, the Sidney and Judith Kranes Foundation and the Dreyfus Foundation. Avid New York Giants Fan; season ticket holder since 1963. A wonderful, compassionate, loving and interesting man. We will all miss him terribly. Funeral from Vorhees - Ingwersen Funeral Home, 59 Main St., Ridgefield Park on Wednesday at 9am. A Funeral Mass will be offered at St. Francis RC Church, Ridgefield Park, at 9:30am. Interment will be private in Pine Plains, New York. Visitation on Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Vorhees-Ingwersen Funeral Home and Visitation on Wednesday, 29pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Pine Plains Free Library, Building Fund, P.O. Box 325, Pine Plains, NY 12567 would be greatly appreciated

Sit through enough of them, and you'll quickly realize that the news conference is a form of political theater, but one with strict forms to be observed. Among them: The order in which the various politicians in the room get to speak. In Albany, governors go first. Then, usually, goes the Senate majority leader or the Assembly speaker. Then go the minority leaders of the Senate and Assembly, if they get invited.And then -- if they're lucky or influential or there's enough time -- go the individual senators or Assembly members who sponsored the legislation, along with (maybe) some advocacy group leaders.

The horrifying aftermath of Monday's massive earthquake in Sichuan province wears on, with the death toll rising to a reported 15,000. How China can successfully stage the Beijing Olympics in less than three months in an open question, but there have been past instances where countries that have suffered devastating disasters were able to persevere and put on huge world sporting events. Probably the best example was Mexico's succesful staging of the 1986 World Cup just eight months after an earthquake in the capital killed some 25,000 people.

I don't know about you, but one of the first things I thought of when I heard about Josef Fritzl - the 73-year-old Austrian who held his daughter prisoner for 24 years and fathered seven children with her - was John Fowles's 1963 novel, "The Collector." In the book, Frederick drugs a 20-year-old art student, Miranda, and imprisons her in a basement/dungeon. In the real world, Josef drugged his 18-year-old daughter, Elisabeth, and imprisoned her in a basement/dungeon. An article in Der Spiegel even refers to Fritzl as a kind of "collector."

My contention in today's Minimalist column is that, more often than not, stuffing is more for appearance than for flavor. I know that stuffing is a venerable and lovely tradition, and certainly one of the world's great foods -- sausage -- wouldn't exist without it. But is it not true that in most cases the stuffing and the food being stuffed would taste just as good side by side? My recipe -- a sandwich of chicken breasts enclosing cooked spinach -- might make the flavor of the spinach slightly more complex, but I like the recipe mostly because it's about the easiest way I know to make boneless chicken breasts look fancy.
(Everett Collection)

The former Smallpox Hospital on Roosevelt Island is now known as the Renwick Ruin for its architect, James Renwick Jr., who also designed St. Patrick's Cathedral. It has been abandoned for about half a century, and is the only ruin in New York City with official landmark status.

As medical advances have allowed patients who might have died as children to survive into adulthood, the patients are falling into a void in a health care system that has yet to develop institutions for the young and "medically fragile," Marc Santora reports. Each year 500,000 youths in the United States with special health care needs resulting from ailments like congenital heart disease, cystic fibrosis, diabetes, renal disease and sickle cell turn 18, according to a survey conducted by the United States Department of Health and Human Services. Many of these young people will transition to adulthood smoothly, but for the most seriously disabled, the options for care often prove limited.

I have a story up on the Chinese earthquake that I started reporting, in effect, in October 2005, when 17,000 students, trapped in more than 7,000 crumpled schools, were among the 70,000-plus victims of the extraordinary Kashmir-area earthquake in Pakistan. The potent temblor that hit China's Sichuan province also exacted an outsize toll on schoolchildren, as several crowded schools pancaked into rubble. In recent years, it has been developing countries that have been most shaken by such events. But experts say there are plenty of schools in western Canada and the United States and other wealthy countries that could similarly tumble someday under assault from known seismic threats.

Jurors in Chicago began deliberations at the corruption trial of the political fund-raiser Antoin Rezko after hearing a prosecutor accuse him of crime “involving the highest levels of power.” Christopher S. Niewoehner, an assistant United States attorney, scoffed at arguments by the defense lawyer, Joseph J. Duffy, that Mr. Rezko had been the victim of a corrupt government witness who lied on the stand out of fear that if he did not he would go to federal prison for the rest of his life. Mr. Rezko is accused of soliciting kickbacks from companies seeking state business or regulatory approval.

Child welfare officials conceded to a judge that a newborn’s mother, held in foster care as a minor after being removed from a polygamous sect’s ranch, is an adult. The woman, who gave birth on April 29, had been held along with more than 400 children taken last month from a ranch run by the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. She was one of two pregnant sect members who officials had said were minors. The other member, who gave birth on Monday, may also be an adult, state officials said.
New research shows exercise in the teenage years, starting as young as age 12, can help protect girls from breast cancer when they are grown.
A revised Senate bill would require drug makers and medical device makers to publicly report gifts over $500 a year to doctors, watering down the standard set in a previous version.

Five men have been arrested in Los Angeles since Thursday in connection with a counterfeit operation that may have produced up to $6 million worth of fake $100 and $20 bills in the past two years in “one of the largest, if not the largest, counterfeit currency rings” ever uncovered in Southern California, said Thomas P. O’Brien, the United States attorney there. Six men were charged with activities related to the ring, including dealing counterfeit securities and printing federal reserve notes on inkjet and laser printers out of the home of Albert E. Talton, 44, in Lawndale. The arrests came after an investigation by multiple law enforcement agencies that began in February. When officers raided Mr. Talton’s home last week, they found almost $250,000 in counterfeit currency and about $825,000 in partially printed bills, officials said.
The end of a decade-long European ban on poultry imports from the United States moved a step closer after the European Commission promised to put forward a formal proposal to lift the embargo.
Staples raised its bid to acquire Corporate Express, an office products supplier based in the Netherlands, by 10 percent, to $2.47 billion, but Corporate Express said it was still too low.
Consumer prices in Britain rose 3 percent in April compared with a year earlier, propelled by rising prices for home gas, electricity and heating oil, the government said.

The National Court dismissed homicide charges against three United States soldiers accused of killing a Spanish television cameraman when they opened fire on a Baghdad hotel in 2003.
The Saudi government accused Iran of backing what it called a coup d’état by Hezbollah fighters in Lebanon.
South Africa, the world’s biggest precious metals producer, said mining output fell 17 percent in March because of power shortages.
Chinese retail sales rose 22 percent in April, an indication that domestic demand is increasing, offsetting the effect of declining exports.
Two Vietnamese journalists whose articles on bribery, corruption and gambling in the Transportation Ministry rocked the ruling Communist Party in 2006 have been arrested and accused of abusing power.

Doctors in Arizona and Pennsylvania announced that they would donate medical care to those in need through the Gridiron Greats Assistance Fund. The former Chicago Bears coach and player Mike Ditka, the most vocal member of the Gridiron Greats group, has criticized the players’ union for ignoring the medical needs of former players with serious injuries who cannot afford to pay for their care. Gridiron Greats has raised more than $1 million since it was formed a year ago. Now, it has doctors at the Surgical Specialty Hospital of Arizona in Phoenix and the OAA Orthopedic Specialists in Allentown, Pa., providing free treatment to former players who qualify, while the organization covers travel and helps with other expenses.
A parish church named for St. Jerome has linked Mott Haven, an upstate D.J. and Dion DiMucci, the doo-wop legend from Belmont who goes by his first name.

The South African Natalie du Toit said qualifying for the Paralympics in the 10-kilometer open water event was “quite overwhelming.” Du Toit, 24, who lost her left leg in a motorcycle accident seven years ago, was fourth in the 6.2-mile race at the open water world championships this month in Seville, Spain. The top 10 finishers qualified for Beijing in the swimming equivalent of a marathon. Du Toit competed at the Paralympic World Cup on Saturday in Manchester, England, winning the 100-meter freestyle. She will also defend her five gold medals at the Beijing Paralympics, which take place two weeks after the Aug. 8-24 Olympics.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s office detailed a pot of discretionary funds that it distributes to council members and said it would tighten the regulation of the funds.

Storm Cat, one of the top stallions in thoroughbred racing history, has been retired as a breeder. Ric Waldman, a stallion consultant at Overbrook Farm where the 25-year-old Storm Cat was born and stood at stud, said owners made the decision because of a steep drop in Storm Cat’s fertility rate. Last year he produced 32 mares in foal, compared with 3 this year. Storm Cat, a descendant of Secretariat who for six straight years commanded a $500,000 stud fee, has produced 160 stakes winners who combined to top $112 million. Among his sires are 88 yearlings that sold for more than $1 million.

Stung by flagging fortunes in recent years, the Kenyan athletics board spelled out tough measures to impose discipline ahead of the Beijing Olympics, officials said. Athletics Kenya (A.K.) ordered 119 men and women to the western town of Eldoret by May 20 to train for the Games, where Kenya has vowed to revive its fading reputation. “We are not going to favor anyone,” said the A.K. chief Isaiah Kiplagat. “Whether you are the best in the world today or a favorite in Beijing, you must attend the camp or be left out.”.

The Buffalo Bills released the injured tight end Kevin Everett in a move that will allow him to apply for disability benefits. Everett sustained a spine injury during a game last Sept. 9 against the Denver Broncos, and doctors initially said he would not walk again. But Everett, 26, has since regained some use of his arms and legs and is able to walk on his own.

The next documentary by Michael Moore, below, untitled but described as “a searing and provocative follow-up to his groundbreaking 2004 documentary ‘Fahrenheit 9/11,’ ” will be financed by Paramount Vantage and Overture Films, the two companies announced on Tuesday. “Fahrenheit 9/11” bashed the Bush administration and won the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival in 2004, when Mr. Moore first hinted at more to come.

The United States government is honoring opera. The National Endowment for the Arts announced Tuesday that it was establishing yearly Opera Honors awards and named the first four recipients (right, from top): James Levine, the Metropolitan Opera’s music director; the soprano Leontyne Price; the composer Carlisle Floyd; and Richard Gaddes, general director of the Santa Fe Opera. Each receives a $25,000 prize. To put that $100,000 in context, the endowment is giving $2.5 million in direct opera grants this year and $7 million in other classical music grants, according to Dana Gioia, its chairman. Total grants to the arts are $72 million, with another $48 million sent to state arts councils to make their own allocations. Mr. Gioia said the awards have an “enormous symbolic value” and were established in part to stir awareness and appreciation of opera. While $25,000 could mean a lot more to a struggling singer, say, than to Mr. Levine, who may make more than that for a guest conducting engagement, Mr. Gioia called the prize “a lifetime achievement award.” “If the N.E.A. opera award is going to have credibility,” he added, “it has to recognize artists that work at the highest reaches of the art and to create, as it were, a hall of fame of American opera artists. It would be remiss, I think, not to start with the very best.”.

Wikipedia got a new rival on Tuesday, when the French publisher Larousse introduced an online French-language encyclopedia inviting users to contribute content and offering free access to its dictionary, Agence France-Presse reported. But larousse.fr said its contributors, unlike Wikipedia’s, would be identified. “People are more and more used to this abundance and are able to distinguish between reference articles and those expressing a point of view,” said Line Karoubi, the assistant director for dictionaries and encyclopedia at Larousse.

“American Gladiators,” NBC’s surprise hit during the writers’ strike, made a disappointing return to network television on Monday after a three-month hiatus, drawing just 4.9 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., Nielsen reported. The athletic competition (with Randee Haynes, above left, and Hulk Hogan) showed promise when it made its debut in early January, attracting 12.1 million viewers and particularly high ratings among adults 18 to 49. Six weeks later, the last episode before the show went on hiatus attracted a much smaller audience (7.3 million). NBC finished fourth for the night over all, faring modestly better during the 10 p.m. hour with “Medium” (8.6 million). ABC led the night in total viewers, thanks to “Dancing With the Stars” at 8 (18.3 million) followed by the season finales of “Samantha Who?” at 9:30 (11 million) and “The Bachelor” at 10 (9.2 million). Among adults 18 to 49, ABC ranked third behind CBS, with its comedy lineup, and Fox, which eked out a victory in the 18-to-49 set courtesy of “House” at 9 (14.8 million), the night’s top-rated show among that age group. CBS won the 10 p.m. hour with “CSI: Miami” (13.7 million).

Russian prosecutors charged the director of the Sakharov Museum in Moscow on Tuesday with inciting hatred or offending human dignity with an exhibition titled “Forbidden Art — 2006,” Agence France-Presse reported. The March 2007 show, which included an image juxtaposing coarse words with Christ’s crucifixion, offended the Orthodox Church, said Anna Stavitskaya, a lawyer for the accused, Yuri Samodurov. The exhibition comprised works deemed by other museum directors to be too shocking for display during the previous year. The art was visible only to viewers peeping through small holes in a white wall. Ms. Stavitskaya said the case was driven by government displeasure with the museum’s involvement in controversial projects. In 2005 Mr. Samodurov was convicted and fined by a Moscow court for instigating religious and ethnic hatred through “Caution, Religion!,” an exhibition intended to provoke discussion about the role of religion in modern society.

“Jackie Mason: The Ultimate Jew” has been extended for a second time, through Aug. 31 at New World Stages. The show opened what was to have been a 10-week run on March 18. ... Three jurors, including the wife of a Baptist preacher, a business executive and a telecommunications company employee, were chosen on Monday in Chicago for the pornography trial of the R&B star R. Kelly, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Kelly is accused of videotaping himself having sex with a girl as young as 13. The supposed victim, now 23, says she is not the person on the tape. Court officials estimate that questioning and selection from a pool of 150 prospective jurors will take about a week.

A mannequin perched on a toilet and a cartoon cat were among the artworks chosen on Tuesday to compete for the Turner Prize, a traditional flash point for controversy about British art, Reuters reported. No painters made the shortlist of four artists. The nominees were sculptors and visual artists: Runa Islam, Goshka Macuga, Cathy Wilkes and Mark Leckey. Mr. Leckey features cartoon characters in his work, Ms. Wilkes uses shop mannequins in many of her installations, Ms. Islam recreates cult movie scenes, and Ms. Macuga draws inspiration from the German horror film “The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari.” Anticipating a hostile or derisive response from critics and newspapers, Stephen Deuchar, director of Tate Britain in London and chairman of this year’s Turner jury, said: “This is art made by people for people. What is vital about the Turner Prize is that it creates informed debate about art. People are not frightened to argue about its merits and demerits.” The Turner Prize, open to British artists under 50, carries a top prize of $49,000. Each runner-up receives $9,740. Work by the shortlisted artists will be exhibited at Tate Britain beginning Sept. 30. The winner will be announced there on Dec. 1.

The Tony nominations are in, and it would be difficult to come up with a season that presented a clearer portrait of where Broadway is headed and where it has been. The creative team behind ''In the Heights,'' a musical with a hip-hop, rap and salsa-infused score that led the field on Tuesday with 13 Tony nominations (including shots at best musical and best direction), is about as young as you get in a Broadway production: 6 of the show's 11 individual nominees are under 33. The show received good, but not glowing, reviews when it made its debut off Broadway last year and raised eyebrows when it moved to Broadway, but may get the last laugh when the Tony winners are announced at the ceremony at Radio City Music Hall on June 15. The success of ''Heights'' is due largely to the talent and charm of its creator, the 28-year-old Lin-Manuel Miranda, a Broadway newbie who has achieved the rare honor of being nominated both for leading actor and for composer/lyricist.

Valentin Fuster, M.D., Ph.D. Director of Mount Sinai Heart The Mount Sinai Medical Center

RAUSCHENBERG--Robert. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of this esteemed artist. His loss will be deeply felt. RAUSCHENBERG --Robert. The Trustees and the Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with deep sadness the passing of Robert Rauschenberg. A beloved friend of the Museum, he was a maverick who worked without boundaries, continually rethinking traditional techniques and categories of media. He embraced everyday objects as suitable materials and his resulting combine paintings of the 1950s redirected the path of postwar art. Rauschenberg was first shown at the Whitney in the 1961 Annual and since then has been included in more than 70 other exhibitions at the Museum. The Whitney is proud to hold more than 50 of his works in our permanent collection, several of which were generous gifts of the artist. We will miss him--his creativity was matchless and he left a legacy that cannot be erased. We extend our condolences to his son Christopher and to his many dear friends. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Robert J. Hurst, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director RAUSCHENBERG--Robert. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art deeply mourn the loss of Robert Rauschenberg. We will remember Bob not only for his protean invention and deeply influential body of work, but also for his remarkable generosity, warmth, and exuberance. His opinion that ''there is no reason not to consider the world as one gigantic painting'' spoke volumes about the creative and open spirit in which he approached his art. Masterpieces such as the Combine paintings Bed and Rebus, both of 1955, are landmarks in this Museum's collection. We extend our deepest sympathy to his son Christopher and his companion Darryl Pottorf. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Ronald S. Lauder, Honorary Chairman Robert B. Menschel, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Donald B. Marron, President Emeritus Jerry Speyer, Chairman Marie-Jose Kravis, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art RAUSCHENBERG--Robert. Trisha Brown Dance Company mourns the loss of longtime Board Chairman and collaborator, Robert Rauschenberg. His vision, leadership, and generosity have made an indelible impression on the Company, and his warm presence and guidance will be missed. His inspiration lives on. Our heartfelt condolences go to his entire family. RAUSCHENBERG--Robert. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation deeply mourn the loss of one of the most important artists, if not the most important artist, of the last half-century. Bob looked into the most chaotic aspects of modern existence and distilled from them an art of seemingly endless wit and invention. In a career that has spanned more than fifty years, he worked in the widest possible range of media, bringing his unerring eye to paintings, drawings, and sculpture, as well as performance and technology-based works. In 1997 the Guggenheim presented his retrospective in New York and Bilbao to record-setting crowds and to equally successful showings in Houston and Cologne. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to his son, Christopher, his sister Janet Begneaud, his companion Darryl Pottorf, and his studio. This is an inconsolable loss for the art world. William Mack, Chairman, Jennifer Stockman, President, Thomas Krens, Director, Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, and Marc Steglitz, Interim Director, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum RAUSCHENBERG--Robert. We deeply mourn the loss of our longtime friend, ingenious collaborator, and generous supporter, Bob Rauschenberg. A huge loss for everyone with eyes. Board, Dancers, Staff of Merce Cunningham Dance Company, and John Cage Trust. He was a dear friend and a great artist. Together we erased boundaries between the arts. Merce Cunningham RAUSCHENBERG--Robert. The board of trustees and staff of amfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research, mourn the loss of a cherished friend and longtime supporter, Robert Rauschenberg. As a passionate advocate in the fight against AIDS and an exceptionally generous supporter of amfAR, he helped galvanize the art community's response to the epidemic and remained involved with the Foundation for 20 years as its champion and benefactor. In 2000, amfAR publicly acknowledged his leadership and generosity with the Foundation's first Award of Excellence for Artistic Contributions to the Fight Against AIDS. Today, we fondly remember Bob's genius, wit, and compassion, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his family and friends. Kenneth Cole, Chairman of the Board Mathilde Krim, Ph.D., Founding Chairman Kevin Robert Frost, Chief Executive Officer amfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research RAUSCHENBERG--Robert. The Foundation for Art and Preservation in Embassies is deeply saddened to learn of the loss of Robert Rauschenberg. His contribution to American art is immeasurable, and we are honored to include his work in our Lee Kimche McGrath Original Print Collection. We are grateful for his donation to the Collection, a gift that displays the best of one of America's greatest artists in U.S. embassies and ambassadorial residences around the world. Jo Carole Lauder, Chairman Ann L. Gund, President

The Sports of The Times column on Monday, about Reggie Williams, a retired Cincinnati Bengals player known for his leadership in and out of the N.F.L., misstated the sequence of events and the timing surrounding the end of apartheid in South Africa -- political change for which Williams lobbied while on Cincinnati's City Council in 1989. Apartheid was dismantled over several years beginning in 1990; the white government was not ousted a mere ''months'' after Williams played in the 1989 Super Bowl. And Nelson Mandela, who was imprisoned for fighting apartheid, was freed in February 1990, which was before -- not after -- the ''white government fell.''

SCHEIN--Harvey, 80, passed away on May 13th peacefully at his home in New York City after a heroic battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Joy, devoted father to Mark and Justin and their wives Maria and Eden, ever-proud grandfather to Aaron, Sophia and Micah. Born in the Bronx and raised in the East New York section of Brooklyn, he went on to serve as editor of the Harvard Law Review in 1951-1952. His career in the entertainment industry spanned many decades. As the president of CBS Records International in the 1960s he helped build their world-wide company. As the president and CEO of Sony America in the 1970s he was of the first Americans to head a Japanese subsidiary, building Sony America into major company and helping to pioneer the concept of home video recording. He also served as head of PolyGram and an executive at Warner Communications and News America Corp. He retired to his homes in Washington, CT and Sanibel, FL where he was devoted to the support of the arts including helping the community build a performing arts center on Sanibel Island. His brilliant mind for business was matched only by his love for his family. He was one of a kind and we miss him dearly. Memorial services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 W. 76th Street. Thursday, May 15, at 11:15am. Donations can be made to the Palliative Care Institute c/o Dr. Diane Meier, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Box 1070, NY, NY 10029.

Associate Cravath Swaine and Moore and Senior Vice President and Head of Personal Trust Department of JP Morgan & Co. for many years. Chairman JP Morgan Investment Mgt. Committee. The former Smallpox Hospital on Roosevelt Island is now known as the Renwick Ruin for its architect, James Renwick Jr., who also designed St. Patrick's Cathedral. It has been abandoned for about half a century, and is the only ruin in New York City with official landmark status.

MYERS--Dr. Theodore M. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the sudden passing of our esteemed Board member and volunteer health consultant, Dr. Theodore ''Ted'' Myers. In addition to his distinguished career in the fields of internal medicine and psychiatry, Dr. Myers chose to devote a major portion of his life to tikkun olam, using his medical talents and inventive mind to help people in need in the developing world. His lifelong interest in JDC's work and his concern for the welfare of the Jews then living in Ethiopia led him to undertake the establishment of JDC's first medical program in Gondar province. Together with his beloved wife, Peggy, who was always at his side, he made ten trips to Ethiopia between 1986 and 1991 to ensure the success of this effort. The health care programs and professional education initiatives that he subsequently developed for JDC in Ethiopia, in Cuba, and in the former Soviet Union continue today to enhance the quality of life for tens of thousands of people-both Jewish and non-Jewish--throughout the JDC world. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Peggy, whose photographic accomplishments as she documented their work together brought him such pride, and to his devoted children and grandchildren. We will miss his advice and wise counsel, and mourn the loss of such a gentle and compassionate soul. May his memory be for a blessing. Judge Ellen M. Heller, President Eugene J. Ribakoff, Chairman of the Board Steven Schwager, Chief Executive Officer

To the Editor: Re ''President Apostate?,'' by Edward N. Luttwak (Op-Ed, May 12):

HAVE children suddenly developed a passionate longing to cook? Or are adults just more determined to shepherd their young into the kitchen? Not so long ago, children learned just from being around grown-ups. So why do food professionals now see them as a special class of pupils whose needs must be met? Could it be the would-be teachers who need a captive audience?

GOLD--Rita. Beloved member and Benefactor together with husband, Herbert. Remembered fondly as Jonah's voice on Yom Kippur. Carole Neely & Steve Blaustein, Co-Presidents Rabbi Paula Winnig Temple Sinai of LI GOLD--Rita Weinstein, cherished wife for 66 years of Herbert, and mother of their late son Richard. Rita was a graduate of Brooklyn College and earned a Masters degree from Teachers College, Columbia University. She was a gifted teacher, poet and lover of music. Her book of poems called ''The Search'', was published by Teachers College. The Golds encouraged and sponsored many young opera singers through the Shoshana Foundation, established by Rita, Herbert and Richard and also through New York City Opera, Julliard and many other opera companies. After retirement, Rita volunteered as a teacher for many years at the Rockville Centre Headstart Program where she played and sang for the children the songs she created. Rita and Herb established the Rita Gold Early Childhood Center at Teachers College, Columbia University and also in Tel Aviv. Her songs have been published by Teachers College and by the Union for Reform Judaism and the Rita Gold Center in Tel Aviv. Funeral services will be held at 11am, Thursday, May 15 at Temple Sinai, 131 Washington Avenue, Lawrence, NY.

The board of an Australian bank, St. George, accepted a takeover bid of 18.5 billion Australian dollars ($17.5 billion) from a larger rival, Westpac Banking, the companies said. Investors, however, have given the bid a mixed welcome, and the deal must clear a number of regulatory hurdles before shareholders get to have their say. The proposed merger is the latest effort by banks to cut costs amid the fallout from the tight credit markets. The boards of the two companies said that, subject to certain conditions, St. George would recommend that shareholders accept Westpac's stock offer of 1.31 shares for each St. George share, which is a 28 percent premium to St. George's closing price on Friday, when the talks began.

As happens every year, Formula One journalists get together Friday evening at the Spanish Grand Prix to race go karts against each other at the Bridgestone karting race to see just how far off their abilities are from the pros they write about. Although the event is open only to journalists, a number of Formula One drivers have become part time journalists after their F1 career is over. That means that drivers such as Marc Surer and Bas Leinders take part in the event. Surprise, surprise, this year the teams of those two drivers came in first and second place in the race. Oh yes, and Autosport came in third. My team came in a poor ninth.

There are perfume legends, there are perfumer legends, and then there are perfumes that become obsessions. Fracas is all three, which is a hat trick less common that you'd think. Still more extraordinary, Fracas is built on a concept of tuberose, a small white flower (unrelated to rose; the name comes from the Latin word describing the plant's tuberous root system) that generates an overpowering scent and is notorious among perfumers for being a difficult raw material to master. Which is perhaps why Fracas's perfumer, Germaine Cellier, managed it.

Although the Hudson River runs right by the city, New Yorkers don't take drinking water from it. But the Hudson remains an important commercial channel, and as it has been cleaned up, native species of fish have responded positively. A new report out today raises some troubling questions about the Hudson, however. The report by Riverkeeper, an environmental organization, says 10 of 13 key species of fish have declined since the 1980s, despite the river being substantially cleaner today than it was a generation ago.

All but three Preakness starters (Behindatthebar, Giant Moon and Icabad Crane) were on the grounds at Pimlico Thursday. Many of the runners shipped in Wednesday, including two from California (Gayego and Yankee Affair) and four from Kentucky (Big Brown, Macho Again, Racecar Rhapsody and Tres Borrachos). So while the training goal is simply to keep the horses happy and prepared for their race on Saturday, with light jogs and easy gallops, for those that shipped in it also includes checking their condition after shipping. All reports appear positive. A couple of the horses also visited the starting gate to just stand and school. Again, quite typical before a major race.

The annual traveling fashion circus that is the Fornarina Urban Beauty Show touched down at the Carrousel du Louvre on Monday night. Imagine, if you will, the poppy Italian sportswear company setting up an enormous temporary shop, and a series of giant, fantastical installations by artists like Moebius, Glenn Barr, tattooist Angelique Houtkamp and Junko Mizuno, featuring lip-synching models dressed up in bedazzled denim mermaid bikinis, trapeze artists and a winged male dancer in tighty whities trapped in a cage. There were thousands of assembled Euros to take it all in, mostly Fornarina's best customers and sales associates (ie, more Italians in France since the Italians ceded Sardinia in 1860). They were shopping up a storm, dancing to music by Aurore LeBlanc, and generally making way more noise than a museum-adjunct space should ever be forced to endure. Things got even louder with the appearance of Lindsay Lohan, who let slip that she's the new face of Fornarina come Spring '09. (The trendy, clubby label and the clubgoer who never saw a flippy party dress she didn't like are a good match if you ask us.) For any of you looking for dirt, we hate to disappoint you: Lohan was on time, well-behaved and all in all quite professional -- though she was indeed wearing leggings. In fact, she confirmed that she is going ahead with producing her own line, called 6126 after Marilyn Monroe's birthday, and admitted it was a retort to the many Internet critics who jeer at her for her leggings habit. Intermix has picked 6126 up, and perhaps there will be more design coming from Lohan. "Maybe a handbag," she said. Let's see how it goes.
