Joe Drape writes that Big Brown arrived late to Pimlico and barely got to the track at Churchill Downs, galloping only three times since the Derby.

My Thursday column is from the Tibetan areas of Qinghai and Gansu Provinces -- the area that used to be the Tibetan region of Amdo. I'd welcome your comments, partly because my Sunday column is also likely to be about the Tibetans. I'm a little vague about my vacation at the moment, since I don't want my trip cut short....
Students strut at a school fashion show, with clothing provided by a New York company.
Ask.com is not giving up on its quest to compete with the big search engines.
The author of “The Library at Night” writes about finding a place to keep his library of some 30,000 books.
The bill received far more than the two-thirds vote needed to override President Bush’s expected veto.

Within just 24 hoursthis week, two of this decade’s best female athletes announced their retirements, and as in previous instances where athletes left near the top of their game, questions arose about their motivations. But maybe their departures of Justine Henin and Annika Sorenstam are right in character.

This Saturday in the Preakness Stakes, a talented thoroughbred named Big Brown will be escorted to the Pimlico wire by a cooperative field of second-rate horses that will look for all the world as if someone had rigged the Washington Generals to run a mile and three-sixteenths. This is virtually a foregone conclusion in a sport that tends to rip up foregone conclusions and leave them in a pile on the OTB parlor floor. And likewise you can be sure of what will happen next: Upon winning the Preakness, Big Brown will be subjected to that silly annual rite whereby people who watch horse racing three times a year declare him the potential savior of a sport that in fact doesn’t need to be saved.
The nation’s first openly gay governor testified Thursday that his estranged wife paid for their 2000 wedding but he doesn’t know who paid for their honeymoon to Rome or how much it cost.

For parents, signing up the kids for sleep-away camp can cause pangs of envy, thanks to the promises of hiking, fishing, river rafting and hearty mountain meals. Now, new family adventure camps from the Appalachian Mountain Club let mom and dad in on the fun for a fraction of the cost of a typical summer vacation.

Could a video game hold the key to getting more Americans in shape? Eighteen months ago, the Nintendo upended the notion of what video games could be with the Wii, an intuitive, family-friendly entertainment experience. “Now Nintendo’s latest brainchild, Wii Fit, could send similar ripples through the home-fitness market,” The Times writes today. An interactive home-fitness system that is used with the Wii console, “Wii Fit is like having a Bob Harper or a Denise Austin who talks back — gently cajoling you through exercises, praising, nudging, even reminding you to eat a banana once in a while.”.

Much has been made lately of Joba Chamberlain’s fist-pump celebrations after big strikeouts, having joined a long list of athletes rejoice after a big play, whether it be a home run, blocked shot or first down catch. Manny Ramirez even high-fived a fan in the middle of a play yesterday. What is the best celebration routine in sports today?.

Sami Lepisto’s overtime goal led Finland to a 3-2 victory over the United States in the world hockey quarterfinals in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Finland advanced to play Russia in the semifinals Friday at Quebec. Canada will play Sweden in the other semifinal.
When the normally undemonstrative Moises Alou was ejected on Wednesday, it suggested a larger point about the game: the Mets seemed to have things under control, until they did not.
On a night in which Yankees Manager Joe Girardi called a players meeting, the team’s struggling offense did what it had to do to help Mike Mussina to a win in the fifth start in a row.

Tom Glavine pitched five and two-thirds effective innings to earn his first win for Atlanta in six years, and the Braves held on for an 8-6 victory against the host Philadelphia Phillies on Wednesday night.
Luis Castillo, who injured his left quadriceps while running out a triple on Sunday, was left out of the lineup on Wednesday.
A picture credit on Tuesday with an article about the discovery of a dead baby red-tailed hawk on the West Side of Manhattan misstated the photographer’s surname. He is D. Bruce Yolton, not Yallon.

An article on Tuesday about the quarterly earnings report of HSBC Holdings, Europe’s biggest bank, referred incorrectly to the impact the turmoil in the American subprime mortgage market has had on financial services companies. They have lost more than $320 billion in asset value through write-downs; they have not lost that much in profit.

An article in some editions on April 29 about a Mass at St. Patrick’s Cathedral to mourn the 13 people killed up to that point this year in construction accidents in New York City referred incorrectly to the victims in some copies. Not all were construction workers; one was a tourist. The error also appeared in headlines and picture captions in some copies.

An article on Wednesday about a trip by Senator John McCain to Washington State to talk about climate issues misstated part of the name of a lake that he visited. It is Chester Morse Lake, not Morris.
An article by The Associated Press on Monday about the crash of a medical helicopter in Wisconsin misstated the make of the helicopter. It was a Eurocopter EC135, not EC13.

A picture caption with the Calendar in the Connecticut weekly section on Sunday about Music for People, a benefit concert on May 17 at 7:30 p.m. at Westport Unitarian Church, gave an incorrect telephone number for ticket information. It is (877) 446-8742.

An article on Monday about the Myanmar military junta’s restrictions on aid distributed to victims of the May 3 cyclone misspelled the name of a well-known Myanmar film star who was prevented by a military patrol from handing out bags of rice. He is Kyaw Thu, not Kyaw Dhyu.

An article on April 22 about the growing scrutiny faced by Patricia J. Lancaster, then New York City’s buildings commissioner, after a series of fatal construction accidents misstated the location of one accident, in which a window installer fell from a condominium tower when a safety strap failed. The tower is on the East Side of Manhattan, not in Queens.
BUSINESS DAY.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Friday about Beverlee McKinsey, a soap opera actress, referred imprecisely to the date of her death. It was Friday, May 2 — not the Friday the obituary was published.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the Tony nominations misstated the age of Arthur Laurents, who was nominated for his direction of “Gypsy.” He is 90, not 89. (The error also appeared on March 23 in an Arts & Leisure article about Laura Benanti, who stars in “Gypsy” as Louise, who becomes Gypsy Rose Lee.).
Zenit became the second Russian team in four seasons to win Europe’s No. 2 club tournament, but the victory was marred by fan violence.
Alaska has become the first state with an average gasoline pump price exceeding $4 a gallon, as rising oil costs are passed along to motorists, according to AAA.
Customs agents seized more than two dozen giant beetles from a package after postal workers heard the insects making scratching noises.
The cost of attending a California State University is going up again after a decision by the system’s governing board to authorize a 10 percent increase in student fees.
A federal appeals court in San Francisco barred logging at three sites in the Plumas National Forest, part of the Sierra Nevada range.
The Pakistan Army released 40 Taliban militants in exchange for 12 members of the army and the paramilitary Frontier Corps.

President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva confirmed the appointment of Carlos Minc as environment minister, replacing Marina Silva, who resigned citing a lack of political support for protecting the Amazon rainforest.

Attacks on Mexican police officers by drug cartels have escalated so severely that three police chiefs have sought asylum in the United States in recent months Customs and Border Protection officials said.
A truck bomb detonated outside a barracks, left, housing police officers and their families in northern Spain, killing an officer.
In the first reported deaths in the capital, two children have died of an intestinal virus that has killed 42 children and infected almost 25,000 others.
The Justice Department lawyer who represents the Bush administration’s legal positions before the Supreme Court says he is resigning after more than seven years on the job.

A 19-year-old freshman at the University of Oklahoma was elected Tuesday as mayor of Muskogee, a city of 38,000 in the northeastern part of the state. With all precincts reporting, the student, John T. Hammons, won with 70 percent of the vote over a former mayor, Hershel R. McBride, said Bill Bull, the Election Board secretary of Muskogee County. “The public placing their trust in me is the greatest, humbling and most awesome experience I’ve ever had in my life,” said Mr. Hammons, who is from Muskogee but attends the university in Norman. Mr. Hammons, who will be sworn in next week, said he planned to continue his college education but expected to transfer to an institution nearer Muskogee. Mr. Hammons said a key to his platform that resonated with voters was openness of government and keeping citizens better informed.
Six insurgents were killed in fighting against government troops this week in Ingushetia, the predominantly Muslim Russian republic adjacent to Chechnya, a Russian general said.
Without giving an exact date for the presidential runoff, the government announced a delay in the election.
The World Bank said it was shifting from an emergency approach to a long-term strategy to combat AIDS in Africa, the epicenter of the global epidemic.
The Kremlin rolled out the red carpet for the German foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier.
A possible missile strike in a border village destroyed a house and killed about a dozen people, residents and a militant spokesman said.
The Knicks are eschewing quick fixes, knowing that if they retain a few solid players and add one superstar in the summer of 2010, they could become contenders.
Once the first 24 hours immediately after an earthquake pass, rescuing survivors becomes a technical exercise best handled by specialists.
As city workers replace signs in Park Slope, alternate-side parking rules are being suspended for a few months.
After three losses in special Congressional races, some senior Republicans urged their party’s candidates to distance themselves from President Bush.
The announcement comes as G.E.’s chief executive, Jeffrey Immelt, tries to fix the troubled conglomerate, which has been hit hard by the slumping economy.
As the Lakers prepared for their game Wednesday, the team realized that it wasn’t going to be able to stand around and wait for Kobe Bryant to fashion another one of his masterpieces.
Hillary Rodham Clinton has several allies on the panel, but not yet enough to achieve her goal of counting Florida and Michigan.
The polluted atmosphere of immigration politics has produced toxic byproducts so extreme that they make a recent rebate glitch seem like a mere annoyance.

Curtis Whitley, a former N.F.L. center who played for three teams in the 1990s and had a history of substance abuse, was found dead in his trailer home in West Texas. The Pecos County sheriff said Wednesday that the 39-year-old Whitley was found Sunday night in Fort Stockton, about 220 miles east of El Paso. Sheriff Cliff Harris said there were no signs of foul play, but the death remains under investigation. Whitley played for San Diego, Carolina and Oakland from 1992-97 and had two suspensions for violating the league’s drug policy.

Prosecutors in Miami say a fifth person has been charged in the slaying of the Redskins’ Sean Taylor. Ed Griffith, a spokesman for the Miami-Dade County State Attorney’s office, said that 16-year-old Timothy Brown was charged with first-degree murder. Taylor died of blood loss in November after he was shot at his Miami-area home during what the police said was a botched robbery.

Top-seeded Ana Ivanovic lost and Venus and Serena Williams advanced to the third round of the Italian Open in Rome. Ivanovic was upset by the qualifier Tsvetana Pironkova, 6-4, 5-7, 6-2. Venus Williams advanced to the third round by defeating Samantha Stosur, 6-4, 6-1; and Serena Williams routed Alona Bondarenko, 6-2, 6-0.

Top-ranked Roger Federer and No. 3 Novak Djokovic cruised into the third round of the Hamburg Masters. Second-ranked Rafael Nadal had to work harder. Federer eased past Jarkko Nieminen, 6-1, 6-3, and Djokovic downed Juan Ignacio Chela, 6-3, 6-1. Nadal needed a tie breaker to overcome Potito Starace, 6-4, 7-6 (6).

Derek Roy scored three goals and added an assist to help defending champion Canada rout Norway, 8-2, in the world hockey quarterfinals in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Canada will face Sweden, a 3-2 overtime winner in Quebec, in the semifinals Friday in Quebec.

Chivas USA, D.C. United, Houston and New England will be the United States representatives in the initial Concacaf Champions League. D.C. United and Houston are among eight teams that qualify directly for the first round, which opens Sept. 16-18. Chivas USA and New England are among 16 teams in a preliminary round to be played Aug. 26-28 and Sept. 2-4. The tournament will include four teams from Mexico; three teams from the Caribbean; two each from Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Panama; and one apiece from Canada, Belize and Nicaragua.
Turner Entertainment is offering a new system intended to pair commercials with relevant moments in the shows they interrupt.
Under threat of impeachment, Marc Dann resigned as Ohio’s attorney general, a consequence of a sex scandal that has consumed the Statehouse for six weeks.
EADS bounced back to a quarterly profit, reflecting an unexpected turnaround at Airbus, its commercial plane maker, and a hefty early payment for its military transport aircraft.
If President Bush really wants to do more to help Lebanon, he will need to talk with Hezbollah’s masters in Syria and Iran.
The more the Yankees lose, and the more impatient Hank Steinbrenner gets, the more speculation General Manager Brian Cashman faces on his future.
In a move that left other professional tennis players stunned, 25-year-old Justine Henin ended a career she described as a “marvelous adventure.”
Merrill Lynch unveiled a new system for rating stocks that suggests Wall Street finally may be mustering up its courage to say “sell” more often.
A measure to ensure that correct information on the terrorist watch list is distributed across the government deserves swift approval as an act of travelers’ mercy.
The woman accused of being the primary booker for the prostitution ring patronized by Eliot Spitzer pleaded guilty under terms of an agreement.
It takes a great deal of courage to retire at the top of the game. In the end, I suspect Henin began to find something in herself that was larger than tennis.
The Celtics beat the visiting Cavaliers, 96-89, on Wednesday night to move to a win from the Eastern Conference finals.
The House approved a five-year, $307 billion farm bill with a solid bipartisan majority while ignoring a veto threat from President Bush.
Barack Obama wore a flag pin three days in a row — the first consecutive days he has worn the pin in the campaign — but aides called it happenstance.
Less than six months after trading their premier position player and their most durable starting pitcher, the Florida Marlins have bullied their way to the top of their division.
In Los Angeles, a gang case has unleashed opposition to the city’s hands-off policy toward immigration enforcement.
Whether or not you care to see Jersey City as New York’s sixth borough, you could write an interesting urban history centered on the area now designated as its Powerhouse Arts District.
Authorities can remove newborns in all but an “extraordinary instance” if the parents previously had children taken from their custody and their case is still open.
To close California’s huge budget gap, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger is looking to Wall Street for a loan.
In its hunt for wealthy Americans who have stashed money overseas to evade taxes, the U.S. government has turned to an obscure law enacted nearly four decades ago.
Mr. Schein led the Sony Corporation of America in the 1970s and doubled its size in spite of championing the failed Betamax video recording system.
Poor weather has meant that Big Brown, the 1-to-2 favorite at the Preakness Stakes, has galloped only three times since the Kentucky Derby.
The Geron Corporation announced Wednesday that its plans to begin the first clinical trial using embryonic stem cells had been delayed by federal regulators.
With the downfall of Gov. Eliot Spitzer and an approaching state election that has senators desperate for support, labor unions are flexing their muscles in the capital.
A group protesting the Iraq war is on its way to Fort Drum, stopping in small towns that have paid a disproportionate price in the war.
The Red Storm’s baseball program has become a consistent winner in the Northeast by relying largely on local players from what is considered by many scouts to be a shallow talent pool.
“Senator and Mrs. McCain are committed to doing everything possible to end the genocide in Darfur,” a campaign spokesman said.
The Chicago Tribune’s managing editor for news, George de Lama, is leaving the newspaper after 30 years.
The West Virginia University faculty demanded that the president of the university quit over awarding a degree to the governor’s daughter, which she had not earned.
The right-wing Colombian paramilitary leader, Diego Fernando Murillo, is accused of conspiring to import thousands of kilograms of cocaine into the United States and to launder the drug proceeds.
A 2005 e-mail message with a crude sexual joke, sent by the agent, was disclosed as part of a lawsuit by black Secret Service agents.
Foie gras, run out of town with great fanfare two years ago, is being allowed back.
Carl Icahn has decided to move ahead with plans for a proxy fight at Yahoo and will propose a dissident slate of directors, people with knowledge of the plans said.
A draft report says that there is no scientific evidence that synthetic turf fields in New York pose major health hazards for people playing on them.
An apparent Red Wings goal with a player barely in the crease, if at all, did not count, but a goal by the Stars with a player clearly in the crease did count.
A museum exhibition focuses on the rise in New York of Roman Catholics from a tiny religious minority to a group that changed what it meant to be a New Yorker.
A judge ruled that Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi could be called to testify about the abduction of a radical Muslim cleric in Milan in 2003.
Fox will introduce a science-fiction-oriented drama from J. J. Abrams of “Lost” and a comedy about life at a luxury hotel starring Jerry O’Connell.
Wall Street advanced Wednesday after a better-than-expected report on consumer prices tempered some of the market’s concerns about inflation.
Deere & Company,the farm machinery maker, said that its second-quarter profit rose 22 percent as high crop prices fed global demand for its farm equipment despite a faltering American economy.
Mr. Gaon was an Israeli industrialist who tried to build trade links with the Arab world and helped the Israeli economy move toward privatization.
Equal parts oh-boy Virginian and oh-man athlete, Josh George,24, has established himself as one of the fastest wheelchair racers.
The bank said it would take a write-down of 855 million Canadian dollars ($846 million) on its second-quarter earnings, largely because of problems in the United States debt market.
The police arrested a man in connection with a small blaze in central Florida, where wildfires have caused some $10 million in damage.
Posting to YouTube, Flickr, Facebook, Twitter or a blog on the go from your mobile phone can be simplified with a little help from ShoZu.
My Mozilla Thunderbird e-mail program sometimes tries to open file attachments in the wrong program, even when my file associations are set. How can I open the attachments?
What is the easier way to run the Windows operating system on Intel-based Macintosh hardware — Boot Camp or a program like Parallels?
Mr. Levine helped create Phil Spector’s groundbreaking “wall of sound” technique on hit records by the Crystals, the Ronettes and the Righteous Brothers.
Meanwhile, the prime minister went to the northern city of Mosul to encourage Iraqi soldiers fighting in a new offensive to rid that area of Sunni Islamic extremists.
The European Commission will propose expanding a directive to ensure that Europeans do not evade taxes on the interest from savings by opening accounts abroad.
Work on a large oil sands project was delayed after the Federal Court of Canada rejected an appeal by Imperial Oil to reinstate a permit that was voided in March.
Macy’s reported a $59 million first-quarter loss because of lower sales and the costs of a consolidation, which the company said should start paying off next year.
Paul A. Volcker warned that the United States could face a 1970s-style period of skyrocketing inflation if investors lost confidence in the buying power of the dollar.
A 1976 triptych by Francis Bacon brought $86.3 million on Wednesday night at Sotheby’s, becoming the most expensive work of contemporary art ever sold at auction.
A Bronx woman was found dead in a Lower East Side parking garage late on Tuesday, and the police said on Wednesday that her estranged husband was wanted for questioning.
Directors and officers of Countrywide, the beleaguered mortgage lender, will have to answer shareholder accusations of insider trading and a failure to monitor lending practices.
Canon’s Selphy CP770, which goes on sale this week, has a color preview screen and five ports that allow photos to be imported from an impressive 20 formats.
Prosecutors said that the volunteer firefighter’s blood-alcohol level was above the legal limit for driving at the time of the accident in August 2006.
There is agreement among golf professionals that the mantle will pass to 26-year-old Lorena Ochoa after the retirement of the dominant player in the L.P.G.A.
An experimental project by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is intended to speed up the service of buses.
Nursing home inspectors routinely overlook or minimize problems that pose a serious, immediate threat to patients, Congressional investigators say.
The Soviet Union collapsed almost 17 years ago, but for many on the edges of the empire it feels like yesterday.
The wreckage in Dujiangyan, China, stands as a tragic monument to a culture that turned its back on its remarkable and glittering history.
The Samsung Glyde cellphone features a slide-out keyboard for people who like the feel of physical buttons when pecking out e-mail and text messages.
The ZeeVee ZV-100, a $500 kit that connects to your PC, avoids many of the common video pitfalls and streams what’s on your computer screen to an open cable channel on your TV.
While personal computers rival the brain’s neural complexity, you do not need to be a neurosurgeon to fix one.
For those who would like to fix their own computers, there are a number of online resources that can help guide you through the process.

The J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles will eliminate 114 jobs and cut programs to marshal resources for the organization’s arts mission, The Associated Press reported. Fewer than 40 people were laid off, and most reductions were accomplished through attrition, a spokesman for the trust, Ron Hartwig, said. James Wood, chief executive of the trust, said, “The whole goal here is to focus the Getty on the core mission of the visual arts.” The cuts were reported Wednesday in The Los Angeles Times. Mr. Hartwig said that many of the positions are staff assistants and jobs in maintenance, communications and management.
The New York Drama Critics’ Circle presented its top awards to the Broadway shows “August: Osage County” and “Passing Strange.”

Defying France’s strict new antismoking laws, Sean Penn, right, president of the jury at the 61st Cannes Film Festival, lighted a cigarette at a news conference yesterday, Agence France-Presse reported. After a couple of puffs in defiance of rules that banned smoking in enclosed spaces since January, he put the cigarette aside and returned to answering reporters’ questions. But a jury member, the Iranian writer and director Marjane Satrapi, prompting laughter, then asked if anyone minded if she smoked “for medical reasons.” She lighted a cigarette; Mr. Penn and the French actress Jeanne Balibar joined her.

The Grammy Award-winning singer Amy Winehouse, 24, will not be charged in connection with a video segment that appeared to show her using drugs, The Associated Press reported on Wednesday, citing her spokesman Chris Goodman. The police questioned her about the footage for nine hours last week.

The first trans-Atlantic broadcast, on March 14, 1925; Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia’s reading of the comics in 1945; and Michael Jackson’s 1982 best-seller “Thriller” were among 25 recordings added Wednesday to the Library of Congress’s National Recording Registry, The Associated Press reported. The archive is part of the library’s endeavor to preserve America’s aural history through recordings deemed “culturally, historically or aesthetically significant.” Other selections this year included Harry S. Truman’s speech at the 1948 Democratic National Convention; the original-cast recording of “My Fair Lady” from 1956; and music by Tommy Dorsey, Roy Orbison, Joni Mitchell and Herbie Hancock.

Leonard Cohen received a standing ovation from a sold-out house when he stepped onstage Sunday for his first show in 14 years, The Globe and Mail of Toronto reported. The appearance by the 73-year-old singer and songwriter at the 700-seat Playhouse in Fredericton, New Brunswick, began a 48-date tour that will take him to 14 countries in coming months. He played two sets of eight songs each and four encores. The list included 1960s standards like “Suzanne,” “Bird on the Wire” and “So Long, Marianne.”.

Jack Black, above, postures amid a small army of faux pandas in an elaborate — what else? — bid for publicity at the Cannes Film Festival. In the animated film “Kung Fu Panda” Mr. Black provides the voice of Po the Panda, a slothful noodle-restaurant waiter called upon to perform heroic feats of martial arts.
For Neil Diamond the 46th time is a charm. His new CD, “Home Before Dark” (Columbia), became the first of his 46 charting albums to reach No. 1.

Possibly the leader of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra on Tuesday could be considered a conductor. Definitely the leader was a semiconductor — a whole lot of them, The Associated Press reported. Asimo, a 4-foot-3-inch Honda robot, led the orchestra in a performance of “The Impossible Dream” from “Man of La Mancha.” After greeting the audience in a childlike voice, Asimo mimicked the actions of a conductor, nodding at sections of the ensemble during the performance and gesturing with one or both hands. At the end Asimo — an aconym for Advanced Step in Innovative Mobility — was greeted by the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, above right, and enthusiastic shouts from the audience. Engineers based the robot’s motions on those of Charles Burke, the orchestra’s education director, as he conducted the piece about six months ago.

“The Real World: Brooklyn” may sound redundant, but MTV has approved plans to start production of a Brooklyn edition of its “Real World” reality series in which seven young strangers live together as the cameras roll. MTV said it had ordered 12 episodes of the show, which is scheduled to run in the first quarter of 2009.
Who in the world is Cubby Bernstein?

Fox’s “Hell’s Kitchen” drew its best ratings ever on Tuesday as 12.4 million viewers tuned in to the competitive cooking show at 9 p.m., Nielsen estimated. The series attracted the night’s second highest ratings among adults 18 to 49, trailing only Fox’s “American Idol,” which dominated the 8 p.m. hour with 24 million viewers. Fox easily led the night over all, while CBS took second place thanks largely to “NCIS” at 8 (14.7 million). CBS remained solid the rest of the night with “Shark” at 9 (10.2 million) and a rerun of “Criminal Minds” at 10 (8.3 million). ABC was third. Despite outpacing “Hell’s Kitchen” during the 9 p.m. hour in total viewers with “Dancing With the Stars” (16.6 million), ABC struggled at 8 with two episodes of “According to Jim,” which together averaged 4.4 million viewers. At 10 ABC’s “Women’s Murder Club” garnered 8.5 million viewers, well short of the season finale of NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” in the hour (11.3 million). NBC finished fourth for the night over all.
A television ad for a heart stent may deceive the public and should be reviewed by federal regulators, according to an article published by a leading medical journal.
It is possible to piece together a picture of a powerful storm but a rescue of not nearly the same magnitude.
Paint is leading the expansion of the green building movement, as manufacturers are being forced to produce cleaner and safer paints.
There is a new yardstick for the size of the universe. It is approximately equal to the size of Kanye West’s ego.
Events, exhibitions, discussions and tours.
“Passion,” a 75-minute show presented by Momix, strikes me as sensationalist trash so brightly harmless that I wish I could fall in line with those who enjoy it as sheer sensation.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
With this year’s crop of summer movies, Hollywood may have trouble topping last year’s success.
Much has been written about contractors from hell, but comparatively little attention is paid to the homeowner from hell, who can make contractors crazy.
Not unlike other thin-and-light laptops, the U110 IdeaPad by Lenovo does not have an internal optical drive and instead uses an external DVD/CD recorder.
The House voted in defiance of President Bush, who believes the bill gives too much money to rich farmers.
A battle of attrition continues to be waged over the barrier that Americans have built to try to establish a safe zone.
Pictures of the stellar debris from an almost 100-year-old explosion of a star within our galaxy reveal it to be the youngest supernova remnant known in the Milky Way.
Senator Arlen Specter is questioning the legitimacy of the Patriots’ accomplishments and calling for a wider inquiry.
Since its introduction of a gay-theme story line last summer “As the World Turns” has actually gained viewers, specifically younger viewers.
The whimsy is ever-present in Target Margin Theater’s new show. So why does this play ultimately feel as if it goes on too long?
Greek officials said that they had sold a 3 percent stake in the country’s public telecommunications operator to Deutsche Telekom, the largest telephone company in Europe.
The husband-and-wife team of Marilyn McCoo and Billy Davis Jr. are a prime illustration of how pop culture eventually congeals into a nostalgic cavalcade.
Ben Daniels has arrived on Broadway this spring as a largely unknown but deeply attractive British import.
In Thomas Perry’s new mystery a killer frets over a job that’s gotten out of hand.
Taking a walk through the flower district with De Juan Stroud, who has a floral design company in TriBeCa.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
As foreclosures mount and contributions to building associations shrink, condo owners find themselves nagging each other to pay their assessments and haggling over chores.
Double-Wide’s sound is a kind of pop-art remake of Southern vernacular.
Investigators are seeking to determine whether companies are blocking generics drugmakers from getting less-expensive medicines to market quickly.
Can Wii Fit, born of a best-selling gaming console, revolutionize exercise? Five testers weigh in.
Q. It took me years to eradicate the spiderwort that had become a rampant weed in my garden. Are the new colors any better behaved than older varieties?
On Thursday, Disney’s video game division will open an online service and social network meant to connect players of Disney games across North America.
It’s time to decide whether to junk that old clunker or a lawnmower and buy a shiny new machine.
The program at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue on Tuesday was a reminder that American composers have been producing terrific sacred choral works since the early 20th century.
Elliott E. Maynard lost the primary election following a conflict-of-interest scandal involving vacation photographs with the chief executive of a coal company.
At a reception in Manhattan last week for year-end design awards at Parsons the New School for Design, graduating students came in nervy new turnouts that rated a spin on the runway.
A casual loose-limbed spirit permeates “Past Half Remembered,” a slight ensemble-created piece by the New International Encounter theater group.
Pilots voted overwhelmingly in favor of changes to their contract that will give them pay raises, an equity stake and other benefits, but also will give management more leeway.
The case involves a jury award to the widow of a 71-year-old man who had a history of heart disease and died of a heart attack after taking Vioxx briefly.
The men were given prison terms of up to seven years on Wednesday for their roles in helping to send French youths to fight alongside insurgents in Iraq.
The House overwhelmingly approved a $300 billion farm bill, making it probable that the measure will become law.
The central bank governor, Mervyn King, said that inflation in Britain, which rose to 3 percent in April, would probably remain that high or rise as energy and food prices increase.
Orange County, Calif., has become a center for small eye care device makers in much the same way that Silicon Valley is a center for technology.
The Ziszor has an appealing heft and its battery-powered motor (it takes four AA’s) keens throatily.
Riverhouse is a 264-unit condominium in Battery Park City being marketed as the latest in environmental sustainability.
The photos in “Armed America: Portraits of Gun Owners in Their Homes” have a cheerful, American Gothic weirdness to them.
Three chairs from the archives of the Dutch modernist architect Gerrit Rietveld are back in production and available for the first time in the United States.
Consumer prices edged up slightly in April, but far more slowly than many economists had anticipated.

May’s list of new books comes weighted with accolades, from within publishing and without. Reviews of works by Inger Ash Wolfe, Aleksandar Hemon, Chris Knopf, Stephenie Meyer, James Meek and Elizabeth George.
The Movado Hour, a series presented at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, offers a different kind of experience.

GOLD--Rita Weinstein. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Rita Gold, whose commitment and generosity strengthened our ability to serve those in need and enriched the Jewish community here and in Israel. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Herbert, and to all who loved Rita. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO GOLD--Rita Weinstein, cherished wife for 66 years of Herbert, and mother of their late son Richard. Rita was a graduate of Brooklyn College and earned a Masters degree from Teachers College, Columbia University. She was a gifted teacher, poet and lover of music. Her book of poems called ''The Search'', was published by Teachers College. The Golds encouraged and sponsored many young opera singers through the Shoshana Foundation, established by Rita, Herbert and Richard and also through New York City Opera, Julliard and many other opera companies. After retirement, Rita volunteered as a teacher for many years at the Rockville Centre Headstart Program where she played and sang for the children the songs she created. Rita and Herb established the Rita Gold Early Childhood Center at Teachers College, Columbia University and also in Tel Aviv. Her songs have been published by Teachers College and by the Union for Reform Judaism and the Rita Gold Center in Tel Aviv. Funeral services will be held at 11am, Thursday, May 15 at Temple Sinai, 131 Washington Avenue, Lawrence, NY.
RAUSCHENBERG--Robert. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Robert Rauschenberg, and send condolences to his family.

Aciman, father of Andre Aciman and father-inlaw of Susan Wiviott, JBFCS Deputy Executive Director. We extend our deepest condolences to Regine, Allan, Andre and the entire family. John A Herrmann, President Paul Levine, Executive VP and CEO ACIMAN--Henri (1915-2008). Husband to Regine, father of Andre and Allan, father-inlaw to Susan and Carole, and grandfather to Alexander, Philip, Michael, and Abigail. His adored grandchildren will treasure his memory and live out the remainder of their lives in his light.

MAHONEY--Olivia Louise (Monjo), passed away on May 11th. Cherished mother of Cate Mahoney, beloved daughter of Louise Monjo and supportive sister of Nick, Charles and Justin Monjo. Innovative VP/Editor-in-Chief of three Hachette Filipacchi publications. We love her eternally and she will always be with us. Please donate to ''Susan G. Komen for the Cure''.

8 P.M. (13) PETER GRIMES Anthony Dean Griffey, above, portrays the ultimate outsider in Benjamin Britten's tragic opera about a misfit English fisherman who may have caused the deaths of his boy apprentices. Taped in March, this ''Great Performances at the Met'' presentation features Patricia Racette as Ellen Orford, the schoolmistress who befriends Grimes; Felicity Palmer as the gossipy widow Mrs. Sedly; and Teddy Tahu Rhodes as the quack apothecary Ned Keene. Writing in The New York Times, Anthony Tommasini commended Mr. Griffey, in his breakthrough portrayal, as ''an elegant singer and courageous actor long overdue for a starring role at the Met.'' 8 P.M. (CW) SMALLVILLE Brainiac (James Marsters), under the guise of Kara (Adrianne Palicki), whom he imprisoned in the Phantom Zone, persuades Lex (Michael Rosenbaum) to go face to face with Clark (Tom Welling) in this seventh-season finale. Meanwhile Chloe (Allison Mack) gets cuffed by the Domestic Security Department, and Lana (Kristin Kreuk) awakens from her coma.

SWEENEY--Thomas J. The Trustees and staff of The Pinkerton Foundation note with sadness the passing of our esteemed colleague, Thomas J. Sweeney. BLAU--Sharon. She brought out the best in everyone because that is who she was the best. My condolences to her daughter Sarah and husband Michael. I will miss you forever. Jacalyn F. Barnett BLAU--Sharon, died at home on May 14, 2008. Adored wife of Michael McCoy, devoted mother of Sarah. Beloved sister of Carol Jolly, she is also survived by her sisters-in-law and brothers-in-law and several nieces and nephews. A respected attorney for nearly 30 years, she was admired by both clients and opponents; her warmth and humor will be deeply missed by her many friends. Contributions in her honor may be made to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NYC 10065; or to Visiting Nurse Service of New York Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, 7th Floor, NYC 10001. Service Thursday 12:45pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

BROWN--Olga Boondas. The family and friends of Olga Boondas Brown sorrowfully announce the passing of Olga on May 13, 2008 after a long illness. She is remembered as a beloved friend, wife, mother, sister and aunt whose kindnesses affected all. At her memorable retirement from the Peninsula Counseling Center in May, 2007, the following encomia from her devoted co-workers were preserved: ''You have been deeply admired and respected from your wisdom, balance and sound judgement: for your integrity, loyalty and ability to inspire a high level of team spirit; for your genuine caring about others and for your skilled professionalism.'' ''Declaration of Love for Olga Brown --Olga, you have been our Penelope, to whom we could always return after our odysseys. You have listened to us and respected our problems, no matter their size. You have shown us how to be tolerant and kind. You have made us feel safe, valued, and special. You have been the best of models and the best of friends.'' Olga was the youngest of four daughters of Photios and Stella Boondas, both of whom came from Messenia, Greece. She was married to Constantine Brown, her devoted husband and companion for 40 years. Together they endured the unexpected loss of their only child, Themis Anastasia. Olga's oldest sister, Catherine Cover predeceased her. She is survived by her sisters Mary Laren and Jennifer Boondas. Other surviving nieces and nephews are Mary Louise DeNardo, John Cover, Inga Lamonaca, Guy Laren, Phillip Laren, and Anders Laren. Throughout her life, Olga demonstrated a tremendous intellectual curiosity in all subjects, but she is most importantly remembered for her moral integrity and a genuine ability to stay focused on true human values. She has had an illustrious professional career in the field of mental health which included clinical practice, supervision, consultation, teaching and administration. Hers was among the first classes to be graduated from Queens College in Flushing, NYC, where she was awarded her diploma Magna Cum Laude. She received her Master's degree in Social Work at Case Western Reserve, Cleveland, Ohio and worked for three meaningful years at the Cleveland Guidance Clinic. Upon her return to New York, she worked for the Community Service Society followed by the Family Service Society of the Five Towns. In 1963 she was awarded a two year Fulbright fellowship to teach social work at Pierce College, Athens, Greece. She joined Columbia University as assistant professor. In 1985 Olga affiliated with Peninsula Counseling Center where she remained for 25 years as a unit administrator until her retirement in 2007. Funeral services will be held Saturday 10am at St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Church, 84-95 152nd, Jamaica, NY 11432. The funeral services will be handled by Litras Funeral Home, 83-15 Parsons Blvd, 718-658-4434, Viewing Friday 5-9pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center, 633 Third Avenue, NY, NY 10017 in Olga's memory.

Dedicated father of Jayson and (Stacy Glass) and Daniel and (Patricia Adler). Dear grandfather to Ava (eight), Liza (six) and Dylan (two weeks old). Also survived by adoring in-laws, Milton and Bertha Psaty. Funeral services were held on Tuesday, May 13, 2008 at Rye Community Synagogue. LITTMAN--Yetta. The Board of Directors and staff of Hebrew Hospital Home extend their deepest condolences to Yetta's daughter Lynne Littman and grandsons Alex and Rio Hackford on the sad occasion of their mother and grandmother's passing. Yetta served as president of our auxiliary for over 30 years and later served as a member of The Board of Directors for almost as many years. She worked tirelessly on behalf of our residents and has earned her eternal rest. Arnold Goldstein, Chairman David Spector, Chairman Emeritus Mary Frances Barrett, Chief Executive Officer LITTMAN--Yetta Abler, who devoted her life to philanthropic work as former Board President and founding member of The Service League of the Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Chronic Sick, died on May 13, 2008 at the age of 99. Born in 1909, the daughter of Gussie and Morris Abler, she attended Wadleigh High School and graduated from Teacher's Training and Hunter College. Following a brief singing career which included a weekly radio show, ''Singing In the Bathtub'' on WYAL, she taught high school in the New York City Public School system. Married in 1936 to the late Carl Littman, attorney and president of Chesterfield Farms Dairy, Mrs. Littman will be remembered for her fierce sense of humor, her indefatigable energy and generosity, her ability to make a great ''deal,'' and her gift for friendship. She is survived by her daughter, Oscar-winning filmmaker, Lynne Littman and grandsons Alex Littman Hackford and Rio Hackford. Services will be held at The Riverside Memorial Chapel on Thursday, May 15, 2008 at 11:30am. Contributions can be made in her memory to The Hebrew Hospital Home Foundation, 61 Grassland Road, Valhalla, New York 10595.

Treasured uncle to John and Honor Brodie and David and Lauren Parsly. His warmth, compassion, inspirational love of family and loyal friendship will be forever cherished. Services May 15th, 2008, 11am at Gutterman and Musicant, Hackensack, NJ. For information, 800-522-0588. SHERMAN--Michael D. Our heartfelt condolences to Joan, Richard and the entire family at the loss of their beloved Michael. He will be dearly missed. Gloria and Jesse Gottlieb

TUTTLE--Gordon M., of Darien, CT, on May 8, 2008 after a short illness at the age of 85. A graduate of Andover, Yale and Harvard Law School, he served as a Staff Sergeant in an artillery battalion of Patton's Army and was awarded the Silver Star, Bronze Star and Purple Heart. A retired lawyer, Vice Chairman of Avco Corporation and Senior Vice President of Textron Inc., he is survived by three children, Garrett M. Tuttle, David P. Tuttle and Dr. Ann Tuttle Koster, seven grandchildren and his special friend, Jane P. Kelly. His wife Alice Wyker predeceased him. At all times his family was his greatest interest. His family and friends will greatly miss his wise counsel, generosity and kind heart. Friends are invited to join the family for a celebration of his life on May 31st, 2008, at the Wee Burn Country Club, 410 Hollow Tree Ridge Road, Darien, CT from 4-6pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to: Phillips Andover Academy, 180 Main Street, Andover, MA 01810; Yale University, P.O. Box 2038, New Haven, CT 06521-2038; the Darien Library, 35 Leroy Avenue, Darien, CT 06820; or the Good Shepherd Orphanage, c/o Pura Vida for Children, P.O. Box 1692, New Canaan, CT 06840.

Many commenters have expressed disbelief in the wake of Friday's decision to overturn the International Association of Athletics Federations' ban against the double-amputee sprinter Oscar Pistorius. What some of them seem to have missed was the reasoning behind the Court of Arbitration for Sport's unanimous decision: that the scientific analysis suggesting Pistorius gained an advantage from his prostheses was fundamentally flawed.

The rain never really stopped Friday and still had not stopped as of 7:30 p.m. So the game between the Yankees and the Mets at Yankee Stadium was postponed. No makeup date has been decided, but the Yankees said it would not be played on Saturday, Sunday or Monday. Anyone with tickets for Friday's game can use them for the rescheduled game or exchange their tickets for any regular-season game at the stadium for the next 12 months. Because of the limited ticket availability, the Yankees are encouraging fans to use their tickets on the rescheduled date. The Yankees and the Mets are scheduled to play at Shea Stadium on June 27, 28 and 29. Sounds as if another day-nighter between the Queens and the Bronx is possible.

Speaker Sheldon Silver's office said Friday that the Assembly would put all pension bills on hold that rely on financial analyses prepared by Jonathan Schwartz, a consultant paid by labor unions. The Speaker said the bills would need new "fiscal notes," which are legally required to explain the cost of bills to taxpayers.The move, which would affect scores of current bills, followed a New York Times report revealing that the Legislature has been using Mr. Schwartz, a union consultant, to draft financial analyses of legislation impacting the city's pension funds.

Driving through California last month, I couldn't believe that gas had passed $4 a gallon. With the price of oil continuing to climb, the rest of the country seems to be heading to $4 as well. But for some gas stations, it's literally impossible to charge more than $3.99 a gallon.

Updated, 7:06 p.m. | A crowd of more than 300 Hasidic Jewish residents began a protest in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, on Friday afternoon to express anger over the assault and robbery of a 16-year-old Jewish man early Friday morning. The protesters marched from the scene of the crime, at Empire Boulevard and Albany Avenue, to the 71st Precinct, and then up New York Avenue to Eastern Parkway, one of the neighborhood's main corridors, where protesters blocked traffic. They were briefly stopped at Kingston Avenue from going forward by a line of police officers who stood arm-to-arm. After the protesters shouted for a while longer, traffic was reopened on the parkway at 6:10 p.m. and the crowd gradually dispersed around 6:45 p.m.

A new version of a plan for an old theater owned by New York University.

The walls of the Provincetown Playhouse theater will be preserved under a revised plan from New York University, according to a group that has been fighting the proposed demolition of the building, which is at 133-139 MacDougal Street. Andrew Berman, the executive director of the group, the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation, said the new plan calls for keeping the facade and the walls around the theater space, demolishing the rest of the building and building a new structure around it.

I am about as far from a cake decorator as anyone you've ever met -- in fact you can count on the fingers of no hands the times I've used the small tips on a pastry tube -- but I know art when I see it, and Karen Tack and Alan Richardson's "Hello, Cupcake!" (Houghton Mifflin, out now; www.hellocupcakebook.com) qualifies. These are "recipes" -- construction directions is more like it -- for the most fanciful and frequently bizarre cupcakes you've ever seen, using ingredients that you may not even want to eat. Whatever; I have not had as much fun simply browsing through a book in months.

Updated | 5:35 p.m. WATERTOWN, S.D.-- Senator Barack Obama responded sharply Friday to recent criticism of his foreign policy by President Bush and Senator John McCain, saying that the Republican leaders were guilty of "dishonest, divisive attacks" and had engaged in "hypocrisy, fear-peddling, fear-mongering" in an effort to continue what Mr. Obama called "the failed policies" of the past seven years.

Kentucky's senior senator, Mitch McConnell, the minority leader, addressed the gathering of the National Rifle Association earlier today at its convention in Louisville. (Senator John McCain, and his former G.O.P. rivals for the nomination -- Mike Huckabee and Mitt Romney -- are also attending.)

Christian Siriano, the winner of Season 4 of Project Runway, has taken on his newest challenge virtual reality. He has teamed up with Gaia, an online community, to create custom looks for its live prom this weekend. We talked to the catchphrase-loving designer about avatar couture, future projects and hot tranny messes.So what attracted you to this Gaia project? They told me, you know, I could design whatever I want. And what designer doesn't want that? I'm looking at one of your prom avatar outfits, and I'm loving this fur-trimmed cape situation. OMG, I know. Well, for the boys I was inspired by the British military. You know, I don't really do men's wear too much but I thought that would be, like, fabulous and who doesn't want to wear a cape to prom? I feel like this would be your outfit for the prom. Totally! And then underneath would be a gold lamé suit. I remember they showed pictures from your prom on Runway, right? Let's talk about it for a second. Tell me what you wore. Well, in the picture you saw I wore a sequined tailcoat that I made and, like, these big wide pants and this satin shirt and I had a mohawk. We looked like we were going to an '80s prom. It was fabulous.Siriano's designs for the virtual prom. That was senior prom? That was senior prom. My junior prom was even worse. I wore a three-piece linen cream suit with an ascot and Joaquin phoenix asked to take a picture of me and my date. It was fabulous. Wait, an ascot? Yeah, an ascot! It was Gucci, and it said "Gucci" all over it. A mohawk also? I think I had like a Flock of Seagulls thing going on. Ok, how were you not the prom king? I don't understand.Well, we didn't have prom king, but trust me, I would have been. So are you going to be at the virtual prom? I'm going to make a cameo appearance. Well, you are very busy. Are you going to bring a date? No, I'm going solo. Stag? Yeah, but I'm going to get bombarded by paparazzi there! Oh my god, prom paparazzi, of course. Have you ever been into virtual stuff before this? Like Second Life or anything? In all honesty I'm not a big Internet person. I don't blog, I am not technically good at computer anything. I'm a more an artsy, creative kind of person. I'm glad I went with this Gaia thing though because it's still about fashion, not just about virtual online. It's still about clothes and about people expressing themselves creatively. I am trying to keep everything more fashion-forward and not go the other direction. Ok, since we are talking about fomal attire, did you go to the Met gala? No, I didn't go! I was doing "TRL" that day with the Gaia divas. I was really sad to miss it, but next year will be bigger and better. Plus, I'll have a whole collection out and I will be able to promote it. Do you think you would've superhero-d it out for yourself if you had gone? Omigod, I would have been so superhero tranny, it would've been amazing. And so would my date, whoever I would've brought would have the most amazing gown for life. Who do you wish you could've dressed this year? And did you love or hate anything? I was bummed out by it because no one really went with total superhero. No one really went there! I'm so sad, I can't believe Victoria didn't ask me to dress her, because she looked a hot mess. I mean, she was wearing, like, a beaded nightie. I was, like, Hon-eeeyyy, what's wrong with you??I know snoozeville.She looked beautiful, but it was like a normal thing you would wear to any event. I wish they would go a little crazier.Let's back up to "hot tranny messes." I have been wondering, has there been backlash from the tranny community since you made that the biggest put-down of all time?No! the trannies LLLLLOVE me, are you kidding?? I kinda use it in a negative way sometimes but I'm meaning it with love. I mean, I love Candice Cayne - she's fabulous and we are so close - so I would never hate on trannies.Ok, so tell me. What's next? Are you doing fashion week this fall?I am, in September, so I hope you'll be there. It's not definite whether I am going to show in the tents. I'm thinking about doing an off-site venue just because it's just more my style. We'll see. I'm very excited, I'm working with sponsors right now. It's just a whirlwind. I'm doing costumes for a new movie, I have a book coming out, I'm doing a small capsule collection for bluefly.com.What's the book about?It's like a fashion kind of how-to book. It's, like, about being fierce and fabulous and about hair and makeup and trends. And it's also like a little biography about, you know, all my projects.Do you like doing so many different things? Or do you think that once you really get it going, after your first show, you're going to chill it out a bit and just focus on your clothes?Yeah, I mean there is also talk of me doing a reality show of my own, basically following me as a new fashion designer.I was wondering when that one was going to come up.You know, that might happen and if it's serious about me being a fashion designer then I will do something like that. But once I get everything in place and I show next season, I don't really wanna do anything else anymore. I mean, I'll do little branding projects and I would continue to do something with Gaia because it's virtual and I don't have to make hundreds of garments for them.Did you live for 'Saturday Night Live'? Were you loving it?Lived, loved, love Amy.It was kind of the best impression of all time, no?I know, it was actually scary because she looks so much like me. I thought it was so cool. I didn't really ever watch "S.N.L." before this happened so I was kinda in the dark but, OMG, loooooved it.Did you get nine million phone calls?Ummm, yeah. I didn't even get to see it when it was on though, I missed it. Luckily though, because Bravo and "S.N.L." are on the same floor at NBC, and I was there that day, I got to meet her the day before, which was great.What's left? What's the wish list? You've got "S.N.L." parody, possible reality show, a book Everything I've done is great, and all I hope is that after my show my clothes get bought and I'm in stores. That is the biggest goal. I mean, yes, lots of different people have bought my clothes and I'm still dressing people. I hope that they wear them to things and you can see them on them, you know?When does that happen? Have you had a big 'open the magazine and see your clothes on a celebrity' moment yet?I've had a couple little things. Heidi placed a big order and I'm dressing her for the Peabody Awards. And Victoria bought a bunch of stuff and she wore my pants and it was in Us Weekly. But, you know, I just hope that after September, after I show a new collection, it'll just go off the charts and people can wear it. That's all I want, it's not a big dream.Just a small dream, world famous fashion designer.It's just world fame, something so simple.It's all you're asking for, I don't see a problem with it.I don't either. I don't understand people; they need to get it together.What is the new 'fierce,' Christian, tell us all.There's not really a new one.But I saw you on "Ugly Betty." If it's banished, what replaces it?I feel that 'ferosh' and 'ferosha coutura' sound much more fabulous so I kinda throw that in. But I mean, 'fierce' will always be around, don't you worry.

Here's what we'll be toasting to this weekend: T Magazine has been nominated for two daytime Emmy awards. The films are "Circle Squared," by Todd St. John and "Dinner Plans," by the Neistat Brothers. We commissioned these shorts for our 2007 holiday series on T's Web site.

The University of Pennsylvania's New Bolton Center is a well-known veterinary hospital, but you could argue that one horse truly put it on the map. The 2006 Kentucky Derby winner Barbaro has helped the hospital raise millions of dollars for patient care and laminitis research. Dr. Dean Richardson, the chief of surgery at the center and a horse lover, discusses (below and at left) his most famous patient, his reaction to Eight Belles and the future of horse racing.

Updated, 3:16 p.m. | The New York City Water Board voted this morning to approve a 14.5 percent increase for water and sewer rates -- the largest increase since 1992. When the new rate is in place on July 1, according to the city's Independent Budget Office, water rates will have risen a cumulative 77 percent [pdf] since 2001, and double digit increases are expected to keep coming for at least a few more years. According to official projections, the average single-family homeowner will pay $800 for water in the fiscal year that starts July 1, up from $700 this fiscal year.

You need water more urgently than anything other than breathable air, yet the difficulty of securing a clean, reliable supply seems to be making headlines all over, and not just in desert areas or in the ravaged wake of disasters like the Sichuan earthquake or the Irrawaddy Delta cyclone.

The Bedford-Atlantic Armory, at the corner of Bedford and Atlantic Avenues in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, is a massive, turreted structure that takes up a full city block near the center of the neighborhood. It is also a 350-bed men's homeless shelter and assessment center, though Department of Homeless Services officials said there were only 345 men staying there on Wednesday, when I visited with a contingent from the department.
With interleague play for the 2008 season starting Friday night, it is a good time to look back at some of the numbers from MLB.com dating back to the start of interleague play in 1997.

Florida State catcher (and sometimes shortstop and closer) Buster Posey played every position during Monday's 10-0 victory over Savannah State. Surprisingly enough he is the fourth player to accomplish this feat under manager Mike Martin, who has been on the bench for 29-seasons at Florida State. Oh, and Posey also hit a grand slam in the second inning to give the Seminoles a 6-0 lead.

The race for the scudetto comes down to the final day of the Italian Serie A season: Inter clings to a one point (and tie-breaker) lead over rival AS Roma. When the neroazzuri visit relegation-threatened Parma on Sunday, and Roma travels to Catania, who is one above the drop zone, they'll do so without their most loyal fans.
Just when we thought we were free, that it was safe to move forward, we have been pulled back by an unknown force. And now, we face an uncertain future -- a pair of Game Fives.

Last week, I finally made it to the Cai Guo-Qiang retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum. The centerpiece is a spectacular cascade of nine white Chevrolet Metros hung inside Frank Lloyd Wright's courtyard. It is titled "Inopportune: Stage One" and was shown earlier in two versions, at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art and the Seattle Art Museum, with white Ford Tauruses instead of the Metros.

The Court of Arbitration for Sport's ruling Fridayclearing the way for Oscar Pistorius to compete for a spot on the South African Olympic team may be the key to a radical re-imagining of what constitutes "disability." As Pistorius himself told the Times of London last year: "Would I want my legs back? I'd have to sit down and think about it."

Update During the White House press gaggle today in Saudi Arabia, Dana Perino and Ed Gillespie expressed shock (!) over the widespread Democratic outrage toward President Bush's remarks to the Knesset in Jerusalem yesterday.

The new summer issue of T Travel charts the season's most intriguing spots both near and far, from the Ontario lakes and the beating heart of Provence to a Himalayan wonderland in the north of India and the otherworldly desert of Namibia. (Be sure to check out Norbert Schoerner's film "Soar," shot near the Namib-Naukluft National Park, the site of our cover shoot.) We also take a look at how the creative class is shaking up Copenhagen; a new hotel that's drawing attention to Australia's Kangaroo Island; and even an unlikely artistic revival in Paducah, Ky. Plus: a guide to Beijing, the laid-back Italian island of Ischia, shopping in Barcelona and more. So come hit the road with us, no passport necessary.
I spent about half of last fall in Spain, taping television with Mario Batali, Gwyneth Paltrow and Claudia Bassols. Here's a preview of the show, which will air on public television this September.

What can make pot-stickers a minimalist dish? One approach is called takeout and is already quite common. The alternative is using the wrappers now sold in just about every supermarket.

New York City is starting an advertising campaign on Monday concentrated on pay phones in Times Square and Chinatown to educate tourists and residents about the social costs of counterfeit and pirated goods.

The consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton said early Friday that it would sell a majority stake of its government practice to the private equity firm Carlyle Group for $2.54 billion. The announcement came four months after DealBook reported that a potential deal with Carlyle, run by David Rubenstein, was in the works.

As someone who commutes by bicycle into Manhattan, I would normally applaud any scientific rationale for more bike lanes. But some calculations in the new issue of the Lancet make me uncomfortable. The authors argue that policies promoting cycling and walking are good for the planet because they could reduce obesity -- and obesity, the authors calculate, contributes to global warming.

What do video artists make of YouTube? Every minute, 10 hours of video are uploaded to the video-sharing site, which now shows hundreds of millions of videos each day. The place is a mess. Maybe artists should avoid it altogether.

The Court of Arbitration for Sport has issued a ruling allowing the double-amputee South African sprinter Oscar Pistorius to compete at the Beijing Olmypics, overturning an International Association of Athletics Federations ban that barred him from competing. The IAAF ruled in January that the carbon-fibre "Cheetah" blades he uses give Pistorius, who runs the 400-meter sprint, a technical edge unavailable to other runners.

James P. Rubin, a former State Department official in the Clinton administration, says John McCain is guilty of hypocrisy when he criticizes Barack Obama for being willing to talk with Hamas. For proof, in a Washington Post op-ed, Rubin brings up some comments McCain made in an interview during the economic forum at Davos, Switzerland, in 2006:

Fox's "American Idol" dominated another night of television ratings on Wednesday as the singing competition reduced its cast of would-be pop stars to two, David Archuleta and David Cook, who will compete in next week's finale.
The latest labor report indicates that the city's economy has remained relatively vibrant even as the rest of the state has continued to lose jobs, Patrick McGeehan reports.

The Hollywood Reporter: "'The Bachelor' will be looking for love all over again on VH1. The lifestyle cable network said Thursday it acquired the full library of ABC's reality competition series." VH1 has set network records with its own dating reality shows.
The Senate voted on Thursday to overturn new, looser media ownership restrictions in the 20 biggest U.S. cities, defying a White House threat to veto the measure.
John McCain, the presumptive G.O.P. nominee, is cleaning up some ethical entanglements after news outlets questioned his campaign's association to some questionable supporters.
General Electric on Friday confirmed that it is exploring a potential sale or spinoff of its appliances business, one of the oldest at the 120-year-old conglomerate.

Shares of Verso Paper, a company backed by private equity firm Apollo Management, fell 17 percent in their market debut Thursday. The company had already cut the number and expected price of shares to be sold.

CNET Networks surprised the market, and no doubt Jana Partners, with its announcement Thursday that it would be acquired by CBS. But the merger agreement filed by CNET on Thursday contains its own surprise. CNET has negotiated a rather unique provision that gives it more leeway than usual to find another, higher bidder. If it can.

Yahoo's chairman, Roy Bostock, rejected late Thursday accusations from the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn that the company's board had acted irrationally in turning down a $47.5 billion takeover offer from Microsoft and repeated that Yahoo remained open to a deal at the right price.

People on Wall Street seem to be vanishing overnight. Thousands are losing their jobs as hard-pressed banks cut deep. But while layoffs are nothing new in the financial industry, this round seems different: it is eerily quiet.
OVP Venture Partners is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year, but the Seattle venture firm apparently isn't slowing down as it gets on in years.
Goldman Sachs and Carl C. Icahn, it seems, will square off once more.
Activist hedge fund Jana Partners generated big gains on Thursday after CBS agreed to buy Internet news provider CNet Networks for $1.8 billion.
It is far too early to say whether Vikram Pandit will be a success as Citigroup's chief executive. But it is already clear that his performance as a hedge-fund manager is nothing to crow about.
Severstal is planning to sell $1.5 billion of bonds, according to media reports.

While Citigroup, Deutsche Bank and other investment banks purge themselves of billions in buyout loans, investors remain skittish about investing in the high-yield debt market, The New York Post reported.
Evercore Capital Partners has bought a majority stake in insurance broker Bollinger in a deal valued at $250 million, The Daily Deal reported citing unnamed sources.

BlackRock's assignment to manage a massive subprime portfolio from UBS is a sign that first buyers are returning to assets long considered too toxic to touch, and more similar deals may follow, Reuters reported.

Athletic shoe manufacturer Yue Yuen Industrial will spin-off its retail distribution business in China, assuming that its minority shareholders give it a nod of approval at a special general meeting next Tuesday.
Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, pushed banks on Thursday to keep raising capital in the aftermath of losses from the credit crisis to avert deeper damage to the economy.

Shares of BHP Billiton set a record high in Sydney, Australia on Friday, after a local newspaper reported that China has approached an Australian superannuation and investment fund to partner in a multibillion-dollar attempt to buy a 9 percent stake in the mining giant.
In a study, Pennsylvania ranked sixth in the nation in health care-focused venture-capital firms.
GrainCorp has offered to buy livestock feed maker Ridley for $390.5 million. The deal would allow eastern Australia's largest grain handler to gain 23 domestic grain mills and sales in North America.
Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has pulled out of the bidding in Royal Bank of Scotland's $13.6 billion auction for its British insurance business.

Prudential is among the parties eyeing Equitable Life's 7 billion pound with-profit fund, which is up for sale in what is expected to be the final restructuring of the troubled mutual, The Financial Times reported.

Morgan Stanley has begun a series of job cuts in London that could see at least 350 people let go. The Telegraph reported that the bank began cutting jobs on Wednesday, with the process expected to take some weeks as Morgan Stanley continues to restructure.
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is strapping on its hard hat.

It's a good time to be in the château and castle business, says a Monaco-based entrepreneur specializing in the market.

With thoroughbred racing praying for an accident-free Preakness and hoping a Triple Crown winner will take the public's mind off the industry's troubles, the time has come to tell the story of "The King and the Pygmy."
The New Jersey State Museum’s main building reopened in Trenton after four years of renovation.

In a lengthy column posted shortly after midnight on The Boston Herald Web site, John Tomase, The Herald's Patriots beat writer, explained how he blundered in his infamous Super Bowl walk-through article. How much damage did Tomase do? In a radio interview Thursday, the Patriots' president, Jonathan Kraft, said the article was a significant distraction for the team the day before its Super Bowl loss to the Giants (more on that below).

Stuck in the office, jonesing for hockey? No problem. Join the Times hockey blog on Friday afternoon at 1:00 Eastern Time for our description of the IIHF World Championship semifinal between Russia and Finland, LIVE, as it happens at Le Colisée in Quebec City. Then return to the Slap Shot blog at 5:00 Eastern for our LIVE play-by-play of the Canada-Sweden semifinal, described as it unfolds in Quebec City. Jeff Z. Klein will narrate the Russia-Finland match, Jeff Hale the Canada-Sweden contest.
Open air theater and festivals are very much part of the summer arts season here in England, despite the considerable vagaries of the weather. So get ready. Be an optimist. Here's your primer:
Location: Philadelphia
Christian Petzold’s enigmatic thriller “Yella” offers a surreal X-ray vision of cutthroat capitalism in 21st-century Germany.
Although “Sangre de Mi Sangre” exhibits a heartfelt connection with illegal immigrants, its myriad inconsistencies and strained plotting are frustrating.
An exuberant, exhilaratingly playful testament to being young and hungry, “Reprise” is a blast of unadulterated movie pleasure.
“Quantum Hoops” tells the story of the California Institute of Technology’s men’s basketball team, a farcical topic in the context of college sports.
“Prince Caspian” is quite a bit darker than “The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe,” both in look and in mood. It is also in some ways more satisfying.
“My Father My Lord” observes the severe family life of an ultra-Orthodox rabbi.
Joseph O’Neill’s stunning new novel set in post-9/11 New York provides a resonant meditation on the American Dream.
Democrats are widening the ideological divide in their own ranks and complicating their ability to find internal consensus.
The defending N.B.A. champion Spurs forced a Game 7 in a series in which the home team has won every game by at least 11 points.
Midfielder DaMarcus Beasley, sidelined by a knee injury since November, was among 33 players on a preliminary United States roster announced for exhibition games during the next month.
An Internal Affairs Bureau sergeant bluntly advised a New York City detective suspected of being involved with illegal drugs on how to avoid investigators.
For the fourth consecutive game, a Rays starter yet to celebrate a 27th birthday stymied the Yankees, and with Thursday’s loss New York dropped to last in the A.L. East.
The defiance, contrarian nature and competitive fire of the new Knicks coach is rooted in atmosphere of the kitchen table of his youth, where debates were lively and opinions mandatory.
Berkshire Hathaway, the investment company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, took advantage of prices driven down by the credit crisis and the slowing American economy.

A film review on May 7 about “Battle for Haditha,” which looks at the killing of 24 Iraqi civilians by United States marines in the city of Haditha in November 2005, referred incorrectly to some of the evidence in the case. According to marines’ testimony in legal proceedings, Iraqi men shot and killed in one house were armed. It has not been established that “no weapons were found in the houses” where Iraqis were killed.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a string of weeklong antiwar marches in upstate New York, culminating at Fort Drum on Saturday, misstated, in some copies, the number of years since the war in Iraq began. It started five years ago, in March 2003, not six years ago.

An article on Saturday about Senator John McCain’s criticism of Senator Barack Obama’s Middle East policy incompletely described Mr. Obama’s position on negotiating with the leaders of countries, including Iran, with which the United States currently has little contact. While Mr. Obama and his aides have indeed described various conditions and limitations on such negotiations, Mr. Obama himself, in a Democratic debate in July 2007, also said he would be willing "to meet separately, without precondition" with the leaders of Iran, Syria, Venezuela, Cuba and North Korea.

The On Education column on May 7, about the impact of the planned closing of Lafayette High School in Brooklyn’s Bath Beach neighborhood and at John Dewey High School, just to the south at Dewey, misspelled the surname of a student at Dewey who discussed overcrowding at the school. She is Elizabeth Piligromova, not Piligromava.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the retirement announcement by Justine Henin, the world’s top-ranked women’s tennis player, misstated the name of the sport’s governing body. It is the Women’s Tennis Association, not the World Tennis Association.

An article on Wednesday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s victory in the West Virginia primary overstated the size of her campaign debt. The total debt is approximately $20 million and includes $11 million in personal loans from Mrs. Clinton; the $20 million is not in addition to those loans.

An article in the special Well section on Tuesday about foot health described incorrectly peripheral artery disease, which reduces blood circulation to the feet. The disease involves narrowing of arteries in the legs, not veins.

An obituary on Tuesday about Dr. Murray Jarvik, whose research helped lead to the nicotine patch to fight smoking addiction, misstated the year in which he learned he had lung cancer, although he was a nonsmoker. It was 1992, not 1982.
FRONT PAGE.

An obituary on Thursday about the Israeli industrialist Benjamin Gaon misstated the amount raised last year by the initial public offering of Gaon Holdings. It was $71 million, not $71 billion. The obituary also misstated the given name of his surviving sister. She is Klila Armon, not Kalia.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a skirmish between rival ice cream truck drivers outside a school building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan referred incorrectly in some copies to the school that shares the building with Public School 9. It is the Anderson School — not the Sarah Anderson School, which is an alternate name for P.S. 9.

SAAR--Joseph, 88, died at home on May 15, 2008, from cancer. He was a psychotherapist in Manhattan, with an office on Central Park West. He lived in White Plains and is survived by his wife of 63 years, Bobbie, with whom he traveled the world. He is also survived by his sons David and Robert, his daughter, Carol; and his five grandchildren, Steven, Karen, Leslie, Brian and Eric. Joe loved theater, Chopin, books, movies, chocolate, Paris, French bread, and a good joke. Above all, he loved Bobbie. He was a wise and compassionate therapist, a loyal and generous friend, a devoted husband and a proud, loving father and grandfather. The family will welcome visitors at Robert's home, 6 Grey Rock Terrace, Irvington, NY. on Saturday, June 14, 2008 from 1 to 6pm.
