THOMPSON--James. Dr. James C. Thompson passed away on May 9th at his home in Galveston, Texas. Dr. Thompson --known as the consummate academic surgeon, role model and mentor --was Chair of the Department of Surgery of the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston from 1970 to 1995. In recognition of his extraordinary dedication and leadership, he was elected President of the American Surgical Association, the American College of Surgeons, the Society for Surgical Chairmen, and the Southern Surgical Association. In 1996, the American College of Surgeons presented him its highest honor, the Distinguished Service Award, and he received the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Society of University Surgeons in 2006. This March, UTMB's Department of Surgery established the James C. Thompson MD Distinguished Chair in Surgery to honor Dr. Thompson's contributions to the Department and to UTMB. Dr. Thompson's work took him to medical and educational institutions throughout the world. He served for brief periods as a visiting professor at over 200 medical schools and hospitals. He was the US-USSR Health Exchange Professor in 1973 and was named Honorary Professor for Life at the University of Beijing in 1991. Dr. Thompson is survived by his long time companion Bebe Jensen (Salt Lake City); his children, Patricia Thompson (Atlanta), Jan Thompson Brown (Austin), Gayle Thompson Crocker (Corpus Christi, TX), James C. Thompson, Jr. (Houston), John W. Thompson (College Station, TX), and his step daughter, Laura Fargas (Washington, DC). He is also survived by seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. A memorial service will be held at UTMB in Galveston on Monday, May 19, 2008 at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

FINKEL--Coleman, passed on May 14th. Dearest father to Andrew, loving brother to Raphael Ben Yosef. Former First Lieutenant USMC, Founder and President of The Coleman Center. Services will be held Sunday, May 18th, 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St.

DANCE PARADE Attention all hoofers, swingers, tappers, pop-and-lockers, tangoers, balletomanes, breakers and roller-discoers: the Dance Parade will shimmy through the streets of downtown Manhattan on Saturday. Created last year to promote and unify the dance styles of different cultures and focus attention on the city's cabaret laws, which require proper licensing for any kind of rhythmic movement, the parade is expected to draw thousands of spectators along the route down Broadway and through the East Village, said Mahayana Landowne, an organizer. The celebration will culminate in a party in Tompkins Square Park, where many of the more than 100 dance groups from the Knicks City Dancers to an Albanian folkloric ensemble to the GrooveHoops, an artsy Hula-Hoop squad, will perform. There will also be free lessons and some site-specific choreography in and around the park, which should make for good brunch conversation in the neighborhood's cafes. At last year's event, above, part of the fun was watching disparate techniques merge, as spangled belly dancers gave lessons to zoot-suited Lindy hoppers, and vice versa. Experiencing it is even better.

EDGERTON--Malcolm, Jr. Malcolm James Edgerton, Jr., of Stamford, CT died on Monday, May 12, 2008, in Stamford. Born in New York City, son of the late Edna Anna Fischer and Malcolm James Edgerton, he was 88. Mr. Edgerton graduated from Groton, Yale and NYU Law School. He served with the US Navy during World War II and was an attorney and partner with White and Case LLP in New York. He was a board member and past president of the Stamford Museum and Nature Center; board member of Edwin Gould Services for Children, Edwin Gould Foundation, Stamford Community Foundation, Fairfield Community Foundation, Stamford Health Foundation, Kaiser Health Plan of the Northeast; board member and chair of New Canaan County School and past chair of the Yale Alumni Fund. He is survived by his wife, Jane Lowe Jackson; four children, Elizabeth, Adele, Anne and Malcolm; three stepchildren, Frances, Diana and Patten; seven grandchildren and seven step-grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister, Janet E. Lanman of Bethesda, MD. He is predeceased by his first wife, Adele Pleasance Edgerton and his sister, Edna Fischer Edgerton. A private service will be held in the chapel at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien for family and invited guests with a memorial service to be held at St Luke's on Saturday, June 14, 2008 at 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Stamford Museum and Nature Center, 39 Scofieldtown Rd, Stamford, CT 06903. EDGERTON--Malcolm J. The Board of Directors of the Abelard Foundation and the entire Wells family mourn the loss of our trustee and dear friend, Malcolm J. Edgerton. We extend our condolences to Malcolm's wife Jane and to the entire family. We will sorely miss Malcolm's wise counsel, from which our family benefited for decades.

JENNIFER JONES RETROSPECTIVE Among the celluloid dream girls manufactured by Hollywood in the 1940s, Jennifer Jones occupies a celestial niche. Beginning with her first major feature, ''The Song of Bernadette,'' in which she played a saintly French peasant who has a vision of the Virgin Mary, the character she represented on the screen was a spiritually exalted being who kept part of herself in reserve. Even when Ms. Jones went notoriously down and dirty to play Pearl Chavez, a sex-crazed half-Indian woman in ''Duel in the Sun,'' right, you had the titillating sense of a lady playing a tramp. (The opposite could be said of Lana Turner in dignified upscale roles.) These polarities are suggested by the title of the Film Society of Lincoln Center's retrospective of Ms. Jones's movies, ''Saint and Sinner: The Tempestuous Career of Jennifer Jones,'' at the Walter Reade Theater. Even as she crawled through the dirt, you still had a sense of her as the abstract embodiment of ideal femininity, 1940s style: a beautiful, empathetic trophy who was fundamentally untouchable.

FOR CHILDREN ACTION/ABSTRACTION FAMILY DAY (Sunday) There will be plenty of action and abstraction at this event, and not just because it is inspired by ''Action/Abstraction: Pollock, de Kooning, and American Art, 1940-1976,'' the new exhibition at the Jewish Museum. Children will be very active -- they can make collages of mixed mediums in an art workshop; use rollers, brushes, sponges and other tools for painting; and join a family collaborative sculpture project. The results, of course, will be abstractions. Noon to 4 p.m., 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3337, thejewishmuseum.org. Free with admission: $12; $10 for 65+; $7.50 for students; free for under 12 and members.

CHILDREN'S FESTIVAL Young adventure fans are still flocking to theaters to see the exploits of Iron Man. But this weekend he will have some competition from a mythical hero not typically encountered in comic books or at the movies: Mouse Woman (who is, by the way, not the nemesis of Cat Woman). ''The Mouse Woman is a magical little creature who gives magical advice to the male heroes of our stories,'' the artist David Boxley said. ''She warns them of the monster that's lurking around. Some people listen, and some don't.''

'BRUCE HIGH QUALITY FOUNDATION: THE RETROSPECTIVE' According to the mission statement (short version) on its Web site, the Bruce High Quality Foundation collective (named after a sign on its building in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn) ''was created to foster an alternative to everything.'' Now after three or four years of fostering, the six Cooper Union graduates who form the collective have decided that it's time to sum things up. ''The Retrospective,'' the collective's first show in a commercial New York gallery, demonstrates an implicitly satiric, reactive style.

A few weeks back, I wrote an article about the comedian Irwin Corey, who is 93. His agent and manager, Irvin Arthur, called last week and told me that another one of his clients, also with a long career as a comedian, would be performing on Saturday night at B. B. King's Blues Club and Grill in Times Square. I went and found Mort Sahl performing for a packed house that included Woody Allen and Dick Cavett, two of his biggest fans. Mr. Cavett introduced Mr. Sahl, who then took the stage without a copy of The New York Times, which was one of his onstage habits, allowing him to riff on the day's news.

So the first thing Ikea wants you to know: Customers will not be allowed to line up outside the new Ikea in Red Hook, Brooklyn, until 48 hours before the grand opening, which is scheduled for 9 a.m. on June 18. That may seem like a bizarre warning, except that a man showed up two and a half weeks before the opening of a West Sacramento Ikea store in California in 2006, and another person showed up two weeks early in Tempe, Ariz., in 2004. (In Brooklyn, there will be giveaways to early arrivals on that opening Wednesday, but not to the very first few people.)

SCHNEIDER--Leo, of North Salem, NY died on May 14, 2008 at his home. He was 92. Mr. Schneider was a science teacher, author of numerous science books for children, and science editor for the Book of Knowledge. He was educated at City College and Hunter College. He earned a Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Biology. He is survived by his loving wife, Rhea, nephews and nieces, as well as many wonderful friends.

Nestled in the foothills on a quarter acre, this 3,426-square-foot house is at the top of a cul-de-sac. The house has views of Superstition Mountain from the inside and a backyard. There is a heated pool and a spa with a waterfall grotto and a swim-up bar. Agent: Carol Kingman, Weichert Realtors Lake Realty; (480) 982-7370; www.lakerealty-az.com.

AMERICAN BALLET THEATER On June 3 audiences will head to the Metropolitan Opera House to see the new Twyla Tharp ballet, ''Rabbit and Rogue.'' Such big premieres aside, American Ballet Theater's spring season belongs to its stars, beginning with the opening-night gala on Monday. Among the pas de deux performances will be Nina Ananiashvili and Angel Corella in ''Giselle''; Gillian Murphy and Ethan Stiefel in ''Don Quixote''; and Julie Kent and José Manuel Carreño in ''Onegin.'' David Hallberg and Herman Cornejo will have solo turns in more story-ballet snippets, while the great Russian ballerina Diana Vishneva will perform ''The Dying Swan,'' a Fokine ballet so short that it might as well be an excerpt. Star-packed opening nights are the norm, but this gala will also feature several Ballet Theater alumni. Kathleen Moore, Martine van Hamel, Bonnie Mathis, Kevin McKenzie and Victor Barbee will all perform in the revival of the 1938 ballet ''Judgment of Paris,'' shown as part of a centennial tribute to the choreographer Antony Tudor. Most of that tribute will take place in the fall, at the company's annual City Center season.

Our hearts are broken. Services to be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Woodbury today at 12 noon. Donations: Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Fund or Manhasset Women's Coalition against Breast Cancer, P.O. Box 1007 Manhasset, NY 11030.

TOMPKINS--Frederic Powers Rumson, New Jersey, age 95, on May 17, 2008 died May 13, 2008. Beloved husband of Blanche S. for 58 years. Father of Frederic F., R. Clayton, Christopher P., Evelyn W. PRUNTY--Richard Pratt, erudite, sesquipedalian, ebullient, chaetophorous, neo-luddite bibliophile --above all, beloved father, brother, and friend. We mourn the loss and celebrate the life of this scholarly, enthusiastic, bearded, polysyllabic-word-using, technology-doubting lover of books and knowledge. Pratt was a dedicated educator, an avid golfer, a political enthusiast, a committed social activist, an undiscriminating collector and a life-long Democrat. Raised on a farm in Oxford, West Virginia, he was educated at West Virginia University and the University of Massachusetts. He worked as a science teacher and later a guidance counselor in Enfield, Connecticut. For 30 years, he lived in the historic Hill-McKnight neighborhood of Springfield, MA. He passed away at age 71 in New York on May 6, 2008, surrounded by his children. Left to look up their own words are Jennifer Prunty (NYC), Meeghan Prunty Edelstein and Steve Edelstein (New York), Adam Prunty (Massachusetts) and Jason Prunty (Oregon); his grandchildren Julian Thomas, Eliza Ruby, Gabriel Pratt, and Julia Rose; and his brothers and sisters in West Virginia and Ohio.

GOLD--Rita Weinstein. Teachers College, Columbia University mourns the passing of Rita Gold, honored Alumna, educator, friend of the College, generous benefactor, and passionate believer in the potential of children and all human beings. Her legacy will live on through the Rita Gold Early Childhood Center, the Rita Gold Scholarship Fund, the wonderful songs she wrote to help young children with behavior, self-esteem and maturation, and most of all through the many students, both young and young at heart, whom she taught, mentored, and exhorted to ''chase your dream''. We offer our condolences to Herb, her loving husband of 66 years, and all who were touched by her life. Susan H. Fuhrman, President John W. Hyland, Jr., William D. Rueckert, Laurie M. Tisch, Board of Trustees GOLD--Rita. A thoughtful and profoundly caring woman who dedicated herself to a world in which education and music are paramount. A man whose former girlfriend left him for an African-American man pleaded guilty in federal court Thursday to sending more than 200 letters threatening to kill prominent African-Americans he believed to be involved in interracial relationships. The man, David A. Tuason, 46, of Pepper Pike, Ohio, began sending letters 20 years ago and sent his last threat, by e-mail, to the singer Al Jarreau in February.

RENÉ PAPE The Act II monologue from Mussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov'' is one of the most powerful scenes in the opera. The superb German bass René Pape will illuminate the desperation of this tormented czar, racked with guilt and doubt, when he sings it on Sunday during a concert performance with the Met Orchestra, led by the dynamic Valery Gergiev. Mr. Pape has not yet sung Boris onstage in New York, although local audiences enjoyed a glimpse of his prowess in the role during a concert performance of the ''Coronation Scene'' at the 2006 Richard Tucker gala, above, in which Mr. Pape's regal bearing and sonorous voice evocatively conveyed the czar's foreboding.

My Sunday column is again from the Gansu and Qinghai areas that are mostly Tibetan, as was Thursday's column. This time I try to focus on the need for a negotiated settlement of the Tibetan question, and the risk that if the stalemate continues Tibetan areas will lose their traditional character and be overwhelmed by Han migration, while Han Chinese areas will face terrorism from Tibetans. I think China, the Dalai Lama and the U.S. are all partly to blame for a failure to pursue serious diplomacy on this issue.

ANNAPOLIS, Md. -- Anyone who has followed lacrosse over the years can't help but have noticed the abundance of uber-preppy names that filter through the sport. (Two that jumped out at me Sunday were Maryland's Ryder Bohlander and Johns Hopkins Orry Michael.)

The Red Bulls (3-1-3, 12 points) entered Saturday night's game against the Kansas City Wizards (3-3-2, 11 points) on a four-game unbeaten streak, and left with a five-game unbeaten streak. The Red Bulls are one of two teams in Major League Soccer (Columbus is the other) with only one loss. Kansas City came into the game on a two-game losing streak, and left without a victory in its last three.

We're back again, blogging the 133rd Preakness Stakes "live" from The Times building in Midtown Manhattan. Can Big Brown claim the second leg of the Triple Crown? Will all of the horses come out of the race unharmed? We sure hope so. As in the Derby, we'll be getting updates from Joe Drape and our other contributors throughout the day. Send in some questions. Here's a quick follow up to a story that I wrote for Sunday's paper regarding the Duke men's and women's lacrosse teams blossoming rapport with the Ronald McDonald House on the Duke campus. The relationship began when the new Duke coach John Danowski made community service a mandatory part of his players' schedules last year. This season, the women's team joined the men's team in volunteering there.

Big Brown absolutely dominated a weak Preakness field. The acceleration he showed when Kent Desormeaux let him loose was something we have not seen in a long time. He won under an easy handride. All this horse has done so far is win, and win easily.

The Pimlico racetrack opened this morning from 5:30 to 6:00 a.m. to allow the Preakness horses to get some light exercise if necessary. For most races, trainers do not train a horse on race day. Big races are different and it makes sense sometimes to take a little edge off the horses so they don't get overly excited during the long day waiting for the big race.

Willie Randolph greeted reporters at his news conference this morning by telling them -- in jest? -- that he had a bodyguard wearing a bulletproof vest stationed toward the back of the room. Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the surprising early success of the Florida Marlins misstated, in some editions, the scheduled length of their series this week with the Cincinnati Reds. It was four games, not three. (They played only three games because the finale on Thursday was postponed because of rain.).

An article on Thursday about Hollywood’s summer movies, including “Sex and the City,” using information provided by New Line Cinema, which made the movie, misstated its release date. It is May 30, not May 28. (On the Hollywood calendar, “summer” movies include those released in May.).

The San Isidro Tilantongo Journal article on Tuesday, about the successful use of old pre-Hispanic farming techniques in the barren Mixteca highlands of Mexico’s Oaxaca State, misstated, in some copies, the three-to-four-fold rise in crop yields in eight villages where the techniques have been applied. The yields have grown to between one and one and a half metric tons per hectare, or 16 to 24 bushels per acre — not 100 to 150 bushels per acre.
A chart on Friday sizing up the field for the Preakness Stakes misstated the distance of the race. It is 1 3/16 miles, not 1 3/4.
An article in some editions on Friday about the comedian Mort Sahl was accompanied by an incorrect picture in some copies. The photograph was of the comedian Shelley Berman, not Mr. Sahl.
Jason Werth homered in his first three at-bats and tied a Philadelphia Phillies record by driving in eight runs in a 10-3 victory against the visiting Toronto Blue Jays on Friday night.

A pop music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about Laura Veirs and Liam Finn, at the Bowery Ballroom next Thursday, misidentified Mr. Finn’s nationality. He is from New Zealand, not Australia. The entry also referred imprecisely to the record label of his solo debut album, “I’ll Be Lightning.” While Independent Records is the label in Ireland, in the United States the album is on Yep Roc Records.

Ben Stiller has found another hallowed institution to flee. The sequel to “Night at the Museum,” the 2006 hit in which he played a security guard trapped in the American Museum of Natural History when its exhibits come alive, will be shot at the Smithsonian’s National Air and Space Museum, below. “Night at the Museum II: Escape From the Smithsonian,” scheduled for release in May 2009, is the first commercial film for which the museum has allowed itself to be used. “The popularity of the first movie convinced us that this is an innovative way to capture the imagination and curiosity of a young audience,” Richard Kurin, the museum’s acting under secretary for history, art and culture, wrote in a memo that was posted on the blog Modern Art Notes at ArtsJournal.com. The cast includes Owen Wilson and Amy Adams. On-location shooting was scheduled to be completed next week.

Sharon F. Patton has resigned after five years as the director of the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of African Art, effective in December. In a statement, Ms. Patton said she had achieved much of what she set out to accomplish, but she also nodded to the appointment of a new leadership at the Smithsonian. (G. Wayne Clough, the president of Georgia Tech, is to assume the post of Smithsonian secretary, or chief executive, on July 1.) “It seems to be the right time to leave,” Ms. Patton, 64, said. Under her leadership the museum’s collection of more than 9,000 African art objects grew to include the Walt Disney-Tishman collection of 500 pieces from nearly every country in Africa. She also increased programming for children and promoted contemporary artists. The Smithsonian has been through considerable turmoil over the last year and a half. Its previous secretary, Lawrence M. Small, resigned over revelations that he spent the institution’s money on luxuries like private jets. In a report on Thursday, the Government Accountability Office cited recent progress at the institution but said it still needed better internal controls.

One of the world’s largest collections of comic art has found a home in Columbus, Ohio. According to The Associated Press, the Cartoon Research Library at Ohio State University will soon exhibit about 200,000 works from the International Museum of Cartoon Art, founded by the cartoonist Mort Walker (“Beetle Bailey”) in Greenwich, Conn., in 1974. The museum, most recently located in a villa in Boca Raton, Fla., was $2 million in debt and closed in 2002. Plans to have its memorabilia — including a Walt Disney storyboard for an early Mickey Mouse cartoon and original drawings for “Dick Tracy,” above — moved to Yale University or be displayed at the Empire State Building fizzled. But Ohio State has plans for the sketches, films, figurines, toys and collectibles, which will double its existing collection, the library’s curator, Lucy Shelton Caswell, told The Associated Press. Ms. Caswell, a former board member of the International Museum of Cartoon Art, said new space was being sought for the collection, expected to go on display in the summer.

A panel of eight men and four women will decide the fate of R. Kelly, the R&B star whose much-delayed trial on child pornography charges is to begin Tuesday in Chicago. During jury selection, which ended Thursday, the defense accused the prosecution of eliminating some African-Americans from the pool of candidates, while the prosecution countered that it had also eliminated some white males, The Chicago Sun-Times reported. The final group of jurors includes an African-American woman married to a Baptist preacher, a young white woman who is an aspiring police officer, a 68-year-old Romanian immigrant and a recent college graduate who was once arrested for marijuana possession. Mr. Kelly was indicted on June 5, 2002, after the appearance of a videotape that prosecutors say shows him having sex with a girl as young as 13. He has pleaded not guilty. On Friday, the judge, Vincent Gaughan, rejected a motion that news organizations have access to sealed court transcripts and records of the case.

Lou Reed will take a break from promoting his forthcoming concert film, “Berlin,” to host a two-hour radio show on the Sirius Satellite Network. Starting Saturday on Channel 70, “Lou Reed’s New York Shuffle” will broadcast a mix of rock, country and jazz, the kind of programming that Mr. Reed said he has enjoyed for years. He will share host duties with the producer Hal Willner, who was the music director of “Berlin.” The staged concert, based on Mr. Reed’s 1973 album of the same name, was taped at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn in December 2006. The film version, directed by Julian Schnabel, is to open in New York and Los Angeles on July 18. Requests for Mr. Reed’s radio show will soon be taken at loureed.com.

During the removal of an installation at the National Gallery in London, “Marcia,” a 500-year-old painting by the 16th-century master Domenico Beccafumi, slipped out of its frame, causing one of its three large panels to break away from the other two. The Art Newspaper, which reported the incident, called it “one of the most serious handling accidents known to have occurred in a U.K. museum in living memory.” The painting, one of three by Beccafumi depicting classical heroines, was part of the “Renaissance Siena” exhibition, which closed early this year. The damage was not made public until recently, when minutes of a National Gallery trustee meeting on Feb. 8 were posted online. Museum authorities ordered an investigation which is still going on, the publication reported, but the panels were restored immediately and the painting is now on public view. “Under present lighting in the gallery, the vertical strip of damage can hardly be seen when looked at straight on although it is just visible when the painting is viewed from the left side,” Martin Bailey wrote in The Art Newspaper.

Finales of “CSI” and “Without a Trace” lifted CBS into first place in the ratings on Thursday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “CSI” attracted 17.7 million viewers to CBS at 9 p.m., the night’s largest audience, while “Without a Trace” won the 10 p.m. hour with 14.5 million viewers. Despite CBS’s edge in total viewers, the network ranked third for the night among adults 18 to 49, just behind NBC, which got a boost from the season finales of “My Name Is Earl” at 8 (7.1 million), “The Office” at 9 (8.1 million) and “ER” at 10 (8.4 million). ABC, trailed by both networks in that demographic, broadcast the night’s top two shows among the 18-to-49 set, “Grey’s Anatomy” at 9 and “Lost” at 10, which delivered 15.2 million and 11.4 million total viewers respectively. Fox finished fourth overall.

On the Rings blog at nytimes.com, readers reacted to the news Friday that Oscar Pistorius, a double-amputee runner from South Africa, may compete in the Beijing Games using blade-like prosthetics called Cheetahs. Here are excerpts, condensed and edited, from the responses.

KAUFMAN--Arthur S., of Livingston, NJ, on May 15, 2008, at age 92. Beloved husband of Harriet for 61 years, loving father of Richard, Jonathan, and Jeanne and father-in-law of Carole and Bob; brother of Bernie. Arthur was born and brought up in New York City, graduated with a Master's Degree in Education from City College, New York, and served as a Master Sergeant in the U.S. Army during World War II. He created the successful import/export firm Arkay International, which he ran for more than 50 years. Arthur was an active member of Temple Beth Shalom of Livingston, where he served for many years on the Ritual Committee. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday, May 18, at 1:15pm, at Bernheim, Apter, Kreitzman Funeral Home in Livingston.

HALBFINGER--Sara, 94, died peacefully in her home in Miami Beach, FL on May 16, 2008. Devoted wife of the late Abraham. Loving mother of Martin (Lynn), Ruth Posner (Monte) (both deceased), Phillip (deceased) (Ann). Adored grandmother of Marla (Scott) Hyndman, Felicia Posner, Bonnie and Caroline Halbfinger. Special greatgrandmother of Melissa and Justin Hyndman. Cherished aunt of Edmund (Marianne) Chanover, Reina (Oded) Leibel and Aliza (Amnon) Kolodney. Her strength was an inspiration to her family and community. Funeral service Sunday, May 18, 2pm at Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 91st St. HALBFINGER--Sara. We mourn the loss of Sara, mother of Martin Halbfinger. Our heartfelt condolences to Marty and Lynn, granddaughters Bonnie and Carly and their entire family. Charles and Judy Temel, Erica, Laura, Dan

GOLD--Rita Weinstein. Teachers College, Columbia University mourns the passing of Rita Gold, honored Alumna, educator, friend of the College, generous benefactor, and passionate believer in the potential of children and all human beings. Her legacy will live on through the Rita Gold Early Childhood Center, the Rita Gold Scholarship Fund, the wonderful songs she wrote to help young children with behavior, self-esteem and maturation, and most of all through the many students, both young and young at heart, whom she taught, mentored, and exhorted to ''chase your dream''. We offer our condolences to Herb, her loving husband of 66 years, and all who were touched by her life. Susan H. Fuhrman, President John W. Hyland, Jr., William D. Rueckert, Laurie M. Tisch, Board of Trustees
WHITE--Rowenna Wight. May 17, 1980 called back September 2, 1998. ''She for whom the sun doth shine.'' Remembered on her 28th birthday by her mother in Egypt

A light rain was falling when the second round of the $2 million Sybase Classic began at 7:15 a.m. at the Upper Montclair Country Club in Clifton, N.J. Soon, the rain was steady and sometimes pelting, the course became soggy and greens were flooded. At 3 p.m., the officials called off the round, then decided that the scores, all partial, would be thrown out. That has happened before on the L.P.G.A. Tour, most recently in 2005 at Williamsburg, Va. The 72-hole Sybase Classic was shortened to 54 holes. The second round was rescheduled for Saturday, with the final round Sunday. After the first round on Thursday, Annika Sorenstam, Rachel Hetherington and Song-Hee Kim were tied for the lead at five-under-par 67. Lorena Ochoa, the two-time defending champion, was among six players at 68.

AUDIO: A SECOND CHANCE FOR PAROLEES Voices of parolees, inmates, a parole officer and program directors who discuss the new effort in Kansas to make parole more effective and useful. Parole in Kansas was once enforced with a spirit that officials recall, only half-jokingly, as ''trail 'em, nail 'em, jail 'em,'' overfilling the prisons but doing little to rehabilitate offenders. Today, the state is a leader of a spreading national effort to reduce reincarcerations.

(Cinemax) YOU KILL ME (2007) Ben Kingsley, left, plays a boozy hit man from Buffalo who is sent to dry out in San Francisco, where he acquires an A.A. sponsor (Luke Wilson), a job sprucing up corpses at a funeral home and a mouthy girlfriend (Téa Leoni). Now he's about to return home to settle some scores, and he's got help. From the grave, Albert Einstein poured gasoline late Thursday on the culture wars between science and religion. A letter Einstein wrote in 1954 to Eric Gutkind, a German philosopher, in which he described the Bible as ''pretty childish'' and scoffed at the notion that the Jews could be a chosen people, sold for $404,000 at an auction in London. That was 25 times the presale estimate.

Senator John McCain chased after the youth vote in two cameo appearances on Saturday Night Live by joking about his age - he is 71 - and sparing viewers the sound of him crooning a medley of Barbra Streisand songs, as he did when he hosted the comedy show in 2002.

Keith Bradsher and Andrew Martin have a sobering story in The Times showing declines in funding for agricultural development assistance and basic research even as the world's poorest regions face spiking prices and shortages of basic foods.

The Olympic champion Aaron Peirsol held off Michael Phelps in the 200 backstroke in 1 minute 55.81 seconds to win at the Santa Clara (Calif.) Grand Prix. Phelps, who has never beaten Peirsol in the backstroke, was second in 1:55.84. Peirsol’s time was the fastest in the world this year.

A Virginia Tech football recruit who led his high school team to consecutive state championships is facing felony drug charges. The recruit, Peter Rose, and six other students were arrested and charged after what the police said was an undercover operation at Amherst High School. Rose, 18, is charged with two counts of distribution of marijuana, a misdemeanor, and two counts of distribution of drugs within 1,000 feet of a school, a felony.
A small airplane crashed in a wooded area near an airport in Ocean County, N.J., on Saturday, killing two passengers and critically injuring the plane’s other two occupants.

Niklas Backstrom made 36 saves and Antti Pihlstrom and Janne Niskala scored in the first period for Finland, which beat Sweden, 4-0, for the bronze medal at the world championship in Quebec City. Afterward, Finland’s Teemu Selanne announced his retirement from international play, but said he might still play in the N.H.L. Canada and Russia play for the gold medal Sunday.

Nwankwo Kanu scored in the first half for Portsmouth to beat Cardiff, 1-0, and win the F.A. Cup final for the first time since 1939. Kanu took advantage of a fumble by Cardiff goalkeeper Peter Enckelman in the 37th minute to give the team manager Harry Redknapp his first major trophy in 25 years of coaching.

Andy Bean birdied the final hole to take a one-shot lead over Mike Goodes heading into the final round of the Regions Charity Classic, a Champions Tour event in Hoover, Ala. Loren Roberts and Denis Watson each shot 66 and were two behind.

Charles Howell shot a five-under-par 67 to take a one-shot lead into the final round of the AT&T Classic. He dropped to 13 under after 54 holes at T.P.C. Sugarloaf in Duluth, Ga. Kenny Perry shot a 69 and is alone in second. Jonathan Byrd, who led by three strokes entering the round, shot a 73 and was two shots back.

Bradley Dredge had seven birdies in a six-under 66 to take a one-stroke lead after the third round of the Irish Open in Adare. Dredge, who lost to Padraig Harrington in a playoff here last year, had birdies in 6 of the last 10 holes. Richard Finch was one shot back after a 65.
Lyon won its seventh consecutive French league title by beating Auxerre, 3-1. Lyon finished ahead of Bordeaux, which managed only a 2-2 draw against Lens in its final game of the season.

Maria Sharapova pulled out of the Italian Open semifinals in Rome because of a strained left calf. In Sunday’s final, Jelena Jankovic will meet Alize Cornet, a qualifier who defeated Anna Chakvetadze, 3-6, 6-4, 6-3.

The Evening Hours column last Sunday misidentified the guest shown with Senator John McCain at the Time magazine party on May 8. last great / (last& gra\t&) / commonly used phrase signifying a place that has retained a rare quality, e.g., “I just had the most amazing journey in Namibia, one of Africa’s last great wildernesses.” An erstwhile cliché, it has taken on new significance as travelers become ever more aware of environmental and cultural fragility, as in, “Ladakh is the last great stronghold of Himalayan Buddhism — like an unfallen Tibet.”.
The Vaucluse is the beating heart of southern France: beautiful, proud, prosperous and much more complex than meets the eye.

Many affluent travelers used to consider a private villa and an after-hours museum tour the ultimate vacation — a way to seal oneself off from the world in a bubble of luxury. But as a cult of authenticity has taken hold among global nomads, the impulse to engage has replaced the desire to escape. And they want more than just superficial encounters with “the natives”; they want their culture unfiltered. What the locavore movement did for food — giving the heirloom tomato from down the road more cachet than an ounce of beluga — this new humanism has done for travel.

With her boyish platinum mop and her penchant for wearing leopard-print pants with silver oxford shoes, the model Agyness Deyn is used to stopping people dead in their tracks. But recently it’s her G4530 Wild West Sweethearts guitar, from the Gretsch Americana limited-edition series, that’s been getting all the attention. “I carry it on my back everywhere I go,” she explains. “When I’m wearing it, people just come up to me and start chatting about it. I get to meet some cool people that way.” For Deyn, who is a new face for Shiseido and a Burberry favorite, crisscrossing the globe is all in a day’s work. In fact, she got her acoustic shredder last year in Japan, a surprise gift picked up by her boyfriend Josh Hubbard (of the band the Paddingtons). The guitar’s compact size makes it easy for lugging on the road, and the campy aesthetic perfectly riffs on Deyn’s own Paris-meets-Lower East Side style. “I love the whole Wild West thing. It reminds me of a Sailor Jerry tattoo,” she says. But Deyn’s love for her little red six-string is no passing fancy. “I think I’ll have it forever.”.

Style Map | Barcelona: Once a neglected tangle of narrow streets around the Picasso Museum and the church of Santa Maria del Mar, the Born district has slowly shed its gritty image to become Barcelona’s version of the West Village. The cafe-lined squares and bosky lanes are filled with young local talent offering their own bold, distinctly Spanish take on fashion, design and cuisine. DALE FUCHS.

Trends don’t take hold easily in Vienna. This is a city charmed by its own traditions — a seventh-generation bootmaker, an Adolf Loos-designed haberdashery. Still, hats are suddenly huge in town, most obviously in the Museumsquartier, where the cool kids are all rocking headgear. But this is no passing fancy for trucker caps or a Pete Doherty trilby. Driving the craze is the 105-year-old hatmaker Mühlbauer, which has lately been revitalized by the fourth-generation owner Klaus Mühlbauer’s clever designs and savvy marketing (Elfie Semotan shot his current ad campain). His newsboy caps, perforated leather fedoras and unisex turbans have become hipster staples. Mühlbauer. Seilergasse 10; 011-43-53-352-6912; muehlbauer.at. MARKUS EBNER.

No longer just for beach totes and barnyards, straw has become a summer favorite of designers looking to stay cool. Witness Salvatore Ferragamo’s retro tote ($650; ferragamo.com), Tom Ford’s posh panama hat ($790; tomford.com) and Anya Hindmarch’s oversize clutch adorned with amethyst ($370; anyahindmarch.com). Thinking outside the picnic basket, Lanvin has made a pair of raffia platform sandals with an ostrich heel ($1,435; lanvin.com). And the French designer Alexis Mabille has even raised a crop of.

A world apart from the seedy foot-rub joints on every Beijing block, Zenspa occupies a hushed courtyard residence in the Chaoyang district. Inside the colorfully lacquered structure, the Hong Kong interior designer David Ng has created a modern retreat where treatments like a fresh milk bath and gold-leaf scrub are administered in suites arranged around a reflecting pool. House 1, 8A Xiaowuji Lu; 011-86-10-8731-2530; www.zenspa.com.cn.

When in Rome, why not eat as the Romans (really) do? One of the surest ways to get off the tourist grid is to read local guidebooks. Never mind if you don’t speak their language — a handful of guides to Italy and France have symbols, numerical ratings and pictures that will steer you toward your next discovery. “Osterie d’Italia,” from Slow Food Italy, recommends restaurants, organized geographically, with a snail icon to indicate that they follow Slow Food principles. If you like nonna-in-the-cucina places, it’s worth the weight. Another Italian bible, “Ristoranti d’Italia del Gambero Rosso,” groups restaurants, trattorias and wine bars regionally. A numerical score is based on a 100-point scale, and a meter indicates value for your money. But the most important symbols are the forks (for restaurants) and shrimps (for wine bars): if you see a place with three, go. In France, “Carnet de Route Omnivore” is for anyone serious about 21st-century French cuisine. The annual book lists 200 experimental restaurants and highlights the best dish at each (under the heading “Le Plat qui Change Tout”). Accompanying recommendations of nearby hotels are a bonus. The same publisher also recently released “Carnet de Vigne Omnivore,” a guide to 200 small, artisanal vineyards, with handy regional maps. And for architecture, art and history lovers, there’s “Ouverts au Public: Le Guide du Patrimoine en France,” which provides visiting information, photos and maps for more than 2,500 state-protected monuments. CHRISTINE MUHLKE.

The new book “A Road Trip Journal” (Phaidon, $250) documents a 1973 cross-country drive the photographer Stephen Shore made from New York to the West Coast and back, one of many such trips he took during the 1970s. The volume recreates the scrapbook Shore made at the time: what TV shows he watched (the Watergate hearings, “All in the Family”), the mileage he clocked, which locations he shot (“Sha-Mar Beauty Salon, Chestnut St.”). He also included every piece of paper he collected — receipts, parking and movie tickets, and, most important, postcards. “I found them fascinating because they were not trying to be works of art,” he says. “They just show you the main street, the so-and-so motel. I was attracted to that matter-of-factness.” Ultimately, it was that matter-of-factness that had a big influence on his own pictures; although made with a view camera on a tripod, they are printed to look like everyday snapshots.
The people, places and things behind the Danish capital’s cultural upswing.
Salta is Argentina’s hottest hot spot, with a boho, Santa-Fe-Sur vibe and dramatic Andean backdrop.

In the 1980s, the distinguished but now forgotten Paris decorator Christian Badin would pose for design magazines with an old-fashioned watering can, dribbling water on the chunky Elizabethan rush matting in his apartment in an 18th-century hôtel particulier. While connoisseurs of the Rolls-Royce of vegetal floor coverings nodded mischievously, many more shrunk at the thought of spores, mildew and the ravishing parquet de Versailles underneath. Watering your parquet? Quelle horreur.

Paul Smith calls London home, but he’s a designer without borders, finding inspiration for clothes and furniture around the globe. His latest project — a travel-themed store in Heathrow’s new Terminal 5 — reinvents the airport gift shop. Between takeoffs, Smith took the T Travel Questionnaire.

Stroll into Cynthia’s Ristorante in downtown Paducah, Ky., on any given Friday night and you’ll likely find a gaggle of artists holding court at the end of the bar, their animated conversations fueled by Finlandia cosmopolitans and Chambord martinis. In the dimly lit dining room toward the back, locals tuck into twice-baked Montrachet goat-cheese soufflés or oak-grilled pork tenderloin wrapped in apple-wood-smoked bacon. The vibe is faintly reminiscent of Elaine’s on a Thursday night, which is a bit of a shock since this Southern town on the western tip of Kentucky is a long way from the Upper East Side.

For the musician Tori Amos, the best way to travel is to step onstage. “Performing is like taking a magic carpet ride,” she says. Her songs cover a wide range of subjects, from sexuality to religion to designer accessories. (Sample lyric: “Somewhere in the hills of Ireland, there’s a Prada bag.”) “Comic Book Tattoo,” an anthology of graphic art inspired by her songs, is due out in July. The book follows last year’s “Legs and Boots,” a series of live “bootlegs” sold through her Web site, and her American Doll Posse World Tour; ever the provocateur, she invited Pope Benedict XVI to her show in Rome. (He never R.S.V.P.’ed.) Despite his absence, Amos still managed to feel a higher power. Of giving a concert, she says: “It’s a legal way to get ecstasy. But there is less of a hangover if you go my way.” ALEX HAWGOOD.

People always tell me, ‘Finally I feel like I’m in Australia,’ even if they’ve been in the country for weeks,” Craig Wickham said as we barreled down a red dirt road on Kangaroo Island. Wickham is tall and graceful, with tan skin and a salt-and-pepper buzz cut. He grew up on a farm on the island’s north coast and now owns the Exceptional Kangaroo Island touring company, which has been taking travelers around this island, 10 miles off the coast of southern Australia, for nearly 20 years. Beyond the dusty windshield of our Land Cruiser scrolled great arcades of silvery gum trees, tossing dappled sunlight onto the road. Every once in a while the greenery dropped away, revealing the island’s famous limestone cliffs and aquamarine water, bright flashes of color amid sedate browns and greens. “K. I. encapsulates everything people were hoping to find here in Australia,” Wickham said. “You can have a lot of people lost in the landscape and you never feel that the land is crowded.”.

Beijing has been attracting plenty of attention (and controversy) lately. Love it or hate it, the Chinese capital is the boomtown of our times. As architects, chefs, designers and filmmakers — to say nothing of the Olympics — leave their mark, this once buttoned-down metropolis has become a stylish city of the future. BY AMY FABRIS-SHI.

Ah, Ischia,” a Neapolitan friend said wistfully when I told him I was headed to the “green island,” as it is known. “I spent every summer there as a kid. You know, those summers where three months last for years and years?” As soon as I made landfall on Capri’s earthier neighbor, 15 miles off the coast of Naples, I knew exactly what he meant. A hard-driving New Yorker, I’d wanted a vacation from a vacation — a simple summer weekend at the beach, without all the glitz and glamour found in most Italian seaside playgrounds.

To the Editor: The May 4 Green Traveler column (“Trying to Lighten that Carbon Footprint”) cites Friends of the Earth’s negative comments regarding Richard Branson’s biofueled flight and the drawbacks of producing biofuels for air travel. Friends of the Earth is considering only the current state of biofuel technology. Mr. Branson showed a successful “proof of concept” that might have boosted the confidence of consumers, industry, policy makers and investors and catalyzed more biofuel research. Evidence that biofuels work in a high-risk and unforgiving mode of transportation is a major step forward in powering them past the novelty stage.

PRUNTY--Richard Pratt, erudite, sesquipedalian, ebullient, chaetophorous, neo-luddite bibliophile --above all, beloved father, brother, and friend. We mourn the loss and celebrate the life of this scholarly, enthusiastic, bearded, polysyllabic-word-using, technology-doubting lover of books and knowledge. Pratt was a dedicated educator, an avid golfer, a political enthusiast, a committed social activist, an undiscriminating collector and a life-long Democrat. Raised on a farm in Oxford, West Virginia, he was educated at West Virginia University and the University of Massachusetts. He worked as a science teacher and later a guidance counselor in Enfield, Connecticut. For 30 years, he lived in the historic Hill-McKnight neighborhood of Springfield, MA. He passed away at age 71 in New York on May 6, 2008, surrounded by his children. Left to look up their own words are Jennifer Prunty (NYC), Meeghan Prunty Edelstein and Steve Edelstein (New York), Adam Prunty (Massachusetts) and Jason Prunty (Oregon); his grandchildren Julian Thomas, Eliza Ruby, Gabriel Pratt, and Julia Rose; and his brothers and sisters in West Virginia and Ohio.

WHITE--Gloria E., 86, died May 9, 2008 in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. Gloria is survived by her three sons, Geoffrey and his wife Eleanor of Martha's Vineyard, MA, Stuart and his wife Patricia of Cuenca, Ecuador, and Randall and his wife Louise of Cambridge, England; by her grandchildren Hubbard, Pedro, Jacob, Nadine, Louise, Anna and Richard; and by her brother Peer Pederson of Rye, NY. She was predeceased by her husband John Robert White in 1995, and her brother Clive Pederson in 2007. Gloria was a passionate and generous mother, wife and friend, with a fearless, mischievous and witty spirit. What a gal!

JAY LENO Huge political fireworks today after President Bush went to Israel and he talked about American politicians who might want to talk with Hamas or other leaders. Politicians who would sit down and appease terrorists. He said he would not do it. He would not put up with it. He would never talk to terrorists. And then he flew to Saudi Arabia to spend a couple of days with the Saudi royal family.

WITH a laser measuring device clipped to his belt and a reel of yellow tape tucked under one arm, Christopher Otteau roamed around a tidy house on a corner lot in Ridgewood, N.J., preparing to deliver the unwelcome news to its occupants. They, like many other homeowners whose property Mr. Otteau has appraised lately, were hoping to hear that their special house in their special neighborhood in their special town was immune to the gravitational force that has been pulling down home prices from coast to coast. Mr. Otteau's oft-repeated response: Sorry, but we are all in this housing slump together.

A review on May 4 about ''The Song of Everlasting Sorrow,'' a novel originally written in Chinese by Wang Anyi, misstated the middle name of one of its translators. She is Susan Chan Egan, not Chang.

IF you love, but can't quite afford, Miu Miu's $1,800 harlequin tunics emblazoned with portraits by the Swedish illustrator Liselotte Watkins, you're in luck. Sort of. Last week Miu Miu introduced a far less expensive T-shirt variation, and then promptly proceeded to sell out of it. ''There was a wait list even before they arrived in store,'' explained a company spokeswoman, who assured us that the new Los Angeles boutique, which opened last Saturday on Rodeo Drive, had a healthy supply of the tees. At press time, at least, it did. T-shirt, $200 at Miu Miu, 317 North Rodeo Drive,

MOSER--Gale Warren. Titusville, NJ. May 16, 2008. Gale Warren Moser, 60, of Titusville, NJ, died peacefully this morning. Born in Louisville, Kentucky, Mr. Moser was a resident of Titusville for more than 30 years. He was predeceased by his father, Novitas R. Moser and his mother, Ruth Patrick Moser; he is survived by his wife of 18 years, Patricia McNamara Moser, his children, Jordan Chase, Nathan Gale, Alexis Leigh and Lillian Ruth Moser, his sister Gwendolyn Irene Moser and his former wife Susan Vasey. Mr Moser graduated from Taylor University in 1970 and received his Masters in Divinity from Princeton Theological Seminary in 1973. Beginning his career at Lehman Brothers, Mr. Moser was later a director at Cowen and Co. and completed his career at Morgan Stanley in Princeton. Mr. Moser was active in the community through his support of many local charitable organizations, most directly with the Mt. Carmel Guild. He was also an active member of Central Baptist Church of Ewing. Additionally he was an active member of the Trenton Country Club, as well as the Surf City Yacht Club. To all who knew him, Mr. Moser was the most kind and gentle person. Diagnosed six years ago with Picks Disease -a rare dementia which strikes at middle age Mr. Moser has made the ultimate gift in death through the donation of his brain to Johns Hopkins University Medical Center for research purposes in the hope of helping to find a cure for this devastating frontal temporal lobe disease. Friends may call at the Blackwell Memorial Home, 21 N. Main St, Pennington, NJ on Monday from 4pm to 8pm. Church Service will take place at the Pennington United Methodist Church, Tuesday at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donation can be made to either the AFTD (Frontal Temporal Dementia) 1616 Walnut St. Suite 1100 Philadelphia, PA 19103 or to the Mount Carmel Guild, 73 N. Clinton Ave, Trenton, NJ 08609.

NEXT TEST FOR BIG BROWN Big Brown's jockey, Kent Desormeaux, said his lead was so comfortable in the final stretch of the Preakness Stakes that he had no need to push the bay colt. ''I started slowing him down and watching TV and making sure nothing went crazy,'' he said.

A picture caption with an article last Sunday about Suze Rotolo's memoir of her relationship with Bob Dylan carried an incorrect credit. The picture of Mr. Dylan in glasses being embraced by Ms. Rotolo was taken by Ted Russell, not by Don Hunstein.

Alex Kotlowitz's insightful piece (May 4) on the cycles of violence that plague many communities makes the points that in matters of health, prevention is more effective than punishment, and that ending any addiction requires us to teach alternatives. Our own experience and a vast body of rigorous research suggest a few simple directives. Support prevention programs that start early, are rooted in community values and resources and are sustained over time. Focus on resources instead of deficits; embrace the hopes, skills and positive values of youth and communities, and build on that foundation. Teach alternatives to violence: anger management, empathy, communication, cooperation, conflict resolution and active community engagement help young people not only avoid violence; they also help inoculate them against the hopelessness that breeds these cycles. STEVEN BRION-MEISELS,

FREDERICKS--Frank O., 89, of Greenwich died Wednesday May 14, at home. Born in New York, NY on January 24, 1919 he was the son of the late Oscar and Ethel Fredericks. Mr. Fredericks was a World War II Veteran serving in the U.S. Army. He was a Lawyer in private practice in New York City specializing in corporate law. He had a passion for race horses owning many champion trotters and was named man of the year in Harness Racing several times. A benevolent man he was a major benefactor to many charities. Mr. Fredericks is survived by his wife Phyllis Fredericks, two nieces Irene Baker, Anne Galletta, and a nephew Jeff Baker. Services will take place Monday May 19, at 11:00am in the Fred D. Knapp & Son Funeral Home, 267 Greenwich Ave. Greenwich, CT. Interment will follow in Putnam Cemetery.

It is true that Big Brown's stallion rights were sold to Three Chimneys Farm for more than $50 million. Michael Iavarone, the president of International Equine Acquisitions Holdings and a co-owner of Big Brown, confirmed he signed a deal Saturday on his way to Pimlico after a week of negotiations. Three Chimneys already stands Smarty Jones, who won the first two legs of the Triple Crown before finishing second at the Belmont Stakes. Smarty Jones commands $100,000 a mating and sees 110 mares a season. Iavarone says Big Brown will not run as a 4-year-old. If he wins the Belmont and becomes the first Triple Crown champion since Affirmed in 1978, he will probably not run again.
Dance Jack Anderson

TUTTLE--Gordon M., of Darien, CT, on May 8, 2008 after a short illness at the age of 85. A graduate of Andover, Yale and Harvard Law School, he served as a Staff Sergeant in an artillery battalion of Patton's Army and was awarded the Silver Star, Bronze Star and Purple Heart. A retired lawyer, Vice Chairman of Avco Corporation and Senior Vice President of Textron Inc., he is survived by three children, Garrett M. Tuttle, David P. Tuttle and Dr. Ann Tuttle Koster, seven grandchildren and his special friend, Jane P. Kelly. His wife Alice Wyker predeceased him. At all times his family was his greatest interest. His family and friends will greatly miss his wise counsel, generosity and kind heart. Friends are invited to join the family for a celebration of his life on May 31st, 2008, at the Wee Burn Country Club, 410 Hollow Tree Ridge Road, Darien, CT from 4-6pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to: Phillips Andover Academy, 180 Main Street, Andover, MA 01810; Yale University, P.O. Box 2038, New Haven, CT 06521-2038; the Darien Library, 35 Leroy Avenue, Darien, CT 06820; or the Good Shepherd Orphanage, c/o Pura Vida for Children, P.O. Box 1692, New Canaan, CT 06840.

HERN--George Louis, Jr., 84 years old, of West Palm Beach, FL, died on Sunday, May 11, 2008 at the V.A. Medical Center in Miami. Born in Los Angeles, CA on May 3, 1924, he was the son of George L. and Charlotte Odette Hern. Mr. Hern attended preparatory schools in California, and was a Veteran of WW II having served with the US Army in the China-Burma-India Theater. He was a graduate of the University of California at Los Angeles, where he was President of the French Club. Mr. Hern obtained a graduate degree in French literature from the University of Paris (Sorbonne) and worked under Avrell Harriman in the economic recovery efforts in Paris until 1953. Mr. Hern served for many years as Director of Press Relations for Air France in New York. In the 1960's, he was a resident of Palm Beach and worked as a columnist for the Palm Beach Daily News, covering the Arts and Society. Following this, he returned to New York and was appointed Director of Public Relations for the French Government Tourist Office, Consulate General of France. Mr. Hern retired from this post in 1995 and became a resident of the Palm Beaches soon thereafter. Mr. Hern became an officer of the Ordre du Merit which was presented to him by President Francois Mitterrand in recognition of his long service to France. In New York, he was a member of the University Club, Paris American Club, and Overseas Press Club. He leaves behind no family. A Memorial Service will soon be scheduled at Bethesda-ByThe-Sea Episcopal Church, Palm Beach, FL, with Rev. Ralph R. Warren, Jr., D.D., Rector, officiating. Please contact Quattlebaum Funeral Home (561)832-5171 for Service information. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Mr. Hern's memory to the Peggy Adams Animal Rescue League, 3200 North Military Trail, West Palm Beach, FL 33409.
Pop Nate Chinen

COX--Beverly Rae Kimes. August 17th 1939-May12th 2008. Passed away May 12, 2008, at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. Born in West Chicago, IL. The daughter of Raymond L. and Grace D. Parrin Kimes. Her growing up years were in Wheaton, IL. She attended U of I Urbana Illinois. Then on to Penn State at State College Pennsylvania for her Masters in Liberal Arts and subsequently to New York City to pursue her career. After finding no work in her field of choice, writing for Theater Publications, she took what she referred to, as a job to pay the bills. The job, however, would become her lifelong career. Hired at Automobile Quarterly in 1963, as a secretary. Her first ride in an Old Car was from Times Square to the Worlds Fair in a 1903 Curved Dash Oldsmobile driven by Henry Austin Clark Jr., of Glen Cove, NY. She would remain at A.Q. until 1981. It is my opinion as well as others, that A.Q. would not have been as it grew to be without her skills, leadership and hard work. She went free lance, and also became the Editor for the Classic Car Club of America, a job she would fulfill for 26 plus years. Her first Book as a free lance author was The Standard Catalog of American Cars 1805-1942, with Henry Austin Clark Jr. The Book has become a must for Automotive Writers as well as Hobbyists through out the World. Her last Book just out is Walter L. Marr, Buick's Amazing Engineer. Her writings are so massive it would be hard to list them all here. For more about her google her: Beverly Rae Kimes. Her Books and Articles have received more Awards than any other Author in the Automotive Field. She was referred to by Life Magazine as the ''nation's foremost automotive scholar'' ACD Club, bestow her Woman of The Year Award, CCCA with their Distinguished Service Award, Distinguished Service Citation from the Automotive Hall of Fame, she became the first historian to receive this award, A Lifetime Achievement Award as well as the Best of Books honor from IAM Awards. She served as the Voice of the Burn Concours d'Elegance of the Eastern United States for 17 years. She was also an Honorary Judge at The Pebble Beach Concours. A past President of The Society of Automotive Historians. She is Survived by Her Husband James H. Cox, a Sister Sharon of Star Lake, WI, a niece Plam Sauer, Mudra, her husband Billy and Grace and Will of Thackerville, OK, Cullen Sauer, wife Michelle and Thomas, of Elburn, IL. Three step kids, James H. Cox Jr, and family Marry Ann, Brittany and Jim Jr of Bushkill, PA, Lori Ann Cox Reeve, and family Tim, Nick, Alexia, and Haily of Hampton, NJ, Cheryl Lynn Cox Redding and family Bill and Lizzy of Baltimore, MD. Beverly Loved New York City and was often involved in programs to make the City a better place, she served as The President of The East 80th St Block Association. She also served as an officer for the U of I Alumni Club of Greater New York. Beverly was Truly a Very Loving and Caring Person, the whole of her life, she touched the hearts and minds of a lot of people, she will be very sadly missed, but she will never be forgotten. Lovingly, Husband Jim. ''Funeral services are private''. Memorial contributions may be made to National Kidney Foundation at www.kidney.org or 1-800-6229010

BRILL--Malcolm Arthur, of Palm Beach, passed away May 14th in Los Angeles at 98. Predeceased by his beloved wife Estelle, he was the proud father of Michael and Judith, grandfather of five grandchildren and greatgrandfather of Ben and Ethan. An attorney, BA and JD at NYU, he spent his career as a respected developer in the New York area through his company BrillTishman. Malcolm always had a smile and never failed to make others laugh with his unique sense of humor. All those who knew him felt a kinship and bond that was born of his love for people. He leaves a big space in the hearts of his family and those who knew him who could never contemplate a world without him. Memorial services will be held in Los Angeles and New York--dates and locations to be announced.

WRIGHT--Jordan M., age 50. Our loving son Jordan passed away Sunday, May 11, 2008. He was the greatest gift from God. He is the founder of the Museum of Democracy and his collection of political memorabilia, considered the finest private collection in the United States, will be lent to the museum of the city of New York for an exhibition from June 23 to December 2008. He authored a book entitled ''Campaigning for President'' which was published by Harper Collins in January 2008. The book was reviewed in the New York Times Book Review as well as the Wall Street Journal. A graduate of Columbia University and Vanderbilt University Law School, he became an attorney in Pennsylvania and New York. He was also a photographer whose photos of New Guinea were shown under the auspices of the Smithsonian Museums and displayed throughout the United States and many parts of the world. Finally, through his company, Volo, he published the magazine entitled ''Pacific Arts''. Survived by our grandchildren Austin and Mackenzie, sister Ingrid Wright. Services and interment private. Faith-Dorian and Martin Wright

GLENDON--Patricia Evers, 83, of Cape, Elizabeth, ME died on April 11, as the result of a stroke. Patricia lived most of her adult life as an avid New Yorker, while enjoying summers at her home in Avondale, RI, and resided in Reno, NV for five years. Patricia was a graduate of Barnard College and received her Master's Degree in Journalism from the University of Rhode Island. She penned the popular advice column ''Teen Talk'' for the World Telegraph and Sun in New York City in the early 1950s. She was also an author, notably as a ghostwriter for legendary heavyweight champ Joe Louis's book ''How to Box.'' Her writing for the Reno Evening Gazette was recognized with numerous awards including ''Most Outstanding Journalist in Nevada'' and her series, ''The Drop Out'', was entered into the U.S. Congressional Record. She was a past president of the New York Junior League Sustainers, and a member of both the Newswomen's Club of New York and The Society of The Silurians. She is survived by her son Teg Glendon and wife Susan Sloane of South Portland, ME; son Richard Glendon and wife Suzanne Sepe of North Haven, CT; three loving grandchildren, Ennis Glendon, Estelle Glendon and Acadia Crouse, to whom she was a devoted grandmother; and Jean Keller, mother of Ennis and Estelle. Condolences may be left at the obituary section of independentdeathcare.com.

THE NEWS A powerful earthquake with a magnitude of 7.9 struck western China last Monday, ravaging a mountainous region outside Chengdu, capital of Sichuan Province. BEHIND THE NEWS The death toll could rise to more than 50,000, the government said, which would make the earthquake China's worst natural disaster since a magnitude 7.5 earthquake killed at least 240,000 people and possibly many more in Tangshan in eastern China in 1976. The initial quake (of the same magnitude as the San Francisco earthquake of 1906) struck at 2:28 p.m., while schools were open. It was felt as far away as Vietnam and set off a smaller tremor near Beijing, 900 miles away.

HIKING THE ROAD TO DAMASCUS, SEPT. 25, 2007 Stefanie Schroeder, 26, left, a photography student, with Constanze Kerth, 24, a painting student, both from Leipzig, Germany, walking down Mount Kassioun. ''We went to Jordan for two weeks with a group of students, and we had some days left before the flight back to Germany. So we spent the time in Damascus. It was beautiful, but we only spent three or four days there, so I couldn't really tell that I was in Damascus. I was there, of course, and I saw the most popular things and got some impressions. But I think I have to spend a little more time in a place to really find something out about it. What's interesting, it looks like there are several times existing next to one another. There are places, they look like you've gone back 1,000 years. Then there are these socialistic buildings in between and it's all covered with lots of colored, plastic animals they sell everywhere. It's amazing -- like layers, one over the other.'' As told to Austin Considine

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the potential rise of biracial politics in the South referred incorrectly to a young man whom George Allen, a Republican senator seeking re-election in Virginia, called a ''macaca,'' widely considered to be a racial slur, during a campaign appearance in 2006. The young man, who was of Indian descent, was conducting opposition research for the Democrats; he was not heckling Mr. Allen.

OUTPOSTS In Oregon in recent days we've seen fresh themes for the general election presented by Senators Barack Obama and John McCain -- and they have very little to do with dated, tribal politics. The fruit trees in the Willamette Valley may be in full blossom, but in Oregon it's November in May. The map of counties that Hillary Clinton won big this year shows a broad swath of Appalachia and rural America, places where a Democrat is unlikely to prevail in the general election. The scab of racial animus can be thick in those counties, judging by exit polls of Clinton supporters who say they would never vote for a black man, and by anecdotal reporting.

SAAR--Joseph, 88, died at home on May 15, 2008, from cancer. He was a psychotherapist in Manhattan, with an office on Central Park West. He lived in White Plains and is survived by his wife of 63 years, Bobbie, with whom he traveled the world. He is also survived by his sons David and Robert, his daughter, Carol; and his five grandchildren, Steven, Karen, Leslie, Brian and Eric. Joe loved theater, Chopin, books, movies, chocolate, Paris, French bread, and a good joke. Above all, he loved Bobbie. He was a wise and compassionate therapist, a loyal and generous friend, a devoted husband and a proud, loving father and grandfather. The family will welcome visitors at Robert's home, 6 Grey Rock Terrace, Irvington, NY. on Saturday, June 14, 2008 from 1 to 6pm.

Last week, I had lunch with the lawyer I worked with nearly 15 years ago in my first job. As we sat across a table the way we had countless times before, I realized that he was the reason I stayed so long in a career that wasn't suited to me. Updated, 3:27 p.m. | The authorities evacuated 12 commercial buildings and rerouted three bus lines this morning after a 20-inch water main broke on West 57th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues around 8:10 a.m. The bus lines that were detoured were the M30, M31 and M57, and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority warned of extensive service delays.

Big Brown boarded a van at 10 a.m. Monday at Pimlico Race Course and is bound for Belmont Park. The colt will take up residence in Bobby Frankel's barn in the stall that was once occupied by the 2003 Belmont Stakes winner, Empire Maker.

Apple ended its Mac clone program in 1998, soon after Steven P. Jobs rejoined the company. At the time, there was little reason to suspect that it would ever be revived. Now a Mac clone is back, but this time without Apple's blessing.

While there is a lot to be said for a sauce of slow-cooked onions, there is one major disadvantage: it's slow. Fresher, greener and milder than onions, leeks cook down and become tender quickly enough to make a distinctive, delicious sauce for spaghetti in little more time than it takes to boil the water and cook the pasta.

In an article on the various ways that drivers become distracted, USA Today cited an interesting finding in a recent survey. "Older drivers were more likely than teens to multitask when driving," wrote Angela Haupt. Time to celebrate those surprisingly responsible young folks? Not exactly.

BRIEFS What happens when the man saying "Don't Tase Me, Bro" has a Taser too? On the weekend police blotter in Boulder, Colorado, a bizarre duel: Casey Dane, a private security guard, "told police he reached for his Taser after [Harvey] Epstein refused to drop the bolt cutters. That, according to Dane, is when Epstein pulled a stun gun out of his pocket and shot him. He fired back, stunning Epstein in return." Neither was injured. [Daily Camera via The Associated Press]

Farmers and consumers in poor countries are now paying the price for decisions made by well-fed Westerners, as reported by my colleagues Keith Bradsher and Andrew Martin in their front-page article on cutbacks in financing for agricultural research. They explain how the Green Revolution faltered after Western governments and agencies slashed funds for agricultural research, partly to shift money to other areas, like environmental projects, and partly because of opposition to high-yield agriculture from advocacy groups.

Despite a $1 billion investment since the early 1990s to install more than 200 elevators and escalators in the New York City subway, the equipment regularly fails, William Neuman reports in a front-page article that drew upon months of research, dozens of interviews and reviews of thousands of pages of documents. One of every six elevators and escalators in the subway system was out of service for more than a month last year, according to New York City Transit data.

Barack Obama and his family greeted a record-breaking crowd of 75,000 in Portland, Ore., on Sunday, ahead of that state's primary this Tuesday. Even if things "go as we hope," he said, his campaign won't declare victory in the Democratic primary that night, even though Oregon could tip the majority of pledged delegates his way.

The chief executive of Austrian Airlines was quoted on Saturday as saying he would be open to a majority takeover of Austria's national carrier if that were needed for it to prosper amid soaring fuel costs, Reuters reported.

FRANCISCUS--Howard E., 79, of Hopatcong, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, on Friday May 16, 2008. Former Senior V.P. at Aon Corporation, NY, NY. Loving husband of 55 years of Marion (O'Farrell). For further information and service times, please visit www.leberlakeside.com or call 973-398-3000.

BYLAND--Bruce E., 58, of Mamaroneck, NY on May 17, 2008 after a valiant struggle with cancer. Beloved husband of Cara Tannenbaum for 27 years, loving father of Leah and Sophie. Who bought the 1976 Francis Bacon painting ''Triptych'' for $86.3 million and the 1995 Lucian Freudpainting ''Benefits Supervisor Sleeping'' for $33.6 million last week at Sotheby's in New York? The 41-year-old London-based Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, The Art Newspaper reported on its Web site (theartnewspaper.com). The Bacon became the most expensive work of contemporary art ever sold at auction, and the Freud was said to be the most expensive work by a living artist. The Art Newspaper said that Mr. Abramovich apparently intended to display both works in his home. His fortune, from oil and gas, is estimated at more than $22 billion.

RUBEL--Ralph, 81, on May 11, 2008 in Merrick, NY. Attorney, counselor, devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend. He demonstrated remarkable fortitude and caring through the extended illness of his best friend and wife, Josephine Rubel, who died eight months before him after a lengthy battle with Alzheimzer's disease. He insisted on caring for Jo at home until the end, and still felt he had not done enough. He touched many lives and had a story and sound advice for all. He graduated from City College and NYU Law School. He had a solo practice on Long Island for 50 years, focusing on family law and litigation, and did not stop until his untimely passing. Survived by his children, Nancy Abeltin, Lori Pickrell and Eric Rubel, and seven grandchildren. Donations to the Alzheimer's Association. www.alz.org

KREVISKY--Joseph. Beloved husband, father, brother. He was an outstanding teacher, author, editor, publisher, a man of courage, and always an advocate for peace, justice and equal rights. Services Plaza Funeral Home, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 90th St, Monday May 19th at 1pm.

BRILL--Malcolm Arthur, of Palm Beach, passed away May 14th in Los Angeles at 98. Predeceased by his beloved wife Estelle, he was the proud father of Michael and Judith, grandfather of five grandchildren and greatgrandfather of Ben and Ethan. An attorney, BA and JD at NYU, he spent his career as a respected developer in the New York area through his company BrillTishman. Malcolm always had a smile and never failed to make others laugh with his unique sense of humor. All those who knew him felt a kinship and bond that was born of his love for people. He leaves a big space in the hearts of his family and those who knew him who could never contemplate a world without him. Memorial services will be held in Los Angeles and New York--dates and locations to be announced.

This is not how it was supposed to happen. It is not, at least, how things looked in Virginia. At the Signature Theater in Arlington, ''Glory Days,'' the four-man musical about growing up, was a hit this year. The reviews were mixed to positive, but the real story was the show's creators, Nick Blaemire, 23, and James Gardiner, 24. So young, andto have written a musical! Two relatively green New York producers offered to take the show to the big dance of Broadway, and it looked like the beginning of a showbiz fairy tale. But after 17 previews, a sheaf of bad reviews, meager ticket sales and one opening night, ''Glory Days'' closed at the Circle in the Square Theater on Broadway, most likely losing its entire $2.5 million investment. It was the first show to close after one regular performance since 2003, when ''Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All'' had said everything she had to say by the opening-night curtain.

YOUNG--Marian Hillyer Wolff Died on May 11, 2008, Mother's Day, in Atlanta Georgia. Born in 1907, she was the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Wolff and was a third generation Atlanta native. Dr. Wolff was Atlanta's first specialist in dermatology. In 1933 Mrs. Young married the late John Maurice Young and moved to New York City. Mr. Young at age 34 was the youngest of seven men who in 1935 resigned from J.P. Morgan & Co. or Drexel & Co. to found the investment banking firm of Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc. Mrs. Young was the last surviving spouse of a Morgan Stanley founder. Mrs. Young was a graduate of Washington Seminary and in 1929 she obtained her A.B. degree from Hollins University where she was a member of the Chi Omega sorority. In New York, she was a member of the Colony Club, the Bedford Garden Club, the National Society of Colonial Dames and The Daughters of the Cincinnati. She was a Fellow of the Morgan Library and since 1962 the New York Director and past president of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Association at Stratford Hall Plantation in Virginia. In 1994, after living 61 years in New York City and Bedford, New York, Mrs. Young moved back to Atlanta and resided at the Lenbrook Square retirement community, where she rejoined many friends from her childhood in Atlanta. Mrs. Young was predeceased by her sister Ellen McDowell Wolff and her brother Dr. Bernard Preston Wolff, both life-long residents of Atlanta. She is survived by three children, daughter Meredith Young Wood, of Hampden, Massachusetts and sons Jonathan McLain Young of Decatur, and Hillyer McDowell Young of Atlanta. She is survived also by four grandsons, Henry Waller Hamilton, Jonathan Caldecot Young, Geoffrey Preston Young, and Carson McLain Young; a great grandson, Preston McDowell Young, a great granddaughter, Wilson Caldecot Young; and the children of her brother, John McDowell Wolff, Bernard Wellborn Wolff, Susan Preston Wolff Lindley, Marian Hillyer Wolff Nolan and Charles Emerson Wolff. Mrs. Youngs grandfather, Judge George Hillyer, was mayor of Atlanta after the Civil War. Mrs. Young was a renowned beauty and remained so until her death. Throughout her long life, Mrs. Young was a treasure to her family and to her many friends. Mrs. Youngs body has been cremated and at a later date her ashes will be buried next to her husbands in the cemetery of St. Matthew's Episcopal church, Bedford, New York where she has been a member since 1937. A memorial service for Mrs. Young will be held at 2pm, Wednesday, May 28, 2008 at Saint Martin in the Fields church, 3110 Ashford Dunwoody Road, Atlanta, GA 30319 (404-261-4292). H. M. Patterson & Son, Oglethorpe Hill (404-261-3510) will be in charge of arrangements. The family requests that no flowers be sent. Those so wishing may send contributions to the Robert E. Lee Memorial Association, Inc., Stratford Hall Plantation, Stratford, Virginia 22558 or to Hollins University, P.O. Box 9629, Roanoke, Virginia 24020.

KELLERMAN--Regina M. Trustees and staff of the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation mourn the death of Regina Kellerman, noted architectural historian and the Society's first executive director. She served on the Society's Preservation Committee until her death. She will be profoundly missed.

In ''Dances at a Gathering,'' Jerome Robbins made a classic of dance and theater, a work that irresistibly invited multiple interpretations that Robbins both planted and discouraged. At New York City Ballet, the company for which he made it in 1969, ''Dances'' has been performed with a kind of quiet understatement that during the last decade and a half has dimmed the ballet into near-dullness. The Royal Ballet at Covent Garden, by contrast, had not danced it for 32 years -- until Saturday. The old Royal Ballet version, performed between 1970 and 1976, was a high point in the company's history. Instead of understatement, however, it fell victim in its later years to overinflection: in particular, to charm. The new Royal Ballet production (I watched both performances on Saturday) is strong on charm too, but not excessively so; and it draws on the best virtue of today's Royal Ballet: highly individual soloists, male and female.

This week, a complex and controversial piece of legislation began to make its way through the British parliament. One of the provisions of the bill permits the creation of "savior siblings" - children created via in vitro fertilization (I.V.F.) to ensure their tissues will match those of a sick older brother or sister, in order that the new child could provide, say, a bone marrow transplant. (Conceiving a child the old-fashioned way doesn't guarantee a tissue match.) Another is a reduction of the legal time-limit on abortion, which up to now has been 24 weeks.
