Robert Irwin's re-assessment of the legacy of Edward Said, 30 years after the publication of "Orientalism" and five years after Said's death, is quite interesting - even if it has that very British (or very TLS) tendency to drop very obscure names as if everyone knows what he's talking about. For instance, in Irwin's view, "Said was utterly oblivious to the humour and stylishness of Alexander Kinglake's 'Eothen.'" Hmmm. Some quick googling shows that Kinglake, an Englishman, traveled to the Levant in the 19th century. And through Project Gutenberg you can even download the entire book. Irwin is the TLS's Middle East editor, and has also written a cute book on the Alhambra.

Tom Kuntz has been a New York Times journalist for more than 20 years. He was a foreign editor during the collapse of communism and the first gulf war. At the Sunday Week in Review, his Word for Word columns of verbatim excerpts led to two books, "The Titanic Disaster Hearings" (Pocket Books, 1998) and "The Sinatra Files" (Three River Press, 2000). After 9/11, he produced Times television documentaries for Discovery about rebuilding ground zero. As a special projects editor, he helped edit "Class Matters," a series about social class in America. As pop music editor, he started New York Times Popcast, a podcast. After returning to the Week in Review in 2007, he started the Laugh Lines and Idea of the Day blogs.

So here are the Pittsburgh Penguins relaxing last night at home. They don't care much about the upcoming primaries, who's got how many delegates in which states with what amount of electoral votes or the proportions of committed vs. uncommitted super-delegates. This is no time for numbers.

Suzanne Lenzer, who works with me on assorted projects and who knows her way around the kitchen, found these wonderful beans from California, and whipped up a nice-sounding dish. Here's her report --MB

CNBC interviews Christopher J. Dodd and Richard C. Shelby, leading members of the Senate banking committee.

The Blood-Horse reported Big Brown had a slight run down behind coming out of the Preakness.

Voters have turned out in droves this primary season, thanks in part to a hotly contested race between Democratic contenders Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama. But the exact opposite trend is being seen among mom-and-pop shareholders, whose already low voting rate has plunged during this spring's proxy season.

Looks like no medals in store for Greek weightlifters at Beijing this year, given the high unlikeliness that the team will show up there after a Greek prosecutor filed misdemeanor charges today against 11 of the weightlifting team's 14 athletes, as well as team coaches and doctors.

Aired Monday night on NBC: Thank you for coming out on such a hot day. It was so hot, Hillary Clinton became delusional, began claiming she could win the White House. I'm sorry, that's the regular Hillary.
A few weeks back, I wrote about Yamaha's Internet-connected, self-playing grand piano, called the Disklavier Mark IV.

Aired Monday night on CBS: I'm trying not to be too depressed about this, but how about the price of gasoline in this country? You know what they're saying now? By Labor Day, it will probably be $20 a gallon.

On the QT is a travel questionnaire for stylish globe trotters. Here New York-based restaurateur, nightlife nabob and men's wear designer Taavo Somer gives us his answers. As the co-owner of Freemans, Freemans Sporting Club and his latest, the Rusty Knot -- a down home version of Trader Vic's -- Somer doesn't get to pencil in too many vacation days. While he's chowed down on fugu in Tokyo and counts Villa D'Este in Lake Como, Italy as one of his favorite hotels, the king of unkempt cool typically prefers old-school America.

Aired Monday night on NBC: Hillary Clinton still campaigning hard. In a speech this weekend that she just gave, Hillary Clinton said that John McCain "couldn't be more out of touch." Yeah. Yeah, then Hillary said, "Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm about to win the Democratic nomination."
Students at Kingsborough Community College lounge waterside between classes. Video  by Corey Kilgannon.
The photographer Nikola Tamindzic is known for capturing images of both the celebrities and mere mortals of New York City night life.

Your full-service Quad lacrosse contributor here. Not only do I provide game previews and reviews, flawed predictions and lame cracks about The Quad's writers and editors, but I also got to drive Mr. Pete Thamel back and forth to the N.C.A.A. quarterfinals last weekend in Annapolis, Md. He even made me fetch him pizza in the press box at Navy Marine Corps Stadium.

Like most people, when I see rhubarb I usually think ''pie'' and leave it at that. Which is a shame, because rhubarb can be a truly interesting ingredient -- deliciously sour, unexpectedly smooth, beautifully pale pink on the plate, and totally seasonal.

I am planning a visit to Greece with our two boys (14, 10) this summer and would like to visit both cultural and historical sites. Keeping the boys in mind, I would also like to spend several days on the beach for some swimming or snorkeling. Can you recommend an itinerary for a 10 day visit? Should we attempt to visit islands on the Aegean on our own or join a tour?

This is a touchy subject, so allow me to start with a disclaimer: I live in France, I love living in France, and I do not eat horse meat -- and neither do 82 percent of the people who live here.

Boone Pickens is probably best known for his big bets on oil and gas. But the Texas billionaire, who celebrates his 80th birthday this week, said Tuesday that he has put a few chips down on Yahoo, the Internet company that is the unwilling object of Microsoft's affections.
Monday's letter from the White House aide Ed Gillespie to the NBC News president Steve Capus was a high-profile complaint about NBC News and MSNBC -- ­ but it was far from the first.
Lisa de Moraes of The Washington Post asks: "Where Are The Shows Of Yesteryear?"

Red Sox fans have to feel good about their young starting pitchers. While the Yankees' Ian Kennedy (0-3) continues to struggle, and Phil Hughes (0-4) remains on the shelf, the Red Sox' Jon Lester pitched a no-hitter Monday night against the Kansas City Royals, just eight months after another young Boston starter, Clay Buchholz, no-hit the Baltimore Orioles on September 1, 2007.

BRIEFS In a pair of health headlines today, the World Health Organization reiterated that most people die from well-known conditions -- heart disease, stroke and diseases from malaria to tuberculosis -- while the National Institutes of Health unveiled an effort to ferret out lesser known ones. The Undiagnosed Diseases Program will tackle "the most puzzling medical cases," according to a news release cited by Wired Science.

With Kentucky in play today, and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton likely to win that state with its sizable swath of rural voters, we asked Dave "Mudcat" Saunders, a Democratic strategist from Roanoke, Va., to talk about this segment of the electorate and its importance to the 2008 campaigns.
By all accounts, the United States military acted with great speed after one of its soldiers used a Koran for target practice in Iraq. But was it the right response?

James Dimon, the head of the banking giant JPMorgan Chase, recently estimated that the credit crunch was about 75 percent over. But Meredith Whitney, the head of equity research at Oppenheimer, believes that it will extend well into 2009 and perhaps beyond that.

New York City is lucky that it doesn't face blackouts with the regularity of India or South Africa. Still we should be prepared. Power failures come and go in New York City. There are solidarity-building blackouts, historically scarring blackouts and blackouts that seem to go on forever (yet the power company only offers a meager $100 per household).

In the end, Representative Vito J. Fossella's announced his decision to abandon his re-election campaign not at a news conference in his district, but by placing a letter on his Congressional and campaign Web sites. The letters first appeared early this morning.

Rick Dutrow says he'd like to see Big Brown race beyond the Belmont and in the Travers Stakes, or the Midsummer Derby, and the Breeders' Cup Classic, where the reigning Horse of the Year Curlin could await.

There are strange things happening down in Texas, at Franklin Bank, the lender that was started by Lew Ranieri, the man who is credited with starting the mortgage securitization business. It seems that the bank has been, well, ignoring, a lot of losses.

China is full of mourning these days because of the Sichuan earthquake, generating a civic and philanthropic response that has been stirring to watch. That's probably what I'm going to write about for Thursday: Suggestions welcome for what the quake response says about China's evolution.
The Associated Press reports:
King me: Eugene Robinson, in his column for The Washington Post, says he likes the memorial statue of Martin Luther King Jr. that the United States Commission of Fine Arts wants reworked.

After more than two weeks of damaging and scandal-filled headlines, Representative Vito J. Fossella of Staten Island has decided not to seek another term in Congress, Jonathan P. Hicks reports, citing several people close to the congressman. Mr. Fossella, 43, has been the object of intense scrutiny since he was arrested in a Washington suburb on May 1 and charged with drunken driving. A week after his arrest, Mr. Fossella, the only Republican representing New York City in Congress, disclosed that he had been on the way to visit Laura Fay, a retired Air Force lieutenant colonel. (See the text of Mr. Fossella's letter to his constituents and supporters.)

ITEN, Kenya - At 6 each morning, the runners appear in groups, three here, five there, dressed in jackets and tights against the chill at 8,000 feet, as many as 500 of them training along red dirt roads that undulate through the farms of this rural village.

An aide to President Bush sent a letter on Monday to the head of NBC News requesting a correction for what he deemed "deceitful editing" of an interview and complaining about the blurring of the lines between news on NBC and opinion on its cable news network MSNBC.
The following is a transcript of Senator Barack Obama’s remarks to supporters on the night of the Kentucky and Oregon primaries, as provided by CQ Transcriptions.
The following is a transcript of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s remarks to supporters on the night of the Kentucky and Oregon primaries, as provided by CQ Transcriptions.

Voters in Kentucky and Oregon will likely give Barack Obama enough pledged delegates tonight to give him a majority of the delegates awarded through the nominating contests -- which could cause more undeclared superdelegates to jump off the fence and support him as well.

More than four years after the meltdown of Italy's Parmalat, the food company is set to begin presenting its case to a U.S. jury on Thursday accusing Citigroup of playing a key role in its collapse, Reuters reported.

Updated, 2:15 p.m. | Gov. David A. Paterson checked into a Manhattan hospital this morning -- his 54th birthday -- after feeling symptoms of a migraine headache. It was at least the third time the governor has been hospitalized in recent years. (Doctors have now given him a diagnosis of acute glaucoma in his left eye, which will require a medical procedure today.)

Franklin Bank, the Texas bank led by mortgage bond pioneer Lewis Ranieri, may seek a buyer after an internal probe of lending practices led to the removal of its chief executive and sparked an inquiry by federal regulators, Bloomberg News reported.
From "Saturday Night Live":

Wall Street banks and securities firms aren't owning up to billions of dollars of write-downs on their income statements, instead taking those losses on their balance sheets, Bloomberg News reported. The accounting treatment, used by Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and ING, is perfectly legitimate, but could just be delaying the inevitable.
Carl C. Icahn prides himself on his poker-playing skills. But he may have just made one of the biggest gambles of his career as he tries to shake up Yahoo.
Carlyle Group co-founder David Rubenstein suggested that private equity investment activity has hit a "bottom" and said he expects to see more deals close in the $2 billion to $4 billion range.
Beer commercial hits the campaign trail:

Residential Capital, the distressed mortgage-finance company, said it has enough support from bondholders to proceed with its offer to exchange or buy back $14 billion of debt in an attempt to stave off bankruptcy, Bloomberg News reported.

The fast-growing buyout firm that owns the fashion house Bill Blass, the retailer Athlete's Foot and the ice cream chain MaggieMoo's appears to be on the verge of collapse, The New York Times reported.
Warren E. Buffett may be one of the few Americans who can still afford to come to Europe for a shopping spree.

Wachovia said on Monday it has had significant losses from a Citigroup hedge fund, Reuters reported. The North Carolina bank is one of at least three that has been hit hard by the decline in the Falcon Strategies hedge fund.
More of your "late night" jokes (send via the comment link below):

American Capital Strategies and Autobahn Funding Company have committed a combined $425 million to Core Business Credit, a new commercial finance firm dedicated to middle-market transactions in the United States.
Under its latest proposal to Yahoo, Microsoft would buy its search business and take a stake in the company, The New York Times reported Tuesday, citing people briefed on the negotiations.

Barclays is considering a takeover bid for a rival investment bank, The Telegraph reported Tuesday. Citing unnamed sources, the paper said that Bob Diamond, the head of Barclays' investment bank unit, is thought to have looked at both Lehman Brothers and UBS in the past few weeks.

Middle East investors are increasingly turning their attention to India, drawn by the country's long-term growth prospects and the belief that is somewhat "decoupled" from the woes of the United States, according to a report in BusinessWeek. Private equity participation is set to come to sectors such as real estate, health care, retailing and education, the article said.

Carlyle Group and Blackstone Group's GSO Capital hedge fund say they're being left out in the cold in the case of a bankrupt homebuilder that they claim fraudulently obtained a credit line designed to keep it afloat, The New York Post reported.
Deutsche Bank's private wealth management said Monday that it has appointed Anurag Mahesh as head of global investments and sales for Asia-Pacific, Finance Asia reported.
Metals USA Holdings, a metal processing company owned by Apollo Management, filed to raise as much as $200 million in an initial public offering on the New York Stock Exchange.
AT&T and Vodafone may be circling China's Huawei, according to media reports cited by CNet's News.com.
American International Group will end up raising about $20 billion by selling a variety of securities, much more than the insurer originally planned, MarketWatch reported.
European Aeronautic, Defence & Space is seeking acquisitions in the U.S. to increase its presence in the world's largest military market, its chief executive said according to Bloomberg News.
San Francisco's Bay Area Council is forging deeper links with China and billionaire developer Vincent Lo, reported The San Francisco Business Times.

Biotechnology firms in the United States drew a record $5.5 billion in venture-capital funding in 2007, according to Ernst & Young's annual report card on the industry. But the sector may not be immune from broader economic ills.
Private jet operator Xojet has secured $2.5 billion in a fourth round of funding to help expand its fleet of 20 planes to 127 by 2012.

In a reminder that the wreckage of the disastrous merger between America Online and Time Warner is still being sifted, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday filed fraud charges against eight former AOL executives, saying they had inflated online advertising revenue by more than $1 billion.
The United Steelworkers union has announced it will fight Esmark's sale to India's Essar Steel.

I've always thought that driving in New York City is a bit like a game of touch football between the Jets and the Giants -- you're always seconds away from a painful collision, but for the most part you don't get clobbered. Getting through a traffic jam on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway is a game of inches. So even though I'm a fan of almost anything with a motor and two wheels, I was a bit skeptical about venturing onto the city streets aboard the Vespa S. After touring through Manhattan and Brooklyn on a group ride for journalists, though, I found myself persuaded that scooters are extremely useful for basic city transport -- at least when the weather is cooperative.
Morgan Stanley is cutting as many as 25 jobs at its Japan real estate securitization unit. This marks the second round of reductions this year, Bloomberg News reported citing two unnamed sources.
Citigroup will close two of its British personal loan operations and could cut more than 650 jobs, the bank said in a statement on Monday.

Lionel LLC, the toy train maker, recently pulled out of a three-and-a-half-year stop in bankruptcy protection. The company's chief executive tells Investment Dealers' Digest that, given a few more years and the right conditions, an initial public offering might be in the cards.

Central China Real Estate has kicked off the institutional roadshow for its upcoming I.P.O. The offering could become the first successful Hong Kong listing of a Chinese property company in more than six months, Finance Asia reported.
Permira Advisers has hired Riccardo Ruggiero, Telecom Italia's former chief executive, to help it find technology, media and telecommunications investments.
China's Chongqing Machinery and Electric has launched pre-marketing for a Hong Kong listing that is expected to raise about $200 million.

Aquiline Capital Partners, the private equity firm run by former Marsh & McLennan chief Jeffrey Greenberg, will announce Tuesday that it has formed a new commercial finance firm with more than $1.75 billion in equity commitments.
What is the best way to cook vegetables? It's one of the most common questions asked by readers, so I decided to explore whether boiled, steamed, microwaved or raw is better.

After initially suggesting that the U.K. market would remain flat in 2008, the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors now predicts a 5 percent decline in values and "at least" a 40 percent drop in the number of transactions.

Speaking in Miami, Senator John McCain argued that Senator Barack Obama is too willing to talk to America’s enemies.
The New York Police Department filed administrative charges on Tuesday against a group of officers involved in the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell.
Federal and state officials announced a crackdown against telemarketing scams that have bilked thousands of consumers, many of them elderly, out of tens of millions of dollars.

Gov. David A. Paterson is scheduled to undergo laser eye surgery on Tuesday to relieve the sharp head pain that sent him to the hospital early in the morning.

The bidding war for the British cooking equipment supplier Enodis intensified as the Manitowoc Company came back with a second offer to trump an approach by another American company, Illinois Tool Works.

The Nissan Motor Company and the NEC Corporation plan a joint venture that would invest 12 billion yen ($115 million) over three years to manufacture lithium-ion batteries for use in next-generation green vehicles.
PSA Peugeot Citroën, the European carmaker, and a Japanese rival, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation have agreed to build sport utility vehicles and midsize cars in Russia.

Tim Duncan, Manu Ginobili, Tony Parker and company will be traveling to Los Angeles to face the Lakers in Game 1 of the Western Conference finals on Wednesday.
Charles Barkley said Monday that he had paid the $400,000 he owed the Wynn Resorts in Las Vegas since October and vowed to stop gambling.
When Manager Joe Girardi discussed the Yankees’ 20-24 record on Sunday night, he said he was embarrassed and he acted disgusted.

A lawyer for Tim Donagh, a disgraced former N.B.A. referee, suggested that games had been influenced by relationships between referees, coaches and players.

Avi Schick, president of the state’s economic development agency, which is in the midst of a political overhaul, will step down in September.

The sprinter Justin Gatlin will go before the Court of Arbitration for Sport on May 28-29 in New York to ask for a further reduction in a four-year doping suspension and so that he can defend his Olympic 100-meter title at the Beijing Games. The United States Olympic trials are set for June 27-July 6 in Eugene, Ore.

Less than a month after the N.F.L. reinstated linebacker Odell Thurman from a two-year suspension, he was waived by Cincinnati. The Bengals appeared to support Thurman during his suspension for violating the league’s substance-abuse and conduct policies. But when he did not attend voluntary on-field workouts last week, the team, which is installing a new defense, let him go. Thurman said he was in Georgia after the death of his grandmother.

A newspaper photographer in Provo, Utah, was speared through the leg by a javelin at a high school meet. Ryan McGeeney of The Standard-Examiner was spared serious injury Saturday, and even managed to snap a photo of his speared leg while others tended to him. “If I didn’t, it would probably be my editor’s first question when I got back,” said McGeeney, a 33-year-old ex-Marine who spent six months in Afghanistan.

Stefan Edberg will return to competitive tennis for the first time in 12 years with two matches on the senior tour. Edberg, 42, who won two Wimbledon titles among his six Grand Slam crowns, had declined to play seniors events but changed his mind when Pete Sampras announced he would play two events this year.

Despite having her training interrupted by treatment for a hip injury, the marathon world-record holder Paula Radcliffe was selected for Britain’s team for the Beijing Olympics. Radcliffe, 34, failed to finish the marathon in Athens four years ago even though she was one of the favorites. She won the New York City Marathon in November — which served as her Olympic qualifying time — but a toe injury forced her to miss the London Marathon last month.

A Florida veterinarian who has conducted a national investigation into breakdowns involving racehorses was named as Kentucky’s first equine medical director. The veterinarian, Dr. Mary Scollay, will help advise on whether — and how — the state should impose steroid tests. The hiring comes at a time when officials have been under fire for not putting in a broad ban on anabolic steroids.
A journal written in Korean led police from a house where a man, his mother and an uncle were found stabbed to death to a casino near Los Angeles.
Columbia University is preparing for its first N.C.A.A. Division baseball tournament appearance since 1976.
Dell, the computer maker, said Monday that Donald J. Carty, hired as chief financial officer a year and a half ago to help lead a turnaround, would resign in June.
Once considered a jewel of the country’s medical system, Ibn Rushid hospital has only four psychiatrists left.
Thousands of Chinese have streamed into the quake region or donated money in an unscripted response.
The next president will have to appoint a skilled and creative team of advisers on the Middle East and be a more honest broker than President Bush has been.
An 85-year-old water main burst beneath West 57th Street, sending torrents of water, some laced with small amounts of asbestos, into a busy commercial district.
Until the Food and Drug Administration rules on bisphenol-a, consumers would be wise to avoid it for babies and young children and use BPA-free alternatives.
The indefinite suspension of alternate-side parking rules in Park Slope, Brooklyn, took effect, and residents and drivers greeted the change with a mix of reactions.
Congress must obtain the promised funds for the Second Chance Act so that states can develop their own reintegration programs for newly released prisoners.

The construction worker who buried a David Ortiz jersey in the cement foundation of the new Yankee Stadium has told friends he buried other Red Sox memorabilia as well.
St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan returned from the drawing board with a more modest redesign of its $1.6 billion development proposal that had been rejected.
A foster mother has been arrested and accused of accidentally killing a 6-year-old girl in her care by placing a powerful medicinal patch on the child’s neck.
Barack Obama is poised to have a majority of pledged delegates after voting in Kentucky and Oregon, but the situation is delicate as he tries to unify his party.
A lawyer for track coach Trevor Graham said in opening arguments at trial Monday that Graham was “the original Balco whistleblower.”

Lowe’s, the second-largest home improvement chain behind Home Depot, cut its forecast for full-year profit and sales and said earnings for the current quarter would trail the year-earlier level.

The House of Commons has defeated a bill that would have banned the creation of so-called hybrid embryos — part human and part animal — for medical research.
An Op-Chart on Friday was premature in describing the accomplishments of the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope. The telescope is not expected to be completed until 2014.
At the N.B.A. draft lottery on Tuesday, a fortunate bounce of the Ping-Pong balls could lend a major boost to the rebuilding efforts of the Knicks’ new management.

Stocks ended mixed Monday after weakness in the technology sector punctured some of the market’s enthusiasm over a report that suggested the economy could still be growing.
The Supreme Court upheld the latest Congressional effort to curb the spread of child pornography on the Internet.

Though quarterly profits, helped by the sale of a chocolate unit, more than doubled from the period a year earlier, results at the Campbell Soup Company fell short of forecasts.

Major League Soccer has imported big-name stars from abroad to bring a certain sophistication to the game. Yet the league remains largely one of haves and have-nots.

“Good Boys and True,” about a scandal at a prep school, is a standard-issue issue play written by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa and acted competently by a likable cast.

ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” delivered Sunday’s top ratings, as the closing minutes of the show’s fourth season gave viewers a brief flash-forward five years into the future. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two-hour finale attracted 16.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., in line with its performance earlier this spring but down two million from its third-season finale a year ago. ABC led the night’s ratings over all. The finale of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition,” from 7 to 9 p.m., attracted a modest 9.4 million viewers, although the show’s second hour averaged 3.5 million more viewers than its first. CBS was runner-up for the night thanks to “60 Minutes” at 7 (10.7 million), followed by the Academy of Country Music Awards, which drew 11.7 million viewers from 8 to 11 p.m., an increase of 2.4 million from a year ago. Fox finished third over all, with season finales of “The Simpsons” at 8 (6.1 million), “King of the Hill” at 8:30 (5.4 million) and “American Dad” at 9:30 (5.6 million). NBC was fourth.
Bartlett Sher has agreed to direct the previously announced new musical by David Henry Hwang and David Yazbeck, “Bruce Lee: Journey to the West.”
“Free for All,” an oral history of the Public Theater, has a 2009 publication date.

No sooner had the Academy of Country Music handed out its awards on Sunday than Kenny Chesney, above, objected to the method that gave him his fourth straight win as entertainer of the year. For the first time in the show’s 43 years, its foremost accolade, traditionally decided by academy members, was determined in an online vote by the public. Backstage on Sunday night, Mr. Chesney said that although he favored the inclusion of fans, he did not think they should determine the academy’s most important award, The Associated Press reported. He emphasized that his criticism was directed at the industry, not the fans, and said that this year’s voting method amounted to “complete disrespect” of the artists, turning the award “into a sweepstakes to see who can push people’s buttons the hardest on the Internet.” The academy did not immediately respond to messages seeking comment. At the ceremony in Las Vegas, Brad Paisley was named top male vocalist and Carrie Underwood top female vocalist, both for the second consecutive time. Honors for vocal group went to Rascal Flatts (six in a row) and for vocal duo to Brooks & Dunn (13 in a row).
Claudius Conrad is investigating music’s power to both stimulate and soothe.

The John Grisham novel “Playing for Pizza” will have its shot at the big screen. Executives at Phoenix Pictures said Monday that they had acquired rights to develop a feature film based on the book, about a washed-up National Football League quarterback who joins a semiprofessional team playing American football in Italy. Mr. Grisham is best known for legal thrillers, several of which became the basis for hit movies, among them “The Pelican Brief” and “The Firm.” Mike Medavoy and Arnie Messer of Phoenix Pictures expect to join the company’s co-president of production, David Thwaites, in producing the film. Among Phoenix’s credits are “Zodiac” and “All the King’s Men.”.

Marty Asher, the editor in chief of the Vintage Anchor paperback imprint of Alfred A. Knopf, is stepping down from his position after 21 years to become an editor at large at the company. In a staff memo, Sonny Mehta, chairman and chief executive of Knopf, said Mr. Asher, 63, wanted to “devote more time to acquiring and editing books.” While he ran the paperback imprint, which largely repackages books already published in hardcover, Mr. Asher’s acquisitions included “Stumbling on Happiness” by Dan Gilbert and “Letter to a Christian Nation” by Sam Harris. He will now spend his time looking for new books and editing them. During his tenure at Vintage Anchor, Mr. Asher, in partnership with Anne Messitte, the imprint’s publisher, helped quadruple gross sales in the last two decades. He also helped shepherd the paperback fortunes of authors including Charles Frazier, David Guterson and Nicholson Baker. Mr. Asher did not return a call seeking comment. Mr. Asher, who reported directly to Mr. Mehta, will be replaced by LuAnn Walther, who is being appointed editorial director of Vintage Anchor, and Edward Kastenmeier, who is being named executive editor of the paperback imprint. Both will report to Ms. Messitte.
Katie Holmes will star next fall in a Broadway revival of Arthur Miller’s “All My Sons.”

JOHNSTON--Anita Donner Greenberg, died on May 16, 2008 after 18 years living with lung cancer. A resident of East Norwich and Brookville, NY. A founding Director of The Lung Cancer Online Foundation which honored her with a research award in her name. A trailblazer in lung cancer advocacy, her tireless, selfless devotion to the cause made possible much of what has been accomplished in the recognition of lung cancer as a major public health nightmare. Her efforts have helped in the destigmatization and humanization of lung cancer for all stricken with it. Survived by her sister Cynthia Brodsky, three children, Laurie, Jon and Jill Greenberg, son-in-law Dr. Mitchell Lester, five grandchildren, James and Michael Andresakis, Leah and Sarah Greenberg, Beth Lester, great-grandchild Michael Andresakis Jr. Donations can be made to Lung Cancer Alliance or Cancer Care in lieu of flowers.

We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her family, especially husband, David Burmester, and daughter, our dear niece, Jennifer Flowers and Jen's fiancee, Alex Maldonado. William E. Flowers, Chairman, Kenneth F. Flowers, President, The Clark & Wilkins Co.

HELLER--Gene, a prominent real estate developer, died Saturday at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, FL at the age of 72. Mr. Heller was diagnosed with Melanoma in January, 2007. Mr. Heller was born in Wilkes-Barre, PA and moved to Newark, NJ at an early age. He graduated Weequahic High School and attended Rutgers University. Mr. Heller later served as a trustee of Rutgers University and Hackensack Hospital. Mr. Heller was involved in a family business with his brothers. He then left and went on to pursue a career in real estate development. He joined with Leonard Stern to co-found the Hartz Mountain Real Estate business. At Hartz, he had the vision for the transformation of the Secaucus Meadowlands from swamp to mixed-use development consisting of residential, hotels, retail, industrial and offices. Under his leadership, Hartz developed approximately 40 million square feet of space throughout New Jersey. In 1991, Mr. Heller went on to establish his own company, G. Heller Enterprises. Mr. Heller is credited with being the driving force behind the rebirth and revitalization of Edgewater, NJ which is part of New Jersey's Gold Coast, as well as other projects in New Jersey. Mr. Heller became a Florida resident in 2006 and enjoyed golf, traveling, spending time with close friends and was an avid St. Louis Cardinals Fan. His greatest joy was being with family. He will be deeply missed by his beloved wife, Penny, his son Tod, his daughter Bonni Konefsky and her husband Steve. He was also a devoted grandfather to Marisa, Jennifer and Jordyn. Mr. Heller is also survived by his former wife, Ticia Heller. Funeral services will be held at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ (1800-938-6372) on Wednesday May 21st, 2008 at 11am. Donations may be made to Yale Cancer Center Melanoma Unit Clinical Research Program, 333 Cedar Street, New Haven, CT 06520.

Jacobs, Rabbi Jonathan Blake, Asst. Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor Jack Stern, Rabbi Emeritus NOREK--Jay Irwin, 86, of Mamaroneck, NY passed away on May 18, 2008. He is survived by his wife Ruth, his soul mate since childhood; children Alfred and wife Meryl of Slingerlands, NY, Susan and husband Nestor Guzman of Scottsdale, AZ, and Betty and husband Dr. Alan Feldman of Fairfield, CT. He was the beloved ''Papa'' to grandchildren Josh Norek, Jennifer Cafarella, Emily and Max Feldman and great-grandchildren Emma and Zoe Cafarella, who ere the recipients of countless corny jokes and loving attention. Jay was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and a decorated Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy, having served on the destroyer USS Betelgeuse in both the Pacific and Atlantic theatres during WWII. Jay was a pioneer in the recreation industry, operating indoor tennis facilities and health clubs, and a founder of the New England Tennis camps. An avid vocalist, Jay sang in several choirs and was most proud of his affiliation with the Westchester Golden Chordsmen. He was a strong supporter of Jewish charitable causes including the Jewish Community Center of Mid-Westchester, Israel Bonds and the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York. A funeral service will be held on May 20, 2008 at 11:30am, at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. To our uncle Jay, we will miss your dirty jokes and amazing sense of humor. Your marriage to Aunt Ruth was one of absolute love and was a treat to witness. Thank you so much for all your support and love. Sam Rosenblatt and Mario D'Andrea NOREK--Jay. Stenberg, President NOREK--Jay. Singer. Jingleist. Joke-Teller. We will miss you, Jay. Charlie, Ed, Roy, Ira, Herb, Bob and Bob.

CELENZA--Dr. Frank Vincent, died quietly at his home with his loving and dedicated wife Raquel nearby Saturday, May 17 after several difficult years of steadily declining health. Prosthodontist, author, international lecturer and mentor to hundreds of dentists around the globe, he shaped the careers of many of the world's leading authorities in specialty dentistry today. He is survived by his eldest son, Dr. Vincent, also a prosthodontist practicing in New York City, father of two sons, Frank and Luke; Dr. Andrea, a psychoanalyst residing in Lexington, MA, mother of Derek and Ethan; daughter Raquel, producer living in Los Angeles, mother of Christopher; and youngest son, Dr. Frank Jr., specialist in adult periodontics and orthodontics practicing in New York City, father of Nicholas, Olivia and Alex. He was an active member of the Columbus Citizens Foundation where he was able to meld his love of gourmet food, fine wines and opera hosting over 70 now legendary opera nights. The surviving family will host a wake at the Fairchild Funeral Home in Manhasset, L.I. on Wednesday, May 21 from 2 to 5pm and 7 to 10pm, and a private family funeral mass will be held the following day. A memorial service is forthcoming in New York City to celebrate the life of this extraordinary man who touched the lives of so many. Details to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to New York University College of Dentistry Celenza Family Fund, attention: Assistant Dean, Rita Startup, 345 East 24th Street, New York, NY 10010 or the Columbus Citizens Foundation, attention: Christine Meola, 8 East 69th Street, New York, NY 10021.

Former Vice President Al Gore is stepping out for the Democratic Party on May 31 -- not to endorse a particular candidate, but to help the party raise money. Mr. Gore, below, is to be the featured guest at a ''unity dinner'' in New York City, with big donors to both Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama helping to organize it. It will be the 11th fund-raiser held by the party and donors to the two campaigns across the country since early March.

KAHAN--Henrietta, age 90, died on May 19th after a valiant struggle with cancer. Beloved mom of Eda and Steven Baruch, Leah Feldon, Jonathan and Barbara Kahan and Deborah Kahan and Stephen Kalos. Adored grandma of Elise and John Trainor, Jason and Maree Baruch, Seth and Jennifer Baruch, Rachel Kahan, Paul, David and Adam Kahan and Joel, Noah and Jake Kalos. She also leaves five greatgrandchildren, Evan and Jenna, Audra and Helena and Benjamin. She loved her family (especially her grandchildren), nature (especially birds and the beach), a good scrabble game (especially winning it), and her many friends (especially in a good bridge game). Most of all she loved her darling Paul, who predeceased her. She was a strong woman who led a full life. She will forever be in the hearts of us all. Services will be held at 3pm, Wednesday, May 21st at Mt. Nebo-Kendall Cemetery, 5900 SW 77th Avenue, Miami (305 372-0641).

WRIGHT--Jordan M., age 50. Our loving son Jordan passed away Sunday, May 11, 2008. He was the greatest gift from God. He is the founder of the Museum of Democracy and his collection of political memorabilia, considered the finest private collection in the United States, will be lent to the museum of the city of New York for an exhibition from June 23 to December 2008. He authored a book entitled ''Campaigning for President'' which was published by Harper Collins in January 2008. The book was reviewed in the New York Times Book Review as well as the Wall Street Journal. A graduate of Columbia University and Vanderbilt University Law School, he became an attorney in Pennsylvania and New York. He was also a photographer whose photos of New Guinea were shown under the auspices of the Smithsonian Museums and displayed throughout the United States and many parts of the world. Finally, through his company, Volo, he published the magazine entitled ''Pacific Arts''. Survived by our grandchildren Austin and Mackenzie, sister Ingrid Wright. Services and interment private. Faith-Dorian and Martin Wright

RAUSCHENBERG--Robert, died May 12, 2008, at his Captiva studio of heart failure. Considered by many to be the greatest living artist, Bob Rauschenberg made artworks that reflected his boundless, enthusiastic appreciation of the fabric of daily life and his passionate curiosity about the world. As a young artist, he couldn't always afford new canvases but he couldn't stop painting either so he would make new paintings right over his old ones. He was a major innovator in the fields of painting, sculpture, dance and print making. Bob's muse and friend Illeana Sonnabend said of his art, ''There was a spiritual quality in his works, as well as a poetic and ephemeral quality. People like to hold on to what they know. Bob likes to shake them out of their habits.'' He was incredibly generous and openhearted. He would cook fabulous dinners for 10 or 20 people and then invite everyone in range to eat. He approached life with a child's optimistic exuberance and was a dogged warrior for peace and the environment. Bob never turned his back on anyone in need. Bob is survived by his sister Janet Rauschenberg Begneaud and her husband, Byron, of Lafayette LA; son, Christopher Rauschenberg and his wife Janet Stein, of Portland OR; nephew Rick Begneaud; grandnephew, Dylan Rauschenberg Begneaud, grandniece, Logan Coleen Begneaud, all of Mill Valley CA, and friend and collaborator Darryl Pottorf of Captiva, FL. To commemorate Bob's long standing involvement in his community a memorial exhibition at the Bob Rauschenberg Gallery, Edison College, Fort Myers, FL will be planned and announced in the near future and a tribute to his art and life is being planned for New York, NY. Bob loved flowers but he would rather have you honor his memory, if you so choose, by making a donation to Change Inc., a foundation he created to give money to artists for emergency needs. Donations may be mailed to Change, Inc., PO Box 54, Captiva, FL 33924.

KARASIK--Muriel, the longtime ardent supporter and fundraiser for the Samuel Waxman Foundation for Cancer Research, passed away at her home in Great Neck on Monday morning after a long illness. She was 80 years old. Mrs. Karasik will be remembered fondly in the world of fine art for her exquisite taste and her keen eye for acquisitions. Born in NYC, the daughter of Jack and Belle Linsky, Muriel was a second generation collector whose love of art was secondary only to that of the love of her family. Muriel Karasik was beloved mother to Richard and Lori Mintzer, David and Nancy Mintzer, Elisabeth Mintzer Frankel, Albert and Victoria Benalloul and Charles and Elena Karasik and beloved grandmother of Alex, Zach, Rebekah, Adam, Benjamin, Olivia, Sam, Andrew, Spencer, Gabby, Isaiah and Jake. She is also survived by her sister Lenore Hecht. Services will be held on Wednesday morning May 21st, 2008 at Riverside Chapel in Great Neck, NY 10am.

An aide to President Bush sent a letter on Monday to the head of NBC News requesting a correction for what he deemed ''deceitful editing'' of an interview and complaining about the blurring of the lines between news on NBC and opinion on its cable news network MSNBC. White House press officials sometimes request corrections at daily press briefings and distribute ''setting the record straight'' statements about news coverage. But letters to news executives released by the White House to ensure widespread coverage of the complaint are rare.

GOLDBERGER--Walter, died accidentally and tragically on May 15th in his 78th year. Brother to the late Arthur Goldberger, he is survived by his aunt Ethel, sister-in-law Maureen, nieces Susan and Julie, great-nephew Cody, many loving cousins and countless friends. Memorial service will be held Tuesday, May 20th, 7:30pm, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street.

9 P.M. (National Geographic) LEFT FOR DEAD: MIRACLE ON EVEREST On May 25, 2006, after developing altitude sickness while descending Mount Everest, Lincoln Hall was left for dead. Attempts by Sherpas to revive him failed, and they were ordered down the mountain by their expedition leader. The next morning, another team came across a man sitting cross-legged near a 10,000-foot drop, changing his shirt. It was Mr. Hall, who was alive after spending the night at an altitude of about 28,000 feet with no oxygen mask, sleeping bag, food or water, and barely any clothes. This is the story of his survival. Above, a scene from the program. 8 P.M. (13) LORD OF THE ANTS They call him the ant man, and at 78, E. O. Wilson hasn't begun to give up his boyhood fondness for exploration. This ''Nova'' special delves into the life of Mr. Wilson, an emeritus professor at Harvard and two-time Pulitzer Prize winner who, David Attenborough says, ''opened up the eyes of millions round the world to the glories, the values, the importance of, to use his term, biodiversity.'' Harrison Ford narrates.

My Thursday column is about the aftermath of the Sichuan earthquake, and what it says about China. I argue that the reaction to the quake shows some of the positive evolution in China over the years, away from a top-down authoritarianism to a less controlled model that isn't a democracy but still is somewhat sensitive to public opinion.

What else is there to say. Monaco. The biggest race of the Formula One calendar. And I arrived last night, since Monaco is also the only race where there is a practice session on the Thursday, and therefore a press conference on the Wednesday. The press conference was interesting for the contrasting views of racing in Monaco, from Sebastien Bourdais' interesting and precise description of what attitude a driver needs to have to go fast here, and why he likes this track, to Felipe Massa's flat statement of dislike for the track. He prefers tracks like Turkey (surprise, surprise) and even China. See details on the FIA site, when it gets there....

Much of the recent heat over biofuels has been focused on how much this booming business may have contributed to the international spike in food prices that has had an outsize impact on poor people. Defenders of farm-grown fuels point to studies showing the biofuels boom has had a minor impact on food prices compared to the surge in energy costs. They also say the eventual goal is to shift away from sources like corn toward plants harvested for their cellulose -- ending competition with cropland or food markets.

When it comes to trying to figure out what we should do in Iraq, the presidential campaign debates are close to useless. Television talk shows, with their ratings-driven shouting matches, are worse. (And even though you're reading a blog, let's not talk about what gets said in most of the blogosphere.)

Poor Detroit. The local economy is crumbling, there are no jobs, the mayor -- who is accused of perjury, obstruction of justice and misconduct in office charges -- spends all his time fighting to save his own job. You know, small stuff. But now, real problems of apocalyptic proportions: the first three games of the Stanley Cup final are going head to head with three Pistons-Celtics NBA semifinal games. On two of those dates, they'll both be playing home games. The horror. THE HORROR!

Here's another dish, like those in today's Minimalist column, that's usually grilled but that works just as well, if not better, in the broiler. For years I never realized that one of the greatest assets of my favorite grilled shrimp dish -- the juices that the shrimp exude -- was just sputtering away on those hot coals. That's why broiled shrimp are so desirable: you get to savor the juices, the essences, produced by the shrimp itself.

When I was a kid growing up in Wisconsin, my grandmother used to take me to the only dentist in the county for regular checkups. Somehow, despite never having a toothache and never eating sweets or drinking soda, I had a mouth full of cavities that necessitated nearly weekly trips for filling after filling -- or so the dentist would have my grandmother believe. That was the era when the authority of doctors and dentists was never questioned. The guys in the white coats were to be respected and their orders followed. It seems as if the American horse racing industry never left that era.

At United States Marine Hospital 43, the hospital on Ellis Island, the powerhouse and laundry building housed the mortuary and autopsy room. Bodies were refrigerated in these eight compartments in the wall. The site was used as a teaching area, and was associated with the Long Island College Hospital. More than 12 million immigrants were processed on Ellis Island, and more than 3,500 died, including about 1,400 children.

Outside.in, a New York-based company that aggregates news and blog discussion around towns and neighborhoods, said Tuesday it has raised $3 million in venture funding and hired a new chief executive, former About.com general manager Mark Josephson.

Bankers at Jefferies Group on Wednesday forecast an improved deal pipeline for initial public offerings for companies in the business of reducing the world's carbon emissions and fossil-fuel consumption, following a dry spell in the first quarter.

Ahmad Fadam was the head of the Iraqi staff in the newsroom of The New York Times in Baghdad. He left Baghdad in May to take up a visiting fellowship at the University of North Carolina. He will continue to contribute to the Baghdad Bureau blog from there.
More of your "late night" jokes (send via the comment link below):
The developer of a Trump residential tower in Panama is defending itself against charges it copied the design of the legendary Burj Al Arab hotel in Dubai.
Manchester United won its third European title at the expense of English rival Chelsea in a rain-soaked penalty shootout.

I hope that's the Japanese sentiment of good luck, as I respectfully wish good things for Casino Drive. Let's take a look at the big picture and try to figure out what Casino Drive is trying to attain.
Across the English Channel, Matt finds art, beer, fries, but also refugees struggling to survive.
Across the English Channel, Matt finds art, beer, fries, but also refugees struggling to survive.
“Depression: Out of the Shadows,” a stark documentary on Wednesday on PBS, makes clear just how devastating clinical depression is.
Location: Ypsilanti, Mich.
Among the thousands of students gathering for today's commencement ceremonies at Columbia University on Morningside Heights, there will be one with a remarkable Olympic background.
Senator Barack Obama declared the nomination “within reach,” while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton continued to make a case that she could prevail.
Senator Barack Obama took a big step toward becoming the Democratic presidential nominee on Tuesday. (Video: MSNBC)

She's got her white voters. He's got his. Her whites go to church every week. His whites are more secular. Her whites have dirt under their fingernails. His are more likely to be changing ink cartridges in the office. Her whites like the hard stuff. His whites will choose Oregon pinot.
“A Jihad for Love” is a dispatch from the outer limits of marginalization: a documentary on devout Muslims struggling with their homosexuality.
In the course of the extraordinary film “The Edge of Heaven,” children are lost, lost parents are never found, and generational and geographical distances grow wider.
For wine lovers, a raft of absorbing new books will help ease the economic blues.
Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama both made campaign stops in Florida, a state whose Democratic delegates have been blocked from the party convention.
The two governors, Charlie Crist and Bobby Jindal, and Mitt Romney are viewed as contenders to run with Senator John McCain.
Business owners are learning how to leverage Web sites that attract young young cosmopolitan customers in their sales efforts.
Despite the downbeat outlook, officials left the impression that they would not be in favor of more interest rate cuts.
Top oil executives tried to shift anger over high prices to a debate over supplies on Wednesday, leading a senator to accuse them of acting like “hapless victims” while racking up record profits.
Maurice R. Greenberg may face civil charges over allegations that he improperly inflated the insurer’s financial statements, a spokesman for Mr. Greenberg said.

A leak of refrigerated gas killed three people on a cargo ship in Fort Lauderdale, a supervisor investigating reports that workers were dizzy and two employees who tried to save him, the authorities said. The victims were found unconscious in the hull of the ship, the Broward County Sheriff’s Office said. The cause of death was chemical asphyxia as a result of inhaling argon gas, which had been leaking from a container the workers were loading. Argon is colorless, odorless and nontoxic, but it can cause suffocation in a contained space. The victims were employees of Florida Transportation Services.
The Boston Celtics beat the Detroit Pistons on Tuesday, maintaining their playoff dominance at TD Banknorth Garden.

New Orleans Saints defensive end Charles Grant has been indicted on a charge of involuntary manslaughter stemming from a February altercation at a Georgia nightclub. An Early County grand jury also charged six other people in the shooting death of Korynda Reed, 23. Grant was stabbed in the neck during the fracas. He was selected by the Saints in the first round of the 2002 draft. He had two and a half sacks in 2007 while starting 14 games for the Saints.
Aided by his army of small donors, Barack Obama bested Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain in April fund-raising.
The shrinking candidacy of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton all but vanished from the television set Tuesday, sidelined by bigger news.
Alex Rodriguez hit a home run on his first game back after a 17-game absence, but Tuesday’s loss was as bad as any of the others the team has suffered this season.
Bergen County authorities are investigating the deaths of two men whose bodies were found in separate communities.
Strong sales of delivered office products to corporate customers at home and overseas helped Staples post a 1.5 percent increase in its first-quarter profit.
Despite news that Airbus had won its biggest contract ever for its next-generation A350 business jet, UBS downgraded shares in its parent company, EADS.
The proposal fell far short of the liberal farm policy favored by countries like Britain but sharpened a debate with France, which has sought to preserve generous support for agriculture.
General Motors reached a tentative labor agreement Tuesday evening at a critical assembly plant in Kansas City, Kan.
After a victory in Oregon and a lopsided loss in Kentucky, Barack Obama said he had enough pledged delegates to claim a nearly insurmountable edge.
A Harlem woman apparently did not check with her foster-care agency before placing a medicinal patch on the neck of a 6-year-old girl, who later died.
As they mourned, friends and family of Gary A. Berwick, a retired New York State Police inspector, struggled to understand what drove him to suicide at his home.
State prosecutors have asked for a six-year prison term for the chairman of Hyundai Motor, Chung Mong-koo, left, who was convicted of embezzlement and breach of trust last year.
The government of Iceland’s bond rating was lowered to Aa1 from Aaa by Moody’s Investors Service on growing concern that the country’s banks may face a credit squeeze.
Eddie Guardado, a former All-star with the Minnesota Twins, has used his gutsy approach to fuel a comeback from Tommy John surgery en route to a mini-revival this year with Texas.

Lindsay Davenport has pulled out of the French Open, the only Grand Slam singles event that she has not won. Tournament organizers said that Davenport, 31, withdrew for personal reasons. Davenport’s best singles finish on the Paris clay came when she reached the semifinals in 1998. She won the French Open doubles title with Mary Joe Fernandez in 1996.

Landon Donovan was among 22 players picked for the United States men’s national team’s exhibition game at England next week and could make his 100th international appearance. Donovan, who leads the United States with 35 career goals, will be 26 years 2 months 24 days old when the Americans play at Wembley next Wednesday. According to the United States Soccer Federation, the only men to reach 100 appearances for their country at a younger age were South Korea’s Cha Bum-Kun, who was 24 when he reached 100 in 1977; and Saudi Arabia’s Sami al-Jaber and Mohammed al-Deayea, who were each 25 in 1998.
German investor confidence declined for a second straight month as rising inflation, the euro’s strength and high oil prices curtailed expectations, a closely watched survey showed.
The Bank of Japan left interest rates unchanged at 0.5 percent, opting to take more time to determine when the fog will clear from the economy, both in Japan and around the world.

Matt Ryan signed a six-year, $72 million contract with the Atlanta Falcons on Tuesday, ending concerns that prolonged negotiations could threaten his chance to become the starting quarterback as a rookie. Ryan, the No. 3 pick in last month’s N.F.L. draft out of Boston College, is guaranteed $34.75 million. His guaranteed money is $4.75 million more than that given to Dolphins offensive tackle Jake Long, the No. 1 choice, who is also represented by the agent Tom Condon.
F.C. Dallas of Major League Soccer fired Coach Steve Morrow after losing its last four games, including a 5-1 thumping by the Los Angeles Galaxy on Sunday.

Juan Pablo Montoya will have his third crew chief in a month when Brian Pattie takes over the No. 42 Dodge for this week’s race in Concord, N.C. Pattie replaces Jimmy Elledge, who was put in charge of the car four races ago in a crew shakeup at Chip Ganassi Racing. Elledge initially exchanged places with Donnie Wingo, who guided Montoya’s transition from Formula One to Nascar, but was moved to Reed Sorenson’s crew in the swap. Montoya is 16th in points with one top-10 finish this season, a second last month in Elledge’s first race leading the crew. He then finished 32nd in Richmond and 23rd in Darlington.
Dan Uggla hit his 14th home run as the Florida Marlins won the opening game in a series between division leaders.
The Supreme Court’s upholding of a law that attempts to ban child pornography risks weakening the protections of free speech.
No one wants a confrontation, but the world cannot sit by while more people die in Myanmar because the junta refuses to cooperate.
Delegates from the United States-backed governing coalition and the Hezbollah-led opposition reached a deal to end a political conflict that had pushed their country to the brink of a new civil war.
An analyst who heard scoffing when he predicted $100-a-barrel oil now expects the price to reach $200.
The buyers of Penn National Gaming and their lenders are working to negotiate the final terms of the financing commitments, people briefed on the matter said.
Tariq Aziz could face the death penalty if he is convicted of having had a role in the 1992 execution of 42 Baghdad merchants who were accused of profiteering on foodstuffs.
For New York City’s five million commuters, especially those struggling with the stairs, any real improvement with stairway alternatives cannot come soon enough.
METRO.

Violent attacks against immigrants, a siege of mayhem that has afflicted the Johannesburg area for more than a week, began to ease, though two more foreigners were killed, bringing the death toll to at least 24 people.
A court in Cyprus has denied Russia’s request to extradite Vladislav Kartashov, a former executive of Yukos, once Russia’s largest oil company.
Farm leaders said they expected talks with the government to restart as soon as Wednesday, after they suspended a national strike and returned to the negotiating table.

Ma Ying-jeou, a Nationalist, took office as president and used his inaugural speech to repeat campaign promises that he would seek closer economic relations with mainland China and an eventual peace accord.
India and Pakistan held high-level talks in Islamabad, marking the first peace negotiations between the rival nuclear nations after a 15-month lapse.
The suspected top political leader of the Basque separatist group ETA was arrested in southwestern France in a joint operation by the French and Spanish police, Spanish anti-terrorism sources said.
The Yankees have struggled to score runs without their best player in the cleanup spot, and they were relieved to have him back after a 17-game absence.
A bad day ended on a frightening note for the Mets when Ryan Church sustained a concussion trying to prevent the final out in a day-night doubleheader dominated by the Braves.
After an arbitration panel awarded city police officers a raise amounting to 9.7 percent over two years, the firefighters’ union said that would reopen its contract covering the same two years.
The Franklin Bank Corporation appears to have ignored the admonitions of its founder, who had warned for the last few years that the housing market was about to collapse.
Public pension actuaries use old methods that have fallen far out of sync with the economic mainstream.
While the former N.B.A. referee Tim Donaghy awaits his fate in federal court, his lawyer and league officials are trading accusations through the courts and the news media.
Some families of Olympic athletes have been shocked to learn that the price of attending the Games this August may be between $5,000 and $10,000 a person.
Water was in short supply on the north side of 57th Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, where a water main break the day before had forced a shutdown.
The Chicago Bulls beat the odds to earn the right to take one of the two consensus top choices in the draft, Derrick Rose of Memphis or Michael Beasley of Kansas State.
The National Trust for Historic Preservation has designated the Lower East Side of Manhattan as one of the 11 most endangered in places in America.
Senators say the legislation approved on Tuesday to help suffering homeowners refinance costly loans could rescue the housing market, but others say the plan is riskier than it seems.
States should be given greater powers to enforce new regulations proposed to curb the hard-sell tactics used to foist private Medicare policies on unwary consumers.
Nikola Tamindzic, a night-life photographer, talks about what he tries to put into his shots.
Parliament voted to keep the legal limit on abortion at 24 weeks, disappointing campaigners who had sought to lower the limit.
The Mets manager was asked to clarify remarks in which he wondered whether he was held to a different standard than some of his white counterparts.
Many people within the Giants’ organization have had to parry questions about the futures of Jeremy Shockey and Michael Strahan.
Seven New York City police officers were formally accused of breaking department rules in the shooting of Sean Bell.
The former lieutenant colonel at the center of an inquiry into the State Police has sought to rebut suggestions that he ran a rogue unit specializing in political favors and dirty tricks.
The medical device maker Medtronic posted higher-than-expected quarterly earnings Tuesday as a recent acquisition increased sales in its spinal products division.
The San Antonio Spurs slept on their plane after mechanical problems forced them to stay in New Orleans and they could not find hotel rooms in the city.
Red Sox catcher Jason Varitek has caught four no-hitters, more than anyone in baseball history.
Mike Piazza, the best-hitting catcher in major league history and a near-certain Hall of Famer, announced his retirement from baseball on Tuesday.
Nearly 30 cities across the United States have seen their scheduled service disappear in the last year.
The American Bible Society said its president and chief financial officer had been placed on temporary leave following reports of payments made to a contractor with ties to online pornography.
A judge has ruled that the Bloomberg administration can continue to build athletic fields on Randalls Island even though a deal to help pay construction costs was voided earlier this year.
A report provides the fullest account to date of internal dissent and confusion within the Bush administration over the use of harsh interrogation tactics.
The White House dismissed a report in The Jerusalem Post that President Bush was preparing to order an attack on Iran a day after it made an even angrier attack on NBC.
The Lakers and the Spurs, who have combined to win seven of the last nine championships, meet again, with the winner taking a giant step toward this year’s title.
The decision by Vito J. Fossella not to seek another term in Congress has roiled the political waters of his reliably Republican district.
Home Depot and Target both reported lower earnings, which they said were linked to the weak economy and battered housing industry.
Gov. David A. Paterson underwent surgery to relieve sharp pain that doctors determined was caused by glaucoma.
Dr. Edwards was a leading cardiac pathologist who assembled a formidable collection of human hearts to let doctors study coronary disease, congenital defects and trauma.

A former schoolteacher was sentenced in Fort Lauderdale to more than seven years in prison for forcing a Haitian girl to work as a virtual slave in her home. The defendant, Maude Paulin, told the court at her sentencing that she had made some mistakes while raising Simone Celestin, but she would not admit she held the girl as a forced laborer. Ms. Paulin, 52, along with her mother, Evelyn Theodore, 74, were convicted of conspiring to violate Ms. Celestin’s civil rights and compelling her to perform forced labor. Ms. Theodore’s sentencing was postponed because she suffered a stroke shortly after her sentencing in March. Ms. Celestin told jurors in March she worked 15 hours a day, was sometimes beaten by the women and was forced to eat table scraps. “I love Simone with all my heart,” said Ms. Paulin at the sentencing hearing. “I regret it. I blame myself.”.

The State Department of Insurance says a body found in a wooded area south of Charlotte is that of an investigator believed killed on the job. The authorities say Sallie Rohrbach, 44, was killed by the owner of an insurance agency she had been sent to audit. Prosecutors have charged an insurance agency owner, Michael Howell, with first-degree murder.
Agriculture Secretary Ed Schafer announced a total ban on the slaughter at meat plants of cows too sick or weak to stand.

A woman who was forgotten in a courthouse holding cell for four days without food or water will not be prosecuted on the charge that landed her there, a prosecutor in Fayetteville said. A charge of selling pirated recordings was dropped after prosecutors were able to verify Adriana Torres-Flores’s alibi, Deputy Prosecutor Mark Booher said.

Leaking natural gas caused an explosion that injured 14 construction workers and damaged four floors of an unfinished 30-story hotel in San Diego, the authorities said. The blast at the bayside Hilton was apparently an accident, caused by a gas leak in a fifth-floor utility room, said a San Diego fire-rescue spokesman, Maurice Luque. Investigators had not determined what ignited the gas.

In flesh and blood, former Gov. Jesse Ventura is stubborn and unvarnished. In oil paint, it is a different story, which is good news for the two high school freshmen who are believed to have made marks on his portrait when their United States government class toured the Capitol in St. Paul. “It turns out the ink wasn’t very stubborn and the paintings had enough varnish to keep the ink from seeping below the surface,” Brian Szott, curator of art at the Minnesota Historical Society, said of the vandalism the students are believed to have inflicted on three portraits of governors. Marks were also drawn across the mouths of Elmer L. Andersen and Harold LeVander. Initial estimates suggested the vandalism would require restoration, costing several thousand dollars. In fact, the repairs cost $175. It took an hour and a mild solvent to remove the ink from the paintings. An investigation is focusing on students from Eastview High School in Apple Valley. Mr. Ventura, a former professional wrestler, called the act “despicable.” A fine and community service are the likely penalties for a misdemeanor of this type, said James Backstrom, the county attorney for Dakota County.
Cardinal Edward M. Egan has reassigned almost 10 percent of the active priests in the Archdiocese of New York without adequately consulting the board that has traditionally advised him.
Mrs. Rockefeller married one of the richest men in America and, after their divorce six years later, won a settlement regarded as a record in its day.
Proposals to implement instant replay in Major League Baseball would address plays like the two incorrect rulings on home runs made this week.
A federal appeals court ruled that the United States discriminates against the blind and those with limited vision because its paper currency is all the same size.
The Regal Entertainment Group, the world’s largest cinema operator, has reached an agreement to equip 1,500 screens to show three-dimensional films.
With the recent issue of equity and debt by A.I.G. expected to raise far more than initially expected, shares of the company dropped on fears of dilutive effect and the possibility of more losses.
Weeks of rain have eased the drought that has gripped the Southeast for two years. But forecasters warn that the crisis is far from over.
As marketers strive to counter the growing ability of viewers to skip or avoid advertisement spots, they are bringing back the live commercial.
Meteorologists who keep records for the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration say that the United States is having its deadliest tornado season in a decade.
John McCain’s chief advertising strategist, Mark McKinnon, followed through on a vow he had made not to work against a Barack Obama candidacy.
A change in New York’s tax abatement certificate program is causing a builder of affordable housing to branch into more market-rate projects.
Detroit sports fans will face a rare dilemma on Saturday and Monday nights: whether to the Red Wings in the Stanley Cup finals or the Pistons in the N.B.A. Eastern Conference finals.
Getting stuck in the mud on its first attempt to leave Manhattan was not the last or the least of the troubles that the aircraft carrier Intrepid has encountered.
The legislation would be aimed at speculators and other investors who use commodities like oil as a way to hedge against swings in other investment instruments.
A California company is planning a string of online auctions next month to clone five dogs, with the bidding to start at $100,000.
A jury convicted an Atlanta police officer of lying to investigators after a botched drug raid that resulted in the death of a 92-year-old woman, but cleared him of more-serious charges.
John Kuhlman, who nearly lost his hearing, has been teaching immigrants to read and write English, to listen and speak.
A judge denied a request for an evaluation of David Tarloff, who faces murder charges in the killing of Kathryn Faughey, a psychotherapist on the Upper East Side.
Most fathers faded into the background or disappeared after the authorities raided a fundamentalist polygamy group in West Texas. Now, a few are breaking that pattern.
A study suggests that the percentage of ground zero workers who suffered post-traumatic stress is roughly the same as for airline crash recovery workers and returning Afghanistan war veterans.
A college student pleaded guilty to vehicular manslaughter in the drunken hit-and-run death of a young woman who had moved to New York City from Scotland.
Rupert Murdoch named Robert J. Thomson as the top editor of The Wall Street Journal, putting an experienced journalist in one of the most important roles in American news media.
A federal appeals court panel ruled against a law that made it a crime for doctors to perform an abortion procedure.
Even with deep pockets and strong currencies on their side, foreign investors in Manhattan’s office market are waiting in the sidelines, weighted down by the credit crunch.
Perhaps the Sichuan earthquake can do some good by helping dispel a widespread myth: that the new generation of Chinese students are materialistic and selfish.
Studies in mice suggest that nanotubes may carry a health risk similar to that of asbestos, but scientists say the findings are not cause for alarm.
The Dutch began playing American baseball in defiance of German occupiers during World War II, and the sport’s wartime popularity has never faded.
A fanciful device born equally of history and imagination, the Telectroscope will visually connect New Yorkers to people in London.
To the Editor:.
Peter Gelb, who completed his second season as general manager on Saturday night, has inaugurated outreach campaigns and digital-media ventures that are the envy of the opera world.

Rupert Goold, who staged the hit production of “Macbeth” currently on Broadway at the Lyceum Theater, has been named an associate director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, Variety reported. He will join the company on a full-time basis 2010. ...Projected for Broadway in 2010 is a new musical based in part on a forthcoming memoir by Zindzi Mandela, a daughter of Nelson and Winnie Mandela who grew up under apartheid in South Africa. The show will deal with the struggle for freedom and its leaders. “The freedom songs were so important to the morale of the people,” Zindzi Mandela said in a statement, “so it’s natural for the story to be told with music as a cornerstone.” ... The two-time Tony and Emmy Award winner Bebe Neuwirth is making her nightclub debut at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency with “Stories With Piano,” a show emphasizing the works of Kurt Weill and Kander & Ebb but also saluting Cole Porter, Stephen Sondheim and Tom Waits. Ms. Neuwirth, appearing through May 31, will be followed from June 3 to 14 by Tony Danza in a new show, “I Could Have Danced All Night,” and from June 17 to 28 by Liz Callaway, whose show “The Beat Goes On” will be devoted to music of the 1960s. ... Keely Smith, whose honorary titles include Queen of Swing and First Lady of Las Vegas, will make her Birdland debut with performances from June 3 through June 8.

Bob Schieffer has reached agreement with CBS News on a new contract that will probably keep him hosting “Face the Nation” for “several more years.” The deal does not specify how long he will host the Sunday morning public affairs show, Mr. Schieffer, 71, said on Monday. But when his tenure on the program does eventually end, said Mr. Schieffer, above, the new contract ensures that he will stay on at CBS News to provide on-camera analysis, including on election nights. “That’s kind of the way Tom Brokaw works at NBC,” Mr. Schieffer said. “Tom’s kind of my model for how to live out the golden years.” Mr. Schieffer said in January that he planned to leave “Face the Nation” soon after the inauguration of the next president, but he later said he had decided to postpone his retirement at the request of CBS News executives. The network has been unable to identify a successor to Mr. Schieffer, at least one who was available. The Washington Post reported on Monday that Mr. Schieffer and CBS had reached a long-term agreement.
The musical “Passing Strange” was honored as best new theater piece when the 53rd annual Village Voice Obie Awards were announced.

ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” attracted Monday’s largest audience as 18.8 million viewers tuned in for the show’s final performances of the season at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The reality competition led its time slot but failed to lift ABC to No. 1 for the night overall as the network’s premiere of “The Bachelorette” struggled from 9 to 11 p.m., averaging 8.8 million viewers. CBS eked out a victory as the night’s most watched network thanks to solid ratings for finales of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10 p.m. CBS’s “CSI: Miami” also led the 10 p.m. hour with 16.1 million viewers. Fox, meanwhile, despite a third-place finish in total viewers, ranked second among adults 18 to 49 behind CBS but ahead of ABC, earning the night’s top ratings in that demographic with the finale of “House” at 9 p.m. (16.2 million). NBC finished a distant fourth over all, drawing just 4 million viewers for “American Gladiators” from 8 to 9:30.

Jurors in the child pornography trial of the R&B star R. Kelly, right, were warned on Tuesday by a prosecutor that they would be required to watch a videotape of an “under-age child performing sex acts that you have never seen before.” In an opening statement in Cook County Criminal Court in Chicago, the prosecutor, Shauna Boliker, said, “A child doesn’t choose to be violated and placed on a videotape, a videotape that will live on forever — long after this child becomes an adult,” The Associated Press reported. Mr. Kelly, 41, a Grammy Award winner, is accused of videotaping himself having sex with an under-age girl. Prosecutors contend that she was as young as 13 when the recording was made, between Jan. 1, 1998 and Nov. 1, 2000. Both Mr. Kelly and the woman, now 23, deny they are the people on the tape, and one of Mr. Kelly’s lawyers, Sam Adam Jr., told the jurors during his opening statement that the videotape is “at best a copy of a copy” and that Mr. Kelly was not the man on the tape. “Not a single witness can tell you that is him on the tape,” he said. If convicted, Mr. Kelly could face as much as 15 years in prison.

Jerusalem, the Holy City, has effectively banned sex. No, not the act but the three-letter word that appears elsewhere in billboard advertising for the new film “Sex and the City.” Sex in the city became an issue when the advertising company Maximedia told the news media that it would not post billboards featuring Sarah Jessica Parker, above, one of the stars, in deference to requests from city officials concerned about “offending public sensitivities” by mentioning “sex,” Agence France-Presse reported. Then the distributor, Forum Films, said that without “sex” there would be no billboards in Jerusalem or Petah Tikva, a town near Tel Aviv that has a large ultra-Orthodox Jewish population. But in other Israeli cities, “sex” in advertising is O.K.

In the second volume of his oral history of baseball, the former major league commissioner, Fay Vincent, records interviews with stars from the sport’s golden years.

American Ballet Theater opened its spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday night.
Gov. David A. Paterson underwent laser eye treatment on Tuesday to relieve the sharp head pain that sent him to the hospital early in the morning.
Robert Mondavi reinvented himself — several times, in fact — and in the process he reinvented Napa Valley and the American wine industry.
The Russian export monopoly warned the European Union that it was endangering the security of its natural gas supplies by planning to break up the Continent’s energy giants.
Although the craftspeople, designers and antique vendors are the raison d’être of the new Brooklyn Flea, there are plenty of options for those who are there to eat.
