The bill is aimed at helping hundreds of thousands of homeowners in danger of foreclosure by expanding the availability of government-insured mortgages.
The drug maker has agreed to pay $58 million as part of a multistate settlement concerning advertising for the now-withdrawn painkiller.
Food and wine related benefits and events.
Restaurant openings, closings and other dining news.

An article last Wednesday about sculpture carved from produce misstated the date of an exhibition of photographs of such work by Hugh McMahon. The photographs are on display at the James Beard House, 167 West 12th Street, through May 31; they will not be on view “next month.”.
The vast majority of the dead came from slums in Bangalore, but several dozen deaths were also reported in nearby rural areas and across the state border in neighboring Tamil Nadu.
A report describes clashes between F.B.I. agents and their C.I.A. and military counterparts over tactics.

A Nationalist, Ma Ying-jeou, took office as Taiwan’s new president on Tuesday and used his inaugural speech to repeat campaign promises to seek closer economic relations with mainland China and an eventual peace accord.
The Berlin Fire Department reported no injuries, and the musicians’ irreplaceable instruments were rescued from the building, the Philharmonie.
Barack Obama said that he had amassed enough pledged delegates to claim a nearly insurmountable advantage over Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Stocks dropped sharply on retail earnings and new concerns about inflation while oil prices continued to rise, closing at $129.07.
After weeks of speculation, the German media conglomerate appointed Markus Dohle, the head of its printing unit, to run the division.
European governments are trying to balance China’s hostility toward the Dalai Lama against their support for human rights in Tibet.
Home Depot reported a 66 percent drop in quarterly profit as the housing slowdown hurt sales and it took a charge to close stores and cut back expansion plans.
After weeks of speculation, Bertelsmann chose Markus Dohle, the head of its printing unit, to run the division.
Spain’s first female defense minister, whose pregnancy became a symbol of Spain’s new commitment to sexual equality, began maternity leave after giving birth to a boy.
The country is undergoing a spasm of xenophobia, with poor South Africans venting their rage on poor foreigners.
The United Nations will use nine helicopters from the World Food Program to reach areas that have so far been largely inaccessible, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said.
Yelp, a San Francisco Internet company, has become a leader in a fast-growing category: Web sites that let people spout off about anything from shops to animal shelters.
Small businesses are trying to provide information to consumers about why their products are considered “green.” Nonetheless, there are few definite rules or standards.
Combing a social movement with a market opportunity, New Resource Bank offers customers financial incentives for green building projects.
While the slow economy has left many small businesses scraping to get by, some enterprises are finding opportunity in the carnage.
Knife guards that are as practical as they are neon-bright.
The Flatbush Food Coop has expanded.
Bold macaroons at the Macaron Cafe, in the garment district.
Setting up and maintaining computers requires time and expertise that may be in short supply. But assistance is easier to find as vendors like Geek Squad focus on small businesses.
Here are some strategies that business owners are using to cope in the face of a sluggish economy.
Ana Corinna and Dana Foley have turned a flea-market friendship into a successful fashion company. But where customers shop, so too do knockoff artists.

A five-bedroom house in Clarkesville, Ga.; a five-bedroom town house in Chicago; and an estate on almost two acres of wooded hills in Mill Valley, Calif.

As soon as the first spring onions hit the market, I picked up a bunch and decided to try my hand at a romesco sauce.

STRAUS--John Wendell, died peacefully on May 18th at his home on Park Avenue. Mr. Straus, born in New York City in 1920, was the son of Herbert N. Straus and Theresa Kuhn Straus. His father's parents were Isadore and Ida Straus, who perished in the Titanic disaster. Mr. Straus attended the Browning School, Milton Academy, Harvard College, and the Harvard Business School's Executive Training Program. He was a captain in the U.S. Air Force during WWII, and taught French Resistance pilots to fly fighter planes. He worked as an executive for 25 years at R.H. Macy, and then left Macy's to serve as Vice President for the Arts at the State University of New York at Purchase. Mr. Straus was a trustee on many boards, including those of the Browning School, Marlboro College, the Fogg Museum at Harvard, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, the American Federation of Arts, the National Foundation for Advancement in the Arts, and Americans for the Arts. He was a lifetime member of the American Association of Arts Deans. Mr. Straus was an avid collector of drawings and other works of art. He also collected various antiques, including antique automobiles. He is survived by his wife, Anne Helburn Straus, three children, four grandchildren and one great-grandchild. In lieu of flowers, contributions to any of the above organizations would be appreciated. STRAUS--John. The Board of Directors of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center notes with sadness the passing of John Straus, our trustee and trustee emeritus for the past 38 years. John's lifelong love of the arts, in particular his stalwart belief in music education programs, led him to be a thoughtful and generous champion of chamber music. We will remember with gratitude and affection the pleasure of his friendship and the many years he devoted to our organization. We send our deepest sympathies to his widow Anne and to his family. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center Peter Frelinghuysen, Chairman Donaldson Pillsbury, Vice Chairman David Finckel and Wu Han, Artistic Directors STRAUS--John W. The Browning School mourns the death of John W. Straus '38, Life Trustee. Visionary, benefactor, advocate, John will be missed for his commitment and involvement over six decades at Browning. James S. Chanos, President Stephen M. Clement III, Headmaster Sharon L. Jacob, President, Parents Association Juan D. Reyes III '86, President, Alumni Association

BART--J. Michael, 59, on May 19, 2008 after a brief illness. Survived by his sister Patricia, her husband James, and his partner of 31 years, David Mallard. He was an accomplished organist, graduating from Mannes College of Music, with additional studies at The Juilliard School. He performed with the Light Opera of Manhattan and was Assistant Organist at the Church of the Heavenly Rest for many years. His years at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church included his current position as Communications Director. He will be missed by many loving friends.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the longtime Massachusetts Democrat and patriarch of the Kennedy family, has a malignant brain tumor, his doctors said on Tuesday. Doctors here at Massachusetts General Hospital, who were investigating the cause of a seizure that Mr. Kennedy, 76, suffered at his Cape Cod compound on Saturday, said preliminary results from a biopsy of the brain had revealed that he has a malignant glioma in the left parietal lobe, the upper left part of his brain.

An article last Wednesday about sculpture carved from produce misstated the date of an exhibition of photographs of such work by Hugh McMahon. The photographs are on display at the James Beard House, 167 West 12th Street, through May 31; they will not be on view ''next month.''

KARASIK--Muriel, the longtime ardent supporter and fundraiser for the Samuel Waxman Foundation for Cancer Research, passed away at her home in Great Neck on Monday morning after a long illness. She was 80 years old. Mrs. Karasik will be remembered fondly in the world of fine art for her exquisite taste and her keen eye for acquisitions. Born in NYC, the daughter of Jack and Belle Linsky, Muriel was a second generation collector whose love of art was secondary only to that of the love of her family. Muriel Karasik was beloved mother to Richard and Lori Mintzer, David and Nancy Mintzer, Elisabeth Mintzer Frankel, Albert and Victoria Benalloul and Charles and Elena Karasik and beloved grandmother of Alex, Zach, Rebekah, Adam, Benjamin, Olivia, Sam, Andrew, Spencer, Gabby, Isaiah and Jake. She is also survived by her sister Lenore Hecht. Services will be held on Wednesday morning May 21st, 2008 at Riverside Chapel in Great Neck, NY 10am.

EDINGER--Lewis, on May 19, 2008, after a brief illness. Beloved husband of the late Hanni, loving father of Monica and Susan, father-in-law of Thomas, doting grandfather of Benjamin and Anna. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions to Doctors Without Borders.

NOREK--Jay. The Board and Staff of the JCC of Mid-Westchester mourns the passing of longtime Board Member Jay Norek. He was a passionate leader, who provided endless spirit and devotion. We extend our sincerest sympathies to his wife Ruth, and the entire Norek family. NOREK--Jay. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Jay Norek, whose unwavering commitment to UJA-Federation and our beneficiary agency, the Jewish Community Center of MidWestchester, enabled us to strengthen the Jewish community in New York, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Ruth; his son, Alfred, and his wife, Meryl; his daughter Susan and her husband, Nestor Guzman; his daughter Betty and her husband, Dr. Alan Feldman; his brother-in-law, Joseph Rosenblatt; his grandchildren; and the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

DeCOVENY--Selma. The Board of Directors and Membership of Glen Head Country Club announce with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed Honorary/Charter Member, Selma DeCoveny. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Ted Tashlik, President
KAPLAN--Gerald, Rabbi, son of the Jewish people. May his memory be for a blessing. Rabbi and Mrs. Charles J. Davidson

BRENNER--Charles, M.D. The members of The NY Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourn the death of our highly esteemed colleague Charles Brenner, M.D. A pillar of psychoanalysis in this country and throughout the world, he was truly beloved by the multitude of friends, colleagues and students who were recipients of his wisdom, wit, and personal generosity. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Among his many contributions during a long life devoted to psychoanalysis, Dr. Brenner was a member of The NY Psychoanalytic Society since 1947, Training and Supervising Analyst since 1957, President of The NY Psychoanalytic Society, 1961-1963 and President of the American Psychoanalytic Association, 1967-1968. Author of ''An Elementary of Textbook of Psychoanalysis'' (1955), ''Psychoanalytic Technique and Psychic Conflict'' (1976) and ''The Mind in Conflict'' (1982), influential and classic texts synonymous with the fundamental ideas of modern Psychoanalysis. Roger Rahtz, M.D., President Philip Herschenfeld, M.D., Dean of Education BRENNER--Charles, M.D. The Pacella Parent Child Center of The NY Psychoanalytic Society and Institute deeply mourn the loss of its dear friend and colleague, Charles Brenner, whose international stature as a psychoanalytic innovator is well known. We were honored with his connection to the Pacella Parent Child Center which was strengthened by his late wife, Erma's, involvement as a teacher and a mentor at the Center. We convey our sympathies to all of his family and friends. Leon Hoffman, M.D., Director Alice Rosenman, Program Coordinator
He's in a fighting mood. SENATOR JOHN KERRY, on Edward M. Kennedy, who was found to have a brain tumor. [A18]

While Senator Barack Obama gingerly commended his rival's ''perseverance,'' the shrinking candidacy of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton all but vanished from the television set on Tuesday, sidelined by bigger news. Even her victory speech in Kentucky, shown live on cable news, was given perfunctory attention -- a footnote to someone else's page in history. When MSNBC called the Kentucky primary early in the evening, Tim Russert, host of ''Meet the Press,'' said her success with women and blue-collar voters ''means Senator Obama has a lot of work to do'' and sketched a rehabilitation plan. He did not mention Mrs. Clinton by name in that disquisition.

HALLEY--Janice Brosh. March 10th, 1920-May 19th, 2008. A courageous and loyal woman. Beloved wife of the late Rudolph Halley, mother of Peter Halley and Michael Halley. Grandmother of Isabel Halley, Thomas Halley and Rudolph Moses Halley and treasured friend of many. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to: Turtle Bay Association.
KARASIK--Muriel. The employees and management offer their sincerest condolences to the Benalloul, Karasik and Mintzer families on the loss of their mother. The Weeks-Lerman Group, LLC.

MORRIS--N. Peter, born January 31, 1927; passed away peacefully May 18, 2008, in Sarasota, Florida. Beloved husband of Dr. Marian Morris for 58 years. Loving father of Robin Ley, Wendy Siegel (Stephen B.), Lori Morris Green (Michael), Wayne (Laurie) and Vickie Goldstein (Richard). Loving grandfather of Jessica (Peter), Alexander, Jared, Cassandra, Sage, Winston, Megan, Samantha, Peter, Brandon, Jaimie, Lauren and Stephanie. A wonderful, multifaceted man who was defined by the words love, kindness and intelligence. A leader in the field of nuclear science and a founding member and President of the American Nuclear Society when he lived in Pittsburgh. While living in Carlsbad, NM, he was President, and a member of the Crisis Committee of the American Red Cross, the American Cancer Society and his synagogue. He was a member of the International Rotary and worked at the Carlsbad Mental Health facility. A man who led his family by example with dignity and quiet strength. He will live in our hearts forever. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to Temple Emanu - EL, 151 South McIntosh Road, Sarasota, FL 34232; or Tidewell Hospice & Palliative Care, 5955 Rand Blvd, Sarasota, FL 34238.

The weak dollar has its detractors, but it is working out just fine for Hewlett-Packard. In an earnings report on Tuesday, H.P. said it did 70 percent of its sales overseas in the last quarter, benefiting from the relative strength of foreign currencies. That helped insulate it from an apparent stagnation in domestic sales amid a weak economy.

HOLLAND--Edward, 76, died May 17, 2008, from complications of Alzheimer's disease. A talented writer, photographer, and publisher, he was a generous man with a quick wit who could tell an excellent story. He and his wife, Karen, shared an incomparable love for each other. He is also survived by a sister, Marion Ortlieb and three children: Maureen Keogh, Tim, and Brian, and five grandchildren. A private memorial service is planned.

STEINBERG--Harry A., died on May 20, 2008, three months shy of age 97. Harry was predeceased by his Eshet Chayil of 50 years, Sylvia Steinberg nee Friedman. Cherished father of Mara and Curt Gruskin, and Lisa and Lee Snow. Very proud grandfather of Amy, David, Michael and Raffi. Dear brother of Sadie Mintz. Adored uncle and great uncle. Born in Seattle in 1911 to Mereh Rashal and Zalman Reuven, Harry was the last surviving member of the first graduating class of Yeshiva College, now Yeshiva University. As directed by his friend Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver, Harry Steinberg was instrumental in generating political and popular support for the establishment of the State of Israel in 1948. As the Executive Director of the American Zionist Federation and a founding member of Writers and Artists for Peace in the Middle East, Harry was a relentless advocate on behalf of Israel and continued to be actively engaged in Middle East politics throughout his life. Funeral service today at 12:45pm at the Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to American Society for Yad Vashem, 500 5th Ave., New York, NY 10110.
INTERNATIONAL WITH QUAKE, PREMIER'S PERSONA

NETZER--Dr. Dick. The Directors of the Adolph and Esther Gottlieb Foundation extend their deepest sympathies to the family of Dr. Dick Netzer, who served as its President for the last 20 years. Dr. Netzer, along with his aunt Esther Dick Gottlieb, helped to form the Foundation in 1975 and served on its board from its founding. He brought a wealth of knowledge about artists' lives and their economic struggles to our organization and he was a guiding spirit in the formation of our two grant programs for individual artists. These contributions were invaluable as they came during a time when there was no model for an artist-endowed foundation to make direct grants to living artists on an on-going basis. Dick's wisdom, good sense, and unfailing generosity of spirit are now a part of the legacy thatwe extend through our programs. His presence will be missed by us all.
$6.2 MILLION 5 King Street

On the day that Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, quelled weeks of speculation by announcing that Markus Dohle, head of the company's printing unit, would take over as chief executive of Random House, industry executives were largely reserving judgment on what it would mean to have a relative outsider in charge of the world's largest publisher of consumer books. Mr. Dohle, 39, will succeed Peter W. Olson, Random House's current chief executive, on June 1. Mr. Olson, 58, who led the publishing division for the last decade, is in negotiations for a senior faculty position at Harvard Business School, according to a person knowledgeable about his plans. Mr. Olson declined to comment.

CELENZA--Dr. Frank. Prosthodontic Associates PC extends our deepest sympathy to Frank's wife Raquel and his children Vincent, Andrea, Raquel and Frank Jr. on his passing. He was the father of our organization, a mentor, teacher, inspiration and friend to so many and he leaves a void in our life that will be difficult to replace. His legacy will continue forever in our commitment to education, patient care and a zest for living. Harold Litvak Michael Litvak George Hribar Richard Greenfield Glenn Simonelli Caroline Grasso CELENZA--Dr. Frank Vincent, died quietly at his home with his loving and dedicated wife Raquel nearby Saturday, May 17 after several difficult years of steadily declining health. Prosthodontist, author, international lecturer and mentor to hundreds of dentists around the globe, he shaped the careers of many of the world's leading authorities in specialty dentistry today. He is survived by his eldest son, Dr. Vincent, also a prosthodontist practicing in New York City, father of two sons, Frank and Luke; Dr. Andrea, a psychoanalyst residing in Lexington, MA, mother of Derek and Ethan; daughter Raquel, producer living in Los Angeles, mother of Christopher; and youngest son, Dr. Frank Jr., specialist in adult periodontics and orthodontics practicing in New York City, father of Nicholas, Olivia and Alex. He was an active member of the Columbus Citizens Foundation where he was able to meld his love of gourmet food, fine wines and opera hosting over 70 now legendary opera nights. The surviving family will host a wake at the Fairchild Funeral Home in Manhasset, L.I. on Wednesday, May 21 from 2 to 5pm and 7 to 10pm, and a private family funeral mass will be held the following day. A memorial service is forthcoming in New York City to celebrate the life of this extraordinary man who touched the lives of so many. Details to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to New York University College of Dentistry Celenza Family Fund, attention: Assistant Dean, Rita Startup, 345 East 24th Street, New York, NY 10010 or the Columbus Citizens Foundation, attention: Christine Meola, 8 East 69th Street, New York, NY 10021.

At United States Marine Hospital 43, the hospital on Ellis Island, the powerhouse and laundry building housed the mortuary and autopsy room. Bodies were refrigerated in these eight compartments in the wall. The site was used as a teaching area, and was associated with Long Island Medical Center. More than 12 million immigrants were processed on Ellis Island, and more than 3,500 died, including about 1,400 children.

HARTFORD--Huntington. Such memories. Opening night of The Museum; the first issue of 'Show'; my first taste of 'Paradise'. EDINGER--Lewis, on May 19, 2008, after a brief illness. Beloved husband of the late Hanni, loving father of Monica and Susan, father-in-law of Thomas, doting grandfather of Benjamin and Anna. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions to Doctors Without Borders.

STEINBERG--Harry A., died on May 20, 2008, three months shy of age 97. Harry was predeceased by his Eshet Chayil of 50 years, Sylvia Steinberg nee Friedman. Cherished father of Mara and Curt Gruskin, and Lisa and Lee Snow. Very proud grandfather of Amy, David, Michael and Raffi. Dear brother of Sadie Mintz. Adored uncle and great uncle. Born in Seattle in 1911 to Mereh Rashal and Zalman Reuven, Harry was the last surviving member of the first graduating class of Yeshiva College, now Yeshiva University. As directed by his friend Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver, Harry Steinberg was instrumental in generating political and popular support for the establishment of the State of Israel in 1948. As the Executive Director of the American Zionist Federation and a founding member of Writers and Artists for Peace in the Middle East, Harry was a relentless advocate on behalf of Israel and continued to be actively engaged in Middle East politics throughout his life. Funeral service today at 12:45pm at the Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to American Society for Yad Vashem, 500 5th Ave., New York, NY 10110.

HALLEY--Janice Brosh. March 10th, 1920-May 19th, 2008. A courageous and loyal woman. Beloved wife of the late Rudolph Halley, mother of Peter Halley and Michael Halley. Most of all she loved her darling Paul, who predeceased her. She was a strong woman who led a full life. She will forever be in the hearts of us all. A front-page picture caption on Tuesday about xenophobic rioting in South Africa showed a man demolishing a shack in Ramaphosa, a settlement near Johannesburg where six immigrants have been killed. Because of an editing error, the caption may have left the mistaken impression that the man was a rioter, and should have made clear he was trying to prevent the spread of a fire.

BRUNN--Ruth (nee Wettengel), 88, on May 19, of Upper Saddle River, NJ. Beloved wife of Richard A. Brunn of Upper Saddle River. Loving mother of Richard W. Brunn and his wife AliceAnne of Waco, TX, James R. Brunn and his wife Leslie of Suffern, NY and John W. Brunn who preceded her in death. Adored grandmother of Ruth Brunn Robinson and her husband Paul Robinson of Woodland Hills, CA, Richard Coleman Brunn and his wife Lu Jing of Pasadena, CA, Geoffrey, Elizabeth and Christopher Brunn of Suffern, NY. Beloved great-grandmother of Frederick James and Henry Charles Robinson of Woodland Hills, CA. Beloved aunt of Carl Wettengel and his wife Carmela of Middletown, DE. Born December 13, 1919, in New York City, to Dr. Walter and Sidonie Ripperger Wettengel. She grew up in the Bronx and moved to Upper Saddle River with her husband and children in 1951. As the niece of noted culinary expert and author Helmut Ripperger Ruth was a gourmet cook who devoted her life to the nurture of her family. She was a lively and engaging woman with an irrepressible zest for life. In her husband's retirement, they enjoyed traveling by cruise ship to countries around the world. She leaves many friends in Upper Saddle River and in New York City, where she was active in several groups at the New York Athletic Club, including the wine society and theatre group. Visitation will be held on Friday from 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Van Emburgh-Sneider-Pernice Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Ave., Ramsey. A Funeral Service will be held on Saturday, May 24, 2008 at 10am at the Old Stone Church in Upper Saddle River, NJ. Cremation will be private. Please send tributes, memories and condolences at vanemburghsneider.com

Is Gov. David A. Paterson's support for Hillary Rodham Clinton starting to cool? On a radio call-in show Thursday afternoon, the New York governor insisted that he still supports Mrs. Clinton's bid for the Democratic presidential nomination. But he sounded as if he is starting to have serious doubts about whether she can prevail against Barack Obama.

Is Gov. David A. Paterson's support for Hillary Clinton starting to cool? On a radio call-in show this afternoon, the governor insisted that he still supports Mrs. Clinton's bid for the Democratic presidential nomination. But he sounded as if he is starting to have serious doubts about whether she can prevail against Barack Obama. "I would say that at this point," Mr. Paterson said, "we're starting to see a little, you know, desperation on the part of a woman who I supported, and woman who I'll support until whatever time she makes a different determination."

But the joke had already turned into reality in McMinnville, Tenn., where a farmer told The Associated Press about his conversion from tractor to mules: "This fuel's so high, you can't afford it ... We can feed these mules cheaper than we can buy fuel. That's the truth."

Kerri Conan, the Kansas-based food writer who has been my co-author on a number of projects and will contribute to Bitten whenever I can persuade her to do so, is as diligent and creative a cook as any I know. When I asked her why no one ever made socca -- chickpea flatbread -- with other flours, she immediately set about trying out alternatives and devised this whole wheat flatbread. I've made it -- and you should too. It's lovely, with heft and flavor -- and easy. --MB

A stuck wheel in the Martian dust turned out to be a lucky accident for the rover Spirit. As the crippled wheel was dragged along, it dug up a trench revealing a white layer of silica apparently produced by hydrothermal vents like the famous hot springs at Yellowstone. And where there was once hot water, there might have been life.

So imagine my - relief? surprise? indifference? contempt? - when this primal larceny came back marked 'A.' " -- London Review of Books

Stuck in New Delhi's rush-hour traffic, my taxi driver finally gave up and turned off the engine. Cars, mopeds and auto-rickshaws were all at a dead stop, their horns continuing to blare as if the right amount of honking would get traffic moving again.
In western Afghanistan, about a thousand people protesting against the shooting of a Koran by a U.S. soldier in Iraq resulted in three deaths, according to The Associated Press:
MyNetworkTV, the low-rated mini-network owned by the News Corporation, is adding a pair of reality shows to its schedule in the fall.

So how exactly did David Cook, age 25, win "American Idol?" His overwhelming victory "probably says as much about his soulful gaze and in-season makeover as it does about his chops as a rocker," The Associated Press surmises. "Or maybe it says even more about who's voting these days." Derrik J. Lang writes:

In a recent post, I lamented what to do with my 5-year-old sprinter in France, a country that favors distance over speed. Since my horse came from England, he wasn't qualified to run handicaps in France, which left me with few choices. I managed to get him into a claiming race Thursday at St. Cloud racecourse outside Paris, and he won by half a length. We had a full field of 20, and Abwaab was a long shot: he paid 72.80 euros for the win and 18.40 for the place. The purse was 7,500 euros, which will pay for his oats for a bit. It certainly pales when compared with a Derby horse like Big Brown, but anybody involved in racing knows that no victory is inconsequential.
Wednesday's decision by the Quebec Court of Appeals rejecting Bell Canada's "plan of arrangement" looks now like a very serious blow to the $51.8 billion buyout.
Aired Wednesday night on NBC: You know, on the news earlier tonight, they showed Barack Obama back in Iowa. And I got scared. I went, "Oh, no. We're starting all over again!"

Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Folks from all over the country are visiting here tonight. Good to have you with us. A lot of out-of-towners? That took a little too long, didn't it? Listen to this: in New York City -- and maybe they do this in your home town, I doubt it -- there's a restaurant downtown in the financial district, down on Wall Street, and I don't know the name of it and I don't even care. But you can go in there and you can order yourself a hamburger. Oh, that's nice, you're saying, "A hamburger -- jeez, I'd like a hamburger." Who doesn't like a hamburger? I'm not done here. How much do you pay for a hamburger? One hundred seventy-five dollars -- now, that seems to me like an incredible waste, especially when you can get a really good steak in New York City for only $250.

Aired Wednesday night on NBC: This week, Barack Obama, true story, campaigned on an Indian reservation and the tribal chief adopted him. Yeah, the Indians actually prefer Obama to John McCain, because they still remember when McCain took their land.

Updated, 4:10 p.m. | Double-decker buses -- a fixture of the streetscape in London and other international cities -- could be making a comeback in New York City. Officials at New York City Transit said today that the agency was considering bringing back double-decker buses, similar to ones that used to run in the city decades ago.
By Donald Morrison

The Hollywood Reporter has the early Nielsen numbers: "The 'American Idol' seventh season finale Wednesday night managed to essentially match last year's performance, with the coronation of David Cook watched by an estimated 31.7 million viewers. Last year, slightly fewer viewers -- 30.8 million -- tuned in to watch Jordin Sparks win Fox's singing competition."
Day 3 of the hockey world being held hostage by the Lords of Scheduling, and there's no hope for an early end to the stalemate.

Manchester United and Chelsea pummeled each other through regulation time and two fatigue-inducing extra periods in the Champions League final before Man U finally prevailed on penalty kicks. Soccer has used penalties to decide tie matches in tournaments for more than three decades, often prompting criticism that it employs a manufactured endgame to settle its most important competitions. Does Wednesday's thrilling finale validate the system as the best one available? And if not, what would?
Letterpress print on paper by Matthew Brannon, 2008. (Friedrich Petzel Gallery)

An estimated 16 million Olympic tickets to be used for this year's Games are embedded with RFID (radio frequency identification) technology to "ensure security," as the China's People's Daily Online reports.

Updated, 4:37 p.m. | The Port Authority board met privately this morning to consider a deal that would allow Larry A. Silverstein, the developer of three of the future World Trade Center towers, to negotiate with Merrill Lynch as the tenant of the central building at the site. As it stands, under his agreement with the authority, Mr. Silverstein must complete the central building, known as Tower 3, by Dec. 31, 2011.
Wow.

LAKEVILLE, Conn. -- The 2008 Karting Challenge, a four-hour endurance race to support the Special Olympics Connecticut, began Tuesday at Lime Rock Park here. At precisely 1 p.m., drivers from 16 teams dashed to their go-karts in a Le Mans-style start. Over the next four hours, the karts would lap the quarter-mile autocross course more than 300 times.

Chelsea captain John Terry has endured "concussion, broken bones and painful wounds," but now he seems overwrought by "emotional trauma" after missing Chelsea's fifth spot kick in the penalty shootout in the Champions League final Wednesday against Manchester United.

The caste lines between perfumes -- which are niche, which luxury and which mass passing as luxury (currently the industry's greatest growth sector) -- have become increasingly blurred, their defining cues both subtle and contradictory. The new David Yurman scent, which will be available at Yurman retail stores in late June followed by Neiman Marcus and Saks in July, provides an excellent example of how fuzzy it's gotten. Perhaps this is because its perfumer, Harry Frémont, is one of the art form's greatest masters at moving between styles and classes.

As the price of oil and gas shoots higher, Big Coal is making a big comeback. Countries from Britain to the United States to China are mining more coal - which is comparatively cheap - and building more coal-fired plants to generate electricity. Coal also enjoys more public acceptance than nuclear power, even though nuclear emits virtually no greenhouse gases.
Damien Cave covered Iraq between July 2006 and December 2007. He is now the Times' Miami bureau chief and we asked him to explain what it's been like readjusting to home.
Today our beta version of Times Reader for the Mac becomes available. The beta is free for all registered members of NYTimes.com to download and try.

I went to a small museum with my family this week, and in one of the galleries noticed a paperback copy of "The Professor of Desire" on a chair against the wall. "Are you reading that?" I asked the guard, who'd been keeping a wary eye on my two young children. He perked right up. "Philip Roth is my favorite author," he said. We chatted a bit about academic concerns - David Kepesh as a narrator versus Nathan Zuckerman, and the playful cross-references between various novels - and as we talked the guard seemed to reach a decision. He leaned confidingly toward me, and his next sentences came all in a rush. "I'm rereading all of his breakup novels right now," he said. "Because I'm going through one of my own, and they just really, really help."

The unending parade of banned-substance and doping stories has become as much of the Olympic narrative as sappy up-close-and-personal featurettes about athletes' family dramas and uplifting moral tales about the unifying pull of the Olympic Spirit.

Updated | 1 p.m. ORLANDO - With the Democratic National Convention only three months away, Senator Barack Obama has asked a tight circle of advisers to begin conducting a confidential search for prospective running mates.
Calais had just enough beauty, and more than enough friendly faces, to make it the perfect introduction to France.

Eliot Spitzer's former top deputy, Richard Baum, has landed at the venerable New York Academy of Sciences, a nonprofit group that bills itself as the third oldest scientific organization in the nation. (The academy recently moved to 7 World Trade Center.)

All on his own, Mets Manager Willie Randolph apologized Wednesday for comments he made to Ian O'Connor of the Bergen Record suggesting that race had something to do with the way Randolph is portrayed or received in the media.
This has been a frustrating time for bears, who see disaster all around them -- except in stock prices.
Sailors take advantage of promotions at local bars near the seaport. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

Gallop boys, gallop girls, exercise riders, that's who we are. I thought I would try to shed some light into the work done by those who ride racehorses during their morning exercises. Michelle Nevin exercises Big Brown. Andy Durnin did the same for Fusaichi Pegasus. They are the people reporters write about when their horses are in the limelight. But there are many of us who do the same thing on horses that are not quite so famous.

Yumei Wang, who heads Oregon's geohazards team, is dynamic and hard-bitten, as you might expect of someone facing the reality of a looming inevitable disaster (Oregon's next great quake on the Cascadia fault) and inadequate preparation, with hundreds of schools, emergency-services buildings and vital water and power links still vulnerable.

The first time I made brownies without my mother was in the late 1960's, using a recipe from Paula Peck, the cookbook writer. Over the years, I tinkered with that and a similar version by Marion Cunningham. As my daughters learned to cook, they experimented a bit further. But we never really strayed from the originals.
CNBC's David Faber analyzes the latest roadblock for the Bell Canada buyout: an appeals court decision that endangers the transaction.

The scantily clad marvel soaring through the video above is the ballet star Carlos Acosta, whose memoir, "No Way Home," I review in the Book Review this weekend. Acosta may not be that well known to casual observers of ballet in the States. He began dancing in Havana, and although he spent a few years in Houston early in his career, and has done a couple of stints as a principal guest artist with American Ballet Theater, he's spent most of his dancing life abroad, most prominently with the Royal Ballet, where he has been since 1998.

When is a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder viewed as good news? How does A.D.H.D. medication affect a child's ability to create art? How do parents and children view attention deficit and hyperactivity problems differently?
Britain’s opposition Conservative Party gained a mid-term parliamentary seat from the ruling Labour Party on Friday, a new setback to Prime Minister Gordon Brown’s fading political fortunes.

Sid Gustafson is a novelist, social commentator, and former thoroughbred attending and examining veterinarian licensed in New York, Washington, and Montana, where he has had significant experience in the regulation of racehorses, especially as it pertains to soundness and breakdowns.

Scanning the financial press this morning, readers would have seen a disturbing yet familiar burst of oil news: rising prices, aghast lawmakers and protests in Europe. But another piece of bad news topped off the fray, one that was much less familiar to close observers of the oil market:

Give Not Invading a Chance: This weekend, "one of the most grotesque events in the political history of the modern world" will take place in Myanmar, writes Timothy Garton Ash on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times. "While dead children still lie face down in muddy flood waters after a devastating cyclone, while survivors get sick with life-threatening diarrhea, while international aid workers are prevented by the military regime from bringing in supplies that could save them, Burmese citizens will be herded into makeshift polling stations to approve by plebiscite a constitution that is designed to prevent the results of a democratic election held 18 years ago from ever being respected."

Crown Heights is experiencing racial tensions, as it has every so often since the 1991 unrest that erupted after a 7-year-old black boy was fatally struck by a Hasidic driver. The violence also left a Jewish man dead. The beating of a 20-year-old black college student last month and the robbery and beating of a Jewish teenager last week are the proximate causes of the latest unease.

This is the second installment of some insider-generated content on how to navigate Mumbai. Last week, three style shapers revealed how to dress for the city. This week, four Mumbaikars -- native and adopted -- share their advice on how to behave like an insider. Thanks to Rohan Gopaldas, Anuvab Pal, Shuchi Pandya and Priya Parker for these tips. As The Times first reported yesterday, Club McCain is open for the weekend in Sedona, Ariz., where some of the G.O.P.'s most electable up-and-comers and swingingest-staters get a chance to mingle with the presumptive nominee.
Now that an appeals court has quashed approval for the $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of Bell Canada, siding with angry bondholders in a ruling, what's next for the troubled telecommunications giant?
Power company NRG Energy has made an unsolicited bid to buy competitor Calpine for about $11 billion in stock, the companies said on Wednesday.
The Art Trading Fund, a hedge fund that deals in fine art, said that Charles Saatchi, the British advertising magnate and art collector, will advise it on contemporary art purchases.
Twitter has raised a new $15 million round of funding, following a bidding war by venture cpitalists eager to get a slice of the micro-blogging start-up, according to an unsourced report from GigaOm.
How can Google, the Internet search and advertising giant, contend that teaming up with Yahoo in search ads would not invite an antitrust challenge?
UBS said Thursday that it is planning a deeply discounted rights issue worth 16 billion Swiss francs, or $15.55 billion.
After a generally bruising March, hedge funds regained ground in April as global stock markets recovered, according to an industry index compiled by Eurekahedge.
The head of Citigroup's troubled Falcon Strategies hedge fund is leaving after spending nearly two decades at the company, Reuters said, citing an internal memo dated on Tuesday.
Jeffrey Mayer, co-head of fixed income at Bear Stearns, has reportedly turned down an offer of $27 million from JPMorgan Chase to join the bank on completion of their merger, Financial News reported.

In another blow to the embattled American International Group, a Florida pension fund accused the insurance giant and a number of its top executives on Wednesday of understating the company's exposure to the subprime mortgage crisis in order to inflate its stock price artificially.

Shareholders in Australian firm Dyno Nobel, the world's second-largest supplier of explosives, overwhelmingly approved a 2.6 billion Australian dollar ($2.5 billion) takeover by fertilizer maker Incitec Pivot, proxy votes showed Thursday.

A former hedge fund manager was convicted Wednesday of leading an investment scheme that caused clients, ranging from former NFL players to his mother, to lose millions of dollars while he spent the money on jewelry, real estate and a $500,000 wedding.
Borders, the bookstore chain put itself up for sale in March, saw its stock jump 9 percent on Wednesday as investors reacted to a report that Barnes & Noble was mulling a bid for its rival.
Merrill Lynch is in renewed talks to move its headquarters to one of the new buildings which being built on the World Trade Center site, according to The Wall Street Journal.
Allianz is in talks that might lead to a sale or merger of its Dresdner Bank unit and sees the "first apparently realistic possibility of a significant consolidation" in Germany's banking market.

Spectrum Brands on Wednesday said it would sell its pet supply business to Salton in a deal worth up to $915 million, with financing from private equity firm and hedge fund Harbinger Capital Partners.
Philips Electronics has agreed to sell its 69.5 percent stake in MedQuist to CBaySystems Holdings of the Virgin Islands for around $285 million.

Mexico's stock exchange operator says it's ready to go public in its home market and in the U.S. next month in an offering that could raise as much as 4.6 billion pesos, or about $444 million.

Nuveen Investments, the largest American manager of closed-end funds, said on Wednesday that it had a commitment for up to $1.75 billion in liquidity support to help refinance the troubled auction-rate preferred shares its funds once issued.
51.com, one of China's largest social networks, is closing a $50 million round and plans to launch a platform for third party developers later this summer, VentureBeat reported.

A federal district court judge on Thursday will re-evaluate the prison sentences of Adelphia founder John Rigas and his son Timothy after an appeals court overturned one part of their convictions last year.

Dubai World, the state-owned investment group managing more than $100 billion, agreed to buy Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide's Turnberry golf resort in Scotland to expand its Leisurecorp sports unit.
The London Stock Exchange Group reported Thursday that full-year profit rose 58.6 percent, boosted by its acquisition of Borsa Italiana.

Under Simon Cowell's deal with Fox, he has the rights to sign the winning singer and runner-up from each "American Idol" contest to a recording contract with his label, Sony BMG, a partnership between Sony Corp and Bertelsmann.
In the largest gift to a university from a living donor this year, Oklahoma State University is being given $100 million by the energy tycoon Boone Pickens, the university announced.
Sun Capital Partners' Jevic Holding is seeking bankruptcy protection, as a nationwide decline in freight volumes has led the trucking company to look for a permanent rest stop.

Apollo Management has hired Morgan Stanley's ex-head of fixed income to develop a commodities business as more companies move into the sector to capitalize on rising prices and volatility.

The Yankees began Joba Chamberlain's transition to the starting rotation on Wednesday, when he worked the final two innings -- 35 pitches -- of the Yankees' 8-0 victory against the Orioles.

"It was a winner by a knockout Wednesday in the finale of the seventh season of 'American Idol,' but the victor was not the contestant who appeared to have delivered the decisive blow during the final night of competition one night earlier," Edward Wyatt reports.
There’s plenty of frantic energy in “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull,” lots of noise and money too, but what’s absent is any sense of rediscovery.
No matter how much money Hillary Rodham Clinton has raised, Barack Obama has consistently outraised and outspent her.
The Texas government turned to the state’s highest court to keep children seized from a polygamy sect in custody.
A Texas state court of appeals ruled Thursday that the state had no right to seize more than 400 children from a polygamist ranch in Eldorado.
Declines in nationwide home prices accelerated in the first quarter, falling a record 1.7 percent from the end of 2007, according to a federal index released on Thursday.
Ford said rising prices for commodities and an accelerating consumer shift from larger vehicles would make it impossible to meet the key milestone in its turnaround efforts.
The crew chief at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday said that they made a mistake by not calling Alex Rodriguez’s hit in the sixth inning a home run.
Three students at a high school in Brooklyn were questioned by investigators after notes were discovered describing a plan to kill people in and around the school.
Manager Joe Girardi used Joba Chamberlain for the final two innings Wednesday, starting a process that will culminate with Chamberlain joining the rotation.
David Cook, a 25-year-old rocker from Blue Springs, Mo., easily defeated David Archuleta, a 17-year-old balladeer from Murray, Utah, in the finale of “American Idol.”
Environmental advocates accused the European Commission of being soft on the auto industry by allowing a proposal to reduce noise from car and truck tires to exempt tires for sport utility vehicles.
Nokia and France Télécom said they had agreed to a partnership to provide Internet services over mobile telephones in nine European countries.

Gov. Sarah Palin says the state will sue to challenge the listing of polar bears as a threatened species under the Endangered Species Act, contending that there was insufficient evidence to support Interior Secretary Dirk Kempthorne’s decision. Mr. Kempthorne says the best available science indicates that the bears’ primary habitat, sea ice, was shrinking and was likely to further recede. Ms. Palin, a Republican, says polar bears’ numbers have increased over 30 years. Conservation groups say that the increase is the result of measures that halted over-hunting but that populations are likely to decrease as summer sea ice diminishes.

Air pollution regulators in the San Francisco Bay Area voted to approve new rules that impose fees on businesses for emitting heat-trapping gases. The Bay Area Air Quality Management District’s board voted 15 to 1 to charge companies 4.4 cents per ton of carbon dioxide they emit. Experts say the fees are the first of their kind in the country. They will take effect on July 1. About seven power plants and oil refineries would have to pay more than $50,000 a year, but most businesses would pay less than $1, according to district estimates.
In the largest gift to a university from a living donor this year, Oklahoma State University is being given $100 million by the energy tycoon Boone Pickens.

A Senate panel approved a measure to reverse a ruling by the Environmental Protection Agency and let California enforce auto emission standards that are tougher than federal law. The Committee on Environment and Public Works voted 10 to 9 to amend the Clean Air Act to grant California’s request for a waiver from E.P.A. rules that prohibit states from establishing their own pollution restrictions. Fourteen other states have adopted or are adopting the California standards and seek similar waivers from the federal rules.
An M.R.I. showed that Chien-Ming Wang had a mild strain of his right calf, but he is still expected to start on Saturday.
Workers dug up a Queens backyard on Wednesday in a police search for human remains after a man imprisoned for murder suggested that he had left a body there, the authorities said.
The Mets manager said his comments suggesting that criticism of him was racial in nature came from frustration and that making them was a mistake.

Civil court judges in England are scheduled to ditch their traditional wigs and robes in October. The old, stuffy outfits — curly gray wigs made from horsehair, severe black robes with winged collars and stiff neckbands — are to be replaced by modern navy robes created by the fashion designer Betty Jackson. Ms. Jackson, who donated her services, is friends with the wife of a judge, a spokesman for the judiciary said. The changes will not apply to criminal court judges, nor to barristers, as lawyers who argue cases in court are known in Britain. Critics of the traditional wigs and robes have long complained that they alienate people in court and look hopelessly out of date.

Despite a Supreme Court order requiring that the renegade Anglican bishop Nolbert Kunonga, left, a supporter of President Robert Mugabe, share dozens of churches in Harare, the capital, with followers of Bishop Sebastian Bakare, church officials and parishioners said the police had continued to harass and lock out the bulk of the city’s Anglicans. “The police have continued to brutalize our people, which is sad,” said Bishop Albert Chama, the dean of the Anglican Province of Central Africa. “This is political interference. I’m sure the police are getting orders from above. They’re protecting Kunonga.”.

An Irish Republican Army veteran was charged in connection with the execution of an undercover British soldier 31 years ago — one of Northern Ireland’s most bitterly debated killings. The veteran, Kevin Crilly, 57, was arrested Tuesday in a predawn raid on his home, where he had been living under an alias. The Northern Ireland police said in a statement that Mr. Crilly was charged with the abduction and false imprisonment of Capt. Robert Nairac, a British intelligence officer who posed as a Belfast I.R.A. member. Mr. Crilly is expected to be arraigned Thursday.
A group of up to 300 young men killed 11 people who were accused of being witches and wizards in western Kenya on Tuesday night and Wednesday morning

India and Pakistan agreed to give consular access to each other’s prisoners and increase cross-border bus service in the disputed region of Kashmir during talks between the countries’ foreign ministers. The small concessions were considered a sign of progress between the nuclear powers. Shah Mehmood Qureshi, foreign minister of Pakistan, said talks were “very frank,” while India’s foreign minister, Pranab Mukherjee, said the two countries “have to cover a long distance.” The governments plan to meet again in July.

An article in some editions on March 13 about the struggle among parents in the New York region over how to answer their children’s questions about the sex scandal that brought down Gov. Eliot Spitzer misstated the name of the 6-year-old daughter of Joy and Jeff Yagid of Maplewood, N.J.. She is Bella, not Della. Ms. Yagid left a note on an online bulletin board on March 14 alerting the reporter to the error, but the reporter did not see the note until Friday.

An article on May 14 about a request to Congress for an infusion of $275 million for the Food and Drug Administration misstated the time frame for spending the money. Legislation is being written to allow the agency to spend the money through fiscal year 2009. A letter from the Food and Drug commissioner, Andrew C. von Eschenbach, to Senator Arlen Specter did not say that the agency could absorb the money in the next few months, nor did it give a specific time period.

An obituary by The Associated Press on April 4 about Rafael Azcona, the Spanish novelist and scriptwriter, misstated his date of death, relying on information from the Spanish Writers and Editors Society, and misstated his widow’s given name. He died on March 24, not March 23, and his widow is Susan Youdelman, not Susi. The Associated Press issued a correction on Wednesday.

An obituary on May 13 about Murray Jarvik, a psychopharmacologist who was among the first to study LSD, referred incorrectly to the chemical compound D-lysergic acid, which he studied in the 1950s. It is a precursor of LSD, not LSD itself. The obituary also referred incorrectly to the publication history of The Village Voice, quoting an account Dr. Jarvik gave in a 2001 interview. The newspaper was founded in 1955; it did not exist in 1953, when, by Dr. Jarvik’s account, he placed an advertisement in the paper seeking subjects for an LSD study at Mount Sinai Hospital.
FRONT PAGE.

A jazz review on Wednesday about the Tomasz Stanko Quartet, at the Museum of Modern Art, referred incorrectly to the selection of music played. Three of the nine pieces were by Mr. Stanko; they were not all by the Polish film composer Krzysztof Komeda.

An article on Friday about CBS’s $1.8 billion deal to buy CNet Networks misstated, in some copies, the color of the sneakers worn by Quincy Smith, president of CBS Interactive, in an appearance last week at the network’s upfront presentation for advertisers. As an accompanying picture showed, they were dark-colored — not his trademark white ones. And the caption for that photograph misstated, in some copies, the day of Mr. Smith’s appearance. It was Wednesday, May 14 — not last Thursday.

A picture caption with an article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about foreign investors’ purchases of Manhattan office buildings reversed the identifications of the two buildings shown. The building at 31 West 52nd Street was shown in the top photograph and the Altria Building, at 120 Park Avenue, was below.

An article on Wednesday about personnel issues confronting the Giants described incorrectly, in some editions, a big Super Bowl catch by Kevin Boss, the team’s promising young tight end. It was a 45-yard play, not a touchdown.

A capsule summary on Wednesday for an article about F.B.I. agents creating a “war crimes file” to document accusations against American military personnel misstated the year that the agents were told to close the file. It was 2003, not 2002.

The Public Lives column in some editions on Friday, about Nadine Strossen, who recently resigned as president of the American Civil Liberties Union, referred incorrectly to her tenure. She served for more than 17 years; she was not an “18-year” incumbent. And while she led the group for the longest period of time under the title of president — changed from “chairman” during the tenure of her immediate predecessor — she is not in fact the A.C.L.U.’s longest-serving leader. (That would be Harry Ward, who served as chairman for 20 years.) The article also misspelled the surname of one of Ms. Strossen’s debating partners over the years. She is Phyllis Schlafly, not Schlafley.

The staff of State Senator Andrea Stewart-Cousins says that her district office in Yonkers has been the target of attacks, but the police have raised questions about some parts of the staff’s account.

Alessandro Bertolini of the Diquigiovanni team won the 11th stage of the Giro d’Italia, a hilly 124-mile course from Urbania to Cesena. Bertolini sprinted away when his Italian compatriot Fortunato Baliani crashed about 500 yards from the finish. Giovanni Visconti of the Quick Step team was one of many riders who crashed in the rain, but he retained the overall race lead.

The feud between Jason Taylor and Bill Parcells intensified Wednesday, making it likely that Taylor, a six-time Pro Bowl defensive end, has played his last game for the Miami Dolphins. Coach Tony Sparano said Taylor was not expected to take part in team activities through camp. The revelation came less than 24 hours after Taylor finished second to Kristi Yamaguchi in the finals of “Dancing With the Stars” in Los Angeles.

Humpy Wheeler announced his retirement as president and general manager of Lowe’s Motor Speedway, ending a 33-year career as one of Nascar’s top promoters. Wheeler, 69, will step down after Sunday’s Coca-Cola 600 at the track near Charlotte. No replacement was selected. Wheeler has done almost everything to get fans to his track. He employed magicians, used back-flipping dogs, re-enacted war scenes in elaborate prerace shows and emphasized driver rivalries to make his track one of the premier locations in Nascar. Wheeler was also behind several of the sport’s innovations. To prevent Nascar from moving the All-Star race to Richmond, Va., Wheeler vowed to make his track the first superspeedway to erect lights.
In light of a report by the Justice Department, the Democrats in charge of Congress should press for full disclosure of President Bush’s inhuman policy on prisoners.
Soaring commodity prices have been an unanticipated boon to coal producing regions that had written coal mining off as a relic of the Industrial Revolution.
Connecticut’s Freedom of Information Commission should firmly deny the request to make public data of everyone who has a municipal ID card.
Regular customers have been speaking up for Antonios Dragonas, a food vendor who is to appear before an administrative law judge to determine whether he can continue operating.
Reforming the health care system can be more effective if doctors admit the errors they make and are candid about how they went astray.
Ryan Church said he expected to miss only one game after suffering his second concussion of the spring on Tuesday night while trying to break up a double play.
It was destructive for Germany’s foreign minister to break ranks with the leader of his government on human rights by refusing to meet with the Dalai Lama.
Tibetan opponents of Beijing are struggling to compete with China’s growing diplomatic and economic clout.
How can Google, the Internet search and advertising giant, contend that teaming up with Yahoo in search ads would not invite an antitrust challenge?
On Tuesday, officials from the baseball commissioner’s office held conference calls with club officials and umpires to remind them of rules designed to quicken the pace of games.

Two unlikely acts top this week’s Billboard album chart. Death Cab for Cutie, a bookish indie-rock quartet from Seattle, has reached No. 1 for the first time, and a Frank Sinatra compilation is No. 2. “Narrow Stairs” (Atlantic), Death Cab for Cutie’s seventh album, sold 144,000 copies in its first week, Nielsen SoundScan reported. “Nothing but the Best” (Reprise), released to coincide with the 10th anniversary of Sinatra’s death, moved 99,000 copies and is the highest-charting Sinatra album since his “Duets” reached No. 2 a dozen years ago. “We Sing. We Dance. We Steal Things.” (Atlantic) by the singer Jason Mraz bowed at No. 3 with 73,000 sales, and another new album, “Rockferry” (A&M/Polydor) by the Welsh singer Duffy, is No. 4, moving 71,000.
The final performance of the rock musical will be exhibited in movie theaters nationwide.

In Paris on Wednesday Sotheby’s sold Simone de Beauvoir’s first completed novel, written when she was 18, along with tapes and other manuscripts of hers, all part of a rare trove of unpublished material compiled by one of her biographers, Fernande Gontier. “Départ,” (“Departure”) is a 351-page autobiographical novel that Beauvoir, above, finished in 1926; it brought about $56,260 and was sold to France’s National Library. Ms. Gontier, who collaborated with Beauvoir until she died in 1986, bought Beauvoir’s earliest manuscripts, including the novel, from a bookstore in Boston in 1980.

Bearing scars from a brazen theft, the Edvard Munch Expressionist masterwork “The Scream” went back on view on Wednesday in Oslo at the Munch Museum, where it was stolen in 2004, Agence France-Presse reported. “The Scream” and “Madonna,” another Munch painting seized at the same time, were presented to the news media and will go on public display from Friday through Sept. 26 under the title “Scream and Madonna — Revisited.” Then “Madonna” will undergo further restoration. The museum said its “Scream,” long thought to have been painted in 1893, as was another version, probably dates from 1910, although some doubts remain. Both paintings were scratched and torn and showed signs of humidity damage when they were recovered by the police in August 2006 under mysterious circumstances.

Spike Lee is at the Cannes Film Festival to promote a new film, but he couldn’t resist taking a few swipes at his fellow directors Joel and Ethan Coen and Clint Eastwood. Speaking about his World War II drama, “Miracle at St. Anna,” Mr. Lee said that, unlike the Coens, he was respectful in the way he portrayed death.“I always treat life and death with respect, but most people don’t,” he said at a news conference on Tuesday, according to The Hollywood Reporter. “Look, I love the Coen brothers; we all studied at N.Y.U. But they treat life like a joke. Ha ha ha. A joke. It’s like: ‘Look how they killed that guy! Look how blood squirts out the side of his head!’ I see things different than that.”Speaking about the casting for his tale of four black American soldiers in Tuscany, Mr. Lee said that black actors appeared in war films too infrequently.“Clint Eastwood made two films about Iwo Jima that ran for more than four hours total, and there was not one Negro actor on the screen,” he said, adding, “There’s no way I know why he did that — that was his vision, not mine.” Mr. Lee also said that he was starting work on a documentary about Michael Jordan.

The monumental Thomas Moran landscape “Green River of Wyoming,” above, estimated at $3.5 million to $5 million, sold on Wednesday for $17.73 million at a Christie’s sale of American art in New York. The price set a record for a 19th-century American painting, surpassing that of John Singer Sargent’s “Robert Louis Stevenson and His Wife,” which fetched $8.8 million when it was sold at Sotheby’s in 2004 to the Las Vegas casino owner Stephen A. Wynn and his wife, Elaine. The buyer of the Moran was the Avery Galleries of Bryn Mawr, Pa. Another oil on canvas, Marsden Hartley’s “Lighthouse,” created in Berlin in 1915 and recently brought to light after its discovery in a museum in eastern Germany, sold for $6.31 million to an anonymous telephone bidder. Christie’s said the painting, with a estimate of $5 million to $7 million, set an auction record for an American Modernist painting, surpassing the $6.16 million for Georgia O’Keeffe’s “Calla Lilies With Red Anemone,” sold at Christie’s in 2001.

Lou Pearlman, right, the former manager of pop acts like the Backstreet Boys and ’N Sync, was sentenced to 25 years in prison on Wednesday for running a decades-long investment scheme that defrauded investors of $300 million. In a sentencing hearing at Federal District Court in Orlando, Fla., Judge G. Kendall Sharp gave Mr. Pearlman an unusual incentive to pay back his investors, offering to reduce the sentence by one month for every $1 million he repays. Mr. Pearlman, 53, pleaded guilty in March to charges of conspiracy and money laundering in connection with a Ponzi scheme in which he used fake accounting documents to lure people to invest in two companies that existed only on paper. Mr. Pearlman fled the country early last year, once federal authorities began investigating him, and in June he was found at a hotel in Bali, registered under the name A. Incognito Johnson. Larry Rifken, a lawyer representing victims of the schemes, said in a statement: “The Creditors Committee is delighted with Judge Sharp’s ruling today on Mr. Pearlman’s sentence and believes that Judge Sharp did an excellent job in maximizing Mr. Pearlman’s incentive to cooperate with the Trustee and the Committee in identifying, locating and monetizing any remaining undisclosed assets.”.

As David Archuleta and David Cook competed for the title of “American Idol,” the second-to-last installment of the Fox show’s seventh season attracted 26.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. That tally was up slightly from the same night a year ago (25.3 million). Fox dominated the night’s ratings over all, attracting 12.6 million with “Hell’s Kitchen” during the 9 o’clock hour after the final performances. ABC was runner up, as 19.9 million viewers tuned in for the finale of “Dancing With the Stars” from 9 to 11. CBS ranked third, earning a large audience for the two-hour finale of “NCIS” (16.4 million). At 10, CBS’s “Shark” delivered more modest ratings (10.5 million). NBC finished fourth over all, with mostly repeats.

LUGGAGE FEE American Airlines said it would begin charging passengers $15 to check a bag and announced a reduction in service and jobs. URGENCY ON OIL With gas prices nearing $4 a gallon, there is pressure for Congress to appear proactive, and momentum is building for several measures. [C1.]

8 P.M. (TCM) DIRECTED BY STEVEN SPIELBERG Just in time for the opening of ''Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull,'' Turner Classic Movies pays tribute to its director. The action begins with Mr. Spielberg's ''Jaws'' (1975), above from left, Roy Scheider, Robert Shaw and Richard Dreyfuss, after which beachgoing was never the same, followed at 10:15 by Richard Schickel's documentary ''Spielberg on Spielberg'' (2007), in which the director talks all about himself, and, at midnight, by the out-of-this-world ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind'' (1977). The evening ends with ''1941'' (1979), Mr. Spielberg's attempt to satirize events surrounding the actual arrival of a Japanese submarine off the coast of Santa Barbara, Calif., during World War II -- and the most critically lambasted film of his career. 8 P.M. (Fox) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE Some will have to think again as this series begins its fourth season with the requisite round of auditions. First stops: Dallas, Salt Lake City, Los Angeles, Milwaukee, Washington and Charleston, S.C., where would-be hoofers put their personal spins on hip-hop, salsa, disco and jive. The Las Vegas round, in which the 20 finalists are announced, begins on June 5.

PRESSMAN--William M., 93, died May 18, 2008 two years after a stroke. Loving husband of the late Rhoda Pressman, loved father of Penny Bernstein (Jonathan) and Fred Pressman (Ronni) and proud grandfather of Sally Pressman Bernstein, Benjamin Rhodes Bernstein, Ryan Alan Pressman and Randy William Pressman. Born in NYC, he graduated from the University of Georgia where he played football for the Bulldogs and went to the Orange Bowl. He was a philosophy major who was also on the boxing team (odd choice for a Jewish boy from Harlem). After college, he joined his brother, Jack, in sales at Pressman Toy. He then created GI Joe as the Executive vice president of Hasbro. He will be greatly missed by his family forever.
City Room SLIDESHOW: FIVE PHOTOGRAPHERS' VIEWS OF NEW YORK

HIRSHKOWITZ--Lois, 72, of New York, NY died on May 20, 2008. She is survived by her husband and best friend Archie, children Roy and wife Pam, Debbie and husband Charlie, Sandy and husband Doug, sister Claire, and sisterin-law Beverly and husband Ed. Beloved grandma to Dylan, Malya, Charlie and Dania. Founding director of Lakewood Prep, a founding editor of Barrow Street poetry journal, author of four books of poetry. Best wife and friend, best mother and grandmother, best sister, best teacher. And in the motto of her life, from Chaucer, ''gladly wolde he lerne and gladly teche''. Services Thursday 11:45am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

An anonymous donor has come to the rescue of St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church in the East Village, saving the building -- which has presided over Tompkins Square Park since 1848 -- from demolition and making it possible for the structure to be reopened as a parish church. The Archdiocese of New York announced on Wednesday that a donor had come forward with an ''unexpected but very welcome gift'' of $20 million after a private meeting with Cardinal Edward M. Egan, the archbishop of New York.

SHATZKIN--Doris (Granoff), age 86, died May 21st. Beloved wife of Dr. E. H. (Herb) Shatzkin, her husband of 64 years, mother of Roger and Steve, mother-in-law of Wendy Kaczerski and Deborah Uhler Shatzkin, sister-in-law of Julius Spencer and aunt of Karen Brunschwig and Lynn Spencer. She was cherished by granddaughters Amy, Natasha and Lilianna, as well as by her sister Harriet Spencer and granddaughter Sarah, who both preceded her in death. Fiercely curious, she adored reading, good food, charitable and political causes, and speaking her mind. Her love for language inspired many, including hundreds of adults who left her classes wiser in the ways of English and their adopted country. Family and friends will greatly miss her. A memorial will be held May 25 at 3pm, at Guttermans Funeral Chapel, 175 N. Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

HALL--S. Jeanne, on May 21st, 2008. Beloved wife of Sherwin Kamin. Loving sister, devoted aunt and highly regarded partner of the law firm Fulton Rowe and Hart. Service Friday, May 23rd, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts.

Hamilton Jordan, a self-proclaimed ''political animal'' who, at 26, ran Jimmy Carter's successful campaign for governor and, at 31, Mr. Carter's winning bid for the White House, then became the president's chief of staff and top strategist, died Tuesday at his home in Atlanta. He was 63. His death was announced by the Carter Center in Atlanta. Mr. Jordan had had long-running battles with cancer, beginning with aggressive lymphoma in the mid-1980s and later bouts of prostate and skin cancer. At his death he was surrounded by friends and family members, including his son Hamilton Jr., who had flown in from Europe, the Carter Center said.

COHEN--Bruce. You will be missed everyday, the best father, grandfather and friend. We will take care of Grandma, and your grandchildren will know how special you were. Donations to Hope for Stroke, 250 Duck Pond Dr., Wantagh, NY 10006. Love your daughters, Erica Rosenfeld and Susan Parker COHEN--Bruce. Hineni Expresses profound sympathy to Sherry Cohen and family. Sherry, you moved mountains to save Bruce. Yours was a marriage sealed in love and that love, as well as your goodness and the goodness and joyous spirit of Bruce will live eternally.

KOEPPEL--Dorothy P., passed away peacefully on May 21st, on her 98th birthday. Predeceased by her husband Louis; survived by her children Mitchell, Richard (Susan), Joel (Carolle); seven grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. Private graveside ceremony at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, Queens.

MEYER--Morton G., passed away on May 15. He was 103 and lived in Lake Worth, FL, and in Eastchester, NY. Morty is survived by his wife, Barbara, two daughters, Phyllis Reichman and Janet Greenberg, three stepchildren, nine grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Association for Mentally Ill Children (AMIC), The Leukemia and LymphomaSociety, or Damon Runyon Cancer Research.
