GRIECO--Anna, on May 20, 2008. Beloved mother of Anthony (and his wife Audrey) and Andrew (and his wife Rebecca). Loving grandmother of Regina and Don Carroll, Matthew Grieco, Timothy and Shari Grieco, and Candice and Joseph Steel. Greatgrandmother of Cassandra, Angelina and Suzanne. Reposing Chas Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th St., NYC. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10am, St. Dominic's Church, Bricktown, NJ. Interment Ocean County Memorial Park, Toms River, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to NYU Langone Medical Center. Viewing Friday 2-4 and 7-9.

BRENNER--Charles. The Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine mourns the loss of our distinguished Life Member. One of the giants of psychoanalysis, he will be missed by his many friends, colleagues, students, and patients. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Jonah W. Schein, President

FILNER--Doris, 94, died on May 11 from complications following an accident suffered on May 9. She was an early childhood educator and tireless campaigner for peace and social justice. She is survived by daughter, Nancy Stein, stepsons Rep. Bob Filner and Dr. Bernard Filner, five grandchildren, Adam, Erin, Jesse, Katy and Matthew and five great-grandchildren. A memorial will be held at the Hallmark Residence in NYC, Noon on June 8th. Donations may be made to the Barack Obama campaign.

KARASIK--Muriel. The Officers and Board of Directors of the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation extend their condolences to the family of Muriel Karasik, our longtime supporter. May your memories be an everlasting source of comfort. Michael Nierenberg Chairman, Board of Directors Samuel Waxman, M.D. Scientific Director Merle Kailas Executive Director

ROSECAN--Jeffrey, M.D. The Trustees and staff of the NYC Police Foundation note with sorrow the passing of our good friend. His wise counsel aided the establishment of a ground - breaking mental health program for NYPD employees and their families in the aftermath of the September 11 attacks. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife and the entire Rosecan family. Pamela D. Delaney, President Ellen Stevenson, M.D. Project COPE

KATZ--Solomon H., 82, of Deerfield Beach, FL, formerly of NYC, passed away May 19, 2008. Dear brother of Sunny Howard. Cherished uncle of Alan, Andrew (Jane), Bruce (Marion), and Debbie (Glen). A New York State judge for over 15 years. Services entrusted to Star of David Florida, 954-722-9000.

LEBWORTH--M. Joseph. The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art mourns the loss of our dear friend, M. Joseph Lebworth. Joe always accompanied his wife, Caral, who has been a treasured member of the International Council since 1971. He traveled with the Council to countries all over the world, generously sharing his intelligence and humor. His wonderful photographs of Council members will be a great source of joy for years to come. Joe will be missed by his many friends. We send heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Caral, and to his family. Brian Urquhart, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President Joanne M. Stern, Vice Chairman The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art LEBWORTH--M. Joseph, died on May 17, 2008 at the age of 86. Joe's heroism and service to his country in World War II will long be remembered. He parachuted into Normandy the night before D-Day as a member of the 101st Airborne Division and received serious leg injuries after 17 days of combat. He was subsequently awarded the Bronze Star, the Purple Heart, the Infantry Combat Badge and France's Liberation Medal. Joe devoted the last several decades to the two great passions in his life: his family, and especially his devoted wife of 46 years, Caral; and not-for-profit endeavors, particularly the Museum of Modern Art film department and his alma mater, Yale University. His loss will leave a great void, and he will be missed by his many friends and family members. We will especially miss Joe's smiling face, his curiosity about every facet of life, his astute political insights and his unfailing courage. He is survived by his wife, Caral; his three stepchildren Glenn Greenberg, Stephen Greenberg and Alva Greenberg; and ten grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Museum of Modern Art Film Department, 11 West 53 Street, NY, NY 10019-5497. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday May 28th at 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue.

The Skin Deep column last Thursday, about spa treatments using locally produced ingredients, referred incorrectly to the Maine Blueberry Pedicure at the Cliff House Resort and Spa in Ogunquit, Me. The pedicure was provided at no extra charge for guests booking a three- or four-night stay last July and August; it is not offered free with the purchase of a Maine Blueberry Body Wrap.

THERE is a sad deficiency of well-made men's swimwear. Apart from classic surfer shorts from reliable suppliers like Birdwell, we are drowning in a sea of bunchy nylon, bad graphics and unfortunate cuts. You know it's bad when the most prevalent and popular trunks are hideously baggy knee-length board shorts covered with weird neon symbols, strange netting and stripes. They make you look like a human energy drink. Even fashion-y swimsuits are lame and poorly rendered. Last summer there was a big ''square-cut brief'' trend, and I bought a pair from a place called Bang Bang or Boing Boing, I can't remember. By July, they had stretched out into the shape of an adult diaper.

NOREK--Jay. To ''Our Handsome Uncle Jay''-we already miss your smile, your terrible jokes, your answering machine jingles, your tie-swapping, your joyful enthusiasm, your love of family and heritage, and most of all, your keeping your eye out for us always. Alice and Bob.

MICHON--Warren F., 73, of Manhattan, died Saturday May 17, 2008. An opera coach, conductor and music librarian, he worked for the NY Public Library Music Division at Lincoln Center from 1967 to 1992. For complete obituary and guestbook, visit www.mcloughlinmason.com

MORRIS--N. Peter, born January 31, 1927; passed away peacefully May 18, 2008, in Sarasota, Florida. Beloved husband of Dr. Marian Morris for 58 years. Loving father of Robin Ley, Wendy Siegel (Stephen B.), Lori Morris Green (Michael), Wayne (Laurie) and Vickie Goldstein (Richard). Loving grandfather of Jessica (Peter), Alexander, Jared, Cassandra, Sage, Winston, Megan, Samantha, Peter, Brandon, Jaimie, Lauren and Stephanie. A wonderful, multifaceted man who was defined by the words love, kindness and intelligence. A leader in the field of nuclear science and a founding member and President of the American Nuclear Society when he lived in Pittsburgh. While living in Carlsbad, NM, he was President, and a member of the Crisis Committee of the American Red Cross, the American Cancer Society and his synagogue. He was a member of the International Rotary and worked at the Carlsbad Mental Health facility. A man who led his family by example with dignity and quiet strength. He will live in our hearts forever. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to Temple Emanu - EL, 151 South McIntosh Road, Sarasota, FL 34232; or Tidewell Hospice & Palliative Care, 5955 Rand Blvd, Sarasota, FL 34238.

HOROWITZ--Dr. Henry, passed away on May 20 after a bout with cancer. Henry was a Psychiatrist in NYC and a board member for many years of the Karen Horney Clinic. Henry served in the US Navy in WWII. He was Attending Psychiatrist at Metropolitan Hospital and had a private practice. He will be missed by his widow Annette, his sons Dr. Eliot Horowitz and David Horowitz, stepsons Mark and Robert Harris, daughters-in-law Melissa, Sarah, Adrienne and Jody and his seven grandchildren. Services May 23 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., at 11:15am.

HALLEY--Janice Brosh. March 10th, 1920-May 19th, 2008. A courageous and loyal woman. Beloved wife of the late Rudolph Halley, mother of Peter Halley and Michael Halley. Grandmother of Isabel Halley, Thomas Halley and Rudolph Moses Halley and treasured friend of many. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to: Turtle Bay Association.
TISCHLER--Sara. A unique woman, forever loved. The Family

This weekend, we're running an article called "Coffee and naps not helping your jet lag? Try starving instead." The snappy headline (thanks to yours truly, ahem), is not totally straightforward. If you read into the text from Reuters, it quotes a study showing that food deprivation, or a drastic change in meal times, can override a mouse's internal clock and its natural mechanism for coordinating waking and sleeping with periods of light and dark. "A period of fasting with no food at all for about 16 hours is enough to engage this new clock," said Dr. Clifford Saper of Harvard Medical School, whose study appears in Science.

With the Memorial Day holiday bearing down hard on a blog that thinks the season of taking your laptop out to a rocking chair on the porch with a cold lemonade handy, a ballgame on the transistor radio and the scent of barbecue wafting through the neighborhood to your eager nostrils can't start soon enough, here are a few items we wish we'd gotten to today before the stampede out of Dodge took hold in earnest:

Biofuels made from farm crops probably are the most controversial form of renewable energy. One reason is their supposed effect on food prices, which have shot up across the world in recent months and led to prortests and riots in some developing nations. Opinion leaders like Jeffrey Sachs of Columbia University are calling on governments to review their targets for biofuels, while many environmental and anti-poverty groups say crop fuels that compete with food should be abandoned entirely.In a new study, New Energy Finance, an energy consultancy in London, shows that biofuels do have an effect on food prices but that this effect may not be quite as significant as some people think.

Omar Minaya is somewhere over middle America, on his way to Denver to either show support for the Mets or to see first-hand what has happened to his $140 million team. The Mets have a front-office representative -- either Minaya, Tony Bernazard, the vice president of development, or the assistant general manager John Ricco -- traveling with the team to every city, but I can't recall Minaya making a trip out here since I took over the beat, in August 2005. Because he can, Minaya will usually pick cities like Miami, San Francisco or Washington, but I can guarantee you that he is not here, on Memorial Day weekend, because he wants to try the Vesta Dipping Grill.

Democratic Party officials in Queens voted today not to endorse State Senator John D. Sabini, a Queens Democrat who has been in office six years. Instead, they voted to back his challenger, City Councilman Hiram Monserrate.

You don't have to search very hard to find the excruciating online videos known as thinspiration, or thinspo. Photomontages of skeletal women, including some celebrities and models, play all over the Internet, uploaded from the United States, Germany, Holland and elsewhere. These videos are designed to "inspire" viewers - to fortify their ambitions. But exactly which ambitions? To lose weight, presumably. To stop losing weight, possibly. Thinspo videos profess a range of ideologies, often pressing morbid images into double service, as both goads and deterrents to anorexia.

The two-hour season finale of "Grey's Anatomy" vaulted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday, attracting 17.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. Although the number of viewers for the show's fourth season conclusion declined nearly 5 million compared to a year ago (22.6 million), it still led the night by a wide margin over its nearest competitor, NBC's "Deal or No Deal," which garnered 10.3 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m.

Gymnast Paul Hamm, who won a gold medal at the 2004 Athens Games and is the only American to win an all-around gold at an Olympics or world championship, has a broken bone in his hand that will probably force him to miss next month's U.S. team trials. News today of one more way human activity might be helping wreck the planet: Research by Italian marine biologists, reported in Environmental Health Priorities, suggests that the sunscreen that washes off the skin of swimmers in the tropics may be contributing to coral bleaching.

Senator Barack Obama added three superdelegates to his total today, a boost that comes after he saw just a trickle of delegates go to his side in recent days. Despite Mr. Obama's triumphant speech in Iowa and the buzz about the vice presidential search, the Senator had not initially capitalized on his performance in Tuesday's primaries, which gave him a majority of pledged delegates. (He received only two superdelegates on Wednesday and none on Thursday).

The battle between financial and strategic buyers has broken out on a new front: Expro, a relatively small oil-service firm based in the United Kingdom. On one side is a consortium of financial investors that includes Goldman Sachs and the British private equity firm Candover. On the other side sits the oil-service giant Halliburton, or "Big Red" as it is known in the trenches.

Ricky Walters, a 43-year-old hip-hop pioneer known for the rap classic "The Great Adventures of Slick Rick" and was convicted of attempted murder in 1991, has received a full pardon from Gov. David A. Paterson. The governor said in a statement that he decided to pardon Mr. Walters, who was released from prison in 1997, to prevent him from being deported to Britain, where Mr. Walters was born and lived until the age of 11.

Bruno Senna carried on a family tradition today, taking victory in the GP2 support race in Monaco. His uncle Ayrton must have been hovering over him somewhere, especially at the start of the race. Senna started second and just leapt into first ahead of the pole sitter, Maldonado. This is Monaco, so the two drivers also finished the race 45 laps later in that same position. Maldonado pressured Senna a few laps before the end but it did no good. In Third was the Indian driver Chandhok, who started sixth. He should have finished fourth, but on the last lap Conway spun out....

In her column, Sheryl Gay Stolberg writes that the very public dust-up between the White House and NBC over the editing of an interview with President Bush, suggests the White House intends a more combative stance with the media in the twilight of the administration, as attention turns away from Mr. Bush and toward those trying to succeed him.

John Thain, the new chief executive of Merrill Lynch, is is raising the volume of his firm's voice in Washington. The New York investment bank replaced its chief in-house lobbyist in March and, according to a document made public late last week, hired a new outside lobbying firm in April. The moves come amid a deluge of legislative efforts aimed at the financial service industry.

Some pretty amazing before-during-and-after photographs of the devastating May 12 earthquake in China have surfaced, photos that exist because of the timing of the quake -- in midafternoon, when several newlywed couples happened to be having their wedding photos taken near the town of Bailu.

A rich pancake, like those often served in Sweden, takes the proportions of a standard pancake and skews them, boosting the proportion of eggs, butter and sugar at the expense of flour. As with brownies or cookies, when you increase fat and sweetness and decrease filler (a k a flour), the results are indisputably better, and -- thanks to beaten egg whites -- supremely light and airy.

The buzz is back: Speculation about a deal between Inbev and Anheuser Busch returned to Wall Street on Friday, when FT Alphaville reported that Inbev was considering a $46 billion takeover approach to its United States-based rival.

Senator Hillary Clinton is keeping hope alive today with a new assessment of the popular vote that says she is poised to finish the primary season on June 3 as the winner of the overall popular vote, at least by the most inclusive measure, which would include the tallies from all states.

What a difference a few weeks make. At the end of April, a barracks at Fort Bragg, the North Carolina home of the Army's 82nd Airborne Division, was a YouTube embarrassment replete with bad plumbing, mold and peeling paint. On Thursday, the commander-in-chief dropped by to witness a dramatically improved building. Freshly-painted walls were bright white, bathroom fixtures gleamed and everything seemed to be in tip-top shape.

The status of Senator John McCain's health over the course of the last eight years or so will be a primary topic of discussion today, as some of his medical records have been made available for the media to review.

There are people who say you have to stand next to the Verizon building at 375 Pearl Street to appreciate how ugly it is -- its blank presence at street level, its disconnection from any human scale. There are others who say the offensiveness of the tower, built to house communications equipment, stems from the way it overshadows the Brooklyn Bridge when viewed from afar, acting as a drab, yet commercialized, backdrop (topped with a light-up Verizon sign ).

Gov. David A. Paterson has quietly declared a political truce with Joseph L. Bruno and his party in a shift that is turning Albany upside down and making some Democrats privately uneasy, Danny Hakim reports. Although the governor is committed to raising money for the state's Democrats, he has been reluctant to recruit candidates to run against incumbent Republicans at a time when the Democrats appear tantalizingly close to taking over the Senate for the first time in more than 40 years.
"Law & Order: Criminal Intent" will remain on the case for another season on USA Network, the Associated Press reports.
WNBC is making another evening newscast change, and this one will install the channel's two leading anchors, Chuck Scarborough and Sue Simmons, at 6 p.m.

Wall Street Journal: "Time Warner Inc. and a partnership between General Electric Co.'s NBC Universal and Blackstone Group LP have emerged as leading contenders to win an auction for the Weather Channel, ahead of Friday's deadline for a second round of bids." Bids are due Friday.

Sandford I. Weill, Citigroup's former chairman and chief executive, has acknowledged that the planning that led to the choice of Charles O. Prince as his successor in 2003 was flawed and turned out not to be the "right thing" for the company, The Financial Times reported.
Shares in Silverjet were suspended Friday as the company revealed a key funding deal had failed to materialize, prompting speculation that the British business-class airline is near collapse.

My column today discusses a surprising decision by the chief judge of the Seventh U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, Frank Easterbrook, that essentially negates a section of the Investment Company Act allowing mutual fund shareholders to sue over management fees they deem to be too high.

As first lady, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton spent eight years standing behind a president in the White House. And now, if she can't get there on her own, former President Bill Clinton is said to be musing, perhaps she ought to do it again - as vice president. Though both campaigns have shrugged off such suggestions, some think the move would help unify the party. And, of course, Senator Barack Obama, assuming he becomes the Democratic nominee, has plenty of other choices.

Tiger Capital Group and SB Capital Group won a bidding war to become the joint stalking-horse bidders to lead a partial liquidation of Linens 'n Things, paving the way for the May 29 auction of Apollo Management's bankrupt retailer.

When General Electric announced it might sell its appliances unit, top bosses at Haier, G.E.'s rival in China, apparently jumped at what could be their last opportunity to buy a U.S. business with a household name.

Serious management failures by immediate superiors allowed a rogue trader at Société Générale to commit the biggest fraud in financial history, according to The New York Times which cited an internal report to be released Friday.
SmartSynch, which sells smart metering technology to the utility industry, has raised $20 million in new funding led by new investors Credit Suisse and Southern Farm Bureau Life Insurance.
Mocana, a maker of security software for non-PC devices like PDAs, has raised $7 million in its second round of venture funding.
Makoto Haga, who in 1998 became the first hedge fund manager at Nomura Holdings, will start his own asset management firm with investments among Japan's 800 largest companies.

A former stock trader was charged on Thursday with duping friends out of $16 million over six years by luring them into various investments, most of which never existed, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said.
Each morning in London, a handful of banks quietly decide how much it costs to borrow money all over the world.

Two hedge funds engaged in a proxy battle with Atos Origin got a surprise vote of support Thursday, but the outcome remained remained unclear as the French IT services firm suspended the annual meeting after an employee shareholder group said it would vote in support of board nominees proposed by rebel hedge fund shareholders.
Borders Group has not had substantial discussions regarding a possible sale and was moving forward on efforts to improve its business, Chief Executive George Jones said Thursday.
Northwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines, which last month announced plans to combine, on Thursday won final federal approval to share revenue and coordinate schedules across the Atlantic.

In the latest sign that the outlook for the airline industry is darkening, Standard & Poor's Ratings Services on Thursday placed nine big airlines on CreditWatch with negative implications, meaning that it was likely to cut their debt ratings.
Two years ago, a financier named Malon Wilkus spied what seemed like a good buy: Scientific Protein Laboratories, of Waunakee, Wis.
Despite apparent market expectations that NRG may raise its $11 billion bid for Calpine, at least one analyst thinks a lengthy courtship between the two power generators is unlikely.

Merrill Lynch is negotiating a deal to build a 70-story headquarters at ground zero, a plan that would make it the first financial firm to return to the 16-acre former World Trade Center site since the terrorist attack destroyed the complex in 2001.

Austrian bank Bawag, which is owned by a consortium headed by the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, said it is likely to be in shape for an initial public offering before its target of 2012.

Halliburton, the world's second-biggest oilfield contractor, offered 1.71 billion pounds ($3.4 billion) for Expro International Group, topping a bid by Candover Partners and Goldman Sachs, as record crude prices spur exploration.

In honor of the the Phoenix's scheduled arrival on Mars this weekend, we have a space-exploration quiz and prize for you. If the NASA spacecraft survives its fiery descent -- the "seven minutes of terror," as my colleague Warren Leary reports-- it will land on Sunday a little before 8 p.m. Eastern time on the arctic plain of Mars. [UPDATE: The Phoenix landed safely and is sending back photos, Ken Chang reports.]

Flock, the creator of a "social Web browser" that is fast gaining traction among devotees of cutting-edge Internet technology, has scored another $15 million in fresh funding, the company announced Thursday.

Overcrowded trains and endless traffic jams are frustrating and stressful, but if you find yourself on a route that is undergoing engineering and structural improvements, your journey can make you lose the will to live.

Infantile, irreverent and boorish to the max, “Postal” explodes with bad attitude and lousy filmmaking.

The city’s Department of Education released a list on Thursday of 74 schools, including its most prestigious high schools, that are to have their budgets for next year cut by more than 5 percent.
BUSINESS DAY.
A sports article on Wednesday about the N.B.A. draft lottery misstated, in some editions, the number of teams the Chicago Bulls leapfrogged to win the No. 1 pick. It was eight, not seven.

An article on Saturday about Representative Anthony D. Weiner’s use of earmarks to finance pet projects in his district — a practice for which he has criticized the New York City Council — misidentified the borough that includes the Ryan Visitor Center of the Gateway National Recreation Area, for which Mr. Weiner secured about $66 million in improvements. The center is in Brooklyn, not Queens.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the plan of a biotech company, BioArts, to use online auctions to sell chances to clone a dog misstated the percentage of embryo transfers that the company said resulted in a puppy. Lou Hawthorne, the chief executive of BioArts, said the success rate was 25 percent — not 1 percent to 4 percent.

An article and a picture caption on Thursday about a class-action lawsuit filed by a Florida pension fund against the American International Group misidentified the founder of A.I.G. It was founded by Cornelius Vander Starr — not by Maurice R. Greenberg, its former chief executive.

An article on Thursday about an investigation into the possibility that a computer error at the Moody’s Corporation led to incorrect credit ratings of securities paraphrased incorrectly a comment by Christopher Cox, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, about his agency’s power in the inquiry. Mr. Cox said it was unclear if the S.E.C. had authority over the ratings, which were assigned in Europe. He did not say that the S.E.C. had no authority.

An article on Wednesday about the struggle to complete renovations to the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum in time for a scheduled fall reopening referred incorrectly to one of its exhibitions, a decommissioned submarine named the Growler. It was diesel powered and carried missiles with nuclear warheads; it was not nuclear powered.

The Abroad column on Tuesday, about the future of Tempelhof Airport in Berlin, misstated the percentage of Berliners who voted in a nonbinding referendum on whether to keep the airport open, and misstated a requirement for the proposal’s approval. About 36 percent of eligible voters took part, not 22 percent. Approval required a “yes” vote from at least 25 percent of eligible voters, not a turnout of 25 percent of eligible voters. (While a large majority of those taking part, as the column noted, voted to keep it open, those votes came from only about 22 percent of eligible voters, short of the requirement.).
The Game Theory column in the Circuits pages on Thursday, reviewing Wii Fit from Nintendo, misstated the price for the product. It is $90, not $180.

The Lens feature in some editions on Wednesday, about the powerhouse and laundry building in United States Marine Hospital 43 on Ellis Island, misstated the name of the mainland medical institution with which the Ellis Island hospital was associated. It is the Long Island College Hospital, not the Long Island Medical Center.
A San Diego Superior Court judge ruled that five men accused of killing a professional surfer should stand trial for second-degree murder, but denied the men constituted a criminal street gang.

Lawyers for a group that opposes same-sex marriage have filed a motion asking the State Supreme Court to stay its recent decision effectively legalizing such marriages and rehear arguments on the issue.

Johnson Wagner bogeyed two of three holes midway through the first round of the Crowne Plaza Invitational in Fort Worth, but matched his best score on the PGA Tour — a seven-under 63 and a two-stroke lead over Phil Mickelson and Brett Wetterich.

The former Southern California star O. J. Mayo has been dropped by his agent because of the ”overwhelming intensity” of allegations that Mayo illegally received cash and gifts. Mayo had announced that Calvin Andrews of Bill Duffy Associates would represent him. But the sports management group issued a statement Thursday saying their association was over. BDA Sports said it would ask the N.B.A. Players Association to waive the standard 15-day cooling-off period so Mayo could sign with a new agent immediately.

Athletes at the Beijing Olympics will be subject to no-advance-notice doping controls at any time and any place, the International Olympic Committee said. The I.O.C. said it would conduct 4,500 tests, up from 3,600 in Athens four years ago.

The Red Wings’ Johan Franzen was expected to miss Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals against Pittsburgh on Saturday, but Coach Mike Babcock said Franzen would return during the series. Franzen leads the N.H.L. with 12 playoff goals despite missing the last five games of the Western Conference finals against Dallas with concussion-like symptoms.

Erica Blasberg shot a seven-under 65 on a raw day, more like early March than late May, to take a two-shot lead over Na On Min of South Korea and Karine Icher of France after the first round of the L.P.G.A. Corning (N.Y.) Classic.

Tony Granato returned as the coach of the Colorado Avalanche, four years after he was demoted from the job. Granato will take over from Joel Quenneville, who left the Avalanche two weeks ago by mutual agreement. Granato was 72-33-17-11 when he led the team from 2002 to 2004.

Lionel Messi will play for Argentina at the Beijing Olympics instead of Barcelona in Champions League qualifying. Messi, who turns 21 next month, told the Spanish sports daily Marca, “It is my decision, and the Olympic Games is something which I will never get the chance to play in again,” he said. He added that he had yet to speak to Barcelona about the decision, but the team cannot prevent Messi from playing in the Games because he is younger than 23. FIFA, the world governing body, considers the Olympics an under-23 championship.

Indiana Coach Tom Crean dismissed forward Brandon McGee from the team, leaving the Hoosiers with three returning players for next season. McGee was kicked off the team because of academic and team guideline violations. The only returning players remaining on the roster are guard Jordan Crawford, forward Kyle Taber and the walk-on guard Brett Finkelmeier. Crean has signed six new players to scholarship offers since becoming the coach last month.

CLASSICAL.

Through all the unpredictability in the first month-and-a-half of this baseball season (the Yankees and Tigers are in last place, the Marlins are in first, and baseball’s best pitcher might be Cliff Lee, of all people), one fact appears to be emerging: The Chicago Cubs are the best team in baseball. Let that sink in. Mull it over. Wrap it around your cerebral cortex. And imagine the terror that this has caused me and my fellow St. Louis Cardinals fans.

How fortunes can change. At the beginning of last season, Kerry Wood was, as Buzz Bissinger wrote for PLAY, “less a real ballplayer than a cautionary tale” whose flamethrower-turned-feeble story symbolized the “nightmarish possibilities for young pitchers.” But after slogging through another rehab and trying his hand in the Cubs bullpen last year, Wood has emerged this season as one of the league’s best closers. Wood has converted 10 of his first 13 save opportunities, using his fastball — which is back in the upper 90s — and nasty slider to strike out 22 in 22 2/3 innings.

As sports become ever more specialized, with left-handed relief specialists and second-down nickel backs rendering versatility downright quaint, few athletes should intrigue us as much as Micah Owings of the Arizona Diamondbacks.

In Las Vegas, if it’s action at the tables or sportsbooks you’re craving, stick with heart-of-the-Strip locales. For the best Sin City golf experiences, however, you’ve got to get out of town. Shadow Creek, a half-hour north of the Strip and the top golf venue for high-rolling MGM/Mirage whales, shut down last week for a seven-month refurbishment. Fortunately, a spectacular new layout opened in May to pick up the slack. The Chase at PGA Golf Club Coyote Springs may be awkwardly named, but the course is seamless from start to finish.

Manchester United and Chelsea pummeled each other through regulation time and two fatigue-inducing extra periods in the Champions League final before Man U finally prevailed on penalty kicks. Soccer has used penalties to decide tie matches in tournaments for more than three decades, often prompting criticism that it employs a manufactured endgame to settle its most important competitions. Does Wednesday’s thrilling finale validate the system as the best one available? And if not, what would?.

''Every vote counts'' is one of those platitudes, like ''Watch your step,'' that doesn't have much meaning until that first really bad fall. It certainly had resonance in the 2000 presidential election, when the Florida voting ended in a hairline finish that took 36 days and a Supreme Court decision to resolve. It was historic and historically awful, until the Sept. 11 attacks wiped away much of the anguish and slapstick. For a while, at least, the Florida vote count seemed as trivial and irrelevant as the results of the Henley Regatta after August 1914.

Infantile, irreverent and boorish to the max, ''Postal'' explodes with bad attitude and lousy filmmaking. Opening with the sine qua non of tasteless 9/11 gags and closing with a shot of President Bush (Brent Mendenhall) skipping through a field of mushroom clouds hand in hand with ''Sammy,'' a k a Osama bin Laden (Larry Thomas), this idiot burlesque of American society manages to be both clueless and fearless. Jokes about Oprah's diet and indecisive Starbucks customers? Tired. A celebrity midget (Verne Troyer) being gang-raped by monkeys to advance the apocalyptic agenda of the orgiastic hippie cult Denomination of Organic Monotheism? Timeless!

SUSAN RETHORST In April of last year, Susan Rethorst's ''208 East Broadway'' was one of the stars of Tere O'Connor's Nothing Festival at Dance Theater Workshop. Having lost her studio space to the rising tide of development, Ms. Rethorst worked with what she had: her living room and seven of the best dancers around, including Vicky Shick and Jeanine Durning. The resulting all-female performance, in which she recreated her living room in the theater, was magical: a commentary on the dire economic state of contemporary dance in New York that completely trumped its impoverished conditions and offered a portrait of human relations that was at once utterly mysterious and unerringly true. In ''208 East Broadway, Part 2: Window,'' which will have its premiere at Danspace Project on Thursday, Ms. Rethorst has branched out -- sort of. Using video, she has widened her scope by incorporating choreography created in the park that is visible through her living room window. (Perhaps she has borrowed a plant or two.)

We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Lorraine, and the entire Annunziata family. Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

BAYOU COUNTRY can be sampled as a day trip from New Orleans or serve as a landing spot for several days of exploration. The redfish is king, but there are other reasons to visit the bayou. Bourgeois Fishing Charters (504-341-5614; http://neworleansfishing.com) offers day trips for fishing. ($475 for two people and $75 for each additional person up to four). Fishing, lodging and meals are available at the Cajun Vista ($375), and there are also fishing-lodging packages for the Cajun Chalet, 18 miles away. Other guides in the area include Papa Joe (504-689-3728; www.fishneworleans.com) and Mike Daigle (504-915-9480; www.castitcharters.com).

In 1954, Frank Lloyd Wright provided Virginia and Don E. Lovness, then in their 20s, with a design for a Usonian-style house. With constant guidance from Wright, the couple built a 1,800-square-foot house, which they called the Studio, on their 20-acre lakefront property. It was completed in 1957 and features a master suite, a large living room overlooking the lake, a wing specifically designed for children, and two bathrooms. In 1974, the couple built an 800-square-foot cottage on the property, as well. It has a loft-style sitting room, a living area and a deck that overlooks the lake. Both the cottage and the main house have dolomite fireplaces, and the main house has radiant heat floors. This price includes all of the original Wright furnishings as well as his drawings for three additional cottages. Agent: Kimberly Falker, Sky Sotheby's International, (612) 743-8669; www.skysothebysrealty.com.

Klein, Rabbi Chanin Becker, Cantor Gerald Cohen, President

FOR CHILDREN AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY (Saturday through Thursday) Creatures that creep, crawl, slither and even swim are definitely the museum's stars this season. On Saturday the popular 2006 exhibition ''Lizards & Snakes: Alive!'' reopens, with more than 60 breathing (and hissing) examples, from five continents. The same day the museum will feature the debut of a new Imax film, ''Sea Monsters: A Prehistoric Adventure,'' playing every half-hour from 10:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Its subject is not the monsters of myth but very real species, like Dolichorhynchops and Styxosaurus, which swam the oceans while T. rex walked the earth. Open daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., at Central Park West and 79th Street, (212) 769-5200, amnh.org. Tickets to special exhibitions and Imax films (includes museum admission): $22; $16.50 for students and 60+; $13 for 12 and younger.

The R. W. Lindholm Residence, which is being sold by the original owners, was completed in 1956. An example of Frank Lloyd Wright's Usonian style, the house is approximately 2,300 square feet and is on seven wooded acres bordered by a city park. The house is in good condition and retains most of its original furnishings, which Wright designed for the house. They include built-in banquette couches and bookcases in the living room. The house has three bedrooms, a study, a kitchen and dining area, a living room with a fireplace and two-car attached garage with a carport. There are two bathrooms. The building materials consist primarily of painted concrete block and red tidewater cypress, and the price includes the original blueprints. Cloquet is about 20 miles west of Duluth. Agent: Dick Wenaas, Coldwell Banker East-West Realty, (800) 628-9212; www.cbeastwestrealty.com

HAMILTON--Gordon C. , of Bedford, New York, died May 21, 2008, aged 91. Beloved husband of Connie and devoted father of Kim Hamilton Gottshall and Jill Hamilton, and proud grandfather of Katherine Howland Gottshall and John Hamilton Gottshall. Born and bred a New Yorker. After graduation from Friends Seminary (1932) and Williams College (1936), he embarked on a 49-year career as a journalist, first in various editorial positions at The Literary Digest and the Daily Mirror, followed by national and international affairs at Newsweek. From there, it was an easy jump to public relations, first at Arabian American Oil Company and then Texaco, contributing his journalistic expertise to corporate publications and protecting the sanctity of the English language from the ''gobbledygook of corporatese.'' Retired in 1986 as Director of Public Relations Services. Inducted into the Army of the United States, in 1942, he initially served in the Signal Corps, where he edited the first manual ever published on something he had never heard of called ''radar.'' He transferred to Air Force Intelligence in 1944 and served in the Estimate Section, Joint Intelligence, Pacific Ocean Areas (stationed in Guam). He was commended for his service by Admiral C. W. Nimitz, who said: ''his estimates were used as the basis for operational planning by the highest commands in the Pacific Ocean Areas.'' Member of the Players Club from 1940 through 2008, he was elected a lifetime member in May 2008.

'THE ECCENTRICITIES OF A NIGHTINGALE' Every season a handful of performances set the city's theater watchers abuzz with excitement. This year has been unusually rich in quality work from actors on Broadway, from the fisticuffs of ''August: Osage County'' to the sweaty farcing of Mark Rylance and company in ''Boeing-Boeing'' to the filigreed performances in ''South Pacific.'' I'm sure they'll linger long in the memory. But the less traveled byways of the city's theater industry are home to performances no less powerful, no less indelible. Too often they pass unheralded; nobody can see everything, after all. I was reminded of this last weekend, when I scorned a rare sunny spring afternoon to catch the production of Tennessee Williams's rarely seen ''Eccentricities of a Nightingale'' at the Clurman Theater on Theater Row. (''Nightingale'' is a 1951 revision of ''Summer and Smoke,'' which Williams preferred to the original.) A colleague's enthusiastic review suggested that this production, from the small Actors Company Theater, was the rare staging of a Williams play that delivered his poetry and his emotional power intact.

SMITH--Alton . The board of trustees and the Ethical Culture Fieldston School community is deeply saddened by the death of Alton Smith '43, a physical education teacher at Fieldston, 1944-46, 1953-91. In addition to his teaching, Smith served as chairman of the physical education department and coached soccer, swimming, and track. Known as ''Smitty'' to generations of students, he was beloved for his irreverent manner, dedication to students, and seminal knowledge of jazz. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Cristie. Beth Beckmann Interim Head of School G. Angela Flemister Henry & Nina P. Freedman, co-chairs Board of Trustees

St. Paul is the host of this year's Republican convention, and the city will have just a fraction of the hotels rooms that New York City had for the 2004 convention. So many delegates and news people will be staying in the sister city of Minneapolis or in the suburbs, with just a few lucky delegations staying within walking distance of the convention. Who gets to stay in the city's choice historic hotel, the St. Paul, which is just a few blocks from the convention center? None other than the delegation from Arizona, home to Senator John McCain. It will be joined in the St. Paul, with its landmark clock tower, by the delegation from Nevada.

BRUSTIEN--Harold G . passed on May 22. He has gone to join his beloved wife Iris. The kindest, most generous, gentle and thoughtful man. His moral compass was true. Harold was a most honest friend. He was a defender of all those in need. Throughout his illness, he never lost his concern for others, insight and humor. He was the ideal father. His children Susie and Steve, their spouses, Peter and Mary and his cherished grandson Matthew flourished under his selfless guidance and devotion. He and his sister, Brew, had a most extraordinary sibling relationship. They were each other's best friend throughout their life's journey. He was a cousin, and uncle, that could always be counted on. Harold helped shape the lives of all those he came in contact with. No words can describe how much he will be missed. Services will be held Sunday, May 25 at 2pm at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Rd., Great Neck, New York. 516-487-0900

ROGER BROWN: 'THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE' The painter Roger Brown forged one of the most distinctive styles of the past half-century. He was one of the Chicago Imagists who came of age in the 1960s, among a group that included Jim Nutt, Ed Paschke and Gladys Nilsson. Brown died in 1997, and his work has not been seen in New York over the past 10 years. This exhibition of paintings from 1971 (including ''Pasadena Garden Residence,'' above) to 1991 will delight his fans and should be a revelation for people unfamiliar with his work. Mr. Brown created expansive, simplified and mysteriously luminous landscapes and townscapes in which natural and artificial elements conform to grid patterns. In some ways his paintings look as if they were made by a self-taught visionary. They're technically rudimentary and rely on certain formulaic devices. The land is always divided by rows of bristly, glowing bushes; buildings described by thin black lines have bright yellow windows framing occupants' shadows; and puffy clouds fill the sky in improbable patterns.

'ALICE IN WONDERLAND' Unless you're an Oxford don with a fondness for nonsense rhymes, onomatopoeia and ceaseless puns, any faithful adaptation of Lewis Carroll's ''Alice'' books is likely to be more fun to watch than to listen to. That is mostly true of the New Acting Company's ''Alice in Wonderland,'' playing through this weekend in Greenwich Village. Its script, by Brainerd Duffield, includes large excerpts from Carroll's original text, drawn from both ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' and its ''Through the Looking Glass'' sequel. But this production is so visually rich and energized that children unused to unadulterated Alice-isms aren't likely to mind that a lot of the dialogue is jabber -- or ''Jabberwocky,'' whose non-English English is recited several times. The stars, in addition to Zoë Frazer (who makes a spunky Alice, seated above with Maxine Dannatt, left, and Théo Klein) and the rest of the talented cast, are clearly Mark Salinas, the costume designer; Gregg Bellon, who created the set and the lighting; and Margeaux Lucas, who designed the art. Large, twirling panels, painted with scenes like chessboards and fairy-tale landscapes, form the backdrops, and ingenious inventions portray characters like the Walrus (an oversize hand puppet), the Mouse Alice meets in the Pool of Tears (an enormous rod puppet) and the Cheshire Cat (a mural-like design with a lingering fluorescent smile). The Caterpillar alone is worth the price of admission: partly a tower of fringed fabric, it has two children and an adult stacked within it, totem-pole-style, with their arms forming the creature's legs.

LEBWORTH--M. Joseph , died on May 17, 2008 at the age of 86. Joe's heroism and service to his country in World War II will long be remembered. He parachuted into Normandy the night before D-Day as a member of the 101st Airborne Division and received serious leg injuries after 17 days of combat. He was subsequently awarded the Bronze Star, the Purple Heart, the Infantry Combat Badge and France's Liberation Medal. Joe devoted the last several decades to the two great passions in his life: his family, and especially his devoted wife of 46 years, Caral; and not-for-profit endeavors, particularly the Museum of Modern Art film department and his alma mater, Yale University. His loss will leave a great void, and he will be missed by his many friends and family members. We will especially miss Joe's smiling face, his curiosity about every facet of life, his astute political insights and his unfailing courage. He is survived by his wife, Caral; his three stepchildren Glenn Greenberg, Stephen Greenberg and Alva Greenberg; and ten grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Museum of Modern Art Film Department, 11 West 53 Street, NY, NY 10019-5497. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday May 28th at 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue.

In 2005, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority considered, then backed away from, a proposal to ban photography on subways and buses (unless a permit was obtained). In 2007, the Bloomberg administration faced a firestorm from photographers and filmmakers over a plan to restrict video recording on streets and in other public spaces. Stephen C. Pinson, the curator of photography at the New York Public Library, sees the debates as examples of the fine line between public and private, a line that has always been an issue in photography.

'CHARLES BOYER AND THE ART OF SEDUCTION' Like all the best movie actors, Charles Boyer knew how to do a lot with a little: the just-raised eyebrow, the hint of a grin, the slight hesitation. Physically, his biggest gifts were his eyes and a deep, purring voice that sounded equally good whispering sweet nothings or delivering smart, fast lines. ''I've always been full of words,'' his character says in Mitchell Leisen's ''Hold Back the Dawn'' (1941). And it's all that persuasive, complicit, amused talk that makes Boyer a great romantic lead (and a great comic actor too). In Hollywood movies, Boyer was able to convey Gallic charm without being a cartoon Frenchman. (Though he inspired one: the skunk Pepe Le Pew.) He also had a career in France that, with gaps, stretched from 1920 to the 1960s. The Film Society of Lincoln Center series ''Charles Boyer and the Art of Seduction'' includes eight American and two French movies, one early and one late. In ''Le Bonheur,'' a rarity from 1934 as nutty as it is interesting, he plays an anarchist who shoots a film star as a political statement. (She survives and, lo and behold, falls for him.) In Max Ophuls's masterpiece ''The Earrings of Madame de ...'' (1953), Boyer gives a deftly complex performance that is completely in sync with the director's vision of a ''superficially superficial'' society.

Most of the big albums of the summer won't be out for weeks, but you can get a jump start on your seasonal reads. ''1001 Books You Must Read Before You Die,'' put together by a British professor, is a good place to start. Better yet is William Grimes's cheat sheet. ''As an experiment,'' he writes, ''I picked three novels, more or less at random, to see how they might change my quality of life: 'Castle Rackrent' by Maria Edgeworth; 'Tarka the Otter' by Henry Williamson; and 'The Invention of Curried Sausage' by Uwe Timm.'' He liked ''Castle Rackrent'' and ''The Invention of Curried Sausage,'' but came away with the feeling that, ''no matter how well read you are, you're not that well read.'' Only one way to fix that. ''Volumes to Go Before You Die,'' by William Grimes

JENKS--Dave . His early departure this Monday so unlike him. He made things happen, he improved many lives, our lives. He always carried through and never disappointed. He was a center of gravity and didn't have time to realize it. He and his adored David Helfrich, Davey, represented the best a couple can be and the loss to him is indescribable and to us, unimaginable and devastating. Our love and devotion to Davey for all he was to Dave and is to us is unlimited and eternal. Our condolences also are extended to the Jenks Family with whom he shared a lifetime of love and respect. To say we miss you Dave is hard, because it would mean we accept that you are gone and you never let us down before kiddo. Jonathan and Pierce

BROOKLYN BRIDGE 125TH BIRTHDAY CELEBRATION New York is a city whose survival is rooted in its ability to shift shape. Ports give way to waterfront parks, cobblestone to paved roads, and other markers of each age vanish, only to be replaced by new ones. Perhaps that is why the city so reveres those few monuments that endure. The Brooklyn Bridge is one of them. ''It's man-made scenery,'' said Ron Schweiger, the Brooklyn borough historian. ''This was all done without the aid of electrical power or gas power.''

For all the talk of signs of change in Cuba now that an ailing Fidel Castro is no longer head of state, it may be on the other side of the Florida Strait, in Miami, that political attitudes are shifting most visibly. Consider this: on Friday, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, a proponent of what he calls ''tough, direct presidential diplomacy'' with the United States' enemies, including Cuba, is scheduled to address the Cuban American National Foundation, the most influential of Miami's anti-Castro Cuban exile groups. A decade ago, it would have been difficult to imagine Mr. Obama, or any other liberal Democrat, being accepted in such a setting, or even thinking it was worthwhile to do so.

Once again, there was rap music playing from a stereo in the middle of the Yankees' clubhouse after Saturday's victory. Such entertainment was rare during the era of Joe Torre, but things have changed in the first year under Joe Girardi.

My Sunday column is about China's pollution problems. One of the challenges will be how well China -- and, behind it in a similar upward trajectory, India -- handles the environmental costs of industrial revolution. Quite aside from the 300,000 Chinese who die prematurely each year from the consequences of air pollution, there are many who suffer from water pollution and overuse of water in the north. Some years the Yellow River doesn't even reach the ocean in peak periods.

Friday might have been one of the worst days of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's political career. Her campaign, as everyone knows, was already struggling. But on Friday, she made a reference to Bobby Kennedy's assassination  a terrible choice of phrase in a presidential campaign that features an African-American candidate.

About 20 Chinese athletes bound for the Beijing Summer Games - including world champion diver Jia Tong - were training in Sichuan Province last week when a powerful earthquake hit southwestern China last week, killing more than 55,000 people.

The Marlins' rise to the top of the N.L. East coincides with Andrew Miller's trading walks for strikeouts. Miller, below, struck out 18 and walked 13 in compiling a 9.12 E.R.A. over his first six starts. In four starts since, he is 3-1 with a 1.44 E.R.A., striking out 26 and walking 7. The Mets, who ripped Miller for five runs in his first start, will face the new Miller this week.

SAN JUAN, P.R. - The beats of salsa and reggaeton were pulsing, the sun was shining and the waves of the Atlantic were rippling in the distance when Senator Barack Obama walked into La Plaza del Quinto to greet supporters one week before the Democratic presidential primary here.

No sooner did David Coulthard make it into the top 10 in today's qualifying than his car slid out from under him and he ran into the guard rail on the tunnel exit and had a massive, high-speed crash at the fastest sector of the Monaco track. His rear wheel ran off down the track, his front right wheel rattled about on its tether, and Coulthard's Red Bull came to a rest in the run-off area at the chicane. He got out of the car, looking terribly shaken, but unhurt.

Politics | What is "libertarian paternalism"? (And is it coming to an administration near you?) In a new book called "Nudge," two informal advisers to Barack Obama, Richard Thaler and Cass Sunstein, argue that people need a government that can help them make better decisions. Otherwise, they save less than they intend to for retirement or use more energy than they need. Or other bad things. But the authors aren't saying people are necessarily stupid. New York Review of Books
Location: Fort Collins, Colo.

Like your average dreamy and morbid literary type, I love a good stroll through a cemetery (provided there's no actual funeral involved, of course). So I was interested to pick up Marilyn Yalom's new book "The American Resting Place: Four Hundred Years of History Through Our Cemeteries and Burials," recently published by Houghton Mifflin. It's perfect reading for Memorial Day, and not as somber as you might imagine.

Re "Information That Doesn't Come Freely" (May 11):You write that "bad things can happen when a government tries to hide the records of its actions." America is in trouble! The only insights into the administration's wrongdoings are the investigative and analytical reporting of the media.Thank you to the reporters Nina Bernstein and David Barstow, to David McCraw, a vice president and assistant general counsel for The Times, and to you. But nothing substantial in the speeches had not been reported before, and nothing in them was not being reported endlessly on cable news. Comcast Corporation is trying to sell 46 cable systems in eight states serving 400,000 to 500,000 subscribers as it seeks to improve efficiency by selling outlying operations.

The Talking Business column last Saturday, about a sharp debate over the advantages and faults of investment instruments called fundamentally weighted index funds, misstated the name of the organization that publishes The Financial Analysts Journal, which prompted the feud by publishing an article on the funds. It is the CFA Institute, not the Chartered Financial Analysts Institute.

An article last Saturday about steps taken by Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign to avoid potential conflicts of interest among his advisers misspelled the surname of a business partner of Craig Shirley, a public relations consultant whose ties to the campaign were severed. She is Diana Banister, not Bannister.

An article last Saturday about a report on lapses at a Las Vegas endoscopy clinic linked to cases of hepatitis C misidentified the jobs of some of the health care workers who, according to the report, did not wear gloves when they administered intravenous medications. They were nurse anesthetists, not anesthesiologists.
The Indians are baseball’s worst hitting team, stuck in a deep, unforgiving slump that has wasted excellent starting pitching and solid defense.
An obituary and a headline on Friday about the architect and preservationist Jan Hird Pokorny misstated his age. As the obituary noted, he was born on May 25, 1914, and therefore was 93, not 83.

The Crown Heights Journal article on Thursday, about racial tension between Jews and blacks in the Brooklyn neighborhood, omitted the name of the publication that first reported a comment by District Attorney Charles J. Hynes on accusations that Shmira, a Hasidic civilian patrol group, has been uncooperative with investigators. His comment, “You can’t have a group, whether it’s the Bloods, Crips or Shmira, acting like vigilantes,” was made to The Jewish Week of New York on April 29.

Nascar officials said there was not enough time to grant Kentucky Speedway a Sprint Cup race in 2009. Bruton Smith, owner of Speedway Motorsports Inc., announced Thursday that he had purchased the Kentucky track with the intention of having a Cup race there next year.

Dina Ammaccapane shot her second 69 in a row for a one-stroke lead after the second round of the L.P.G.A. Corning Classic in Corning, N.Y. Ammaccapane was at six-under 138. The first-round leader, Erica Blasberg (74); Janice Moodie (68); Wendy Ward (70); and Katie Futcher (69) were one back.

Phil Mickelson had 11 one-putts and converted all six sand saves in a two-under-par 68 in the second round of the Crowne Plaza Invitational in Fort Worth, taking the lead at seven-under 133. Mickelson led Matt Kuchar (64), Brian Gay (65) and Johnson Wagner (71) by one stroke.

Closing with a 25-foot putt for birdie, Tom Purtzer took the lead after the second round of the Senior P.G.A. Championship on Friday in Rochester, N.Y. Purtzer, a five-time PGA Tour winner, shot a three-under-par 67 to go to even-par 140. That put him one up on Jay Haas, the first-round leader, who shot a two-over 72, and Massy Kuramoto, who finished at two under.

These have been good days for art lovers. In Colorado the Aspen Art Museum, home to contemporary art exhibitions, film and video series, has announced that starting on Thursday its admission will be free for the next 10 years, thanks to an undisclosed contribution by John and Amy Phelan. (The admission was previously $5 and under.) The Phelans are members of the museum’s council and part-time residents of Aspen. In New York, El Museo del Barrio, which showcases the art and cultured of Latin America, Puerto Rico and the rest of the Caribbean region, has received a $3 million gift from Carmen Ana Unanue, its chairwoman, and her family. The museum, at 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, East Harlem, is closed for a major renovation and is expected to re-open in September 2009.

The $16.8 million sale of a landmark Modernist house by Richard Neutra has been derailed, Christie’s said on Friday. An unidentified bidder bought the 1946 residence, the Kauffmann House in Palm Springs, Calif., above, at Christie’s auction of postwar and contemporary art in New York on May 13. But Marc Porter, president of Christie’s, said in a brief telephone interview on Friday that the deal had fallen apart. “The contract has been terminated by the seller by reason of a breach of its terms by the buyer,” he said. He declined to identify the buyer or to say whether that person had failed to deliver a payment. The sellers, Brent Harris and Beth Edwards Harris, who have divorced, could not immediately be reached for comment. The midcentury landmark of glass, steel and stone sold at the low end of its estimate of $15 million to $25 million at the auction. It was commissioned by the department store owner Edgar J. Kaufmann Sr., the same client who commissioned Frank Lloyd Wright to build Fallingwater in Pennsylvania in the 1930s.

Paul Newman has stepped down as the director of “Of Mice and Men” at the Westport Country Playhouse for health reasons. The production, scheduled for Oct. 7 through Nov. 1 at the Connecticut theater run by Mr. Newman’s wife, Joanne Woodward, was to be his directorial debut. Mark Lamos, who won a Tony Award for work with the Hartford Stage company, will fill in.

Wesley Snipes can spend his Memorial Day weekend a free man. Last month in Ocala, Fla., he was sentenced to three years in prison for willfully failing to file his tax returns, one year for each misdemeanor conviction. He plans to appeal the conviction, handed down in February, and on Thursday Judge William Terrell Hodges granted his motion for bail, saying Mr. Snipes did not pose a flight risk, according to The Associated Press. At his sentencing, Mr. Snipes read a statement apologizing for some unspecified mistakes and failures; he did not mention taxes.

he Leon Levy Foundation, run by Shelby White, a philanthropist, and named for her husband, a hedge fund pioneer who died in 2003, is giving $25 million to New York City parks in what the city has described as the biggest private “green” gift. The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, below with Henry Moore’s “Large Two Forms,” will get $15 million to create a new native plant garden to study and showcase Northeast flora. In Brooklyn Prospect Park will receive $10 million to finance the Lakeside Center, a new 36,000-square-foot building that will replace Wollman Rink and its surroundings. The 26-acre area will be restored to the original design of Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, with a natural-habitat sanctuary and pedestrian pathways along the lake, and will be open year round.

What can a popular ex-president do as a second act? Collaborate with his wife, of course — or try to. And in the former Czech leader Vaclav Havel’s case, return to his roots on the stage. Mr. Havel’s first new play in 20 years opened in the Archa Theater in Prague on Thursday. The play, “Odchazeni” (“Leaving”), is about a chancellor who must re-adjust to civilian life and the loss of power after being forced out by his former deputy. (Mr. Havel, now 71, whose last presidential term ended in 2003, has said he wrote most of the play before taking office.) It alludes to “King Lear” and “The Cherry Orchard” but has some postmodern touches: the playwright himself appears in a recorded voice-over. The play received mostly positive reviews in the Czech press. But this highly anticipated absurdist comedy was marred by some personal drama when Mr. Havel’s wife, Dagmar Havlova, who he said helped inspire the work, was barred from performing in it. The National Theater of Prague, which was originally scheduled to stage it, cited a policy against guest actors in rejecting Ms. Havlova for a role written for her. Mr. Havel responded by shopping the show to other theaters; citing health problems, Ms. Havlova eventually dropped out of the production altogether shortly before it opened at the Archa. In September the play is scheduled to run at the Orange Tree Theater in London.

The trial of the R& B star R. Kelly, who is charged with 14 counts of child pornography stemming from a video in which, prosecutors say, he has sex with an under-age girl, wrapped up its first week on Friday in Chicago. In testimony this week Stephanie Edwards, a singer, identified the girl in the tape as her niece and said the girl was 13 or 14 when it was made. Mr. Kelly’s defense team filed a motion to call to the stand Jim DeRogatis, the pop music critic for The Chicago Sun-Times, who anonymously received the tape in 2002. Judge Vincent Gaughan said lawyers for The Sun-Times had until next Friday to respond. The trial is to resume on Tuesday. Mr. Kelly has pleaded not guilty, and the woman, now 23, said to be the girl on the tape, has denied that she is.

The two-hour season finale of “Grey’s Anatomy” vaulted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday, attracting 17.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although the number of viewers for the show’s fourth-season conclusion declined by nearly 5 million from a year ago (22.6 million), it still led the night by a wide margin over its nearest competitor, NBC’s “Deal or No Deal,” which garnered 10.3 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. NBC finished third for the night, earning mediocre results from 9:30 to 11 with the start of the sixth edition of “Last Comic Standing” (5.9 million). Fox ranked second over all, thanks to the fourth-season premiere of “So You Think You Can Dance,” which averaged 8.6 million viewers from 8 to 10. Despite its modest number of total viewers, the Fox dancing contest fared particularly well among adults 18 to 49, winning the 8 o’clock hour in that demographic, ahead of ABC’s finale of “Ugly Betty,” which drew 8.8 million total viewers. CBS finished fourth with a lineup of all repeats.

COOPER--George W., of New York and Stamford, CT, passed away Thursday morning at age 80. He graduated from Columbia College in 1947 and from Columbia Law School in 1950. In 1960, he joined Avon Products Inc. as its first international attorney and was Corporate Vice President of Avon until his retirement in 1979. Thereafter, he was in private practice, specializing in trademark and unfair competition law. George is survived by his wife, Isolde, his sons Daniel and Richard, and his daughter, Julia Cooper Parzen.

KOHEN - KLIEMAN--Clara, died May 21 surrounded by family. Beloved wife of Marshall, mother of Adrian and Gabriela, mother-in-law of Ariela and Geoff, Bobe to Jacob, Julian, Maia and Benjamin, sister of David, aunt of Gabriel and Ariel, step-mother of Lisa, Mindy, Mitchell, Beth and Kenny and stepgrandmother of their children. She was a teacher and a healer. Services Sunday, 1pm at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam.

SHATZKIN--Doris (Granoff), age 86, died May 21st. Beloved wife of Dr. E. H. (Herb) Shatzkin, her husband of 64 years, mother of Roger and Steve, mother-in-law of Wendy Kaczerski and Deborah Uhler Shatzkin, sister-in-law of Julius Spencer and aunt of Karen Brunschwig and Lynn Spencer. She was cherished by granddaughters Amy, Natasha and Lilianna, as well as by her sister Harriet Spencer and granddaughter Sarah, who both preceded her in death. Fiercely curious, she adored reading, good food, charitable and political causes, and speaking her mind. Her love for language inspired many, including hundreds of adults who left her classes wiser in the ways of English and their adopted country. Family and friends will greatly miss her. A memorial will be held May 25 at 3pm, at Guttermans Funeral Chapel, 175 N. Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

LEBWORTH--M. Joseph, died on May 17, 2008 at the age of 86. Joe's heroism and service to his country in World War II will long be remembered. He parachuted into Normandy the night before D-Day as a member of the 101st Airborne Division and received serious leg injuries after 17 days of combat. He was subsequently awarded the Bronze Star, the Purple Heart, the Infantry Combat Badge and France's Liberation Medal. Joe devoted the last several decades to the two great passions in his life: his family, and especially his devoted wife of 46 years, Caral; and not-for-profit endeavors, particularly the Museum of Modern Art film department and his alma mater, Yale University. His loss will leave a great void, and he will be missed by his many friends and family members. We will especially miss Joe's smiling face, his curiosity about every facet of life, his astute political insights and his unfailing courage. He is survived by his wife, Caral; his three stepchildren Glenn Greenberg, Stephen Greenberg and Alva Greenberg; and ten grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Museum of Modern Art Film Department, 11 West 53 Street, NY, NY 10019-5497. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday May 28th at 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue.

LAVEY--Stewart E., 62, loving husband of Suzanne (Laurence) Lavey, died suddenly on Thursday, May 22, 2008. Mr. Lavey lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan with his wife, who had a 34-year career as a dancer with the Metropolitan Opera Ballet. He was an enthusiastic supporter of the Met and various other educational and charitable organizations. Mr. Lavey was an attorney at Drinker Biddle & Reath LLP, where he was a managing partner and a leader of the corporate and securities practice in the Florham Park, NJ, office. Mr. Lavey practiced law for 38 years, joining Shanley & Fisher as of counsel in 1985 and becoming a partner in July 1987. When Shanley combined with Drinker Biddle in 1999, he was instrumental in helping lead their integration. Mr. Lavey was a 1970 graduate and adjunct faculty member of Fordham University School of Law. He was a proud graduate and active alumnus of The Pingry School (Class of 1963), and was a respected member of the Schwab House Board of Directors. Mr. Lavey was an avid boater and enjoyed spending many of his summers off the Atlantic coast. Services are Sunday, May 25, at The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. in New York. Interment follows at the Cedar Park Cemetery/Beth El Cemetery in Paramus, N.J. Donations, in lieu of flowers, can be made to The Seeing Eye, Inc., P.O. Box 375, Morristown, NJ 07963; Golfers Against Cancer, 1700 Lake Kingwood Trail, Kingwood, TX 77339; Morris Animal Foundation, 10200 E. Girard Ave., B430, Denver, CO 80231, or the American Heart Association. He will be missed by all of the people he knew and institutions he supported.
BIRNBAUM--Eugene A., 81. Services at ''The Riverside'', W. 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Sunday June 1st at 2pm.

CAPA--Cornell. The entire International Center of Photography community mourns the death of the man whose vision continues to guide us today. As a renowned photographer and humanitarian, as the founder of the International Fund for Concerned Photography, and the founder of ICP in 1974, Cornell was a singular force in the world of photography, opening our eyes to the power of the photographic image as an agent of change. At ICP he ventured far beyond photojournalism and brought the full range of photography to the public's attention through an institution that was born, wholecloth, as a true center--both Museum and School. There Cornell was available to the many photographers from around the world who came to him for advice and encouragement. ICP and photographers everywhere are his lasting legacy. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held on September 10th at 10am at The Times Center, 242 West 41st Street in Manhattan. Contributions in Cornell's memory may be made to the Cornell Capa Legacy Project at ICP. Gayle Greenhill Chairman, Board of Trustees Jeffrey A. Rosen President, Board of Trustees Willis E.Hartshorn Ehrenkranz Director International Center of Photography

GAL--Andreas (Bandi), 91, passed away peacefully on May 22 in New York City. He is survived by his daughter Julie Gal, grandchildren Mati and Talia Kalter, son-in-law Henry Kalter, and an extended family and many friends to all of whom he was very devoted. Bandi was predeceased by Susanne Fried Gal, his wife of 58 years and by his son Peter who died at age five and a half. Born in Hungary, he was interned in a labor camp during the war, later escaping and working with the underground in Budapest; his parents and extended family were murdered in Auschwitz. Trained as a lawyer, Bandi served in the early postwar Hungarian government before emigrating in the late 1940s and, with Susanne, establishing textile and related businesses in Europe and the US. In addition to their many successful business ventures, Bandi and Susanne cherished their ability to help others in need, especially in Israel where he was a regular visitor. Funeral service at Kiryat Shaul, Tel Aviv, 2pm May 25.

Dear brother of Nancy Shea, Marge McCarthy and Clare Shea (deceased). Friend to all. Reposing Macken Mortuary, Rockville Centre Chapel, 52 Clinton Avenue, Sunday May 25, 2-4, 7-9pm. Funeral Mass St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre Monday, May 26, 11am. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Nassau Meals-onWheels c/o Catholic Charities, 201 Debevoise Avenue, Roosevelt, NY, 11575. mackenmortuary.com
