It was Davydenko’s 13th ATP Tour title and second of the season; he won the Masters Series event in Miami last month.
Mikael Samuelsson broke out of a slump with two unassisted goals and Chris Osgood made 19 saves to help Detroit stifle the Pittsburgh Penguins in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup Finals.
Jered Weaver pitched three-hit ball over eight innings and Vladimir Guerrero hit a go-ahead home run in the sixth to lead the visiting Los Angeles Angels over the Chicago White Sox, 2-0, on Saturday.
In his annual news conference before the Stanley Cup finals, Commissioner Gary Bettman said that the size of goaltenders’ equipment would be reviewed in the off-season.

Kyle Busch drove to victory at Lowe’s Motor Speedway in Concord, N.C., in a Nationwide Series race. It was Busch’s fourth Nationwide victory this season and eighth over all spanning Nascar’s top three series.

Jeff Francoeur hit a game-ending, two-run homer against Chad Qualls in the ninth inning, and the Atlanta Braves overcame a 10-strikeout performance by Randy Johnson to beat the visiting Arizona Diamondbacks, 3-1.
Jean-Pierre Bemba, who was once a rebel leader and, later, the vice president of Congo, was arrested at the request of the International Criminal Court, a prosecutor said.
A 16-year-old was beaten up in a fight that broke out among prisoners while he was in a holding cell awaiting arraignment in Brooklyn Criminal Court.
A tourist helicopter crashed in rainy weather on an island off the coast of Southern California on Saturday morning, killing three people and injuring three others.
Waterloo, N.Y., has expanded its Memorial Day celebration. Festive celebration now coexists with somber tradition.
Five people were wounded, one of them seriously when a gunman opened fire on a street in Jackson Heights, Queens in what police say may be a gang-related shooting.
Agnieszka Radwanska beat top-seeded Elena Dementieva of Russia, 6-3, 6-2, to win the Istanbul Cup and become the first Polish woman to surpass $1 million in career earnings on the WTA Tour.

N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman said each team would play every other team at least once next season. The announcement came Saturday before Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals between Pittsburgh and Detroit, which did not meet during the regular season because of an unbalanced schedule. Bettman also said in his annual news conference before the finals that the size of goaltenders’ equipment would be analyzed during the off-season.

Liu Xiang won the men’s 110-meter hurdles before 45,000 fans in Beijing’s new National Stadium in an Olympic test event. Liu, the defending Olympic and world champion, won in 13.18 seconds. The four-day China Open is the first full-scale test for the new site before the Olympics.

Ricky Hatton prevailed in a lopsided decision over Juan Lazcano to retain his International Boxing Organization light-welterweight title before a raucous home crowd in Manchester, England. Hatton won easily on all three judges scorecards. It was his first fight since he lost a World Boxing Council welterweight bid against Floyd Mayweather Jr. in December, his first loss in 44 career fights.

Haile Gebrselassie ran his fastest 10,000 meters in four years at the FBK Games in Hengelo, Netherlands, as he pushed his case to be included on the Ethiopian Olympic team. Gebrselassie finished second in 26 minutes 51.20 seconds, only 0.67 behind his compatriot Sileshi Sihine. Gebrselassie, who runs mostly marathons, said he would not run the marathon at the Beijing Olympics because the smog and heat might bother his asthma.
With General Manager Omar Minaya watching on Saturday, the Mets granted Manager Willie Randolph a temporary reprieve by beating the Colorado Rockies at Coors Field.
Jeff Francoeur hit a game-ending, two-run homer against Chad Qualls in the ninth inning, and the Atlanta Braves overcame a 10-strikeout performance by Randy Johnson.
After 12 years of racing everything from quarter midgets to late model stock cars, Joey Logano has finally reached the beginning of his career.
Felipe Massa of Brazil will start the Monaco Grand Prix from the pole position after leading a 1-2 finish for Ferrari in qualifying Saturday.
Phil Mickelson overcame an early bogey and some missed chances with seven birdies in his last 13 holes for a five-under 65 that put him at 12-under 198.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s comments invoking the death of Senator Robert F. Kennedy have raised fresh questions about her motivations, overshadowing her campaign.
Jason Giambi hit a three-run homer in the second inning, and Bobby Abreu added a two-run shot in the sixth as the Yankees extended their winning streak to a season-high four games.
A group led by Mortimer B. Zuckerman is buying the Fifth Avenue building and three other Midtown towers from the Macklowe family for $3.95 billion.
Customers returned on Saturday to Eden Dry Cleaners and Tailoring, whose shopkeeper was found dead on May 16, the victim of an apparent robbery.

Harry Carson, the Giants Hall of Fame linebacker, inducted Vince Lombardi into the New Jersey Hall of Fame recently, and according to Carson, the Super Bowl champions had better be prepared for every game.

Gilles Simon defeated fifth-seeded Julien Benneteau, 7-5, 6-2, in an all-French clay-court final in Casablanca, Morocco, for his third career title. The 23-year-old Simon’s other titles came last year in Marseille, France, and Bucharest, Romania.
Emanuele Sella won the 14th stage of the Giro d’Italia after breaking away on a steep climb 34 miles from the finish, and Gabriele Bosisio took the overall lead.
Accounts of a shooting on West 90th Street suggested that an informal turf war between youths from the East and West Sides of Manhattan had turned deadly early Saturday morning.
Syracuse topped Virginia, 12-11, in double overtime, with a Mike Leveille goal with 1 minute 43 seconds remaining capping a 6-1 Syracuse run to end the game.
A former Marine Corps captain is using Fleet Week as a way to broach the subject of post-traumatic stress disorder in a more leisurely setting.
Northwestern has won the last three N.C.A.A. titles. The Wildcats (20-1) are seeded No. 1 here (Penn is No. 2). Northwestern’s offense is frenetic, its defense relentless in double teaming.
Dwyane Wade was on top of the basketball world two years ago, carrying the Miami Heat to the 2006 N.B.A. title. But his last two seasons have been marred by shoulder and knee injuries.
The boy’s mother said the auction listing had been a joke, but the baby has been put in state custody while the police is investigating.
The Australian Open runner-up Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France withdrew from the French Open on Saturday because of an injured right knee. He is expected to have surgery next week.

Miller, below, struck out 18 and walked 13 in compiling a 9.12 E.R.A. over his first six starts. In four starts since, he is 3-1 with a 1.44 E.R.A., striking out 26 and walking 7. The Mets, who ripped Miller for five runs in his first start, will face the new Miller this week.

The Green Traveler column on May 4, about the use of biofuels in air travel, summarized incorrectly a statement by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change on the effect of jet exhaust. The panel said exhaust contributed to global warming by emitting carbon dioxide and nitrogen oxides at high altitude and by forming condensation trails; it did not say jet engine exhaust depletes the ozone layer.

To the Editor: We were pleased to see The New York Times take note of the Festival au Desert in Mali (“In Mali, S.U.V.’s and Camels Deliver the Fans,” May 11). Unfortunately, the article flattened the richness and complexity of the festival, which combines entertainment with the functions of a county fair, town-hall meeting and community clinic. We heard great music, but also saw workshops on AIDS prevention, witnessed Doctors Without Borders at work and heard a discussion of “the duties of a good citizen” presented in French and Tamashek.

To the Editor: What fun to read “Rockin’ the Casbah” (May 11) after having spent 10 days in Morocco last summer. I was surprised to read your endorsement of Villa Maroc as a place to stay in Essaouira. We and another couple stayed there only one night. We carried our bags up three flights of circuitous stairs to our rooms — small and musty with only one window that opened onto an alleyway, and noisy well into the night. The area around this riad is charming and quaint, but we should have stayed at the modern Sofitel overlooking the beautiful beach instead. Our memories would have been fonder.Pam Sloane.

LEBWORTH--M. Joseph , died on May 17, 2008 at the age of 86. Joe's heroism and service to his country in World War II will long be remembered. He parachuted into Normandy the night before D-Day as a member of the 101st Airborne Division and received serious leg injuries after 17 days of combat. He was subsequently awarded the Bronze Star, the Purple Heart, the Infantry Combat Badge and France's Liberation Medal. Joe devoted the last several decades to the two great passions in his life: his family, and especially his devoted wife of 46 years, Caral; and not-for-profit endeavors, particularly the Museum of Modern Art film department and his alma mater, Yale University. His loss will leave a great void, and he will be missed by his many friends and family members. We will especially miss Joe's smiling face, his curiosity about every facet of life, his astute political insights and his unfailing courage. He is survived by his wife, Caral; his three stepchildren Glenn Greenberg, Stephen Greenberg and Alva Greenberg; and ten grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Museum of Modern Art Film Department, 11 West 53 Street, NY, NY 10019-5497. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday May 28th at 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue.

PETER C. SUTTON looked a little weary as he presided over a senior staff meeting at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn. Dr. Sutton had just returned the night before from a business trip to Japan, where he had given a lecture on Vermeer and the Delft School, his specialty, and discussed loans of artworks for future shows at the Bruce. Now he was listening as Nancy Hall-Duncan, senior curator of art, reported on plans for a 2009 show devoted to the French Impressionist painter Alfred Sisley. Ms. Hall-Duncan's summary, which included details of loan requests and a complementary costume exhibition, was as close as Mr. Sutton would get to working with art that day. Earlier that morning he had met with a board member, then attended a governance committee meeting. Immediately after the staff briefing came another meeting, one with visiting members of the Connecticut Commission on Culture and Tourism. By 6 p.m. he had left the museum, heading to what he called a ''donor cultivation event'' at the home of a local collector.

THE United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled last week that the Treasury Department's paper currency discriminates against the blind and those with poor vision because the bills are the same size no matter their value. In addition, the department didn't show that it would be too burdensome to change the bills. So what's to be done? It's not clear yet. Charles Miller, a spokesman for the Department of Justice, said, ''We're reviewing the court's ruling at this juncture, and no determination has been made as to the government's next step.'' Since that step won't be taken immediately, the Week in Review asked three graphic designers to offer their solutions. Scott Stowell of Open, a New York design firm, took his cue from countries where bills of different denominations vary in size. Woody Pirtle of Pirtle Design, also in New York, borrowing from greeting-card technology, has attached a paper-thin chip that speaks the denomination. Tamara Shopsin, an illustrator, proposes perforations in the shape of icons, each symbolic of the president depicted. STEVEN HELLER

OVERLOOKING WENTWORTH FALLS, BLUE MOUNTAINS NATIONAL PARK, Feb. 23, 2008 Jolanta Kalnina, 25, from Riga, Latvia. ''I work for Air Baltic, and it's very commonplace for my colleagues to go for vacation to Bangkok, which I consider too crowded. My boyfriend and I decided instead to stay closer to nature. The main difference between Australia and other places I have traveled is the natural harmony -- wild nature and people living together. The nature in Australia is its history and culture at the same time. The most unforgettable thing was the Blue Mountains National Park. We got a bit lost that day and found this lookout point almost by accident, following our intuition. I still remember the lovely excitement we had at the end of this sandy road, where we discovered a point that hadn't been used in a long time, looking over Wentworth Falls and all the might of nature. It was our first stop on our five-day trip through the park, and the sun created a lovely rainbow over the falls. It was an amazing play of colors in the water. I could never get tired of traveling in Australia, I think.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

IN an era when much of the 20th century's lexicon of geopolitical stock phrases -- Iron Curtain, ''collaborator,'' ''enemy within'' -- has lost the power to stir passions, the last 10 days have proven once again that cries of ''appeasement'' still resonate. ''Some seem to believe we should negotiate with terrorists and radicals,'' President Bush said before the Israeli Parliament. ''We have an obligation to call this what it is -- the false comfort of appeasement.''

O'BRIEN--Fr. Frederick J., S.J. , died on Monday, May 19, 2008, at Hollywood Presbyterian Hospital in Hollywood, California. He was 76 years of age. He had been a member of the Society of Jesus for 58 years and a priest for 46 years. Father O'Brien was born in Hyde Park, MA on October 31, 1931, and was baptized at Most Precious Blood Church in the Archdiocese of Boston. He attended Boston College High School from 1945 to 1949 and entered the Society of Jesus on July 30, 1949 at Shadowbrook in Lenox, MA, where he also did his first studies as a Jesuit. He received his theological training in preparation for priesthood at Woodstock College in Woodstock, MD, and was ordained a priest there on June 17, 1962. Father O'Brien held a Master's Degree in History from the Catholic University of America in Washington, DC, but achieving that degree did not put an end to his continuous study of history and his keen sense for historical detail which frequently informed his conversation. He taught history at Boston College from 1968 to 1971 and at Fairfield University from 1971 to 1976. In 1976 Father O'Brien's career took him from Jesuit universities into Jesuit high schools. Although he was always a Bostonian at heart, it was at this time that Father O'Brien moved to New York City. There he began to teach history at Regis High School in Manhattan, but almost immediately he moved into high school administrative positions at Regis High School and then at Fordham Preparatory in the Bronx. He returned to New England to be Principal and later to be both Principal and President at Bishop Connolly High School in Fall River, only to return again to the Big Apple to assume the office of Principal at Regis High School from 1983 to 1989. Father O'Brien became Assistant to the New York Provincial for Secondary Education from 1990 to 2001. Having finished his career in secondary education, Father O'Brien indulged his interest in history by becoming the New York Province Archivist. Fluent in English, Spanish and German, Father O'Brien helped manage many of the international correspondences from the Provincial's office. In addition, Father O'Brien wrote the obituaries of deceased Jesuits for various publications. Father O'Brien fulfilled these duties until he died. Besides having been a scholar, an administrator and a historian, Father O'Brien was a devoted priest. He spent several weeks each year on the west coast providing pastoral care in the Archdiocese of Los Angeles, especially at Blessed Sacrament Church in Hollywood, CA. It was during his last visit to the west coast that Father O'Brien fell ill, received hospitalization, and died. Father O'Brien is survived by his cousins Richard O'Brien of Humarock, MA, Patricia O'Brien of West Roxbury, MA, and Robert O'Brien of Washington Depot, CT. Friends may call Monday May 26th, 2-4 and 7-9pm and Tuesday May 27th, 2-4pm at Regis High School Chapel, 55 East 84th Street, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday May 27th at 7:30pm at St. Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street.

An essay on May 11 about the American intellectual scene in 1958 referred incorrectly to Jack Kerouac's ''Dharma Bums,'' published that year. It was his fourth novel, not the second. It followed ''The Town and the City'' (1950), ''On the Road'' (1957) and ''The Subterraneans'' (also 1958)

HAMILTON--Dr. Harlan (Hal) Bernhardt , of New York City, formally of Massachusetts died peacefully, surrounded by family in Manchester, NH on March 23, 2008. Hal was born in Medford MA, on November 29, 1927; the firstborn of Harlan Lombard Hamilton and Jeanie (Bernhardt) Hamilton. The Hamilton family first settled in Berwick, Maine in 1751, Hal was quite proud of his Maine heritage. After graduating from Boston Latin School in 1946, he enlisted in the US Navy where he served in Shanghai during World War II. After serving his country as a Navy medic, Hal enrolled in the University of Colorado, graduating with a degree in English. He continued his education earning a Masters Degree from Columbia University and a Doctor of Education degree from Boston University. Hal shared his passion for literature and the arts as an Associate Professor of English at Jersey City State College in New Jersey. Hal wrote published articles and plays, culminating his writing with the publication of his book ''Lights and Legends''. The book is a Historical Guide to Lighthouses of Long Island Sound, Fishers Island Sound, and Block Island Sound. He was an avid sailor, both in Long Island Sound and in the Caribbean. Writing his book combined Hal's passion for sailing and literature. The book was published in 1987, and has had multiple printings making it available today through many booksellers. A member of the Screen Actor's Guild, Opera, Film, Off Broadway Theater, and Television were all stages Hal appeared on. Hal was a resident of New York City for over 40 years. ''There's no place like it,'' Hal would often exclaim. Hal was a volunteer at the Metropolitan Museum of Modern Art, and has donated his stamp collection on Film to the Museum. He was a Senior Mentor for Mt. Sinai Hospital, working with future physicians. Hal is survived by two sisters Beverly Royce of Phoenix, AZ and Nancy Wiley of Halifax, MA and his brother James Hamilton of Billerica, MA. He was predeceased by a brother Norman. He enjoyed time with his many nieces and nephews, sharing stories of family history, New York, and his many travels around the world. Hal was a founding member of several AA chapters in Manhattan. A Memorial Service will be held for Harlan Hamilton at St. Anthony of Padua Church, Sullivan and Houston St. in New York City on Saturday, May 31 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Hal's memory to the NYC Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Ave, NY, NY 10017.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended May 10, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

THE NEWS Senate Democrats vented their fury at oil executives over high gasoline prices and warned of a new tax on so-called windfall profits. BEHIND THE NEWS Such showdowns have become routine but took on a new urgency as lawmakers prepared for a Memorial Day recess where they expected to hear from angry voters. Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee suggested corporate greed was a factor pushing up oil prices. But the executives suggested Democrats were at fault for not allowing more drilling for domestic oil. ''As repetitive and uninteresting as it may sound,'' said one executive, ''the fundamental laws of supply and demand are at work.''

She worked at Fort Monmouth Army Base during World War II. She married Robert L. Gault in 1946. She is survived by her six loving children and their families: Netta Gault LaValle, John A. Gault and his wife Joyce, Mary E. Gault and her daughter Chandler Lass, James D. Gault, William R. Gault, his wife Dana and their two children Anna and Andrew Gault, and Robert A. Gault. She is also survived by her sister Jean Newkirk. Her warmth, sympathetic nature, sense of humor and the best pies in America will be missed and long remembered. Condolences may be sent to sixgaultkids@gmail.com.

TEXT BY T. COLE RACHEL It's a classic story, but with a French twist. In 2004, a group of high-school friends with little or no musical experience decide to start a band. Their playing lacks finesse but has plenty of enthusiasm. Punchy, two-minute songs become their calling card. Fame ensues. Meet the Plastiscines: Marine Neuilly, Katty Besnard and Louise Basilien. The Paris-based band's 2007 major label debut, ''LP1,'' may be only 28 minutes long, but it packs a punch -- all power chords,tambourines and odes to the endless party. Think '60s garage rock by way of the Ramones and Françoise Hardy. From left: Marine Neuilly is in a Thread Social dress and Jill Stuart top. Katty Besnard wears a Chanel dress. Louise Basilien wears a Brian Reyes dress and Yves Saint Laurent top. Au Revoir Simone's Erika Forster, Annie Hart and Heather D'Angelo are known for folky keyboard lullabies suited for night drives and long, solitary walks. On their latest album, ''The Bird of Music,'' the Brooklyn-based trio conjure the ghosts of AM radio past. But for an act that relies almost exclusively on vintage synthesizers and drum machines (all three members play keyboards and sing), the sound is remarkably organic and decidedly old-fashioned. Twee musical musings about embracing the sunshine and measuring the nighttime stars that could easily become too precious for words are tempered with a note of melancholy. From left: Erika Forster wears an Alexander Wang romper. Larkspur & Hawk necklace. Annie Hart is in a Roberto Cavalli blouse. Jill Stuart skirt. Lulu Frost and Alexis Bittar necklaces. Belmacz ring. Heather D'Angelo wears a Brian Reyes camisole and headband. Dior by John Galliano slip. Max Azria shorts. David Yurman ring. Lulu Frost bracelet. It's almost redundant to talk about the weird and wonderful musical gifts that Iceland has given us: Bjork, Mum, Gus Gus. . . . Add to that list Amiina. Edda Run Olafsdottir, Hildur Arsaelsdottir, Solrun Sumarlidadottir and Maria Huld Markan Sigfusdottir initially got together in 2004 as a string quartet but soon packed up every instrument they could find and retreated to an isolated mountaintop studio. GAL--Andreas (Bandi) , 91, passed away peacefully on May 22 in New York City. He is survived by his daughter Julie Gal, grandchildren Mati and Talia Kalter, son-in-law Henry Kalter, and an extended family and many friends to all of whom he was very devoted. Bandi was predeceased by Susanne Fried Gal, his wife of 58 years and by his son Peter who died at age five and a half. Born in Hungary, he was interned in a labor camp during the war, later escaping and working with the underground in Budapest; his parents and extended family were murdered in Auschwitz. Trained as a lawyer, Bandi served in the early postwar Hungarian government before emigrating in the late 1940s and, with Susanne, establishing textile and related businesses in Europe and the US. In addition to their many successful business ventures, Bandi and Susanne cherished their ability to help others in need, especially in Israel where he was a regular visitor. Funeral service at Kiryat Shaul, Tel Aviv, 2pm May 25. GAL--Andreas. The American Committee for Shenkar College in Israel records with deep sorrow the passing of Andreas (Bandi) Gal, beloved father of our board member Julie Gal and extends it's condolences to the Gal Kalter family. Bandi and his late wife Suzanne Gal were loyal and dedicated supporters of Shenkar College of Engineering and Design in Ramat Gan. He will be missed. David Pernick, Chancellor Bruce Pernick, President Charlotte A. Fainblatt, Executive Director GAL--Andreas. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted Trustee and benefactor Andreas Gal. Heartfelt sympathy to the family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President

An article on April 27 about commercial applications for hybrid vehicles described a bucket truck used by Florida Power and Light incorrectly. While the truck's hybrid system can indeed power the bucket, it can also power the drive wheels.

FELDER--Bettina . The Glorious Food Family mourns the loss of our beloved colleague Bettina Felder who passed away after a long illness on May 16th, 2008. As a Senior Account Executive for the past 25 years, she touched the lives of numerous co-workers and clients forging many friendships. She faced her illness ''Head-on'' with great courage and was an inspiration to all of us. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be scheduled at a later date. FELDER--Bettina Hensley, of New York, died May 16th at Calvary Hospital. She was hospitalized three weeks ago. She was born in Greenwich, CT, August 27th, 1948, the daughter of Thomas B. and Betty R. Felder, and spent her childhood in Italy, returning to the U.S. in 1960 to attend the Garrison Forest School. She moved to New York in 1970 after attending the University of Denver. She was employed at several small companies, including the jeweler Gubelin, before joining the staff of Glorious Food in 1983. She will be fondly remembered by the many New Yorkers who knew her well as a friend, or in connection with her long tenure as an account executive at Glorious Food, where she was the first woman to hold that position, and was responsible for many important social, business and charity events over the past twenty-five years. She was an active and enthusiastic competitive tennis player, a member of the Executive Women's Golf Association, a lifelong member of the Screen Actors Guild, and a member of the Girls Vacation Fund Board. She traveled extensively, most recently to Peru and Russia. She is survived by her brother Wilson, sister-in-law Laura, nephew William and niece Julia. Donations in her memory are welcome to the Roundabout Theater Company's Take Your Seat Campaign.

THE 2008 Karting Challenge, a four-hour endurance race to support the Special Olympics Connecticut, began Tuesday at Lime Rock Park here. At precisely 1 p.m., drivers from 16 teams dashed to their go-karts in a Le Mans-style start. Over the next four hours, the karts would lap the quarter-mile autocross course more than 300 times.

A BREATHLESS America awaits ... more presidential debates. In this, the ultramarathon of presidential runs, the candidates continue to talk and talk, with approximately 3,283 debates so far. Or, at least, it feels that way. John McCain is trying to make sure that the fun continues through the fall; his campaign has floated the idea of a new series of Lincoln-Douglas-style debates with his Democratic opponent. Barack Obama, who is likely to be that opponent, has said it sounds like a good idea to him.

AUDIO: THE MAKING OF A SNAKE To encourage his son, Tim, to improve his performance in school, Fred Heiler offered a powerful incentive -- a replica version of the Shelby 427 Cobra. Mr. Heiler kept his promise, and the two of them assembled the collectable car together in their garage.
BIRNBAUM--Eugene A. , 81. Services at ''The Riverside'', W. 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Sunday June 1st at 2pm.

JENKS--Dave . His early departure this Monday so unlike him. He made things happen, he improved many lives, our lives. He always carried through and never disappointed. He was a center of gravity and didn't have time to realize it. He and his adored David Helfrich, Davey, represented the best a couple can be and the loss to him is indescribable and to us, unimaginable and devastating. Our love and devotion to Davey for all he was to Dave and is to us is unlimited and eternal. Our condolences also are extended to the Jenks Family with whom he shared a lifetime of love and respect. To say we miss you Dave is hard, because it would mean we accept that you are gone and you never let us down before kiddo. Jonathan and Pierce

BRUSTIEN--Harold G . passed on May 22. He has gone to join his beloved wife Iris. The kindest, most generous, gentle and thoughtful man. His moral compass was true. Harold was a most honest friend. He was a defender of all those in need. Throughout his illness, he never lost his concern for others, insight and humor. He was the ideal father. His children Susie and Steve, their spouses, Peter and Mary and his cherished grandson Matthew flourished under his selfless guidance and devotion. He and his sister, Brew, had a most extraordinary sibling relationship. They were each other's best friend throughout their life's journey. He was a cousin, and uncle, that could always be counted on. Harold helped shape the lives of all those he came in contact with. No words can describe how much he will be missed. Services will be held Sunday, May 25 at 2pm at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Rd., Great Neck, New York. 516-487-0900

HALL--S. Jeanne . The Museum of Arts and Design mourns the passing of our dear friend, esteemed colleague, and founder and chairman of the Museum's Professional Advisory Council. Jeanne was a steadfast and passionate advocate for the Museum's capital expansion project. Her leadership, influence, goodwill and grace inspired peers and colleagues to raise the bar during this important time of growth and change. We extend our deepest sympathies to Sherwin Kamin and family. Jerry Chazen, Holly Hotchner, Nan Laitman, Barbara Tober, PAC, and the entire board and staff of the Museum of Arts and Design.

LAVEY--Stewart E. , 62, loving husband of Suzanne (Laurence) Lavey, died suddenly on Thursday, May 22, 2008. Mr. Lavey lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan with his wife, who had a 34-year career as a dancer with the Metropolitan Opera Ballet. He was an enthusiastic supporter of the Met and various other educational and charitable organizations. Mr. Lavey was an attorney at Drinker Biddle & Reath LLP, where he was a managing partner and a leader of the corporate and securities practice in the Florham Park, NJ, office. Mr. Lavey practiced law for 38 years, joining Shanley & Fisher as of counsel in 1985 and becoming a partner in July 1987. When Shanley combined with Drinker Biddle in 1999, he was instrumental in helping lead their integration. Mr. Lavey was a 1970 graduate and adjunct faculty member of Fordham University School of Law. He was a proud graduate and active alumnus of The Pingry School (Class of 1963), and was a respected member of the Schwab House Board of Directors. Mr. Lavey was an avid boater and enjoyed spending many of his summers off the Atlantic coast. Services are Sunday, May 25, at The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. in New York. Interment follows at the Cedar Park Cemetery/Beth El Cemetery in Paramus, N.J. Donations, in lieu of flowers, can be made to The Seeing Eye, Inc., P.O. Box 375, Morristown, NJ 07963; Golfers Against Cancer, 1700 Lake Kingwood Trail, Kingwood, TX 77339; Morris Animal Foundation, 10200 E. Girard Ave., B430, Denver, CO 80231, or the American Heart Association. He will be missed by all of the people he knew and institutions he supported.
Dance Claudia La Rocco

ZOOM There are many photographs of Manadel al-Jamadi's body at Abu Ghraib, but it is the one with Specialist Sabrina Harman that stands out among them -- the photograph of a pretty American girl who is alive (giving the ''thumbs up'') and a battered Iraqi man who is dead. The photograph misdirects us. We become angry at Harman, rather than angry at the killer. We see al-Jamadi's body, but we don't see the act that turned him from a human being into a corpse. We don't understand what the photograph means, nor what it is about.

LONDON -- With Internet gambling predicted to surpass $20 billion in 2008, and with illegal wagering accounting for $150 billion in the United States, by some estimates, the temptation for those seeking to influence the outcome of games has never been greater. Now, a raft of gambling scandals in sports, from cricket to soccer and most recently tennis, has raised an uncomfortable question: Are the games we watch fixed? Last Monday, a report commissioned by the major tennis governing bodies recommended that 45 matches played in the last five years be investigated because betting patterns gave a ''strong indication'' that gamblers were profiting from inside information. And those matches, the report said, may be only the tip of the iceberg.

WILLIAMS--W. K. (Bill) , (September 30, 1927--May 18, 2008). He led a life anyone would be proud to live. Longtime Coordinator of Amnesty International Group 9 (West Village), Bill worked tirelessly for human rights and against the death penalty. Honorably discharged from the U.S. Army in 1947, he was an NAACP member and civil rights activist since college (U. of Conn., BA, 1950). His management consulting firm, W.K. Williams & Co., specialized in non-profits and government. But he was happiest leading a mushroom walk along the Pallisades for the NY Mycological Society; he edited its newsletter, as well as ''Toxic And Hallucinogenic Mushroom Poisoning'' by mycologist Gary Lincoff and D.H. Mitchel, M.D. Eternally curious, he studied at the Jung Institute, Switzerland. A dedicated Village Democrat, he regularly volunteered at a Village homeless shelter. He'd wrinkle his nose, reading this, as his self-deprecating wit was as quick as his wisdom and humility were great. He'll be missed forever by the love of his life, his wife Helen; sister Rhoda; nephew Alan; niece Andrea; grandniece Alexis; and hundreds of friends who knew his unconditional love. Please donate to Amnesty International USA, Northeast Region, 58 Day St. Somerville, MA 02144.

HEARD--Helen Owsley Heard , died on May 21 in Branford, CT. She was born on August 18, 1920 to Helen Blanche Hall and John Ebsworth Owsley in Watch Hill, Rhode Island. Helen spent her childhood in New Haven, Connecticut and attended Chatham Hall in Danville, Virginia. Married to the late Drayton Heard who died in 2003, they lived many years in Sewickley, Pennsylvania before they moved to New Haven in 1979. Helen is survived by sons Drayton and John and by a daughter Helen Hetherington. Also by grandchildren Nancy Krahmer, Allison Dugan, Thomas Hetherington and Holly Hetherington and six great-grandchildren, by her nephews Richard and Sam Goodyear and by her nieces Elizabeth Guy and Jeannette Kadish. She will be remembered by her family and friends for her beauty, cheerfulness, pearls of wisdom, loyalty and sense of humor. She was unfailingly courteous but had a sharp perceptive wit, often combined with a streak of mischief. Fond of quoting her grandmother about one's duty in life to give other people pleasure, Helen lived by that rule --she was fun, and had fun. There will be a private graveside service in Sewickley, Pennsylvania. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, June 10th at 11:00 am at Dwight Chapel in New Haven Connecticut.

I'VE always thought that driving in New York City is a bit like a game of touch football between the Jets and the Giants -- you're always seconds away from a painful collision, but for the most part you don't get clobbered. Getting through a traffic jam on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway is a game of inches. So even though I'm a fan of almost anything with a motor and two wheels, I was a bit skeptical about venturing onto city streets aboard a Vespa. After touring through Manhattan and Brooklyn on a group ride for journalists on a recent Saturday, though, I discovered that scooters are extremely useful for basic city transport.

PRESSMAN--William M. , 93, died May 18, 2008 two years after a stroke. Loving husband of the late Rhoda Pressman, loved father of Penny Bernstein (Jonathan) and Fred Pressman (Ronni) and proud grandfather of Sally Pressman Bernstein, Benjamin Rhodes Bernstein, Ryan Alan Pressman and Randy William Pressman. Born in NYC, he graduated from the University of Georgia where he played football for the Bulldogs and went to the Orange Bowl. He was a philosophy major who was also on the boxing team (odd choice for a Jewish boy from Harlem). After college, he joined his brother, Jack, in sales at Pressman Toy. He then created GI Joe as the Executive vice president of Hasbro. He will be greatly missed by his family forever.

ROSENTHAL--Irving . President Gregory H. Williams and the students, faculty and alumni of The City College of New York mourn the death and celebrate the life of Irving Rosenthal, a great teacher and mentor to generations of journalists in newsrooms and broadcast studios around America. Professor Rosenthal taught journalism at CCNY for 40 years. Among his numerous students were a veritable ''Who's Who'' of American journalism that included: A. M. Rosenthal, the late executive editor of The New York Times; Daniel Schorr of NPR and formerly CBS; Marvin Kalb of CBS and NBC News, and Stephen B. Shepard, dean of the Graduate School of Journalism of the City University of New York and former editor of Business Week. A 1933 CCNY graduate, Professor Rosenthal joined the College's English faculty upon graduation. He transitioned to journalism three years later after creating two journalism courses. He retired in 1976 as Professor Emeritus of English and Chairman of Communications and Mass Media. Besides teaching, Professor Rosenthal also served as CCNY's Director of Public Relations, co-authored two books on writing and wrote for several publications.
BARBIERI--William J . A friend beyond compare, you helped make this world a better place. Albert and Shirley Sack

CAPA--Cornell . The entire International Center of Photography community mourns the death of the man whose vision continues to guide us today. As a renowned photographer and humanitarian, as the founder of the International Fund for Concerned Photography, and the founder of ICP in 1974, Cornell was a singular force in the world of photography, opening our eyes to the power of the photographic image as an agent of change. At ICP he ventured far beyond photojournalism and brought the full range of photography to the public's attention through an institution that was born, wholecloth, as a true center--both Museum and School. There Cornell was available to the many photographers from around the world who came to him for advice and encouragement. ICP and photographers everywhere are his lasting legacy. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held on September 10th at 10am at The Times Center, 242 West 41st Street in Manhattan. Contributions in Cornell's memory may be made to the Cornell Capa Legacy Project at ICP. Gayle Greenhill Chairman, Board of Trustees Jeffrey A. Rosen President, Board of Trustees Willis E.Hartshorn Ehrenkranz Director International Center of Photography

BRADLEY--Barbara Louise . (December 12, 1927--May 2, 2008). Recognized as one of the greatest and most inspiring teachers of drawing in the country, Barbara Bradley died May 2, 2008 in California following an automobile accident. She was an awardwinning illustrator, instructor, painter, and author, as well as a loving wife, daughter, mother and grandmother. She was Director of the School of Illustration at the Academy of Art University in San Francisco for twenty-five years, and was the only Academy teacher to have a hall named after her (Bradley Hall, 540 Powell Street, San Francisco). She was one of a handful of successful females in a male-dominated profession, although she didn't consider herself a pioneer; she merely did what she loved to do. Barbara was the only child of Gerard and Josie Preston. She was born in Los Angeles, but spent most of her childhood in San Francisco. Barbara graduated from Lowell High School in San Francisco, then attended the University of California, Berkeley, where she met her first husband Herbert Briggs (a fellow artist) while drawing for the rally committee. Herb and Barbara studied at Art Center College of Design in Los Angeles before setting off for New York to begin their careers. Barbara was soon hired to work at the prestigious Charles E. Cooper Studio in New York City, where she achieved great success. After returning to California, Barbara continued her career as a freelance illustrator. Specializing in figure drawing, she became best known for her depictions of children (while raising three of her own, all of whom did their stints as models for her). Her work for such clients as Bank of America, Borden, Dole, PG&E, and C&H Sugar brought her many awards. In 1958, Barbara was invited to speak at the Academy of Art in San Francisco. She was thereupon invited to teach, and was ultimately encouraged by Academy thenpresident Richard Stephens to build, class-by-class, what would become the School of Illustration as it is today at the Academy of Art University. Over the next five decades, Barbara inspired generations of students to become professional appreciators of story, figure, gesture, character, and costume; to love color, value, and composition; and to become lifetime learners. Always attired in one of her paisley smocks, Barbara continued to teach drawing until last December, when she formally retired at the age of 80. Barbara also taught drawing classes and workshops at many locations throughout the United States and London, including Disney Animation Studios, Pixar and Lucas Arts. Her work is displayed in the Museum of American Illustration at the Society of Illustrators in New York and in the permanent collection of the US Air Force. Encouraged by her second husband Neil in 2003, Bradley published the longanticipated Drawing People: How to Portray the Clothed Figure (NorthLight Books). Known as a ''must have book for any artist'', one reviewer noted that ''the information is better than any class I have taken or book I have read. It is not a book just on technique, but it teaches how to see the object. Barbara Bradley shares a road map...every artist should have this book.'' Last year, Bradley received the coveted Distinguished Educator Award from the Society of Illustrators in NY. She was selected by a jury of 75 esteemed illustrators and artists from all over the world, joining a prestigious list of previous winners. This was the capstone to her career; she had also received numerous vocational and teaching awards, and in 1992 was awarded Honorary Life Membership In the San Francisco Society Of Illustrators. Barbara always said that she had two families. Her ''first family'' included her husband, Neil, who passed away on May 4, 2008 due to injuries suffered in the same automobile accident, and her survivors: children Lauchlin Briggs Divine, Glennis Briggs, Andy Bradley and his wife Bella; and grandchildren Diana Divine and Lydia Bradley. Her son-in-law Craig Divine died in 2006. Her ''second family'' included the hundreds of students who she taught and from whom she learned. Today, those students can be found as close as San Francisco and as far away as Shanghai. Though Barbara would say that all of her students were notable, some who have earned national or international recognition include Kazuhiko Sano, Francis Livingston, Zahid Sardar, Robert Hunt, Tim Bower, Chuck Pyle, Bob Walker, Lisa Berrett and Melissa Marshall. Many former Bradley students were inspired to become teachers. A long-time resident of Berkeley, California, Barbara wrote that she was happy about the choices she'd made during her life, including ''choosing to raise a family rather than being a full-time illustrator, choosing to make my kids' clothes and fancy birthday cakes rather than spending time 'on the board', and eventually choosing to become more involved in teaching illustration than in the doing of it.'' When she celebrated 50 years of teaching at the Academy last December, also commemorating her 80th birthday and her sixdecade career, she said it was ''a wonderful event that made my choices not only inevitable but the right ones.'' The fire that Barbara's passion and enthusiasm has kindled in the hearts of artists the world over continues to burn, and will certainly be passed on for many generations to come. Memorial Service for Barbara Bradley, 2151 Van Ness Avenue at Broadway, Academy of Art University Chapel (Formerly St. Brigids Church), San Francisco, California, Thursday, June 5, 2008, 7 o'clock pm.

PETER C. SUTTON looked a little weary as he presided over a senior staff meeting at the Bruce Museum here. Dr. Sutton had just returned the night before from a business trip to Japan, where he had given a lecture on Vermeer and the Delft School, his specialty, and discussed loans of artworks for future shows at the Bruce. Now he was listening as Nancy Hall-Duncan, senior curator of art, reported on plans for a 2009 show devoted to the French Impressionist painter Alfred Sisley.

Nick's recent column about China's evolution toward greater freedom in the aftermath of the Sichuan earthquake generated numerous comments from Chinese readers. Some questioned the value of democracy for China, while others rallied to the defense of Prime Minister Wen Jiabao (温家宝). The support shown here for Mr. Wen is consistent with the outpouring of approval that can be found elsewhere on the Web, including Facebook and sites on the Chinese blogosphere. Readers' response to the Communist Party was generally tempered, with neither heavy criticism nor praise for the government's management of the earthquake and its handling of the news media.

Casino Drive, who after only two starts appears to be the strongest contender to upset Big Brown's Triple Crown, is scheduled to have a work Wednesday. We will also learn Wednesday which jockey will be riding Casino Drive in the Belmont. Kent Desormeaux rode Casino Drive in his Peter Pan win, but he is Big Brown's regular rider.

FOXBOROUGH, Mass. -- Sometimes things in sports transcend the final score, the statistic sheet and the midfield postgame celebration. Of all of the factors spurring Syracuse to the 2008 national lacrosse title with a 13-10 victory over Johns Hopkins on Monday, none may have loomed larger than the emotion of the team playing in honor of Aaron Guadagnolo.

FOXBOROUGH, Mass. -- The crew is just about finished clearing the stands here at Gillette Stadium after the conclusion of the 2008 N.C.A.A. lacrosse tournament. Syracuse defeated Johns Hopkins, 13-10, and we figured we'd send you out with a few links before we leave the stadium.

Frankie Hejduk is back on the United States men's national team 22-man roster, replacing Benny Feilhaber, for Wednesday's friendly against England at Wembley Stadium in London. At 33, Hejduk is the team's elder statesman.
In light of recent, very public issues related to horse racing, Congress is beginning to take a closer look at the sport.

Oprah Winfrey's audience is falling off, The Times reports today, but maybe what she's losing in numbers is made up in, well, audience fervor. Or is that an understatement? You be the judge, as she announces her "favorite things" giveaway the other day:

Many of the questions I get from readers have to do with money -- specifically how people fund a career shift. I try to get these financial details as often as possible, and I recently heard from a reader, Nina Murphy, whose story of how her husband, Bart Ferris, left the corporate world to start a gourmet foods company with a partner touched on just this issue. It turns out that Ms. Murphy was a big part of the story herself since she is bringing her own skills to her husband's venture by working as the company's publicist. (Career reinvention is always a little easier with a supportive spouse in the wings. But that's a subject for another post.) I asked Ms. Murphy to tell their story here in the blog, with a focus on how they managed the financial side of things. And now, I'll leave it to Ms. Murphy:

"CNN is starting a weekly talk show on international issues led by Newsweek's Fareed Zakaria that will debut next Sunday with former British Prime Minister Tony Blair as an interview subject," the Associated Press reports.

BAYAMON, P.R. -- Traditionally, Puerto Ricans have both served in the Armed Forces and died in combat in numbers disproportionate to their share of the population. So it rankles many on the island that, even as their sons and daughters are serving with distinction in Iraq and Afghanistan, they do not enjoy all of the same rights and privileges of citizenship as other Americans.

New York Times: Meet Amanda Lorber, a subject and the unexpected star of the MTV reality series "The Paper." Joey Cheek, the gold medalist speed skater and founder of Team Darfur, has a powerful essay in The Washington Post today, calling on Olympians to use their spotlight to push the case for Darfur. He doesn't want a boycott, and he's sensitive to the Chinese desire to host a great event, but he does want people to pressure China and the international community to put Darfur on the top of the international agenda.

The Iraq team that unified its war-torn nation is on the verge of exclusion from the Beijing Games.

FIFA announced today that it has suspended Iraq from all international soccer competitions for one year after last week's decision by the Iraqi government to dissolve its national Olympic committee. Iraq was already facing a suspension from the International Olympic Committee that could prevent its athletes from going to Beijing.

I'm writing this in a scant spare minute in Bordeaux, where I've parachuted in for a whirlwind weekend touring Pessac-Léognan and Graves. It's a land of haves and have-nots, where I've seen both vineyards that have succumbed to neglect because the owners no longer had the money or energy to care for them and grand chateaux restored in full opulent detail by the prosperous elite. Incidentally, plenty of job opportunities must exist in chateau restoration as it seems to be a never-ending Bordeaux phenomenon.

I'm pausing to reflect on Memorial Day, which commemorates those who gave their lives in military service for the United States. Here's a little background, in music and words, on Arlington National Cemetery, which was created in 1864 and now is slowly running out of room. Several years ago, I wrote a song about Arlington, performed by the band I'm in, Uncle Wade (I'm not sure I could be a journalist if I didn't have music, too):

Let me introduce you to a horse that makes all the earlier debate about whether fillies can run against colts look just a little silly. Meet Princesse D'Anjou, a 7-year-old thoroughbred mare who on Sunday won the Grand Steeplechase de Paris for the second time. The event at Auteuil racecourse in Paris is the premiere steeplechase on the Continent, covering 5,800 meters, or just over three and a half miles, with 369,000 euros, or $582,000, going to the winner.

A 4-0 loss in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals has Pittsburgh trailing in a series for the first time this postseason, and Penguins Coach Michel Therrien is looking to shake things up. He switched his lines for practice, dropping Pascal Dupuis from Sidney Crosby’s line and replacing him with Ryan Malone. For Detroit, Johan Franzen moved a step closer to making his return from a concussion, practicing on Sunday.

A man convicted in a multimillion dollar investment fraud case whose victims included N.F.L. players has committed suicide in jail in Atlanta. The man, Kirk Wright, 37, hanged himself Saturday in the Union City jail, Betty Honey, an investigator with the Fulton County Medical Examiner’s office, said Sunday.

Joakim Noah, a Chicago Bulls forward and former Florida star, has been charged with possession of marijuana and having an open container of alcohol in Gainesville, Fla. The police spokesman Sgt. Rick Roberts says Noah was arrested around 1:50 a.m. Sunday after an officer spotted him on a sidewalk holding a plastic cup containing an amber drink. During a search at the station, officers found marijuana in his pocket. He could face up to six months in jail and a $500 fine for the marijuana charge.

Lewis Hamilton overcame an early accident on wet roads at the Monaco Grand Prix on Sunday for a victory that put him at the top of the Formula One standings. Hamilton, a 23-year-old Briton who finished second to his former McLaren teammate Fernando Alonso at Monaco last year, beat BMW Sauber’s Robert Kubica by three seconds. He is the first English driver to win at Monaco since Graham Hill in 1969.

The authorities are investigating the death of the former N.F.L. lineman Thomas McHale, who was found dead at a friend’s home in Wesley Chapel, Fla. He was 45. The Pasco County Sheriff’s Office said McHale was found by the friend early Sunday. The authorities say foul play is not suspected. McHale played at Cornell, then for Tampa Bay from 1987 to 1992, for Philadelphia for two seasons and for Miami for one.

Michel Fournier, a 64-year-old retired French army officer, is expected to attempt to parachute some 25 miles to earth early Monday in Saskatchewan. Fournier’s original plan was to jump on Sunday morning, but weather conditions were expected to be more favorable Monday.

RIEGEL--Lawrence M., of New York City died on May 22, 2008 at the age of seventyfour. Beloved husband of Jeanne for fifty years and devoted father of Jennifer Elmlinger, Heather Harper, Whitney Mooney, and Cynthia Von Arx. He was the proud father-in-law of Paul, Roger, John, and Eric. He was the adored grandfather of eight. Larry was born in New York City and made his home here. He was educated at the Choate School and Princeton University. Larry spent 48 years in the advertising business and retired as senior vice president of Avrett Free and Ginsburg. His greatest passion was his love of family, friends, and travel. A celebration of Larry's life will be held Monday, June 2nd, 11am at Saint James' Episcopal Church in NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Make a Wish Foundation where Larry devoted his volunteer time and to the Cottage Club at Princeton University.

LEBWORTH--M. Joseph, died on May 17, 2008 at the age of 86. Joe's heroism and service to his country in World War II will long be remembered. He parachuted into Normandy the night before D-Day as a member of the 101st Airborne Division and received serious leg injuries after 17 days of combat. He was subsequently awarded the Bronze Star, the Purple Heart, the Infantry Combat Badge and France's Liberation Medal. Joe devoted the last several decades to the two great passions in his life: his family, and especially his devoted wife of 46 years, Caral; and not-for-profit endeavors, particularly the Museum of Modern Art film department and his alma mater, Yale University. His loss will leave a great void, and he will be missed by his many friends and family members. We will especially miss Joe's smiling face, his curiosity about every facet of life, his astute political insights and his unfailing courage. He is survived by his wife, Caral; his three stepchildren Glenn Greenberg, Stephen Greenberg and Alva Greenberg; and ten grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Museum of Modern Art Film Department, 11 West 53 Street, NY, NY 10019-5497. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday May 28th at 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue.

When ''Panic in Level 4'' by Richard Preston is released Tuesday, it will join a group of books devoted to explaining, challenging and exalting science. ''Panic,'' top left, tells unusual stories like the search for hosts of the Ebola virus and the Russian brothers who built a supercomputer in their apartment in their quest to dissect the number pi. Books with a light approach do well. ''Spook: Science Tackles the Afterlife,'' top right, is a worldwide hunt to pin down the human soul, and ''How to Fossilize Your Hamster'' is a guide to experiments for grown-ups to try at home. O'BRIEN--Fr. Frederick J., S.J., died on Monday, May 19, 2008, at Hollywood Presbyterian Hospital in Hollywood, California. He was 76 years of age. He had been a member of the Society of Jesus for 58 years and a priest for 46 years. Father O'Brien was born in Hyde Park, MA on October 31, 1931, and was baptized at Most Precious Blood Church in the Archdiocese of Boston. He attended Boston College High School from 1945 to 1949 and entered the Society of Jesus on July 30, 1949 at Shadowbrook in Lenox, MA, where he also did his first studies as a Jesuit. He received his theological training in preparation for priesthood at Woodstock College in Woodstock, MD, and was ordained a priest there on June 17, 1962. Father O'Brien held a Master's Degree in History from the Catholic University of America in Washington, DC, but achieving that degree did not put an end to his continuous study of history and his keen sense for historical detail which frequently informed his conversation. He taught history at Boston College from 1968 to 1971 and at Fairfield University from 1971 to 1976. In 1976 Father O'Brien's career took him from Jesuit universities into Jesuit high schools. Although he was always a Bostonian at heart, it was at this time that Father O'Brien moved to New York City. There he began to teach history at Regis High School in Manhattan, but almost immediately he moved into high school administrative positions at Regis High School and then at Fordham Preparatory in the Bronx. He returned to New England to be Principal and later to be both Principal and President at Bishop Connolly High School in Fall River, only to return again to the Big Apple to assume the office of Principal at Regis High School from 1983 to 1989. Father O'Brien became Assistant to the New York Provincial for Secondary Education from 1990 to 2001. Having finished his career in secondary education, Father O'Brien indulged his interest in history by becoming the New York Province Archivist. Fluent in English, Spanish and German, Father O'Brien helped manage many of the international correspondences from the Provincial's office. In addition, Father O'Brien wrote the obituaries of deceased Jesuits for various publications. Father O'Brien fulfilled these duties until he died. Besides having been a scholar, an administrator and a historian, Father O'Brien was a devoted priest. He spent several weeks each year on the west coast providing pastoral care in the Archdiocese of Los Angeles, especially at Blessed Sacrament Church in Hollywood, CA. It was during his last visit to the west coast that Father O'Brien fell ill, received hospitalization, and died. Father O'Brien is survived by his cousins Richard O'Brien of Humarock, MA, Patricia O'Brien of West Roxbury, MA, and Robert O'Brien of Washington Depot, CT. Friends may call Monday May 26th, 2-4 and 7-9pm and Tuesday May 27th, 2-4pm at Regis High School Chapel, 55 East 84th Street, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday May 27th at 7:30pm at St. Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street.

9 P.M. (Sundance) REQUIEM FOR BILLY THE KID (2006) Anne Feinsilber puts a European twist on the American myth of the notorious young outlaw who died at the hand of the New Mexico sheriff Pat Garrett. Or then again, maybe he didn't. Using Western history, vintage photographs, film clips and accounts of a sheriff's efforts to exhume the body of Billy's mother, Ms. Feinsilber examines the theory that Billy's grave does not contain his body. Since she is French, she also compares the gunman to the existential poets Arthur Rimbaud and Paul Verlaine. Kris Kristofferson lends his voice as Billy. 7 P.M. Don Mattingly has played in or coached in more than 2,000 major league games, but he had never visited Wrigley Field. That finally changed on Monday after Mattingly, a special assignment coach with the Los Angeles Dodgers, saw the famous ivy on the outfield walls and heard the Bleacher Bums. "My mom always wanted me to play here," Mattingly said. "It was day baseball. It was five hours from my home. You were close enough so that you could get home, but not so close that you would have people bothering you all the time." When Mattingly, who played his entire career with the Yankees, was asked if he ever came close to playing for the Chicago Cubs, he said that he had not. Then Mattingly laughed and added, "Well, not that I know of." As Mattingly and Manager Joe Torre drove to Wrigley on Monday, he told Torre that he had never seen the Friendly Confines. The Yankees played here in 2003, but Mattingly, who lives in Evansville, Ind., did not became a Yankees coach until 2004. Mattingly was supposed to be the Dodgers' batting coach, but he assumed a lesser role so he could be home with Jordon, his youngest son. Mattingly and his wife, Kim, filed for divorce last November. Jordon is in high school. Although Joe Girardi beat out Mattingly for the Yankees' manager position, Mattingly said he still wanted to manage. Mattingly said he would renew his quest once his family situation was stabilized. He will not travel to Shea Stadium with the Dodgers for the series starting Thursday because he is taking Jordon to compete in a horse jumping show.

When Microsoft joined the One Laptop Per Child project earlier this month, I wrote an article noting the change in heart by both sides. The O.L.P.C. project, intended to bring cheap computers to children in poorer nations, had been committed to using the freely distributed Linux operating system, an open-source alternative to Microsoft's Windows. And Microsoft had resisted joining anything that promoted open-source software.

LAS VEGAS - The family tree of Senator Barack Obama has been the subject of much discussion - and inspection - since he arrived on the national political stage four years ago.

In 1952, Adlai Stevenson ran for president on the Democratic ticket against Republican Dwight D. Eisenhower and was labeled "egg-head" for being an intellectual. But worse, he was saddled with the ignominious distinction of being too frugal. During a campaign stop, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photograph by William M. Gallagher of The Flint Journal revealed a hole in the sole of Governor Stevenson's right shoe, and this quickly became a trademark. The shoe was made into metallic lapel pins, proudly worn by supporters in both the '52 and '56 elections.

The heart of this document is the background to the transaction section -- the company's disclosure, mandated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, of the events leading up to Wrigley's agreement to be bought for about $23 billion.

As people are becoming more aware of the fate of racehorses after they finish running, it is important to highlight those horses that have successfuly transitioned from the racetrack to a second career. To show that our stars have other options. And as more people become aware of the qualities thoroughbreds can bring to other equestrian disciplines, we can expand the "adopter pool" for Off Track Thoroughbreds (OTTBs) and increase the numbers that can then avoid the miserable fate of horse slaughter.

Updated MOSUL - The closest thing to a Memorial Day barbecue for soldiers at Combat Outpost Rabiy came when one of their Bradley fighting vehicles, rumbling along a rubble-strewn street in Mosul, hit a sheep.

BRIEFS We've seen navies take on pirates and green pirates take on whale hunters. But a navy hunting sharks? That's a new one. After a series of rare attacks that left two swimmers dead, the Mexican Navy is searching for the feared beast by helicopter, boat and binoculars.

Now that Time Warner Cable is to be spun off from parent company Time Warner, questions have emerged about what it will do with its newfound freedom. Richard Greenfield, an analyst at Pali Research, said in a report Tuesday that he thinks it may move to swallow a smaller rival.

Once again, there was considerable heartbreak for some very well known names (and some not so well known) at the Monaco Grand Prix and the Indy 500 (both held on Sunday). Let's go in chronological order:

Here is a little-known fact about New York's accidental governor, David A. Paterson: He is the first Freemason to hold that office in more than 60 years. He joined the fraternal order in 2002, his office confirmed. In fact, he is actually the 20th New York governor to be a member, according to the Grand Lodge of New York (which is still on a public-relations binge to demystify itself).Having governors on the membership rolls hasn't necessarily helped the Freemasons fend off the conspiracy theories swirling around them, ranging from possession of the Holy Grail, the founding of Atlantis and the hiding of secret symbols in Washington architecture and United States currency.

DENVER-Senator John McCain kept up his attacks on Senator Barack Obama on Tuesday as naïve in foreign policy and appeared critical of the Bush administration's diplomatic engagement in North Korea. Both positions were precursors of a speech on nuclear security policy that Mr. McCain gave today at the University of Denver.

A day after FIFA decided to boot last year's darlings of international soccer, the world soccer governing body announced a more welcome decision, lifting a confrontational ban on international matches played at high altitude.

The attacks of Sept. 11 transformed ports of entry into points of anxiety, but the job itself didn't get any easier -- just as illegal drugs slipped through loopholes, so did potential security threats. While no attacks have originated at the ports, reminders that they are vulnerable are frequent -- from the Sept. 11 Commission's final report to the uproar over a proposal to allow a Dubai company manage some operations at U.S. ports.

Neil Asher Silberman, the former director of the Ename Center for Public Archaeology and Heritage Presentation in Belgium, explains in The Washington Post why he dislikes "the world's most famous fictional archaeologist." Between the surprise start by the Florida Marlins and the stunning struggles of the Mets, the Atlanta Braves carved out a spot for themselves in second place in the National League East, tied with the Philadelphia Phillies at two and a half games back. But this is all about to change, according to the Atlanta Journal-Constitution's Mark Bradley.
The dynamism of 2007 -- when the world woke up to climate change -- has transformed this year into something more familiar to longtime observers of policies on global warming: talks about targets.

The first boisterous fan tried to start a "Fire Willie" chant in the eighth inning on Monday night. It did not last long; 20 seconds, at the most. The fan couldn't find any vocal allies in his call for Willie Randolph, the Mets' manager, to lose his job.
With names like Rock Star, Full Throttle and Monster, it's no wonder new super-caffeinated energy drinks appeal to teens.

The hoof specialist Ian McKinlay was giddy Monday night about how quickly Big Brown was healing from a quarter crack, or stress fracture, in his left front hoof. He basically declared him cured, and predicted he would be on the track this morning.

After finishing the piece about Pat Capolupo of Pat & Rose last week, I went to Monaco to see the Grand Prix-hence my recent silence. Pat's last word to me as I left the factory was "Ferrari." I laughed. Pat likes to keep things simple: pick a great name. On the plane to Nice I saw Tory Burch, who was going to visit some friends near Monaco, though probably wasn't going to stay for the Grand Prix. Later, the next day, the sun shining as it's meant to, we got together for lunch on the beach at Cap d'Ail. She introduced me to her friends, who invited me to a cocktail party at their home that night, where I met some more people who I would see throughout the weekend at various places. Monaco, I guess, is like that during the GP.

The following is a very detailed question from Linda Plaut of Golden, Colo. She's looking for a great location for a wedding anniversary that fulfills a long list of criteria. Based on your own trips and travel experiences, do you have any advice that helps meet this tall order? We put this question to you, readers.

The Friday before Memorial Day is a good day for a company to disclose information that it would otherwise prefer to keep quiet. Most of the press and the investment community is already physically -- if not mentally -- out of town. So, by the time the markets re-open Tuesday, the news is already stale and apt to be lost in the mix.
If you can get wild salmon -- and it is the season -- its flavor is almost always better than that of farmed.

This week, David R. Jones, the president of the Community Service Society of New York, will be answering questions about how New York City and its residents can fight poverty, and how to help low-wage, working Americans who are increasingly marginalized by the global economy.

Bear Stearns tried at least six times to raise billions of dollars in the months before its dramatic collapse -- and considered selling a stake to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts -- but the efforts fizzled each time, according to an article in The Wall Street Journal that recounts the firm's missed opportunities in that fateful period. Those opportunities, the article said, "might have been able to save the 85-year-old brokerage."

More than a year after buying Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village in Manhattan for a record-breaking $5.4 billion, Tishman Speyer Properties has accused hundreds of rent-stabilized tenants of living somewhere other than their apartments, The Times reports. Residents and their lawyers say that tactic is part of an aggressive attempt to drive out tenants paying lower rents to turn their units into market rate rentals.

The Rockefeller family built one of the great American fortunes by supplying the nation with oil. Now history has come full circle: some family members say it is time to start moving beyond the oil age.

An important theme of Dot Earth is limiting losses from inevitable disasters -- what I call "hard knocks." As the human population heads toward 9 billion, more or less, with most of the growth coming in struggling places, unless more is done to boost resilience to known hazards -- earthquakes included -- there will be ever more wrenching imagery like that out of China (and Myanmar, as well).
A looming decision in a heated lawsuit brought by railroad giant CSX could shut down a loophole used by activist hedge funds to hide their stake from the market, The New York Post reported.

BCE won its request for an expedited process as the Supreme Court of Canada considers whether or not it will hear an appeal of a lower court ruling that threatened the phone company's buyout deal. The court suggested on Monday it may hear an appeal in three weeks.
The acrimonious battle between J-Power, one of Japan's biggest energy producers, and The Children's Investment Fund has escalated after J-Power published an open letter to shareholders.

Let the countdown begin. With just a week between now and the final primaries in South Dakota and Montana on June 3 and a few days until Puerto Rico holds its contest, the Democratic nominating fight may be coming to an end.
The Web site for the preservation of the Borders Group, the country's second-largest book chain, goes live today at www.borders.com.

Divine Park rallied to beat the even-money favorite Commentator by two lengths in the $600,000 Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park on Monday. Divine Park, an improving 4-year-old, won for the sixth time in eight races. Commentator, bidding for a third straight victory, set a fast pace in the 115th running of the Met, the traditional Memorial Day feature, but could not hold off Divine Park, who came rolling down the center of the track.

Leslie Osborne, a midfielder on the United States women’s team, will miss the Olympics after tearing the anterior cruciate ligament in her left knee. Osborne was hurt during practice at Carson, Calif., on Thursday, according to the United States Soccer Federation. She will have knee surgery in the next week and will have reconstructive ankle surgery in about a month.
The Detroit Red Wings beat the visiting Pittsburgh Penguins, 3-0, to take a 2-0 lead in the Stanley Cup finals.

Ridouane Harroufi of Morocco burst ahead on the downhill leading to the finish line at Folsom Field to win the 10-kilometer Bolder Boulder in Colorado for the second consecutive year. Harroufi finished in 28 minutes 32 seconds, one second ahead of Dmessew Tsega of Ethiopia.
The surprising Marlins lead the National League East with a record of 30-20, and the Mets, a preseason favorite, are in fourth place at 23-26.

An article in some editions on May 17 about the killing of Kyung-Sook Woo, the owner of a dry-cleaning shop in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, referrred incorrectly to the length of her hair, which friends said she often did not curl until she was at work because she had risen so early to open the shop. Her hair was short, not long.

An article on Wednesday about cutbacks in airline service to American cities erroneously included a city among those where scheduled service disappeared in the last year. New Haven, Conn., does indeed have regularly scheduled service. (US Airways has flights at Tweed New Haven Regional Airport.) The article also described incorrectly Myrtle Beach DirectAir’s thrice-weekly service at Plattsburgh, N.Y. The airline offers service to South Carolina, not North Carolina.

An article on Saturday about Cindy McCain’s release of a summary of her 2006 income taxes misstated the greatest amount of income Senator Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, reported in the seven years of tax returns they have released. It was $4.2 million in 2007, not $1.7 million in 2005.

An article on Saturday about Michel Fournier, the retired French army officer with plans to sky dive from a balloon gondola 25 miles above the earth’s surface, misstated the point during his journey at which he expects to experience weightlessness, and it misstated the altitude at which his parachute was designed to open. He would experience weightlessness during descent, not while in the balloon’s gondola. And his parachute is designed to open at around 5,000 feet, not 20,000 feet.

Shaun Marcum won for the first time in four starts, Gregg Zaun hit a two-run homer and the Toronto Blue Jays beat visiting Kansas City, 7-2.

Bell Canada is appealing a court decision that withdrew approval for a $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of the company last week.

China Mobile lost more than $26 billion in market value in Hong Kong trading on Monday after the government said it would merge smaller operators to increase competition.
Following the announcement that it may face more losses from mortgage securities, the bank fell the most in more than two months in Swiss trading on Monday.

Criteria CaixaCorp agreed to buy 20 percent of Grupo Financiero Inbursa, a Mexico City bank, to tap into that country’s economic growth.

Gregory Echenique, one of the nation’s top high school centers, has signed a letter of intent to play for Rutgers. He is a Venezuelan native who starred at St. Benedict’s Prep in Newark. Rutgers also said that forward Jonathan Mitchell, Mr. New York Basketball 2006, would transfer from Florida.

Miami was selected as the top seed for the 64-team N.C.A.A. Division I baseball tournament. The Hurricanes (47-8), who won the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament for the first time, will host one of 16 double-elimination regionals that begin Friday. The other seeds, in order, are: North Carolina (46-12), Arizona State (45-11), Florida State (48-10), Cal State Fullerton (37-19), Rice (42-13), L.S.U. (43-16-1) and Georgia (35-21-1).

Virginia’s Somdev Devvarman became only the fourth player in the last 50 years to win consecutive N.C.A.A. men’s singles championships Monday by beating the Tennessee freshman J. P. Smith, 6-3, 6-2. Devvarman won the match in 61 minutes, joining Georgia’s Matias Boeker (2001-2) and Mikael Pernfors (1984-85), and Southern California’s Dennis Ralston (1963-64) as the only repeat champions in the past half-century.

DONDERO--Dr. Grace M., 59, of Lake Worth Florida, died Friday May 23, 2008. She was born February 28, 1949 in Brooklyn, New York to the late Henry A. and Grace L. Dr. Dondero earned a BS and MS from St. John's University and an Ed.D. in Education from Fordham University. She was a New York City Public School teacher for more than 20 years and a retired Associate Professor of Education at St. John's University. Grace received numerous awards for her commitment to Education, most recent, the Leadership in Education Award from the School of Education at St. John's University. Grace was the loving sister of Dr. Henry J. and sister-in-law of Barbara A.; cherished aunt and godmother to Henry M. and Jennifer G.; a lifelong teacher and a kind friend to many. Visitation will be held Wednesday, May 28, 2-5pm and 79pm at F.G. Guido Funeral Home, 440 Clinton St., Brooklyn, New York 11231. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Dr. Grace M. Dondero Endowed Scholarship, St. John's University, Utopia Parkway, Queens, NY, 11439.

LEBWORTH--M. Joseph, died on May 17, 2008 at the age of 86. Joe's heroism and service to his country in World War II will long be remembered. He parachuted into Normandy the night before D-Day as a member of the 101st Airborne Division and received serious leg injuries after 17 days of combat. He was subsequently awarded the Bronze Star, the Purple Heart, the Infantry Combat Badge and France's Liberation Medal. Joe devoted the last several decades to the two great passions in his life: his family, and especially his devoted wife of 46 years, Caral; and not-for-profit endeavors, particularly the Museum of Modern Art film department and his alma mater, Yale University. His loss will leave a great void, and he will be missed by his many friends and family members. We will especially miss Joe's smiling face, his curiosity about every facet of life, his astute political insights and his unfailing courage. He is survived by his wife, Caral; his three stepchildren Glenn Greenberg, Stephen Greenberg and Alva Greenberg; and ten grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Museum of Modern Art Film Department, 11 West 53 Street, NY, NY 10019-5497. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday May 28th at 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue.
