Michel Fournier, the retired French army officer who plans to fly a giant helium balloon a record 25 miles into the atmosphere and parachute down, postponed his attempt until Tuesday morning because of wind near the launch site in northern Saskatchewan. It was the second consecutive day weather caused Fournier to reschedule. On Monday, overcast skies before dawn delayed the launch by two hours. Shortly after 6 a.m., Fournier, 64, entered the balloon's gondola and began breathing pure oxygen for the next two hours in order to purge nitrogen from his body and reduce the risk of an embolism at high altitude. Meanwhile, winds increased to 12 miles per hour by 9 a.m., forcing cancellation of the launch.

Fidel Castro stepped aside as president of Cuba in February and has not been seen much since undergoing surgery in July 2006, but he is still very much a presence in the island nation he has turned over to his brother Raúl. He also is full of opinions, and on Monday he gave Senator Barack Obama an endorsement of sorts, calling him ''the most progressive candidate to the U.S. presidency'' while also berating him for his plan to continue the trade embargo against Cuba. ''Were I to defend him, I would do his adversaries an enormous favor,'' Mr. Castro said. ''I have therefore no reservations about criticizing him.''

TORNBERG--Edwin 82, owner of an East Coast Broadcasting Co., passed away May 23rd at his home in Potomac, MD after a long illness. He was Chairman of New World Radio Group, which owns and operates radio stations including WUST Washington and WNWR Philadelphia. Mr. Tornberg started in business brokerage and consulting in 1954. In 1957, Mr. Tornberg formed Edwin Tornberg and Co., Inc. specializing in brokerage, consulting and appraisal work for the banking, broadcasting and cable TV industries. His firm was based in NYC for 17 years, later moving to Washington. Illustrative clients included Bankers Trust, Bank of New York, Century Communications, Broadband Communications, New York Times Company, Nationwide Communications, Heftel Broadcasting Corp. and Wrather Corp., among others. Mr. Tornberg was in telecommunications since 1960. In addition to the stations he operated at the time of his death, he previously owned radio stations in Virginia, California, Kentucky, Oregon and Indiana and cable TV systems throughout the Western U.S. They were sold to Telecommunications, Inc. (NASD). Mr. Tornberg was regarded as something of a pioneer in the Washington radio-TV market as he went against conventional wisdom in 1992 by founding Washington's first exclusively multicultural broadcast station, WUST. The station broadcasts programs, many locally-originated, in as many as a dozen different languages to serve the needs of the Washington area's diverse population of diplomats, international civil servants and immigrants. After the success of WUST, Mr. Tornberg brought the concept to Philadelphia three years later with the purchase of WNWR, a 50,000 watt outlet which he converted to multilingual broadcasting. Mr. Tornberg recently retired as a director of Citizen's Communications Co., Stamford, CT, a NYSE-listed company. Edwin Joshua Tornberg was born in Plainfield, NJ and grew up in New Jersey and New York. He attended Stevens Institute of Technology and served in the US Army. He was a member of various broadcasting associations. Survivors include his wife Ina, of Potomac and Stuart, FL, son Donald (Sandy), brother Ralph, grandson Jayson, granddaughters, Alyssa and Samantha, stepsons Alan Hahn (Joan), Ronald Smith, Martin Smith (Linda), and Lawrence Smith (Lori), stepdaughter Alexandra Chesterton (David), five step-grandchildren and two step-greatgrandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife Chi-Chi, his first wife Shirley from whom he was divorced and their son Gary (Sharyn Tornberg Gold).

An exhibition of the work of more than a dozen photographers who captured the rock star Jimi Hendrix between 1967 and 1970 will open on Thursday at the Celebrity Vault gallery in Beverly Hills. The show, ''Hendrix Revealed: A Life through the Lens,'' was presented in London earlier this year and has been organized in association with Raj Prem Fine Art Photography in London. A portion of proceeds from the opening-day sales will benefit the nonprofit arts organization Experience Music Project, in Seattle, where Hendrix was born. Among the images on display will be Ed Caraeff's shot from the 1967 Monterey International Pop Music Festival of Hendrix setting fire to his Fender guitar.

Fort Tompkins, which dates to the 17th century and began to assume its current masonry form in 1807, was for decades a vital element in the defense of New York Harbor. In the 19th-century fortification on the north coast of Staten Island, opposing walls, the scarp and counterscarp, are faced with granite and have rifle slits in them, which enabled troops to create a cross-fire to fend off attackers in the ditch between the walls.

Tonight the 2008 Stanley Cup final makes its U.S. broadcast network debut, moving to NBC from the quiet niche of Versus. People walking around East Harlem and the Upper East Side this afternoon may have noticed black smoke billowing in the air, visible from quite a distance. On Tuesday night -- the first Tuesday in months that Fox has not had "American Idol" to lift it to the top of the ratings -- "Hell's Kitchen" did the trick instead, as 9.4 million viewers tuned in to the cooking competition at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. Although CBS's "NCIS" repeat earned slightly more total viewers at 8 p.m. (9.7 million), the Fox reality series remained far and away the night's leader among adults 18 to 49.

ELMONT, N.Y. -- The two-time Belmont Stakes winner Edgar Prado will ride undefeated Casino Drive in the test of the champion, Nobutaka Tada, racing manager for owner Hidetoshi Yamamot, announced Wednesday.

Alexander Hamilton's country home, the Grange, has been sitting on Convent Avenue and 141st Street for 119 years; long enough for neighbors to get well used to it. On Monday, however, it drew all kinds of astonished stares.

New York University has just started up a potentially important program called the Moral Courage Project, run by a spiky-haired dynamo named Irshad Manji (I've said more about her, as well as Ayaan Hirsi Ali, here). The program seeks to encourage and promote maverick scholars and writers who dissent from the orthodoxies of their own communities without giving up their particular identities or affiliations. Fittingly, its first speaker was the Sudanese scholar Abdullahi Ahmed An-Na'im, the author of a remarkable book, "Islam and the Secular State."

An important part of the Kyoto climate treaty allows rich-world countries to sponsor carbon-cutting projects in the developing world. The idea is to offset rich-world emissions and promote sustainable development where economies are growing fastest.

Updated, 5:26 p.m. | For years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has given its board members free passes to drive across its bridges and tunnels without paying tolls and to ride the subways, buses and commuter railroads without paying a fare. And when the board members retire, they are allowed to keep the passes for life.On Wednesday the authority said it will go to court to defend the practice in the face of a challenge by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, who said that giving E-ZPass tags to board members violates a law that they must serve without compensation.

Has anyone ever told you that you looked sad or tired when you weren't? If the problem isn't your mood, it might be your face, according to a study in the medical journal Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery.

The Wednesday pollution reading in Beijing reached "hazardous," the second-worst of the eight air quality categories used by the municipal government. The conditions in the capital evoked the spectre of event cancellations at the Games, which the International Olympic Committee promised it would do if the smog is too thick in August.

I rent a penthouse studio with a large terrace. There is major construction on the exterior of the building, making the terrace impossible to use. This was not a problem in January, when construction began and I wasn't using the terrace. But now that the weather is warming, they are telling me that they don't anticipate completion until July.

I've said it before, and I guess I'll continue to say it: I'm not a vegetarian. But sometimes a week will go by without any meat on my plate. My most recent meat-less week passed without much notice; it wasn't difficult, and it wasn't especially conscious. Here, though, is someone who's making it sound as it was as challenging as a week without solid food.

This Mediterranean leek salad combines a bunch of thinly sliced raw leeks with a quick vinaigrette and some tomatoes and cucumber. And it can be made more elaborate with the addition of a handful of chopped black olives, either oil-cured or a good variety like calamatas.

TV Week: After working at 20th Century Fox Television for 22 years, "Emmy Award-winning writer-producer David E. Kelley signed an exclusive three-year development and production deal with Warner Bros. Television," the company announced Tuesday. Mr. Kelley most recently developed the new drama "Life on Mars."

The shooting rampage that left seven people injured late Monday night reminded residents of Harlem's not-too-distant past, when gunshots were far more common in part because of the crack cocaine trade. The drug dealing ravaged the neighborhood in the late 1980s and 1990s, Timothy Williams and Christine Hauser report. And this week's events juxtaposed uneasily with the new Harlem: For a while early Tuesday, for example, yellow police tape was up outside a Starbucks on Lenox Avenue.

Not many Mets fans will miss Shea, with its shabby surroundings and leaky pipes and unimaginative design. And in all likelihood, not many will be sorry to see the current version of the Mets obliterated. After all, many of the same players who collaborated on one of the great collapses of all time last September are back at it again, playing lifeless baseball.

Names of the Dead.

The Sun-Times Media Group, the newspaper publisher once led by Conrad M. Black, won Canadian court approval of the settlement of a four-year dispute that will end control over the company by Hollinger Inc.
Bank of America plans to raise its stake in China Construction Bank to nearly 11 percent, by exercising an option it has to buy more common shares of the Beijing-based bank.
The Bank of Nova Scotia and the Bank of Montreal both reported lower second-quarter profit and warned that they were increasing provisions for credit losses.
The Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista, below, is planning a 5.59 billion real ($3.37 billion) initial public offering of OGX Petroleo e Gas Participacoes.

Mike Jarvis was introduced as the men’s basketball coach at Florida Atlantic, returning to run a program for the first time since St. John’s fired him six games into the 2003-4 season. University trustees must still approve the hiring, a process that now seems little more than a formality. Jarvis’s four-year deal will almost certainly become official Wednesday.
Lawyers for Roger Clemens responded to a two-month-old motion by his former trainer, Brian McNamee, that asked for the dismissal of a defamation lawsuit brought by Clemens.

A man who killed a convenience store owner was put to death in the first execution in Virginia in nearly two years. The man, Kevin Green, 31, left, was convicted of the 1998 killing of Patricia Vaughan. His execution was the third since the United States Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of lethal injection in April. The court on Tuesday refused to hear an appeal in Mr. Green’s case. Gov. Tim Kaine, a Democrat, also refused a clemency request based on the lawyers’ assertion that Mr. Green was mentally disabled.
Johan Santana did not overwhelm on Tuesday, but he lasted seven innings and eased the burdens on the Mets’ inconsistent offense as the team defeated the first-place Marlins.
A communications glitch kept the Phoenix lander from getting instructions for its second day on Mars, mission officials said.

The Philadelphia city government said it would fight a lawsuit by the local Boy Scouts organization that seeks to block the city’s efforts to evict it from rent-free premises because of alleged anti-gay policies. City officials say the policies violate a city ordinance and have told the Cradle of Liberty group to renounce its ban on gay Scouts, start paying $200,000 a year in rent or vacate its headquarters by May 31. “We are not going to subsidize the violation of our ordinance,” said Shelley Smith, the city solicitor. “It’s still our intention to take the legal action necessary to evict them.”.

Two Philadelphia police officers accused of beating a man they saw painting graffiti were charged with assault and falsifying records. Charges in the August attack come about three weeks after a videotaped beating of three suspects by a swarm of Philadelphia officers. The authorities say Officers Sheldon Fitzgerald and Howard Hill III broke the graffiti painter’s jaw on one side and dislocated it on the other before throwing him head first into the back of a patrol car. The man was never charged with a crime. “This is an unfortunate incident, but it is in no way a reflection on the entire department,” Police Commissioner Charles Ramsey said. District Attorney Lynne Abraham said her office completed its investigation into the attack this month.

A federal judge has refused to throw out a bribery indictment against a Democratic Louisiana congressman who argued that his alleged misdeeds were technically more akin to influence peddling than bribery. Judge T. S. Ellis III of Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., denied a motion filed by the congressman, William J. Jefferson, above, seeking dismissal of 15 of the 16 counts against him. Prosecutors accuse Mr. Jefferson of receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes in exchange for using his influence to broker business deals in Africa. Mr. Jefferson’s lawyer, Robert Trout, declined to comment.

Prosecutors have dropped the most serious charge against a teenager accused of plotting to blow up his school. Prosecutors said the student, Ryan Schallenberger, left, would not be charged with attempting to use a weapon of mass destruction, which carries a potential life sentence. Mr. Schallenberger, an 18-year-old senior at Chesterfield High School, has instead been indicted on three explosives charges that carry a combined maximum sentence of 40 years. Kevin McDonald, the acting United States attorney, would not give any specifics about why the most serious charge was dropped. Mr. Schallenberger was arrested April 19.
Josh Hamilton hit a grand slam and drove in five runs Tuesday to help Vicente Padilla and the visiting Texas Rangers to a 12-6 victory over the American League East-leading Rays.
Jay Bruce went 3 for 3 in his eagerly awaited debut Tuesday night and Adam Dunn hit a milestone three-run homer, leading the host Cincinnati Reds to a 9-6 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

The Jets signed the free-agent running back Musa Smith. Smith played the last five seasons for Baltimore, where he set career highs last year with 264 yards rushing and 27 catches for 192 yards. A former third-round pick out of Georgia, Smith adds depth behind Thomas Jones, Leon Washington and Jesse Chatman.

Congress expects to hold a hearing next month on thoroughbred racing, looking into horse safety and other issues after the death of Eight Belles. The Subcommittee on Commerce, Trade and Consumer Protection sent letters last week to several industry leaders, asking for their views on the sport.

Pocono Raceway is not for sale. Rose Mattioli said Tuesday that her family has no plans to sell the Nascar track, which has two Sprint Cup races. “It never was available; it never will be available,” said Mattioli, who owns the track with her husband, Joseph. Speedway Motorsports Inc. purchased Kentucky Speedway last week, and there was speculation the company’s owner, Bruton Smith, had his eye on Pocono. If he bought that track, he could have moved one or both of its race dates to any of his speedways.

The United States will face host China on Aug. 10 in the final game on the opening day of the Olympic men’s basketball tournament. FIBA announced the game times for the preliminary rounds of the men’s and women’s tournaments. Their Americans’ games are scheduled for either 8 p.m. or 10:15 p.m. local time. Beijing is 12 hours ahead of Eastern time. The United States women play a qualifier in their Aug. 9 opener then play China on Aug. 11 at 8 p.m.

Michelle Wie will make her first appearance in a full Ladies European Tour field at this week’s German Open. Wie, 18, was given a sponsor’s invitation to play in the event, which begins Thursday. A sore wrist in March and studies at Stanford have limited Wie to just two tournaments on the L.P.G.A. Tour this year. Wie, ranked 172nd, shot a practice round with Amy Yang, 18, of South Korea, the European Tour’s leading money earner.

The sport’s world governing body suspended its ban on international matches at high altitude, allowing Bolivia to host coming World Cup qualifiers at La Paz. FIFA’s executive committee also backed the objectives of Joseph S. Blatter, the FIFA president, regarding his plan to force professional clubs to field at least six players who are eligible to play for the national team of that club’s country.
Trinity College rallied for two runs in the ninth inning to take the N.C.A.A. Division III baseball title, after a loss earlier in the day broke its 44-game unbeaten streak.
The move raised the possibility that the Sunni bloc, known as Tawafiq, could extend what has already been a yearlong boycott of the Shiite-dominated government.
Nearly 40,000 military personnel have been given diagnoses of post-traumatic stress disorder since 2003, Pentagon records show.
Wall Street advanced in uneven trading after a decline in oil prices and an unexpected gain in new-home sales encouraged investors to put money back into the market.
Premature single births have been increasing in the United States, mostly among infants delivered by Caesarean section, researchers are reporting.
Dr. Stuhlinger was one of the most prominent of the Germans who brought their skills in rocket science to the United States after World War II.

The three presidential candidates warned the Sudanese government not to try to run out the clock on the Bush administration.
A measure asks residents to give the go-ahead to turn 496 acres into a neighborhood of homes, research and office buildings, retail space and a new stadium.
The crew aboard the International Space Station is working on a problem with the system for collecting solid and liquid waste.
JetBlue said that it would put off buying 21 new Airbus jetliners that it planned to receive starting next year for four to five years because of rising fuel costs.

While the number of hotel deals during the first quarter plummeted by more than 40 percent, some hotel industry experts see fire sales on the horizon.

Thomas Keller will be the president of the American team at next year’s Bocuse d’Or, a contest that is considered to be the Olympics of food.
The ex-girlfriend of the minister of foreign affairs, Maxime Bernier, was linked to Quebec’s motorcycle gangs, which have long attempted to infiltrate politics and the justice systems.
A small red berry called miracle fruit temporarily rewires the way the palate perceives sour flavors, rendering lemons as sweet as candy.

Out-of-context theater reviews in advertisements that make a theatrical turkey sound like the second coming of “Hamlet” are now subject to criminal prosecution in Britain, Variety has reported. Enacted in response to European Union regulations, a consumer protection law that took effect on Monday to combat misleading or aggressive marketing practices empowers prosecutors to defend the hoodwinked. The prosecutors must prove that theatergoers were misled. Guilty theater operators could be fined as much as $9,900 and sent to prison for two years.

The French architect Jean Nouvel has been selected to design a high-rise building that will strikingly alter the skyline in La Défense business district on the outskirts of Paris, officials announced on Tuesday. His project was chosen from among those of five finalists, among them Norman Foster and Daniel Libeskind. The building, dubbed the Signal Tower, is part of an ambitious plan to revitalize La Défense that was conceived in 2006 when Nicolas Sarkozy, who is now France’s president, led a public body dedicated to that goal. Patrick Devedjian, who succeeded him, said the tower would be the “most important architectural act since the Eiffel Tower.” Comprising four segments that resemble stacked cubes, the tower will have apartments on the upper floors, as well as a hotel, offices and a business plaza. (Above, an artist’s rendering of an interior view, and, right, of the tower, shown with the Grande Arche.) It is to be completed by 2015. Mr. Nouvel, who captured the Pritzker Prize, architecture’s top honor, this year, also designed the Quai Branly Museum in Paris, which opened in 2006, and is at work on a satellite of the Louvre Museum in Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates.

Cate Blanchett joined forces on Tuesday with prominent people in the arts to protest plans by the police to initiate an obscenity prosecution over images by Bill Henson, an eminent photographer, that feature nude 12- and 13-year-olds, Agence France-Presse reported. An open letter signed by Ms. Blanchett, who, with her husband, the playwright Andrew Upton, is a joint artistic director of the Sydney Theater Company, declared that the potential prosecution “does untold damage to our cultural reputation.” The signers included Elizabeth Ann Macgregor, director of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Sydney, and the writer Larissa Behrendt. Last week, responding to a complaint from a member of the public, the police raided and closed the Henson exhibition at the Roslyn Oxley9 Gallery in Sydney and seized 20 works. They said they were likely to bring charges in connection with the images, described by Prime Minister Kevin Rudd as “absolutely revolting.” All the signers of the protest letter took part last month in Canberra in Mr. Rudd’s national summit on future directions. The letter said that Mr. Henson’s “work itself is not pornographic, even though it includes depictions of naked human beings. It is more justly seen in a tradition of the nude in art that stretches back to the ancient Greeks, and which includes painters such as Caravaggio and Michelangelo.”.

Featuring 170 works, a $7.1 million museum dedicated to the Belgian Surrealist René Magritte is to open in Brussels on June 9, 2009, the director of Belgium’s fine arts museums, Michel Draguet, announced on Tuesday, Agence France-Presse reported. ... Al Jaffee, above, the veteran Mad magazine cartoonist, received the Reuben Award as cartoonist of the year at the National Cartoonists Society’s annual ceremony in New Orleans, according to the group’s Web site (reuben.org). Mr. Jaffee, 87, who lives in Manhattan, created the Mad Fold-In in 1964 and still draws it. He is also known for Mad’s “Snappy Answers to Stupid Questions.” Also nominated for the award, often called the profession’s top honor, were Dave Coverly, who draws “Speed Bump,” and Dan Piraro, who draws “Bizarro.” ... The Brooklyn Philharmonic, led by a guest conductor, George Garrett Keast, and featuring the violinist Tim Fain, will present a free concert in Central Park at 7:30 p.m. on June 24 as part of the 103rd season of the Naumburg Orchestral Concert Series. The performance, in the Naumburg Bandshell, will include works by Mozart, Stravinsky and Beethoven. ... Carl Reiner will be saluted by the National Yiddish Theater Folksbiene at a gala benefit concert on June 17 at Town Hall, where Brian Williams, a self-described Yiddish enthusiast, will serve as host, and featured guests will include Mary Tyler Moore, Theodore Bikel, Fyvush Finkel, Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara and Renée Taylor. ... Running from mid-January to mid-April, an exhibition devoted to the life of the Danish-American entertainer Victor Borge will be presented at Scandinavian House to commemorate the 100th anniversary of his birth.

Ratings were low all around for prime-time television over the Memorial Day holiday, as repeats on CBS ranked first on Monday, and Nascar coverage lifted Fox to No. 1 on Sunday. Opposite mostly low-rated repeats, Fox’s live broadcast of the annual Nascar All-Star race drew an average of more than seven million viewers from 7 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. One day later, on Monday, only reruns of CBS’s regular Monday lineup managed to earn more viewers. Led by “Two and a Half Men” at 9, the night’s most watched show with 10.7 million viewers, CBS easily outdrew its Monday competitors, ABC, NBC and Fox, which finished in a virtual tie for runner-up. ABC was closest, attracting 5.5 million viewers for “The Bachelorette” from 9 to 11. Meanwhile, NBC’s “American Gladiators” delivered 5.2 million viewers from 8 to 9:30, followed by a 90-minute edition of “Dateline,” which also earned 5.2 million viewers. Fox broadcast an encore of its two-hour “So You Think You Can Dance” premiere from 8 to 10 (4.9 million).

A monument featuring two men kissing was unveiled by Germany in Berlin on Tuesday in memory of thousands of homosexuals who were persecuted, tortured and killed by the Nazis, Agence France-Presse reported. Designed by the Danish-born Michael Elmgreen and the Norwegian-born Ingar Draset, both based in Berlin, the memorial, situated in the Tiergarten park, near the Brandenburg Gate and the Holocaust memorial, consists of a gray concrete slab about 13 feet high. Inside, at eye level, is a gap filled by a television screen that shows the kissing men, above. Bernd Neumann, Germany’s minister of culture, evoked the present when he said the monument was “also first and foremost an expression of our conviction that in our country there is no place for the discrimination of homosexuals, of people who think and live differently.” On hand for the unveiling was Berlin’s openly gay mayor, Klaus Wowereit, but no survivors. The last known survivor, Pierre Seel, died in November 2005. Homosexuality was illegal in Germany until 1969 and not formally decriminalized until 1994.

Diana Vishneva is injured and will not dance as scheduled in American Ballet Theater’s “Swan Lake” on Thursday night at Lincoln Center. (Her replacement, one of Ballet Theater’s other Russian stars, Nina Ananiashvili, will dance with Marcelo Gomes.) Ms. Vishneva’s manager, Sergei Danilian, said the dancer originally hurt her ankle in April, while performing with the Kirov Ballet during its New York season. Ms. Vishneva did dance a short solo, “The Dying Swan,” at Ballet Theater’s opening-night gala, but Mr. Danilian said that her injury has worsened. Kelly Ryan, a Ballet Theater spokeswoman, said that Ms. Vishneva would not appear in Twyla Tharp’s new “Rabbit and Rogue,” which opens next week. “We are hopeful that she will be able to perform in ‘Don Quixote’ on June 11, and in ‘Giselle’ on July 11,” Ms. Ryan said. In addition to her Ballet Theater commitments, Ms. Vishneva is scheduled to appear on June 15 in Moscow, at a gala arranged in honor of the Bolshoi ballerina Marina Semonova, and in St. Petersburg, Russia, on June 22 in her own show, “Beauty in Motion.”.

The Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista, below, is planning a 5.59 billion real ($3.37 billion) initial public offering of OGX Petroleo e Gas Participacoes, betting the country's recent oil finds will lure investors who snubbed other offerings this year. Mr. Batista founded Rio de Janeiro-based OGX less than a year ago. He paid $800 million in November to buy his first oil-exploration licenses off Brazil's coast. Francisco Gros, vice president of the OGX board and former chief executive, said in an interview April 4 that OGX might have oil reserves of 4.8 billion barrels, according to a study by DeGolyer and MacNaughton, an oil-reserve appraisal firm based in Dallas.

DONDERO--Dr. Grace M., 59, of Lake Worth Florida, died Friday May 23, 2008. She was born February 28, 1949 in Brooklyn, New York to the late Henry A. and Grace L. Dr. Dondero earned a BS and MS from St. John's University and an Ed.D. in Education from Fordham University. She was a New York City Public School teacher for more than 20 years and a retired Associate Professor of Education at St. John's University. Grace received numerous awards for her commitment to Education, most recent, the Leadership in Education Award from the School of Education at St. John's University. Grace was the loving sister of Dr. Henry J. and sister-in-law of Barbara A.; cherished aunt and godmother to Henry M. and Jennifer G.; a lifelong teacher and a kind friend to many. Visitation will be held Wednesday, May 28, 2-5pm and 79pm at F.G. Guido Funeral Home, 440 Clinton St., Brooklyn, New York 11231. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Sacred Heart-St. Stephen Church on Thursday, May 29 at 10:30am. Interment will follow at Calvary Cemetery in Woodside, Queens. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Dr. Grace M. Dondero Endowed Scholarship, St. John's University, Utopia Parkway, Queens, NY, 11439.

SAN ANTONIO A rivalry layered with big shots, big stars and tension that often stretches deep into May added a new chapter Tuesday night. A 3-pointer that went wide at the buzzer. An apparent foul that wasn't called. And a superstar with nerves of steel admitting to a minor anxiety attack. Kobe Bryant had reason to be nervous as San Antonio's Brent Barry took a bump from Derek Fisher and heaved a 3-pointer, while 18,797 people gasped and the final seconds ticked away at the AT&T Center. But the shot smacked into the backboard, the whistles all stayed silent and the Los Angeles Lakers giddily danced off the court with a 93-91 victory and full control of the Western Conference finals.

The political career of Mike Gravel came to a close on Sunday at the Libertarian Party convention in Denver. It was his second loss of a party's presidential nomination in one year. ''From 15 years old to now, my political career is over, and it's no big deal,'' Mr. Gravel said at the convention.

The French architectJean Nouvel has been selected to design a high-rise building that will strikingly alter the skyline in La Défense business district on the outskirts of Paris, officials announced on Tuesday. His project was chosen from among those of five finalists, among them Norman Foster and Daniel Libeskind. The building, dubbed the Signal Tower, is part of an ambitious plan to revitalize La Défense that was conceived in 2006 when Nicolas Sarkozy, who is now France's president, led a public body dedicated to that goal. Patrick Devedjian, who succeeded him, said the tower would be the ''most important architectural act since the Eiffel Tower.'' Comprising four segments that resemble stacked cubes, the tower will have apartments on the upper floors, as well as a hotel, offices and a business plaza. (Above, an artist's rendering of an interior view, and, right, of the tower, shown with the Grande Arche.) It is to be completed by 2015. Mr. Nouvel, who captured the Pritzker Prize, architecture's top honor, this year, also designed the Quai Branly Museum in Paris, which opened in 2006, and is at work on a satellite of the Louvre Museum in Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates.

Cate Blanchett joined forces on Tuesday with prominent people in the arts to protest plans by the police to initiate an obscenity prosecution over images by Bill Henson, an eminent photographer, that feature nude 12- and 13-year-olds, Agence France-Presse reported. An open letter signed by Ms. Blanchett, who, with her husband, the playwright Andrew Upton, is a joint artistic director of the Sydney Theater Company, declared that the potential prosecution ''does untold damage to our cultural reputation.'' The signers included Elizabeth Ann Macgregor, director of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Sydney, and the writer Larissa Behrendt. Last week, responding to a complaint from a member of the public, the police raided and closed the Henson exhibition at the Roslyn Oxley9 Gallery in Sydney and seized 20 works. They said they were likely to bring charges in connection with the images, described by Prime MinisterKevin Rudd as ''absolutely revolting.'' All the signers of the protest letter took part last month in Canberra in Mr. Rudd's national summit on future directions. The letter said that Mr. Henson's ''work itself is not pornographic, even though it includes depictions of naked human beings. It is more justly seen in a tradition of the nude in art that stretches back to the ancient Greeks, and which includes painters such as Caravaggio and Michelangelo.''

Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut is scheduled to speak in July at a conference in Washington sponsored by a group run by the Rev. John C. Hagee, the televangelist whose endorsement was rejected by Senator John McCain last week. Mr. McCain, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, rejected the support of Mr. Hagee, a prominent evangelical minister, saying several of his remarks were reprehensible. Mr. Hagee, bottom right, has said that God created Hurricane Katrina to punish New Orleans for its sins and that the Roman Catholic Church conspired with Hitler.

7 P.M. (HBO) DAVID McCULLOUGH: PAINTING WITH WORDS As an art student at Yale, David McCullough, above, planned to become a portraitist -- which he did, but not exactly as he imagined. Mr. McCullough has used words as his medium to create portraits of the American Revolution, the building of the Brooklyn Bridge and of the Panama Canal, the early years of Theodore Roosevelt and the presidency of Harry S. Truman. This documentary follows Mr. McCullough, a two-time winner of both the National Book Award and the Pulitzer Prize, as he speaks with state legislators, climbs a Philadelphia church steeple and takes his annual walk across the Brooklyn Bridge. The film also visits his home and peeks in on his relationship with his wife, Rosalee, whom he calls ''the star I steer by.'' 7:30 P.M. (21) LEAVING LONG ISLAND Part 2 of this three-episode, town-hall-style series searches for solutions to the exodus of young professionals from Nassau and Suffolk counties.

Sometimes Butoh, the outré, avant-garde dance movement that developed in mid-20th-century Japan, seems tailor made for New York. On Sunday night Pamela Herron of Vangeline Theater gave a free dance performance outside Chashama, at 217 East 42nd Street in Manhattan, before the Katsura Kan show ''Curious Fish,'' presented by Chashama and Vangeline. Barefoot and wearing black tulle, a pleatherlike tank and long gloves, with a ruff of black fabric pulled over her eyes like something out of a Rebecca Horn film, Ms. Herron undulated and grimaced, moving between ecstasy and the grotesque.

READER--Helen Charlotte Brown. After an eight year battle with Alzheimer's, Helen Charlotte Brown Reader, 89, died Tuesday afternoon May 20, at her home in Rye Brook, NY. She was born July 18, 1918 in Dover, New Hampshire and had lived in Rye, NY, for over 80 years. She received her B.A. from Cornell University and her M.A. from Columbia University. She taught world history and African studies in Port Chester Junior High School from 1965 to 1977. She was married for sixty-three years to Dr. George Gordon Reader, the former Livingston Farrand Prof. and Chairperson of the Department of Public Health at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University. He died in October of 2005. She is survived by her four sons, Jonathan W. Reader, Florham Park, NJ, David P. Reader, Port Chester, NY, Mark M. Reader, Haddonfield, NJ and Peter M.F. Reader, Maplewood, NJ and five grandchildren. She was a lifelong member of the Rye Presbyterian Church and the American Yacht Club. She was a member of the Rye Historical Society, the League of Women Voters, the Women's Club and the Daughters of the American Revolution. A memorial service will be held at the Rye Presbyterian Church on Saturday at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her honor to The Rye Free Reading Room, 1061 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580 or the Helen Charlotte Brown Scholarship in Women Studies, The Development Office, Drew University, 36 Madison Ave., Madison, NJ 07940.

LARKIN--Edith G., died peacefully on May 10th at her home in New York. Former wife of the late Frank Yoakum Larkin, she is survived by her four children; Barbara Franklin and Patricia Larkin of Washington DC, Frank Larkin of Brattleboro VT, Edith Hubbell of Norwich VT, seven grandchildren and three great - grandchildren. She is also survived by her sister Allison Caesar and her four sons, two half sisters, Joan Anderson and Maude Greer, a half brother, John Garver, and a cousin John Bennett. She graduated from the Brearley School and attended Vassar College and the Columbia School of Fine Arts. A professional actress, she appeared on Broadway in Lanford Wilson's Fifth of July, and many off Broadway plays and regional productions. She was a co-founder of the Hampton Theater Company in Quogue, L.I. and appeared in several of their productions. She was a past board member of the Terry Schreiber Studio and for several years participated in Book Pals, a literacy program for children, sponsored by the Screen Actors Guild. She was a longtime member of the Snarks, the Amateur Comedy Club, the Cosmopolitan Club, and the Players Club. A memorial service will be held on June 12, 2pm at St. George's Chapel, Rutherford Place, between 16th and 17th St, NYC.

Correction Appended Summer hadn't quite arrived in the city over the Memorial Day weekend, but in the garden of the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, on upper Fifth Avenue, it was several hundred degrees in the shade. Onstage in the Corning Museum GlassLab, four sweat-beaded men in black T-shirts rotated elongated rods -- tipped with molten glass hot enough to ignite anything it touched, whether metal, wood or flesh -- with the nonchalance of baton twirlers.

WILSON--Kendrick R., Jr., former Chairman of Avco Corporation and longtime resident of Darien, CT, died peacefully in his home in Vero Beach, FL on Sunday, May 11. He was 95. Loving husband of Katharine for 62 years and adoring father of Schuyler Field, Kendrick R. Wilson III, Holland Wilson and James Wilson. Known as XO to 10 grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren. A graduate of Exeter and Dartmouth, Phi Beta Kappa, Mr. Wilson also served in World War II as a Lieutenant Commander. Mr. Wilson was very personable and well known for his keen sense of humor and quick wit. Services will be held at St. Luke's Church in Darien, CT, June 4th, 2008, at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to St. Luke's Church, Darien, CT 06820 or Hospice of Indian River County, Vero Beach, FL 32963.

The Democratic National Committee Rules and Bylaws Committee will meet on Saturday in Washington, but the action will hardly be limited to the room where party leaders will debate the fates of the Florida and Michigan primaries. Supporters of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton are organizing to protest outside the meeting. ''They're coming up on buses, they're taking the train, they're Metro-ing, they're coming up with friends,'' said Allida Black, a professor at George Washington University and an event organizer. ''We're trying to flood it.''

CRAVER--John ''Jack'', 77, 2346 Bob White Lane, Lancaster, PA, died on Thursday, May 22nd at Lancaster General Hospital of respiratory failure. Born in New York City, his parents were the late Lloyd F. Craver, M.D. and Anna Sullivan Craver. He graduated from Horace Mann High School and then Cornell University with a Bachelor of Science in 1952. While attending the Hotel School at Cornell, Jack met his wife of 55 years, Elizabeth Libby Hunsberger Craver. With nearly 50 years of experience in the hospitality industry, Craver spent most of his career holding several executive-level management positions at lodging companies and properties throughout the United States, including The Mayflower Hotel (Washington, DC), The Plaza Hotel (New York City, NY), Host Enterprises (Lancaster, PA), Americana Hotels, and Horizon Hotels. He began his career with Hotel Corporation of America (later, Sonesta Hotels) at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York City from 1954-1960. He returned from 1971-1975 to serve as General Manager of Plaza Hotel. In 2002, The American Hotel & Lodging Association (AH&LA) presented him the prestigious Lawson A. Odde Award. The award recognizes individuals who make outstanding contributions to the lodging industry. At the presentation, AH&LA CEO Joseph A. McInerney stated ''I am delighted that were honoring Jack with one of our most treasured awards, he has been a devoted comrade to many in the hospitality industry and has provided inspiration for future leaders coming through the ranks.'' A former US Army lieutenant, Craver held leadership roles with volunteer organizations including Past President of the Cornell Hotel Society, Past President, Pennsylvania Travel Council, and the Skal Club of Central Pennsylvania. He was a member of Donegal Presbyterian Church, Mt. Joy and the church choir. He is survived by his beloved wife, Libby, son Jeffrey L. (Anne) Craver, M.D. of St. Louis, daughter Deborah A. Wolfe of Arizona, daughter Linda J. Bumsted of McLean, VA, son Scott F. (Jeannine) Craver of Catasauqua, PA and brother, William Craver, M.D. of Rochester, NY. He is also the beloved grandfather of six grandchildren: Mary Pat Craver, Kathryn Wolfe, Jenee Craver, Rachael Bumsted, Megan Craver, Jessica Bumsted, and one greatgrandchild, Lily May Clark. He was preceded in death by a sister, Anne Craver Sammons. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Jack Craver Memorial Scholarship for students of the Cornell Hotel School, 147 Statler Hall, Ithaca, NY www.lifecelebration.com

Looking through the counterscarp gallery at Fort Tompkins on Staten Island. In this 19th-century fortification, opposing walls, the scarp and counterscarp, are faced with granite and have rifle slits in them, enabling the fort's troops to create a cross-fire to fend off attackers in the ditch between the walls.

Diana Vishneva is injured and will not dance as scheduled in American Ballet Theater's ''Swan Lake'' on Thursday night at Lincoln Center. (Her replacement, one of Ballet Theater's other Russian stars, Nina Ananiashvili, will dance with Marcelo Gomes.) Ms. Vishneva's manager, Sergei Danilian, said the dancer originally hurt her ankle in April, while performing with the Kirov Ballet during its New York season. Ms. Vishneva did dance a short solo, ''The Dying Swan,'' at Ballet Theater's opening-night gala, but Mr. Danilian said that her injury has worsened. Kelly Ryan, a Ballet Theater spokeswoman, said that Ms. Vishneva would not appear in Twyla Tharp's new ''Rabbit and Rogue,'' which opens next week. ''We are hopeful that she will be able to perform in 'Don Quixote' on June 11, and in 'Giselle' on July 11,'' Ms. Ryan said. In addition to her Ballet Theater commitments, Ms. Vishneva is scheduled to appear on June 15 in Moscow, at a gala arranged in honor of the Bolshoi ballerina Marina Semonova, and in St. Petersburg, Russia, on June 22 in her own show, ''Beauty in Motion.''

ABC, CBS and NBC have agreed to set aside the same hour of prime-time television on the first Friday night in September for a live, joint telethon benefiting cancer research, representatives for the networks said in interviews. Among those who encouraged the networks to put aside their competitive instincts, albeit temporarily, was Katie Couric, anchor of the ''CBS Evening News,'' who will appear on the fund-raiser alongside her principal rivals, Brian Williams of NBC and Charles Gibson of ABC. All three have had immediate family members die of the disease, and another principal, Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC and Ms. Couric's former boss, is a colon cancer survivor. To publicize the benefit, which is being called Stand Up to Cancer, Ms. Couric will return on Wednesday to NBC's ''Today,'' the program she left in 2006 after more than a decade. (Her former partner, Matt Lauer, teased her return on Tuesday's program, coyly saying she was coming back to make a major announcement.) On ''Today,'' Ms. Couric will be joined by Mr. Gibson and Mr. Williams, who are also expected to appear with her on Wednesday on ''Good Morning America'' on ABC and ''The Early Show'' on CBS.

KOEPPEL--William Martin, 79 years very young. ''Yes, the women definitely stopped in their tracks for you Dad.'' On May 26, 2008 after a brief illness and horrific accident, he left us way too quickly but luckily without much pain. The funniest man I knew; always quick with a joke. ''You got a coff of cupee? Or a tettuce and lomato sandwich?'' A yachtsman, a pilot, a marine, a drummer, a Sinatra lover, an overly spoiling father to Lisa, a doting grandfather to Henry and Charlotte, a husband, a brother, an uncle, a son, a cousin and a true friend to so many including every waitress and mechanic in town. You will be missed every Sunday, every pool day and every Joe's stone crab dinner. Our lives will certainly be much quieter without you bossing us around. Services will be held May 29th 12pm at ''Schwartz Bros.'' (76th Rd. and Queens Blvd.) Forest Hills, NY.

CHASE--Randolph M., Jr., M.D. The Department of Medicine of the NYU Langone Medical Center is saddened by the passing of our longtime colleague, Dr. Randolph Chase, in his 80th year of life. A member of the faculty since 1964, Dr. Chase served with distinction until his retirement in 2005. One of the first African-American physicians on our faculty, Dr. Chase was a beloved physician and teacher. We extend our deep condolences to his wife, Claudia Dade Chase, M.D., and to the entire family. Martin J. Blaser, M.D., Chair, Department of Medicine NYU Langone Medical Center CHASE--Randolph M. Jr., MD of NYC died on May 16th, 2008 at the age of 79, after a long illness. Dr. Chase was Associate Professor of Medicine at NYU School of Medicine from 1970 to 2005. He is survived by his wife Claudia, children Mark, Lance, Amelia and Maya, grandchildren, a great-grandchild, former wife Anita, nieces, nephews, and in-laws. He will be remembered for his boundless care and concern for family, friends and patients. A memorial service will be held on May 30th at noon at the Riverside Church, Christ Chapel. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the National Medical Association.

A $200 million resort hotel does not exactly resemble a suburban home. But scratch the surface of the sales market for each property category, and they look remarkably similar today. The number of hotel deals in the United States during the first quarter plummeted by more than 40 percent, to 127. There is a gaping spread between what sellers are asking for hotels and what buyers are willing to pay. And lenders are writing much smaller mortgages at higher interest rates than they were a year ago.

Four words you don't want to hear in space: The toilet is broken. The crew aboard the International Space Station is working on a problem with the system for collecting solid and liquid waste, a trickier proposition without gravity. Space toilets use jets of fan-propelled air to guide waste into the proper container. A NASA status report noted that while using the toilet system last week, ''the crew heard a loud noise and the fan stopped working.'' The solid waste collector is functioning properly, but the system for collecting liquid waste is not. Nicole Cloutier-Lemasters, a NASA spokeswoman, said mission managers were considering plans to take replacement parts to the station on the next shuttle mission, scheduled to begin Saturday. In the meantime, she said, ''they're bypassing the troublesome hardware'' for urine collection with a ''special receptacle'' attached to the toilet.

President Bush ''convinces himself to believe what suits his needs at the moment,'' and has engaged in ''self-deception'' to justify his political ends, Scott McClellan, the former White House press secretary, writes in a critical new memoir about his years in the West Wing. In addition, Mr. McClellan writes, the decision to invade Iraq was a ''serious strategic blunder,'' and yet, in his view, it was not the biggest mistake the Bush White House made. That, he says, was ''a decision to turn away from candor and honesty when those qualities were most needed.''

7 P.M. (HBO) DAVID McCULLOUGH: PAINTING WITH WORDS As an art student at Yale, David McCullough, above, planned to become a portraitist -- which he did, but not exactly as he imagined. Mr. McCullough has used words as his medium to create portraits of the American Revolution, the building of the Brooklyn Bridge and of the Panama Canal, the early years of Theodore Roosevelt and the presidency of Harry S. Truman. This documentary follows Mr. McCullough, a two-time winner of both the National Book Award and the Pulitzer Prize, as he speaks with state legislators, climbs a Philadelphia church steeple and takes his annual walk across the Brooklyn Bridge. The film also visits his home and peeks in on his relationship with his wife, Rosalee, whom he calls ''the star I steer by.'' 7:30 P.M. (21) LEAVING LONG ISLAND Part 2 of this three-episode, town-hall-style series searches for solutions to the exodus of young professionals from Nassau and Suffolk counties.

Over the years the annual free concert on Memorial Day by the New York Philharmonic at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine has become a very meaningful holiday event for music-loving New Yorkers. Before the cathedral began its extensive renovations several years ago, it used to be possible for more than 2,500 people to attend these concerts. But renovation has caused the entire nave of the cathedral to be closed off with a wooden partition. So on Monday night, with David Robertson conducting two popular symphonies, Schubert's ''Unfinished'' and Mendelssohn's ''Italian,'' the Philharmonic performed in a constricted area, as it has for the past two Memorial Day concerts. The musicians were positioned on a makeshift platform in front of that temporary wall, and rows of seats for about 800 people extended almost up to the altar area.

DIAMOND--Walter H. Internationally recognized tax expert in foreign trade and investment. Author of 82 books. Devoted husband of Dorothy for 61 years. Service on Thursday, May 29th, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue and 81st Street. At home Friday 7-9pm.

The French architectJean Nouvel has been selected to design a high-rise building that will strikingly alter the skyline in La Défense business district on the outskirts of Paris, officials announced on Tuesday. His project was chosen from among those of five finalists, among them Norman Foster and Daniel Libeskind. The building, dubbed the Signal Tower, is part of an ambitious plan to revitalize La Défense that was conceived in 2006 when Nicolas Sarkozy, who is now France's president, led a public body dedicated to that goal. Patrick Devedjian, who succeeded him, said the tower would be the ''most important architectural act since the Eiffel Tower.'' Comprising four segments that resemble stacked cubes, the tower will have apartments on the upper floors, as well as a hotel, offices and a business plaza. (Above, an artist's rendering of an interior view, and, right, of the tower, shown with the Grande Arche.) It is to be completed by 2015. Mr. Nouvel, who captured the Pritzker Prize, architecture's top honor, this year, also designed the Quai Branly Museum in Paris, which opened in 2006, and is at work on a satellite of the Louvre Museum in Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates.

Out-of-context theater reviews in advertisements that make a theatrical turkey sound like the second coming of ''Hamlet'' are now subject to criminal prosecution in Britain, Variety has reported. Enacted in response to European Union regulations, a consumer protection law that took effect on Monday to combat misleading or aggressive marketing practices empowers prosecutors to defend the hoodwinked. The prosecutors must prove that theatergoers were misled. Guilty theater operators could be fined as much as $9,900 and sent to prison for two years.

BEATTIE--Charles, Ph.D., M.D., born in Louisville, KY on January 6, 1940, died at his home in Baltimore on May 25, 2008. He retired from the NYU School of Medicine in 2007 where he served as Executive Vice Chairman of the Department of Anesthesiology. Dr. Beattie was also Chairman of the Department of Anesthesiology at Vanderbilt and was on the faculty of the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Department of Anesthesiology and Critical Care Medicine where he served as interim chairman before going to Vanderbilt. He is survived by his wife Missy Comley Beattie and three children, John Charles Beattie, John Whitlow, and Hunter Beattie. The family requests donation to the National Parkinson Foundation.

His happiest times were being surrounded by his family and friends. He will be deeply missed but will live on in our hearts forever.

Updated, 5:50 p.m. | Consolidated Edison has sued New York City and a contractor, contending they contributed to the explosion of one of the utility's steam pipes in Midtown Manhattan last summer that killed one person, injured dozens of others and displaced thousands more.Con Edison alleged that a sealant used by Team Industrial Services, a contractor hired by the utility to prevent leaks, clogged steam traps designed to remove condensation from steam pipes. With the traps not working, water built up and helped trigger the explosion, according to the complaint, which was filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

Diptyque is an avant-garde, resolutely chic Parisian scent concern whose perfumes and candles push boundaries, take risks and generally form one of the most interesting collections in the world. Their brilliant Philosykos, created in 1996 for Diptyque by Olivia Giacobetti, is often credited with the late 1990s fig craze. Eau de Lierre is mesmerizing, Olene is wonderfully strange and L'Ombre dans l'Eau is not merely strange but bracingly rebarbative. Against the flood of focus-grouped syrup, the house has resolutely charted noncommercial, inaccessible territory and done it brilliantly. This is why the choice of its latest triptych of launches at first seems odd.

Social security is no longer the undisputed third rail of American politics. Israel, race and religion and the draft all earned the title in May, leaving readers bewildered and journalists struggling to keep their dark metaphors straight. For the sake of clarity, shall we rotate the title on a weekly basis? We'll kick it off with an unusual -- yet completely plausible -- nominee: the doughnut.

For the third time in under two months, the "CBS Evening News" received a record low rating among total viewers last week. The newscast saw an average of 5.33 million viewers for the week of May 19, eclipsing the record low of 5.39 million set the week of April 14.

Russia, bursting with wealth and pride, is on a huge roll in sports. Just this month in soccer, Zenit St. Petersburg won the UEFA Cup, Europe's second most important club competition, and Moscow played host to the European Champions League final, the top competition. In ice hockey this month, the national team won the world championship, and recently the national team retained the world championship in bandy too (bandy, possible Olympic demonstration sport in 2014). All this to go along with recent triumphs for Russians in tennis and, ahem, the Eurovision song contest, perhaps the most important championship of all:

To many experts in Spain, the "official" government housing statistics are a joke. Even though anyone involved in the property business can attest that prices have been sliding for the past year---and reports show the number of transactions dropping by more than 30 percent through the first part of 2008---government numbers still show prices rising, albeit not at the same pace as the go-go years of double-digit inflation.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will revoke free E-ZPass tags and free subway, bus and commuter rail passes it has given to its former board members, the authority announced on Thursday. Current board members of the authority will be allowed to keep the tags and passes, but they may use them only while traveling to or performing their official duties, such as attending meetings.

Last week in this space, I agonized over the issue of releasing the books in my Missing Manual series in electronic form. The issue had come up when two readers, claiming to be blind, asked for PDF copies -- and then wound up releasing them to piracy Web sites for all to download.
Very few auction notices that appear in my e-mail inbox catch my eye. Here's one that did: McQueen's Le Mans Porsche to be Auctioned.

The relatively positive press coverage that Senator Barack Obama enjoyed early in the campaign began to turn negative later in the primary season and references to the senator's "youth and inexperience" appear to be on the rise, according to a new study that examined media coverage of the presidential race.

More boys than girls died as a result of injuries in New York City from 2001 and 2006, and many more black children died than white or Hispanic ones, according to a report released by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg this morning in Brooklyn, the borough that logged the highest number of injury-related deaths among children.The report [pdf] focuses on deaths resulting from fire and scald burns from 2001 to 2006 of children ages 1 to 12. Nearly one-quarter of those deaths resulted from fires sparked by children who were playing with matches, candles or lighters, with 81 percent of those fires starting in a bedroom, most often the child's bedroom.

Even in the metropolis of incongruity, it's hard to say which is most remarkable: that polo games were played on fields out in New York Harbor until World War II; that they were free and open to the public, attracting the likes of young Carl Spielvogel from Greenpoint ("Greenpernt," he corrects himself); or that they are to resume - at least for one match.But let's cut to the news. Governors Island will reopen to the public on Saturday. At 3 p.m., a North American Polo League match is scheduled on the South Island fields between the Black Watch team, with Nacho Figueras as captain, and the Skeeterville team, with Will Johnston as captain. Admission to the island, passage on the ferry from the Battery Maritime Building and the game are all free.

CHICAGO - Senator Barack Obama was in "excellent health" at the time of his last examination more than a year ago, according to a letter released today by his physician, and has no known medical problems that would affect his ability to serve as president.
The mood on Wall Street has turned happy, or at least less worried. First quarter GDP was revised up, exports are strong and the stock market is rallying.

To me, there are two exquisitely interesting aspects to this post by Ed: one, the cake itself, and two, his insistence that the oven be set at 360 degrees. Surely, I asked him, this was a typo. His reply: "360 is the new 350. Really. 350 isn't a good temperature, and this cake wants to be nice and cooked. Just as 425 is the new 400."Alrighty then! --MB

Fruit-basket sellers, biotech companies, coffee-shop chains: They have all fallen victim to this year's chill in the market for initial public offerings. On Wednesday, Liberty Lane Acquisition joined the parade, electing to withdraw its public offering because of the oft-cited "market conditions."
As gentrification increases housing prices and racial tension in northeast Portland, Ore., the city is encouraging black and white residents to talk it out.
What we're looking at on the Web today...

There have been plenty of attacks in the last year or so on corporate boards' use of compensation consultants to help determine how much to pay "C-suite" executives. But at least one line of criticism -- focused on conflicts of interest -- may be overstated, according to a new academic study highlighted by Compliance Week magazine. The study, whose authors include a professor at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, found that while the use of compensation consultants generally does pump up executive pay, the size of the increase doesn't seem to be affected by other business ties between the consultant and the company.

After going through more than 200 entries from readers, the Lab judges have picked a winner in the Space Exploration Quiz. You can read about the quiz and see all the entries by clicking here. (You can also still take the 10-question online quiz yourself, or read full explanations of the 10 answers.)

I spent a few minutes Wednesday with F. Sherwood Rowland, the atmospheric chemist from the University of California, Irvine, who shared a Nobel Prize for his work revealing the threat to the ozone layer from CFC's and similar synthetic chemicals. He has a very sobering forecast for levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
First there were "Cops" on Fox. Soon there may be border patrol agents on ABC.

This cooling yogurt concoction from India is salad, relish, dip and side dish in one. The basic recipe here is usually not eaten as is but as the foundation for other raitas; there are infinite variations, and you can take them in almost any direction you like. And you don't need to employ raita in exclusively Indian ways. It is terrific as a dip for flatbread, or, when made extra thick, an alternative to potato salad or coleslaw.

Just in time for summer, Newsweek has weighed in with a list of the most-fattening ice cream flavors. In the past several years, ice creams have gotten more fattening than ever as premium brands like Häagen-Dazs and Ben & Jerry's load up their ice creams with chocolate-coated nuts, fudge-laden pretzels, decadent cake and brownie batters and even candy bars.

During his commencement address to Air Force Academy graduates on Wednesday, President Bush made a fairly uncontroversial declaration. "The war on terror," he said, "will dominate your military careers." But will it always have the same name?
The expression "New York minute" is taking on literal meaning with a contest that invites would-be directors to unleash their inner Joe Pyktas or Ridley Scotts and make commercials.

It's official: A majority of Bear Stearns shareholders on Thursday voted in favor of the securities firm's sale to JPMorgan Chase. The approval -- which was essentially a forgone conclusion, if only because JPMorgan already owned nearly half of Bear's stock -- clears the way for Bear to be subsumed into JPMorgan, ending its 85-year history as an independent entity. More than half of Bear's employees are expected to lose their jobs in the sale, which was hastily arranged in March to avoid a complete collapse of the firm.

After 52 years as one of the most heavily used branches of the New York Public Library system, the Donnell Library Center on West 53rd Street will mostly close at the end of this week. A small circulating collection will remain open, in the basement, through the end of August. Then the building will be razed to make way for an 11-story hotel. When the $220 million hotel opens, sometime around 2011, a new Donnell will occupy part of the first floor and an underground area, coexisting with hotel guests paying $750 to $2,000 per night for a room.

Despite putting up big numbers year after year since his breakthrough with the Yankees, Alfonso Soriano has had a tough time earning true superstar status. Maybe being traded for Alex Rodriguez had something to do with the high expectations over the years.

The euro-dollar exchange rate is a killer. No way around it. And no way not to have it affect your experience of every meal abroad, because unless you're made of money, you're gauging the quality of what you eat against what you paid for it. You're wondering if the enjoyment redeems the expenditure.
Los Angeles Times: "Spanish-language television network Azteca America is now producing its U.S. national and local Los Angeles newscasts from Mexico City."
In the wake of Eight Belles's death after the Kentucky Derby, the Rail had lively and useful discussion about where thoroughbred racing needed to go to insure safety for its athletes.
BAGHDAD -- Spring has come.

Gov. David A. Paterson has directed all state agencies to begin to revise their policies and regulations to recognize same-sex marriages performed in other jurisdictions, like Massachusetts, California and Canada, Jeremy W. Peters reports in a front-page story.

Questioning Question Time: George Will doesn't like John McCain's promise to answer questions as president in front of Congress in a British Parliament-style "Question Time." ("I will ask Congress to grant me the privilege of coming before both houses to take questions, and address criticism, much the same as the prime minister of Great Britain appears regularly before the House of Commons," McCain pledged.)

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who has declined to get in the middle of the nominating fight between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, made both a prediction and a promise about the race on Wednesday.

Bankers who arranged financing for last year's largest leveraged buyouts -- TXU and First Data -- are leaving their firms as the pace of takeovers slows, creating an opportunity for less established lenders to fund acquisitions, Bloomberg News reported.
"The Daily Show" is a bellwether for the evolution of Internet video. It is also one of those programs that signify for people why they pay so much money for cable.
Clear Channel Communications said on Wednesday that its $17.9 billion takeover by private equity funds THL Partners and Bain Capital is now fully funded in escrow with the Bank of New York.
Yahoo's chief executive, Jerry Yang, said on Wednesday a potential deal with Microsoft has "tremendous power," but the software giant appears no longer interested in a full merger.

This is Bear Stearns's last day on Earth. The shareholder meeting to approve the acquisition by JPMorgan Chase is at 10 a.m. I assume that immediately after the acquisition is approved, Bear will be merged out of existence as a public company.

Days after FIFA decided to suspend the Iraqi soccer federation for the government's "serious political interference" in sport, soccer's ruling authority reconsidered Thursday, lifting the ban and clearing the way for a crucial World Cup qualifier against Australia on Sunday.

Ontela, a Seattle-based startup that helps consumers move photos from their mobile phone to their computers for a monthly fee, has raised $10 million in a second round of funding.

An initial public offering of 10 million shares of Safe Bulkers, a Greek shipping company, was priced at $19 per share, a dollar below the low end of its target range, the underwriter said on Wednesday.

My Thursday column is about the threat of terrorism at the Beijing Olympics. Usually, Chinese officials downplay security threats, but these days there's an odd reversal. The Public Security Ministry keeps hyping the threat from Uighur terrorists, while foreigners keep saying it's over-stated. I must say that on the whole Uighurs didn't strike me as discontent as I had expected, certainly more content than Tibetans are and no more unhappy than when I first visited southern Xinjiang in 1993.

South Dakota, along with Montana, is going to have the Last Primary on Tuesday. When you live in a reliably red state with only 23 electoral votes and no real fund-raising potential, it takes being overlooked in the presidential races to a whole new level. The people here, like Hillary, can use a good moment.
Nicholas D. Kristof visits the Xinjiang region of western China and finds that local Uighurs don’t feel very Chinese despite being part of China.

If you want to see where dance is headed, start with Somewhere Out There, Movement Research’s spring festival.

For three quarters the Celtics looked absolutely magnificent, but they came ever so close to blowing a double-digit lead in the fourth before escaping with a victory.

The former star Roscoe Tanner has been arraigned on felony theft charges. According to the Knox County General Sessions Court, Tanner is accused of writing a $72,263.43 check to a Toyota dealership in Knoxville, Tenn., for two Highlanders and not returning them when the check bounced.

The eventing pony Theodore O’Connor was euthanized after an accident at the barn of the equestrians Karen and David O’Connor in northern Virginia. The O’Connors said in a statement that Theodore O’Connor, a 13-year-old gelding, bolted and slipped running back to the barn, severely cutting his hind leg and severing tendons and ligaments.

The jury deliberating the fate of the track coach Trevor Graham reached a verdict on one of three counts but was “hopelessly deadlocked” on the other two. Graham is charged with lying to investigators who were looking into steroid use in sports.
The Mets bucked the criticism that they don’t compete with ferocity when trailing in late innings by pulling off a come-from-behind victory in the 12th inning on Wednesday.
The Staten Island Democratic Party voted to endorse City Councilman Michael E. McMahon as its choice for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella, a Republican.
The Stanley Cup finals are suddenly competitive again after Sidney Crosby scored two goals on Wednesday night to give the Penguins a toehold.
A body was found wrapped in a comforter in a truck in Queens shortly before noon on Wednesday, the police said.
The Yankees avoided getting swept by the Orioles as Joba Chamberlain, who could take his turn in the rotation as soon as Monday, threw 28 pitches in relief.
Barack Obama said he was considering going to Iraq this summer, but dismissed an invitation from John McCain to take a joint trip.
Pedro Martínez allowed four hits and two runs in six innings against Vero Beach and pronounced himself ready for any assignment the Mets choose to give him.

An article in Business Day on Saturday about the adjustment by Americans to higher gasoline prices misstated, in some editions, the year of a car owned by Florian Bialas, who lives near Chicago and plans to begin walking to save money. It was a 1997 Pontiac Sunfire, not a 1987. (The Sunfire was not introduced until the 1995 model year.).

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Saturday about a gift to New York City parks from the Leon Levy Foundation referred incorrectly to a project for which the New York Botanical Garden received $15 million. It is to create a native plant garden for the study and display of Northeastern flora, not a native plant bed.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Wednesday about television ratings over the Memorial Day weekend misidentified the Nascar race that Fox showed Sunday night. It was the Coca-Cola 600, not the All-Star race. (That race was held May 17.).
The Quick Bite article on Sunday, about the Kent Coffee & Chocolate Company in Kent, Conn., gave an incorrect telephone number for the shop. It is (860) 927-1445.

A summary capsule on Wednesday for an article in The Arts about Daniel Evans, an actor who is the star of a Broadway revival of “Sunday in the Park With George” and is also studying philosophy, misidentified the university in New York where he recently attended a philosophy seminar. It was at the City University of New York Graduate Center, not New York University.

An article on Tuesday about the breaching of a dam on the Clark Fork River in Montana as part of a toxic waste cleanup misstated the reason that arsenic-laden waste is found in the river. The waste comes from naturally occurring arsenic in the ore minerals that have been mined in the area over the years; arsenic was not used by miners to separate metal from rock.

An article on Tuesday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s references to her husband’s 1992 race for the Democratic presidential nomination referred incorrectly to Paul E. Tsongas, one of his opponents that year. At the time Mr. Tsongas was running, he was a former senator from Massachusetts, not a sitting senator.

An article on Tuesday about the growing use of machines on upstate New York farms to replace lost migrant workers omitted a passage in some editions at the start of the continuation. The complete article is at nytimes.com/nyregion. The article also misspelled the given name of the United States senator from California who tried to attach a guest worker program to an Iraq spending bill. She is Dianne Feinstein, not Diane.
The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about inherited cancers, misstated a viral cause of certain cancers. It is human papillomavirus, not herpes papilloma virus.

An article on Monday about challenges to the tax-exempt status of nonprofit institutions referred incorrectly to an effort by local assessors to tax Smith College, arguing that as a women’s college it engaged in sex discrimination and thus was not charitable. That effort took place in the early 1980s, not recently, and the assessment involved an observatory owned by Smith in Whatley, Mass.; the assessors were not trying to tax the entire college, which is in Northampton.

Schedule information on Wednesday with a theater review of the plays in Series B of “Marathon 2008,” at the Ensemble Studio Theater on West 52nd Street, using information from the program, misstated the closing date. Series B runs through June 20, not this Saturday. (Series C will run from June 6 through June 28.).

Bucky Dent, a former Yankee infielder who played with Willie Randolph, told his old double-play partner to “trust your instincts and just keep doing what you’re doing.”
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg offered a bit of criticism of Senators Barack Obama, Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain.
Seven people, including two Customs and Border Protection officers accused of taking bribes, have been charged in a scheme to import drugs and contraband through Kennedy International Airport.

A new application process intended to simplify pre-kindergarten enrollment has left parents confused and angry about options for their children, New York City’s public advocate said.
Four men whose brutal beating of an off-duty police officer in the Bronx set in motion a series of events that led to his death were sentenced to prison terms of 5 to 10 years.

Farmers resumed their national strike after the government broke off talks over a controversial export tax.
President Nicolas Sarkozy announced that France would open its borders on July 1 to all workers from eight former Communist countries that joined the European Union four years ago.
The Czech Constitutional Court ruled that the government had the right to demand fees from patients using the health care system.
In an annual report on human rights worldwide, Amnesty International again urged the United States to close the Guantánamo Bay detention camp.
If all goes well, Moises Alou will return from his calf injury in San Diego on June 5, when he is eligible to return from the disabled list.
A Manhattan teenager has been charged with murder in the fatal shooting of a youth outside an Upper West Side apartment building.
