The Chicago Bulls rookie forward Joakim Noah accepted a deferred prosecution agreement in his marijuana possession case, resulting in six months’ probation and a $200 fine.

Marcus Smith has been named the president and general manager of Lowe’s Motor Speedway, replacing Humpy Wheeler. Smith’s father, Bruton Smith, who owns Speedway Motorsports Inc., made the announcement. Wheeler retired last week after 33 years of running Lowe’s in Concord, N.C.
Senators Joseph I. Lieberman and Lindsey Graham seemed to be in contravention of the McCain campaign’s conflict-of-interest rules.
As additional mergers in the airline industry look less likely, American carriers face a future of making further cuts to survive in an era of soaring jet-fuel prices.
Michael Iavarone has presented himself as a “high-profile investment banker,” but he has misstated his work history and has been fined for making unauthorized trades.
Portland, Ore., is encouraging black and white residents to talk about gentrification and race.
In Tuesday’s primary, Republicans should nominate Richard Zimmer for the Senate and Leonard Lance to run for the Representative seat.
The Supreme Court’s decision this week to uphold the rights of employees who charge discrimination is a welcome break from some of its recent rulings.
For all of its self serving, Scott McClellan’s book serves one good purpose: It is a reminder that we still don’t know how far President Bush waded in a “culture of deception.”
There has always been a sort of been-there, done-that sense about Phil Jackson’s career since he began collecting titles, but this year’s journey has been like no other.

Seeking a new trial, a defrocked priest in the sex abuse scandal among clergy members in the Boston Archdiocese is challenging what are called the repressed memories of his accuser. The former priest, Paul Shanley, is serving a sentence of 12 to 15 years in prison after being convicted in 2005 of repeatedly raping a boy at a Newton parish in the 1980s. In a motion for a new trial, Mr. Shanley said his former lawyer did not properly challenge the repressed memory evidence that helped convict him. The boy testified that he had repressed memories of the abuse until 2002, when they returned as the scandal gained publicity. A judge is expected to hear arguments on Mr. Shanley’s motion in Suffolk Superior Court on Thursday.

Gov. Ted Strickland has named the dean of the Ohio State University law school to serve temporarily as the state’s attorney general. The dean, Nancy Rogers, will replace Marc Dann, a Democrat, who resigned after complaints of sexual harassment and unprofessionalism, and an affair with a subordinate. Dean Rogers will lead the office for about six months but does not plan to run in the November election. Mr. Strickland, a Democrat, still must select a candidate to run for the remaining two years of Mr. Dann’s term.
The Mets’ general manager said the team based its decisions about how to handle Ryan Church’s concussion on regular consultations with Church and the team’s medical staff.
Scientists began releasing the robotic arm on NASA’s new Mars spacecraft, the Phoenix lander, one day late because of a radio problem.

Fourteen states have sued the Environmental Protection Agency, saying smog regulations issued in March watered-down standards for ground-level ozone and air pollution. The states — New York, California, Connecticut, Delaware, Illinois, Massachusetts, Maryland, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, Oregon, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island — were joined by New York City and the District of Columbia.
Francis S. Collins, who has led the National Human Genome Research Institute since 1993, will step down on Aug. 1.

A Tennessee woman who spent almost all of her life in an iron lung died after a power outage shut down the machine. The woman, Dianne Odell, 61, had been restricted to the machine after contracting polio at age 3. Her brother-in-law, Will Beyer, said family members were unable to start an emergency generator for the iron lung after a power outage at the family’s home near Jackson. In the late 1950s, iron lungs were largely replaced by ventilators that give users much more freedom of movement. But a spinal deformity from the polio kept Ms. Odell from wearing a more portable breathing device.

Senator Joseph I. Lieberman said that he would speak at a pro-Israel dinner organized by the Rev. John Hagee, who was spurned by Senator John McCain for saying that God sent Hitler to help Jews reach the Promised Land.

The Union County district attorney said the county would meet a federal judge’s deadline for a new trial in the case of a death row inmate whose trial was questioned by the United States Supreme Court. The state is facing a June 17 deadline to retry or free the inmate, Paul House, who has been in limbo since June 2006, when the Supreme Court concluded that reasonable jurors would not have convicted him had they seen the results of DNA tests from the 1990s. The district attorney, Paul Phillips, said he would not seek the death penalty. Mr. House, 46, who has multiple sclerosis and must use a wheelchair, was sentenced in the 1985 killing of Carolyn Muncey. He has been in a state prison since 1986 and continues to maintain his innocence.
Ahead of an expected W.T.O. ruling on subsides, European officials suggested this week that they would help finance the Airbus A350, the rival to the Boeing 787.
Mothers of children who were taken in the raid on a polygamist ranch in Texas have started speaking out more forcefully about the effects of separation on their children.
Companies have been building capacity to import natural gas, but much of it is idle as imports have fallen.
At the 2008 Robin Hood Foundation benefit, hedge fund managers donated $56.5 million to charity. But many of the market wizards are making less these days — and they are giving away less, too.
Using pumps so old that the meters go only as high as $3.99 a gallon, some service stations are pricing gasoline by the half-gallon.
More and more American celebrities are getting involved in auto racing — everyone from actors to Hall of Fame athletes to world champion boxers.
The United States, Canada, Russia, Norway and Denmark aimed to defuse tensions over the likelihood that global warming will open northern waters to shipping, energy extraction and other activities.
While many of the new breed of PGA Tour players recognize Jack Nicklaus and respect his accomplishments, there were 10 others who withdrew from the tournament he founded.
The beverage bottler Coca-Cola Enterprises said it expects second-quarter profit to fall by nearly 10 percent, citing the weak North American economy.
While Ian Kennedy will not be out long, it is not known where he will pitch when he returns, with Joba Chamberlain increasing his pitch count and Kennedy struggling.
Gov. David A. Paterson has directed all state agencies to begin to revise their policies and regulations to recognize same-sex marriages from other jurisdictions, like California and Canada.

The sheer volume of discarded items that have been sitting around gathering dust for years seemed to cast Nassau County in the role of the profligate old grandmother who had been piling up loot in the attic.
Stocks rose for a second day as a rebound in oil prices set off a late-day rally in energy shares, and a better-than-forecast report on durable goods orders lifted industrial companies.

The Museum at Bethel Woods will relive the hippies’ antiwar days of sex, drugs and rock ’n’ roll.

A love of graffiti has gained Steve Powers notoriety on the streets, fame in the art world and a long arrest sheet. It has also earned him a Fulbright scholarship.

Madonna’s adoption of David Banda, below, a Malawian boy she met in an orphanage in 2006, was approved by a judge in Malawi on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. Madonna did not appear in court for the ruling, which took Justice Andrew Nyirenda an hour to read. Justice Nyirenda said that he was satisfied that Madonna and her husband, Guy Ritchie, a British filmmaker, “are perfect parents.” Critics had accused Madonna of getting around Malawian adoption laws because she is a celebrity. David’s father said on Wednesday that he was glad the adoption was successful. The child’s mother died when he was a month old; he is now 2.
Paid attendance at Broadway shows, at 12.2 million, was down slightly from last season’s record of 12.3 million, according to a new report.

“Hell’s Kitchen” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday as 9.4 million viewers tuned in to that reality series cooking competition at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although CBS’s “NCIS” repeat earned slightly more total viewers at 8 p.m. (9.7 million), “Hell’s Kitchen” remained far and away the night’s leader among adults 18 to 49. Meanwhile, Fox’s “Moment of Truth” delivered the second-highest results in that demographic, despite garnering a modest audience of 7.3 million viewers at 8 p.m. Ratings for that game show, in which contestants are questioned after being strapped to a polygraph machine, were down three million viewers, compared with the last time it appeared on Fox’s schedule eight weeks ago (although the show had preceded “American Idol” then). CBS ranked second for the night in total viewers with a rerun of “The Unit” at 9 (6 million) and a “48 Hours” special at 10 (8.3 million). Among adults 18 to 49, CBS finished third behind Fox and NBC, which got a boost from repeats of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” at 9 (7.1 million) and at 10 (7.3 million). ABC was fourth over all.

Young@Heart, the chorus group of about two dozen elderly performers who cover the songs of an array of artists — James Brown, Coldplay, the Clash, the Bee Gees — are scheduled to play at the Beacon Theater in New York next month. Currently featured in the documentary “Young@Heart,” the group, which began in 1982 in a center for the elderly in Northampton, Mass., specializes in reinterpretations of rhythm and blues, rock and punk classics. Tickets to the concert, on June 22, are available through Ticketmaster and can also be purchased at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street.

The Munch Museum, which has the world’s largest collection of works by Edvard Munch, is moving across Oslo to a new building, near the futuristic new opera building, city officials said on Wednesday. Agence France-Presse reported the move in an article about plans for a cultural center that includes the museum. The center, which will include two museums and a library, is to be built on the banks of the Oslo Fjord behind the opera house. It is to be inaugurated in 2014 when Norway celebrates the 200th anniversary of the signing of its constitution. The Munch Museum was in the headlines in 2004 when ‘The Scream” and “Madonna” were stolen from it; they were retrieved two years later and went back on display last week.

Lyrics for the Amy Winehouse song “Love Is a Losing Game,” written with Mark Ronson, appeared on a final exam taken by English students at Cambridge University, the BBC reported. Students were told to compare Ms. Winehouse’s words with Billie Holiday’s song “Fine and Mellow,” Bob Dylan’s song “Boots of Spanish Leather” and the Walter Raleigh poem beginning, “As You Came From the Holy Land.” A university spokesman said that English students had always been asked to compare writers of different eras, according to the BBC.

Twenty-four outfits that defined the sartorial character of Tony Soprano, the mobster played by James Gandolfini on HBO, are on sale for charity, The Associated Press reported. Proceeds from the June 25 auction at Christie’s will go to the Wounded Warrior Project, a nonprofit group that assists soldiers severely wounded in Iraq or Afghanistan. The outfits, above, include the button-down blue shirt that Tony wore in the opening credits of “The Sopranos,” the bathrobe in which he collected the morning newspaper and the blood-splattered black-and-beige polo shirt, white tank top and black pants he wore when he was shot by Uncle Junior. Mr. Gandolfini’s wardrobe, which includes many items with the original production tags attached, is expected to fetch up to $36,000. His contract allowed him to keep the clothes after “The Sopranos” ended last year.

Three new albums take the top spots on the Billboard album chart this week. The rock band 3 Doors Down is at No. 1 with 154,000 sales of its self-titled new album on Universal, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Bun B of the long-running Texas rap duo UGK is No. 2 with his second solo record, “II Trill” (Rap-A-Lot/Asylum), with 98,000. (Bun B’s partner in UGK, Pimp C, died in December.) Third place goes to Julianne Hough, a 19-year-old country singer and “Dancing With the Stars” alumna; her self-titled debut on Mercury Nashville sold 67,000 copies. Last week’s No. 1, Death Cab for Cutie’s “Narrow Stairs” (Atlantic), slipped to No. 5 with 53,000 sales. Down the chart, Donna Summer’s first CD of new material in 17 years, “Crayons” (Burgundy), opened at No. 17 with 23,000.

Shakespeare’s crumbling grave marker at Holy Trinity Church in Stratford-upon-Avon, left, needs a makeover, The Associated Press reported. But the superstitious can exhale: Shakespeare’s remains would not be moved, so workers could avoid the curse on anyone who “moves my bones,” as the stone tablet’s inscription warns. Friends of Shakespeare’s Church hope to raise £4 million ($7.9 million) to restore the marker and other elements of the church, Josephine Walker, a spokeswoman for the group, said. The church, still used for worship, attracts 100,000 tourists a year, Ms. Walker said. Shakespeare was baptized at Holy Trinity on April 26, 1564, and buried there on April 25, 1616.

Golden Oldies, a company that has sold antique furniture and accessories to dealers, set designers and decorators for over 30 years, is cutting its inventory in half. Merchandise includes copper pots ($10 to $150), chandeliers ($600 to $4,000) and painted cupboards from the late 19th and early 20th centuries ($500 to $2,500). Cash and checks only. Golden Oldies, 132-29 33rd Avenue (College Point Boulevard), Flushing, Queens, (718) 445-4400. MARIANNE ROHRLICH.

STERN--Dov, 88 passed away on May 26. Beloved husband of Naomi, adored father of Danny Stern, stepfather to Barbara Manners, father-inlaw to Billy and Morgan, and cherished grandfather to Roni, Ofer, Eyal, Shir and David. His burial will be in Israel.

Utah Phillips, ''the Golden Voice of the Great Southwest,'' died on Friday at his home in Nevada City, Calif. He was 73. The cause was congestive heart failure, his family said in a statement.

DIAMOND--Walter H. Syracuse University and its Martin J. Whitman School of Management mourn the passing of friend, alumnus, world-renowned tax authority and economist, and primary authority on foreign trade zones and international tax treaties. His wisdom and expertise will be greatly missed.

ROSE--Jacques. It is with profound sadness that we acknowledge the passing of our friend and partner, with whom we had the pleasure of practicing law for more than 25 years. Jacques leaves behind a loving wife and devoted daughter, as well as a proud legacy of fighting for causes that he believed in. He will be missed. Robert Hartman David Ratner ROSE--Jacques F., on May 26, 2008. He is survived by his wife, Carol Ule, daughter, Nora, brother, Harvey, sister-inlaw, Sally and nephew Matthew. Services Friday at 11:15am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to NYS Tenants & Neighbors Information Service, 236 West 27th Street, NY, NY 10001.

LARKIN--Edith G., died peacefully on May 10th at her home in New York. Former wife of the late Frank Yoakum Larkin, she is survived by her four children; Barbara Franklin and Patricia Larkin of Washington DC, Frank Larkin of Brattleboro VT, Edith Hubbell of Norwich VT, seven grandchildren and three great - grandchildren. She is also survived by her sister Allison Caesar and her four sons, two half sisters, Joan Anderson and Maude Greer, a half brother, John Garver, and a cousin John Bennett. She graduated from the Brearley School and attended Vassar College and the Columbia School of Fine Arts. A professional actress, she appeared on Broadway in Lanford Wilson's Fifth of July, and many off Broadway plays and regional productions. She was a co-founder of the Hampton Theater Company in Quogue, L.I. and appeared in several of their productions. She was a past board member of the Terry Schreiber Studio and for several years participated in Book Pals, a literacy program for children, sponsored by the Screen Actors Guild. She was a longtime member of the Snarks, the Amateur Comedy Club, the Cosmopolitan Club, and the Players Club. A memorial service will be held on June 12, 2pm at St. George's Chapel, Rutherford Place, between 16th and 17th St, NYC.

CHASE--Randolph M. Jr., MD of NYC died on May 16th, 2008 at the age of 79, after a long illness. Dr. Chase was Associate Professor of Medicine at NYU School of Medicine from 1970 to 2005. He is survived by his wife Claudia, children Mark, Lance, Amelia and Maya, grandchildren, a great-grandchild, former wife Anita, nieces, nephews, and in-laws. He will be remembered for his boundless care and concern for family, friends and patients. A memorial service will be held on May 30th at noon at the Riverside Church, Christ Chapel. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the National Medical Association.

Survived by her sister Vera and her daughters Judith and Jane and their families (Richard, Christopher and Jason) (Bill, Justin and Michelle). Memorial to follow at a later date.

SINGER--Beatrice, died peacefully on May 28 at her home in White Plains. She is survived by her beloved husband of 60 years, Bernard, her children, Sheila and Martin Major, and Carol and Frank Huband, her grandchildren Sharon, Jonathan and Seth, her great-grandchildren Jacob and Joshua, and her sister Ruth Diller. An analysis by lawyers for the Democratic Party says party rules call for Florida and Michigan to lose at least half their delegate strength at the party's convention in August, an outcome that could close off Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's last opportunity to cut significantly into Senator Barack Obama's lead in delegates. The legal analysis, sent late Tuesday to the party's rules committee, is expected to guide a meeting this weekend where the committee will try to settle one of the most contentious issues remaining in the Democratic presidential race: what to do with delegates from Florida and Michigan, which violated party rules by moving up their primaries ahead of Feb. 5.

FRUIT--Chuck. The Board of Directors of the National Kidney Foundation (NKF) mourns the passing of a cherished volunteer, visionary leader and wonderful friend, Chuck Fruit, on May 27. Chuck's service on our board and as the NKF national Chairman was marked by numerous accomplishments and contributions. A highly respected marketing executive at The Coca-Cola Company, Chuck wholeheartedly applied his professional expertise to his NKF role by launching a major rebranding initiative and a national advertising campaign for the organization. His dedication, energy and business acumen enabled NKF to greatly expand vital early detection programs and services for kidney patients and their families. But beyond his achievements, we remember Chuck for his kindness, caring and thoughtfulness. We were fortunate to have had Chuck as such an integral part of our organization and know that his NKF legacy will live on for years to come. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Sharon and his entire family. We will miss you, Chuck.

POLLACK--Sydney. The Film Foundation joins the entertainment community in mourning the loss of Sydney Pollack. Mr. Pollack was a founding member of the board of directors of the foundation and was actively involved in its preservation and artists rights programs. ''Sydney was a leading light in the effort to protect and preserve film. He cared passionately about every aspect of the creative process and his love of movies and the people who make them was evident in his work as a director, a producer, and an actor. He will be sorely missed,'' said foundation chair, Martin Scorsese. Mr. Pollack joined Martin Scorsese, Woody Allen, Francis Ford Coppola, Stanley Kubrick, George Lucas, Robert Redford, and Steven Spielberg in creating The Film Foundation in 1990 to address the issue of film preservation. He remained deeply involved in the foundation's work, helping to advocate for preservation and filmmakers' rights. In 2000, Mr. Pollack received the ''John Huston Award for Artists Rights'' for his advocacy, including his 1987 testimony before a Senate Judiciary Committee against the alteration of motion pictures without the director's consent. An excerpt from Mr. Pollack's statement highlights his commitment: ''...Films are part of our cultural history. Like all accurate representations of who and what we were, they deserve preservation in their authentic form. Like a building, a photograph, or a document it helps locate us in time and gives us a sense of the geography of our lives. We need an accurate understanding of the past in order to point us accurately toward the future.'' The Film Foundation expresses its condolences to Mr. Pollack's family.

JUSTIN--Jane, after a long illness Jane died peacefully at her home. Jane had a unique personal style and sophistication that led her to a career in fashion. She blended classic fabrics with updated modern silhouettes and was known for her good ''eye in the industry.'' After graduating from The Parsons School of Design, she went on to many years of success and prominence in the fashion industry. Not finished yet she spent 12 years at Macy's as Vice President for Corporate Apparel Design. She is survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Barbara and Mark Handler. She was loving and generous to her niece Jody Cooper and husband Neal and to her nephew Jonathan Handler and his wife Cindy. She was a ''kvelling'', doting over the top ''grand-aunt'' to Lori, Caroline and Evie. She leaves behind her longtime companion and soulmate Les Suchman.

WERNER--Lesli E. Taken suddenly and too soon, in Queens, NY, January 2, 2008. She leaves behind Angelo, Bonnie, Barbara, Fran, and many dear friends and family. Memorial service Friday, May 30, 2008, Queens Botannical Gardens, Flushing, NY.

Besides his wife, he leaves five children: Thomas and his wife, Pamela, of Darien CT, Peter and his wife, Johanna, of Ardsley-on-Hudson NY, Mary Jane Marchisotto and her husband, Alan, of New York City, Philip and his wife, Kathleen, of Rochester, NY and Nancy Elia and her husband, Steve, of Summit NJ, and nine grandchildren. A funeral mass will be held today at 10:30am at St. Patrick Church, 32 E. Main St. Mystic, CT. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Edmunds Retreat Enders Island PO Box 399, Mystic, CT 06355.

POLLACK--Esther, beloved mother and grandmother. She is survived by her children and grandchildren, David and Liz, Ira and Marcia, Sharon and Corinne, Paul, Rachel, Jason, Adam, Sophia and Daniel. May her memory be for a blessing.

WROBEL--Eta. The American Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors and Decedents mourns the passing of Eta Wrobel. Eta was a fearless, feisty woman who led by example. Sole survivor of a family of twelve, Eta escaped deportation and a Nazi prison before becoming commander of a Jewish partisan group in the forests around her home town, Lukow, Poland. She began life anew in Brooklyn with devotion to family, Holocaust remembrance and support for Israel. Our condolences to her family. WROBEL--Eta. The Board of Directors and staff of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research mourn the passing of our dear friend, Eta Wrobel. As a Jewish partisan fighter in Nazi-occupied Poland, she showed remarkable courage and strength, carrying these qualities with her into her new life in America. Her dedication to YIVO, yidishkayt, Holocaust remembrance, and Israel was truly exemplary. Founding Chair of YIVO's International Women's Committee, she helped keep historical memory alive. Our profound condolences to her husband Henry and extended family. She will be sorely missed. May her memory be for a blessing. Bruce Slovin, Chairman Carl Rheins, Exec. Director

Keck Observatory, above, with the world's largest optical and infrared telescopes, where 13 telescopes in all, operated by astronomers from 11 countries, look farther into the universe than ever before. 7 P.M. (Sundance) RED DOORS (2005) In her feature-length debut, the director Georgia Lee humorously dissects a dysfunctional Chinese-American family whose three daughters go into a tailspin when their retired father checks into a Buddhist monastery.

INTERNATIONAL OLMERT AIMS TO STAY IN PLACE Despite Call for Resignation More straws landed upon the back of Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel as Ehud Barak, the Minister of Defense called for him to step down pending the outcome of his corruption inquest. Mr. Olmert refused, saying that he did not believe that he should step down simply because of an investigation. An official close to him said that Mr. Olmert did not want the political machine to trump the legal one, and believed it would become clear during the inquest that he had done nothing wrong. Page A10 THE GERMAN MILK PARTY? The Federation of European Dairy Farmers estimates that, on Wednesday alone, 10.6 million gallons of milk were dumped in a boycott by European dairy farmers. Why? While food prices have soared, the price of milk has not, in part because the European Union has raised quotas but not prices. As the price of milk fell, prices of fuel and feed rose. But cows keep producing and will sicken if not milked, so dairy farmers will keep working, and dumping, as long as the boycott lasts. Page A6 THE LAST DAYS OF NEPAL'S MONARCHY Nepal's 239-year-long monarchy neared its end, as a newly elected assembly told Gyanendra, king of Nepal, to step down from his throne in 15 days. The assembly is led by former Maoist guerrillas who emerged from the jungle after 10 years of war and traded gunplay for politics. They also demanded an end to the monarchy. Winning more than a third of Parliament's 601 seats, they hold a majority position and the party's leader is expected to take over as prime minister. Those suspected of remaining loyal to the monarchy have spoken by detonating small bombs in Katmandu. Page A8 SOUTH AFRICA WEIGHS SHELTER PLAN Waves of xenophobic violence have been visited against immigrants in South Africa, leading them to flee the impoverished squatter areas they had been living in. Relief organizations have proposed shelters intended as a temporary solution that could house as many as 70,000, but have been delayed pending a government decision. Doubts have been raised about South Africa's ability to run them, and international agencies fear that the camps could become rife with conflicts and sexual violence. Page A12 NATIONAL A PARTIAL PICTURE Of Carbon Footprints A new study by the Brookings Institution rating energy use showed, in general, smaller carbon footprints for the West Coast, with the Honolulu area ranked No. 1 followed by the area including Los Angeles and Orange Counties in California, the Portland-Vancouver area in the Northwest and the New York metropolitan area. At the bottom: a cluster of rust-belt urban areas including Cincinnati; Indianapolis; Lexington, Ky.; and Toledo, Ohio. PAGE A21 A PLAN FOR THE OCEANS With numerous projects being proposed for the waters off its shores, Massachusetts is now the first state to have a framework for a protection plan for its ocean waters. It sets ground rules for all offshore projects and businesses, including energy ventures and conservation areas that lie within three miles of the coast. PAGE A15 FINDING THE TABLES TURNED As President Bush's press secretary, Scott McClellan was part of the apparatus used by the White House to take on Mr. Bush's critics. Having departed that job, and with a new book that now casts him as one of those critics, Mr. McClellan is learning that the apparatus still functions without him. PAGE A14 CARE FOR THOSE WHO GIVE CARE The Army has begun to recognize that the war in Iraq is taking a toll not only on the troops, but also on those who counsel those troops, the chaplains. None have been killed, but some have been wounded, some in ways that cannot be seen. ''I've been really pushed to my limits and beyond,'' one said. ''At times, I've really wondered if I could get through.'' PAGE A19 SECT MOTHERS SPEAK OUT As the highest court in Texas prepares to rule on whether child welfare authorities had the right to take 468 children from a ranch early last month, the mothers are trying to make their case with the public by speaking out more forcefully about the harm they think the separation has already done to their children. PAGE A14 BUSINESS WITH FURTHER MERGERS UNLIKELY, Airlines Face Making Own Cuts Mergers other than the already-announced deal between Delta and Northwest seem unlikely, so airlines seeking to offset rising fuel prices are likely to cut costs, cut routes and park planes without the camouflage that a merger would have provided. And that means that the grumbling will come through unfiltered. PAGE C1 EXXON CHALLENGE DEFEATED Exxon Mobil's chairman and chief executive, Rex W. Tillerson, defeated a shareholder effort supported by many members of the Rockefeller family that would have divided the chairman and chief executive positions. The vote was at an annual meeting punctuated by a debate of the company's policy toward renewable energy and global warming and, though nonbinding, would have been a serious rebuke. PAGE C3 NATURAL GAS RISING LIKE GASOLINE A longstanding assumption of American energy policy -- that natural gas will be plentiful abroad, and therefore readily available for importation, as production falls off in North America -- is being challenged as the supertankers that were supposed to deliver cargoes of gas from Africa and the Middle East to the United States are taking them to places like Spain and Japan instead. PAGE C1 LIFE VALUES IN THE CORPORATE WORLD Students who join Stewart Friedman's management class at the Wharton business school commit to sharing intimate details with their classmates about their most important relationships. And though that may not sound like the stuff of business school education, Mr. Friedman and others have tapped into a desire by both students and established entrepreneurs for more integration of their careers and personal lives. PAGE C5 Strength in Durable Goods econ C4 METRO EXERCISER'S LOUD NOISES Lead to Assault Trial Stuart Sugarman adjusted the stationary bicycle for his frame, clicked his specialty cycling shoes into the pedals and, when spinning class started, began the most conspicuous part of his ritual: his loud noises. Christopher Carter, who was two bikes down, took issue with the noises. Now a trial in Manhattan Criminal Court is to determine whether what Mr. Carter did to stop Mr. Sugarman from making those noises qualifies as assault. PAGE A25 DEFENDING A PERK Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York says giving members of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board free E-ZPasses to drive across its bridges and tunnels without paying tolls, as well as passes to ride the subways, buses and commuter railroads without paying, violates a state law requiring that members serve without compensation. The authority disagrees, and plans to go to court to fight for the perk. PAGE A24 STYLES STILL TURNING A PROFIT In Fashion's Fast Lane One survey this month found more than half the respondents saying they planned to spend less on apparel; another found almost a third of people reporting ''severe anxiety'' about their personal finances. All of which can be good news, it seems, if you happen to be in the fast-fashion business. ''The least vulnerable brands now are the ones at the lower end of the luxury market and the upper end of the midtier market,'' one analyst said. PAGE E1 YOGA FOR THE MASSES The explosion in popularity of yoga has been good news for novices looking for classes -- there is seemingly one on every corner, and maybe another upstairs. But for the advanced student looking for something a little -- or a lot -- more challenging, the result is not so good. In seeking to be accessible to the many, classes become less desirable for the few. PAGE E10 FEEL THE STRETCH, AVOID THE MARK Various concoctions are marketing as being able to prevent stretch marks resulting from pregnancy. Can they? The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists says no. But the American Pregnancy Association suggests that women can reduce the probability of stretch marks (the key word being ''probability''). But be aware that genetics and race play a role in stretch marks, too. skin PAGE E3 NO ORDINARY JOE This sort of thing used to be reserved for wines, but beers have gotten into the act, along with single malt scotches. And so it follows that coffee tastings -- known to aficionados as cuppings -- now appear, at which the devoted might pay $20 each to taste three coffees, each from a different country. Take along a sophisticated palate if you want to pick up the hints of basil and jasmine. PAGE E6 SPORTS AT 17, READY TO RUN Against Sport's Elite Chanelle Price is a high school senior with some typical items on her to-do list this time of year: finish writing two papers, take two final exams. She also has one most unusual item: run the 800 meters at the Prefontaine Classic in Eugene, Ore., on June 8. From there, who knows, maybe the Olympics in Beijing. PAGE C12 WHEN IT WENT TO THE WIRE The occasion of this year's run at horse racing's Triple Crown cannot help calling forth memories of the last one, 30 years ago, when two outstanding horses not only faced off in each of the three races but also finished 1-2 in each of them. ''Seen through the current prism of fragile, transient champions, Affirmed and Alydar seem from another planet, another age, another breed,'' George Vecsey writes in Sports of The Times. PAGE C14 HOME FINDING AN ALTERNATIVE To That Chlorine Smell For those who want -- or have -- a swimming pool, but do not want the smell and possible other side effects of a chlorine sanitation system, other options exist. Pool installers may not tell you about them, and they are not cheap, but for some people they are a must. ''Our target audience is the person who shops at Whole Foods,'' said one installer. PAGE F1 PUTTING DOWN (SHALLOW) ROOTS Move often enough, Peter Moore says, and ''you realize quickly how you are burdened by your past, and so you become a ruthless editor.'' And Mr. Moore, an architect and developer, and his wife, Kathryn Lynch, a painter, have moved often enough. But they've been in the same place for three years now: the top floor of an 1890s brick warehouse on Washington Street. ''Our semipermanent home,'' he calls it. PAGE F5 Shopping for Newlyweds F4 OBITUARIES DAVID GAHR, 85 He turned his back on a promising career as a scholar to take pictures and listen to music and as a result landed among the pre-eminent photographers of American folk, blues, jazz and rock musicians of the 1960s and beyond. PAGE C11 SOPHIE B. ALTMAN, 95 In 1961 she started a television quiz show for precocious high school students, later added pep bands and cheerleaders and was as surprised as anybody when the show, ''It's Academic,'' became the world's longest-running quiz show. PAGE C11 ARTS ABC IN ANCHOR TALKS With Charles Gibson ABC passed over Charles Gibson in 2005 as anchor of ''World News,'' but events put him in the job anyway, success followed, and now he is in talks to stay there for the foreseeable future. Does he want to? ''I honestly don't know,'' he says. One person who must be anxiously waiting the outcome is Diane Sawyer, whose future probably is linked to the result. PAGE B1 AN ETHICS DISCLAIMER The media reporter (and sometimes ethics arbiter) Howard Kurtz invited Kimberly Dozier, the CBS journalist wounded in Iraq, onto his program on CNN on Sunday to talk about her memoir, ''Breathing the Fire.'' After the interview, he revealed that his wife had ''done some promotion work'' for the book. He and his employers see no problem with that. Some media ethicists do. PAGE B3 'LOST' LEADING THE LOST Even committed viewers of the ABC series ''Lost'' might be forgiven for not being able to follow every twist of its anarchic plot or not being aware of the relevance -- even the existence -- of the many obscure allusions made. And anyone who has looked even briefly at ''Lost'' blogs knows that some people are trying way too hard. Season Four concludes tonight. PAGE B1 Gliding Through Space B5 EDITORIAL IN DEFENSE OF WORKERS The Supreme Court upheld the rights of employees who charge age and race discrimination. Perhaps the justices realized that Americans want a court that does not stack the deck for the powerful. Or, they may simply be getting better at respecting precedent. PAGE A26 I KNEW IT ALL ALONG A new memoir by President Bush's former press secretary, Scott McClellan, could be named: ''I Knew It Was a Terrible Mistake, but I Didn't Mention It Until I Got a Book Contract.'' PAGE A26 NEW JERSEY PRIMARY CHOICES The Editorial Board endorses Frank Lautenberg for the Democratic Senate primary and former Representative Richard Zimmer for the Republican race. Republicans should pick Leonard Lance for the Seventh Congressional District. PAGE A26 OP-ED NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF Does Islamic terrorism threaten this year's Olympic Games? The Chinese authorities have warned of terror plots emanating from the mostly Muslim region of Xinjiang. On a trip to the ancient Silk Road oasis of Kashgar, signs abound of the authorities' anxiety about stability in China's Muslim west. PAGE A27 GAIL COLLINS South Dakota, along with Montana, is going to have the Last Primary on Tuesday. When you live in a reliably red state with only three electoral votes and no real fund-raising potential, it takes being overlooked in the presidential races to a whole new level. The people here, like Hillary, can use a good moment. PAGE A27

FOR mountain bikers, a new generation of hydration backpacks promises to let them have their water and their carrying capacity, too, all with almost no sign of a sweaty back. Improvements like ventilation channels in the back panel or designs that elevate packs off the rider's back allow perspiration-eliminating air to flow. And a cooler rider is one who can concentrate on the trail, said Ned Overend, a former professional mountain biker and an author of ''Mountain Bike Like a Champion.'' He added that some new models also carry loads well, which is paramount at high speeds, when a bouncing pack can throw a rider, and at slower paces, when subtle moves and precise balance are required.

After 14 years in the post, Leonard A. Lauderhas stepped down as chairman at the Whitney Museum of American Art. He remains a trustee and the chairman emeritus, with full voting rights. On Tuesday the Whitney board chose two people to share the chairman's job: Robert J. Hurst, who had been the museum's president, and Brooke Garber Neidich, a longtime trustee and a former vice chairwoman. Neil G. Bluhm, who had been a vice chairman with Ms. Neidich, is the Whitney's new president. Chuck Close, who became the first artist to become a Whitney trustee when he was elected in 2000, will leave the board. The artist Fred Wilson will join it. Mr. Lauder is a leading benefactor of the Whitney; in March he announced a $131 million donation by his art foundation, the biggest gift in the museum's history.

Nick Zito is considering a second entry in the Belmont with the Barbaro Stakes runner-up Da' Tara. He already plans to run Anak Nakal, the seventh-place finisher in the Kentucky Derby. Da' Tara had an encouraging work at Saratoga on Thursday, going a half in 49.67.

No one who has flown in the past year will be at all surprised to hear that in a recent survey by the University of Michigan, customers gave airline service the worst grades since 2001, with the industry's overall scores dropping for the third straight year. What I think all of us poor passengers are continually amazed at (or maybe it's just really disheartening) is how low the airlines are willing to go - and I'm not talking prices. First punctuality was all but eliminated, then food, then the pillows and blankets. I was recently charged on Air Canada for seat selection. Now American is charging not only for the second piece of luggage (as many airlines have already done) but for the first. Still, a recent short hop I took on Horizon Air set a new dismal standard for cost efficiency.

One sign that life in China is getting back to normal after the catastrophic earthquake in Sichuan is that the Olympics and Tibet are again attracting the world's attention - though it's hard to know what "normal" means in China these days.

Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Memorial Day celebrations, a makeover at the Empire State Building and Fleet Week festivities. Here are highlights from City Room and the most recent New York headlines.

The Sudanese Embassy in the United States has challenged a joint statement issued earlier this week by all three presidential candidates in which they blamed the government of Sudan for atrocities against civilians in Darfur.

In Tahiti, writing in his journal after having watched surfing for the first time, Capt. James Cook "could not help concluding that this man felt the most supreme pleasure while he was driven on so fast and so smoothly by the sea." Other newcomers to Polynesia in the 18th and 19th century -- explorers, traders, missionaries -- also noted the powerful effect surfing had on natives, particularly in Hawaii: entire villages stood empty during a good run of surf, island priests tried to conjure up better waves by thrashing the water with vines and chanting invocations, and the local mythology included tales of surfing-based romance, conquest and treachery.

On Tuesday, the state tax on cigarettes will rise by $1.25 a pack -- to $2.75 from $1.50 -- driving up the cost of a typical pack in New York City to around $8.50. The city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, which has waged a relentless campaign against smoking since 2002, is promoting that fact, telling smokers that they could save about $3,000 a year if they quit a pack-a-day habit. They could use that money, the city says, to buy season Major League Baseball tickets ($2,025), a quarter-carat diamond engagement ring ($2,799) or a 10-day Caribbean cruise ($1,750).
The upfront market for the broadcast networks to sell commercial time during their prime-time shows for the 2008-9 season may already be under way.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Friday that he strongly supported the idea of two-hour train service between New York and Washington contained in a bill cosponsored by Rep. John L. Mica of Florida, the ranking Republican on the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. The mayor made his statement after meeting with Mr. Mica.The legislation would require the secretary of transportation to solicit proposals for the financing, design, construction and operation of a high-speed rail system between the two cities, with the goal of "achieving less than two-hour express service." The proposal was described in The New York Sun today. Amtrak's Acela express trains currently make the trip in 2 hours 45 minutes.

President George W. Bush declines to commit the United States to fixed, binding targets on reducing emissions. But other major developed nations -- including those formerly led by climate change skeptics, like Australia -- regard tough regulatory action as the surest way to transform their energy systems. That's something that all three candidates for the U.S. presidency seem to agree on, too.

They ended up losing on a three-run homer by Adrian Gonzalez in the bottom of the 18th, but the ramifications of having to use so much of the team's pitching staff in a single game could end up outweighing the loss.

Gilfoyle and Helen Lefkowitz Horowitz, in association with the American Antiquarian Society.

Thursday's two-hour finale of "Lost" attracted 12.2 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, lifting ABC to No. 1 in the night's ratings. Although the show's fourth season conclusion drew 1.7 million viewers less than the final episode a year ago, it still easily led with the night with the highest ratings, outperforming Fox's "So You Think You Can Dance" from 8 to 10 p.m. (9.4 million).

It's been barely two years since former Representative Bob Barr of Georgia renounced the Republican party, after having made his name as the scathing orator who led Congress's campaign to impeach President Bill Clinton. "Let's do it!" was his passionate rallying cry.

Not so long ago, even rank amateurs pretended to be sound engineers when listening to jazz or Journey. Just like a real audiophile, you furrowed your brow over graphic equalizers and studied up on reference speakers and multi-CD changers. If your life was going to include a party or seduction, you needed a stereo - and your choice of equipment made a statement. Then the iPod and iTunes changed that; for all but the fanatics, they took the art out of playing music in the car or at home. And then came that unromantic iPod dock: no longer did your choice of Harman/Kardon or a scuffed boombox say anything about you except that that you were lugging around some antiquated junk. What a comedown. The old rarefied knowledge - and finesse with the levers and knobs and high-stacked component systems - suddenly seemed worthless.

Penguins defenseman Kris Letang was enjoying an off day on Wednesday when a call from his agent delivered the horrible news that Luc Bourdon, one of Letang's best friends, had been killed in a motorcycle accident.

Nepal's long path from monarchy to republic has come to this: an eviction notice for Gyanendra, the world's last Hindu king. He has two weeks to leave the palace. Luckily, he also has a private residence in Katmandu, above.
What do you dream about? Many readers of the Well blog apparently are dreaming about elevators.
From Jonathan D. Glater, a DealBook colleague:

Two students were arrested for trespassing at the Armed Forces recruiting station in Times Square today as part of a series of sit-in protests in the Northeast against the Pentagon's "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policy. About 20 people took part in the protest, organized by the Harvard Right to Serve Campaign; most left the scene when the police arrived.
He has juggling tricks no one else has. And 30-foot-high ceilings.

The "Punk: No One Is Innocent" museum exhibition in Vienna. Top: a banner on the Vienna Kunsthalle facade showing Soo Catwoman in a photograph by Ray Stevenson; the view of the punk exhibition. Above: Anja Frejya's portrait of Gudrun Gut in 1977 (Gut later co-founded Berlin post-punk band Malaria); punk merchandise for sale in the gift shop.
Boxing's biggest star yearns to be even bigger.

As more and more video is available on the Internet, one question moves sharply into focus: What will happen to cable and satellite television providers? Do we really need specialized networks for our TV, or will the Internet be enough once someone figures out an easy way to get Internet video onto our TV screens?

BRIEFS Abu Muqawama, an anonymous blogger we've mentioned several times in The Lede's posts on Iraq, has revealed himself as Andrew Exum, an Iraq War veteran and military scholar with a few New York Times op-eds under his belt. He also decided to hand the blog over to other contributors in order to pursue his academic work in Lebanon, not that everyone took him that seriously. "I figure it's a Jay-Z-style retirement," Spencer Ackerman, another blogger on security issues, wrote in response.

One argument we hear against synthetic tracks in the debate which has been raging long before Eight Belles is that they -- or at least some of them -- take the emphasis off early speed. In pulling his horses out of Del Mar, where last year's initial Polyseason featured slow times and an end to the speed bias which has been a part of the game in California for so long, his owner Ahmed Zayat said: "You need a surface that is both safe and maintains the integrity of racing. ... You can't take the speed out."
From Ed, a regular Bitten contributor. --MB
The frozen credit markets are thawing, at least for issuers with halfway decent credit.
Tuesday, May 27

The results of a very telling survey gauging interest among German adults in the Olympics vs. interest in the European Nations Football Championship are in. Surprisingly, Germans are about equally interested in both, even though Euro 2008 begins in June and the 2008 Beijing Games begin in August.

Updated Senator Hillary Clinton's campaign says that the Democratic party cannot award any of the "uncommitted" delegates from Michigan to any specific candidate, setting up a potentially major battle with the campaign of Senator Barack Obama.

Yes, it's a hit at the box office, but are the critics happy with the World Science Festival? Well, I liked what I've seen so far, and the the early reviews from my Times colleagues have been good, too. More reviews from Lab readers are welcome.

Neighbors chow down at the First Wednesday potluck club in Oakland, Calif. Read the full story, "The Supper Club," which will appear in this Sunday's Times Magazine. (Gillian Laub for The New York Times)
Mike Emrick was honored by the Devils during the 1998-99 season for his 2,000th pro hockey broadcast.

As the 58th FIFA congress draws to a close, the most controversial development was one that was entirely expected. By a vote of 155 to five, with 40 abstentions, soccer's governing body backed further discussion of Sepp Blatter's "6+5" plan limiting the number of foreign players on club teams.

Five months into a tough year for deal-making, a few statistics confirm what practitioners in the trenches already knew. The volume of announced mergers around the world is down from last year's heady levels: It declined about 35 percent through May 29 compared with the equivalent period in 2007, according to Dealogic's numbers. And the value of leveraged buyout deals has positively plunged, down 76 percent from a year ago.
Teddy Cruz's graphic analysis of the San Diego-Tijuana border (Estudio Teddy Cruz).
Workers at the site of the crane collapse on East 91st Street in Manhattan react to the accident.
What we're looking at on the Web today...
So Edgar Prado has the mount on Casino Drive, and he has won the Belmont and ruined previous Triple Crown bids. A solid choice for Casino Drive's jockey for sure.

Updated Democrats have been wrestling for months over whether to reconsider seating the large swath of delegates from Florida and Michigan. The party stripped them of their delegates because they broke party rules by leap-frogging over the Feb. 5 primary date set for most other states.

Calpine's rejection Friday of an unsolicited, $11 billion takeover offer from rival power generator NRG Energy wasn't exactly a shock. Calpine's shares have consistently traded about $1 above the value of NRG's all-stock offer since NRG's overture was made public two weeks ago.

Who doesn't love a good U.F.O. tale? As the city of Denver and the rest of the world await a local activist's proof of alien life -- footage of a living extraterrestrial -- City Councilman Charlie Brown is frowning. From The Rocky Mountain News:

Bjorn Lomborg, excoriated by some and lionized by others for being a best-selling promoter of free-market problem-solving, has teamed with eight leading economists and other experts in Copenhagen to produce a "Copenhagen Consensus" -- a menu for getting the most advancement of the human condition out of an extra (hypothetical) $75 billion over four years. Whichever of the above-mentioned groups you may be in, the resulting list of investments, sorted mainly through a cost-benefit analysis (a process some would reject out of hand), is worth exploring.

Recently in this space, Dwight Garner offered photographic evidence that Barack Obama has been working his way through Fareed Zakaria's new book, "The Post-American World," and wondered out loud what John McCain should read.
More of your "late night" jokes (send via the comment link below):

I'll never forget the first time I sat shotgun in a rally car. It was a 1999 Ford Focus WRC, driven by Thomas Radstrom, a snow specialist. While rally cars might not have the crazy horsepower of other top-level racecars, nothing can prepare you for the amount of low-end torque they have. The Focus WRC was equipped with a six-speed sequential gearbox, so the acceleration was just insane.

Mariano Duncan played under Joe Torre for two years with the Yankees and is now Torre's first base coach on the Los Angeles Dodgers. Duncan batted .340 in 1996 and helped the Yankees secure a World Series title. He also coined the phrase that the team wore on T-Shirts: "We play today, we win today. Dassit."

Geraldine Ferraro, who has been making headlines for months over what she contends is the sexist treatment of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in this presidential cycle, has penned an Op-Ed in the Boston Globe.
In his column today, Carl Hulse writes Democrats have been encouraged to emphasize the veterans education program developed by Senator James Webb of Virginia as a political rallying cry this summer.

New York is a tough town to open a show in, but the World Science Festival already looks like a smash. The first day's events were sold out on Thursday. Of the 46 events in the four-day festival, all but five are either sold out or virtually sold out (meaning there are a few single tickets left), says Adam Pockriss, a spokesman for the festival.
He put the 'Gomez' in Gomez Inc., but now an Internet entrepreneur finds himself relegated to the fine print.
Saul Zabar, the president and co-owner of the Upper West Side’s culinary epicenter, discusses his reluctant path into the family business.

The stretch of Stillwell Avenue between Surf Avenue and the Boardwalk, like most of Coney Island, has seen a lot of change over the years. Once home to amusements like Stauch's Baths (featured prominently in "The Warriors") and the Tornado and Bobsled roller coasters, the street emptied over the years as attractions burned down or went out of business, and property owners bulldozed land for redevelopment that never materialized.

Earlier this week, passengers with tickets on US Airways learned there would be no more pretzels and peanuts on domestic flights. On Friday, the airline's employees were told that there's no merger rolling down the aisle either.

37 Days to L'Etape. On the training schedule: last night after work I did a one-hour recovery ride of light intensity (that following a one-hour session of intense interval training the night before, overseen by my coach, with the bike on an indoor trainer hooked up to a machine that allowed me to gauge the power in watts of every pedal stroke).

Ray Paulick, the former editor and chief of The Blood-Horse, has a good column about Japanese horse racing on ESPN.com. He says no on should be surprised that Casino Drive is here for the Belmont Stakes and, in fact, we should be prepared for the colt to win.
A different kind of eggplant salad in every way, from cooking method to seasoning.
Nathaniel Rich is an editor at The Paris Review. His first novel, "The Mayor's Tongue," was published this spring.

As part of the blog he did about his (successful) attempt to ride L'Etape last summer, Matt Smith, the Web master at Cervelo, was filmed by the bike manufacturer's videographer. So those of you who want to get a better handle on just what it looks like when 8,000 amateurs pit themselves against a mountain stage of the Tour de France, can check out the video of Matt's ride in the 2007 edition of L'Etape.
Greetings from Beaune, center of the Burgundy wine region, where I've been touring about for the last few days.

There's been a lot of chatter in blogville about the merits of Jim Webb, the Democratic senator from Virginia, as Barack Obama's running mate: antiwar, veteran, Reagan Democrat. Ezra Klein of the American Prospect understands Webb's appeal, but he also thinks Webb would be the wrong choice.

Gov. David A. Paterson discusses how he arrived at his stance on gay rights in an interview with Jeremy Peters and Danny Hakim.
