Reuters: "A consortium including NBC Universal and Blackstone Group bidding for the Weather Channel is offering about $1.8 billion in equity for their bid, or roughly half the total offer, a source familiar with the matter said."
Iraqi women answer questions from readers.

In his new memoir, "What Happened," Scott McClellan, the former White House press secretary, said the national news media neglected their watchdog role in the run-up to the invasion of Iraq, calling reporters "complicit enablers" of the Bush administration's push for war.
Gas prices, apparently, are still not high enough to convince some people to get out of their cars, according to a new Commuter Pain Survey released by I.B.M. Friday.

Sapphire Energy, which says it's producing the chemical equivalent of gasoline from algae, has come out of stealth mode, announcing that it raised $50 million from ARCH Venture Partners, Venrock, and the Wellcome Trust.
New York City's financial sector might only slice 15,000 to 25,000 jobs in the current downturn, which could prove shorter than the mayor has predicted, the city comptroller said on Thursday.

Updated, 7:40 p.m. | The city's Office of Emergency Management has provided an update about the deadly crane collapse on the Upper East Side. City officials have confirmed that two construction workers were killed in the 8 a.m. collapse, at East 91st Street and First Avenue, and that two other people were injured. A total of eight buildings with 212 apartments were evacuated for much of the day, but residents and businesses were being allowed to return this evening to all but the most heavily damaged building, 354 East 91st Street.
United Airlines told US Airways on Thursday that it had decided not to continue talks on a possible merger, The New York Times reported.

As economic issues have come to dominate the national dialogue over the last few months, the war in Iraq has taken a backseat. But on the campaign trail in recent days, Senator John McCain has been sounding foreign policy and national security themes, and hitting Senator Barack Obama hard on Iraq.

LAS VEGAS -- The governor of the state made famous in part for its quick, private divorces is now embroiled in a breakup so tawdry, so publicly spectacular and so potentially grueling that how it plays out could have implications from Carson City to the White House.

The reviews for the new "Sex and the City" flick are less than ecstatic, so you could do worse than this TV Land parody with Bea Arthur and Sally Struthers from a few years back. Here's Metamucil in your Cosmopolitan!
Who needs "Sex and the City" anyway? Relinquish your panties for a cause (well, a different cause). From the Canadian Press:

John F. Marshall spent decades teaching at business schools and watching his students parlay his lessons into fortunes on Wall Street. But when he and another professor reached for some of those riches themselves, events took a startling turn, the authorities say.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned Thursday that the nation's ailing banking industry was likely to weaken further. The F.D.I.C. said the combined profit of the financial institutions it regulates plunged 46 percent, to $19.3 billion, during the first three months of the year.

The effectiveness of hedges against mortgage- and credit-related losses will be a major focus as investment banks such as Lehman Brothers, Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs report quarterly results in coming weeks, analysts say. MarketWatch reports that some hedging strategies have been showing cracks, raising concerns about more write-downs on top of an already weak environment for big brokerages.

Harvey Korman, the comedic actor who rose to fame playing second banana to Carol Burnett on her TV variety series and who starred in hit movies like "Blazing Saddles" and "High Anxiety," died on Thursday at 81. One of his favorite roles was the dastardly Hedley Lamarr in Mel Brooks's "Blazing Saddles" from 1974:

Microsoft and Yahoo seem to hang out in all the same places but somehow keep missing each other. That's turned speculation over what it will take to get the two of them together into something of a C.E.O. parlor game.
A banker indicted in a tax inquiry of the Swiss giant UBS is expected to enter a guilty plea next month and cooperate with investigators.
Goldman Sachs usually doesn't have trouble taking its clients public.

The Sears Holdings Corporation, the parent of Sears and Kmart, reported an unexpected $56 million first-quarter loss on Thursday, dealing another setback to Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire hedge fund manager who has struggled to turn the company around.

Sopogy, a small-scale solar thermal start-up, has closed a $9.1 million round from investors including the investment vehicle of eBay founder Pierre Omidyar, Ohana Holdings, New Energy Finance reported.

Under a new deal to bring that Margaritaville flavor further north, those living in the Northeast may now only have to travel as far as the Jersey Shore to find Jimmy Buffett blowing out his flip flop or searching for that lost shaker of salt.

Tommy Gahan, who helped build Deutsche Bank's securities business in the United States, is in discussions to join Providence Equity Partners, a private equity firm that specializes in media and telecommunications deals, The New York Post reported.

Deutsche Bank's chief executive, Josef Ackermann, said his firm is considering the possibility of a "multi-year" bonus system, where less would depend on an employee's performance in the previous 12 months. The move comes amid mounting criticism of a bonus culture at investment banks that some say encourages excessive risk-taking.

French judges have filed preliminary charges of insider trading against Noël Forgeard, the former co-chief executive of European Aeronautic Defense and Space, Europe's largest aerospace group, his lawyer said Friday. The charges relate to delays in the program to build the A380 superjumbo.

Faced with enormous political pressure to tighten the oversight of energy trading, federal regulators said Thursday that they have been investigating oil and derivative markets for six months to look into potential price manipulation.
Noble Environmental Power's planned initial public offering brings "good news and bad news" for investors interested in the alternative energy sector, according to TheStreet.com.

UPDATED 5/30, 8:45 AM After I wrote about Google's spat with an advertising trade group over the company's refusal to put a link to its privacy policy on the home page of Google.com, I discovered that there is actually a California law on the subject.
Two Russian metals tycoons, Vladimir O. Potanin and Alisher B. Usmanov, are moving to merge their companies with the goal of creating the world's largest mining concern.

Norway's $400 billion oil fund is close to owning more than 1 percent of the entire European stock market as it takes advantage of market turmoil to buy more equities, and has set up a division that will seek larger stakes in companies, similar to a private equity investor.
The Man Group posted a 60 percent gain in earnings last year, but said it is losing the man that helped turn it into the world's largest publicly traded hedge fund manager.
Belon Group, a Russian coal mining company, is planning to float at least 15 percent of its shares on the London Stock Exchange in the second half of 2009, a business daily reported on Friday.
Origin Energy of Australia rejected on Friday a revised $13 billion takeover bid from the British gas producer BG Group and upped the ante by doubling its own gas reserves estimate.

Several journalists I really respect (Pat Jordan, Dan Shaughnessy, Selena Roberts) have written or talked lately about shrinking access to players. I won't pretend to know what it was like before I started in this business, in 1990, but in the role of beat writer, I rarely end the day thinking I did not have enough access.
Six months after a deal to sell its European operations fell through, Quebecor World has found another buyer for the assets, but at a much lower price than initially sought.

Right now, Bill Turner is the only living trainer of a Triple Crown winner. His horse, the great Seattle Slew, was undefeated in nine races, a streak that ended with his Belmont Stakes win in 1977. Bill might lose that distinction June 7, if Big Brown takes the Belmont, but for now the reporters are still dropping by his barn in the mornings, asking whether he thinks Big Brown will win, or just collecting memories of that past Triple Crown campaign.
Grants approved in 2007 under the Suffolk County Legislature’s Community Support Initiative Program.
Illustrations by Ardeshir Mohassess at the Asia Society. Karen Rosenberg reviews.
Grants approved in 2007 under the Nassau County Legislature’s Community Revitalization Program.
Markets may be slowing around the world, but there are still signs of life in the Caribbean.
Triple champion Rafael Nadal, playing for the fourth day running in the rain-hit tournament, can look forward to a rest day at last after he crushed Finn Jarkko Nieminen 6-1 6-3 6-1.
USA’s new series featuring a hardboiled-but-dedicated babe with a badge follows all the clichés of the genre but knows it and will find ways to twist the formula in novel, interesting ways.
Just when “Bigger, Stronger, Faster*” seems content to be an entertaining exploration of the use of anabolic steroids, it turns a corner and plunges into deeper waters.

I'm still on the road (just talked at the Trento Festival in Italy, Barcelona next) -- and mysteriously unable to post images to this blog. But I have a bit more time now. I assume that most readers have gotten over their Two Minutes Hate; anyway, I expect to be posting a few pieces about economics over the weekend.
The U.S. women's softball team goes for the gold in what could be its last Olympic campaign.

The gala presentation of “Michelangelo: La Dotta Mano” (“Michelangelo: The Wise Hand”), a volume of photographs of this Renaissance master’s sculptures, may well have been the most lavish book debut in history.
The Olympians are playing local all-stars on a nationwide tour.
I was an admirer of Ken Burns's Civil War documentary, shown on PBS in 1990. As the last program wound down, I remember thinking: How will he put a bow on it -- and do the series justice?
As the Wing Luke Asian Museum reopens in Seattle, the celebrations are about more than mere institutional accomplishments.

Basking in the afterglow of a Mets victory Wednesday night, Scott Schoeneweis got to talking about Duaner Sanchez's solid bunt in the 11th inning. Earlier, Willie Randolph had complimented Guy Conti and Sandy Alomar Sr. for working on pitchers with their bunting, so I asked Schoeneweis how his skills compared.
Amid surging prices for synthetic fertilizers and organic food, guano, bird droppings found on islands off the coast of Peru, has become a niche fertilizer sought around the world.
Location: Toledo, Oh.
The enthralling documentary “Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic” follows the creation of a lofty operatic collaboration.
Giuseppe Tornatore’s sleazy Hitchcockian thriller, “The Unknown Woman,” keeps you glued to the screen despite your increasingly nagging doubts about its integrity.
There are no supernatural happenings, just people under extreme stress succumbing to their worst instincts, in Stuart Gordon’s grim, expert little thriller “Stuck.”
“The Strangers” proves adept at eliciting the fear and dislocation that accompany the violation of our most sacred space.
A little Botox goes a long way in “Sex and the City,” but a little decent writing would have gone even further.
“Savage Grace,” Tom Kalin’s long-awaited second feature (after “Swoon”), swoons through a number of lovely, storied places on its way to a sad and sordid end.
“The Foot Fist Way” is an itsy-bitsy, ultra-indie, super-silly comedy packing huge laughs and unexpected heart.
The proposal strikes a deep chord with a public fed up with an unpopular war and anxious about their own economic future.
As part of the military’s effort to remake Guam into a strategic hub in the western Pacific, the Pentagon is planning to upgrade and expand World War II-era air bases.
Kobe Bryant scored 17 of his 39 points in the fourth quarter as the Lakers rallied from an early 17-point deficit to beat the San Antonio Spurs.
Thursday’s win over the Dodgers shifted the focus from the Mets Willie Randolph’s future to the team’s return to a .500 record.
Francis H. Powers, a retired Wall Street executive, was endorsed as the Republican candidate for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella.
Tiffany said each ring, made of white gold and diamonds, has an estimated value of roughly $25,000.
The H. J. Heinz Company raised its forecast for annual earnings growth, with foods it promotes as healthier and business in emerging markets contributing to the increase.
Minorities and people without college degrees pay more in mortgage fees than do white applicants and those with a higher education, according to a study.

The New York State Racing and Wagering Board, which is responsible for regulating horse racing, passed new restrictions on steroid use in thoroughbred and standardbred racing. The proposal would allow one of four types of steroids to be used on a horse at a time and set new concentration limits for the drugs. The rules comply with standards supported by the Racing Medication Testing Consortium and the Association of Racing Commissioners International. Gov. David Paterson will evaluate the guidelines, and then they will be submitted to the Department of State for a 45-day public comment period.
When Joe Torre was asked to describe the biggest controversy he has handled as Dodgers manager, he was silent for 10 seconds. He could not muster an answer.

The Entrepreneurial Edge column in Business Day on May 15, about the development of biomeadical companies in Orange County, Calif., misidentified the developer of a stent used to prevent glaucoma. He is Dr. Rick Hill, an ophthalmologist formerly with the University of California, Irvine — not Dr. Richard Little, who is still an ophthalmologist there.

An article on Wednesday about the leadership of Ben S. Bernanke as Federal Reserve chairman misattributed comments about the Fed’s new lending programs for financial institutions. The quotations — “These new facilities are Ben’s initiatives” and “He has been willing to take a fresh look at how the system works and press the boundaries in a thoughtful way” — were by Richard W. Fisher, president of the Dallas Federal Reserve Bank — not by Charles I. Plosser, president of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank.

An article last Friday about a federal effort to use information on Medicare claims to assess the risks of drugs already on the market misstated the number of prescription purchases by Americans. The average among all Americans is 16 a year — not 13, the average among Americans younger than 65.

A picture caption on Tuesday with an obituary about the film director Sydney Pollack misidentified the film from which a scene was shown and misidentified the actress in it in some editions. The scene was from “Out of Africa,” not “The Way We Were,” and the actress, shown kissing Robert Redford, was Meryl Streep, not Barbra Streisand. The obituary also omitted part of the name of the Indiana high school Mr. Pollack attended. It was South Bend Central High School, not South Bend High School.

An article on Saturday about electoral gains by the opposition Conservative Party of Britain under the leadership of David Cameron referred incorrectly to the honing of his oratory skills. While Mr. Cameron is known for his quick repartee in parliamentary debates with Prime Minister Gordon Brown, the Labor Party leader, he never participated in the debates of the Oxford Union as a student.

Two picture captions on Thursday with an article about efforts in Portland, Ore., to encourage black and white residents to talk about gentrification misstated, in some editions, the name of a street there that was once predominantly black. As the article correctly noted, it is Alberta Street, not Albert.
FRONT PAGE.

The ruling junta, disappointed that international aid pledges for cyclone relief added up to $150 million, rather than the $11 billion it asked for, insisted that survivors could get by without foreign handouts. “People from the Irrawaddy Delta can survive on their own, even without bars of chocolate donated by the international community,” said the government-run Myanma Ahlin newspaper, adding that they could live on “fresh vegetables that grow wild in the fields and on protein-rich fish from the rivers.” No aid agency is known to be distributing chocolate bars.
A Ugandan police officer working for international peacekeeping forces in Sudan’s Darfur region has been shot dead, according to the joint United Nations-African Union force.
A Sri Lankan television journalist and his friend were killed in an army-held area in the northern Jaffna peninsula on Wednesday.
The governments of Albania, Bosnia, Croatia, Montenegro, Serbia and Slovenia agreed to increase cross-border conservation efforts.
Randy Johnson tied Roger Clemens on Thursday night for second place on the career strikeout list.
Fernando Tatis added to the list of incredible moments in his career with Wednesday’s double in the bottom of the 12th that drove in two runs.
The company that runs “Bodies ... the Exhibition” admitted that it could not prove that the bodies on display were not those of prisoners who might have been tortured or executed.
Barely 24 hours after saying it would defend free travel perks for its former and current board members, the authority announced that it was backing down.
The N.H.L. chalked up a small victory Wednesday night in its battle with the N.B.A. for the attention of sports viewers in Detroit.
Gov. David A. Paterson is stepping to the forefront of an issue that has often tripped up his party.
Normally placid Falun Gong gatherings in Flushing have become turbulent in recent weeks as the group has been confronted over its condemnation of the Chinese government.
Despite support, plans to take the carbon dioxide that spews from coal-burning power plants and pump it back into the ground have hit roadblocks.

Luc Bourdon, a promising rookie defenseman with the Vancouver Canucks, was killed Thursday when his motorcycle struck a tractor-trailer near his hometown of Shippagan, New Brunswick. He was 21. His death was confirmed by his sister Eve Bourdon and stepmother Maryse Godin. Both declined further comment when reached at the family’s home in Shippagan. Bourdon was the first-round draft pick of the Canucks in 2005, the 10th overall selection. He split time this season with the Canucks and the Manitoba Moose of the American Hockey League.

Rutgers has given Coach Fred Hill a two-year contract extension, but he did not receive a salary increase under the deal, which will run through the 2012-13 season. Hill, 48, received a five-year contract worth $500,000 per year when he succeeded Gary Waters in 2006. The Scarlet Knights were 11-20 last season, including 3-15 in the Big East.
The Finnish nordic combined skier Hannu Manninen announced his retirement from the sport. Manninen, 30, won the World Cup title from 2004-7 and recorded 45 career individual victories.
Hockey.
Congress should be willing to spend a little more to find out how much of the taxpayers’ dollars are being wasted in the Pentagon’s budget.
Gov. Bobby Jindal needs to make sure that the state’s new plan truly follows the Missouri model of a juvenile justice system.
Sadly, in Idaho, wolves are nothing more than another game animal to be managed for the benefit of human hunters.
New York State Legislature should prove its commitment to equality and justice by granting gay couples the right to marry in the state.
European governments, already under pressure from slowing economic growth and falling tax revenue, are concerned that anger over higher gas prices could grow.
A scarf that the food celebrity Rachael Ray wore in a Dunkin’ Donuts advertisement on the Web has generated much attention from conservative bloggers.
Surging prices for synthetic fertilizers and organic foods are shifting attention to guano, an organic fertilizer once found in abundance on more than 20 islands off the coast of Peru.
Starting next season, the league will fine players for “flopping” — the art of exaggerating a collision to provoke referees into calling a foul.
New data show two starkly different paths toward death in New York City’s hospitals, one for patients at elite private institutions, another for those at public hospitals.
A divided Supreme Court of Texas agreed that the state had illegally seized 468 girls and boys from a ranch last month on unproven grounds of physical and sexual abuse.
A retired professor at St. John’s University is accused of passing inside information about a multibillion-dollar corporate takeover to a professor at Pace University.
Some finishers were saying a radar gun was required to clock the fast greens at Thursday’s first round of the Memorial Tournament in Dublin, Ohio.
Chee Soon Juan, the most dogged critic of Singapore’s former prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew, finally confronted his accuser this week.
Chile’s top police official and at least 14 other people were killed Thursday when a Panamanian Air Force helicopter crashed on top of a building in the heart of the city.
A banker indicted in a tax inquiry of the Swiss giant UBS is expected to enter a guilty plea next month and cooperate with investigators.
If nothing else, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has clearly solidified her front-running position as the presidential candidate to have cocktails with.
The Detroit Red Wings weren’t fretting over losing their stranglehold on the Stanley Cup finals. Instead, they took the day off to hang out together.
The value of processed fryer oil has increased, and there have been reports of thefts in multiple states.
The United States Olympic softball team is preparing more publicly than any other, winding through 25 states. The 2008 games are scheduled to be the last for softball.
Without increased government aid the city would raise rents for some public housing tenants and eliminate many community centers, according to the chairman of the housing authority.
Back in the clubhouse, and not feeling symptomatic, Ryan Church he said that he had no misgivings about how he or the Mets handled his recent concussion.
The Department of Defense has identified 4,078 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.
The final Harry Potter installment gave a much-needed jolt to the publishing industry last July, but publishers still struggled to sell more books overall than they did in 2006.
The explosive reaction to the new memoir by Scott McClellan prompted his publisher to allow sales of the book several days ahead of the original publication date.
Environmental groups want to shut down Vermont’s only nuclear power plant, but closing it might mean the state would probably have to derive extra power from suppliers that use fossil fuels.
Some high-profile journalists have agreed with Scott McClellan’s assertion that the media neglected its watchdog role in the run-up to the invasion of Iraq.
MasterCard, the credit and debit card processor, said it expected double-digit revenue growth for 2008, and raised its long-term profit outlook.
The two top Democrats in Congress said they were pressing uncommitted superdelegates to make their choice public by the middle of next week.
Invariably, books like Scott McClellan’s new confessional of sorts are labeled “tell-all.” But “tell when” is more the issue.
Federal regulators said that they have been investigating oil and derivative markets for six months to look into potential price manipulation.
Legal challenges to Gov. David A. Paterson’s plan to recognize same-sex marriages from other jurisdictions will face difficulties, given New York’s unusual legal terrain.
The Rhode Island Board of Elections has restored the voting rights of two men who were stripped of them because they were found to be not guilty of murder by reason of insanity.
A United Nations conference on Iraq ended Thursday with a declaration encouraging debt forgiveness, but without commitments from Iraq’s biggest creditors.
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned that the nation’s ailing banking industry was likely to weaken further.

You’ve just finished a hard workout, satisfied from a personal best in a 10-mile run or additional reps with free weights. Your attitude is “You’ll do it again tomorrow, for sure,” Gretchen Reynolds writes in her Phys Ed column “Swallow This.” “But then it hits - the aftermath” - soreness from strained or tired muscles that usually settles in roughly 12-24 hours after a workout. So how can you best repair and refresh those muscles? Start with a postworkout meal full of glucose and protein (no carbo-loading allowed!).

“As Spain goes, so goes toreo, or bullfighting,” Michael Kimmelman writes in PLAY. In today’s Spain, though, a curious divide exists between indifference to and fascination with bullfighting. While the country apparently cares less about what bullfighters do, it is loathe to have people from the outside suggest that it’s time to do away with this centuries-old tradition. Even as it is ignored by a new generation of Spaniards and attacked by animal rights activists, it persists as an complex part of the national consciousness. There are more bullfights now than ever, and as Kimmelman writes, “Spaniards tell their children to be nice to the dog, but they talk bullfighting with their friends.”.

Vladimir Galchenko is one of the world’s best jugglers. Penn Jillette, from Penn & Teller fame, explains Galchenko’s talent this way: “It couldn’t be simpler. He can throw more things in the air and catch them in order.” As Jason Fagone writes in PLAY, Galchenko’s YouTube clips are inspiring kids who have started to change the face of juggling, “evolving a culture whose values - speed, numbers, athleticism, technique - are distinct from the traditional juggling values of balance, expression, and showmanship.” But as Fagone also notes, Galchenko, known as Vova, has a career problem: once you’ve reached the pinnacle of an endeavor few people care about, where do you go next?.

If Tiger Woods is the royalty in the current realm of sports greatness, then Floyd Mayweather is the Hollywood entertainer. Too bad he’s in an Indie production. Widely regarded as the world’s best pound-for-pound boxer, Mayweather is a star in a fringe sport — famous, but, as Carlo Rotella writers for PLAY, not famous enough for his own taste. So he’s taken control of his career and, while at the top of his profession, is “pursuing mainstream fame and money a la Paris Hilton more strenuously than he’s chasing Sugar Ray Robinson and all-time greatness as a boxer.”.

When Chip Brown went to Florida for two weeks in March for an up-close look at the Tiger Woods phenomenon, he left knowing that Woods, still just 32, was one of the most written-about athletes of all time, the subject of many millions of words, including some 85 books. He also knew Woods himself wouldn’t add much to the body of knowledge: These days, Woods talks mostly in the form of unrevealing banalities.

WORLD SCIENCE FESTIVAL The conventional wisdom in New York is that street fairs are all alike. But the one to be held on Saturday in Greenwich Village won't feature gyros, tube socks or T-shirts, though it may well involve gyroscopes, test tubes and lab coats. This is the World Science Festival's Youth and Family Street Fair, a daylong concentration of brain power in and around Washington Square Park. The festival, which began on Thursday and runs through Sunday (article, Page 4), includes scientific panels for adults, but the street fair is for smaller enthusiasts.

PREVIOUSLY ON LOST Fan-fiction writers have nothing on Adam Schatz and Jeff Curtin, Brooklynites and the founders of what they believe is the world's first (only?) TV-recap rock band. Technically a duo, Previously on Lost was born about a year ago, when Mr. Schatz, 20, a jazz saxophone studies major at New York University, and Mr. Curtin, 25, who runs a recording studio, decided to parlay their love of ''Lost,'' the byzantine ABC series about a group of plane-crash survivors on an island, into a musical entity. ''The fan base was already there,'' Mr. Schatz noted.

Alexander Hamilton's country home, the Grange, has been sitting on Convent Avenue and 141st Street for 119 years, long enough for neighbors to get well used to it. BASIC ASSEMBLY: 'GAME ON' Benjamin Asriel and Ashleigh Leite are dancers; Keith Skretch is a video designer; Joe Levasseur is a lighting designer. So what are they all doing sitting at a table, above, playing a card game onstage? Is it a play? Is it a dance? None of the above? ''Game On,'' which opened on Thursday night at the Chocolate Factory, took shape while on tour in Slovakia, Mr. Levasseur said, when he was playing cards in a hotel courtyard with Mr. Skretch and Mr. Asriel. Every so often, he would have to wave his arms around to activate the motion sensors that switched on the lights, and the activity struck him as interestingly choreographic. They began to talk casually about making a piece based on the idea, a collaborative work that would blur the lines of their professional identities.

ROTH--Marjorie Englander, a loving wife, sister, mother and grandmother who lived in New York City, Coronado, California, Westhampton and Larchmont, New York passed away Wednesday morning. She was 84 years old. Married to Harold Roth on June 22, 1941 in New Rochelle, New York, she graduated from Hunter College. She was a beloved kindergarten teacher at the Chatsworth Avenue School in Larchmont, New York. Married for 67 years, she is survived by her husband, Harold Roth, a leading executive with Grosset & Dunlap, Simon & Schuster and Pocket Books, Inc. book publishers; a daughter, Joan Roth Saffa and her husband Dr. Robert Saffa; two sons, Dr. Richard Roth and his wife Jane and Peter Roth and his wife Andrea; her brother, Roger Englander and his wife Simone; and her seven grandchildren, Jason, Aaron and Lauren Saffa; David, Michael, Erica and Brian Roth. Private services will be held. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Alzheimer's Association.

As Oliver Stone prepares an unflattering biographical film about President Bush for release just before the presidential election, Senator John McCain, the prospective Republican nominee, is mustering a little movie power of his own. At a fund-raising stop in California on Wednesday, Mr. McCain quietly slipped into a suite at the Beverly Hilton Hotel, where he recorded an interview to be included with the first DVD edition of the 1987 film ''The Hanoi Hilton.''

Senator Barack Obama expressed disappointment on Thursday over new statements from the pulpit of his Chicago church. This time, however, the words were not from his former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., but from a Roman Catholic priest who was mocking Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. In a guest appearance last Sunday at Trinity United Church of Christ, the priest, the Rev. Michael Pfleger, delivered a blistering critique of Mrs. Clinton's candidacy. Father Pfleger, a well-known activist Chicago priest and a friend of Mr. Obama, said Mrs. Clinton was stunned by ''a black man stealing my show.''

8 P.M. (ABC) 2008 SCRIPPS NATIONAL SPELLING BEE Can you spell serrefine? How about ursprache? Appoggiatura? Autochthonous? Those are just some of the winning words from recent years in this annual competition, started in 1925 by The Courier-Journal of Louisville, Ky., as a way to inject a little buzz into a humdrum subject. In this two-hour championship round, broadcast live from Washington, 288 spellers, ages 8 to 15, make like dictionaries for a grand prize including $30,000, an engraved trophy, a $2,500 savings bond and a reference library. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) DOG WHISPERER Cesar Millan tries to rehabilitate Chipper, a Rhodesian Ridgeback-boxer mix who has attacked five dogs, forcing her owner to sign legal documents promising to keep Chipper muzzled at all times. Then there are Rudy and Monte, who behave badly each time a customer enters their owners' pet boutique.

LESSER--Steven Charles, died May 28, 2008. He leaves behind his beloved wife, Elizabeth, and their adored children Emma, Molly, Sophie and Aaron, his mother Deena, his sisters Laura Lesser and Julie Barkan and many relatives and friends. He was a devoted and loving husband and father. He was an Options Trader at The American Stock Exchange, actively involved in their governance and, ultimately, a Senior Vice President there. During that period, he also designed and successfully marketed with his partner, Biddle Worthington, a computer program to be used widely by floor traders. Steven was a man of many talents --a woodworker, a gardener, a bicyclist and a world - class mensch --a ''green'' man before his time. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Transportation Alternatives or The Reconstructionist Synagogue of the North Shore, 1001 Plandome Rd., Manhasset, NY, where services will be held Sunday, June 1, 2008 at 10:00am.

JUSTIN--Jane. You were more than a friend. You were family. We love you and we will miss you. Ilene Somkin Lowenthal and Family JUSTIN--Jane, after a long illness Jane died peacefully at her home. Jane had a unique personal style and sophistication that led her to a career in fashion. She blended classic fabrics with updated modern silhouettes and was known for her good ''eye in the industry.'' After graduating from The Parsons School of Design, she went on to many years of success and prominence in the fashion industry. Not finished yet she spent 12 years at Macy's as Vice President for Corporate Apparel Design. She is survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Barbara and Mark Handler. She was loving and generous to her niece Jody Cooper and husband Neal and to her nephew Jonathan Handler and his wife Cindy. She was a ''kvelling'', doting over the top ''grand-aunt'' to Lori, Caroline and Evie. She leaves behind her longtime companion and soulmate Les Suchman. JUSTIN--Jane. Dear Jane, I'll miss reminiscing about Mom and Dad. I'll miss your always perfect fashion advice. I'll miss singing camp songs. I'll miss sharing memories and borrowing clothes. I'll miss having a sister. I'll miss you. Love, Barbara

JUN NGUYEN-HATSUSHIBA: 'VIETNAM: A MEMORIAL WORK' In a dreamy 15-minute film by Jun Nguyen-Hatsushiba, six young men struggle to pedal and drag three pedicabs across the sandy and rocky bottom of a shallow sea, right. Not equipped with breathing apparatus, they periodically swim to the surface for air before resuming their Sisyphean task. Near the end they abandon their burdens and swim away in a lovely image of submarine flight. The son of a Japanese mother and a Vietnamese father, Mr. Nguyen-Hatsushiba was born in Tokyo in 1968. He moved to Texas when he was 9 and studied painting in the United States before relocating to Vietnam in 1996.

Chile's top police official and at least 10 other people were killed when a Panamanian Air Force helicopter crashed on top of a building in the heart of Panama's capital. The official, Gen. José Alejandro Bernales, 59, was the director of the Carabineros, Chile's national police force, and was in Panama for a conference on terrorism. His wife, Teresa Bianchini, also died in the crash. Three Chilean police officials, three Panamanian police officials, the captain and a member of the flight crew were also among those killed. Officials said the cause of the crash was still unknown.

GOLDEN--Francis ''Frank'', of Scituate, MA, May 28th, age 91. Loving husband of Marie (Betzmer). Devoted father of Peter and his wife, Janet of Woodbury, MN and Tony and his wife, Judy of Scituate. Loving grandfather of Ian, Jeremy, Elliot, Erin and Renee Golden. Sister of Elsie O'Neil of Concord, NH. Also survived by two nephews. Funeral at the Richardson-Gaffey Funeral Home, 382 First Parish Rd., Scituate on Saturday, May 31st at 11am. Visiting hours Friday from 4-8 pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Scituate Animal Shelter, 61 Driftway, Scituate, MA 02066.

MARTEN--Dr. Milton A., 86 years old, died on May 29, 2008. Beloved husband of Teddy for 58 years. Devoted father of Kenneth and Randi. Cherished grandfather of Samantha and Joshua. Loving brother-in-law of Dr. Irving M. and Madeline Fishman. Retired periodontist, Professor of Periodontics at NYU School of Dentistry and Director of Periodontics at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens. Services Sunday, 1pm at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to UNICEF and the Hospice Care Network.
LEE BUL Lehmann Maupin
JESSICA JACKSON Hutchins
MYERS--Farlan I., 89, passed away May 27, 2008 in his Los Angeles home, with his family by his side. Memorial Services will be held Sunday, June 1, 2008 at 12 o'clock. (800) 576-1994.

BENWITT--Millicent Groman, 93, died on May 27, 2008. Devoted wife of the late Herman Benwitt, beloved sister of Elaine Shapiro and the late Gladys Schorr, cherished aunt of many nieces, nephews, grand-nieces, grandnephews, and great-grandnieces. Millie helped generations of students as a teacher and guidance counselor at New York City public high schools. A world traveler and artist, her loving spirit extended to her family and the many charities she supported generously.

SCHNEIDERMAN--Robert, passed away in Palm Beach, FL on May 19, at age 93. He was born in New York, attended New York University, served in the U.S. Army during World War II, and had a distinguished career as an executive at Gino Paoli, Anne Klein, and Izod Lacoste. He was a loving husband to his late wife Mary, devoted father to Stuart, David, and daughter-in-law Dana, adoring grandfather to Katherine. An Eternal Optimist he will be missed by his family, by his dear friend Rebecca, by the gang at the Palm Beach Grill, and by Regina and Paul at Charley's Crab.

KLEIN--Miriam, 88, died peacefully, May 27. A long time resident of West Orange, NJ, she was residing in Boca Raton, FL with her companion of 18 years, Paul Marks. Wife of the late S. Lawrence Klein, Miriam is survived by her son Bill, daughter - in - law Elaine, grandchildren Michael, Steven, Rachel and Lauren.

An editorial on May 11 about veterans' mental health problems incorrectly described how the Department of Veterans Affairs released data on veterans' suicide attempts. The information was given to CBS News in reply to a Freedom of Information Act request, not in Congressional testimony by an official.

TEATROSTAGEFEST 2008 For the second year, several New York City theater companies will team up with colleagues from Latin America, the Caribbean and Spain to present a two-week celebration of Latino performance at several locations around the city. The festival, which includes plays, concerts, comedy, panel discussions and even a high school playwriting competition, starts on Monday, when Bianca Marroquin, Broadway's current Roxie Hart in ''Chicago,'' performs a solo evening at Joe's Pub, offering a mix of her original songs, show tunes and Mexican standards. Other festival participants include the stalwart New York company Repertorio Español, now in its 40th-anniversary season, which will present ''Doña Flor y Sus Dos Maridos'' (''Doña Flor and Her Two Husbands''), a surreal Brazilian comedy about a woman living with -- and sleeping with -- both her new husband and the ghost of her dead ex. Among the visiting troupes are Teatro La Zaranda, from Andalucía, Spain, offering the absurdist clown tale ''Los Que Ríen Los Últimos'' (''Those Who Laugh Last''), above, and Grupo Doble Ve, from Buenos Aires. That Argentinean troupe will perform two one-act plays, ''Harina'' (''Flour'') and ''Guardavidas'' (''Lifeguard''), to be presented in Spanish with live English translation. (Monday through June 15 at various locations, 212-695-4010, teatrostagefest.org.)

The Lakers, who have not been to the NBA finals since Bryant and Shaquille O'Neal feuded their way through the spring of 2004, are heading back to the championship round.

The big economic debate of the moment is whether the Fed and its peers have made a terrible mistake by focusing on staving off financial crisis while more or less ignoring the rise of inflation. "Inflation is rising and it seems the world's central banks have critically misjudged the situation," says Wolfgang Munchau in the FT. I've heard even more apocalyptic views from some serious people in the last couple of weeks.

Tonight one of the largest Canadian TV audiences of the year will scurry back from their refrigerators and bathroom breaks during the first intermission of Stanley Cup final Game 4 to absorb the words of Don Cherry. His Coach's Corner segment on Hockey Night in Canada remains hugely popular and has made Cherry probably the most recognizable person in the country.

This week for the New York premiere of "Sex and the City," Sarah Jessica Parker wore a strapless Nina Ricci gown designed by Olivier Theyskens. It was one of 40 outfits that Parker planned for the movie's premieres in London and Berlin, and the press junkets. She looked glamorous and happy in the dress and was asked several times by reporters on the red carpet if it was the sort of dress that Carrie Bradshaw would have worn. New Yorkers have no trouble seeing SJP as Carrie, and given the TV show's name-dropping familiarity with the fashion world, what she wore to the opening was bound to get attention. It had to be stand-out.

WASHINGTON  Democratic Party officials met privately for five and a half hours late Friday night to discuss the Michigan and Florida delegations to the party's convention but did not resolve their differences.

The Rules and Bylaws Committee of the Democratic Party meets today in Washington to consider a question that has loomed large over the primary season - what to do about the Democratic delegates from the states of Florida and Michigan.

Motion, 44, was born into a racing family (his father a bloodstock agent; his mother an amateur jockey) in Cambridge, England, and now resides in Fair Hill, Md., with his wife, Anita, and his two children, Jane and Marcus. He is ranked 13th on the 2008 earning's list ($2,542,037), with 50 wins in 237 starts.

Donald Leo, a crane operator, looked forward to his June wedding. Ramadan Kurtaj worked long hours on water and sewer lines to help his family in Kosovo. Today, both men are dead.

The Celtics made play upon play in the fourth quarter in a decisive charge led by Kevin Garnett to earn a trip to the N.B.A. finals for the first time since 1987.

Tiffany & Company reported that strong growth in Asia-Pacific and European markets helped first-quarter profit rise 19 percent.

Daisuke Matsuzaka was placed on the 15-day disabled list Friday by the Boston Red Sox, who opted to take a cautious approach towards a mild strain of his right rotator cuff.

Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun is being treated for a second bout of skin cancer but expects to be on the bench this fall for his 23rd season with the Huskies. Calhoun, 66, said doctors determined last month that a lump in the upper right side of his neck near the jaw line was squamous cell cancer, a type of skin cancer. He had an operation May 6 to remove the lump, several dozen surrounding lymph nodes and part of his salivary gland.
A week after an angry outburst following a collision with a car driven by Ryan Briscoe, Danica Patrick said she has not changed her tune about the incident.
Antonio Di Natale scored twice and Mauro Camoranesi had a goal to lead host Italy, the World Cup champion, over Belgium, 3-1, in Florence in its only tuneup for the European Championships next month.

Luc Bourdon, the Canucks defenseman who died Thursday, received his motorcycle license two weeks before he was killed when his bike veered into a truck on a winding, two-lane road near his hometown, Shippagan, New Brunswick. Investigators said Friday that the 21-year-old Bourdon’s inexperience on a motorcycle might have played a role in his death.
Concerned about the national ramifications of same-sex marriages, attorneys general from 10 states have asked the California Supreme Court to stay its decision legalizing the marriages.

Russia’s 10 wealthiest businessmen have donated $12 million to a fund that will pay bonuses to Russian athletes who win medals at the Beijing Olympics. Gold, silver and bronze medalists already receive $25,000, $15,000 and $10,000 from the government. The additional amount each medalist will receive has not yet been determined, said Alexander Katushev of the Fund to Support Olympians.

The Devils signed the free-agent defenseman Anssi Salmela of Finland. Contract terms were not immediately available. The 23-year-old Salmela had 16 goals and 16 assists in 56 games with Tappara of the Finnish League last season. His 16 goals were the most for a defenseman in the league.

Greg Biffle held off the Busch brothers with a lap of 155.219 miles an hour at Dover (Del.) International Speedway to take the pole for Sunday’s Best Buy 400 and bolster his bid to drive the No. 16 Ford to his first victory of the season. Kurt Busch was second at 153.971, and Kyle Busch, the Sprint Cup points leader, was third at 153.767 on the one-mile concrete track. Jimmie Johnson and Jamie McMurray round out the top five for the race.

Time is running out for the Bush administration and Congress to take action to arrest the alarming decline of this country’s ocean resources.

Marian Hossa’s performance in the playoffs has made the Penguins’ trade for him at the deadline look brilliant, but the Red Wings have slowed him down in the finals.
Ending years of wrangling, the German Parliament on Friday voted to sell a stake in Deutsche Bahn, the former state railroad monopoly that is now a logistics company.
The shuttle Discovery is scheduled to blast off at 5:02 Saturday afternoon. Its cargo includes an all important unit needed to repair the malfunctioning toilet.
Jeff Harnar completes a four-night tribute to Cole Porter at the Metropolitan Room on Saturday.
As the Wing Luke Asian Museum reopens on Saturday, the celebrations are about more than mere institutional accomplishments.
The gala presentation of “Michelangelo: La Dotta Mano,” a volume of photographs of the Renaissance master’s sculptures, may well have been the most lavish book debut in history.

A week and a half after a fire damaged its concert hall, the Berlin Philharmonic moved on to playing an airport. The orchestra performed Berlioz’s “Symphonie Fantastique” and “Mort de Cleopatre” in a hangar at the Tempelhof Airport on Thursday night as planes landed nearby, including one during the quietest moment of the symphony, The Associated Press reported. It was the second temporary facility for the orchestra; after a fire caused by welding work tore through the roof of the Philharmonic on May 20, it also performed in an open-air stadium used for rock concerts. The Philharmonic hopes to return to its home, whose interior was not severely damaged, by Monday.

“Natasha,” a story written by Vladimir Nabokov around 1924 as his career began, will be published for the first time in English in the summer fiction issue of The New Yorker, on sale Monday. The story, which was part of Nabokov’s archives at the Library of Congress, was translated by his son, Dmitri Nabokov. It tells of a young woman who cares for her father in Berlin as he mourns their exile from Russia.

A music critic for The Chicago Sun-Times who gave the police the tape that prosecutors say shows R. Kelly, right, having sex with an under-age female must testify at Mr. Kelly’s child pornography trial, a judge ruled Friday. Judge Vincent Gaughan of Cook County Criminal Court ruled that the defense can question the critic, Jim DeRogatis, about what he did with the VHS cassette between the time he received it and the time he gave it to the authorities, The Chicago Tribune reported. Lawyers for Mr. Kelly, the R&B singer who won a Grammy in 1997 and is known for his raunchy ballads, contend that their client is not on the tape and that Mr. DeRogatis has a personal bias against him. Mr. Kelly, 41, has pleaded not guilty to 14 counts of child pornography. The trial continues Monday.

The world premiere of the first opera by the novelist Ian McEwan (“Atonement”), a collaboration with the composer Michael Berkeley, has been postponed because the leading man has voice problems, Media Wales reported. The opera, “For You,” was to be staged in a partnership with the Hay Festival at Theatr Brycheiniog in Brecon on Saturday and Sunday, before embarking on a tour. But Eric Roberts, a Welsh baritone who sings the role of a womanizing composer, has been told by doctors that he must rest. Music Theater Wales, which is staging the opera, has also been forced to cancel a performance at Clwyd Theatr Cymru in Mold on Thursday.

It is unclear whether they discussed makeup, but on Thursday in Stockholm, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice had a late-night meeting with the rock group Kiss. Ms. Rice was in Sweden for an international conference concerning Iraq; the band was there to play a sold-out concert and asked to meet her. After a dinner with Carl Bildt, the Swedish foreign minister, Ms. Rice joined Gene Simmons, Paul Stanley, Eric Singer and Tommy Thayer in the executive lounge of the Sheraton Hotel, where they signed autographs and gave T-shirts to her staff. “It was really fun” to meet them, Ms. Rice said, according to The Associated Press, adding that they seemed well informed about politics. Though she said she had never seen the band perform, she named “Rock and Roll All Nite” as her favorite Kiss song.

Two months after Fox News said it had wiped out a bedbug infestation in its Midtown Manhattan newsroom, a network employee who says she was bitten on three occasions has filed a negligence suit against the building’s owners and managing agent and two cleaning companies. In a suit filed Thursday, the employee, Jane Clark, a coordinator in the department that transmits the channel’s satellite feeds around the world, seeks unspecified damages for “pain, shock, mental anguish,” which she says resulted from bites on her arms, leg and neck. Ms. Clark is on medical leave. Fox News is not named in the suit. A statement by one of the building owners and Cushman & Wakefield, its managing agent, said tenants were responsible for providing extermination services. A four-foot-high metal and fabric sculpture of a spider by Louise Bourgeois sold for $4.5 million, a record price for the artist, at Christie’s International in Paris, Bloomberg News reported. The sculpture by Ms. Bourgeois, 96, was bought by a European collector on the telephone, competing against three other bidders on Tuesday, the auction house said. Works by Ms. Bourgeois, known for her spider sculptures, already commanded the highest prices for a living female artist. Her most expensive sculpture, an eight-foot-high arachnid, fetched $4 million with fees at Christie’s New York in November 2006, according to Artnet.

Djimon Hounsou is Mateo, a reclusive painter dying of what seems to be AIDS, whom Johnny and Sarah's daughters (above right, from left, Emma and Sarah Bolger) befriend. Mr. Sheridan (''My Left Foot'') wrote the screenplay with his own two daughters. ''This movie, from moment to moment, feels small, almost anecdotal,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''It is only afterward that, like Mr. Sheridan's other films, it starts to grow into something at once unassuming and in its own way grand.''

Abdul Qadeer Khan, the founder of Pakistan's nuclear weapons program, was reported to have withdrawn an admission that he sold nuclear technology to Iran, North Korea and Libya. In a telephone interview with a correspondent from The Guardian, a British newspaper, Dr. Khan said he had made it under pressure from President Pervez Musharraf. ''It was not of my own free will,'' he told The Guardian. Western intelligence agencies fear that any technology passed on by Dr. Khan could be used by terrorists.

Weather and technology both seem to be cooperating for launching the space shuttle Discovery on Saturday to begin a mission to the International Space Station. The shuttle, with its crew of seven astronauts, is scheduled to blast off at 5:02 p.m. and take a tour-bus-size science laboratory, the $1 billion Kibo module, to the station. The astronauts will also have a last-minute addition to their cargo: replacement parts to repair the broken zero-gravity toilet aboard the station. The urine collection system has lost the vacuum that directs urine flow and the subsystem that separates the liquid from air for storage. (The part of the toilet that captures solid waste is working properly.) The astronauts at the station have attached a receptacle that bypasses the separation system, but the complicated workaround is time consuming and wastes water.

A highly regarded member of our faculty and an extraordinarily talented psychoanalyst, she had a deep belief in the ability of psychoanalytic treatment to change the lives of her patients. Her passing is a profound loss to all who have been touched by her. Our heartfelt condolences to her family. Allan Frosch, President, IPTAR

An obituary by The Associated Press in some copies on Friday about the comic actor Harvey Korman, who appeared for 10 seasons on ''The Carol Burnett Show,'' misstated the history of the ending of the show. Ms. Burnett chose to end it after the 11th season; it was not canceled because it was failing. The obituary also misstated the title of the skit in which Mr. Korman and Ms. Burnett played a combative married couple raising the wife's teenage sister. It was called ''Carol and Sis,'' not ''Old Folks at Home.''

A letter published in the May 26 issue of Time magazine protests the inclusion, in Time's list of the world's 100 most influential people, of two researchers allied with the organization Cure Autism Now (a name that speaks for itself). The letter writer declares himself to be "outraged" because, in his view, "Autistic spectrum disorders are not diseases, but rather markers of 'genetic difference' in the same vein as skin color [and] gender." He equates the search for a cure with genocide - it's "part of a campaign to wipe out ASDs" [autism spectrum disorder] - and he wants the world to know that those to whom the cure would be offered neither need it nor desire it: "I speak for many when I say we are happy the way we are."A genetic difference is often adaptive and can be regarded as an advance in the evolutionary process; it is well-known that autism sometimes brings with it remarkable powers in the areas of music, art and mathematics. In the 2006 movie "X-Men: The Last Stand," the augmented powers of those known as "mutants" are even more remarkable and include the ability to walk through walls, to move metal objects as large as California's Golden Gate Bridge, to auto-generate fire or ice, to be in seven places at the same time, to read minds, to assume any identity, to kill with a touch, to fly like Icarus, to change the weather. These abilities are seen by many "normal" human beings, and a few mutants, as disabilities, as an indication that the person who possesses one of them is a freak.

As Twins reliever Juan Rincon headed into pitch the 11th inning Saturday night, the Daily News beat writer Mark Feinsand turned to me in the Metrodome press box and said: "Juan Rincon. The greatest quote of all time."To those of us who covered Game 4 of the division series in Minneapolis in 2004, this required no explanation.That's the game where Rincon, then a dominant Twins setup reliever, blew a 5-1 lead in the eighth for Johan Santana.It was 5-2 when Rincon hung a slider that Ruben Sierra sent clattering into the retractable seats above the baggie in right-center for the game-tying three-run homer. The Yankees went on to win, 6-5, and clinch the series, and afterward Rincon, a Venezuelan whose English wasn't the greatest, said, "Nobody wants to be in my pants right now."This morning's news: With the bullpen overworked the last few days, the Yankees summoned Scott Patterson from Scranton/Wilkes-Barre and designated Morgan Ensberg for assignment. Ensberg got the news shortly after he arrived at the Metrodome this morning, and was back out the door within minutes. Patterson is the 28-year-old career minor leaguer who had a surprisingly good spring (0.00 ERA in seven and two-thirds innings over eight appearances) and hung around until the final cuts.

An article on May 18 exploring the question of who might be the first female president of the United States referred imprecisely in some copies to a constitutional requirement for candidates. In a brief reference to Maria Shriver, the article noted that her husband (Arnold Schwarzenegger) “can’t run because he was not born in this country.” The Constitution says only that the president must be “a natural-born citizen,” not that the president must have been born in the United States.

The icons were not all representing former presidents.

To the Editor: Matt Gross’s recent visit to Toronto as the Frugal Traveler would have benefited from more research and/or a longer stay. His article “O Canada, Where Have Your Bargains Gone?” (May 18) paints a rather shallow and limited picture of the many modestly priced attractions in this cosmopolitan, accessible, largely peaceful city, whose metropolitan population is more than 2.7 million, and which harbors communities drawn from nearly every other country.

To the Editor: Regarding Dan Barry’s search for the “real” Ireland in his article, “Does the ‘Real’ Ireland Still Exist?” (May 18): The issue lies in what he is searching for. If you believe the real Ireland to be the one portrayed in “The Quiet Man” or more recently in “Far and Away,” you are searching for something that exists primarily in the minds of movie producers or those nostalgic for a past no longer widely seen.

RIEGEL--Lawrence M. , of New York City died on May 22, 2008 at the age of seventyfour. Beloved husband of Jeanne for fifty years and devoted father of Jennifer Elmlinger, Heather Harper, Whitney Mooney, and Cynthia Von Arx. He was the proud father-in-law of Paul, Roger, John, and Eric. He was the adored grandfather of eight. Larry was born in New York City and made his home here. He was educated at the Choate School and Princeton University. Larry spent 48 years in the advertising business and retired as senior vice president of Avrett Free and Ginsburg. His greatest passion was his love of family, friends, and travel. A celebration of Larry's life will be held Monday, June 2nd, 11am at Saint James' Episcopal Church in NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Make a Wish Foundation where Larry devoted his volunteer time and to the Cottage Club at Princeton University.

RICHMAN--Saul, of Pinehurst, NC at 90; born Philadelphia, PA April 19, 1918. Predeceased by his beloved wife of 64 years, Ruby Olive Richman. Leaves behind sons Ted (Terry) and Joe, daughter Ruth (Kenny MacDonald), granddaughter Lisa, grandson Matt, and niece Ellen Love. Worked his way through Penn State University graduating with a degree in journalism. Attended University of California, Berkley, later becoming editor of The Napa Valley Register where he met his future wife, a teacher in Healdsburg. Became an editor of radio news at the Associated Press in San Francisco, moving with them to Salt Lake City and NYC. He then joined the Rockefeller family organization providing Public Relations advice for the family until he moved to the Council on Foundations which published his Public Information Handbook for Foundations. He enjoyed sailing, classical music, reading and fishing and was a daily reader of the NY Times. Private family services. Donations may be made to: United Jewish Communities, P.O. Box 30, Old Chelsea Station, NY, NY 10113

AFTER many years of selling the responsibility of all-wheel drive and safety, Subaru wants to make more of an emotional connection between the brand and its buyers. The latest batch of television commercials shows owners reluctant to part with their used Subarus, even after buying a new one, and using their Subarus for quirky activities, like driving to the easternmost point in the United States to be the first to greet the new year. The new tagline is: ''Love. It's what makes a Subaru a Subaru.''

CLOSE--Major General Winton, R. ''Now cracks a noble heart...'' Major General Winton R. Close, US Air Force, Retired, died in Bluffton, South Carolina, May 23, 2008 after 90 years of service to his Country and devotion to his family. A command pilot with more than 7000 flying hours to his credit, General Close was born in Columbus, Ohio and raised in New York City and Los Angeles. This graduate of Beverly Hills High School and Stanford University joined the Army Air Corps in 1939, earned his wings and commission at Kelly Field, Texas, and subsequently went on to a distinguished military career which included flying ''the hump'' in the China-Burma-India theater as a B-29 squadron commander and leading B-29s out of the Mariana Islands as a group operations officer in 1945. General Close returned from World War II after 600 combat hours and 35 missions. In 1952 he commanded the 98th Bomb Wing at Yokota Air Base, Japan where he flew 21 more combat missions over Korea. During the Cold War the General played an integral role in the Strategic Air Command and Operation Looking Glass. His career culminated with his command of JT2 at Sandia Base, New Mexico, working directly under the Joint Chiefs. The General retired in 1968, and moved with his wife, the former Joan Millsop of Weirton, West Virginia, to Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, where this former college polo and tennis player found time to express his athleticism as a Champion golfer. General Close was preceded in death by his wife of 55 years in 1998. He is survived by his four daughters: Leslie Joan Close of Bellevale, NY; Christine Campbell of Colorado Springs; Joey Close Baffico of Montclair, NJ; Barbara Vote of Hillsboro, Oregon; and, five grandchildren. The General's ashes were interred on Hilton Head Island on May 30, 2008. ''Good night, sweet prince, And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.''

DISICK--Ethel (nee Rieger) , in Boynton Beach, FL, born 1927 in NYC. Ethel will always be cherished by her family and friends for her nurturing spirit, generosity and loving, compassionate nature. Ethel was beautiful inside and out, and happiest when giving of herself to those she loved. She is survived by her husband, Dr. David Disick, their children, grandchildren, great - grandchild, sister, nieces and nephew.

At the Coachella festival in April the set by M.I.A., in one of the festival's bigger tents, was packed. Really packed. Hanging from the rafters packed, nearly unsafe packed. Her gig at McCarren Park Pool in Brooklyn on Friday, the opening concert of the summer concert series there, is looking as if it could be one of the New York shows of the year. No doubt it will be uncomfortably packed too. But this is suitable: M.I.A.'s records and her show imitate the chaos and density of a busy city street -- some sort of multipurpose intersection with a thousand signs, signals, smells and sounds. They're like bad cellphone connections to carnival chants and truck sirens, low-grade video uplinks from Sri Lanka to London to Trinidad to Mozambique. It's meant to be clashing and confusing and provocative. If the problem with the hipsterism of Greenpoint-Williamsburg is the cozy provincialism that comes with it, her show might hold that provincialism at bay, at least for an evening. 7 p.m., Lorimer Street, between Driggs Avenue and Bayard Street, Greenpoint, mccarrenpark.com; sold out.

MARTEN--Dr. Milton A. , 86 years old, died on May 29, 2008. Beloved husband of Teddy for 58 years. Devoted father of Kenneth and Randi. Cherished grandfather of Samantha and Joshua. Loving brother of the late Isabel Calica and her husband Leo and loving brother-in-law of Dr. Irving M. and Madeline Fishman. Beloved uncle of Rob, Jerry, Carolyn and Linda and their spouses Jill, Deanne and Bruce. Retired Periodontist, Professor of Periodontics at NYU School of Dentistry and Director of Periodontics at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens. Services Sunday, 1pm at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to UNICEF and the Hospice Care Network.

JOHNSON--Keith N., aged 62, mathematician, economist and longtime resident of Lower Manhattan died suddenly and unexpectedly on May 11, 2008. Born May 30, 1945 to Robert and Helen Johnson, Keith was raised in Joliet, Illinois, graduated from Harvard University and pursued postgraduate studies at the Universities of Chicago and Pennsylvania where he received a Ph.D. in Economics from the Wharton School in 1979. Keith taught economics at Columbia and NYU and worked in the advisory groups of Townsend-Greenspan & Co., JP Morgan and Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. He ''retired'' in 1996, the better to pursue more theoretical interests in mathematics/econometrics and an equivalent passion for apartment/house remodeling and electric system design applied, in a tradition passed down from his father, for the benefit of family and friends. Keith was a remarkable individual, smart and compassionate well beyond the ordinary. He impacted many lives. He loved, he was loved and he will be missed. Keith is survived by his companion Kathryn Cruze, four brothers, Kent, Carl, Theodore and Glen (Deborah), a sister Ellen (Tim) Johnson-Caspar, two sons Jamil and Omar (Beth) Albertelli, an aunt, Betty Neiswender, numerous beloved nephews, nieces and grandchildren, Aria and Sarina.

The golf-course architect Robert Trent Jones Jr. uses the phrase ''shock and awesome'' to describe one of his latest creations, Chambers Bay, the much-ballyhooed municipal course on a stretch of windswept Puget Sound coastline outside Tacoma, Wash. And while the 68-year-old architect is surely a little biased, I'm not so quick to dismiss his boast as promotional pap. Given Jones's résumé as a designer (more than 240 courses and counting) and his bloodlines (his late father, Robert, was a highly acclaimed golf-course architect, as is his brother, Rees), you'd have to assume the man would know when he has nailed it. Though Chambers Bay is barely a year old, the United States Golf Association has tapped it to host the 2015 U.S. Open, making it just the third public golf course (after Bethpage Black and this year's site, Torrey Pines) ever selected to host an Open. That helps ease the sting of the steep-for-a-muni cost to play ($170 a round for nonresidents on summer weekends). Built atop an old sand-and-gravel quarry, Chambers is a barren, links-style layout pimpled with dunes and mounds; it's so true to the British Isles that if not for the snow-capped Olympic Mountains looming in the background, you'd swear you were hacking around Scotland or Ireland. Only one tree, a lone fir, was left standing on the course -- and for that reprieve, it can thank the bald eagle that chose to nest there. (The tree can also thank the Audubon Society, which certified the course as a Silver Signature Sanctuary, making it the first golf course in the Pacific Northwest to earn such bird-friendly status.)

Q I moved into an apartment on a one-year lease. Thirty days before the end of my lease, I gave notice to vacate and requested, in writing, the return of my security deposit and interest. I moved out on March 2 and have yet to receive a check or a notice stating that the landlord was keeping the deposit. There was no damage to the apartment, so I expect the full deposit to be returned. They are not returning my calls.

''ENTHUSIASM, emotion, and fashion ... voilà!'' Babeth Djian, the highly influential fashion stylist and editor of Numéro magazine, proclaimed with the kind of throaty laugh only the French seem to have. ''That is me in three words.'' ''Babeth,'' a monograph conceived by her friend Karl Lagerfeld, manages to capture it all. Filled with photographs fashion-directed by Ms. Djian and shot by the likes of Peter Lindbergh, Paolo Roversi and Solve Sundsbo (to name a few), the book contains some of the more arresting fashion images of the last two decades -- edited down in two mornings' time. ''It was easy,'' she said of the process. ''I love everything I do, but I just picked the most stylish ones.'' Needless to say, the book has heft. ''Babeth'' by Babeth Djian

The introduction to a chart last Sunday showing artists' proposals for currency that would help the visually impaired differentiate among denominations referred incorrectly to one proposal. Two of the icons that the designer called for punching into each bill represented the founding fathers Hamilton (a pistol for the $10 bill) and Franklin (a kite for the $100 bill). The icons were not all representing former presidents.

An article on May 18 exploring the question of who might be the first female president of the United States referred imprecisely in some copies to a constitutional requirement for candidates. In a brief reference to Maria Shriver, the article noted that her husband (Arnold Schwarzenegger) ''can't run because he was not born in this country.'' The Constitution says only that the president must be ''a natural-born citizen,'' not that the president must have been born in the United States.

Not so long ago, even rank amateurs pretended to be sound engineers when listening to jazz or Journey. Just like a real audiophile, you furrowed your brow over graphic equalizers and studied up on reference speakers and multi-CD changers. If your life was going to include a party or seduction, you needed a stereo -- and your choice of equipment made a statement. Then the iPod and iTunes changed that; for all but the fanatics, they took the art out of playing music in the car or at home. And then came that unromantic iPod dock: no longer did your choice of Harman/Kardon or a scuffed boombox say anything about you except that that you were lugging around some antiquated junk. What a comedown. The old rarefied knowledge -- and finesse with the levers and knobs and high-stacked component systems -- suddenly seemed worthless. But not so fast! Just as I was hanging it up as an aspiring stereo expert, I perceived a new skill set taking shape, one that eclipsed my old sound geekery. Graphic design! Sure, I can't write any actual code or even do much with HTML, but the finish work on my technology now consumes days. I customize everything with colors and fonts and photos and choices of backgrounds, wallpaper, screen savers. It's like decorating my 10th-grade notebook with stickers of Rossignol and Vuarnet logos, as well as cryptic verse from Edie Brickell -- all meant to suggest both a rich interior life and an intimacy with high-end brands.

A famous Italian filmmaker befriends a maker of wedding videos on a beach in Sicily. Then, smitten with the subject of the wedding director's next and most important job -- the nuptials of the daughter of a local prince -- he muscles the hapless videographer aside and takes on the project himself. That may sound like more than enough infrastructure for a darkly humorous farce, but ''THE WEDDING DIRECTOR'' (2006) is the work of the ageless Italian provocateur Marco Bellocchio, so the complications just keep piling up. The filmmaker-hero (Sergio Castellitto) is also working on an adaptation of Manzoni's classic 19th-century novel of love, honor and delayed marriage, ''The Betrothed.'' The prince's daughter (Donatella Finocchiaro) tries to audition for the film, but leaves after an assistant recommends that she begin by giving the director oral sex -- ''literally or figuratively,'' he says, either is fine, as long as it's done ''with style.'' In a nod to Mr. Bellocchio's 1960s New Wave roots, the prince is played by the veteran French actor Sami Frey, star of Jean-Luc Godard's ''Bande à Part.'' Wednesday through June 9, Museum of Modern Art, (212) 708-9400, moma.org; $10. More Italian fare: The Film Society of Lincoln Center is presenting 14 features in OPEN ROADS: NEW ITALIAN CINEMA, including works by festival favorites like Silvio Soldini and Ferzan Ozpetek. Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 975-5600, filmlinc.org; $11.

The can-do looks of Mary McCormack (''The West Wing,'' ''ER,'' ''K Street'') make her unusually well cast as a federal marshal in the new series ''IN PLAIN SIGHT,'' which makes its debut Sunday at 10 p.m. on the USA Network. She appears to be the sort of person who can take care of business, and as Mary Shannon in this new drama about the witness protection program, that's exactly what she does: playing real estate agent, friend, chamber of commerce, nanny, shrink and bodyguard to underground criminals and those with the poor timing to have happened on a crime when they surely should have been playing bingo. Mary's job is to keep these unfortunates alive and listen to their sad-sack stories, and it's unclear which is harder. Like ''Burn Notice,'' USA's other escapade in hiding out, ''In Plain Sight'' maintains a light touch. ''THE MOLE,'' the reality series that returns to ABC Monday at 10 p.m., takes itself more seriously. The guiding principle, however, is the same: Trust no one. Grown men and women are sent on a mission that a saboteur among them is trying to thwart, while Americans everywhere try to identify the mole because, well, ''Idol'' is over.

1962 -- Best Featured Actress in a Play (''Take Her, She's Mine'') I SAW Geraldine Page in ''Sweet Bird of Youth'' in probably 1959 and later saw Kim Stanley in ''A Far Country.'' They rocked my world. I had never seen anything like it. I was one of those kids who was never in community theater. I didn't know if theater was what I wanted to do, but I wanted to try and find out. ... Geraldine Page's performance was like what happened when you saw Brando for the first time. It was so viscerally real. You knew what the character was thinking.

VERY few auction notices that appear in my e-mail inbox catch my eye. But a recent one did that was from Bonhams & Butterfields about a Porsche 908/2 being auctioned on Aug. 15 during the Pebble Beach auto weekend in California. Steve McQueen raced the Porsche in 1970 in the 12 Hours of Sebring, one of the greatest sports stories you've probably never heard of. Mario Andretti won, driving for Ferrari, but the race was an event where even the subplots were tremendous tales, none more intriguing than the driver pairing of the second-place car, McQueen and Peter Revson, a budding Formula One driver. Revson was also an heir to the Revlon cosmetics fortune.

I am visiting Prague this summer with friends. We are all young working professionals who love food and the night life, but don't want anything too expensive. Any suggestions on where to stay, restaurants and good neighborhoods to go out in? -- Kathryn Seifert, Chicago Prague won't let you down for what you're looking for: good food and good night life at a good price. And our archive of past Travel articles and related slide shows on the Prague travel guide of nytimes.com/travel offers more than enough excellent options. In ''36 Hours in Prague'' (March 25, 2007), Evan Rail recommends the Old Town Square and the old Jewish ghetto neighborhoods for exploring and for affordable dining options like Café Savoy (Vitezna 5; 420-257-311-562; www.ambi.cz) and the ''literary cafe'' Tynska literarni kavarna (Tynska 6; 420-224-827-807; www.tynska.cz). To partake in the lively Czech tradition of social swilling, Mr. Rail recommends the club Palac Akropolis (Kubelikova 27; 420-296-330-911; www.palacakropolis.cz); the former speakeasy Blind Eye (Vlkova 26); and Pivovarsky klub (Krizikova 17; 420-222-315-777), a pub with ''around 200 kinds of bottled beers, most of which you'll not see anywhere else.''
