GORDON--Lillian. The Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research (IPTAR) mourns the loss of one of our esteemed founders, Lillian Gordon. President of IPTAR from 1967-1970 and Fellow (Training Analyst and Supervisor), Lillian made invaluable contributions to the development of our Society and Training Institute over many years. A highly regarded member of our faculty and an extraordinarily talented psychoanalyst, she had a deep belief in the ability of psychoanalytic treatment to change the lives of her patients. Her passing is a profound loss to all who have been touched by her. Our heartfelt condolences to her family. Allan Frosch, President, IPTAR

MICHAEL FRIEDMAN, the in-house composer for the CIVILIANS theater troupe, has become the downtown prince of the indie musical, writing the scores to shows about 19th-century American politics (''Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson''), 19th-century Parisian revolutionaries (''Paris Commune'') and 20th-century Brooklynites (''The Fortress of Solitude''). He has, it is safe to say, given voice to some rather eclectic demographics. Now he's written the music and lyrics for a show about evangelical Christians. Scratch that: two musicals about evangelical Christians. There's ''This Beautiful City,'' a Civilians piece about churches in Colorado Springs, which is opening at the Kirk Douglas Theater in Los Angeles this fall and at the Vineyard in New York next year. And there's ''SAVED!,'' in previews at Playwrights Horizons, with an opening set for Tuesday. (Mr. Friedman wrote the music for ''Saved!'' and wrote the lyrics with John Dempsey and Rinne Groff, both of whom also wrote the book).

They sit in cubicles in the sky, at the controls inside an operator's cab 20 or 30 stories above the streets of New York City. They spend their days hooking and hoisting -- even when off-duty, since a number of them unwind by going fishing. They have withstood sudden wind gusts, irate contractors and even lightning strikes, all in a day's work, for a maximum salary of about $60 an hour. They are the city's crane operators. Two deadly construction crane collapses in Manhattan in less than three months -- one that killed seven people on March 15 and another that killed two people on Friday -- have saddened and rattled crane operators, bringing their often unseen, unheralded and misunderstood jobs into the public eye.

As sporting challenges go, hiking the length of the Presidential Range in New Hampshire's White Mountains has serious advantages over most mountaineering endeavors, not least of which is the fact that you can do it in one day. The basics are appealingly straightforward. A little more than two hours from the Manchester, N.H., airport (three from Boston's Logan airport), the Presidential Range stretches in a zigzagging line of peaks, most of them named for former American presidents. At the center, more or less, is 6,288-foot Mount Washington, with the oft-cited distinction of having some of the worst weather in the world. A fair number
2004 -- Best Book of a Musical (''Avenue Q'')

GAZING AT THE KUANG SI WATERFALLS, MARCH 1, 2008 Darrell McDowall, 61, a retired cattle rancher from Byron Bay, Australia, on an exploratory hike just outside Luang Prabang. ''On this trip, I was definitely going from one stage of life to another and dealing with morals and the truth about what love is. And I was being very monkish -- I wasn't drinking and I wasn't packing anything other than my daily bread. I went to Cambodia and up through Laos, up the Mekong and then across to Thailand, and back to my old wat where I was a Buddhist monk in Thailand in the 70s. I was a Vietnam vet so I was always searching for something else after Vietnam, and I had gone into this Buddhist wat. You have to do the Vipassana meditation to become a monk, so I had shaved my head and my eyebrows and we meditated 19 hours a day. I did that for months until the master said 'you're ready,' and then I had to meditate from Monday morning at 4:30 to lunchtime Thursday without sleep. Going back was definitely a spiritual journey for me.'' As told to Austin Considine

In commemoration of Noah Webster's 250th birthday this year, this set of puzzles is presented in high definition. The puzzles owe their inspiration to Webster's pioneering work (or more precisely to his work's direct descendant, Merriam-Webster's Collegiate Dictionary, 11th Edition). To begin, solve the first six puzzles, each of which will give you a six-letter answer. Then follow the instructions for the final puzzle, ''The Last Word,'' to get the answer to the question: Why can a reference librarian afford new dictionaries every year?

THE NEWS After a nine-month, 422-million-mile journey from Earth, NASA's Phoenix spacecraft made a flawless landing on Mars. BEHIND THE NEWS The $420 million mission is to investigate Mars's northern polar region, using a 7.7-foot-long robotic arm to dig into the surface and extract dirt and ice. Scientists have been intrigued with the polar region since NASA's orbiting Odyssey spacecraft in 2002 discovered vast quantities of water-ice lying a few inches below the surface. The landing was captured in a picture taken by the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter passing overhead. ''An engineer's delight,'' one of the scientists said of the photograph.

Travel is often a means of escape, and this year's travel books offer plenty of it. Failed relationships, dead-end jobs and other disappointments infest the current crop like bedbugs in a youth hostel, driving their authors around the globe in search of transformation. The seekers range from bored young drifters to anxiety-stricken middle-agers, motivated by the quixotic hope that cutting loose will stimulate the mind and heal the soul. ''I was ready for Paris,'' Bryce Corbett announces at the beginning of A TOWN LIKE PARIS: Falling in Love in the City of Light (Broadway, paper, $12.95). ''Ready for a change of scene and the shedding of some emotional baggage.'' After a breakup with a longtime girlfriend, the 28-year-old Australian quits his job at Sky News in London and boards the Eurostar for a new life. What follows is a refreshing variation on a shopworn theme: the Anglophone at large in the French capital, coping with the language barrier, inaccessible Gallic women and bad plumbing. Corbett finds a job he isn't ''qualified for, much less interested in,'' lands a hideously furnished flat in the Marais and joins a circle of partygoing fellow expatriates, whom he annoyingly calls the ''Paris Posse.'' It's not quite ''A Moveable Feast,'' and the tone can be smugly self-satisfied, but Corbett's sharp observations lend the tale a dash of élan. Lamenting the decline of Shakespeare and Company into a Left Bank tourist trap, he notes that its ''literary credibility'' has ''long since been replaced by the distinct aroma of upper-middle-class America -- a mixture of Snapple Ice Tea, sweaty Teva sandals and Tommy Hilfiger cologne.'' When Corbett abandons his quest for a French girlfriend and falls in love with an Australian nightclub entertainer he calls ''the Showgirl,'' you can't help wishing him bonne chance.

MOLDAW--Stuart G. March 25, 1927-May 24, 2008, a life-long business entrepreneur, philanthropist and friend to a wide range of civic, charitable and political organizations, died Saturday, May 24, 2008 at age 81. Mr. Moldaw, a loving husband, father and grandfather, is survived by his wife Phyllis, daughters Carol and Susan Moldaw, and four grandchildren. His wife and family were able to be with him during his illness and final hours of life. Mr. Moldaw, a pioneer in the specialty retail and clothing business, founded Ross Dress for Less in 1982 and was a founding investor in The Gymboree Corporation in 1986. Ross Stores is a Fortune 500 company with more than 900 locations, and Gymboree is a leading children's clothing and activity brand with 585 stores in the United States and Canada. Mr. Moldaw served as the Chairman of the Board at Ross Stores for more than a decade, and as Chairman Emeritus, he remained an active board member. He also was Chairman Emeritus of The Gymboree Corporation, and cofounded U.S. Venture Partners, a Menlo Park based venture capital firm. Mr. Moldaw started his first company, Country Casuals, in 1958 in Palo Alto, California, and went on to develop a successful retail presence based on a passion for customer service, a belief in distinctive marketing and a drive for competitive pricing. He was known for his foresight into customer preferences and for recognizing and fostering the strengths of his business partners and associates. Mr. Moldaw was born in Boston, Massachusetts, and spent his childhood in Brookline. His father was a Russian immigrant who came to the United States amid his homelands civil war. In 1944, Mr. Moldaw enlisted in the U.S. Navy and was called to active duty aboard a troop transport ship, the Ulysses S. Grant. After the war, he attended Syracuse University on the G.I. Bill, graduating in 1949 with a bachelor's degree in Marketing and Economics. While attending Syracuse, he met his future wife, Phyllis Israelson of Portland, Maine. They married in August 1950. Soon after graduating college, he went to work for the Le Bon Marche, a department store in Lowell, Massachusetts, and later G. Fox & Co., a specialty department store in Hartford, Connecticut. In 1955, he moved to California to take a job with Lerner Shops, and he went on to open more than 20 Lerner stores during the late 1950s. Always entrepreneurial, he gave his notice at Lerners in the spring of 1959 and struck out entirely on his own. Beyond his business accomplishments, Mr. Moldaw was a great believer in people and what they could accomplish in life. ''He was an unforgettable man a visionary, entrepreneur, leader and philanthropist,'' said Norman Ferber, chairman of Ross Stores. Mr. Moldaw served on the boards of many San Francisco Bay Area non-profit groups, including the Moldaw-Zaffaroni Boys and Girls Club of East Palo Alto, REDF, Communities in Schools, the Jewish Community Endowment Fund and the Palo Alto Medical Foundation. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, The San Francisco Ballet and KQED, and a leading supporter of 899 Charleston, a seniors living center in Palo Alto. In politics, he was a longtime, active Democrat who was appointed by President Clinton as a Public Delegate to the U.S. Mission at the United Nations in 1993 and as Chairman of the White House Commission on Presidential Scholars in 1996. In 2000, Gov. Gray Davis appointed Mr. Moldaw to chair California's World Trade Commission, and two years later to a serve as commissioner on the states Little Hoover Commission. In 2006, Mr. Moldaw captured his personal story in a book titled A Life Story For My Grandchildren. He wrote: ''My greatest happiness came not from money and possessions but from engagements, accomplish ments, challenges, the camaraderie with the people I have met along the way, and the love of my family. I also hope that my grandchildren will come to understand the joy of helping their less fortunate fellows to fulfill their dreams. We can do so much to make the world a better place. The advantage of financial wellbeing can make a person indulgent, rob him of the true measure of meaningful accomplishment and allow him to live a shallow life; or it can give him the ability to make a difference in the world that cries out for compassion, action and commitment.'' Mr. Moldaw's family is planning a private service. A memorial celebration of his life will take place at a later date. The family requests that any memorial gifts be made to The Moldaw-Zaffaroni Boys and Girls Club of East Palo Alto, Eastside College Preparatory School, The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, and The Jewish Community Federation of San Francisco.

WIGTON--Richard Benson, II , 77, died May 29, 2008 of complications from a fall in December. He was born in Albany, NY the son of Nutting and Jenette Torrey Wigton of Loudonville, NY. He attended Lawrenceville School in Lawrenceville, NJ from its earliest form and graduated in 1949. He graduated from Hamilton College in Clinton, NY in 1953. Mr. Wigton joined Kidder Peabody in 1956. He became Managing Director and served on the Management Committee and The Board of Directors of Kidder Peabody. Mr. Wigton managed various trading operations at Kidder Peabody. His entire career was spent at Kidder Peabody which he thoroughly enjoyed. He retired in 1989. After living and raising their family in Summit, NJ, the Wigtons moved to Vero Beach, FL and also had a home in Morristown, NJ. He belonged to John's Island Club and Redstick Golf Club in Vero Beach, Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, NJ and Dorset Field Club in Dorset, Vermont. Mr. Wigton leaves his wife of 54 years, Cynthia Kain Wigton. He also leaves his children, Nancy Foster Wigton of Chatham, NJ; Richard Benson Wigton, III and his wife, Nancy of Centennial, CO and Suzanne Wigton Booth and her husband James of Denver, CO. Also three grandchildren Richard, Conner and Sarah Wigton of Centennial, CO. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Lawrenceville School or the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. A memorial service will be Wednesday, June 4th, at Calvary Episcopal Church, 31 Woodland Ave, Summit, NJ, 11am.

You can have your Kentucky Derby and all its ersatz tradition and dubious charm (the last time the world saw so many loud, boozy people in funny hats, the Vikings were sacking Irish monasteries). The season's best horse racing experience, for my money, is the Travers Stakes, held each August in Saratoga Springs, a placid little spa town in upstate New York. The Travers, known to the horsy set as the Midsummer Derby and regarded by some as the fourth leg of the Triple Crown, is where the racing season hits the quarter pole, and the event reliably draws a handful of the best 3-year-olds in the land. There's wonderful history here: it's the country's oldest major thoroughbred race, run in one of the country's oldest major sporting venues (a gorgeous one, at that) -- and it is nothing less than the quintessence of horse racing, the sport of kings and scoundrels alike. Some background: Saratoga Race Track was the brainchild of John ''Old Smoke'' Morrissey, a Tammany Hall hack who allegedly masterminded the killing of New York's infamous gang lord Bill the Butcher. Under Morrissey's stewardship, and with financing from the New York stockbroker William Travers, Saratoga hosted its first thoroughbred meeting in 1863, and the first Travers Stakes was run the following year. In the 1921 Travers, in a two-horse race, a colt named Sporting Blood upset the heavy favorite, Prudery -- a result that might be regarded less suspiciously had a third horse not mysteriously scratched and had Sporting Blood's owner, Arnold Rothstein, not been accused of fixing the 1919 World Series. ''Saratoga is the wickedest spot in the United States,'' wrote the journalist Nellie Bly, where ''gamblers, horse owners, jockeys, millionaires and actors mingle together promiscuously.''

Just before Germany invaded the Netherlands in May 1940, Amsterdam's pre-eminent art dealer, Jacques Goudstikker, who was Jewish, escaped by ship with his wife and young son. He died in a shipboard fall, and the fortune in fine art he left behind was possessed by the Nazi leader Hermann Göring. In 2006 the Dutch government returned 200 paintings from the Goudstikker collection to their rightful heir, Marei von Saher, the widow of the dealer's son and a resident of Greenwich, Conn. How great was the Goudstikker collection? Pretty great, judging by a beautiful display of 40 paintings included in ''RECLAIMED: PAINTINGS FROM THE COLLECTION OF JACQUES GOUDSTIKKER,'' at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich. A specialist in northern Baroque art, Mr. Goudstikker sold paintings not only to Dutch and other European museums but also to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Art Institute of Chicago and to Andrew Mellon for the National Gallery of Art in Washington. Dating mostly from the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries, the paintings in the exhibition all look like pieces those institutions would still have on their wish lists.

Looked at one way, music is all about space: the space between notes in time, which allows for rhythm, or the space between them in pitch, which creates the basic condition for harmony. A piece of music can also render the concept of space. (See Holst, Gustav, and ''The Planets.'') You can ponder these thoughts on Sunday afternoon while listening to the AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA, conducted by Leon Botstein, at Lincoln Center. Mr. Botstein and his band of fine New York-area freelancers are presenting a program titled ''Spatial Explorations.'' The tone of the afternoon will tend toward the eerie. The program consists of Toru Takemitsu's ''Cassiopeia''; Andrzej Panufnik's Symphony No. 5, ''Symphony of the Spheres''; Rued Langgaard's ''Music of the Spheres''; and two works by Gyorgy Ligeti, ''Apparitions'' and ''Atmosphères.'' The Panufnik and Langgaard pieces are receiving their American premieres, according to the orchestra's Web site. At 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, americansymphony.org; $27 to $55.

When I think of home, I think of the index-card reminder that arrives in the mailbox each month with the words ''FIRST WEDNESDAY'' scribbled in Magic Marker. If we lived in a small town in Iowa, or in Pennsylvania Dutch country, the freewheeling potluck dinner that has been held on our block on the first Wednesday of every month for the past 18 years might not seem like such big a deal. But this is Oakland, Calif. Our first inkling that something unusual might be up on the block came only weeks after we moved into the house with the big redwood tree in 2001. Dazed migrants from New York, we were surrounded by a sea of boxes on Sept. 11, watching the horrific news on the TV parked on the floor. At some point, the doorbell rang. It was our neighbors Bissie and Jerry Miller, whom we'd never met, bearing four glasses and a bottle of vodka.

Private services will be held. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Alzheimer's Association.

For the past couple of decades, I have pursued an irregular and not entirely legal summer pastime: I have attempted to swim across every body of water I happen upon as I travel throughout the United States. The quest began near my home in Oregon, on a highway that passed so close to a lake it seemed you could dive in from the guardrails. The water's black skin was still; it bore reflections of the rocks on the banks. I pulled over and swam in my shorts, the traffic roaring each time I came up for air.

OUTPOSTS There are people with us still who remember the Great Plains in its birthday suit. Once, the grassland spanned at least 14 states, from Minnesota to Texas, the second biggest ecosystem in North America. It's gone because the grass was overturned and the bison were chased off the land and the riot of biodiversity that had evolved over 10,000 years was replaced by a few commodity crops to feed us. It's not worth arguing over whether this was a good or a bad thing, because most of the intentions were good, even if the excesses were bad. But it's always worthwhile to wonder whether humans can fix what they messed up.

CEDAR LAKE CONTEMPORARY BALLET and its artistic director, Benoit-Swan Pouffer, have not received quite enough credit for bringing to New York a number of little-seen choreographers, often already popular in Europe, and commissioning them to create new work. In January the troupe offered pieces from Jacopo Godani, Stijn Celis and Crystal Pite; none were very well known here, but Ms. Pite in particular was a distinctive new voice. And starting Monday the company's spring season offers another intriguing batch of dances: a new work, ''Sunday, Again,'' by the Norwegian choreographer Jo Stromgren; Angelin Preljocaj's ''Annonciation,'' an important work in his career; and a reprise of ''Lasting Imprint,'' a piece created for Cedar Lake by Nicolo Fonte in 2006. Mr. Preljocaj is the best known of the bunch, but even his work is infrequently seen in New York. In his native France ''L'Annonciation,'' a 1995 piece for two women, is one of his more popular pieces; it's in the repertory of the Paris Opera Ballet and other companies. Set to fragments of Vivaldi's ''Magnificat'' and an electronic score by Stéphane Roy, it offers a lyrical, sensuous account of the encounter between Mary and the Angel Gabriel that shows Mr. Preljocaj's ability to evoke intense emotion through a vivid physicality. Mr. Stromgren is more of an unknown quantity, but we can always hope -- at a time when ballet companies almost universally play it safe -- that discovery is at hand.

CLOSE--Major General Winton, R. ''Now cracks a noble heart...'' Major General Winton R. Close, US Air Force, Retired, died in Bluffton, South Carolina, May 23, 2008 after 90 years of service to his Country and devotion to his family. A command pilot with more than 7000 flying hours to his credit, General Close was born in Columbus, Ohio and raised in New York City and Los Angeles. This graduate of Beverly Hills High School and Stanford University joined the Army Air Corps in 1939, earned his wings and commission at Kelly Field, Texas, and subsequently went on to a distinguished military career which included flying ''the hump'' in the China-Burma-India theater as a B-29 squadron commander and leading B-29s out of the Mariana Islands as a group operations officer in 1945. General Close returned from World War II after 600 combat hours and 35 missions. In 1952 he commanded the 98th Bomb Wing at Yokota Air Base, Japan where he flew 21 more combat missions over Korea. During the Cold War the General played an integral role in the Strategic Air Command and Operation Looking Glass. His career culminated with his command of JT2 at Sandia Base, New Mexico, working directly under the Joint Chiefs. The General retired in 1968, and moved with his wife, the former Joan Millsop of Weirton, West Virginia, to Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, where this former college polo and tennis player found time to express his athleticism as a Champion golfer. General Close was preceded in death by his wife of 55 years in 1998. He is survived by his four daughters: Leslie Joan Close of Bellevale, NY; Christine Campbell of Colorado Springs; Joey Close Baffico of Montclair, NJ; Barbara Vote of Hillsboro, Oregon; and, five grandchildren. The General's ashes were interred on Hilton Head Island on May 30, 2008. ''Good night, sweet prince, And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.''

WHEN it comes to active couples, especially in warm weather, presents like outdoor games or sports equipment easily trump china place settings and other housewares. For a winning gift, consider a pair of folding bicycles -- one pink, one silver, perhaps -- that can transport newlyweds down wooded trails and dusty lanes and then be stored in a closet, even in the smallest apartment.

The federal government is showering households with tax rebates to spur spending and invigorate a troubled economy. But many Americans are so consumed with debt and the soaring price of gasoline that they are opting to save the money or use it to pay bills, according to surveys, sales data and interviews with people from Florida to California. Between late April and the end of last week, the Treasury handed out more than $50 billion of the $100 billion in tax rebates it plans to distribute to 132 million households. But only once in the last six weeks have chain stores registered an increase in sales, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers, whose weekly sales survey is a widely watched barometer.

In the annals of role reversal, the switch by the United Nations' atomic sleuths in Vienna and the American intelligence community has been striking. Having long taken a back seat to the Bush administration in publicly challenging Iran's nuclear program, the global inspectors last week moved into the driver's seat, demanding that Tehran come clean on any progress it has made toward building a bomb. What gives?

RICHMAN--Saul , of Pinehurst, NC at 90; born Philadelphia, PA April 19, 1918. Predeceased by his beloved wife of 64 years, Ruby Olive Richman. Leaves behind sons Ted (Terry) and Joe, daughter Ruth (Kenny MacDonald), granddaughter Lisa, grandson Matt, and niece Ellen Love. Worked his way through Penn State University graduating with a degree in journalism. Attended University of California, Berkley, later becoming editor of The Napa Valley Register where he met his future wife, a teacher in Healdsburg. Became an editor of radio news at the Associated Press in San Francisco, moving with them to Salt Lake City and NYC. He then joined the Rockefeller family organization providing Public Relations advice for the family until he moved to the Council on Foundations which published his Public Information Handbook for Foundations. He enjoyed sailing, classical music, reading and fishing and was a daily reader of the NY Times. Private family services. Donations may be made to: United Jewish Communities, P.O. Box 30, Old Chelsea Station, NY, NY 10113

JOHNSON--Keith N. , aged 62, mathematician, economist and longtime resident of Lower Manhattan died suddenly and unexpectedly on May 11, 2008. Born May 30, 1945 to Robert and Helen Johnson, Keith was raised in Joliet, Illinois, graduated from Harvard University and pursued postgraduate studies at the Universities of Chicago and Pennsylvania where he received a Ph.D. in Economics from the Wharton School in 1979. Keith taught economics at Columbia and NYU and worked in the advisory groups of Townsend-Greenspan & Co., JP Morgan and Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. He ''retired'' in 1996, the better to pursue more theoretical interests in mathematics/econometrics and an equivalent passion for apartment/house remodeling and electric system design applied, in a tradition passed down from his father, for the benefit of family and friends. Keith was a remarkable individual, smart and compassionate well beyond the ordinary. He impacted many lives. He loved, he was loved and he will be missed. Keith is survived by his companion Kathryn Cruze, four brothers, Kent, Carl, Theodore and Glen (Deborah), a sister Ellen (Tim) Johnson-Caspar, two sons Jamil and Omar (Beth) Albertelli, an aunt, Betty Neiswender, numerous beloved nephews, nieces and grandchildren, Aria and Sarina.

SMITH--Alfred B., born in Virginia on June 29, 1925, made his transition on May 24, 2008. He is survived by his second wife Osceola Davis-Smith, his three daughters, Andrea, Linley, Diana, his son-in-law, Tony, two grandsons, Christopher and Ian, along with numerous friends and associates.

A caption with an article last Sunday about the Nintendo video-game designer Shigeru Miyamoto misidentified the character from the Zelda series shown. It is Link, not Zelda.

LOOKING out the window to see who was at the bird feeder, I noticed buds on the Carolina jessamine. It was one of the first things I had planted in the garden; when I found it at the nursery, I was transported back to an island off the Georgia coast where it climbed high into the trees, perfuming the air and showering me with golden petals. That was eight years ago, and it had never bloomed. I rushed outside to be sure, and, yes, there were quite a few delicate pale yellow buds. I was thrilled, but eight years is a long time, and that thought brought a faint chill to the bright spring afternoon. Time hovers over me and the garden. Time does that a lot these days.

Wade Stadium, Duluth, Minn.: ''Is there a better place on the planet to watch a ballgame?'' asks Kevin Reichard of the indispensable ballparkdigest.com, where you can find reviews of more than 150 professional, minor-league and amateur baseball fields. One of the last Works Progress Administration parks still standing, the Wade, as it's known, was restored in the 1990s and retains its simple brick-and-concrete charms. The stadium is home to the Duluth Huskies of the Northwoods League, a college-level wood-bat circuit, and true to its egalitarian roots, there isn't a bad seat in the house. duluthhuskies.com. Modern Woodmen Park, Davenport, Iowa: One of the oldest baseball stadiums still in use, Modern Woodmen opened in 1931 and, despite several renovations, is still very much of its place: barges drift down the Mississippi just beyond the fences, and you can smell the water from the park. A home run to right could very well find the river, thus raising the possibility that a ball hit in Iowa will settle somewhere near the Yucatan. riverbandits.com.

Forget the rites of spring. Give me the rites of late summer. July marks the start of N.F.L. training camp, the first opportunity to comfortably act like a football fanatic. It is at camp, before the N.F.L. enters its grandiose regular-season mode, that the game can be enjoyed in a more casual setting. Players are housed in the dorms of small colleges like the Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology in Terre Haute, Ind. On check-in day, quarterback and lineman alike arrive lugging pillows and TV sets. After a few days of sequestration, the undergraduate impulse kicks in, and some rookie will inevitably try to break curfew. If you should happen to run into him at the local bar, so much the better. It is this rare sense of intimacy that always drove me to make the trip to camp. As a kid, I watched the Dallas Cowboys train in Thousand Oaks, Calif. Before the morning drills, I would station myself near the locker room and pester star players with impunity. After practice, we kids would typically get to lug the players' helmets back to the locker room. I once asked the second-string kicker if I could do him the honor, and he gave me a weak, almost apologetic smile. He hadn't expected to make the roster, much less get valet service.

FITTINGLY, Josh Sparks, the owner of the once moribund clothing line Imitation of Christ (the label that infamously held a fashion show in a funeral parlor) has been pondering resurrection. ''It's such a revolutionary concept,'' he enthused. ''Especially when put in a secular context. How would it look economically, politically, environmentally?'' Such is the subject of a photo exhibition at the National Arts Club, for which Mr. Sparks asked 11 artists, from the established (Mark Borthwick) to the emerging (Hanna Liden, Martina Hoogland Ivanow), to explore the idea of resurrection, the only guideline being that they include a piece of the clothing. ''There was no commercial objective -- they could cut it up if they wanted to,'' he said. ''The point was to start a dialogue about where we are and where we're going.''

GORDON--Lillian . The Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research (IPTAR) mourns the loss of one of our esteemed founders, Lillian Gordon. President of IPTAR from 1967-1970 and Fellow (Training Analyst and Supervisor), Lillian made invaluable contributions to the development of our Society and Training Institute over many years. A highly regarded member of our faculty and an extraordinarily talented psychoanalyst, she had a deep belief in the ability of psychoanalytic treatment to change the lives of her patients. Her passing is a profound loss to all who have been touched by her. Our heartfelt condolences to her family. Allan Frosch, President, IPTAR

WIGTON--Richard Benson, II, 77, died May 29, 2008 of complications from a fall in December. He was born in Albany, NY the son of Nutting and Jenette Torrey Wigton of Loudonville, NY. He attended Lawrenceville School in Lawrenceville, NJ from its earliest form and graduated in 1949. He graduated from Hamilton College in Clinton, NY in 1953. Mr. Wigton joined Kidder Peabody in 1956. He became Managing Director and served on the Management Committee and The Board of Directors of Kidder Peabody. Mr. Wigton managed various trading operations at Kidder Peabody. His entire career was spent at Kidder Peabody which he thoroughly enjoyed. He retired in 1989. After living and raising their family in Summit, NJ, the Wigtons moved to Vero Beach, FL and also had a home in Morristown, NJ. He belonged to John's Island Club and Redstick Golf Club in Vero Beach, Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, NJ and Dorset Field Club in Dorset, Vermont. Mr. Wigton leaves his wife of 54 years, Cynthia Kain Wigton. He also leaves his children, Nancy Foster Wigton of Chatham, NJ; Richard Benson Wigton, III and his wife, Nancy of Centennial, CO and Suzanne Wigton Booth and her husband James of Denver, CO. Also three grandchildren Richard, Conner and Sarah Wigton of Centennial, CO. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Lawrenceville School or the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. A memorial service will be Wednesday, June 4th, at Calvary Episcopal Church, 31 Woodland Ave, Summit, NJ, 11am.

THE Italian entrepreneur Alberto Moretti, who recently revived the Tuscan leather-goods brand Arfango, claims to have many crazy ideas. His latest: a line of velvet loafers honoring his friend Lapo Elkann. As the story goes, Mr. Elkann, the Fiat heir, took such a liking to the Arfango slip-ons that he wore them all around Paris Fashion Week in February. Mr. Moretti, in return, had the shoes produced with an inscription on the sole: ''Dedicated to my friend Lapo Elkann by Alberto Moretti.'' The shoes will be sold in 33 shops worldwide, each in a limited supply of 33 pairs. Why 33? ''It's just another crazy idea,'' Mr. Moretti explained. Lapo's shoes, $450, available in the United States only at Barneys New York.

ROTH--Marjorie Englander , a loving wife, sister, mother and grandmother who lived in New York City, Coronado, California, Westhampton and Larchmont, New York passed away Wednesday morning. She was 84 years old. Married to Harold Roth on June 22, 1941 in New Rochelle, New York, she graduated from Hunter College. She was a beloved kindergarten teacher at the Chatsworth Avenue School in Larchmont, New York. Married for 67 years, she is survived by her husband, Harold Roth, a leading executive with Grosset & Dunlap, Simon & Schuster and Pocket Books, Inc. book publishers; a daughter, Joan Roth Saffa and her husband Dr. Robert Saffa; two sons, Dr. Richard Roth and his wife Jane and Peter Roth and his wife Andrea; her brother, Roger Englander and his wife Simone; and her seven grandchildren, Jason, Aaron and Lauren Saffa; David, Michael, Erica and Brian Roth. Private services will be held. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Alzheimer's Association.

LIEBMANN--John E. , 88 years old, died May 30th, 2008 at home. Beloved husband of Ellin Tiefenthal Liebmann for 64 years, devoted father of Kathryn and John Jr.; wonderful father-in-law of Milagros Santiago Liebmann and step-grandfather of Elvin Flores. John, a native New Yorker attended Lincoln School in Manhattan where he made lifelong friends. He graduated from Brown University in 1941 and enlisted shortly thereafter in the US Army serving as an officer in the 272nd Field Artillery Battalion in Europe where he was awarded the Bronze Star. From 1946-1964 he worked at Liebmann Breweries, brewers of Rheingold Beer. Later he was for many years Director of the New York Office of the Brown University Development Department where he played a major role in the University's first large capital campaign. For more than 60 years he was a loyal and distinguished alumnus in a variety of volunteer and staff roles. He also assisted Tougaloo College in Jackson, Mississippi with their fundraising. In retirement he volunteered with the Court Monitors program through the Manhattan District Attorney's Office and was a longtime student at Marymount College. He lived a life of ''usefulness and reputation.'' In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Police Athletic League or Brown University.

In a recent column, Nick describes the links between China's brutal environmental tolls and its economic boom. While the government is working to curb pollution, dirty air and tainted water persist. Readers responded by sharing stories about brown air, smog clouds and bronchial issues, as well as suggesting that the situation calls for international cooperation. In the Chinese media, environmental news of the moment includes the ban ("限塑令") prohibiting shops from giving out free plastic shopping bags that went into effect on June 1. Reactions have been warm, with one report from Xinhua news agency finding that most people are feeling confident about environmental protection ("大部分市民表现出的态度让人对 '环保' 充满信心").

According to a series of blog posts on The Huffington Post by Laura Vanderkam, a new type of outsourcing is sweeping dual-income households around the country, and it has a lot to do with sweeping (or not sweeping) the floors. The first post describes what Ms. Vanderkam refers to as the core competency mom, who manages to both have a job and a career by focusing her limited time at home on tasks that give her the most time with her children. As she puts it, "Going on a hike with your teenage children on a Saturday is a better way to show you care than washing their jeans." As for the floor sweeping -- that falls into the category of stuff that is either outsourced or ignored by the core competency mother.

The Red Wings are hoping to turn tonight's Game 5 at Joe Louis Arena into their coronation with the hoisting of their fourth Cup in 11 years. The Penguins are trying to mess up that plan, but as this series goes along, they are looking more and more like the Edmonton Oilers of 1983. That is the young, ridiculously talented team that, before they could dominate the rest of the '80s, took a drubbing in the Cup final from a proud, aging Islanders dynasty.

Betsey Armstrong is the goalkeeper for the U.S.A. women's water polo team, which is favored to win the gold medal in the Olympics this summer. Armstrong is an Ann Arbor, Mich., native and a 2005 Michigan graduate who helped Team U.S.A. win gold at the 2007 Pan American Games. She'll be writing occasional posts for the Rings blog in the buildup to the Olympics.

Bloomberg is playing host to a party at Gracie Mansion to kick off New York City Internet Week -- "a weeklong festival of events saluting New York's thriving Internet industry and the many talented companies, organizations and innovators creating the future of online media!"

Starting today, McLaren will be reporting for The Moment from Switzerland's Art Basel fair where he is unveiling "Shallow (1-21)," a series of "Musical Paintings," as part of a special curated section entitled Art Basel Projects.

Two years after James E. Hansen, the leading climate scientist at NASA, and other agency employees described a pattern of distortion and suppression of climate science by political appointees, the agency's inspector general has concluded that such activities occurred and were "inconsistent" with the law that established the space program 50 years ago.

With one swoop, City Councilman Simcha Felder changed the dynamics of two contests that are shaping up to be among the most competitive in next year's elections: races for New York City comptroller and Brooklyn's 21st State Senate District seat.Viewed for many months as an all-but-declared candidate for the comptroller's position, Mr. Felder announced this morning that he will seek the Democratic nomination for the State Senate, taking on a three-time incumbent, and a fellow council member who is also vying for the post.

Regis Philbin made a promising return to prime-time television on Sunday as the host of a new game show, "Million Dollar Password." The series, an updated version of the classic game show in which contestants team up with celebrity guests to win a million dollars, attracted the night's largest audience, 10.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. Today's Times reports on "Garfield Minus Garfield," which strips away everybody in the "Garfield" comic strip except for Jon Arbuckle, the main human. Without the cutesy thought-bubbles of his lasagna-loving cat, Jon's observations seem to teeter between existential crisis and deep despair. (Originally in the first strip below, for example, Garfield kept Jon company in all three panels. In the middle one, Garfield thinks, "Oh sure," and then in the third: "There's the one about the 12-foot chocolate éclair ...") Jim Davis, "Garfield's" creator, says he's flattered rather than peeved by the imitation. Read more ...

Does anyone understand why "What Happened," Scott McClellan's Book of Non-Revelation, has caused such a ruckus? Pro-war Republicans get to yelp about his disloyalty (as Gail Collins pointed out, it's not as if they could argue with his thesis), while antiwar Democrats get to say, not for the last time, "We told you so."

He has been answering questions about how New York City and its residents can fight poverty, and how to help low-wage, working Americans who are increasingly marginalized by the global economy. We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

Another day, another banking defenestration. This time, it was G. Kennedy Thompson of Wachovia who was shown the door. His exit from the Charlotte banking giant inevitably raises one question: Who will take his place?

Olympics organizers have announced they will revise the English-language manual for volunteers after it drew criticism for portraying disabled athletes and visitors as "introverted," "unsocial," "stubborn," and "controlling." The guide, distributed to 100,000 volunteers for the Games, drew strong criticism last week for its advice on how to assist the disabled, whom it called "defensive" and with "a strong sense of inferiority," but organizers have since expressed their "deepest apologies."

Tavern on the Green, the restaurant on the western edge of Central Park, has agreed to pay $2.2 million to settle a racial discrimination lawsuit filed last fall by the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. In a news release announcing the settlement, the commission said on Monday that Tavern on the Green had "engaged in severe and pervasive sexual, racial and national origin harassment of female, black and Hispanic employees."

Game 5 of the Stanley Cup final goes tonight with Detroit having a chance to win their 11th championship. Their 10 ranks third in the NHL behind the Canadiens (24, including one prior to the formation of the NHL) and the Leafs (who last won the Cup when Canada had a prime minister who was born in the 19th century).
(Everett Collection)

I took some time yesterday to read "The Laws of Simplicity," by John Maeda, an MIT technologist (his word, not mine) who can actually write. The book is about a hundred pages long, and while I don't recommend you rush out and buy it (it's all on the Web site), and besides it's extremely simple stuff -- as it should be), there was one section that really struck me as being relevant to cooking, at least the style of cooking in which I'm interested.

A state judge sentenced Jack Jordan, the man convicted of stalking the actress Uma Thurman, to three years probation on Monday, ordering Mr. Jordan to receive psychiatric treatment but declining a request by prosecutors to jail Mr. Jordan for up to a year, the maximum penalty. [See update.]

Following through on a campaign promise, Prime Minister Kevin Rudd of Australia is withdrawing all his country's combat troops from Iraq. At a low-key ceremony on Sunday, troops lowered an Australian flag at Camp Terendak, an American-run base in the southern part of the country, to symbolize the departure of 550 Australian troops. The country still has 1,000 soldiers deployed in Afghanistan.

34 Days to L'Étape. Today is a day off after two long, hilly rides north of the city on Saturday (60 miles) and Sunday (70 miles). Rode alone on Saturday, across the George Washington Bridge and up, in pouring rain, what local cyclists call River Road, which includes a 1.5 mile climb up a 7% grade hill near Alpine, N.J. Chanel was born in 1883, Dior in 1905. At his death, Saint Laurent was 71: do the math.

Federal, state and city officials have reached an agreement with the owners of Starrett City, a 34-year-old housing complex on Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn, that would allow the sale of the 140-acre, 5,881-unit enclave under guidelines while ensuring that it remains a haven of housing affordable to working-class and middle-class families, Charles V. Bagli reports.

The first week of June 2008 may be one for the history books, either because it could be when Senator Barack Obama all but wraps up the Democratic presidential nomination after Tuesday's primaries in Montana and South Dakota, or, when Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton decides to make a game-changing decision -- to continue fighting for a while longer.

TPG has agreed to take a 23 percent stake in Bradford & Bingley, the troubled British mortgage lender, for 179 million pounds ($353 million). Bradford & Bingley also said Monday that it slashed the price of a proposed rights offerings; its stock plunged as much as 32 percent.

Cerberus Capital Management is hardly the only one feeling the pain from the troubles at Chrysler and GMAC. According to a report in The Financial Times, the buyout firm sold "significantly" more than half its equity in those two businesses shortly after winning control of them.

G. Kennedy Thompson, the head of Wachovia, on Monday became the latest banking executive to be shown the door during the credit squeeze, as Wachovia's board requested that he step down amid a stock slide and a series of losses.

Appaloosa Management is getting hit from multiple angles in its attempt to walk away from the deal they struck with auto parts maker Delphi. Appaloosa, a hedge-fund firm, is not only being sued by Delphi, but now creditors of Delphi are seeking to intervene on the case, HedgeCo.Net reports.

Angry investors in an embattled $650 million Greenwich, Conn. hedge fund sued last week to take control of the fund from Philip and Alan Milton, the brother investment team that had steered the fund through many years of fat returns before it hit trouble in 2007.
New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo will get his last chance Tuesday to have four key charges reinstated to the blockbuster lawsuit against former New York Stock Exchange chieftain Richard Grasso.
Former Yahoo and Warner Bros. Entertainment chief, Terry Semel, plans to make a run at acquiring private-equity investor Teddy Forstmann's IMG marketing and talent agency, The New York Post reported.
French engineering group Alstom on Monday denied a newspaper report it was mulling a tie-up with British aero engine and turbines group Rolls-Royce.

Investors don't often get a peek inside the vast, opaque and unregulated world of credit default swaps, those privately traded insurance contracts that essentially allow participants to bet on or against a debt issuer's financial condition. (Remember, these are the same instruments that played such a pivotal role in the collapse of Bear Stearns.)
When the Walt Disney Company bought its rival, Pixar, in 2006 for $7.4 billion, many people assumed the deal would play out like most big media takeovers: abysmally.
Arrow Energy said it no longer needs to spin off its overseas coal seam gas operations now that it has reached a deal for an investment from Royal Dutch Shell.
Société Générale announced Friday that it would replace its head of investment banking, Jean-Pierre Mustier, in the latest effort to restore a reputation badly bruised by a massive trading scandal.
Ending years of wrangling, the German Parliament on Friday voted to sell a stake in Deutsche Bahn, the former state railroad monopoly that is now a logistics company.
On June 9, shares in Kenyan mobile service provider Safaricom will begin trading on the Nairobi Stock Exchange, in the biggest initial public offering ever in sub-Saharan Africa.
An investor group led by NBC Universal and two private equity firms appeared to be leading the bidding for the Weather Channel, as final offers were due Friday night, The New York Times reported.

A former Credit Suisse investment banker convicted of insider trading was sentenced to 10 years in prison by a judge who said Wall Street professionals were failing to understand that it was a serious crime to cheat in the markets.

The group that oversees the London interbank offered rate will implement no changes in the way it is set, confounding critics who said the rate, known as Libor, had become unreliable as a gauge of the cost of borrowing.
When Kirk Wright was found dead last weekend, suspended from a rope improvised from bedsheets in his jail cell, the book seemed all but complete on a tale of greed and betrayal.
Goldman Sachs on Monday announced two new co-heads to its investment banking group for Asia excluding Japan, highlighting a shifting of talent by Western banks to Asia.

Origin Energy, Australia's biggest producer of gas from coal seams, said Sunday that it remained open to further talks with BG Group after rejecting its sweetened 13.6 billion Australian dollar ($13 billion) takeover offer last week.

Sourcefire, a network security company, has had a rough go of it on the Nasdaq since going public in March. Now, private-equity-backed Barracuda wants to end its run.
All remaining stores of bankrupt gadget retailer Sharper Image will be closed and liquidated, its new owners said on Sunday.

Centro Properties Group, one of Australia's biggest casualties of the global credit crunch, won more time to repay about 2.8 billion Australian dollars ($2.67 billion) in debt, sparking a rally in its shares on Monday.
The New York Mercantile Exchange has pushed back a meeting with members unhappy over the terms of a $9 billion merger with the CME Group.

KSL Capital Partners, a U.S. buyout firm that counts golf-course operator Clubcorp among its investments, is one of half a dozen suitors to have submitted initial offers for British fitness club chain Esporta last week, The Times of London reported.

An Indian media conglomerate that owns The Times of India, the world's largest-circulation English newspaper, has agreed to buy Virgin Radio Holdings for 53.2 million pounds ($105 million) in its first foreign acquisition.

China Telecom and its state parent will pay more than $14 billion to buy a wireless network owned by the China Unicom group, entering a lucrative mobile arena in the first deal reached under Beijing's sweeping overhaul of the world's largest telecommunications industry, according to a report.
Silverjet on Friday became the third business-class-only airline in just six months to cease operations, unable to cope with rising fuel costs or attract new financing.

India's Sterlite Industries on Saturday agreed to buy the operating assets of bankrupt copper miner Asarco for $2.6 billion, the latest in the series of overseas acquisitions by Indian firms.

The story in today's column about the United Mine Workers comes from an old paper by John Taylor, Union wage settlements during a disinflation. What I really like about that paper is the concreteness: economists often talk about how expectations of inflation get embedded in price- and wage-setting, but don't offer direct evidence that this is happening. Taylor, however, had the goods: you can actually see the wage settlements, and you can even see the difference between settlements with and without escalator clauses.

The news wires are buzzing with reports that the media monster known as Brangelina is settling into the south of France. Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie and their rapidly expanding brood have apparently signed a 3-year lease on the 35-bedroom, 880-acre estate known as Chateau Miraval.
It is safe to say that when the Council of Fashion Designers of America gives Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg its annual award, it will not be for his groundbreaking clothing selections.

Regulators and racing authorities are making headway in their efforts to curb the sport's seemingly insatiable appetite for drugs, Bill Finley writes in Monday's Times, but when Big Brown and his rivals compete in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, horse racing will still be in the midst of its steroid era.

Two weeks into this post-grunge band’s reunion tour, Scott Weiland, the lead singer, seemed bedraggled and bushed, like a scarecrow.

It remains uncertain whether Florida and Michigan delegates will get a full vote, and whether the Clinton campaign will challenge the decision.
A Swedish maker of beds that cost up to $65,000 has launched a campaign that celebrates its products as fashionable luxury goods.
Never before have so many states played a role in the nominating process, but in the end, will this year’s calendar be judged a success? Most Democrats think not.
Manager Willie Randolph began a weeklong homestand in danger of being fired, but left town for an overnight flight to the West Coast with five victories in his last six games.
Jay Haas shot a six-under 65 to repeat as champion of the Principal Charity Classic in West Des Moines, Iowa, and move into first place on the Champions Tour money list.

Jason Taylor, a six-time Pro Bowl defensive end, says he wants to play one more season, even if it is with the Dolphins. Taylor denied reports Sunday that he demanded to be traded from Miami, but he said for the first time that if Miami wanted to move him, he would be receptive. “Do I want to be here?” he said. “Yeah, I’d love to be here. I would love to be a Dolphin and win games and have it work out for everybody. But that may not be the case.”.

Jackie Vasquez hit a three-run homer in the third inning, leading Arizona State to a 3-1 victory against Alabama and its first trip to the Women’s College World Series finals, in Oklahoma City. In the best-of-three championship, which begins Monday, the Sun Devils will face fifth-seeded Texas A&M, which beat top-seeded Florida, 1-0.

A dance review on Thursday about “The ’80s and ’90s on Screen,” part of the Somewhere Out There spring festival presented by Movement Research, using information in the program, misstated the title of a 1984 solo by Ishmael Houston-Jones that was shown. It is “f/i/s/s/i/o/n/i/n/g” not “f/i/s/s/i/o/n/i/n/8.”.
NATIONAL.

An article on Saturday about attorneys general from 10 states asking the California Supreme Court to stay its decision legalizing same-sex marriages misstated the given name of the governor of New York, who last week ordered state agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed elsewhere. He is David A. Paterson, not James.

An article on Tuesday about the growth of women’s wrestling at small, private institutions referred imprecisely to the location of Menlo College, which has had a team since 2001. It is in Atherton, Calif., in the San Francisco Bay Area — not in San Francisco.

An article in some editions last Monday about the consecration of the first major Hindu temple on Staten Island misidentified the geographical region that is the home of Rajiv S. Gowda, a City Council candidate from Staten Island who called the temple “a true blessing for our community.” Mr. Gowda’s home country, India, is in South Asia — not Southeast Asia.

An article last Monday about the problems of Argentina’s first elected female president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, in her first five months in office misidentified a political job once held by Alfonso Prat-Gay, a former central bank chief who criticized her tax increases on agricultural products. He was the economic adviser to Elisa Carrió, the opposition candidate defeated by Mrs. Kirchner in last year’s election; he was not Mrs. Carrió’s running mate. (Her running mate was Rubén Giustiniani, a senator.).

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about film and theater events in Bryant Park this summer misstated the day of the week for the Broadway in Bryant Park lunchtime concerts. The concerts, from July 10 through Aug. 14, are on Thursdays, not Mondays.

A picture caption on Friday with an art review of exhibitions of sculpture by Anish Kapoor at a museum in Boston and at two galleries in Manhattan misstated the name of the museum. As the review noted, it is the Institute of Contemporary Art, not the Museum of Contemporary Art.
An off-duty police officer fatally shot a man who pulled a gun on the officer’s wife and 3-year-old daughter outside the door of their Bronx apartment, the police said on Sunday.

RAWSON--Toby, (nee Treger), a loving wife, sister, mother and grandmother who lived in Roslyn, NY passed away Friday afternoon with her family at her side, she was 85 years old. RECHTSCHAFFEN--Joseph, M.D., on May 30th, 2008. Beloved husband of Frances, dear and wise father of Stephan, Robert, Lisa and Scott. Loving grandfather of ten. Services Monday, June 2nd, 11:15am at ''The Riverside'' 180 West 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. RECHTSCHAFFEN--Joseph, M.D., 88, passed away peacefully on May 30, 2008, surrounded by his children. Joe lived in Manhattan with Frances, his wife of over 60 years. Joe was Chief of Internal Medicine at Beekman-Downtown and was on staff at Beth Israel and Doctors Hospitals. His focus on nutrition, his passion for great food and the friendship of many of the City's top restaurateurs, led him to author ''Dr. Rechtschaffen's Diet for Lifetime Weight Control and Better Health'', hailed for its common-sense approach to nutrition and health. Joe was known for his generosity, never turning away a patient for an inability to pay, never refusing a request for help, and no one left his home without having enjoyed the finest foods, spirits, cigars and conversation. His remarkable wisdom, insights into the human mind and soul and his love of philosophy left an indelible mark on his children and grandchildren. Joe led his life to the fullest and we were fortunate to be able to have shared it with him. Joe is survived by his beloved wife, Frances, his sisters Shirley and Paula, his children Stephan, Robert, Lisa and Scott and 10 grandchildren. Donations can be made to The Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Research Foundation at One Intrepid Square, West 46th Street and 12th Avenue, New York, NY 10036.

Google, Privacy And California After I wrote about Google's spat with an advertising trade group over the company's refusal to put a link to its privacy policy on the home page of Google.com, I discovered that there is a California law on the subject. It requires the operator of a commercial Web site that collects personal information about users to ''conspicuously post its privacy policy'' on its home page or first ''significant'' page after entering the site.

HINDUS--Eva (Tenenbaum), of Newton, MA on Saturday, May 31, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Professor Milton Hindus. Devoted mother of Myra Hindus of Jamaica Plain, MA. FORD--William Patrick, (Bill) beloved husband of Mary Anne, devoted father of Miriam, Bill, Ruth, Elizabeth, Rebecca and John and adored grandfather of Samuel, Thomas and Carolina Marth, Billy, Maggie and Mary Ita Ford, Anna and Alex Esteverena, son of the late William Patrick Ford and Mildred O'Beirne Ford, brother of Irene Coriaty and of the late Ita Ford, Maryknoll missionary. He died June 1 in the arms of his family after a courageous 17 month battle with endstage esophageal cancer. Born on April 28, 1936, he was a graduate of Brooklyn Prep, Fordham University (B.A. 1960) and St. John's University (LLB 1966). Bill married Mary Anne Heyman on February 4, 1961, whose decision to marry him, he later said, made him ''the luckiest man alive''. He served in the US Army from 1957-1958, and again in 1961. He was a clerk to Federal Court Judge Richard Levet, a founder and senior partner of Ford Marrin Esposito Witmeyer and Gleser, recipient of honorary doctorates from Fordham University, St. John's University, the College of St. Elizabeth and Niagara University and claimed his greatest successes as the births of his six children and eight grandchildren. Bill served as an Essex County Democratic Committeeman. An active member of St. Casssian Church in Upper Montclair, NJ, he was a founding trustee of the North Jersey Inter-Religious Task Force on Central America and a member of the Commission on Justice and Peace for the Archdiocese of Newark. After the December 2, 1980 murder in El Salvador of his sister Ita and her companions, Bill tenaciously sought to bring those directly responsible for the deaths of his sister and her three religious companions to justice. For over 22 years, Bill worked unceasingly to hold those in command positions responsible for the death of his sister and so many Slavadoran victims. His efforts laid the groundwork for the eventual successful prosecution of two Salvadoran generals. His personal courage, integrity and undying love of family are the hallmarks of a life well lived. He will be forever remembered by the quiet kindnesses he did for so many. May his soul rest in peace. Visitation Tuesday, June 3 from 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Hugh Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park Street, Montclair, NJ. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Wednesday, June 4 at 10:30am at St. Cassian Church, 187 Bellevue Avenue, Upper Montclair, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Maryknoll Sisters, Box 39, Maryknoll, NY 10545 or Cristo Rey NY High School, 112 East 106 Street, NY, NY 10029.

When I was a kid growing up in the U.S., my mother, a Hong Konger, bought those plastic molds used for making popsicles. American neighbors taught her to pour in anything sweet, like orange juice or fruit punch, and then putting them in the freezer for a healthy, homemade dessert.

They just keep getting weirder. The "they" I'm referring to are the bdelloid rotifers - small transparent animals that live in damp places such as puddles, or patches of moss. Among evolutionists, these animals have something of a cult following, because they have a lifestyle that is not supposed to exist. As far as anyone can tell, the bdelloid rotifers are ancient asexuals: they appear to have been living entirely without sex for more than 85 million years. And each time we learn more details of their lifestyle, the wackier it becomes.

One of my favorite things about going to baseball games when I was younger was filling out the All-Star ballots. I would find something sharp, usually my dad's car key, and punch out those little holes beside players I loved watching. Maybe that's why Wes Chamberlain got all those votes.
Melena Ryzik reports from the gala benefit for the Dance Theater Workshop.
Cable's summer season is off to a high-rated start.

It's funny how baseball works sometimes. The Yankees are going to extraordinary lengths to protect the golden arm of Joba Chamberlain, who turns 23 in September. Baseball history is littered with pitchers who threw too many innings too soon in their careers, none more prominent than Mark Prior.
Melena Ryzik reports from the gala benefit for the Dance Theater Workshop.

I'm writing from my hotel room in Paris. My windows are open to the fresh air, and I can hear kids playing basketball and rugby in the schoolyard - I'm surprised each time I visit to see how big rugby is in France: allez les bleus! But the clouds are out and soon it will rain. How do I know this? I arrived in France on May 23 and it has rained every single day since, including the five days I spent in Burgundy.

Terry Finley is the founder and president of West Point Thoroughbreds, which will run the second-place Preakness finisher Macho Again in the Belmont Stakes. A graduate of West Point, Finley is a former Army Captain and Airborne Ranger. He lives in Mount Laurel, N.J., with his wife, Debbie, the operations manager for the company, and his daughter, Erin, and son, Ryan.

"You know you've come full circle when you have Hummer involved in a press conference about energy independence and the environment. The world truly is changing. But here it is: The Hummer HX concept, powered by the extremely capable Flex Fuel V-6 powertrain."-- Mark LaNeve, vice president of sales and marketing for General Motors, at the Detroit auto show.

I was out of town for stretches of May, and so I'm still catching up on some of what happened in the world in general, the restaurant world in particular and most especially the world of griping about restaurants.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has told supporters that she would agree to be Senator Barack Obama's running mate if he offered her the vice presidential spot.

The comments to our posts about a rule that forced Amazon.com and some other large online stores to collect sales tax on shipments to New York State residents reflect the interest Internet shoppers have in tax policies. Many agreed with a respondent named Michael who said, "And just like that, I stop using Amazon. Pity."

You may say the modern renaissance of New York City is complete: We will be celebrating the beauty of our own sludge tonight when the eight great digester "eggs" of the Newtown Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant in Brooklyn are illuminated with what the designer Hervé Descottes of L'Observatoire International calls a "diaphanous layer of blue light."
A running tally of non-New York Times articles (not a ranking):
Joba Chamberlain's long-awaited and much-debated debut as a starting pitcher at the major league level will take place tonight against the Toronto Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium.

The gymnasium at 200 Madison Street, inside the Rutgers Houses Community Center on the Lower East Side, hardly look like a repository of great art. The low-slung, brick-fronted building, part of a public housing complex built in the 1960s, could hardly look more different than the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with its Beaux Arts facade, wide steps and imposing columns.

The American sprinter Antonio Pettigrew has agreed to return the gold medal he won as part of the U.S. 4x400-meter relay team at the 2000 Sydney Olympics after admitting last month that he took EPO and human growth hormone, the Associated Press is reporting.

While the publishing world headed west to L.A. for B.E.A. last week, I headed east - to Italy, for a long-scheduled vacation. While in Rome, where I lived in the late 90s, I did a book-related guest post for Eternallycool.net, the blog about Rome run by my friends Laura Flusche and Susan Sanders, high-end tour guides, teachers and experts in all things Roman, from what's up with the Palatine excavations to where to find funky sandals.

Coming off exit 26B of the Cross Island Parkway onto Hempstead Turnpike, the looming magnitude of Belmont Park is unavoidable; it's there in front of you, and then to your left, as you head toward the main gate. It seems to go on forever.

Less than a week after his agent called the rumor "hot air," and days after being dismissed from Manchester City, Sven Goran Eriksson has a new job. The Swede, and former England manager, will take over as coach of Mexico, according to the Associated Press, after a vote Tuesday by the owners of Mexico's 18 first-division clubs.

In my last entry, you may recall I used smoke in biblical proportions to try to force the queen bee of one of my two hives into the lower, or brood, chambers. That's where I wanted her to lay her eggs, saving the upper boxes, or supers, for honey collection.

Two years ago, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg set the goal of attracting 50 million visitors a year to the city by 2015, it seemed like one of those audacious goals that were all the rage in corporate boardrooms in the 1990s.
Updated | 10:20 p.m. Five minutes after the polls closed in Montana, the Obama campaign released what might be called a little insurance: a list of 28 superdelegates pledging their support.
The Tampa Bay Lightning announced Tuesday John Tortorella will not return next season as the team's head coach. They have scheduled a news conference for 5 PM today.
John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC discusses the beginning of the end of the Democratic race for the presidential nomination.

At international conferences, some of the most important behind-the-scenes maneuvers take place in the kitchen. And the delicate dance is particularly sensitive at this week's United Nations food summit in Rome, which takes place as the global food crisis continues.

I've said many times, too many times, that I like videos of demos and how-tos. But I haven't been completely honest. While I like these videos in principle, I have never used a single one myself. I didn't use one to learn how to tie a symmetrical bow, or to make gingerbread, or to rig up a cheap laptop-cooling system. It kept not occurring to me.
At Gracie Mansion on Monday night, a bunch of New York's Internet executives gathered to hear Mayor Michael Bloomberg proclaim the beginning of Internet Week.

People with a family history of colon cancer carry the emotional burden of knowing they have twice the risk of developing the disease themselves. But now, a new study may ease some of their anxiety. Patients with a family history of colon cancer are also more likely to survive the disease.

The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here Alexa Adams and Flora Gill, the designers behind the women's wear label Ohne Titel, share a few of their stylish essentials. After working for Karl Lagerfeld (Adams also worked for the real Helmut Lang), the two founded Ohne Titel in 2006 and quickly became known for their abstract approach to tailored pantsuits and print dresses. They chose their equally conceptual moniker as an homage, in part, to the artist Anselm Kiefer, who titled many of his paintings "ohne titel" (German for "untitled.") The East Village-based designers are currently hard at work on their spring collection, which will take place during New York fashion week in September.

Dear New Yorker: If a postcard from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum lands in your mailbox within the next few weeks, don't toss it in the recycling bin. Stop and read it. The city really does want to hear you out.Starting next week, the mayor and public advocate will send postcards to 100,000 homes that have been randomly selected to participate in a survey about the quality of city services. The survey will come in the mail in the weeks that follow, in English or in one of three other languages -- Russian, Chinese or Spanish -- of the recipient's choice.

Repeats on Fox lifted the network to No. 1 in the ratings on Monday, as "House" at 9 p.m. attracted the night's largest audience, 9.4 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. While Fox's "Bones" was the most watched show during the 8 p.m. hour with 6.7 million viewers, it trailed in its time slot among adults 18 to 49.

So, we're about to proceed to report on turnout in South Dakota and Montana, the last primary states. But first, can we just pause for a moment of reflection here? We're reporting on turnout in the last two primary states, South Dakota and Montana.

City Councilman Domenic M. Recchia Jr. made official today what many have long suspected. He withdrew from the race for the Congressional seat now held by Vito J. Fossella and endorsed a fellow Democratic councilman, Michael E. McMahon, for the seat.

Is it over? The Atlantic's Marc Ambinder says yes, "the Democratic primary campaign is over." He expects Hillary Clinton to "acknowledge reality" and "publicly acknowledge that Obama has crossed the threshold" of 2,118 delegates, the number required to secure the nomination.

One dark and freakishly stormy night several years ago in San Diego, my car stalled at a flooded intersection. As I pushed the car out of the intersection, lightning was going off all around like flash bulbs. I felt lucky to be able to restart the engine and drive safely home.
Water shortages are striking mainland Europe and in particular the Spanish province of Murcia, where prosperity is on the rise but where farmers are fighting with developers over water rights.

After a hiatus of several months, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has started to round up feral cats at Kennedy International Airport again, drawing protests from animal advocacy groups.

In another sign of just how bedeviled the Clinton campaign continues to be, it spent this morning frantically trying to keep news organizations from following an Associated Press report that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will concede tonight that Barack Obama has enough delegates to claim the nomination.

Almost two weeks of violent protests in the Indian state of Rajasthan showed no sign of stopping today. But the protesting Gujjars, a group of traditionally nomadic shepherds, stopped to cremate at least four of their dead, according to Reuters. More than 40 people have died, many from gunfire from police trying to beat back the demonstrations aimed at getting more government benefits. For more on their struggle, check out Somini Sengupta's article from last year, "Indian Officials to Rule How 'Backward' Group Is."
After a four year absence, ExxonMobil will resume sponsorships of PBS programs this month, the public broadcaster announced Tuesday.

However much Americans may talk about the air pollution in Beijing as the Olympics draw near, one thing they can't say is that China lags behind the United States when it comes to the plague of plastic bags that litter the landscape. In fact, on Sunday China surged ahead of the U.S. by instituting a nationwide ban on the production and distribution of ultra-thin plastic bags in an effort to address its growing environmental problem.
Chief executives rarely come right out and admit that they massively overpaid in a merger deal. But the accountants have to be a bit more forthcoming.

33 Days to L'Étape. Today's training: climbing repeats. Given the constraints of a weekday schedule, this interval training will have to take place on a shorter, less steep slope than those available to New York-area riders on weekends, so I'll be riding up Harlem Hill in Central Park again and again and again, to work on the muscles needed for going up much more serious climbs in the near future.

Nicki Bennett is an American aid worker who bounces around from one hot spot to the next, working for Oxfam. She has been deployed to Sudan, eastern Congo, Chad, Zimbabwe, Malawi, Zambia and Guatemala. She recently spent six months in Bangladesh, working on post-hurricane reconstruction, and is now in Jerusalem focusing on Israeli-Palestinian water policy.
CNBC interviews Joe Nocera, a columnist for The Times, about the wide range of quality that exists among modern chief executives.

Gov. David A. Paterson said on Tuesday that he would propose a ceiling on increases to local property taxes, embracing the recommendation of a commission led by the Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, that studied the issue. Rising property taxes have been a major complaint of homeowners in the suburbs, upstate and on Long Island."The property tax cap is a blunt instrument, but it will force us to make hard choices," the governor said at a news conference. "It will force us to save our state from the peril that looms in our future if we don't act."
(Paolo Roversi)
At the end of next season, "The Simpsons" will be the longest-running series in the history of prime time television.

Citizen of the City. The phrase echoes Citizen of the World, which is more or less what it means when the city in question is New York. It is also how the chief marketing officer at NYC & Company, Jane Reiss, described the celebrities in its "Just Ask the Locals" campaign. She described them as "really committed to the city and want to donate their time to the city -- they're passionate about the city."

Cue the whiny voice: "Ever wonder whether Andy Rooney would be better if there were less of him?" Well, wonder no more: Joe Mande, a comic, claims on his blog to have invented the "Andy Rooney Game": simply edit out everything but the first and last sentence of each Rooney "60 Minutes" commentary, then post the result on YouTube. There. That better?

This week's guest blogger is Malcolm McLaren - the legendary punk rock impresario, fashion maverick, performer, producer, philosopher, would-be politician and now, officially, artist. Starting today, McLaren will be reporting for The Moment from Switzerland's Art Basel fair where he is unveiling "Shallow (1-21)," a series of "Musical Paintings," as part of a special curated section entitled Art Basel Projects. Read Malcolm McLaren's previous blog posts here.

Aired Monday night on NBC: Over the weekend, a man named Usain Bolt of Jamaica set a new world record in the 100 meter dash -- 9.72 seconds. That broke the old world record of 9.73 seconds set by superdelegates running away from Hillary Clinton.

As some reports tell it today, Robert E. Murray merely suggested in August that an earthquake caused the collapse of the coal mine he co-owns at Crandall Canyon, Utah. But his point of view was more like downright insistence that scientists were wrong to say the opposite -- that the mine collapse caused the seismological readings.

Aired Monday night on CBS: Let's talk about the presidential Democratic primary. Over the weekend, I guess you know this, Hillary Clinton won the Puerto Rican primary, so she is now president of Puerto Rico.

Valerie Solanas, the subject of the 1996 movie "I Shot Andy Warhol," is remembered these days mostly for, well, shooting Andy Warhol exactly 40 years ago today. But on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times, A.S. Hamrah suggests that Solanas should be remembered as something of a prophet, not just a "failed assassin and crackpot writer."

Here's a quick roundup of some new and emerging experiments aimed at charting how humanity might head toward a stable, prospering population without too much wreckage along the way.Yale Environment 360, also called e360, is a new online magazine on the environment. It is the brainchild of Gus Speth, the dean of the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies and author of a string of books on balancing human advancement and the planet's limits. Don't expect a genteel, Ivy League approach. The editor is Roger Cohn, formerly editor in chief of Mother Jones.

Residential Capital said its parent company, GMAC, and GMAC lead investor Cerberus Capital Management agreed to inject $1.43 billion in cash to help keep the distressed mortgage-finance company afloat, Bloomberg News reported.

The primary season, which began on the snowy roads of Iowa and New Hampshire six months ago, ends today on the plains of South Dakota and Montana. As voters in both states cast their ballots, The Times's Adam Nagourney reports that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is preparing to deliver what aides described as a "farewell speech" in New York, clearing the way for Barack Obama to claim the mantle of presumptive Democratic nominee.

Australia has become a refuge for a new endangered species: the high-flying banker. With layoffs rampant throughout Europe and the U.S., bankers are increasingly looking down under for shelter, according to a report by Reuters.

The ouster of G. Kennedy Thompson as chief executive of Wachovia, announced Monday morning, leaves the Charlotte, N.C.-based bank confronting an uncertain future. Some see Mr. Thompson's hasty exit as a sign that the troubles at Wachovia - and indeed at many banks - will continue to deepen as credit problems spread.
