China Merchants Bank, coming from behind in a three-month auction, has agreed to buy 53 percent of Wing Lung Bank, a family-controlled lender in Hong Kong. It will also offer to buy the rest of Wing Lung's shares at the same price, valuing the bank at $4.66 billion.

U.S. Bank National Association, the lead bank of U.S. Bancorp., on Monday completed its acquisition of Mellon 1st Business Bank in California, previously announced in March. The companies did not disclose details of the cash deal, The Minneapolis/St. Paul Business Journal reported.

Europe and Asia are quietly gaining in clean tech and software venture capital according to a survey released Tuesday by Deloitte and the National Venture Capital Association. Further, nearly three out of every five of U.S. venture capitalists, or 57 percent, are now investing outside the country, compared with 46 percent last year, the survey found.

Italy’s captain, Fabio Cannavaro, will miss the European Championships after tearing ligaments in his right ankle on Monday during the Azzurri’s first training session in Enzersdorf, Austria. Italy replaced Cannavaro with Fiorentina defender Alessandro Gamberini; goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon will most likely become captain. Italy opens next Monday against the Netherlands.

Seth Rogen and James Franco play stoners in the coming film “Pineapple Express,” and they reprised their roles at the MTV Movie Awards on Sunday night: they pulled out a bag of fake marijuana onstage, then Mr. Rogen lighted a fake joint and Mr. Franco puffed on it. “Kids don’t really smoke fake weed like this,” Mr. Rogen, above with glasses, told the crowd at the Gibson Amphitheater in Los Angeles, where they were presenting the award for the best summer movie so far. Before television viewers could get a closer look at what was real and what was not, the camera moved to a wide angle and stayed that way until Mr. Rogen and Mr. Franco, above in white T-shirt, left the stage, The Associated Press reported. It was an awkward moment that made some in the audience laugh. Backstage, Mr. Franco told The Associated Press that MTV had put them up to the joke — supplying the script as well as the fake pot and joint — and then had a last-second change of heart.

The ashes of Kurt Cobain were stolen from the Hollywood home of his widow, Courtney Love, The Guardian of London reported. Ms. Love, left, told authorities that the ashes had recently been stolen from a heart-shaped handbag in a secret hiding place in a wardrobe. She said that she was suicidal as a result of the theft, The Guardian reported, and that the ashes had been taken by an acquaintance. “I can’t believe anyone would take Kurt’s ashes from me,” she said. “If I don’t get them back I don’t know what I will do.” Most of the ashes of Cobain, the lead singer and songwriter for Nirvana, were scattered at a New York Buddhist temple and in the Wishkah River near Aberdeen, Wash., where he lived as a boy. He committed suicide in 1994.

“Man on Wire” will kick off the 11th annual Newport International Film Festival when it opens Tuesday in Newport, R.I. The film, directed by James Marsh, explores Philippe Petit’s high-wire routine between the twin towers of the World Trade Center on Aug. 7, 1974. It picked up a prize for best documentary at the Sundance Film Festival this year. Mr. Petit, who will be on hand for the screening, walked between the buildings eight times in 45 minutes. This year’s films, more than 100 in all, are almost evenly divided between feature-length documentaries and narrative films, with four programs of shorts. They include a celebration of the life of the Italian actress Anna Magnani — who would have turned 100 this year — with a screening of “The Rose Tattoo,” for which she won an Oscar in 1956. The festival runs through Sunday. More information can be found at newportfilmfestival.com.

Regis Philbin made a promising return to prime-time television on Sunday as the host of “Million Dollar Password” on CBS. The new series, an updated version of the classic game show, attracted the night’s largest audience, 10.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. It followed “60 Minutes” at 7 p.m. (10 million); together, the two shows made CBS the night’s most-watched network, despite more modest ratings later with repeats of “Cold Case” (7.8 million) and “The Unit” (5 million) opposite NBC’s “Dateline” from 9 to 11 (8.1 million). NBC finished second in total viewers but first among adults 18 to 49. An encore of NBC’s special “100 Most Outrageous Moments of All Time” averaged 5.4 million viewers from 7 to 9 p.m. Fox and ABC finished in a tie for third place. Both networks broadcast lineups of all reruns.

She’s back. Amy Winehouse, in her first concert since leaving rehab, showed up almost an hour late with a bandage on her hand to an outdoor music festival in Lisbon. “I’m sorry I’m late,” Ms. Winehouse, above, told the crowd, according to The Associated Press, which said that she appeared distracted, that she had cuts on her left arm, and that her right arm was bandaged. She also apologized for having a sore throat, and her voice cracked during the set. Some in the crowd of 90,000 booed when Ms. Winehouse failed to appear on time, although she is known for missed concerts and odd behavior. Ms. Winehouse walked offstage in Lisbon without playing an encore, after singing hits like “Rehab” as well as soul classics and reggae songs. She is scheduled to appear at a series of music festivals in Europe this summer.
The 92nd Street Y has announced its 2009 lineup for Lyrics & Lyricists, its popular series devoted to the American songbook.

Tatum O’Neal was arrested and released after being accused of buying crack cocaine near her home in Manhattan, The Associated Press reported Monday. Police officers said Ms. O’Neal, 44, was seen making the purchase at about 7:30 p.m. on Sunday on the Lower East Side. She was charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance. Ms. O’Neal, right, who wrote about her problems with addiction in her memoir “A Paper Life,” appears regularly on “Rescue Me,” the FX television series about New York City firefighters. Ms. O’Neal, the daughter of the actor Ryan O’Neal, became the youngest person to win an Oscar in 1974 when, at age 10, she received the best supporting actress award for her role in “Paper Moon.”.

The French filmmaker Jean-Luc Godard has dropped plans to attend a film festival in Tel Aviv after a Palestinian group urged him to boycott Israel, Reuters reported. Mr. Godard, one of the founders of the French New Wave of the 1960s, canceled the trip to the Tel Aviv International Student Film Festival, citing “circumstances beyond his control,” festival organizers said Monday. The Palestinian Campaign for the Academic and Cultural Boycott of Israel urged Mr. Godard in an open letter last week to “take a courageous stand and cancel your trip to Israel.” The letter asked: “Did you ever go to an Afrikaner film festival in apartheid South Africa? Why Israel, then?” Reuters said a source in Mr. Godard’s office declined to comment but said he had canceled his visit for political reasons. Festival organizers said they were disappointed but respected Mr. Godard’s decision. Pro-Palestinian groups frequently call on prominent cultural and academic figures to boycott Israel because of its occupation of the West Bank and its blockade of the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip.

DAHAN--Rachel. Bar - Ilan University and its American Friends mourn the passing of Rachel Dahan of Baltimore. With her husband Aharon, our Honorary Global Chairman, Mrs. Dahan was known for her unparalleled devotion and generosity to the University. Among the cutting edge programs and projects that the Dahans sponsored at BarIlan University: The Aharon and Rachel Dahan Exodus Classroom Building, The Dahan Center for Sephardic Heritage, Dahan Unity Park and, important projects in high-tech engineering and nanotechnology. We extend our profound sympathies to her husband Aharon, sons Nissim (Mira), Eliav (Marsha) and the entire family. May they be comforted among all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Professor Moshe Kaveh, President Michael Jesselson, Chairman, American Board of Trustees Mordecai D. Katz, Chairman, Global Board of Trustees Peter Rzepka, President, American Board of Trustees Mark D. Medin, Executive V. P. & CEO American Friends Gen. (ret.) Yehuda Halevy, Executive V. P. Emeritus American Friends

Also survived by daughter-inlaw Melissa Hart and brother Oscar Bortner. He will be deeply missed by all those who knew him and loved him. Services Thursday June 5, 1:15 at ''The Riverside'', 180 West 76th at Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

EDWARDS--Jaroldeen Asplund, 76, widow of Weston Eyring Edwards, passed away Friday morning, May 30, 2008, after struggling valiantly with heart complications. A noted author and speaker, Jaroldeen is survived by four of her five siblings, her twelve children, seventy-six grandchildren, and twenty great-grandchildren. The funeral will be Tuesday, June 3, in Pleasant Grove, Utah. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Weston and Jaroldeen Edwards Family Endowed Scholarship Fund at BYU: c/o LDS Philanthropies, P.O. Box 27188, Provo, UT 84602-7188.

A prominent Uzbek human rights advocate was freed after more than two years in captivity, a release that coincided with a visit by an American official. The advocate, Mutabar Tadjibaeva, said by telephone that she had left a prison in Tashkent, the country's capital, and was driven to her native city, Margilan. She was not asked to sign a confession, as is often the case in Uzbekistan, whose president, Islam Karimov, has crushed political opposition and put dozens of human rights advocates in jail. Ms. Tadjibaeva was released during a visit by Richard A. Boucher, the assistant secretary of state for South and Central Asian affairs.

The Chicago White Sox owner Eddie Einhorn is creating a national youth tournament that will go head-to-head this year with the Little League World Series. Eight associations, including Babe Ruth Baseball and Pony Baseball, will send their top teams to Memphis from Aug. 21 to 24 to compete in the National Youth Baseball Championship. The Little League World Series, which dates to 1947, will take place Aug. 15-24 in Williamsport, Pa.

d'HARNONCOURT--Anne, was a highly respected force in the art world, who led the way for women in the rarified area of museum directorship. She, along with her husband, curator Joe Rishel, brought so much, not only to Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Museum itself, but also to the art world as a whole both nationally and internationally. Anne was a true visionary who had an incredibly keen eye for both art and for people. She was a kind and compassionate friend to so many of the artists that she supported. Anne's stature, presence and old world elegance will be sorely missed by the art community that respected her so greatly, and by us, as a dearly loved friend and colleague. Agnes Gund and Daniel Shapiro d'HARNONCOURT--Anne. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the sudden death of Anne d'Harnoncourt. Her father, Rene d'Harnoncourt, became Director of the Museum in 1949 and retired almost 20 years later in 1968. Anne's strong ties to MoMA began during this time as she developed her passion for the visual arts. After completing her graduate studies in the history of art she joined the museum profession, which she has served with exemplary distinction, first as a curator and then as Director of The Philadelphia Museum of Art for more than twenty-five years. Besides her expertise in surrealist artists, especially Marcel Duchamp, Anne demonstrated an informed enthusiasm for the wide range of art, from the ancient to the contemporary, represented in The Philadelphia Museum of Art collections. Visual arts organizations and museum colleagues across the nation sought her counsel, which was always wisely and generously given. We shall miss her astute intelligence, good humor, and graciousness. We extend our deepest sympathies to her husband, Joe Rishel. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Ronald S. Lauder, Honorary Chairman Robert B. Menschel, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Donald B. Marron, President Emeritus Jerry Speyer, Chairman Marie-Jose Kravis, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art d'HARNONCOURT--Anne. The Association of Art Museum Directors is shocked and deeply saddened by the loss of our colleague and friend Anne d'Harnoncourt. Anne defined leadership for a field committed to the public understanding and appreciation of art. As a scholar, esteemed curator, and one of the most admired directors of any art museum in this country or abroad, Anne will be missed by the innumerable people she has helped personally and by the many who have sought to follow her example. Gail Andrews, President, Association of Art Museum Directors d'HARNONCOURT--Anne. Christie's mourns the loss of Anne d'Harnoncourt, a great art world leader. Christopher Burge, Honorary Chairman Stephen S. Lash, Chairman Marc Porter, President d'HARNONCOURT--Anne. The Trustees and faculty of Bard College mourn the passing of Anne d'Harnoncourt, friend and honorary alumna. She was a great and distinguished leader in the world of art and culture. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Leon Botstein, President Charles P. Stevenson, Jr, Chairman d'HARNONCOURT--Anne. The art world has suffered a very great loss. At this incomprehensibly sad time, our hearts go out to Joe and to Anne's extended family at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Anne was deeply loved and will be very much missed by all who knew her. Kate and Dan

LAUFER--Murray. Loving husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Murray Laufer, age 87, of New York City, died at home on June 1, 2008. Murray lived a full and balanced life. A graduate of Columbia University in 1947, Murray formed a fastener distributorship, Columbia Nut and Bolt in 1953, named after his alma mater. The business was a successful one, meeting the fastener needs of the nation's military and he eventually sold it in 1999. Murray was known for creating a chess set out of nuts and bolts which he patented in 1972. Over a period spanning 25 years he sent his chess sets to hundreds of world leaders and media personalities who he felt encouraged the pursuit of world peace. He named his program Moves for Peace. He loved the arts, music, theater, sports and politics. Above all Murray enjoyed spending time with his family. He and his wife Margie were married 59 years and their devotion to each other was the core of the family. Murray is survived by his wife Margie, son Bill, daughter Joanna, daughter-in-law Barbara, son-in-law Ken, his four grandchildren, Jessica (Eric), Alex, Benjamin and Karlen and greatgrandchildren Andrew and Justin. He is also survived by his brother Jack and sister-inlaw Edith and sister Beatrice. The funeral will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 76th St., NYC . The service begins at 11:15am and guests will be received from 10:15am. In lieu of flowers, please remember Murray by sending a memorial contribution to The Society for Progressive Supranuclear Palsy, Executive Plaza 3, 11350, McCormick Rd., Suite 906, Hunt Valley, MD 21031.

DELTA INTERNATIONALDelta Air Lines, which has said that more than 40 percent of its flying will be in international traffic by this summer, will start nine new international routes through June 12, including nonstop service between Salt Lake City and Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris in a partnership with Air France. Delta said it has added more international capacity than any major domestic airline in the last two years. TOP AIRPORTS Tampa International in Florida and Incheon International in South Korea were jointly chosen as the world's leading airports in the 2008 Eagle Awards presented by the International Air Transport Association at its annual meeting on Monday in Istanbul. The award is given for performance in customer service and cost efficiency, the group said.

Bo Diddley, a singer and guitarist who invented his own name, his own guitars, his own beat and, with a handful of other musical pioneers, rock 'n' roll itself, died Monday at his home in Archer, Fla. He was 79. The cause was heart failure, a spokeswoman, Susan Clary, said. Mr. Diddley had a heart attack last August, only months after suffering a stroke while touring in Iowa.

CROWN--Marian Ruth, known to everyone as Rufus, 95. Born on March 8, 1913 in Nashville, TN, lived her remarkable adult life on 5th Ave. and CPW, and, never having lost her Nashville accent nor her Southern charm, died peacefully at home on May 31st. For 41 enchanted years, married to Alfred Crown, the Broadway and motion picture producer. Adored mother of Patricia Crown, the New York entertainment lawyer, who survives her, along with her beloved son-in-law and granddaughter Tony and Julia Radice. Rufus had a magical gift for friendship; she touched, embraced and united the lives of a remarkable breadth of people of every age and description, from the famous to the rest of us, and cared about each one individually. She was a mentor, teacher, civic volunteer, hostess extraordinaire, friend and patron of theater, music, the arts and numerous artists, and supporter of all causes liberal and progressive, including black-listed writers, Alger Hiss, civil rights, women's rights and the demise of the Bush administration. In lieu of flowers, donations to a fund to be created supporting children in need would be appreciated.

STEINHART--Leonard, died on May 30, 2008 at age 85 from complications due to emergency abdominal surgery, while on vacation in Barcelona, Spain. Born on May 20, 1923 in Peakskill, NY. Attended George Washington University. Served with distinction as a Squadron Navigator in WWII. Retiring many years later as a full Colonel in the Air Force Reserves. Founded and operated his own manufacturing business for 50 years. Was a loving husband to his wife Jetta for 60 years and the proud father of his children, Randi and Garry. We love you Dad and we will miss you always.

KOGAN--Louis, age 86, died peacefully, surrounded by his family, on Monday, June 2, 2008. Beloved husband of Matty. Father of Ronald (Arlene), Jeffrey (Faith), Melanie (Scott). Grandfather to Mathew, Alex, Jenna, Ian, Eric, Dylan, Kyle, and Fallon. Great-grandfather of Eliana. Dear brother to Leona Levine and the late Murray Levine. Friend to countless others. Former President of Pine Hollow Country Club, former Treasurer of Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, and former Treasurer of Temple Beth Shalom. Services Wednesday, June 4, at 11am, Temple Beth Shalom, Roslyn, NY.

Some Russians declared that the Kremlin had a right -- or even an obligation -- to bar opposition politicians from the nation's television networks. Others described such a practice as nothing more than blatant censorship that harked back to the old days. Those two strains of opinion dominated the responses from Russian bloggers to a version of the accompanying article that was translated into Russian. The article was posted on Friday on a Russian-language blog run by The New York Times on the most popular blogging platform in Russia, livejournal.com.

FLORIO--Clem, 78 years old, died on Sunday, May 25, 2008 in Florida after a long battle with lung and pancreatic cancer. A giant among men, Clem was a nationally renowned handicapper and odds maker, an acclaimed turf and boxing writer, a former professional boxer, and a legendary raconteur. His passing is a profound loss to his legion of friends and colleagues; we will miss the stories, the laughter and insights, the fierce loyalty and most of all, Clem's fearless passion and inspiring zest for life. Our heartfelt condolences to his family and loved ones.

BADGER--Mariette Starr Arguimbau, a Greenwich resident for 59 years, passed away on Monday, May 26, 2008 at the age of 90. A pioneering civic leader, she led in establishing Greenwich Planned Parenthood, the Greenwich Recycling Advisory Board, and the Greenwich Land Trusts annual benefit. She served three terms in the Greenwich Representative Town Meeting, and in 1979 she was chosen by the Greenwich Time as ''Clubwoman of the Year.'' A respected horticulturalist, Mariette won ten Greenwich Garden Club and Garden Club of America awards between 1978 and 2008. A ranking tennis player, she competed in the Nationals at Forest Hills, the predecessor to the U.S. Open, and won numerous New England championships. Survived by her husband, Daniel; two sons, Vincent Badger of NYC and Daniel Badger Jr. of London; two daughters, Starr Badger Shippee of Greenwich, and Diana Badger Bohr of Sebastopol, CA; and six grandchildren. She is also survived by her sister, Suzanne Davis of Darien. A memorial service will be held at 1:00pm on June 7, at Christ Church in Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Greenwich Land Trust, 132 E. Putnam Ave., Cos Cob, CT 06807.

Karen Salmansohn has written 29 books and, in the process, created her own mini genre that she calls "self-help for people who wouldn't be caught dead reading self-help." The ingredients for a Salmansohn book include bold graphics, advice distilled to digestible nuggets and lots of humor. The levity does not preclude her from tackling weighty subjects, and her latest, "The Bounceback Book," looks at the psychology behind resiliency and offers 75 tips on how to bounce back after both minor setbacks or major trauma. The tips are brief and punchy ("Walk yourself out of a bad mood," "If you ask depressing questions, you will 100 percent get depressing answers." "Change your body. Change your mind.") and the text that follows offers scientific backing or quotes from the likes of Aristotle, Deepak Chopra or Martin Seligman, a leader in the field of positive psychology.

Everyone knows that we face a "silver tsunami" of senior citizens as baby boomers age and as researchers find new ways to turn back the diseases that once limited lifespan. Yet large-scale clinical trials often exclude the elderly, or include too few to draw statistically valid guidance for clinical practice. The effects of high blood pressure treatment in older folks have remained a particularly vexing gap in our knowledge, particularly because this condition becomes more prevalent as we age.

I was on the airplane flying over from Paris to Canada when the news of Max Mosley's victory in the FIA vote broke. Formula One-related FIA pronouncements are a moving target, and I was never sure whether the results would be announced on Tuesday or on Wednesday. In any case, for months - or was it only weeks? - I had been saying to anyone who asked my opinion, that the vote was foregone conclusion, Max would win. So what did I care? Best get on with business and wait for the real stories to break, those of the vote's aftermath.

PARIS -- The tan Chevrolet Tahoe -- something that would never warrant a second glance in the U.S. -- parked around the corner from my apartment here in Paris looked like the proverbial bull in a china shop. It towered over the tiny French hatchbacks beside it, and took up more parking acreage than a handful of Smart cars. A sticker on the rear window read "American Car City" and included a phone number. I was on my cell phone and dialing in less time than it takes to say "nine dollars a gallon."

"We should not sort athletes by what sex they are, but rather by their skill," Eileen McDonagh and Laura Pappano write in "Playing with the Boys: Why Separate Is Not Equal in Sports." At first glance, this book might seem one more example of gender equality gone wild, like coed bathrooms or pornography for women. Mixed-sex football? But give the authors a chance to make their argument and they begin to play with your head. Their book isn't well-written, and it's no fun to read, but start thinking about the issues they raise and you may never stop.

Aired Tuesday night on NBC: The good news -- the whole voting process ended tonight. The bad news -- the 2012 Democratic primary starts on Thursday.
A longtime haven for tired visitors, the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are temporarily off limits. Video by Corey Kilgannon.
Meet Paul Rutgersen, a bagpiper who practices by the West Side Highway. Video by Corey Kilgannon.
Fuse, a lesser known version of MTV and VH1, has endured a revolving door of top executives and rebranding campaigns over the past five years, Claire Atkinson reports.
The workers behind the horses' starting gate at Belmont Park talk about the importance of their jobs. Video by Corey Kilgannon.
Aired Tuesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: John McCain is campaigning, out traveling around the country, looking for donors, mostly organ donors.
The field for the 140th Belmont Stakes grew by one Wednesday, when Guadalcanal, who is owned and trained by Fred Seitz, was entered in the race.

The requisite chants of "Come on Inger-land!" which usually course through a game at Wembley are only echoes a week after the Euro 2008 exiles defeated a stale United States men's national team 2-0.

Aired Tuesday night on NBC: The Associated Press reported today that Barack Obama has won enough delegates to clinch the Democratic presidential nomination. As a result, Hillary Clinton will concede sometime in the next 30 years.

Updated, 3:30 p.m. | This morning, a Boston-born performance artist, Yazmany Arboleda, tried to set up a provocative art exhibition in a vacant storefront on West 40th Street in Midtown Manhattan with the title, "The Assassination of Hillary Clinton/The Assassination of Barack Obama," in neatly stenciled letters on the plate glass windows at street level.By 9:30 a.m., New York City police detectives and Secret Service agents had shut down the exhibition, and building workers had quickly covered over the inflammatory title with large sheets of brown paper and blue masking tape. The gallery is across the street from the southern entrance to The New York Times building.
Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Our Vice President, our old friend Dick Cheney, apologized for a joke he made about West Virginia. Nothing yet on the Iraqi war.
A call for an Olympic amnesty marks the 19th anniversary of the Chinese government's crackdown on pro-democracy protesters at Tiananmen Square.

Today is the 19th anniversary of the crackdown on the Tiananmen Square pro-democracy protests. In an op-ed piece in today's Washington Post, Wang Dan, a student organizer who was sent to prison for his role in the 1989 pro-democracy protests at Tiananmen Square, calls for the Chinese government to declare an "Olympic amnesty" for what he says are the thousands of Chinese who are "serving long prison terms for activities that are normal political engagement in most of the world" and "to allow those of us who are in exile to at last return home."

Aired Tuesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: It looks like we have a Democratic nominee for president, Barack Obama. And now, Hillary Clinton is indicating privately to friends, who then blab it to the cable news channels, that she would be open to the vice presidency. That would mean the chain of command would be Hillary as vice president, Obama as president, and then Oprah on top of them.
I asked Monday if there should be another science festival in New York next year. I now have the answer from the organizers of the first World Science Festival: The show must go on!

When a proposal emerged to build an immense statue on an island off the coast of one of India's largest cities, there was no point in denying a nod to New York: "It is true that the Statue of Liberty was perhaps an inspiration a little bit," one official told Reuters.

The oldest of the baby boom generation were infants when Assault won the Triple Crown in 1946, and toddlers when Citation swept the series in 1948. They were adults scarred by the war in Vietnam and aghast at Watergate by the time Secretariat became the first in a quarter century to win the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes in 1973, and enamored of Big Red's charisma, many had embraced the sport by the time Seattle Slew and Affirmed earned racing immortality during the 1970s.

I asked and answered a provocative, and rhetorical, question the other day, and it engendered some strong responses. Here's what I wrote about a marine denizen that is among the world's largest, and most venerable, reptiles: "Does the world need leatherback turtles? Most likely not."

It had been almost 30 years since Ana Mojica last saw her half brother, Ruben ,on Fordham Road. In the intervening decades, she moved to Reading, Pa., started a family and eventually her own housecleaning business. Comfortable and far away from the Bronx, she still prayed to find her brother.

On Tuesday Yahoo finally set an Aug. 1 date for its annual shareholder meeting. Why they picked this date over any other in this time period, including the July 3 one originally scheduled, I have no idea.
Last week, 19 skydivers successfully jumped out of an airplane in the skies above Madrid to spell the word "Honda" live on British television.

Who knows whether or not Microsoft and Yahoo will ever merge. In the meantime, investment bankers might consider cruising eBay for their next assignment. The online auction site has money in the bank, a unit it may want to sell and a track record of growing through acquisitions.

The Democratic nomination fight has been hog heaven for the celebrity-journalism style of campaign reporting: with two candidates not too different on the issues (despite the health care divide), plus a special dispensation (under the Clinton rules) to invent scandals when needed, it was all personalities -- make that all personas, because the way politicians are portrayed generally has little or nothing to do with what they're really like -- all the way.

Contemporary art collectors on the lookout for a bargain should be tempted by an annual event that occurs this weekend: a gathering of YBA's (Young British Artists, a group of cutting edge contemporary British artists) selling their work from the back of cars. Yes it's time for the 4th Annual Vauxhall Art Car Boot Sale, (known as a "trunk sale" in the US), held between noon and 6 pm on 8th June at the Truman Brewery in Brick Lane in East London.

At the junction of three sections of Water Tunnel No. 3 under construction beneath Manhattan - at this point, 580 feet beneath Manhattan. This section of the tunnel is 10 feet in diameter. The project, to bring more drinking water to New York City, was authorized in 1954 and started in 1970; several stages remain to be built.

Five days after "Entertainment Tonight" reported that Angelina Jolie had given birth to twins, it is starting to look more and more as if the syndicated show - which is on every weeknight, primarily on CBS affiliates - made a serious mistake.

Reuters reports: "CBS Corp. said on Wednesday it reached a deal to allow its Web videos to be carried by Yahoo Inc., part of a broader plan by the media company to add new outlets for its television shows."

On the schmooze: Swiss collector Maja Hoffmann, artist Ugo Rondinone, film producer Stanley Buchthal, collector Peter Soros, collector Randy Slifka, artist Doug Aitken (on Slifka's shoulder), New Museum curator Masimilliano Gioni and Gagosian Gallery's Beijing director Nick Simunovic.
"Inside the NFL," which HBO Sports canceled in February after a 31-year run, was picked up by Showtime, Richard Sandomir reports.

As the end of his term nears, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his senior advisers have been exploring strategies that would allow him to remain in political life, including the undertaking a campaign to overturn the city's term limits law or making a bid for governor, Raymond Hernandez reports.

The following column, "Man Here Loves His Horse," by Red Smith, the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist, appeared in The New York Times on June 10, 1978, and is from "To the Swift: Classic Triple Crown Horses and Their Race for Glory" (St. Martin's Press), edited by Joe Drape.
On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for "Living With Music," a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

What we know after Tuesday's final primary contests is that Senator Barack Obama has clinched the Democratic nomination, becoming the first black candidate to lead a major political party into the general election. Under a history-making banner headline, The Times's Jeff Zeleny writes that Mr. Obama's showing in the South Dakota and Montana primaries as well as a "last-minute rush of Democratic superdelegates" allowed him to claim victory over his rival, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton:

If Google is serious about selling business applications, it may need to make a major acquisition to catalyze that effort. Two analysts at The 451 Group present their point of view on why Salesforce.com would be one of the better targets -- though an expensive one.

Anil Ambani, the billionaire Indian industrialist, is considering linking up with private equity groups on his bid to gain a powerful foothold in South African mobile operator MTN, The Financial Times reported citing unnamed sources close to the matter.
(Bill Batten)

Under fire for the high ratings they awarded to subprime mortgage securities, three large credit rating firms are close to announcing a broad deal with the New York attorney general to reform some of their core business practices, The New York Times reported citing people briefed on the investigation.

The investor Carl C. Icahn stepped up the pressure on Yahoo on Tuesday, vowing to remove Jerry Yang, its chief executive, if he succeeds in replacing the company's board with his own slate of directors.
New research hints red wine may slow aging, but you'd have to drink like four glasses a day, at least. Four glasses? Maybe it's time to start marketing wine like beer:
The Senate Banking Committee is planning to hold a hearing next Tuesday to examine underwriting practices at some of the top investment banks, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters.

Texas Pacific Group plans to use its investment in Bradford & Bingley as a springboard for stake-building in other banks. The Telegraph reported that such a move could trigger a wave of private equity investments in Britain's distressed financial services sector.
David Einhorn thinks another big Wall Street bank is headed for trouble - and he is not being quiet about it.

J.M. Smucker Company said Wednesday it would buy the Folgers coffee business from Procter & Gamble in a stock deal it valued at about $3.3 billion, including the assumption of about $350 million of Folgers debt.

BNP Paribas and European rivals including Societe Generale and Barclays may need to raise additional capital as their finances weaken, Bloomberg reported citing statements made by a Fitch Ratings executive.
Rally Software Development, based in Boulder, Colo., was expected to announce that it raised $16.85 million in venture funding in a Series C round led by Mohr Davidow Ventures.

Iberdrola, one of the world's largest energy companies, proposed on Tuesday to build hundreds of wind turbines in New York. The move significantly raises the stakes in its nine-month battle with state regulators over its intended purchase of Energy East, a power company.

In what is quickly turning into a heated bidding war, a consortium of Antam and Shenzhen Zhongjin have offered up to A$524 million ($500 million) for Australian mineral exploration and development company Herald Resources, trumping an earlier offer made by Bumi Resources.
Polygon Investment Partners' chief investment officer, Alexander Jackson, is the latest casualty of the ongoing credit cruch.

The third time may not be the charm for San Jose investor William "Boots" Del Biaggio III. A new lawsuit accuses Mr. Del Biaggio of scamming Modern Bank of New York out of a $10 million loan so he could buy an interest in the Nashville Predators hockey team.
Smith International has agreed to acquire W-H Energy Services for $3.2 billion, The Daily Deal reported.
Online video site Veoh has received a further $30 million in financing from such new backers as Intel and Adobe Systems.
Restoration Hardware said earlier this week that two proxy advisories had recommended shareholders vote in favor of a proposed buyout by a Catterton Partners-led group valued at $4.50 per share.

The Carlyle Group has announced the closing of its third European property fund at 2.2 billion euros ($3.4 billion), far above its initial fundraising target of 1.5 billion euros, and an indication of the continued strength of European demand, The Daily Deal reported.
China Telecom said it is in talks to sell a stake to a strategic investor to help it expand after acquiring mobile-phone assets, Bloomberg reported.
Securities exchange IntercontinentalExchange has entered into an agreement to buy credit processor Creditex Group in a cash and stock deal valued at $625 million, The Associated Press reported.

Novartis has bought U.S.-based Protez Pharmaceuticals in a deal worth up to $400 million, Reuters reported. The deal would give Novartis rights to an antibiotic which could be used to fight superbugs such as MRSA, the Swiss drugmaker said.
Sinosteel has lifted its stake in Midwest to 28.4 percent from just under 20 percent in its tussle for control of the miner with Australian bidder Murchison Metals.
Kirin Holdings and Warrnambool Cheese & Butter Factory will partner to bid for Dairy Farmers, the Australian producer of Bornhoffen yogurt and the Coon and Cracker Barrel cheeses, Bloomberg reported.

Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited is considering offering shares to government employees along with a considerable reservation for BSNL staff. Should the proposal go through, it would be the first such I.P.O., RTT News reported.
Anu's Laboratories and Gokul Refoils & Solvent gained on their first day of trading in Mumbai, following the slowest month for initial share sales in two years, Bloomberg News reported.

"I'm mind-boggled; I really never thought that I would live to see a black candidate," Mr. Cousey said. Maybe it was her night after all: Hillary Clinton decided not to withdraw from the presidential campaign tonight, and the liberals in blogville are not happy about it, to put it mildly. Matthew Yglesias of The Atlantic begins his blog post on Clinton's speech by writing, "I probably shouldn't write any more about this woman and her staff. Suffice it to say that I've found her behavior over the past couple of months to be utterly unconscionable and this speech is no different." He continues, " I think if I were to try to express how I really feel about the people who've been enabling her behavior, I'd say something deeply unwise. Suffice it to say, that for quite a while now all of John McCain's most effective allies have been on Hillary Clinton's payroll."

“Inside the NFL,” which HBO Sports canceled in February after a 31-year run, was picked up by Showtime. It will be produced by CBS Sports, a corporate sister of Showtime, and NFL Films, and be shown Wednesday nights. HBO dropped the program, saying that it had lost its uniqueness amid the proliferation of N.F.L.-oriented studio programs on television.

Influential officials from the International Olympic Committee accused the United States committee of refusing to renegotiate its “immoral” share of global Olympic revenues, reopening a dispute that could harm Chicago’s bid for the 2016 Games. Under a long-standing deal with the international committee, the United States Olympic Committee receives nearly 13 percent of American TV rights fees and 20 percent of global marketing revenues — hundreds of millions of dollars. Discussions about reducing the share have failed to produce an agreement. “I simply do not understand how you can justify that the rest of the world has to pay for the training of American athletes,” said Hein Verbruggen, a Dutch I.O.C. member.

Antonio Pettigrew agreed to return the Olympic relay gold medal he won in 2000 after admitting to doping during the Sydney Games. During the trial of the former track coach Trevor Graham, Pettigrew last month admitted to using EPO and human growth hormone from 1997 to 2003. Graham was found guilty of lying to federal investigators about his relationship to a steroids dealer.

Sven-Goran Eriksson, the former manager of the English national team, has been hired as Mexico’s national team coach. Eriksson’s contract with Manchester City of the Premier League was terminated Monday after only one season in charge, and with two years remaining. .
A judge has barred any contact between a 16-year-old girl who, her lawyers said, was sexually abused in a West Texas polygamist group, and her father, Warren S. Jeffs, who leads that group.
The Bush administration’s strategy for bending science to its political ends has resulted in seven lost years in this country’s fight against global warming.
Coco Crisp hit a tie-breaking double as Boston won a matchup of the American League East’s top two teams, defeating the visiting Tampa Bay Rays, 7-4, on Tuesday night.
With his horse just one race away from becoming the first Triple Crown champion since 1978, Rick Dutrow cannot help but talk trash.
A new call to cap property taxes for schools is an election-year gimmick that will do far more damage than good for New York.

The trial into an alleged plot to blow up as many as seven trans-Atlantic airliners on a single day in 2006 is expected to last eight months in London.
Critics see a push to teach the “strengths and weaknesses” of Darwinian theory as an effort to undermine evolution.

A judge ruled that the City of Philadelphia could not enforce new ordinances that would ban assault weapons and limit handgun purchases to one per person per month. The judge, Jane Cutler Greenspan of the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas, ruled in favor of the National Rifle Association, which argued that only the legislature had the right to make gun laws. But Judge Greenspan denied on procedural grounds the association’s request to overturn three other gun ordinances. One would allow guns to be removed from people who were declared to be a risk to themselves or others, and another would do the same for those under a protection-from-abuse order. The third would require the reporting of lost or stolen guns.
Eight Belles will be interred at the Kentucky Derby Museum, near the grave sites of four Kentucky Derby winners.

Senator Robert C. Byrd, left, was taken to a hospital Monday evening and will be treated there for a mild infection for several more days, his office said. Mr. Byrd, 90, a West Virginia Democrat who is the longest-serving senator, was hospitalized after feeling lethargic at work. He went home after a 5:30 p.m. Senate vote, was found to have a fever and was taken to Inova Fairfax Hospital for observation. A spokesman, Jesse Jacobs, said Mr. Byrd was “alert, talking with staff and in good spirits, and looks forward to getting back to work as soon as possible.”.

The San Francisco medical examiner said a teenager had marijuana and alcohol in his system when he was killed on Dec. 25 by an escaped tiger at the San Francisco Zoo. The toxicology report was included with an autopsy concluding that “blunt force injuries of the head and neck” killed Carlos Sousa Jr., 17. Mr. Sousa’s family has filed a claim against the city as a precursor to a lawsuit. Michael Cardoza, a lawyer for the Sousa family, said it was “totally irrelevant” whether the teenager had been drinking or smoking marijuana before the mauling.
One day after undergoing surgery on a malignant brain tumor in North Carolina, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts was walking around, a statement said.

A man accused of joining Al Qaeda in the early 1990s and helping teach fellow Muslim extremists to bomb American and European targets overseas pleaded guilty to planning terrorist attacks. The man, Christopher Paul, 44, left, entered a plea agreement that calls for a 20-year term. Judge Gregory L. Frost of Federal District Court in Columbus accepted the plea but said he would not give final approval to the deal until he saw the government’s presentencing report. Prosecutors say Mr. Paul, who was born and raised in Ohio, traveled to Pakistan and Afghanistan beginning in 1990 to meet Qaeda members.

A death row inmate received a reprieve from execution about 90 minutes before he was scheduled to be put to death after lawyers questioned whether the state’s lethal injection procedures were legal. The inmate, Derrick Sonnier, 40, left, was convicted of killing a suburban Houston woman and her 2-year-old son. He would have been the first prisoner put to death in the state in nearly nine months. Executions had been postponed while the United States Supreme Court considered a similar challenge to injection procedures in a Kentucky case. In October, the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals, which granted the reprieve, halted the execution of Heliberto Chi on the same issues. The Chi case has still not been resolved.
Mr. Kelley created the visual equivalent of an acid trip in psychedelic concert posters for artists like the Grateful Dead and Jimi Hendrix.

A well-known immigrant advocacy organization based in Silver Spring said it had received a string of anonymous telephone messages threatening violence. The Rev. Simón Bautista, vice president of the board of the group, CASA de Maryland, said a message was left Sunday on an office phone warning that he could have a “bullet in the back” of his brain, while a bomb threat was left the same day on the cellphone of Mario Quiroz, the group’s spokesman. The group, which runs several centers for immigrant day laborers in Maryland, frequently receives hostile calls and e-mail, Mr. Quiroz said, but threats of violence are unusual. Maryland police and the F.B.I. said they were investigating the calls.
Brazil will seek sanctions against the United States after winning a World Trade Organization ruling on cotton subsidies, a top Brazilian trade official said Tuesday.

A Paris court on Tuesday found Brigitte Bardot, right, guilty of provoking discrimination and racial hatred for writing that Muslims are destroying France, The Associated Press reported. It was her fifth conviction for inciting racial hatred. Ms. Bardot, the film star turned animal rights campaigner, was also fined $23,325 and ordered to pay $1,555 to the French group Movement Against Racism and for Friendship of People. The group filed a lawsuit last year over a letter Ms. Bardot sent in December 2006 to Nicolas Sarkozy, then the interior minister and now the president of France. In that letter, published in her animal rights foundation’s journal, Ms. Bardot said that France was “tired of being led by the nose by this population that is destroying us, destroying our country by imposing its acts.” She was referring to the Muslim feast of Aid el-Kebir, which is celebrated by slaughtering sheep.

The nonprofit MAK Center for Art and Architecture in Los Angeles has acquired R. M. Schindler’s renowned Modernist Fitzpatrick-Leland House, shown above when it was built in 1936, perched on a cliff near the intersection of Laurel Canyon Boulevard and Mulholland Drive, the center said. The three-level L-shaped house, with its interlocking volumes, was a gift from Russ Leland, who bought it in 1990 and spent years restoring it to its original design. The MAK Center said the house would be used for its new Urban Future Initiative program, which grants two-month residencies to researchers from around the world exploring urban issues like sustainability, immigration and social justice.

The defense begins presenting its case on Wednesday in the R. Kelly child pornography trial in Chicago, after testimony by a woman who said she had had several three-way sexual encounters with Mr. Kelly and an allegedly under-age victim. The prosecution witness, Lisa Van Allen, 27, told jurors on Monday that Mr. Kelly, the R&B star, offered her $250,000 last year to recover a tape of one of the trysts, The Associated Press reported. She denied a defense lawyer’s accusation that she was trying to extort money, but admitted stealing his $20,000 diamond-studded watch. Mr. Kelly, 41, has pleaded not guilty to charges of videotaping himself having sex with a girl who prosecutors say was as young as 13. On Tuesday, the judge, Vincent Gaughan, issued a new order for a Chicago Sun-Times reporter to appear in court. The reporter, Jim DeRogatis, who was sent the tape in question, has argued that his actions are protected under the First Amendment.

Repeats on Fox lifted that network to No. 1 in the ratings on Monday, as “House” at 9 p.m. attracted the night’s largest audience, 9.4 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. While Fox’s “Bones” was the most-watched show during the 8 p.m. hour, with 6.7 million viewers, it trailed in its time slot among adults 18 to 49. Fox ranked third for the night in that demographic, just behind CBS and NBC, which tied for first. CBS earned second place in total viewers thanks to solid ratings for repeats of its comedy lineup followed by a rerun of “CSI: Miami” at 10 (8.8 million). Meanwhile, NBC’s live coverage of Game 5 of the N.H.L. Stanley Cup finals averaged about 6 million viewers, on a par with ABC’s schedule for the night. ABC broadcast a two-hour edition of “The Bachelorette” (6.5 million), followed by the season premiere of “The Mole” at 10 (4.7 million). ABC finished fourth over all among the 18-to-49 set.

From the classical music world come two stories of coping. The Philharmonie, home of the Berlin Philharmonic, reopened for concerts and tours on Monday, less than two weeks after a fire, and the Philadelphia Orchestra turned its Beijing concert into a benefit for rebuilding after the earthquake that devastated parts of Sichuan Province, China, last month. The German Symphony Orchestra was the first to perform in the Philharmonie’s main concert hall after a May 20 fire forced rescue crews to tear down a quarter of the roof, The Associated Press reported. The Berlin Philharmonic is scheduled to return Thursday to perform works by Shostakovich and Ravel. Meanwhile on Tuesday, the Philadelphia Orchestra’s concert, with the pianist Lang Lang and the conductor Christoph Eschenbach, was to be recorded and broadcast by CCTV, China’s largest television network, and fed to Phoenix TV in Hong Kong for broadcast, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. Negotiations are under way with PBS for an American broadcast, according to the report. The proceeds will help rebuild the Sichuan school system. The orchestra, which is near the end of a three-week tour of Asia, is waiving its broadcast fee and will make a donation to the China Youth Development Foundation. The broadcasts will solicit individual donations.
Peter Gelb, the Metropolitan Opera’s general manager, has added a member to his brain trust.

The Justice Department and the International Spy Museum have reached a settlement to bring the museum into compliance with the Americans With Disabilities Act, making its exhibitions and public programs more accessible to people with impaired hearing and vision, the department said on Tuesday. The museum will begin offering tactile maps and floor plans, as well as tours with a docent to talk about the visual presentations and exhibits. Since opening in 2002, the private International Spy Museum has been a popular attraction in Washington.

The singer-songwriter Tori Amos has left Epic Records after six years to become independent and urged her fellow artists to “stop being dependent, dependent on any system that has become undependable,” Reuters reported. In a statement on her Web site (toriamos.com), Ms. Amos, 44, said she looked forward to crossing into the new uncharted music frontier. She released three albums on Epic, most recently “American Doll Posse” in 2007, which hit No. 5 on the Billboard 500. Before that she was with Atlantic from 1992 to 2001, when she, along with Rod Stewart, Poe, Collective Soul and other artists, left that label.

She was loved and adored by all, including six grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Janet attended Teachers College at Columbia University and graduated from New York University. DUBIN--Warren B., passed away June 1, 2008 at age 87 in Delray Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Anne (Meyer), devoted father of Emily. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, he served as an Army Lieutenant in the Pacific area during WWII. Previous resident of Stamford, CT. Longtime President of the Stamford Symphony Orchestra and co-founder of the Stamford Senior Center. His business life was in advertising and marketing (Milton Biow Co., Norman B. Services will be private. Donations may be made to Alzheimer's Association.

d'HARNONCOURT--Anne, was a highly respected force in the art world, who led the way for women in the rarified area of museum directorship. She, along with her husband, curator Joe Rishel, brought so much, not only to Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Museum itself, but also to the art world as a whole both nationally and internationally. Anne was a true visionary who had an incredibly keen eye for both art and for people. She was a kind and compassionate friend to so many of the artists that she supported. Anne's stature, presence and old world elegance will be sorely missed by the art community that respected her so greatly, and by us, as a dearly loved friend and colleague. Agnes Gund and Daniel Shapiro d'HARNONCOURT--Anne. We grieve for the loss of our dear friend. John and Rosamond d'HARNONCOURT--Anne. The directors and staff of the Henry Luce Foundation mourn the sudden loss of their distinguished colleague, and convey deepest sympathy to her husband Joseph Rishel. Serving on the foundation's board since 1994, she brought enormous energy, insight and intelligence to our deliberations, particularly in the field of American art. We will remember her fondly and will miss her profoundly. Margaret Boles Fitzgerald, Chair Michael Gilligan, President d'HARNONCOURT--Anne. The John Cage Trust at Bard College mourns the loss of Anne d'Harnoncourt. A long and valued friend of John Cage and Merce Cunningham, she was a founding trustee of the John Cage Trust and instrumental in its placement at Bard College. Her warmth, humor, enthusiasm, and lovely common sense will be sadly missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, Joseph Rishel, and to all of the members of the staff at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Laura Kuhn, Exec. Director Merce Cunningham and David Vaughan,Trustees The John Cage Trust at Bard College d'HARNONCOURT--Anne. The Board of Trustees and staff at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation deeply mourn the sudden loss of their esteemed colleague Anne d'Harnoncourt. Her leadership of the Philadelphia Museum was inspiring to all. William Mack, Chairman Jennifer Stockman, President Thomas Krens, Director Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation Marc Steglitz, Interim Director Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum d'HARNONCOURT--Anne. We mourn the loss of Anne d'Harnoncourt, a dear friend to Isamu Noguchi and member of the editorial board for his catalogue raisonne. The loss of this most gracious woman, fine scholar and steadfast leader impacts our community greatly. We offer condolences to her husband and family. Respectfully, Samuel Sachs II, Chairman; Richard Lanier, Vice Chairman; Jenny Dixon, Director; Bonnie Rychlak, Managing Editor, Catalogue Raisonne; and The Board of Trustees of The Isamu Noguchi Foundation and Garden Museum

MacDONALD--Arley Lundie, 78, died Sunday, June 1, 2008, in Asheville, North Carolina. Burial was at Trinity Episcopal Church in Asheville. She held an earned doctorate from Columbia University in Library Service and masters degrees from New York University (Medieval Literature) and Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, New York (Library and Information Science). She taught at New York University and Queens College of the City of New York and at the Graduate School of Library and Information Services at Simmons College in Boston. She was Technical Librarian at Kennecott Copper Corporation, a Library Consultant, and retired as Head Librarian of the Fairfield County Historical Society. Mrs. MacDonald moved to North Carolina in 1992 and was preceded in death by her husband, Bryce Inglis MacDonald. She is survived by two brothers, Kenneth Gordon Lundie of Riegelsville, PA and Stuart Stevenson Lundie of Hudson, MA, their families, as well as her husband's children and their families. Memorials may be sent to the Bryce I. MacDonald Engineering Deans Fund at Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, 14853. Groce Funeral Home, Arden, NC grocefuneralhome.com.

DRESHER--Lottie. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Lottie Dresher of Glencoe, Ill. A warm and kind person and a zealous supporter of Israel and the Technion, Mrs. Dresher, together with her husband Max, of blessed memory, provided generous support for numerous ATS endeavors as members of the Chicago and Palm Beach Chapters. Among the projects they supported are the Max and Lottie Dresher Chair in Aerospace Performance and Propulsion, and the Dresher Laboratory Maintenance Fund. Mr. Dresher spearheaded the concept of the Technion Guardians, a group that now represents the highest level of support. Mr. Dresher received an Honorary Fellowship from the Technion in 1985, and an Honorary Doctorate in 1991. To son Glen Dresher, grandchildren, and nephew Owen Wilner, we send our heartfelt condolences. Joan Seidel, President Dr. Stephen A. Laser, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Cynde Hirschtick Munzer, Chicago Chapter President Richard D. Zelin, West Central Region Director

WALSH--Richard S., 78, died on Saturday, May 31, 2008 at his home in Savannah, GA. Dick was born in New York City on January 19, 1930. He was the son of Richard and Catherine (Leahy) Walsh. Dick graduated from All Hallows High School and Fordham College. After service in the US Navy, he graduated from Fordham Law School. Concurrent with night law school he started a 38 year career with Metropolitan Life Insurance Company as an attorney in the Law Department and as an executive in the Group Department retiring in 1994 as a Senior Vice President. Survivors: His wife of 45 years, Anita June (nee Sullivan). Children: Denise McMonagle (Robert) of Davenport, Iowa; Karen Mosier (Carl) of Fredonia, NY; and Richard D. Walsh (Maureen) of Haddonfield, NJ. Grandchildren: Patrick and Grace McMonagle; Katie and Chris Anne Mosier; and Shannon and Molly Walsh. He was preceded in death by his parents and his siblings: Helen Williams; Msgr. James Walsh; Margaret Crimmins; and Mary Chartrand. Mass of Christian Burial: 11:00am Thursday June 5, 2008 at St. James Catholic Church in Savannah, GA. Visitation one hour before Mass at St. James. A Memorial Service will also be held on June 14, 2008 at 10:30am at Blessed Sacrament Catholic Church in New Rochelle, NY with interment to follow at Holy Sepulchre Cemetery in New Rochelle, NY. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to Habitat for Humanity International, 121 Habitat Street, Americus, GA 31709-3498. Please sign our on - line guest book at www.foxandweeks.com.

FIGEL--Christina Jean, of Jersey City, 40, passed on Monday, June 2, 2008 at her sister's home in Toms River. Born in Toms River, she lived in England for two years before relocating to the New York City metro area. Christina was a Director of Special Markets for Random House, Inc. in Manhattan. Christina is survived by her parents Donald and Jean Figel of New Smyrna Beach, Florida, her sister and brother-in-law Heather and Michael Feimer of Toms River, and her brother Matthew of New Smyrna Beach, Florida. Her nieces and nephew are Brandilyn Christina Feimer, Caliann Sophia Feimer, and Michael Anthony John Feimer. An informal memorial gathering will be held on Saturday, June 7, 2008 from 3-5pm at the Silverton Memorial Funeral Home, 2482 Church Rd, Toms River, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate memorial donations to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, a cause to which Christina diligently contributed. Christina's sister wishes to hand-deliver the gifts in August. Christina passionately lived a life she designed herself, integrating friends gained during her world travels with lifelong bonds to hometown loved ones, fanatical exercise with contemplative reading, a glamourtinged career in Manhattan publishing with a deep devotion to spiritual wholeness. Her journey through this life indelibly marked the hearts of those who knew her, hearts forever incomplete because of her loss.

AUGUST--Stanley, M.D., died peacefully on June 2, 2008 at the age of 90. Dr. August practiced internal medicine and cardiology in Brooklyn for 40 years. He graduated from the Harvard Medical School in 1942, where he studied with the renowned cardiologist Dr. Paul Dudley White. Following medical school, he served as a Captain in the US Army during World War II and participated in the liberation of the Dachau concentration camp. He returned to Brooklyn and married his beloved Renee Levine. Working at Downstate Medical Center, he published the first report of methotrexate use in severe psoriasis. He was also an NYPD captain and surgeon. He was known for his kindness, wit and erudition. He leaves his children, Ellen, Phyllis, Bill and David, their spouses, M. Suthanthiran, Barbara August and Amy Wilson, his sister Selma Rubenstein and his grandchildren, Benjamin, Nathaniel, Aaron, Seth and Harry. Services will be at the Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Thursday, June 5 at 11:15am. Donations can be sent to The Wright Center on Aging, NY Presbyterian Hospital, 1484 1st Avenue, NY, NY 10075.

SUSSMAN--Harold, loved by his wife and soulmate Mindy, his daughter Marian, his grandchildren Maya and Joshua and his son-in-law Michael, passed away Monday June 2nd, 2008. He was a modern architect in New York City who lived life to its fullest and was a kind and compassionate human being. The funeral will be Wednesday, June 4th at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on Amsterdam Avenue and 91st Street at 10am. Donations may be made to National Brain Tumor Foundation www.braintumor.org SUSSMAN--Harold. The community of West End Synagogue, A Reconstructionist Congregation, grieves over the loss of our voice of reason and artistic expression. And his delicious basso profundo never-ever-refused us anything. His Mindy's amazing, but not surprising, walk with him through his long and painful leavetaking was a celebration of their life together. Our love to Mindy and all their family.

AIELLO--Lydia Lee LeBrun, on June 1st, 2008, in New York at the age of 69. A beautiful mother, daughter, wife, sister, friend came to rest in God's arms. She will be missed and loved always. ''...It might have appeared to go unnoticed, but I've got it all here in my heart. I want you to know I know the truth. I would be nothing without you. Did you ever know that you're my hero? You're everything I wish I could be. I could fly higher than an eagle, for you are the wind beneath my wings.''-Larry Henley, Jeff Silbar. Visitation Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 at ''The Riverside'' 76th and Amsterdam. Funeral Mass at Old St. Patrick's Church, Thursday, 10:30am. Interment at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to a charity of your choice.

BRASINO--Dr. John Joseph, of Hastings-On-Hudson, NY, on June 1, 2008 at the age of 90 after a prolonged illness. He is survived by his wife Anne of 12 years and his children by his first marriage, Christine and John (Terry), his grandchildren Elizabeth, Marie, Lauren, Michael, Christopher and Claudia. His brother Paul (Adie) and sister Josephine, many nephews and one niece. Dr. Brasino served in WWII as Chief of Surgery in Iceland and Newfoundland. His residency training in OB-GYN was at St. Clare's Hospital, NYC. He also practiced at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers and Mt. Vernon Hospital. He was a member of Westchester County Medical Society, MSSNY, AMA, FACS, FICS, FACOG. He was board certified in 1954 and recertified in 1973. Visitation will be held Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9pm, at the Flynn Memorial Home Inc., (1652 Central Park Ave.) Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Thursday 11am, St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Bronxville, NY. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Memorial donations may be made to Good Counsel Home Inc., PO Box 6068, Hoboken, NJ 07030.

In quiet ceremonies, several Israeli families buried remains of relatives who were killed in the 2006 war against Hezbollah in Lebanon. After Hezbollah, a militant Shiite organization, sent a box of soldiers' body parts across the border in a surprise move on Sunday, the Israeli military quickly identified tissue belonging to five soldiers. Hezbollah's gesture, after Israel freed a Hezbollah member convicted of spying, has been widely seen in Israel as a possible prelude to a prisoner exchange involving the two Israeli soldiers whose capture by Hezbollah set off the monthlong war. ISABEL KERSHNER

THINKING SMALLER With gas near $4 a gallon, more people are deciding that the benefits of owning big vehicles are not worth the costs. Economic Scene: David Leonhardt. General Motors announced drastic cuts in the production of sport utility vehicles and pickups and stepped up plans for smaller cars and engines. [C1.]

As rice prices doubled in three years, the poverty rate in Bangladesh, one of the world's poorest countries, has begun to increase after a recent decline, a preliminary study by the nonpartisan Center for Policy Dialogue says. ''The spectacular rise in the price of rice appears to have reversed the trends of the recent past,'' Mustafizur Rahman, research director at the center, based in Dhaka, said by e-mail. According to data from the government of Bangladesh, the cost of rice, the staple of the Bengali diet, is 46 percent of a poor household's monthly expenses. The army, which backs Bangladesh's caretaker government, lately has been promoting greater consumption of potatoes. SOMINI SENGUPTA

Devoted husband of Juliet Bortner, beloved father of Kathy Gabriel, Ph.D. and Judd Bortner, Ph.D., proud grandfather of Jazmine, David, Ben, Jacob and Isaac. Also survived by daughter-inlaw Melissa Hart and brother Oscar Bortner. He will be deeply missed by all those who knew him and loved him. Before yesterday, the last time I visited the Mont Tremblant racing circuit was in 1999. It was not just old and decrepit, it was a veritable ghost of a lost Formula One track. The pit building was nothing but rubble, the surface of the track had not been redone since it was first laid down in 1964. But I loved the charm of the place.

Outside, as the casket was brought to the sidewalk after the service, Pierre Berge waved a final farewell. It's hard to imagine his thoughts and emotions at the end of Saint Laurent's life, which was, after all, linked so deeply to his own.

Gov. David A. Paterson has picked Robert G. Wilmers, the chairman and chief executive of M&T Bank Corporation, to become chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation -- the economic development arm of the state government.Mr. Wilmers has been a prolific campaign contributor to both political parties and donated $40,000 to the Spitzer-Paterson campaign in 2005 and 2006. He will remain chairman of Buffalo-based M&T Bank, according to a spokesman for the Paterson administration -- a move that will likely require him to consult with the Commission on Public Integrity about navigating conflicts of interests.

One reason I like small literary magazines is that they offer aesthetic refuge from the rest of the news cycle. The best are like little walled gardens: safe spots for delicate specimens where everything from the paper stock to the kerning has received careful attention from the editors. And while I'm a Web guy (I think "Web Guy" is actually my job title here at the Book Review), I have no problem saying I prefer my lit mags between paper covers. The online offerings at n+1 and McSweeney's are fun for a quick break, but the sites don't invite an easy-chair reverie - at least not from me. And if I find a story I want to read in Narrative, I'm going to print it out first.

The profoundly ambivalent images of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed -- of a disheveled captive in a mug shot, and of a ruthless tactician over years of terrorism -- intersected at the military tribunal in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, where he was arraigned today. For most Americans, the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow are a ghost Games. When Jimmy Carter pulled out the U.S. team to protest the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, hundreds of athletes lost their only chance at Olympic glory. And it wasn't good news for NBC either. They were looking forward to breaking ABC's monopoly on Games coverage, but ended up being stuck for $34 million and showing only a handful of taped highlights.

The funeral this afternoon for Yves Saint Laurent at the Église Saint-Roch began at 3:30 and ended around 5, although photographers had gathered in front of the small church before 9 o'clock this morning. Rue St.-Honoré was eventually closed for the arrival of French president Nicolas Sarkozy and his wife, Carla, who wore a charcoal pantsuit, and there were throngs of people in the smaller streets nearby.About 800 people were reportedly invited to the funeral for Saint Laurent, who died Sunday evening at his home. Pierre Bergé was of course there, as was Saint Laurent's mother, Lucienne Saint Laurent. Among the designers attending were Hubert de Givenchy, Jean Paul Gaultier, Alber Elbaz, John Galliano, Sonia Rykiel, Stefano Pilati, Christian Lacroix and Vivienne Westwood. According to wire reports, Karl Lagerfeld, who first met Saint Laurent in the 1950s when they won Wool Secretariat prizes, was away on business. It surprised me, though, that he didn't attend the funeral.

In the 139 runnings of the Belmont Stakes, 60 (43 percent) have been won by the post-time favorite, but only five of those have captured the Test of the Champion in the past 25 years. Odds-on favorites have raced in 30 Belmonts, with 12 (40 percent) winning, 10 finishing second and 3 running third. While the performances of favorites has been better than the national average of approximately 33 percent of winners, there are some historical factors to consider if you want to take a stand against Big Brown in the top spot Saturday.

One of the great criticisms of the euro has always been that it imposes one-size-fits-all monetary policy. If Germany is booming while Italy is slumping, well, that's too bad: the ECB sets the same interest rate for everyone. The answer, said euro advocates, was labor market flexibility -- a euphemism for saying that Italian wages should fall so as to make industry more competitive, effectively achieving the same real result as a lira devaluation. But as far as I know, there is no economy anywhere in which nominal wages fall quickly in the face of weak demand.

On Sunday PLAY presented readers an online video debate over the question of whether Tiger Woods was the greatest athletic performer of all time. Readers were allowed to cast their own vote and share their opinion, and the result was a mixture of outrage, rumination, praise and detailed analysis. As of mid-day Thursday, almost 4,700 readers had cast votes, with 72 percent saying Woods is not the best ever, and 28 percent saying he is. More than 500 people posted comments, ranging from “He has good aim, does that make him an athlete?” to “without Tiger, Obama would not be possible.”.

“Why can’t The New York Times write about the SAVAGERY and BRUTALITY” of bullfighting, ended one letter from a reader in Chicago. It was a sentiment echoed by a New Jersey reader who wrote, “This kind of gory spectacle deserves to die. To glorify it is disgusting.”.

“The power of the sports commercial is that it conveys the illusion of intimacy with an athlete,” Bryan Curtis writes in the June issue of PLAY. “It was from a commercial that we learned that Michael Jordan was jolly; that LeBron James could inhabit multiple characters with the aplomb of Alec Guinness in ‘Kind Hearts and Coronets’ (or at least Eddie Murphy in ‘The Nutty Professor’); that Peyton Manning was a hipster ironist. In the span of a 30-second ad, the gulf between athlete and fan seems to close, at least a bit. Against all evidence to the contrary, Charles and Michael and Peyton and LeBron begin to feel like our old pals.

How’d we get from icing and Advil to drinking chocolate milk for muscle recovery? Gretchen Reynolds, who wrote about recovery from workouts in the latest issue of PLAY, says that until recently, no one actually tested the conventional strategies. Rather, many athletes just trusted the advice passed down by a friend or relative. But now, she says, we have some solid evidence, in the form of legitimate medical studies, about what works and doesn’t work. If you want to see real benefits, studies show, you’ll need the right mix of proteins and carbohydrates to replenish stressed muscles, and the sooner their taken after a workout, the better. That’s where the chocolate milk comes in (and the multitude of protein drinks now available.).
