CBS’s lineup of mostly repeats edged past Fox for the most viewers on Tuesday, even as Fox easily led the night among adults 18 to 49. Fox broadcast the top two shows in that demographic, “The Moment of Truth” at 8 p.m. and “Hell’s Kitchen” at 9 p.m., with “Hell’s Kitchen” also delivering the night’s largest audience, 9.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Leading the night for CBS was a rerun of “NCIS” (9.1 million), which easily outdrew Fox’s “Moment of Truth” (6.7 million) in total viewers during the 8 p.m. time slot. At 9, CBS’s “48 Hours Mystery” garnered 8 million viewers, while CBS’s repeat of “Without a Trace” won the 10 p.m. hour (7.6 million) ahead of reruns of ABC’s “Boston Legal” (3.9 million) and NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (5.9 million). NBC finished third for the night, followed by ABC.

After a four-year absence,ExxonMobil will resume sponsorships of PBS programs this month, PBS announced. ExxonMobil will partly underwrite the news program “Nightly Business Report” and the science program “Nova” through the end of 2008. The company had sponsored “Masterpiece Theater” and other PBS programs for three decades but decided to withdraw its support in 2004. The new sponsorship fills a significant gap for “Nightly Business Report,” a half-hour daily broadcast. One of the show’s two sponsors, A. G. Edwards, ended its support in January, citing budget restraints. The other sponsor, Franklin Templeton, renewed its deal in January. The program still has room for two more sponsors. “Nova” is also underwritten by the Howard Hughes Medical Institute and David H. Koch, an owner of Koch Industries. That program is seeking another sponsor as well.

A writer for The Chicago Sun-Times refused to answer questions on Wednesday at R. Kelly’s child pornography trial, The Associated Press reported. In his refusal, the writer, Jim DeRogatis, cited an Illinois law that governs reporters’ rights, as well as the First and Fifth Amendments to the Constitution. Mr. DeRogatis read a statement more than a dozen times in response to questions, including whether he had once made a copy of a sex tape that is at the center of the trial. Defense lawyers have said that copying the tape — which is said to show Mr. Kelly having sex with a minor — would have been a crime. Mr. Kelly has said that he was not the man in the tape. After Mr. DeRogatis’s 10 minutes on the stand, Judge Vincent Gaughan of Cook County Criminal Court said reporters’ privileges did not apply. But the judge ruled that Mr. De Rogatis did not have to testify, citing his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.

Lynyrd Skynyrd, Bob Marley and Jimi Hendrix are among the performers whose vintage concerts will become part of the nearly 500 recordings available for download purchase at Wolfgang’s Vault, the music and memorabilia site (wolfgangsvault.com). The additions came through a deal between Universal Music Group and the founder of Wolfgang’s Vault, Bill Sagan, Reuters reported. Of the 1,434 concerts on the site, 488 can be downloaded now, Mr. Sagan told Billboard.com, adding that “some very major artists will be downloading within the next 30 to 60 days.”.

The revival of “A Chorus Line,” playing at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on Broadway, will close on Aug. 17. The critically praised production opened in October 2006 and will have played 18 previews and 759 regular performances when it closes. It recouped its $8 million investment in less than five months. ... Sharon Stone is not welcome at the Shanghai International Film Festival, as the backlash in China against her continued on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Stone stirred outrage in China after suggesting that the recent earthquake had been the result of bad karma. Meanwhile, the Black Eyed Peas helped raise nearly $870,000 for victims of the earthquake at a private charity concert in Shanghai, Agence France-Presse reported. ... Van Morrison and Patti Smith will be among the 30 acts at this year’s four-day Stockholm Jazz Festival, which is to start on July 16, organizers said.
The division of Paramount Pictures that helped produce the Oscar-winning films “No Country for Old Men” and “There Will Be Blood” has been cut back.

Ed McMahon, below, Johnny Carson’s former sidekick on “The Tonight Show” and the former host of “Star Search,” is said to face foreclosure on his multimillion-dollar Beverly Hills house, above, because he is $644,000 behind in payments. The Associated Press reported that Mr. McMahon had fallen behind in payments on $4.8 million in mortgage loans. A unit of the Countrywide Financial Corporation filed a default notice on Feb. 28 with the Los Angeles County Recorder’s Office, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. Beyond his decades of work with Carson, Mr. McMahon, 85, has also been a spokesman for the American Family Publishers’ sweepstakes. But Howard Bragman, his spokesman, said Mr. McMahon had not been able to work as a spokesman for various products since he broke his neck 18 months ago. He added that Mr. McMahon had been in “very fruitful discussions” with the lender to resolve the situation. It is unclear whether Mr. McMahon and his wife, Pamela, will remain in the six-bedroom, five-bathroom house, in a hilltop gated community overlooking Mulholland Drive. It is listed for sale at $6.25 million and has been on the market for two years, said a real estate agent, Alex Davis.

Usher, below, has made the second-biggest splash of the year on the Billboard chart. His new album, “Here I Stand” (LaFace/Zomba), sold 433,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan; so far only Mariah Carey has had a bigger entrance, with “E=MC2” (Island) moving 463,000 in April. In an otherwise slow week, Usher’s album sold more than the rest of the Top 10 put together. The soundtrack to “Sex and the City” (New Line) bowed at No. 2 with 66,000. Last week’s top seller, the self-titled record on Universal Republic by 3 Doors Down, dropped to No. 3 with 63,000, and Bun B’s “II Trill” (Rap-A-Lot/Asylum) fell two spots to No. 4, with 40,000. Leona Lewis, a 23-year-old British singer who has been a steady presence in the Top 10 for two months, moved up one to No. 5, with 39,000 sales of “Spirit” (Syco/J). Down the chart, Al Green scored the highest opening-week chart position of his career: his acclaimed new album, “Lay It Down” (Blue Note), moved 34,000 copes to reach No. 9.

CROWN--Marian Ruth, known to everyone as Rufus, 95. Born on March 8, 1913 in Nashville, TN, lived her remarkable adult life on 5th Ave. and CPW, and, never having lost her Nashville accent nor her Southern charm, died peacefully at home on May 31st. For 41 enchanted years, married to Alfred Crown, the Broadway and motion picture producer. Adored mother of Patricia Crown, the New York entertainment lawyer, who survives her, along with her beloved son-in-law and granddaughter Tony and Julia Radice. Rufus had a magical gift for friendship; she touched, embraced and united the lives of a remarkable breadth of people of every age and description, from the famous to the rest of us, and cared about each one individually. She was a mentor, teacher, civic volunteer, hostess extraordinaire, friend and patron of theater, music, the arts and numerous artists, and supporter of all causes liberal and progressive, including black-listed writers, Alger Hiss, civil rights, women's rights and the demise of the Bush administration. In lieu of flowers, donations to a fund to be created supporting children in need would be appreciated.

The CableBox is large enough --16 inches long, 6 1/4 inches wide and 5 1/2 inches tall -- to conceal most surge protectors, with enough room left over for the tangle of wires surrounding them. Made of fire-retardant plastic, it has openings at either end so cords can run in and out, above, and generously sized rubber feet to keep it from sliding across the floor. Dominic Symons, the designer, describes it as ''the absolute simplest way'' of organizing cables. ''Basically, you can take the mess under your desk,'' he said, ''fit it in the box without even unplugging any of the cables, and put the lid on it.'' Available later this month for about $30. Information: bluelounge.com.

TENDING THE FARM ON A VISIT TO FRANCE The Frugal Traveler, Matt Gross, works for his keep in southwestern France through Wwoof, which stands for World Wide Opportunities on Organic Farms. Wwoof is an international network of farmers who offer room and board in exchange for the labor of travelers. Visits can last as little as a week, or as long as six months, depending on one's skills, schedule and relationship with the host. And except for a modest fee to join a country's branch, Wwoof-ing is free. nytimes.com/frugaltraveler

IVERS--Lenore Sophia, 54, of New York, NY died Friday May 30, 2008 in the St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital, New York City. Lenore was born in Gardner, on March 23, 1954, the daughter of the late Joseph and the late Frances E. (Tawter) Ivers. She leaves two brothers, Dr. James J. Ivers with wife Gail, daughters Melissa and Katelyn, and son Jonathan of West Boylston, MA, and Paul F. Ivers with wife Sarah and two sons, Joseph and Noah of Bedford, MA. She grew up in Gardner and attended Sacred Heart School grades 1-8, then graduating from Gardner High School as Valedictorian in 1972. Upon graduation, she earned a Bachelor degree in Economics from Wellesley College, followed by an M.B.A. from Columbia University in New York. Lenore has lived in New York City for over 32 years, building a career in the financial sector which included most recently the position of Joint Staff Pension Funds Senior Investment Officer at the United Nations, and was preceded by the positions Portfolio Manager and Director of Research at Prudential Management International, Supervisory Portfolio Administrator at Reich and Tang, and Performance Analyst at Sanford Berstein and Company. Her career not only fulfilled her professionally, but dovetailed with her love of travel and the arts, since it was centered in New York City and it involved international investment efforts. Funeral services will be held Friday, June 6, 2008 at 1:30pm at the Sacred Heart Church in Gardner. Burial will follow in St. John's Cemetery. Calling hours will be held Friday, June 6, 2008 from 12:30pm at the John H. Mack Funeral Home, 91 Vernon St., Gardner. Donations may be made in her memory to either Operation Smile, 6435 Tidewater Dr., Norfolk, VA 23509, www.operation smile.org, or Sacred Heart School, 53 Lynn St., Gardner, MA 01440, www.sacredheart gardner.org. For more information or to sign our online guest book please visit: www.mackfuneralhome.com John H. Mack Funeral Home, 91 Vernon St., Gardner, is directing services.

AUGUST--Stanley, M.D., died peacefully on June 2, 2008 at the age of 90. Dr. August practiced internal medicine and cardiology in Brooklyn for 40 years. He graduated from the Harvard Medical School in 1942, where he studied with the renowned cardiologist Dr. Paul Dudley White. Following medical school, he served as a Captain in the US Army during World War II and participated in the liberation of the Dachau concentration camp. He returned to Brooklyn and married his beloved Renee Levine. Working at Downstate Medical Center, he published the first report of methotrexate use in severe psoriasis. He was also an NYPD captain and surgeon. He was known for his kindness, wit and erudition. He leaves his children, Ellen, Phyllis, Bill and David, their spouses, M. Suthanthiran, Barbara August and Amy Wilson, his sister Selma Rubenstein and his grandchildren, Benjamin, Nathaniel, Aaron, Seth and Harry. Services will be at the Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Thursday, June 5 at 11:15am. Donations can be sent to The Wright Center on Aging, NY Presbyterian Hospital, 1484 1st Avenue, NY, NY 10075.

BRADSHAW--Ronald Francis. Ronald Francis Bradshaw, 49, died peacefully at home in Houston on June 2, 2008 from pancreatic cancer. A leading interior designer, his work was praised for combining the best of historic European style with American practicality, and was widely published. His notable projects include the public spaces of the Pierre Hotel, New York; the Palm Court Hotel, Palm Beach; and a residence designed by noted architect I.M. Pei. His most recent design commissions were residences in New York, Stockbridge, Boston, Miami, Fort Worth, Houston, Indian Wells, Greenwich, and Santa Fe. He graduated in 1982 from the Fashion Institute of Technology of the State University of New York, which awarded him its prestigious New York City Decorator's Club Award given annually to the most promising graduating student. While a student he was employed by R. Michael Brown Design Associates, New York, rising to Director of Design. After graduation, he joined the internationally recognized firm, Melanie Kahane & Associates, New York. Following Ms. Kahane's death in 1989, Ron formed his own design firm, Ronald F Bradshaw & Company, New York. He relocated his design offices to Houston in 1997. He is survived by his life partner, Michael ''Tripp'' Carter, his father Raymond Napoleon Bradshaw, his brother Raymond J. Bradshaw, all of Houston; his brother Robert J. Bradshaw of Pawtucket, Rhode Island; and his beloved pets, Henry, Mikey and Edna. Visitation, 57pm June 4, 2008 at the Bradshaw-Carter Funeral Home, 1734 West Alabama Street, Houston, Texas. A mass of Christian burial, June 5, 2008 at St. Anne Catholic Church, 2140 Westheimer Road, Houston. Private interment, June 5, 2008 at Glenwood Cemetery, Houston. Online tributes may be posted at: bradshawcarter.com.

PERLS--Klaus. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of distinguished honorary trustee, donor, and friend Klaus Perls, who with his late wife Dolly was an important collector and gallery owner for more than 60 years. Through their generosity, a magnificent collection of 153 African royal objects from the Kingdom of Benin joined the collection of the Metropolitan Museum in 1991. This gift was heralded by a major exhibition that then toured the United States. In 1996, they donated 13 exceptional works by School of Paris artists, including Picasso, Braque, Modigliani, and Soutine, as well as significant gifts to the Greek and Roman Department. Klaus was a connoisseur and scholar, with a love of fine objects. Because of his fine eye and acumen, so distinctive and personal, combined with his publicspiritedness, these two magnificent gifts will forever enrich the collections of the Metropolitan. We extend condolences to his daughter Katherine and to the entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Philippe de Montebello, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

The most entertaining moment in today's practice sessions was when Felipe Massa 15 minutes before the end of the second session became involved in teaching the track marshals how to drive his Ferrari. In case you missed the show, Massa had to pull out of the session with a likely engine problem and park at the edge of the track. The car was parked in such a way that the yellow flags came out. It was soon clear that the car was in a slightly dangerous position, so a group of marshals gathered round to pull the car through an opening in the guardrails to make sure it was on the other side of barrier and out of the way of the other drivers.

I saw my first Belmont in 1986. It was run over a sloppy track on which Danzig Connection became the trainer Woody Stephens's fifth consecutive Belmont Stakes winner. I knew it was a big deal for a trainer to win a Triple Crown race even once, but I was new to the sport, and even when the crowds began chanting "Wood-y! Wood-y!" I didn't fully appreciate how extraordinary this record was.

The French stuntman Alain Robert, the first of two men who climbed the New York Times building, said in an interview on Friday that he chose the 52-story tower because it was so simple to scale and because it was known as a "green" building.A few nights before his climb of the 52-story building on Thursday, he said, he tested the sturdiness of the rods at 2 a.m. by climbing up on the overhang and tugging on the rods. He said he climbed several feet and discovered that scaling the whole building would not be hard. (The company said Friday it was undertaking new security measures.)

The debut of CBS's "Swingtown" attracted moderate interest on Thursday, delivering an audience of 8.6 million viewers at 10 p.m.,according to Nielsen's estimates. The provocative new series set in the 1970s has drawn scrutiny for its relatively explicit depictions of sex and drugs. Among adults 18 to 49, it was far from the night's highest rated show, but "Swingtown" did improve on CBS's performance in that demographic earlier in the night.

Today's employment report wasn't as bad as the markets seem to have thought: the big jump in the unemployment rate was due to a jump in labor force participation -- maybe by teens looking for gas money? -- rather than a large drop in employment. The economy still seems to be in a sort of slow-mo slump: employment gradually falling, labor markets gradually worsening, GDP positive but barely.

RZA, one of the founders of the Wu-Tang Clan, the rap super group, is a huge chess fan, and a pretty good player. On Monday, in conjunction with Chesspark, he launched a Web site called Wuchess.com, where fans of the group (and even those who are not) can play chess and socialize online. The site also has news and information about Wu-Tang and its members. RZA has said the site may have monthly tournaments with the winner playing a game against him online. GARRISON, N.Y. -- Life's not always fair, and every story doesn't have the right ending. Four months after saying goodbye to the rickety refuge on the Hudson that he helped to define, they'll say goodbye to John Guinan today and Saturday, and in the process say goodbye to a bit of the river's soul as well. From 1959 to the beginning of this year, Guinan's -- between the Garrison railroad station and the east bank of the Hudson -- was a combination deli, general store and pub with a tiny barroom with green walls and an alarmingly sloping floor that had Irish Music Nights the first Thursday after each full moon. Run first by his father, Jim, it evolved over time into one of those rare places that transcends its own myth -- a time capsule, a home away from home, a place to hide out, and in the richest way a community.

Watching the Red Wings drive through the playoffs drove home a point for me. They are the perfect example of a franchise that is built on a philosophy. They decided years ago how they want to play and hired people skilled at finding players who fit an archetype. They are dedicated to being a puck possession team, one that plays a solid and cohesive brand of defense and for the most part ignores the hue and cry for thuggery.

From the first day of spring training until the final out of the season, baseball players spend at least seven months together. They eat together, play together, travel together and critique each other. Players are around each other more than most families. And not every family holds hands all the time.

Blessed are the list makers, with their sharp pencils, their certainties, their mix of words and numbers. Walt Whitman made lists. Nabokov made lists. Last year, while declaring in Time magazine that "literary lists are basically an obscenity," Tom Wolfe admitted to having made many in his life, and then introduced a new one, ranking the best novels in the world.

A small woman holds the lead at the U.S. gymnastics championships, as Juliet Macur reports from Boston, which for casual followers of the sport seems true to form -- aren't all top female gymnasts small? Those who follow women's gymnastics more closely understand that there is a wider range of body types among elite performers, but still, you have to be getting up there in years to remember a time when female Olympians were generally bigger than the athletes who started to dominate the discipline in the 1970s.

[UPDATED 6/9, 11:30 p.m.: John Tierney, hardly a Jim Hansen cheerleader, has strongly endorsed "tax and dividend." UPDATED 12:10 p.m. with slide show.] Even as Senate Republicans blocked Democrats' attempt to move forward with global warming legislation today, other approaches to federal climate action have already begun to percolate. James E. Hansen, the NASA climate expert who has long been a bellwether for global warming campaigners, has strongly endorsed one of the less-popular options -- a variant on the "cap and dividend" system for cutting greenhouse-gas emissions. (This is very different from the "cap and trade" mechanism in the blocked Lieberman-Warner-Boxer bill, which would invest revenue in a host of ways, with little money returning directly to taxpayers.)
